## 12302           as well as not knowing how to get to Plymouth; for Lucy it seems
## 12303    borrowed all her money before she went off to be married, on purpose we
## 12304     suppose to make a show with, and poor Nancy had not seven shillings in
## 12305        the world;--so I was very glad to give her five guineas to take her
## 12306       down to Exeter, where she thinks of staying three or four weeks with
## 12307          Mrs. Burgess, in hopes, as I tell her, to fall in with the Doctor
## 12308        again.  And I must say that Lucy's crossness not to take them along
## 12309      with them in the chaise is worse than all.  Poor Mr. Edward! I cannot
## 12310      get him out of my head, but you must send for him to Barton, and Miss
## 12311                                         Marianne must try to comfort him."
## 12312                                                                           
## 12313        Mr. Dashwood's strains were more solemn.  Mrs. Ferrars was the most
## 12314                   unfortunate of women--poor Fanny had suffered agonies of
## 12315         sensibility--and he considered the existence of each, under such a
## 12316        blow, with grateful wonder.  Robert's offence was unpardonable, but
## 12317        Lucy's was infinitely worse.  Neither of them were ever again to be
## 12318     mentioned to Mrs. Ferrars; and even, if she might hereafter be induced
## 12319           to forgive her son, his wife should never be acknowledged as her
## 12320    daughter, nor be permitted to appear in her presence.  The secrecy with
## 12321          which everything had been carried on between them, was rationally
## 12322    treated as enormously heightening the crime, because, had any suspicion
## 12323     of it occurred to the others, proper measures would have been taken to
## 12324          prevent the marriage; and he called on Elinor to join with him in
## 12325          regretting that Lucy's engagement with Edward had not rather been
## 12326      fulfilled, than that she should thus be the means of spreading misery
## 12327                                farther in the family.-- He thus continued:
## 12328                                                                           
## 12329        "Mrs. Ferrars has never yet mentioned Edward's name, which does not
## 12330           surprise us; but, to our great astonishment, not a line has been
## 12331    received from him on the occasion.  Perhaps, however, he is kept silent
## 12332    by his fear of offending, and I shall, therefore, give him a hint, by a
## 12333        line to Oxford, that his sister and I both think a letter of proper
## 12334       submission from him, addressed perhaps to Fanny, and by her shewn to
## 12335    her mother, might not be taken amiss; for we all know the tenderness of
## 12336     Mrs. Ferrars's heart, and that she wishes for nothing so much as to be
## 12337                                          on good terms with her children."
## 12338                                                                           
## 12339      This paragraph was of some importance to the prospects and conduct of
## 12340         Edward.  It determined him to attempt a reconciliation, though not
## 12341             exactly in the manner pointed out by their brother and sister.
## 12342                                                                           
## 12343      "A letter of proper submission!" repeated he; "would they have me beg
## 12344          my mother's pardon for Robert's ingratitude to HER, and breach of
## 12345     honour to ME?--I can make no submission--I am grown neither humble nor
## 12346    penitent by what has passed.--I am grown very happy; but that would not
## 12347         interest.--I know of no submission that IS proper for me to make."
## 12348                                                                           
## 12349     "You may certainly ask to be forgiven," said Elinor, "because you have
## 12350           offended;--and I should think you might NOW venture so far as to
## 12351      profess some concern for having ever formed the engagement which drew
## 12352                                               on you your mother's anger."
## 12353                                                                           
## 12354                                                   He agreed that he might.
## 12355                                                                           
## 12356           "And when she has forgiven you, perhaps a little humility may be
## 12357    convenient while acknowledging a second engagement, almost as imprudent
## 12358                                                 in HER eyes as the first."
## 12359                                                                           
## 12360        He had nothing to urge against it, but still resisted the idea of a
## 12361      letter of proper submission; and therefore, to make it easier to him,
## 12362      as he declared a much greater willingness to make mean concessions by
## 12363      word of mouth than on paper, it was resolved that, instead of writing
## 12364          to Fanny, he should go to London, and personally intreat her good
## 12365      offices in his favour.-- "And if they really DO interest themselves,"
## 12366       said Marianne, in her new character of candour, "in bringing about a
## 12367    reconciliation, I shall think that even John and Fanny are not entirely
## 12368                                                            without merit."
## 12369                                                                           
## 12370    After a visit on Colonel Brandon's side of only three or four days, the
## 12371    two gentlemen quitted Barton together.-- They were to go immediately to
## 12372     Delaford, that Edward might have some personal knowledge of his future
## 12373    home, and assist his patron and friend in deciding on what improvements
## 12374        were needed to it; and from thence, after staying there a couple of
## 12375                          nights, he was to proceed on his journey to town.
## 12376                                                                           
## 12377                                                                           
## 12378                                                                           
## 12379                                                                 CHAPTER 50
## 12380                                                                           
## 12381                                                                           
## 12382     After a proper resistance on the part of Mrs. Ferrars, just so violent
## 12383       and so steady as to preserve her from that reproach which she always
## 12384     seemed fearful of incurring, the reproach of being too amiable, Edward
## 12385          was admitted to her presence, and pronounced to be again her son.
## 12386                                                                           
## 12387    Her family had of late been exceedingly fluctuating.  For many years of
## 12388    her life she had had two sons; but the crime and annihilation of Edward
## 12389        a few weeks ago, had robbed her of one; the similar annihilation of
## 12390           Robert had left her for a fortnight without any; and now, by the
## 12391                                resuscitation of Edward, she had one again.
## 12392                                                                           
## 12393       In spite of his being allowed once more to live, however, he did not
## 12394     feel the continuance of his existence secure, till he had revealed his
## 12395           present engagement; for the publication of that circumstance, he
## 12396    feared, might give a sudden turn to his constitution, and carry him off
## 12397          as rapidly as before.  With apprehensive caution therefore it was
## 12398           revealed, and he was listened to with unexpected calmness.  Mrs.
## 12399      Ferrars at first reasonably endeavoured to dissuade him from marrying
## 12400     Miss Dashwood, by every argument in her power;--told him, that in Miss
## 12401       Morton he would have a woman of higher rank and larger fortune;--and
## 12402     enforced the assertion, by observing that Miss Morton was the daughter
## 12403    of a nobleman with thirty thousand pounds, while Miss Dashwood was only
## 12404      the daughter of a private gentleman with no more than THREE; but when
## 12405                she found that, though perfectly admitting the truth of her
## 12406        representation, he was by no means inclined to be guided by it, she
## 12407          judged it wisest, from the experience of the past, to submit--and
## 12408           therefore, after such an ungracious delay as she owed to her own
## 12409        dignity, and as served to prevent every suspicion of good-will, she
## 12410         issued her decree of consent to the marriage of Edward and Elinor.
## 12411                                                                           
## 12412    What she would engage to do towards augmenting their income was next to
## 12413    be considered; and here it plainly appeared, that though Edward was now
## 12414          her only son, he was by no means her eldest; for while Robert was
## 12415         inevitably endowed with a thousand pounds a-year, not the smallest
## 12416      objection was made against Edward's taking orders for the sake of two
## 12417      hundred and fifty at the utmost; nor was anything promised either for
## 12418        the present or in future, beyond the ten thousand pounds, which had
## 12419                                                     been given with Fanny.
## 12420                                                                           
## 12421    It was as much, however, as was desired, and more than was expected, by
## 12422     Edward and Elinor; and Mrs. Ferrars herself, by her shuffling excuses,
## 12423                   seemed the only person surprised at her not giving more.
## 12424                                                                           
## 12425       With an income quite sufficient to their wants thus secured to them,
## 12426         they had nothing to wait for after Edward was in possession of the
## 12427     living, but the readiness of the house, to which Colonel Brandon, with
## 12428                an eager desire for the accommodation of Elinor, was making
## 12429           considerable improvements; and after waiting some time for their
## 12430       completion, after experiencing, as usual, a thousand disappointments
## 12431     and delays from the unaccountable dilatoriness of the workmen, Elinor,
## 12432      as usual, broke through the first positive resolution of not marrying
## 12433          till every thing was ready, and the ceremony took place in Barton
## 12434                                                church early in the autumn.
## 12435                                                                           
## 12436    The first month after their marriage was spent with their friend at the
## 12437      Mansion-house; from whence they could superintend the progress of the
## 12438        Parsonage, and direct every thing as they liked on the spot;--could
## 12439    chuse papers, project shrubberies, and invent a sweep.  Mrs. Jennings's
## 12440    prophecies, though rather jumbled together, were chiefly fulfilled; for
## 12441            she was able to visit Edward and his wife in their Parsonage by
## 12442         Michaelmas, and she found in Elinor and her husband, as she really
## 12443      believed, one of the happiest couples in the world.  They had in fact
## 12444     nothing to wish for, but the marriage of Colonel Brandon and Marianne,
## 12445                                and rather better pasturage for their cows.
## 12446                                                                           
## 12447    They were visited on their first settling by almost all their relations
## 12448     and friends.  Mrs. Ferrars came to inspect the happiness which she was
## 12449    almost ashamed of having authorised; and even the Dashwoods were at the
## 12450                        expense of a journey from Sussex to do them honour.
## 12451                                                                           
## 12452     "I will not say that I am disappointed, my dear sister," said John, as
## 12453        they were walking together one morning before the gates of Delaford
## 12454     House, "THAT would be saying too much, for certainly you have been one
## 12455          of the most fortunate young women in the world, as it is.  But, I
## 12456           confess, it would give me great pleasure to call Colonel Brandon
## 12457       brother.  His property here, his place, his house, every thing is in
## 12458      such respectable and excellent condition!--and his woods!--I have not
## 12459     seen such timber any where in Dorsetshire, as there is now standing in
## 12460       Delaford Hanger!--And though, perhaps, Marianne may not seem exactly
## 12461    the person to attract him--yet I think it would altogether be advisable
## 12462       for you to have them now frequently staying with you, for as Colonel
## 12463               Brandon seems a great deal at home, nobody can tell what may
## 12464       happen--for, when people are much thrown together, and see little of
## 12465        anybody else--and it will always be in your power to set her off to
## 12466             advantage, and so forth;--in short, you may as well give her a
## 12467                                              chance--You understand me."--
## 12468                                                                           
## 12469      But though Mrs. Ferrars DID come to see them, and always treated them
## 12470     with the make-believe of decent affection, they were never insulted by
## 12471      her real favour and preference.  THAT was due to the folly of Robert,
## 12472         and the cunning of his wife; and it was earned by them before many
## 12473     months had passed away.  The selfish sagacity of the latter, which had
## 12474     at first drawn Robert into the scrape, was the principal instrument of
## 12475            his deliverance from it; for her respectful humility, assiduous
## 12476    attentions, and endless flatteries, as soon as the smallest opening was
## 12477       given for their exercise, reconciled Mrs. Ferrars to his choice, and
## 12478                               re-established him completely in her favour.
## 12479                                                                           
## 12480      The whole of Lucy's behaviour in the affair, and the prosperity which
## 12481    crowned it, therefore, may be held forth as a most encouraging instance
## 12482       of what an earnest, an unceasing attention to self-interest, however
## 12483       its progress may be apparently obstructed, will do in securing every
## 12484        advantage of fortune, with no other sacrifice than that of time and
## 12485      conscience.  When Robert first sought her acquaintance, and privately
## 12486     visited her in Bartlett's Buildings, it was only with the view imputed
## 12487     to him by his brother.  He merely meant to persuade her to give up the
## 12488    engagement; and as there could be nothing to overcome but the affection
## 12489     of both, he naturally expected that one or two interviews would settle
## 12490         the matter.  In that point, however, and that only, he erred;--for
## 12491      though Lucy soon gave him hopes that his eloquence would convince her
## 12492         in TIME, another visit, another conversation, was always wanted to
## 12493     produce this conviction.  Some doubts always lingered in her mind when
## 12494            they parted, which could only be removed by another half hour's
## 12495     discourse with himself.  His attendance was by this means secured, and
## 12496      the rest followed in course.  Instead of talking of Edward, they came
## 12497        gradually to talk only of Robert,--a subject on which he had always
## 12498           more to say than on any other, and in which she soon betrayed an
## 12499           interest even equal to his own; and in short, it became speedily
## 12500      evident to both, that he had entirely supplanted his brother.  He was
## 12501         proud of his conquest, proud of tricking Edward, and very proud of
## 12502         marrying privately without his mother's consent.  What immediately
## 12503          followed is known.  They passed some months in great happiness at
## 12504      Dawlish; for she had many relations and old acquaintances to cut--and
## 12505           he drew several plans for magnificent cottages;--and from thence
## 12506        returning to town, procured the forgiveness of Mrs. Ferrars, by the
## 12507           simple expedient of asking it, which, at Lucy's instigation, was
## 12508            adopted.  The forgiveness, at first, indeed, as was reasonable,
## 12509    comprehended only Robert; and Lucy, who had owed his mother no duty and
## 12510          therefore could have transgressed none, still remained some weeks
## 12511            longer unpardoned.  But perseverance in humility of conduct and
## 12512     messages, in self-condemnation for Robert's offence, and gratitude for
## 12513      the unkindness she was treated with, procured her in time the haughty
## 12514    notice which overcame her by its graciousness, and led soon afterwards,
## 12515         by rapid degrees, to the highest state of affection and influence.
## 12516       Lucy became as necessary to Mrs. Ferrars, as either Robert or Fanny;
## 12517     and while Edward was never cordially forgiven for having once intended
## 12518     to marry her, and Elinor, though superior to her in fortune and birth,
## 12519       was spoken of as an intruder, SHE was in every thing considered, and
## 12520      always openly acknowledged, to be a favourite child.  They settled in
## 12521      town, received very liberal assistance from Mrs. Ferrars, were on the
## 12522            best terms imaginable with the Dashwoods; and setting aside the
## 12523     jealousies and ill-will continually subsisting between Fanny and Lucy,
## 12524     in which their husbands of course took a part, as well as the frequent
## 12525         domestic disagreements between Robert and Lucy themselves, nothing
## 12526                 could exceed the harmony in which they all lived together.
## 12527                                                                           
## 12528        What Edward had done to forfeit the right of eldest son, might have
## 12529    puzzled many people to find out; and what Robert had done to succeed to
## 12530            it, might have puzzled them still more.  It was an arrangement,
## 12531        however, justified in its effects, if not in its cause; for nothing
## 12532          ever appeared in Robert's style of living or of talking to give a
## 12533    suspicion of his regretting the extent of his income, as either leaving
## 12534       his brother too little, or bringing himself too much;--and if Edward
## 12535            might be judged from the ready discharge of his duties in every
## 12536    particular, from an increasing attachment to his wife and his home, and
## 12537      from the regular cheerfulness of his spirits, he might be supposed no
## 12538            less contented with his lot, no less free from every wish of an
## 12539                                                                  exchange.
## 12540                                                                           
## 12541      Elinor's marriage divided her as little from her family as could well
## 12542    be contrived, without rendering the cottage at Barton entirely useless,
## 12543       for her mother and sisters spent much more than half their time with
## 12544    her.  Mrs. Dashwood was acting on motives of policy as well as pleasure
## 12545       in the frequency of her visits at Delaford; for her wish of bringing
## 12546      Marianne and Colonel Brandon together was hardly less earnest, though
## 12547          rather more liberal than what John had expressed.  It was now her
## 12548       darling object.  Precious as was the company of her daughter to her,
## 12549    she desired nothing so much as to give up its constant enjoyment to her
## 12550        valued friend; and to see Marianne settled at the mansion-house was
## 12551    equally the wish of Edward and Elinor.  They each felt his sorrows, and
## 12552     their own obligations, and Marianne, by general consent, was to be the
## 12553                                                             reward of all.
## 12554                                                                           
## 12555       With such a confederacy against her--with a knowledge so intimate of
## 12556         his goodness--with a conviction of his fond attachment to herself,
## 12557            which at last, though long after it was observable to everybody
## 12558                                     else--burst on her--what could she do?
## 12559                                                                           
## 12560      Marianne Dashwood was born to an extraordinary fate.  She was born to
## 12561      discover the falsehood of her own opinions, and to counteract, by her
## 12562           conduct, her most favourite maxims.  She was born to overcome an
## 12563    affection formed so late in life as at seventeen, and with no sentiment
## 12564       superior to strong esteem and lively friendship, voluntarily to give
## 12565       her hand to another!--and THAT other, a man who had suffered no less
## 12566       than herself under the event of a former attachment, whom, two years
## 12567    before, she had considered too old to be married,--and who still sought
## 12568                       the constitutional safeguard of a flannel waistcoat!
## 12569                                                                           
## 12570          But so it was.  Instead of falling a sacrifice to an irresistible
## 12571 passion, as once she had fondly flattered herself with expecting,--instead
## 12572           of remaining even for ever with her mother, and finding her only
## 12573      pleasures in retirement and study, as afterwards in her more calm and
## 12574      sober judgment she had determined on,--she found herself at nineteen,
## 12575     submitting to new attachments, entering on new duties, placed in a new
## 12576    home, a wife, the mistress of a family, and the patroness of a village.
## 12577                                                                           
## 12578         Colonel Brandon was now as happy, as all those who best loved him,
## 12579    believed he deserved to be;--in Marianne he was consoled for every past
## 12580    affliction;--her regard and her society restored his mind to animation,
## 12581           and his spirits to cheerfulness; and that Marianne found her own
## 12582        happiness in forming his, was equally the persuasion and delight of
## 12583       each observing friend.  Marianne could never love by halves; and her
## 12584     whole heart became, in time, as much devoted to her husband, as it had
## 12585                                                   once been to Willoughby.
## 12586                                                                           
## 12587          Willoughby could not hear of her marriage without a pang; and his
## 12588    punishment was soon afterwards complete in the voluntary forgiveness of
## 12589     Mrs. Smith, who, by stating his marriage with a woman of character, as
## 12590      the source of her clemency, gave him reason for believing that had he
## 12591     behaved with honour towards Marianne, he might at once have been happy
## 12592       and rich.  That his repentance of misconduct, which thus brought its
## 12593        own punishment, was sincere, need not be doubted;--nor that he long
## 12594    thought of Colonel Brandon with envy, and of Marianne with regret.  But
## 12595           that he was for ever inconsolable, that he fled from society, or
## 12596    contracted an habitual gloom of temper, or died of a broken heart, must
## 12597            not be depended on--for he did neither.  He lived to exert, and
## 12598       frequently to enjoy himself.  His wife was not always out of humour,
## 12599    nor his home always uncomfortable; and in his breed of horses and dogs,
## 12600        and in sporting of every kind, he found no inconsiderable degree of
## 12601                                                         domestic felicity.
## 12602                                                                           
## 12603         For Marianne, however--in spite of his incivility in surviving her
## 12604       loss--he always retained that decided regard which interested him in
## 12605           every thing that befell her, and made her his secret standard of
## 12606    perfection in woman;--and many a rising beauty would be slighted by him
## 12607                  in after-days as bearing no comparison with Mrs. Brandon.
## 12608                                                                           
## 12609         Mrs. Dashwood was prudent enough to remain at the cottage, without
## 12610    attempting a removal to Delaford; and fortunately for Sir John and Mrs.
## 12611       Jennings, when Marianne was taken from them, Margaret had reached an
## 12612         age highly suitable for dancing, and not very ineligible for being
## 12613                                                  supposed to have a lover.
## 12614                                                                           
## 12615         Between Barton and Delaford, there was that constant communication
## 12616      which strong family affection would naturally dictate;--and among the
## 12617      merits and the happiness of Elinor and Marianne, let it not be ranked
## 12618          as the least considerable, that though sisters, and living almost
## 12619           within sight of each other, they could live without disagreement
## 12620          between themselves, or producing coolness between their husbands.
## 12621                                                                           
## 12622                                                                           
## 12623                                                                           
## 12624                                                                    THE END
sensesensibility_DF <- sensesensibility_DF[-c(1:12),]
sensesensibility_DF
##     [1] "The family of Dashwood had long been settled in Sussex.  Their estate"       
##     [2] "was large, and their residence was at Norland Park, in the centre of"        
##     [3] "their property, where, for many generations, they had lived in so"           
##     [4] "respectable a manner as to engage the general good opinion of their"         
##     [5] "surrounding acquaintance.  The late owner of this estate was a single"       
##     [6] "man, who lived to a very advanced age, and who for many years of his"        
##     [7] "life, had a constant companion and housekeeper in his sister.  But her"      
##     [8] "death, which happened ten years before his own, produced a great"            
##     [9] "alteration in his home; for to supply her loss, he invited and received"     
##    [10] "into his house the family of his nephew Mr. Henry Dashwood, the legal"       
##    [11] "inheritor of the Norland estate, and the person to whom he intended to"      
##    [12] "bequeath it.  In the society of his nephew and niece, and their"             
##    [13] "children, the old Gentleman's days were comfortably spent.  His"             
##    [14] "attachment to them all increased.  The constant attention of Mr. and"        
##    [15] "Mrs. Henry Dashwood to his wishes, which proceeded not merely from"          
##    [16] "interest, but from goodness of heart, gave him every degree of solid"        
##    [17] "comfort which his age could receive; and the cheerfulness of the"            
##    [18] "children added a relish to his existence."                                   
##    [19] ""                                                                            
##    [20] "By a former marriage, Mr. Henry Dashwood had one son: by his present"        
##    [21] "lady, three daughters.  The son, a steady respectable young man, was"        
##    [22] "amply provided for by the fortune of his mother, which had been large,"      
##    [23] "and half of which devolved on him on his coming of age.  By his own"         
##    [24] "marriage, likewise, which happened soon afterwards, he added to his"         
##    [25] "wealth.  To him therefore the succession to the Norland estate was not"      
##    [26] "so really important as to his sisters; for their fortune, independent"       
##    [27] "of what might arise to them from their father's inheriting that"             
##    [28] "property, could be but small.  Their mother had nothing, and their"          
##    [29] "father only seven thousand pounds in his own disposal; for the"              
##    [30] "remaining moiety of his first wife's fortune was also secured to her"        
##    [31] "child, and he had only a life-interest in it."                               
##    [32] ""                                                                            
##    [33] "The old gentleman died: his will was read, and like almost every other"      
##    [34] "will, gave as much disappointment as pleasure.  He was neither so"           
##    [35] "unjust, nor so ungrateful, as to leave his estate from his nephew;--but"     
##    [36] "he left it to him on such terms as destroyed half the value of the"          
##    [37] "bequest.  Mr. Dashwood had wished for it more for the sake of his wife"      
##    [38] "and daughters than for himself or his son;--but to his son, and his"         
##    [39] "son's son, a child of four years old, it was secured, in such a way, as"     
##    [40] "to leave to himself no power of providing for those who were most dear"      
##    [41] "to him, and who most needed a provision by any charge on the estate, or"     
##    [42] "by any sale of its valuable woods.  The whole was tied up for the"           
##    [43] "benefit of this child, who, in occasional visits with his father and"        
##    [44] "mother at Norland, had so far gained on the affections of his uncle, by"     
##    [45] "such attractions as are by no means unusual in children of two or three"     
##    [46] "years old; an imperfect articulation, an earnest desire of having his"       
##    [47] "own way, many cunning tricks, and a great deal of noise, as to outweigh"     
##    [48] "all the value of all the attention which, for years, he had received"        
##    [49] "from his niece and her daughters.  He meant not to be unkind, however,"      
##    [50] "and, as a mark of his affection for the three girls, he left them a"         
##    [51] "thousand pounds a-piece."                                                    
##    [52] ""                                                                            
##    [53] "Mr. Dashwood's disappointment was, at first, severe; but his temper was"     
##    [54] "cheerful and sanguine; and he might reasonably hope to live many years,"     
##    [55] "and by living economically, lay by a considerable sum from the produce"      
##    [56] "of an estate already large, and capable of almost immediate"                 
##    [57] "improvement.  But the fortune, which had been so tardy in coming, was"       
##    [58] "his only one twelvemonth.  He survived his uncle no longer; and ten"         
##    [59] "thousand pounds, including the late legacies, was all that remained for"     
##    [60] "his widow and daughters."                                                    
##    [61] ""                                                                            
##    [62] "His son was sent for as soon as his danger was known, and to him Mr."        
##    [63] "Dashwood recommended, with all the strength and urgency which illness"       
##    [64] "could command, the interest of his mother-in-law and sisters."               
##    [65] ""                                                                            
##    [66] "Mr. John Dashwood had not the strong feelings of the rest of the"            
##    [67] "family; but he was affected by a recommendation of such a nature at"         
##    [68] "such a time, and he promised to do every thing in his power to make"         
##    [69] "them comfortable.  His father was rendered easy by such an assurance,"       
##    [70] "and Mr. John Dashwood had then leisure to consider how much there might"     
##    [71] "prudently be in his power to do for them."                                   
##    [72] ""                                                                            
##    [73] "He was not an ill-disposed young man, unless to be rather cold hearted"      
##    [74] "and rather selfish is to be ill-disposed: but he was, in general, well"      
##    [75] "respected; for he conducted himself with propriety in the discharge of"      
##    [76] "his ordinary duties.  Had he married a more amiable woman, he might"         
##    [77] "have been made still more respectable than he was:--he might even have"      
##    [78] "been made amiable himself; for he was very young when he married, and"       
##    [79] "very fond of his wife.  But Mrs. John Dashwood was a strong caricature"      
##    [80] "of himself;--more narrow-minded and selfish."                                
##    [81] ""                                                                            
##    [82] "When he gave his promise to his father, he meditated within himself to"      
##    [83] "increase the fortunes of his sisters by the present of a thousand"           
##    [84] "pounds a-piece.  He then really thought himself equal to it.  The"           
##    [85] "prospect of four thousand a-year, in addition to his present income,"        
##    [86] "besides the remaining half of his own mother's fortune, warmed his"          
##    [87] "heart, and made him feel capable of generosity.-- \"Yes, he would give"      
##    [88] "them three thousand pounds: it would be liberal and handsome! It would"      
##    [89] "be enough to make them completely easy.  Three thousand pounds! he"          
##    [90] "could spare so considerable a sum with little inconvenience.\"-- He"         
##    [91] "thought of it all day long, and for many days successively, and he did"      
##    [92] "not repent."                                                                 
##    [93] ""                                                                            
##    [94] "No sooner was his father's funeral over, than Mrs. John Dashwood,"           
##    [95] "without sending any notice of her intention to her mother-in-law,"           
##    [96] "arrived with her child and their attendants.  No one could dispute her"      
##    [97] "right to come; the house was her husband's from the moment of his"           
##    [98] "father's decease; but the indelicacy of her conduct was so much the"         
##    [99] "greater, and to a woman in Mrs. Dashwood's situation, with only common"      
##   [100] "feelings, must have been highly unpleasing;--but in HER mind there was"      
##   [101] "a sense of honor so keen, a generosity so romantic, that any offence of"     
##   [102] "the kind, by whomsoever given or received, was to her a source of"           
##   [103] "immovable disgust.  Mrs. John Dashwood had never been a favourite with"      
##   [104] "any of her husband's family; but she had had no opportunity, till the"       
##   [105] "present, of shewing them with how little attention to the comfort of"        
##   [106] "other people she could act when occasion required it."                       
##   [107] ""                                                                            
##   [108] "So acutely did Mrs. Dashwood feel this ungracious behaviour, and so"         
##   [109] "earnestly did she despise her daughter-in-law for it, that, on the"          
##   [110] "arrival of the latter, she would have quitted the house for ever, had"       
##   [111] "not the entreaty of her eldest girl induced her first to reflect on the"     
##   [112] "propriety of going, and her own tender love for all her three children"      
##   [113] "determined her afterwards to stay, and for their sakes avoid a breach"       
##   [114] "with their brother."                                                         
##   [115] ""                                                                            
##   [116] "Elinor, this eldest daughter, whose advice was so effectual, possessed"      
##   [117] "a strength of understanding, and coolness of judgment, which qualified"      
##   [118] "her, though only nineteen, to be the counsellor of her mother, and"          
##   [119] "enabled her frequently to counteract, to the advantage of them all,"         
##   [120] "that eagerness of mind in Mrs. Dashwood which must generally have led"       
##   [121] "to imprudence.  She had an excellent heart;--her disposition was"            
##   [122] "affectionate, and her feelings were strong; but she knew how to govern"      
##   [123] "them: it was a knowledge which her mother had yet to learn; and which"       
##   [124] "one of her sisters had resolved never to be taught."                         
##   [125] ""                                                                            
##   [126] "Marianne's abilities were, in many respects, quite equal to Elinor's."       
##   [127] "She was sensible and clever; but eager in everything: her sorrows, her"      
##   [128] "joys, could have no moderation.  She was generous, amiable,"                 
##   [129] "interesting: she was everything but prudent.  The resemblance between"       
##   [130] "her and her mother was strikingly great."                                    
##   [131] ""                                                                            
##   [132] "Elinor saw, with concern, the excess of her sister's sensibility; but"       
##   [133] "by Mrs. Dashwood it was valued and cherished.  They encouraged each"         
##   [134] "other now in the violence of their affliction.  The agony of grief"          
##   [135] "which overpowered them at first, was voluntarily renewed, was sought"        
##   [136] "for, was created again and again.  They gave themselves up wholly to"        
##   [137] "their sorrow, seeking increase of wretchedness in every reflection that"     
##   [138] "could afford it, and resolved against ever admitting consolation in"         
##   [139] "future.  Elinor, too, was deeply afflicted; but still she could"             
##   [140] "struggle, she could exert herself.  She could consult with her brother,"     
##   [141] "could receive her sister-in-law on her arrival, and treat her with"          
##   [142] "proper attention; and could strive to rouse her mother to similar"           
##   [143] "exertion, and encourage her to similar forbearance."                         
##   [144] ""                                                                            
##   [145] "Margaret, the other sister, was a good-humored, well-disposed girl; but"     
##   [146] "as she had already imbibed a good deal of Marianne's romance, without"       
##   [147] "having much of her sense, she did not, at thirteen, bid fair to equal"       
##   [148] "her sisters at a more advanced period of life."                              
##   [149] ""                                                                            
##   [150] ""                                                                            
##   [151] ""                                                                            
##   [152] "CHAPTER 2"                                                                   
##   [153] ""                                                                            
##   [154] ""                                                                            
##   [155] "Mrs. John Dashwood now installed herself mistress of Norland; and her"       
##   [156] "mother and sisters-in-law were degraded to the condition of visitors."       
##   [157] "As such, however, they were treated by her with quiet civility; and by"      
##   [158] "her husband with as much kindness as he could feel towards anybody"          
##   [159] "beyond himself, his wife, and their child.  He really pressed them,"         
##   [160] "with some earnestness, to consider Norland as their home; and, as no"        
##   [161] "plan appeared so eligible to Mrs. Dashwood as remaining there till she"      
##   [162] "could accommodate herself with a house in the neighbourhood, his"            
##   [163] "invitation was accepted."                                                    
##   [164] ""                                                                            
##   [165] "A continuance in a place where everything reminded her of former"            
##   [166] "delight, was exactly what suited her mind.  In seasons of cheerfulness,"     
##   [167] "no temper could be more cheerful than hers, or possess, in a greater"        
##   [168] "degree, that sanguine expectation of happiness which is happiness"           
##   [169] "itself.  But in sorrow she must be equally carried away by her fancy,"       
##   [170] "and as far beyond consolation as in pleasure she was beyond alloy."          
##   [171] ""                                                                            
##   [172] "Mrs. John Dashwood did not at all approve of what her husband intended"      
##   [173] "to do for his sisters.  To take three thousand pounds from the fortune"      
##   [174] "of their dear little boy would be impoverishing him to the most"             
##   [175] "dreadful degree.  She begged him to think again on the subject.  How"        
##   [176] "could he answer it to himself to rob his child, and his only child too,"     
##   [177] "of so large a sum?  And what possible claim could the Miss Dashwoods,"       
##   [178] "who were related to him only by half blood, which she considered as no"      
##   [179] "relationship at all, have on his generosity to so large an amount.  It"      
##   [180] "was very well known that no affection was ever supposed to exist"            
##   [181] "between the children of any man by different marriages; and why was he"      
##   [182] "to ruin himself, and their poor little Harry, by giving away all his"        
##   [183] "money to his half sisters?"                                                  
##   [184] ""                                                                            
##   [185] "\"It was my father's last request to me,\" replied her husband, \"that I"    
##   [186] "should assist his widow and daughters.\""                                    
##   [187] ""                                                                            
##   [188] "\"He did not know what he was talking of, I dare say; ten to one but he"     
##   [189] "was light-headed at the time.  Had he been in his right senses, he"          
##   [190] "could not have thought of such a thing as begging you to give away half"     
##   [191] "your fortune from your own child.\""                                         
##   [192] ""                                                                            
##   [193] "\"He did not stipulate for any particular sum, my dear Fanny; he only"       
##   [194] "requested me, in general terms, to assist them, and make their"              
##   [195] "situation more comfortable than it was in his power to do.  Perhaps it"      
##   [196] "would have been as well if he had left it wholly to myself.  He could"       
##   [197] "hardly suppose I should neglect them.  But as he required the promise,"      
##   [198] "I could not do less than give it; at least I thought so at the time."        
##   [199] "The promise, therefore, was given, and must be performed.  Something"        
##   [200] "must be done for them whenever they leave Norland and settle in a new"       
##   [201] "home.\""                                                                     
##   [202] ""                                                                            
##   [203] "\"Well, then, LET something be done for them; but THAT something need"       
##   [204] "not be three thousand pounds.  Consider,\" she added, \"that when the"       
##   [205] "money is once parted with, it never can return.  Your sisters will"          
##   [206] "marry, and it will be gone for ever.  If, indeed, it could be restored"      
##   [207] "to our poor little boy--\""                                                  
##   [208] ""                                                                            
##   [209] "\"Why, to be sure,\" said her husband, very gravely, \"that would make"      
##   [210] "great difference.  The time may come when Harry will regret that so"         
##   [211] "large a sum was parted with.  If he should have a numerous family, for"      
##   [212] "instance, it would be a very convenient addition.\""                         
##   [213] ""                                                                            
##   [214] "\"To be sure it would.\""                                                    
##   [215] ""                                                                            
##   [216] "\"Perhaps, then, it would be better for all parties, if the sum were"        
##   [217] "diminished one half.--Five hundred pounds would be a prodigious"             
##   [218] "increase to their fortunes!\""                                               
##   [219] ""                                                                            
##   [220] "\"Oh! beyond anything great!  What brother on earth would do half so"        
##   [221] "much for his sisters, even if REALLY his sisters!  And as it is--only"       
##   [222] "half blood!--But you have such a generous spirit!\""                         
##   [223] ""                                                                            
##   [224] "\"I would not wish to do any thing mean,\" he replied.  \"One had rather,"   
##   [225] "on such occasions, do too much than too little.  No one, at least, can"      
##   [226] "think I have not done enough for them: even themselves, they can hardly"     
##   [227] "expect more.\""                                                              
##   [228] ""                                                                            
##   [229] "\"There is no knowing what THEY may expect,\" said the lady, \"but we are"   
##   [230] "not to think of their expectations: the question is, what you can"           
##   [231] "afford to do.\""                                                             
##   [232] ""                                                                            
##   [233] "\"Certainly--and I think I may afford to give them five hundred pounds"      
##   [234] "a-piece.  As it is, without any addition of mine, they will each have"       
##   [235] "about three thousand pounds on their mother's death--a very comfortable"     
##   [236] "fortune for any young woman.\""                                              
##   [237] ""                                                                            
##   [238] "\"To be sure it is; and, indeed, it strikes me that they can want no"        
##   [239] "addition at all.  They will have ten thousand pounds divided amongst"        
##   [240] "them.  If they marry, they will be sure of doing well, and if they do"       
##   [241] "not, they may all live very comfortably together on the interest of ten"     
##   [242] "thousand pounds.\""                                                          
##   [243] ""                                                                            
##   [244] "\"That is very true, and, therefore, I do not know whether, upon the"        
##   [245] "whole, it would not be more advisable to do something for their mother"      
##   [246] "while she lives, rather than for them--something of the annuity kind I"      
##   [247] "mean.--My sisters would feel the good effects of it as well as herself."     
##   [248] "A hundred a year would make them all perfectly comfortable.\""               
##   [249] ""                                                                            
##   [250] "His wife hesitated a little, however, in giving her consent to this"         
##   [251] "plan."                                                                       
##   [252] ""                                                                            
##   [253] "\"To be sure,\" said she, \"it is better than parting with fifteen hundred"  
##   [254] "pounds at once.  But, then, if Mrs. Dashwood should live fifteen years"      
##   [255] "we shall be completely taken in.\""                                          
##   [256] ""                                                                            
##   [257] "\"Fifteen years! my dear Fanny; her life cannot be worth half that"          
##   [258] "purchase.\""                                                                 
##   [259] ""                                                                            
##   [260] "\"Certainly not; but if you observe, people always live for ever when"       
##   [261] "there is an annuity to be paid them; and she is very stout and healthy,"     
##   [262] "and hardly forty.  An annuity is a very serious business; it comes over"     
##   [263] "and over every year, and there is no getting rid of it.  You are not"        
##   [264] "aware of what you are doing.  I have known a great deal of the trouble"      
##   [265] "of annuities; for my mother was clogged with the payment of three to"        
##   [266] "old superannuated servants by my father's will, and it is amazing how"       
##   [267] "disagreeable she found it.  Twice every year these annuities were to be"     
##   [268] "paid; and then there was the trouble of getting it to them; and then"        
##   [269] "one of them was said to have died, and afterwards it turned out to be"       
##   [270] "no such thing.  My mother was quite sick of it.  Her income was not her"     
##   [271] "own, she said, with such perpetual claims on it; and it was the more"        
##   [272] "unkind in my father, because, otherwise, the money would have been"          
##   [273] "entirely at my mother's disposal, without any restriction whatever.  It"     
##   [274] "has given me such an abhorrence of annuities, that I am sure I would"        
##   [275] "not pin myself down to the payment of one for all the world.\""              
##   [276] ""                                                                            
##   [277] "\"It is certainly an unpleasant thing,\" replied Mr. Dashwood, \"to have"    
##   [278] "those kind of yearly drains on one's income.  One's fortune, as your"        
##   [279] "mother justly says, is NOT one's own.  To be tied down to the regular"       
##   [280] "payment of such a sum, on every rent day, is by no means desirable: it"      
##   [281] "takes away one's independence.\""                                            
##   [282] ""                                                                            
##   [283] "\"Undoubtedly; and after all you have no thanks for it.  They think"         
##   [284] "themselves secure, you do no more than what is expected, and it raises"      
##   [285] "no gratitude at all.  If I were you, whatever I did should be done at"       
##   [286] "my own discretion entirely.  I would not bind myself to allow them any"      
##   [287] "thing yearly.  It may be very inconvenient some years to spare a"            
##   [288] "hundred, or even fifty pounds from our own expenses.\""                      
##   [289] ""                                                                            
##   [290] "\"I believe you are right, my love; it will be better that there should"     
##   [291] "be no annuity in the case; whatever I may give them occasionally will"       
##   [292] "be of far greater assistance than a yearly allowance, because they"          
##   [293] "would only enlarge their style of living if they felt sure of a larger"      
##   [294] "income, and would not be sixpence the richer for it at the end of the"       
##   [295] "year.  It will certainly be much the best way.  A present of fifty"          
##   [296] "pounds, now and then, will prevent their ever being distressed for"          
##   [297] "money, and will, I think, be amply discharging my promise to my father.\""   
##   [298] ""                                                                            
##   [299] "\"To be sure it will.  Indeed, to say the truth, I am convinced within"      
##   [300] "myself that your father had no idea of your giving them any money at"        
##   [301] "all.  The assistance he thought of, I dare say, was only such as might"      
##   [302] "be reasonably expected of you; for instance, such as looking out for a"      
##   [303] "comfortable small house for them, helping them to move their things,"        
##   [304] "and sending them presents of fish and game, and so forth, whenever they"     
##   [305] "are in season.  I'll lay my life that he meant nothing farther; indeed,"     
##   [306] "it would be very strange and unreasonable if he did.  Do but consider,"      
##   [307] "my dear Mr. Dashwood, how excessively comfortable your mother-in-law"        
##   [308] "and her daughters may live on the interest of seven thousand pounds,"        
##   [309] "besides the thousand pounds belonging to each of the girls, which"           
##   [310] "brings them in fifty pounds a year a-piece, and, of course, they will"       
##   [311] "pay their mother for their board out of it.  Altogether, they will have"     
##   [312] "five hundred a-year amongst them, and what on earth can four women want"     
##   [313] "for more than that?--They will live so cheap! Their housekeeping will"       
##   [314] "be nothing at all.  They will have no carriage, no horses, and hardly"       
##   [315] "any servants; they will keep no company, and can have no expenses of"        
##   [316] "any kind!  Only conceive how comfortable they will be!  Five hundred a"      
##   [317] "year! I am sure I cannot imagine how they will spend half of it; and as"     
##   [318] "to your giving them more, it is quite absurd to think of it.  They will"     
##   [319] "be much more able to give YOU something.\""                                  
##   [320] ""                                                                            
##   [321] "\"Upon my word,\" said Mr. Dashwood, \"I believe you are perfectly right."   
##   [322] "My father certainly could mean nothing more by his request to me than"       
##   [323] "what you say.  I clearly understand it now, and I will strictly fulfil"      
##   [324] "my engagement by such acts of assistance and kindness to them as you"        
##   [325] "have described.  When my mother removes into another house my services"      
##   [326] "shall be readily given to accommodate her as far as I can.  Some little"     
##   [327] "present of furniture too may be acceptable then.\""                          
##   [328] ""                                                                            
##   [329] "\"Certainly,\" returned Mrs. John Dashwood.  \"But, however, ONE thing"      
##   [330] "must be considered.  When your father and mother moved to Norland,"          
##   [331] "though the furniture of Stanhill was sold, all the china, plate, and"        
##   [332] "linen was saved, and is now left to your mother.  Her house will"            
##   [333] "therefore be almost completely fitted up as soon as she takes it.\""         
##   [334] ""                                                                            
##   [335] "\"That is a material consideration undoubtedly.  A valuable legacy"          
##   [336] "indeed! And yet some of the plate would have been a very pleasant"           
##   [337] "addition to our own stock here.\""                                           
##   [338] ""                                                                            
##   [339] "\"Yes; and the set of breakfast china is twice as handsome as what"          
##   [340] "belongs to this house.  A great deal too handsome, in my opinion, for"       
##   [341] "any place THEY can ever afford to live in.  But, however, so it is."         
##   [342] "Your father thought only of THEM.  And I must say this: that you owe no"     
##   [343] "particular gratitude to him, nor attention to his wishes; for we very"       
##   [344] "well know that if he could, he would have left almost everything in the"     
##   [345] "world to THEM.\""                                                            
##   [346] ""                                                                            
##   [347] "This argument was irresistible.  It gave to his intentions whatever of"      
##   [348] "decision was wanting before; and he finally resolved, that it would be"      
##   [349] "absolutely unnecessary, if not highly indecorous, to do more for the"        
##   [350] "widow and children of his father, than such kind of neighbourly acts as"     
##   [351] "his own wife pointed out."                                                   
##   [352] ""                                                                            
##   [353] ""                                                                            
##   [354] ""                                                                            
##   [355] "CHAPTER 3"                                                                   
##   [356] ""                                                                            
##   [357] ""                                                                            
##   [358] "Mrs. Dashwood remained at Norland several months; not from any"              
##   [359] "disinclination to move when the sight of every well known spot ceased"       
##   [360] "to raise the violent emotion which it produced for a while; for when"        
##   [361] "her spirits began to revive, and her mind became capable of some other"      
##   [362] "exertion than that of heightening its affliction by melancholy"              
##   [363] "remembrances, she was impatient to be gone, and indefatigable in her"        
##   [364] "inquiries for a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of Norland; for"      
##   [365] "to remove far from that beloved spot was impossible.  But she could"         
##   [366] "hear of no situation that at once answered her notions of comfort and"       
##   [367] "ease, and suited the prudence of her eldest daughter, whose steadier"        
##   [368] "judgment rejected several houses as too large for their income, which"       
##   [369] "her mother would have approved."                                             
##   [370] ""                                                                            
##   [371] "Mrs. Dashwood had been informed by her husband of the solemn promise on"     
##   [372] "the part of his son in their favour, which gave comfort to his last"         
##   [373] "earthly reflections.  She doubted the sincerity of this assurance no"        
##   [374] "more than he had doubted it himself, and she thought of it for her"          
##   [375] "daughters' sake with satisfaction, though as for herself she was"            
##   [376] "persuaded that a much smaller provision than 7000L would support her in"     
##   [377] "affluence.  For their brother's sake, too, for the sake of his own"          
##   [378] "heart, she rejoiced; and she reproached herself for being unjust to his"     
##   [379] "merit before, in believing him incapable of generosity.  His attentive"      
##   [380] "behaviour to herself and his sisters convinced her that their welfare"       
##   [381] "was dear to him, and, for a long time, she firmly relied on the"             
##   [382] "liberality of his intentions."                                               
##   [383] ""                                                                            
##   [384] "The contempt which she had, very early in their acquaintance, felt for"      
##   [385] "her daughter-in-law, was very much increased by the farther knowledge"       
##   [386] "of her character, which half a year's residence in her family afforded;"     
##   [387] "and perhaps in spite of every consideration of politeness or maternal"       
##   [388] "affection on the side of the former, the two ladies might have found it"     
##   [389] "impossible to have lived together so long, had not a particular"             
##   [390] "circumstance occurred to give still greater eligibility, according to"       
##   [391] "the opinions of Mrs. Dashwood, to her daughters' continuance at Norland."    
##   [392] ""                                                                            
##   [393] "This circumstance was a growing attachment between her eldest girl and"      
##   [394] "the brother of Mrs. John Dashwood, a gentleman-like and pleasing young"      
##   [395] "man, who was introduced to their acquaintance soon after his sister's"       
##   [396] "establishment at Norland, and who had since spent the greatest part of"      
##   [397] "his time there."                                                             
##   [398] ""                                                                            
##   [399] "Some mothers might have encouraged the intimacy from motives of"             
##   [400] "interest, for Edward Ferrars was the eldest son of a man who had died"       
##   [401] "very rich; and some might have repressed it from motives of prudence,"       
##   [402] "for, except a trifling sum, the whole of his fortune depended on the"        
##   [403] "will of his mother.  But Mrs. Dashwood was alike uninfluenced by either"     
##   [404] "consideration.  It was enough for her that he appeared to be amiable,"       
##   [405] "that he loved her daughter, and that Elinor returned the partiality."        
##   [406] "It was contrary to every doctrine of hers that difference of fortune"        
##   [407] "should keep any couple asunder who were attracted by resemblance of"         
##   [408] "disposition; and that Elinor's merit should not be acknowledged by"          
##   [409] "every one who knew her, was to her comprehension impossible."                
##   [410] ""                                                                            
##   [411] "Edward Ferrars was not recommended to their good opinion by any"             
##   [412] "peculiar graces of person or address.  He was not handsome, and his"         
##   [413] "manners required intimacy to make them pleasing.  He was too diffident"      
##   [414] "to do justice to himself; but when his natural shyness was overcome,"        
##   [415] "his behaviour gave every indication of an open, affectionate heart."         
##   [416] "His understanding was good, and his education had given it solid"            
##   [417] "improvement.  But he was neither fitted by abilities nor disposition to"     
##   [418] "answer the wishes of his mother and sister, who longed to see him"           
##   [419] "distinguished--as--they hardly knew what.  They wanted him to make a"        
##   [420] "fine figure in the world in some manner or other.  His mother wished to"     
##   [421] "interest him in political concerns, to get him into parliament, or to"       
##   [422] "see him connected with some of the great men of the day.  Mrs. John"         
##   [423] "Dashwood wished it likewise; but in the mean while, till one of these"       
##   [424] "superior blessings could be attained, it would have quieted her"             
##   [425] "ambition to see him driving a barouche.  But Edward had no turn for"         
##   [426] "great men or barouches.  All his wishes centered in domestic comfort"        
##   [427] "and the quiet of private life.  Fortunately he had a younger brother"        
##   [428] "who was more promising."                                                     
##   [429] ""                                                                            
##   [430] "Edward had been staying several weeks in the house before he engaged"        
##   [431] "much of Mrs. Dashwood's attention; for she was, at that time, in such"       
##   [432] "affliction as rendered her careless of surrounding objects.  She saw"        
##   [433] "only that he was quiet and unobtrusive, and she liked him for it.  He"       
##   [434] "did not disturb the wretchedness of her mind by ill-timed conversation."     
##   [435] "She was first called to observe and approve him farther, by a"               
##   [436] "reflection which Elinor chanced one day to make on the difference"           
##   [437] "between him and his sister.  It was a contrast which recommended him"        
##   [438] "most forcibly to her mother."                                                
##   [439] ""                                                                            
##   [440] "\"It is enough,\" said she; \"to say that he is unlike Fanny is enough."     
##   [441] "It implies everything amiable.  I love him already.\""                       
##   [442] ""                                                                            
##   [443] "\"I think you will like him,\" said Elinor, \"when you know more of him.\""  
##   [444] ""                                                                            
##   [445] "\"Like him!\" replied her mother with a smile.  \"I feel no sentiment of"    
##   [446] "approbation inferior to love.\""                                             
##   [447] ""                                                                            
##   [448] "\"You may esteem him.\""                                                     
##   [449] ""                                                                            
##   [450] "\"I have never yet known what it was to separate esteem and love.\""         
##   [451] ""                                                                            
##   [452] "Mrs. Dashwood now took pains to get acquainted with him.  Her manners"       
##   [453] "were attaching, and soon banished his reserve.  She speedily"                
##   [454] "comprehended all his merits; the persuasion of his regard for Elinor"        
##   [455] "perhaps assisted her penetration; but she really felt assured of his"        
##   [456] "worth: and even that quietness of manner, which militated against all"       
##   [457] "her established ideas of what a young man's address ought to be, was no"     
##   [458] "longer uninteresting when she knew his heart to be warm and his temper"      
##   [459] "affectionate."                                                               
##   [460] ""                                                                            
##   [461] "No sooner did she perceive any symptom of love in his behaviour to"          
##   [462] "Elinor, than she considered their serious attachment as certain, and"        
##   [463] "looked forward to their marriage as rapidly approaching."                    
##   [464] ""                                                                            
##   [465] "\"In a few months, my dear Marianne.\" said she, \"Elinor will, in all"      
##   [466] "probability be settled for life.  We shall miss her; but SHE will be"        
##   [467] "happy.\""                                                                    
##   [468] ""                                                                            
##   [469] "\"Oh! Mama, how shall we do without her?\""                                  
##   [470] ""                                                                            
##   [471] "\"My love, it will be scarcely a separation.  We shall live within a few"    
##   [472] "miles of each other, and shall meet every day of our lives.  You will"       
##   [473] "gain a brother, a real, affectionate brother.  I have the highest"           
##   [474] "opinion in the world of Edward's heart.  But you look grave, Marianne;"      
##   [475] "do you disapprove your sister's choice?\""                                   
##   [476] ""                                                                            
##   [477] "\"Perhaps,\" said Marianne, \"I may consider it with some surprise."         
##   [478] "Edward is very amiable, and I love him tenderly.  But yet--he is not"        
##   [479] "the kind of young man--there is something wanting--his figure is not"        
##   [480] "striking; it has none of that grace which I should expect in the man"        
##   [481] "who could seriously attach my sister.  His eyes want all that spirit,"       
##   [482] "that fire, which at once announce virtue and intelligence.  And besides"     
##   [483] "all this, I am afraid, Mama, he has no real taste.  Music seems"             
##   [484] "scarcely to attract him, and though he admires Elinor's drawings very"       
##   [485] "much, it is not the admiration of a person who can understand their"         
##   [486] "worth.  It is evident, in spite of his frequent attention to her while"      
##   [487] "she draws, that in fact he knows nothing of the matter.  He admires as"      
##   [488] "a lover, not as a connoisseur.  To satisfy me, those characters must be"     
##   [489] "united.  I could not be happy with a man whose taste did not in every"       
##   [490] "point coincide with my own.  He must enter into all my feelings; the"        
##   [491] "same books, the same music must charm us both.  Oh! mama, how"               
##   [492] "spiritless, how tame was Edward's manner in reading to us last night!"       
##   [493] "I felt for my sister most severely.  Yet she bore it with so much"           
##   [494] "composure, she seemed scarcely to notice it.  I could hardly keep my"        
##   [495] "seat.  To hear those beautiful lines which have frequently almost"           
##   [496] "driven me wild, pronounced with such impenetrable calmness, such"            
##   [497] "dreadful indifference!\""                                                    
##   [498] ""                                                                            
##   [499] "\"He would certainly have done more justice to simple and elegant prose."    
##   [500] "I thought so at the time; but you WOULD give him Cowper.\""                  
##   [501] ""                                                                            
##   [502] "\"Nay, Mama, if he is not to be animated by Cowper!--but we must allow"      
##   [503] "for difference of taste.  Elinor has not my feelings, and therefore she"     
##   [504] "may overlook it, and be happy with him.  But it would have broke MY"         
##   [505] "heart, had I loved him, to hear him read with so little sensibility."        
##   [506] "Mama, the more I know of the world, the more am I convinced that I"          
##   [507] "shall never see a man whom I can really love.  I require so much!  He"       
##   [508] "must have all Edward's virtues, and his person and manners must"             
##   [509] "ornament his goodness with every possible charm.\""                          
##   [510] ""                                                                            
##   [511] "\"Remember, my love, that you are not seventeen.  It is yet too early in"    
##   [512] "life to despair of such a happiness.  Why should you be less fortunate"      
##   [513] "than your mother?  In one circumstance only, my Marianne, may your"          
##   [514] "destiny be different from hers!\""                                           
##   [515] ""                                                                            
##   [516] ""                                                                            
##   [517] ""                                                                            
##   [518] "CHAPTER 4"                                                                   
##   [519] ""                                                                            
##   [520] ""                                                                            
##   [521] "\"What a pity it is, Elinor,\" said Marianne, \"that Edward should have no"  
##   [522] "taste for drawing.\""                                                        
##   [523] ""                                                                            
##   [524] "\"No taste for drawing!\" replied Elinor, \"why should you think so? He"     
##   [525] "does not draw himself, indeed, but he has great pleasure in seeing the"      
##   [526] "performances of other people, and I assure you he is by no means"            
##   [527] "deficient in natural taste, though he has not had opportunities of"          
##   [528] "improving it.  Had he ever been in the way of learning, I think he"          
##   [529] "would have drawn very well.  He distrusts his own judgment in such"          
##   [530] "matters so much, that he is always unwilling to give his opinion on any"     
##   [531] "picture; but he has an innate propriety and simplicity of taste, which"      
##   [532] "in general direct him perfectly right.\""                                    
##   [533] ""                                                                            
##   [534] "Marianne was afraid of offending, and said no more on the subject; but"      
##   [535] "the kind of approbation which Elinor described as excited in him by the"     
##   [536] "drawings of other people, was very far from that rapturous delight,"         
##   [537] "which, in her opinion, could alone be called taste.  Yet, though"            
##   [538] "smiling within herself at the mistake, she honoured her sister for that"     
##   [539] "blind partiality to Edward which produced it."                               
##   [540] ""                                                                            
##   [541] "\"I hope, Marianne,\" continued Elinor, \"you do not consider him as"        
##   [542] "deficient in general taste.  Indeed, I think I may say that you cannot,"     
##   [543] "for your behaviour to him is perfectly cordial, and if THAT were your"       
##   [544] "opinion, I am sure you could never be civil to him.\""                       
##   [545] ""                                                                            
##   [546] "Marianne hardly knew what to say.  She would not wound the feelings of"      
##   [547] "her sister on any account, and yet to say what she did not believe was"      
##   [548] "impossible.  At length she replied:"                                         
##   [549] ""                                                                            
##   [550] "\"Do not be offended, Elinor, if my praise of him is not in every thing"     
##   [551] "equal to your sense of his merits.  I have not had so many"                  
##   [552] "opportunities of estimating the minuter propensities of his mind, his"       
##   [553] "inclinations and tastes, as you have; but I have the highest opinion in"     
##   [554] "the world of his goodness and sense.  I think him every thing that is"       
##   [555] "worthy and amiable.\""                                                       
##   [556] ""                                                                            
##   [557] "\"I am sure,\" replied Elinor, with a smile, \"that his dearest friends"     
##   [558] "could not be dissatisfied with such commendation as that.  I do not"         
##   [559] "perceive how you could express yourself more warmly.\""                      
##   [560] ""                                                                            
##   [561] "Marianne was rejoiced to find her sister so easily pleased."                 
##   [562] ""                                                                            
##   [563] "\"Of his sense and his goodness,\" continued Elinor, \"no one can, I"        
##   [564] "think, be in doubt, who has seen him often enough to engage him in"          
##   [565] "unreserved conversation.  The excellence of his understanding and his"       
##   [566] "principles can be concealed only by that shyness which too often keeps"      
##   [567] "him silent.  You know enough of him to do justice to his solid worth."       
##   [568] "But of his minuter propensities, as you call them you have from"             
##   [569] "peculiar circumstances been kept more ignorant than myself.  He and I"       
##   [570] "have been at times thrown a good deal together, while you have been"         
##   [571] "wholly engrossed on the most affectionate principle by my mother.  I"        
##   [572] "have seen a great deal of him, have studied his sentiments and heard"        
##   [573] "his opinion on subjects of literature and taste; and, upon the whole, I"     
##   [574] "venture to pronounce that his mind is well-informed, enjoyment of books"     
##   [575] "exceedingly great, his imagination lively, his observation just and"         
##   [576] "correct, and his taste delicate and pure.  His abilities in every"           
##   [577] "respect improve as much upon acquaintance as his manners and person."        
##   [578] "At first sight, his address is certainly not striking; and his person"       
##   [579] "can hardly be called handsome, till the expression of his eyes, which"       
##   [580] "are uncommonly good, and the general sweetness of his countenance, is"       
##   [581] "perceived.  At present, I know him so well, that I think him really"         
##   [582] "handsome; or at least, almost so.  What say you, Marianne?\""                
##   [583] ""                                                                            
##   [584] "\"I shall very soon think him handsome, Elinor, if I do not now.  When"      
##   [585] "you tell me to love him as a brother, I shall no more see imperfection"      
##   [586] "in his face, than I now do in his heart.\""
