##   [587] ""                                                                            
##   [588] "Elinor started at this declaration, and was sorry for the warmth she"        
##   [589] "had been betrayed into, in speaking of him.  She felt that Edward stood"     
##   [590] "very high in her opinion.  She believed the regard to be mutual; but"        
##   [591] "she required greater certainty of it to make Marianne's conviction of"       
##   [592] "their attachment agreeable to her.  She knew that what Marianne and her"     
##   [593] "mother conjectured one moment, they believed the next--that with them,"      
##   [594] "to wish was to hope, and to hope was to expect.  She tried to explain"       
##   [595] "the real state of the case to her sister."                                   
##   [596] ""                                                                            
##   [597] "\"I do not attempt to deny,\" said she, \"that I think very highly of"       
##   [598] "him--that I greatly esteem, that I like him.\""                              
##   [599] ""                                                                            
##   [600] "Marianne here burst forth with indignation--"                                
##   [601] ""                                                                            
##   [602] "\"Esteem him! Like him! Cold-hearted Elinor! Oh!  worse than"                
##   [603] "cold-hearted! Ashamed of being otherwise.  Use those words again, and I"     
##   [604] "will leave the room this moment.\""                                          
##   [605] ""                                                                            
##   [606] "Elinor could not help laughing.  \"Excuse me,\" said she; \"and be assured"  
##   [607] "that I meant no offence to you, by speaking, in so quiet a way, of my"       
##   [608] "own feelings.  Believe them to be stronger than I have declared;"            
##   [609] "believe them, in short, to be such as his merit, and the suspicion--the"     
##   [610] "hope of his affection for me may warrant, without imprudence or folly."      
##   [611] "But farther than this you must not believe.  I am by no means assured"       
##   [612] "of his regard for me.  There are moments when the extent of it seems"        
##   [613] "doubtful; and till his sentiments are fully known, you cannot wonder at"     
##   [614] "my wishing to avoid any encouragement of my own partiality, by"              
##   [615] "believing or calling it more than it is.  In my heart I feel"                
##   [616] "little--scarcely any doubt of his preference.  But there are other"          
##   [617] "points to be considered besides his inclination.  He is very far from"       
##   [618] "being independent.  What his mother really is we cannot know; but, from"     
##   [619] "Fanny's occasional mention of her conduct and opinions, we have never"       
##   [620] "been disposed to think her amiable; and I am very much mistaken if"          
##   [621] "Edward is not himself aware that there would be many difficulties in"        
##   [622] "his way, if he were to wish to marry a woman who had not either a great"     
##   [623] "fortune or high rank.\""                                                     
##   [624] ""                                                                            
##   [625] "Marianne was astonished to find how much the imagination of her mother"      
##   [626] "and herself had outstripped the truth."                                      
##   [627] ""                                                                            
##   [628] "\"And you really are not engaged to him!\" said she.  \"Yet it certainly"    
##   [629] "soon will happen.  But two advantages will proceed from this delay.  I"      
##   [630] "shall not lose you so soon, and Edward will have greater opportunity of"     
##   [631] "improving that natural taste for your favourite pursuit which must be"       
##   [632] "so indispensably necessary to your future felicity.  Oh! if he should"       
##   [633] "be so far stimulated by your genius as to learn to draw himself, how"        
##   [634] "delightful it would be!\""                                                   
##   [635] ""                                                                            
##   [636] "Elinor had given her real opinion to her sister.  She could not"             
##   [637] "consider her partiality for Edward in so prosperous a state as Marianne"     
##   [638] "had believed it.  There was, at times, a want of spirits about him"          
##   [639] "which, if it did not denote indifference, spoke of something almost as"      
##   [640] "unpromising.  A doubt of her regard, supposing him to feel it, need not"     
##   [641] "give him more than inquietude.  It would not be likely to produce that"      
##   [642] "dejection of mind which frequently attended him.  A more reasonable"         
##   [643] "cause might be found in the dependent situation which forbade the"           
##   [644] "indulgence of his affection.  She knew that his mother neither behaved"      
##   [645] "to him so as to make his home comfortable at present, nor to give him"       
##   [646] "any assurance that he might form a home for himself, without strictly"       
##   [647] "attending to her views for his aggrandizement.  With such a knowledge"       
##   [648] "as this, it was impossible for Elinor to feel easy on the subject.  She"     
##   [649] "was far from depending on that result of his preference of her, which"       
##   [650] "her mother and sister still considered as certain.  Nay, the longer"         
##   [651] "they were together the more doubtful seemed the nature of his regard;"       
##   [652] "and sometimes, for a few painful minutes, she believed it to be no more"     
##   [653] "than friendship."                                                            
##   [654] ""                                                                            
##   [655] "But, whatever might really be its limits, it was enough, when perceived"     
##   [656] "by his sister, to make her uneasy, and at the same time, (which was"         
##   [657] "still more common,) to make her uncivil.  She took the first"                
##   [658] "opportunity of affronting her mother-in-law on the occasion, talking to"     
##   [659] "her so expressively of her brother's great expectations, of Mrs."            
##   [660] "Ferrars's resolution that both her sons should marry well, and of the"       
##   [661] "danger attending any young woman who attempted to DRAW HIM IN; that"         
##   [662] "Mrs. Dashwood could neither pretend to be unconscious, nor endeavor to"      
##   [663] "be calm.  She gave her an answer which marked her contempt, and"             
##   [664] "instantly left the room, resolving that, whatever might be the"              
##   [665] "inconvenience or expense of so sudden a removal, her beloved Elinor"         
##   [666] "should not be exposed another week to such insinuations."                    
##   [667] ""                                                                            
##   [668] "In this state of her spirits, a letter was delivered to her from the"        
##   [669] "post, which contained a proposal particularly well timed.  It was the"       
##   [670] "offer of a small house, on very easy terms, belonging to a relation of"      
##   [671] "her own, a gentleman of consequence and property in Devonshire.  The"        
##   [672] "letter was from this gentleman himself, and written in the true spirit"      
##   [673] "of friendly accommodation.  He understood that she was in need of a"         
##   [674] "dwelling; and though the house he now offered her was merely a cottage,"     
##   [675] "he assured her that everything should be done to it which she might"         
##   [676] "think necessary, if the situation pleased her.  He earnestly pressed"        
##   [677] "her, after giving the particulars of the house and garden, to come with"     
##   [678] "her daughters to Barton Park, the place of his own residence, from"          
##   [679] "whence she might judge, herself, whether Barton Cottage, for the houses"     
##   [680] "were in the same parish, could, by any alteration, be made comfortable"      
##   [681] "to her.  He seemed really anxious to accommodate them and the whole of"      
##   [682] "his letter was written in so friendly a style as could not fail of"          
##   [683] "giving pleasure to his cousin; more especially at a moment when she was"     
##   [684] "suffering under the cold and unfeeling behaviour of her nearer"              
##   [685] "connections.  She needed no time for deliberation or inquiry.  Her"          
##   [686] "resolution was formed as she read.  The situation of Barton, in a"           
##   [687] "county so far distant from Sussex as Devonshire, which, but a few hours"     
##   [688] "before, would have been a sufficient objection to outweigh every"            
##   [689] "possible advantage belonging to the place, was now its first"                
##   [690] "recommendation.  To quit the neighbourhood of Norland was no longer an"      
##   [691] "evil; it was an object of desire; it was a blessing, in comparison of"       
##   [692] "the misery of continuing her daughter-in-law's guest; and to remove for"     
##   [693] "ever from that beloved place would be less painful than to inhabit or"       
##   [694] "visit it while such a woman was its mistress.  She instantly wrote Sir"      
##   [695] "John Middleton her acknowledgment of his kindness, and her acceptance"       
##   [696] "of his proposal; and then hastened to shew both letters to her"              
##   [697] "daughters, that she might be secure of their approbation before her"         
##   [698] "answer were sent."                                                           
##   [699] ""                                                                            
##   [700] "Elinor had always thought it would be more prudent for them to settle"       
##   [701] "at some distance from Norland, than immediately amongst their present"       
##   [702] "acquaintance.  On THAT head, therefore, it was not for her to oppose"        
##   [703] "her mother's intention of removing into Devonshire.  The house, too, as"     
##   [704] "described by Sir John, was on so simple a scale, and the rent so"            
##   [705] "uncommonly moderate, as to leave her no right of objection on either"        
##   [706] "point; and, therefore, though it was not a plan which brought any charm"     
##   [707] "to her fancy, though it was a removal from the vicinity of Norland"          
##   [708] "beyond her wishes, she made no attempt to dissuade her mother from"          
##   [709] "sending a letter of acquiescence."                                           
##   [710] ""                                                                            
##   [711] ""                                                                            
##   [712] ""                                                                            
##   [713] "CHAPTER 5"                                                                   
##   [714] ""                                                                            
##   [715] ""                                                                            
##   [716] "No sooner was her answer dispatched, than Mrs. Dashwood indulged herself"    
##   [717] "in the pleasure of announcing to her son-in-law and his wife that she"       
##   [718] "was provided with a house, and should incommode them no longer than till"    
##   [719] "every thing were ready for her inhabiting it. They heard her with"           
##   [720] "surprise. Mrs. John Dashwood said nothing; but her husband civilly hoped"    
##   [721] "that she would not be settled far from Norland. She had great"               
##   [722] "satisfaction in replying that she was going into Devonshire.--Edward"        
##   [723] "turned hastily towards her, on hearing this, and, in a voice of surprise"    
##   [724] "and concern, which required no explanation to her, repeated,"                
##   [725] "\"Devonshire! Are you, indeed, going there? So far from hence! And to"       
##   [726] "what part of it?\" She explained the situation. It was within four miles"    
##   [727] "northward of Exeter."                                                        
##   [728] ""                                                                            
##   [729] "\"It is but a cottage,\" she continued, \"but I hope to see many of my"      
##   [730] "friends in it.  A room or two can easily be added; and if my friends"        
##   [731] "find no difficulty in travelling so far to see me, I am sure I will"         
##   [732] "find none in accommodating them.\""                                          
##   [733] ""                                                                            
##   [734] "She concluded with a very kind invitation to Mr. and Mrs. John Dashwood"     
##   [735] "to visit her at Barton; and to Edward she gave one with still greater"       
##   [736] "affection.  Though her late conversation with her daughter-in-law had"       
##   [737] "made her resolve on remaining at Norland no longer than was"                 
##   [738] "unavoidable, it had not produced the smallest effect on her in that"         
##   [739] "point to which it principally tended.  To separate Edward and Elinor"        
##   [740] "was as far from being her object as ever; and she wished to show Mrs."       
##   [741] "John Dashwood, by this pointed invitation to her brother, how totally"       
##   [742] "she disregarded her disapprobation of the match."                            
##   [743] ""                                                                            
##   [744] "Mr. John Dashwood told his mother again and again how exceedingly sorry"     
##   [745] "he was that she had taken a house at such a distance from Norland as to"     
##   [746] "prevent his being of any service to her in removing her furniture.  He"      
##   [747] "really felt conscientiously vexed on the occasion; for the very"             
##   [748] "exertion to which he had limited the performance of his promise to his"      
##   [749] "father was by this arrangement rendered impracticable.-- The furniture"      
##   [750] "was all sent around by water.  It chiefly consisted of household linen,"     
##   [751] "plate, china, and books, with a handsome pianoforte of Marianne's."          
##   [752] "Mrs. John Dashwood saw the packages depart with a sigh: she could not"       
##   [753] "help feeling it hard that as Mrs. Dashwood's income would be so"             
##   [754] "trifling in comparison with their own, she should have any handsome"         
##   [755] "article of furniture."                                                       
##   [756] ""                                                                            
##   [757] "Mrs. Dashwood took the house for a twelvemonth; it was ready furnished,"     
##   [758] "and she might have immediate possession.  No difficulty arose on either"     
##   [759] "side in the agreement; and she waited only for the disposal of her"          
##   [760] "effects at Norland, and to determine her future household, before she"       
##   [761] "set off for the west; and this, as she was exceedingly rapid in the"         
##   [762] "performance of everything that interested her, was soon done.--The"          
##   [763] "horses which were left her by her husband had been sold soon after his"      
##   [764] "death, and an opportunity now offering of disposing of her carriage,"        
##   [765] "she agreed to sell that likewise at the earnest advice of her eldest"        
##   [766] "daughter.  For the comfort of her children, had she consulted only her"      
##   [767] "own wishes, she would have kept it; but the discretion of Elinor"            
##   [768] "prevailed.  HER wisdom too limited the number of their servants to"          
##   [769] "three; two maids and a man, with whom they were speedily provided from"      
##   [770] "amongst those who had formed their establishment at Norland."                
##   [771] ""                                                                            
##   [772] "The man and one of the maids were sent off immediately into Devonshire,"     
##   [773] "to prepare the house for their mistress's arrival; for as Lady"              
##   [774] "Middleton was entirely unknown to Mrs. Dashwood, she preferred going"        
##   [775] "directly to the cottage to being a visitor at Barton Park; and she"          
##   [776] "relied so undoubtingly on Sir John's description of the house, as to"        
##   [777] "feel no curiosity to examine it herself till she entered it as her own."     
##   [778] "Her eagerness to be gone from Norland was preserved from diminution by"      
##   [779] "the evident satisfaction of her daughter-in-law in the prospect of her"      
##   [780] "removal; a satisfaction which was but feebly attempted to be concealed"      
##   [781] "under a cold invitation to her to defer her departure.  Now was the"         
##   [782] "time when her son-in-law's promise to his father might with particular"      
##   [783] "propriety be fulfilled.  Since he had neglected to do it on first"           
##   [784] "coming to the estate, their quitting his house might be looked on as"        
##   [785] "the most suitable period for its accomplishment.  But Mrs. Dashwood"         
##   [786] "began shortly to give over every hope of the kind, and to be convinced,"     
##   [787] "from the general drift of his discourse, that his assistance extended"       
##   [788] "no farther than their maintenance for six months at Norland.  He so"         
##   [789] "frequently talked of the increasing expenses of housekeeping, and of"        
##   [790] "the perpetual demands upon his purse, which a man of any consequence in"     
##   [791] "the world was beyond calculation exposed to, that he seemed rather to"       
##   [792] "stand in need of more money himself than to have any design of giving"       
##   [793] "money away."                                                                 
##   [794] ""                                                                            
##   [795] "In a very few weeks from the day which brought Sir John Middleton's"         
##   [796] "first letter to Norland, every thing was so far settled in their future"     
##   [797] "abode as to enable Mrs. Dashwood and her daughters to begin their"           
##   [798] "journey."                                                                    
##   [799] ""                                                                            
##   [800] "Many were the tears shed by them in their last adieus to a place so"         
##   [801] "much beloved.  \"Dear, dear Norland!\" said Marianne, as she wandered"       
##   [802] "alone before the house, on the last evening of their being there; \"when"    
##   [803] "shall I cease to regret you!--when learn to feel a home elsewhere!--Oh!"     
##   [804] "happy house, could you know what I suffer in now viewing you from this"      
##   [805] "spot, from whence perhaps I may view you no more!--And you, ye"              
##   [806] "well-known trees!--but you will continue the same.--No leaf will decay"      
##   [807] "because we are removed, nor any branch become motionless although we"        
##   [808] "can observe you no longer!--No; you will continue the same; unconscious"     
##   [809] "of the pleasure or the regret you occasion, and insensible of any"           
##   [810] "change in those who walk under your shade!--But who will remain to"          
##   [811] "enjoy you?\""                                                                
##   [812] ""                                                                            
##   [813] ""                                                                            
##   [814] ""                                                                            
##   [815] "CHAPTER 6"                                                                   
##   [816] ""                                                                            
##   [817] ""                                                                            
##   [818] "The first part of their journey was performed in too melancholy a"           
##   [819] "disposition to be otherwise than tedious and unpleasant.  But as they"       
##   [820] "drew towards the end of it, their interest in the appearance of a"           
##   [821] "country which they were to inhabit overcame their dejection, and a view"     
##   [822] "of Barton Valley as they entered it gave them cheerfulness.  It was a"       
##   [823] "pleasant fertile spot, well wooded, and rich in pasture.  After winding"     
##   [824] "along it for more than a mile, they reached their own house.  A small"       
##   [825] "green court was the whole of its demesne in front; and a neat wicket"        
##   [826] "gate admitted them into it."                                                 
##   [827] ""                                                                            
##   [828] "As a house, Barton Cottage, though small, was comfortable and compact;"      
##   [829] "but as a cottage it was defective, for the building was regular, the"        
##   [830] "roof was tiled, the window shutters were not painted green, nor were"        
##   [831] "the walls covered with honeysuckles.  A narrow passage led directly"         
##   [832] "through the house into the garden behind.  On each side of the entrance"     
##   [833] "was a sitting room, about sixteen feet square; and beyond them were the"     
##   [834] "offices and the stairs.  Four bed-rooms and two garrets formed the rest"     
##   [835] "of the house.  It had not been built many years and was in good repair."     
##   [836] "In comparison of Norland, it was poor and small indeed!--but the tears"      
##   [837] "which recollection called forth as they entered the house were soon"         
##   [838] "dried away.  They were cheered by the joy of the servants on their"          
##   [839] "arrival, and each for the sake of the others resolved to appear happy."      
##   [840] "It was very early in September; the season was fine, and from first"         
##   [841] "seeing the place under the advantage of good weather, they received an"      
##   [842] "impression in its favour which was of material service in recommending"      
##   [843] "it to their lasting approbation."                                            
##   [844] ""                                                                            
##   [845] "The situation of the house was good.  High hills rose immediately"           
##   [846] "behind, and at no great distance on each side; some of which were open"      
##   [847] "downs, the others cultivated and woody.  The village of Barton was"          
##   [848] "chiefly on one of these hills, and formed a pleasant view from the"          
##   [849] "cottage windows.  The prospect in front was more extensive; it"              
##   [850] "commanded the whole of the valley, and reached into the country beyond."     
##   [851] "The hills which surrounded the cottage terminated the valley in that"        
##   [852] "direction; under another name, and in another course, it branched out"       
##   [853] "again between two of the steepest of them."                                  
##   [854] ""                                                                            
##   [855] "With the size and furniture of the house Mrs. Dashwood was upon the"         
##   [856] "whole well satisfied; for though her former style of life rendered many"     
##   [857] "additions to the latter indispensable, yet to add and improve was a"         
##   [858] "delight to her; and she had at this time ready money enough to supply"       
##   [859] "all that was wanted of greater elegance to the apartments.  \"As for the"    
##   [860] "house itself, to be sure,\" said she, \"it is too small for our family,"     
##   [861] "but we will make ourselves tolerably comfortable for the present, as it"     
##   [862] "is too late in the year for improvements.  Perhaps in the spring, if I"      
##   [863] "have plenty of money, as I dare say I shall, we may think about"             
##   [864] "building.  These parlors are both too small for such parties of our"         
##   [865] "friends as I hope to see often collected here; and I have some thoughts"     
##   [866] "of throwing the passage into one of them with perhaps a part of the"         
##   [867] "other, and so leave the remainder of that other for an entrance; this,"      
##   [868] "with a new drawing room which may be easily added, and a bed-chamber"        
##   [869] "and garret above, will make it a very snug little cottage.  I could"         
##   [870] "wish the stairs were handsome.  But one must not expect every thing;"        
##   [871] "though I suppose it would be no difficult matter to widen them.  I"          
##   [872] "shall see how much I am before-hand with the world in the spring, and"       
##   [873] "we will plan our improvements accordingly.\""                                
##   [874] ""                                                                            
##   [875] "In the mean time, till all these alterations could be made from the"         
##   [876] "savings of an income of five hundred a-year by a woman who never saved"      
##   [877] "in her life, they were wise enough to be contented with the house as it"     
##   [878] "was; and each of them was busy in arranging their particular concerns,"      
##   [879] "and endeavoring, by placing around them books and other possessions, to"     
##   [880] "form themselves a home.  Marianne's pianoforte was unpacked and"             
##   [881] "properly disposed of; and Elinor's drawings were affixed to the walls"       
##   [882] "of their sitting room."                                                      
##   [883] ""                                                                            
##   [884] "In such employments as these they were interrupted soon after breakfast"     
##   [885] "the next day by the entrance of their landlord, who called to welcome"       
##   [886] "them to Barton, and to offer them every accommodation from his own"          
##   [887] "house and garden in which theirs might at present be deficient.  Sir"        
##   [888] "John Middleton was a good looking man about forty.  He had formerly"         
##   [889] "visited at Stanhill, but it was too long for his young cousins to"           
##   [890] "remember him.  His countenance was thoroughly good-humoured; and his"        
##   [891] "manners were as friendly as the style of his letter.  Their arrival"         
##   [892] "seemed to afford him real satisfaction, and their comfort to be an"          
##   [893] "object of real solicitude to him.  He said much of his earnest desire"       
##   [894] "of their living in the most sociable terms with his family, and pressed"     
##   [895] "them so cordially to dine at Barton Park every day till they were"           
##   [896] "better settled at home, that, though his entreaties were carried to a"       
##   [897] "point of perseverance beyond civility, they could not give offence."         
##   [898] "His kindness was not confined to words; for within an hour after he"         
##   [899] "left them, a large basket full of garden stuff and fruit arrived from"       
##   [900] "the park, which was followed before the end of the day by a present of"      
##   [901] "game.  He insisted, moreover, on conveying all their letters to and"         
##   [902] "from the post for them, and would not be denied the satisfaction of"         
##   [903] "sending them his newspaper every day."                                       
##   [904] ""                                                                            
##   [905] "Lady Middleton had sent a very civil message by him, denoting her"           
##   [906] "intention of waiting on Mrs. Dashwood as soon as she could be assured"       
##   [907] "that her visit would be no inconvenience; and as this message was"           
##   [908] "answered by an invitation equally polite, her ladyship was introduced"       
##   [909] "to them the next day."                                                       
##   [910] ""                                                                            
##   [911] "They were, of course, very anxious to see a person on whom so much of"       
##   [912] "their comfort at Barton must depend; and the elegance of her appearance"     
##   [913] "was favourable to their wishes.  Lady Middleton was not more than six"       
##   [914] "or seven and twenty; her face was handsome, her figure tall and"             
##   [915] "striking, and her address graceful.  Her manners had all the elegance"       
##   [916] "which her husband's wanted.  But they would have been improved by some"      
##   [917] "share of his frankness and warmth; and her visit was long enough to"         
##   [918] "detract something from their first admiration, by shewing that, though"      
##   [919] "perfectly well-bred, she was reserved, cold, and had nothing to say for"     
##   [920] "herself beyond the most common-place inquiry or remark."                     
##   [921] ""                                                                            
##   [922] "Conversation however was not wanted, for Sir John was very chatty, and"      
##   [923] "Lady Middleton had taken the wise precaution of bringing with her their"     
##   [924] "eldest child, a fine little boy about six years old, by which means"         
##   [925] "there was one subject always to be recurred to by the ladies in case of"     
##   [926] "extremity, for they had to enquire his name and age, admire his beauty,"     
##   [927] "and ask him questions which his mother answered for him, while he hung"      
##   [928] "about her and held down his head, to the great surprise of her"              
##   [929] "ladyship, who wondered at his being so shy before company, as he could"      
##   [930] "make noise enough at home.  On every formal visit a child ought to be"       
##   [931] "of the party, by way of provision for discourse.  In the present case"       
##   [932] "it took up ten minutes to determine whether the boy were most like his"      
##   [933] "father or mother, and in what particular he resembled either, for of"        
##   [934] "course every body differed, and every body was astonished at the"            
##   [935] "opinion of the others."                                                      
##   [936] ""                                                                            
##   [937] "An opportunity was soon to be given to the Dashwoods of debating on the"     
##   [938] "rest of the children, as Sir John would not leave the house without"         
##   [939] "securing their promise of dining at the park the next day."                  
##   [940] ""                                                                            
##   [941] ""                                                                            
##   [942] ""                                                                            
##   [943] "CHAPTER 7"                                                                   
##   [944] ""                                                                            
##   [945] ""                                                                            
##   [946] "Barton Park was about half a mile from the cottage.  The ladies had"         
##   [947] "passed near it in their way along the valley, but it was screened from"      
##   [948] "their view at home by the projection of a hill.  The house was large"        
##   [949] "and handsome; and the Middletons lived in a style of equal hospitality"      
##   [950] "and elegance.  The former was for Sir John's gratification, the latter"      
##   [951] "for that of his lady.  They were scarcely ever without some friends"         
##   [952] "staying with them in the house, and they kept more company of every"         
##   [953] "kind than any other family in the neighbourhood.  It was necessary to"       
##   [954] "the happiness of both; for however dissimilar in temper and outward"         
##   [955] "behaviour, they strongly resembled each other in that total want of"         
##   [956] "talent and taste which confined their employments, unconnected with"         
##   [957] "such as society produced, within a very narrow compass.  Sir John was a"     
##   [958] "sportsman, Lady Middleton a mother.  He hunted and shot, and she"            
##   [959] "humoured her children; and these were their only resources.  Lady"           
##   [960] "Middleton had the advantage of being able to spoil her children all the"     
##   [961] "year round, while Sir John's independent employments were in existence"      
##   [962] "only half the time.  Continual engagements at home and abroad, however,"     
##   [963] "supplied all the deficiencies of nature and education; supported the"        
##   [964] "good spirits of Sir John, and gave exercise to the good breeding of his"     
##   [965] "wife."                                                                       
##   [966] ""                                                                            
##   [967] "Lady Middleton piqued herself upon the elegance of her table, and of"        
##   [968] "all her domestic arrangements; and from this kind of vanity was her"         
##   [969] "greatest enjoyment in any of their parties.  But Sir John's"                 
##   [970] "satisfaction in society was much more real; he delighted in collecting"      
##   [971] "about him more young people than his house would hold, and the noisier"      
##   [972] "they were the better was he pleased.  He was a blessing to all the"          
##   [973] "juvenile part of the neighbourhood, for in summer he was for ever"           
##   [974] "forming parties to eat cold ham and chicken out of doors, and in winter"     
##   [975] "his private balls were numerous enough for any young lady who was not"       
##   [976] "suffering under the unsatiable appetite of fifteen."                         
##   [977] ""                                                                            
##   [978] "The arrival of a new family in the country was always a matter of joy"       
##   [979] "to him, and in every point of view he was charmed with the inhabitants"      
##   [980] "he had now procured for his cottage at Barton.  The Miss Dashwoods were"     
##   [981] "young, pretty, and unaffected.  It was enough to secure his good"            
##   [982] "opinion; for to be unaffected was all that a pretty girl could want to"      
##   [983] "make her mind as captivating as her person.  The friendliness of his"        
##   [984] "disposition made him happy in accommodating those, whose situation"          
##   [985] "might be considered, in comparison with the past, as unfortunate.  In"       
##   [986] "showing kindness to his cousins therefore he had the real satisfaction"      
##   [987] "of a good heart; and in settling a family of females only in his"            
##   [988] "cottage, he had all the satisfaction of a sportsman; for a sportsman,"       
##   [989] "though he esteems only those of his sex who are sportsmen likewise, is"      
##   [990] "not often desirous of encouraging their taste by admitting them to a"        
##   [991] "residence within his own manor."                                             
##   [992] ""                                                                            
##   [993] "Mrs. Dashwood and her daughters were met at the door of the house by"        
##   [994] "Sir John, who welcomed them to Barton Park with unaffected sincerity;"       
##   [995] "and as he attended them to the drawing room repeated to the young"           
##   [996] "ladies the concern which the same subject had drawn from him the day"        
##   [997] "before, at being unable to get any smart young men to meet them.  They"      
##   [998] "would see, he said, only one gentleman there besides himself; a"             
##   [999] "particular friend who was staying at the park, but who was neither very"     
##  [1000] "young nor very gay.  He hoped they would all excuse the smallness of"        
##  [1001] "the party, and could assure them it should never happen so again.  He"       
##  [1002] "had been to several families that morning in hopes of procuring some"        
##  [1003] "addition to their number, but it was moonlight and every body was full"      
##  [1004] "of engagements.  Luckily Lady Middleton's mother had arrived at Barton"      
##  [1005] "within the last hour, and as she was a very cheerful agreeable woman,"       
##  [1006] "he hoped the young ladies would not find it so very dull as they might"      
##  [1007] "imagine.  The young ladies, as well as their mother, were perfectly"         
##  [1008] "satisfied with having two entire strangers of the party, and wished for"     
##  [1009] "no more."                                                                    
##  [1010] ""                                                                            
##  [1011] "Mrs. Jennings, Lady Middleton's mother, was a good-humoured, merry,"         
##  [1012] "fat, elderly woman, who talked a great deal, seemed very happy, and"         
##  [1013] "rather vulgar.  She was full of jokes and laughter, and before dinner"       
##  [1014] "was over had said many witty things on the subject of lovers and"            
##  [1015] "husbands; hoped they had not left their hearts behind them in Sussex,"       
##  [1016] "and pretended to see them blush whether they did or not.  Marianne was"      
##  [1017] "vexed at it for her sister's sake, and turned her eyes towards Elinor"       
##  [1018] "to see how she bore these attacks, with an earnestness which gave"           
##  [1019] "Elinor far more pain than could arise from such common-place raillery"       
##  [1020] "as Mrs. Jennings's."                                                         
##  [1021] ""                                                                            
##  [1022] "Colonel Brandon, the friend of Sir John, seemed no more adapted by"          
##  [1023] "resemblance of manner to be his friend, than Lady Middleton was to be"       
##  [1024] "his wife, or Mrs. Jennings to be Lady Middleton's mother.  He was"           
##  [1025] "silent and grave.  His appearance however was not unpleasing, in spite"      
##  [1026] "of his being in the opinion of Marianne and Margaret an absolute old"        
##  [1027] "bachelor, for he was on the wrong side of five and thirty; but though"       
##  [1028] "his face was not handsome, his countenance was sensible, and his"            
##  [1029] "address was particularly gentlemanlike."                                     
##  [1030] ""                                                                            
##  [1031] "There was nothing in any of the party which could recommend them as"         
##  [1032] "companions to the Dashwoods; but the cold insipidity of Lady Middleton"      
##  [1033] "was so particularly repulsive, that in comparison of it the gravity of"      
##  [1034] "Colonel Brandon, and even the boisterous mirth of Sir John and his"          
##  [1035] "mother-in-law was interesting.  Lady Middleton seemed to be roused to"       
##  [1036] "enjoyment only by the entrance of her four noisy children after dinner,"     
##  [1037] "who pulled her about, tore her clothes, and put an end to every kind of"     
##  [1038] "discourse except what related to themselves."                                
##  [1039] ""                                                                            
##  [1040] "In the evening, as Marianne was discovered to be musical, she was"           
##  [1041] "invited to play.  The instrument was unlocked, every body prepared to"       
##  [1042] "be charmed, and Marianne, who sang very well, at their request went"         
##  [1043] "through the chief of the songs which Lady Middleton had brought into"        
##  [1044] "the family on her marriage, and which perhaps had lain ever since in"        
##  [1045] "the same position on the pianoforte, for her ladyship had celebrated"        
##  [1046] "that event by giving up music, although by her mother's account, she"        
##  [1047] "had played extremely well, and by her own was very fond of it."              
##  [1048] ""                                                                            
##  [1049] "Marianne's performance was highly applauded.  Sir John was loud in his"      
##  [1050] "admiration at the end of every song, and as loud in his conversation"        
##  [1051] "with the others while every song lasted.  Lady Middleton frequently"         
##  [1052] "called him to order, wondered how any one's attention could be diverted"     
##  [1053] "from music for a moment, and asked Marianne to sing a particular song"       
##  [1054] "which Marianne had just finished.  Colonel Brandon alone, of all the"        
##  [1055] "party, heard her without being in raptures.  He paid her only the"           
##  [1056] "compliment of attention; and she felt a respect for him on the"              
##  [1057] "occasion, which the others had reasonably forfeited by their shameless"      
##  [1058] "want of taste.  His pleasure in music, though it amounted not to that"       
##  [1059] "ecstatic delight which alone could sympathize with her own, was"             
##  [1060] "estimable when contrasted against the horrible insensibility of the"         
##  [1061] "others; and she was reasonable enough to allow that a man of five and"       
##  [1062] "thirty might well have outlived all acuteness of feeling and every"          
##  [1063] "exquisite power of enjoyment.  She was perfectly disposed to make every"     
##  [1064] "allowance for the colonel's advanced state of life which humanity"           
##  [1065] "required."                                                                   
##  [1066] ""                                                                            
##  [1067] ""                                                                            
##  [1068] ""                                                                            
##  [1069] "CHAPTER 8"                                                                   
##  [1070] ""                                                                            
##  [1071] ""                                                                            
##  [1072] "Mrs. Jennings was a widow with an ample jointure.  She had only two"         
##  [1073] "daughters, both of whom she had lived to see respectably married, and"       
##  [1074] "she had now therefore nothing to do but to marry all the rest of the"        
##  [1075] "world.  In the promotion of this object she was zealously active, as"        
##  [1076] "far as her ability reached; and missed no opportunity of projecting"         
##  [1077] "weddings among all the young people of her acquaintance.  She was"           
##  [1078] "remarkably quick in the discovery of attachments, and had enjoyed the"       
##  [1079] "advantage of raising the blushes and the vanity of many a young lady by"     
##  [1080] "insinuations of her power over such a young man; and this kind of"           
##  [1081] "discernment enabled her soon after her arrival at Barton decisively to"      
##  [1082] "pronounce that Colonel Brandon was very much in love with Marianne"          
##  [1083] "Dashwood.  She rather suspected it to be so, on the very first evening"      
##  [1084] "of their being together, from his listening so attentively while she"        
##  [1085] "sang to them; and when the visit was returned by the Middletons' dining"     
##  [1086] "at the cottage, the fact was ascertained by his listening to her again."     
##  [1087] "It must be so.  She was perfectly convinced of it.  It would be an"          
##  [1088] "excellent match, for HE was rich, and SHE was handsome.  Mrs. Jennings"      
##  [1089] "had been anxious to see Colonel Brandon well married, ever since her"        
##  [1090] "connection with Sir John first brought him to her knowledge; and she"        
##  [1091] "was always anxious to get a good husband for every pretty girl."             
##  [1092] ""                                                                            
##  [1093] "The immediate advantage to herself was by no means inconsiderable, for"      
##  [1094] "it supplied her with endless jokes against them both.  At the park she"      
##  [1095] "laughed at the colonel, and in the cottage at Marianne.  To the former"      
##  [1096] "her raillery was probably, as far as it regarded only himself,"              
##  [1097] "perfectly indifferent; but to the latter it was at first"                    
##  [1098] "incomprehensible; and when its object was understood, she hardly knew"       
##  [1099] "whether most to laugh at its absurdity, or censure its impertinence,"        
##  [1100] "for she considered it as an unfeeling reflection on the colonel's"           
##  [1101] "advanced years, and on his forlorn condition as an old bachelor."            
##  [1102] ""                                                                            
##  [1103] "Mrs. Dashwood, who could not think a man five years younger than"            
##  [1104] "herself, so exceedingly ancient as he appeared to the youthful fancy of"     
##  [1105] "her daughter, ventured to clear Mrs. Jennings from the probability of"       
##  [1106] "wishing to throw ridicule on his age."                                       
##  [1107] ""                                                                            
##  [1108] "\"But at least, Mama, you cannot deny the absurdity of the accusation,"      
##  [1109] "though you may not think it intentionally ill-natured.  Colonel Brandon"     
##  [1110] "is certainly younger than Mrs. Jennings, but he is old enough to be MY"      
##  [1111] "father; and if he were ever animated enough to be in love, must have"        
##  [1112] "long outlived every sensation of the kind.  It is too ridiculous!  When"     
##  [1113] "is a man to be safe from such wit, if age and infirmity will not"            
##  [1114] "protect him?\""                                                              
##  [1115] ""                                                                            
##  [1116] "\"Infirmity!\" said Elinor, \"do you call Colonel Brandon infirm?  I can"    
##  [1117] "easily suppose that his age may appear much greater to you than to my"       
##  [1118] "mother; but you can hardly deceive yourself as to his having the use of"     
##  [1119] "his limbs!\""                                                                
##  [1120] ""                                                                            
##  [1121] "\"Did not you hear him complain of the rheumatism?  and is not that the"     
##  [1122] "commonest infirmity of declining life?\""                                    
##  [1123] ""                                                                            
##  [1124] "\"My dearest child,\" said her mother, laughing, \"at this rate you must"    
##  [1125] "be in continual terror of MY decay; and it must seem to you a miracle"       
##  [1126] "that my life has been extended to the advanced age of forty.\""              
##  [1127] ""                                                                            
##  [1128] "\"Mama, you are not doing me justice.  I know very well that Colonel"        
##  [1129] "Brandon is not old enough to make his friends yet apprehensive of"           
##  [1130] "losing him in the course of nature.  He may live twenty years longer."       
##  [1131] "But thirty-five has nothing to do with matrimony.\""                         
##  [1132] ""                                                                            
##  [1133] "\"Perhaps,\" said Elinor, \"thirty-five and seventeen had better not have"   
##  [1134] "any thing to do with matrimony together.  But if there should by any"        
##  [1135] "chance happen to be a woman who is single at seven and twenty, I should"     
##  [1136] "not think Colonel Brandon's being thirty-five any objection to his"          
##  [1137] "marrying HER.\""                                                             
##  [1138] ""                                                                            
##  [1139] "\"A woman of seven and twenty,\" said Marianne, after pausing a moment,"     
##  [1140] "\"can never hope to feel or inspire affection again, and if her home be"     
##  [1141] "uncomfortable, or her fortune small, I can suppose that she might bring"     
##  [1142] "herself to submit to the offices of a nurse, for the sake of the"            
##  [1143] "provision and security of a wife.  In his marrying such a woman"             
##  [1144] "therefore there would be nothing unsuitable.  It would be a compact of"      
##  [1145] "convenience, and the world would be satisfied.  In my eyes it would be"      
##  [1146] "no marriage at all, but that would be nothing.  To me it would seem"         
##  [1147] "only a commercial exchange, in which each wished to be benefited at the"     
##  [1148] "expense of the other.\""                                                     
##  [1149] ""                                                                            
##  [1150] "\"It would be impossible, I know,\" replied Elinor, \"to convince you that"  
##  [1151] "a woman of seven and twenty could feel for a man of thirty-five"             
##  [1152] "anything near enough to love, to make him a desirable companion to her."     
##  [1153] "But I must object to your dooming Colonel Brandon and his wife to the"       
##  [1154] "constant confinement of a sick chamber, merely because he chanced to"        
##  [1155] "complain yesterday (a very cold damp day) of a slight rheumatic feel in"     
##  [1156] "one of his shoulders.\""                                                     
##  [1157] ""                                                                            
##  [1158] "\"But he talked of flannel waistcoats,\" said Marianne; \"and with me a"     
##  [1159] "flannel waistcoat is invariably connected with aches, cramps,"               
##  [1160] "rheumatisms, and every species of ailment that can afflict the old and"      
##  [1161] "the feeble.\""                                                               
##  [1162] ""                                                                            
##  [1163] "\"Had he been only in a violent fever, you would not have despised him"      
##  [1164] "half so much.  Confess, Marianne, is not there something interesting to"     
##  [1165] "you in the flushed cheek, hollow eye, and quick pulse of a fever?\""         
##  [1166] ""                                                                            
##  [1167] "Soon after this, upon Elinor's leaving the room, \"Mama,\" said"             
##  [1168] "Marianne, \"I have an alarm on the subject of illness which I cannot"        
##  [1169] "conceal from you.  I am sure Edward Ferrars is not well.  We have now"       
##  [1170] "been here almost a fortnight, and yet he does not come.  Nothing but"        
##  [1171] "real indisposition could occasion this extraordinary delay.  What else"      
##  [1172] "can detain him at Norland?\""                                                
##  [1173] ""                                                                            
##  [1174] "\"Had you any idea of his coming so soon?\" said Mrs. Dashwood.  \"I had"    
##  [1175] "none.  On the contrary, if I have felt any anxiety at all on the"            
##  [1176] "subject, it has been in recollecting that he sometimes showed a want of"     
##  [1177] "pleasure and readiness in accepting my invitation, when I talked of his"     
##  [1178] "coming to Barton.  Does Elinor expect him already?\""                        
##  [1179] ""                                                                            
##  [1180] "\"I have never mentioned it to her, but of course she must.\""               
##  [1181] ""                                                                            
##  [1182] "\"I rather think you are mistaken, for when I was talking to her"            
##  [1183] "yesterday of getting a new grate for the spare bedchamber, she observed"     
##  [1184] "that there was no immediate hurry for it, as it was not likely that the"     
##  [1185] "room would be wanted for some time.\""                                       
##  [1186] ""                                                                            
##  [1187] "\"How strange this is! what can be the meaning of it!  But the whole of"     
##  [1188] "their behaviour to each other has been unaccountable! How cold, how"         
##  [1189] "composed were their last adieus! How languid their conversation the"         
##  [1190] "last evening of their being together! In Edward's farewell there was no"     
##  [1191] "distinction between Elinor and me: it was the good wishes of an"             
##  [1192] "affectionate brother to both.  Twice did I leave them purposely"             
##  [1193] "together in the course of the last morning, and each time did he most"       
##  [1194] "unaccountably follow me out of the room.  And Elinor, in quitting"           
##  [1195] "Norland and Edward, cried not as I did.  Even now her self-command is"       
##  [1196] "invariable.  When is she dejected or melancholy? When does she try to"       
##  [1197] "avoid society, or appear restless and dissatisfied in it?\""                 
##  [1198] ""                                                                            
##  [1199] ""                                                                            
##  [1200] ""                                                                            
##  [1201] "CHAPTER 9"                                                                   
##  [1202] ""                                                                            
##  [1203] ""                                                                            
##  [1204] "The Dashwoods were now settled at Barton with tolerable comfort to"          
##  [1205] "themselves.  The house and the garden, with all the objects surrounding"     
##  [1206] "them, were now become familiar, and the ordinary pursuits which had"         
##  [1207] "given to Norland half its charms were engaged in again with far greater"     
##  [1208] "enjoyment than Norland had been able to afford, since the loss of their"     
##  [1209] "father.  Sir John Middleton, who called on them every day for the first"     
##  [1210] "fortnight, and who was not in the habit of seeing much occupation at"        
##  [1211] "home, could not conceal his amazement on finding them always employed."      
##  [1212] ""                                                                            
##  [1213] "Their visitors, except those from Barton Park, were not many; for, in"       
##  [1214] "spite of Sir John's urgent entreaties that they would mix more in the"       
##  [1215] "neighbourhood, and repeated assurances of his carriage being always at"      
##  [1216] "their service, the independence of Mrs. Dashwood's spirit overcame the"      
##  [1217] "wish of society for her children; and she was resolute in declining to"      
##  [1218] "visit any family beyond the distance of a walk.  There were but few who"     
##  [1219] "could be so classed; and it was not all of them that were attainable."       
##  [1220] "About a mile and a half from the cottage, along the narrow winding"          
##  [1221] "valley of Allenham, which issued from that of Barton, as formerly"           
##  [1222] "described, the girls had, in one of their earliest walks, discovered an"     
##  [1223] "ancient respectable looking mansion which, by reminding them a little"       
##  [1224] "of Norland, interested their imagination and made them wish to be"           
##  [1225] "better acquainted with it.  But they learnt, on enquiry, that its"           
##  [1226] "possessor, an elderly lady of very good character, was unfortunately"        
##  [1227] "too infirm to mix with the world, and never stirred from home."              
##  [1228] ""                                                                            
##  [1229] "The whole country about them abounded in beautiful walks.  The high"         
##  [1230] "downs which invited them from almost every window of the cottage to"         
##  [1231] "seek the exquisite enjoyment of air on their summits, were a happy"          
##  [1232] "alternative when the dirt of the valleys beneath shut up their superior"     
##  [1233] "beauties; and towards one of these hills did Marianne and Margaret one"      
##  [1234] "memorable morning direct their steps, attracted by the partial sunshine"     
##  [1235] "of a showery sky, and unable longer to bear the confinement which the"       
##  [1236] "settled rain of the two preceding days had occasioned.  The weather was"     
##  [1237] "not tempting enough to draw the two others from their pencil and their"      
##  [1238] "book, in spite of Marianne's declaration that the day would be"              
##  [1239] "lastingly fair, and that every threatening cloud would be drawn off"         
##  [1240] "from their hills; and the two girls set off together."                       
##  [1241] ""                                                                            
##  [1242] "They gaily ascended the downs, rejoicing in their own penetration at"        
##  [1243] "every glimpse of blue sky; and when they caught in their faces the"          
##  [1244] "animating gales of a high south-westerly wind, they pitied the fears"        
##  [1245] "which had prevented their mother and Elinor from sharing such"               
##  [1246] "delightful sensations."                                                      
##  [1247] ""                                                                            
##  [1248] "\"Is there a felicity in the world,\" said Marianne, \"superior to"          
##  [1249] "this?--Margaret, we will walk here at least two hours.\""                    
##  [1250] ""                                                                            
##  [1251] "Margaret agreed, and they pursued their way against the wind, resisting"     
##  [1252] "it with laughing delight for about twenty minutes longer, when suddenly"     
##  [1253] "the clouds united over their heads, and a driving rain set full in"          
##  [1254] "their face.-- Chagrined and surprised, they were obliged, though"            
##  [1255] "unwillingly, to turn back, for no shelter was nearer than their own"         
##  [1256] "house.  One consolation however remained for them, to which the"             
##  [1257] "exigence of the moment gave more than usual propriety; it was that of"       
##  [1258] "running with all possible speed down the steep side of the hill which"       
##  [1259] "led immediately to their garden gate."                                       
##  [1260] ""                                                                            
##  [1261] "They set off.  Marianne had at first the advantage, but a false step"        
##  [1262] "brought her suddenly to the ground; and Margaret, unable to stop"            
##  [1263] "herself to assist her, was involuntarily hurried along, and reached the"     
##  [1264] "bottom in safety."                                                           
##  [1265] ""                                                                            
##  [1266] "A gentleman carrying a gun, with two pointers playing round him, was"        
##  [1267] "passing up the hill and within a few yards of Marianne, when her"            
##  [1268] "accident happened.  He put down his gun and ran to her assistance.  She"     
##  [1269] "had raised herself from the ground, but her foot had been twisted in"        
##  [1270] "her fall, and she was scarcely able to stand.  The gentleman offered"        
##  [1271] "his services; and perceiving that her modesty declined what her"             
##  [1272] "situation rendered necessary, took her up in his arms without farther"       
##  [1273] "delay, and carried her down the hill.  Then passing through the garden,"     
##  [1274] "the gate of which had been left open by Margaret, he bore her directly"      
##  [1275] "into the house, whither Margaret was just arrived, and quitted not his"      
##  [1276] "hold till he had seated her in a chair in the parlour."                      
##  [1277] ""                                                                            
##  [1278] "Elinor and her mother rose up in amazement at their entrance, and while"     
##  [1279] "the eyes of both were fixed on him with an evident wonder and a secret"      
##  [1280] "admiration which equally sprung from his appearance, he apologized for"      
##  [1281] "his intrusion by relating its cause, in a manner so frank and so"            
##  [1282] "graceful that his person, which was uncommonly handsome, received"           
##  [1283] "additional charms from his voice and expression.  Had he been even old,"     
##  [1284] "ugly, and vulgar, the gratitude and kindness of Mrs. Dashwood would"         
##  [1285] "have been secured by any act of attention to her child; but the"             
##  [1286] "influence of youth, beauty, and elegance, gave an interest to the"           
##  [1287] "action which came home to her feelings."                                     
##  [1288] ""                                                                            
##  [1289] "She thanked him again and again; and, with a sweetness of address which"     
##  [1290] "always attended her, invited him to be seated.  But this he declined,"       
##  [1291] "as he was dirty and wet.  Mrs. Dashwood then begged to know to whom she"     
##  [1292] "was obliged.  His name, he replied, was Willoughby, and his present"         
##  [1293] "home was at Allenham, from whence he hoped she would allow him the"          
##  [1294] "honour of calling tomorrow to enquire after Miss Dashwood.  The honour"      
##  [1295] "was readily granted, and he then departed, to make himself still more"       
##  [1296] "interesting, in the midst of a heavy rain."                                  
##  [1297] ""                                                                            
##  [1298] "His manly beauty and more than common gracefulness were instantly the"       
##  [1299] "theme of general admiration, and the laugh which his gallantry raised"       
##  [1300] "against Marianne received particular spirit from his exterior"               
##  [1301] "attractions.-- Marianne herself had seen less of his Mama the"               
##  [1302] "rest, for the confusion which crimsoned over her face, on his lifting"       
##  [1303] "her up, had robbed her of the power of regarding him after their"            
##  [1304] "entering the house.  But she had seen enough of him to join in all the"      
##  [1305] "admiration of the others, and with an energy which always adorned her"       
##  [1306] "praise.  His person and air were equal to what her fancy had ever drawn"     
##  [1307] "for the hero of a favourite story; and in his carrying her into the"         
##  [1308] "house with so little previous formality, there was a rapidity of"            
##  [1309] "thought which particularly recommended the action to her.  Every"            
##  [1310] "circumstance belonging to him was interesting.  His name was good, his"      
##  [1311] "residence was in their favourite village, and she soon found out that"       
##  [1312] "of all manly dresses a shooting-jacket was the most becoming.  Her"          
##  [1313] "imagination was busy, her reflections were pleasant, and the pain of a"      
##  [1314] "sprained ankle was disregarded."                                             
##  [1315] ""                                                                            
##  [1316] "Sir John called on them as soon as the next interval of fair weather"        
##  [1317] "that morning allowed him to get out of doors; and Marianne's accident"       
##  [1318] "being related to him, he was eagerly asked whether he knew any"              
##  [1319] "gentleman of the name of Willoughby at Allenham."                            
##  [1320] ""                                                                            
##  [1321] "\"Willoughby!\" cried Sir John; \"what, is HE in the country? That is good"  
##  [1322] "news however; I will ride over tomorrow, and ask him to dinner on"           
##  [1323] "Thursday.\""                                                                 
##  [1324] ""                                                                            
##  [1325] "\"You know him then,\" said Mrs. Dashwood."                                  
##  [1326] ""                                                                            
##  [1327] "\"Know him! to be sure I do.  Why, he is down here every year.\""            
##  [1328] ""                                                                            
##  [1329] "\"And what sort of a young man is he?\""                                     
##  [1330] ""                                                                            
##  [1331] "\"As good a kind of fellow as ever lived, I assure you.  A very decent"      
##  [1332] "shot, and there is not a bolder rider in England.\""                         
##  [1333] ""                                                                            
##  [1334] "\"And is that all you can say for him?\" cried Marianne, indignantly."       
##  [1335] "\"But what are his manners on more intimate acquaintance? What his"          
##  [1336] "pursuits, his talents, and genius?\""                                        
##  [1337] ""                                                                            
##  [1338] "Sir John was rather puzzled."                                                
##  [1339] ""                                                                            
##  [1340] "\"Upon my soul,\" said he, \"I do not know much about him as to all THAT."   
##  [1341] "But he is a pleasant, good humoured fellow, and has got the nicest"          
##  [1342] "little black bitch of a pointer I ever saw.  Was she out with him"           
##  [1343] "today?\""                                                                    
##  [1344] ""                                                                            
##  [1345] "But Marianne could no more satisfy him as to the colour of Mr."              
##  [1346] "Willoughby's pointer, than he could describe to her the shades of his"       
##  [1347] "mind."                                                                       
##  [1348] ""                                                                            
##  [1349] "\"But who is he?\" said Elinor.  \"Where does he come from?  Has he a"       
##  [1350] "house at Allenham?\""                                                        
##  [1351] ""                                                                            
##  [1352] "On this point Sir John could give more certain intelligence; and he"         
##  [1353] "told them that Mr. Willoughby had no property of his own in the"             
##  [1354] "country; that he resided there only while he was visiting the old lady"      
##  [1355] "at Allenham Court, to whom he was related, and whose possessions he was"     
##  [1356] "to inherit; adding, \"Yes, yes, he is very well worth catching I can"        
##  [1357] "tell you, Miss Dashwood; he has a pretty little estate of his own in"        
##  [1358] "Somersetshire besides; and if I were you, I would not give him up to my"     
##  [1359] "younger sister, in spite of all this tumbling down hills.  Miss"             
##  [1360] "Marianne must not expect to have all the men to herself.  Brandon will"      
##  [1361] "be jealous, if she does not take care.\""                                    
##  [1362] ""                                                                            
##  [1363] "\"I do not believe,\" said Mrs. Dashwood, with a good humoured smile,"       
##  [1364] "\"that Mr. Willoughby will be incommoded by the attempts of either of MY"    
##  [1365] "daughters towards what you call CATCHING him.  It is not an employment"      
##  [1366] "to which they have been brought up.  Men are very safe with us, let"         
##  [1367] "them be ever so rich.  I am glad to find, however, from what you say,"       
##  [1368] "that he is a respectable young man, and one whose acquaintance will not"     
##  [1369] "be ineligible.\""                                                            
##  [1370] ""                                                                            
##  [1371] "\"He is as good a sort of fellow, I believe, as ever lived,\" repeated"      
##  [1372] "Sir John.  \"I remember last Christmas at a little hop at the park, he"      
##  [1373] "danced from eight o'clock till four, without once sitting down.\""           
##  [1374] ""                                                                            
##  [1375] "\"Did he indeed?\" cried Marianne with sparkling eyes, \"and with"           
##  [1376] "elegance, with spirit?\""                                                    
##  [1377] ""                                                                            
##  [1378] "\"Yes; and he was up again at eight to ride to covert.\""                    
##  [1379] ""                                                                            
##  [1380] "\"That is what I like; that is what a young man ought to be.  Whatever"      
##  [1381] "be his pursuits, his eagerness in them should know no moderation, and"       
##  [1382] "leave him no sense of fatigue.\""                                            
##  [1383] ""                                                                            
##  [1384] "\"Aye, aye, I see how it will be,\" said Sir John, \"I see how it will be."  
##  [1385] "You will be setting your cap at him now, and never think of poor"            
##  [1386] "Brandon.\""                                                                  
##  [1387] ""                                                                            
##  [1388] "\"That is an expression, Sir John,\" said Marianne, warmly, \"which I"       
##  [1389] "particularly dislike.  I abhor every common-place phrase by which wit"       
##  [1390] "is intended; and 'setting one's cap at a man,' or 'making a conquest,'"      
##  [1391] "are the most odious of all.  Their tendency is gross and illiberal; and"     
##  [1392] "if their construction could ever be deemed clever, time has long ago"        
##  [1393] "destroyed all its ingenuity.\""                                              
##  [1394] ""                                                                            
##  [1395] "Sir John did not much understand this reproof; but he laughed as"            
##  [1396] "heartily as if he did, and then replied,"                                    
##  [1397] ""                                                                            
##  [1398] "\"Ay, you will make conquests enough, I dare say, one way or other."         
##  [1399] "Poor Brandon! he is quite smitten already, and he is very well worth"        
##  [1400] "setting your cap at, I can tell you, in spite of all this tumbling"          
##  [1401] "about and spraining of ankles.\""                                            
##  [1402] ""                                                                            
##  [1403] ""                                                                            
##  [1404] ""                                                                            
##  [1405] "CHAPTER 10"                                                                  
##  [1406] ""                                                                            
##  [1407] ""                                                                            
##  [1408] "Marianne's preserver, as Margaret, with more elegance than precision,"       
##  [1409] "styled Willoughby, called at the cottage early the next morning to make"     
##  [1410] "his personal enquiries.  He was received by Mrs. Dashwood with more"         
##  [1411] "than politeness; with a kindness which Sir John's account of him and"        
##  [1412] "her own gratitude prompted; and every thing that passed during the"          
##  [1413] "visit tended to assure him of the sense, elegance, mutual affection,"        
##  [1414] "and domestic comfort of the family to whom accident had now introduced"      
##  [1415] "him.  Of their personal charms he had not required a second interview"       
##  [1416] "to be convinced."                                                            
##  [1417] ""                                                                            
##  [1418] "Miss Dashwood had a delicate complexion, regular features, and a"            
##  [1419] "remarkably pretty figure.  Marianne was still handsomer.  Her form,"         
##  [1420] "though not so correct as her sister's, in having the advantage of"           
##  [1421] "height, was more striking; and her face was so lovely, that when in the"     
##  [1422] "common cant of praise, she was called a beautiful girl, truth was less"      
##  [1423] "violently outraged than usually happens.  Her skin was very brown, but,"     
##  [1424] "from its transparency, her complexion was uncommonly brilliant; her"         
##  [1425] "features were all good; her smile was sweet and attractive; and in her"      
##  [1426] "eyes, which were very dark, there was a life, a spirit, an eagerness,"       
##  [1427] "which could hardily be seen without delight.  From Willoughby their"         
##  [1428] "expression was at first held back, by the embarrassment which the"           
##  [1429] "remembrance of his assistance created.  But when this passed away, when"     
##  [1430] "her spirits became collected, when she saw that to the perfect"              
##  [1431] "good-breeding of the gentleman, he united frankness and vivacity, and"       
##  [1432] "above all, when she heard him declare, that of music and dancing he was"     
##  [1433] "passionately fond, she gave him such a look of approbation as secured"       
##  [1434] "the largest share of his discourse to herself for the rest of his stay."     
##  [1435] ""                                                                            
##  [1436] "It was only necessary to mention any favourite amusement to engage her"      
##  [1437] "to talk.  She could not be silent when such points were introduced, and"     
##  [1438] "she had neither shyness nor reserve in their discussion.  They speedily"     
##  [1439] "discovered that their enjoyment of dancing and music was mutual, and"        
##  [1440] "that it arose from a general conformity of judgment in all that related"     
##  [1441] "to either.  Encouraged by this to a further examination of his"              
##  [1442] "opinions, she proceeded to question him on the subject of books; her"        
##  [1443] "favourite authors were brought forward and dwelt upon with so rapturous"     
##  [1444] "a delight, that any young man of five and twenty must have been"             
##  [1445] "insensible indeed, not to become an immediate convert to the excellence"     
##  [1446] "of such works, however disregarded before.  Their taste was strikingly"      
##  [1447] "alike.  The same books, the same passages were idolized by each--or if"      
##  [1448] "any difference appeared, any objection arose, it lasted no longer than"      
##  [1449] "till the force of her arguments and the brightness of her eyes could be"     
##  [1450] "displayed.  He acquiesced in all her decisions, caught all her"              
##  [1451] "enthusiasm; and long before his visit concluded, they conversed with"        
##  [1452] "the familiarity of a long-established acquaintance."                         
##  [1453] ""                                                                            
##  [1454] "\"Well, Marianne,\" said Elinor, as soon as he had left them, \"for ONE"     
##  [1455] "morning I think you have done pretty well.  You have already"                
##  [1456] "ascertained Mr. Willoughby's opinion in almost every matter of"              
##  [1457] "importance.  You know what he thinks of Cowper and Scott; you are"           
##  [1458] "certain of his estimating their beauties as he ought, and you have"          
##  [1459] "received every assurance of his admiring Pope no more than is proper."       
##  [1460] "But how is your acquaintance to be long supported, under such"               
##  [1461] "extraordinary despatch of every subject for discourse?  You will soon"       
##  [1462] "have exhausted each favourite topic.  Another meeting will suffice to"       
##  [1463] "explain his sentiments on picturesque beauty, and second marriages, and"     
##  [1464] "then you can have nothing farther to ask.\"--"                               
##  [1465] ""                                                                            
##  [1466] "\"Elinor,\" cried Marianne, \"is this fair? is this just? are my ideas so"   
##  [1467] "scanty?  But I see what you mean.  I have been too much at my ease, too"     
##  [1468] "happy, too frank.  I have erred against every common-place notion of"        
##  [1469] "decorum; I have been open and sincere where I ought to have been"            
##  [1470] "reserved, spiritless, dull, and deceitful--had I talked only of the"         
##  [1471] "weather and the roads, and had I spoken only once in ten minutes, this"      
##  [1472] "reproach would have been spared.\""                                          
##  [1473] ""                                                                            
##  [1474] "\"My love,\" said her mother, \"you must not be offended with Elinor--she"
