##  [1475] "was only in jest.  I should scold her myself, if she were capable of"        
##  [1476] "wishing to check the delight of your conversation with our new"              
##  [1477] "friend.\"-- Marianne was softened in a moment."                              
##  [1478] ""                                                                            
##  [1479] "Willoughby, on his side, gave every proof of his pleasure in their"          
##  [1480] "acquaintance, which an evident wish of improving it could offer.  He"        
##  [1481] "came to them every day.  To enquire after Marianne was at first his"         
##  [1482] "excuse; but the encouragement of his reception, to which every day gave"     
##  [1483] "greater kindness, made such an excuse unnecessary before it had ceased"      
##  [1484] "to be possible, by Marianne's perfect recovery.  She was confined for"       
##  [1485] "some days to the house; but never had any confinement been less"             
##  [1486] "irksome.  Willoughby was a young man of good abilities, quick"               
##  [1487] "imagination, lively spirits, and open, affectionate manners.  He was"        
##  [1488] "exactly formed to engage Marianne's heart, for with all this, he joined"     
##  [1489] "not only a captivating person, but a natural ardour of mind which was"       
##  [1490] "now roused and increased by the example of her own, and which"               
##  [1491] "recommended him to her affection beyond every thing else."                   
##  [1492] ""                                                                            
##  [1493] "His society became gradually her most exquisite enjoyment.  They read,"      
##  [1494] "they talked, they sang together; his musical talents were considerable;"     
##  [1495] "and he read with all the sensibility and spirit which Edward had"            
##  [1496] "unfortunately wanted."                                                       
##  [1497] ""                                                                            
##  [1498] "In Mrs. Dashwood's estimation he was as faultless as in Marianne's; and"     
##  [1499] "Elinor saw nothing to censure in him but a propensity, in which he"          
##  [1500] "strongly resembled and peculiarly delighted her sister, of saying too"       
##  [1501] "much what he thought on every occasion, without attention to persons or"     
##  [1502] "circumstances.  In hastily forming and giving his opinion of other"          
##  [1503] "people, in sacrificing general politeness to the enjoyment of undivided"     
##  [1504] "attention where his heart was engaged, and in slighting too easily the"      
##  [1505] "forms of worldly propriety, he displayed a want of caution which Elinor"     
##  [1506] "could not approve, in spite of all that he and Marianne could say in"        
##  [1507] "its support."                                                                
##  [1508] ""                                                                            
##  [1509] "Marianne began now to perceive that the desperation which had seized"        
##  [1510] "her at sixteen and a half, of ever seeing a man who could satisfy her"       
##  [1511] "ideas of perfection, had been rash and unjustifiable.  Willoughby was"       
##  [1512] "all that her fancy had delineated in that unhappy hour and in every"         
##  [1513] "brighter period, as capable of attaching her; and his behaviour"             
##  [1514] "declared his wishes to be in that respect as earnest, as his abilities"      
##  [1515] "were strong."                                                                
##  [1516] ""                                                                            
##  [1517] "Her mother too, in whose mind not one speculative thought of their"          
##  [1518] "marriage had been raised, by his prospect of riches, was led before the"     
##  [1519] "end of a week to hope and expect it; and secretly to congratulate"           
##  [1520] "herself on having gained two such sons-in-law as Edward and Willoughby."     
##  [1521] ""                                                                            
##  [1522] "Colonel Brandon's partiality for Marianne, which had so early been"          
##  [1523] "discovered by his friends, now first became perceptible to Elinor, when"     
##  [1524] "it ceased to be noticed by them.  Their attention and wit were drawn"        
##  [1525] "off to his more fortunate rival; and the raillery which the other had"       
##  [1526] "incurred before any partiality arose, was removed when his feelings"         
##  [1527] "began really to call for the ridicule so justly annexed to sensibility."     
##  [1528] "Elinor was obliged, though unwillingly, to believe that the sentiments"      
##  [1529] "which Mrs. Jennings had assigned him for her own satisfaction, were now"     
##  [1530] "actually excited by her sister; and that however a general resemblance"      
##  [1531] "of disposition between the parties might forward the affection of Mr."       
##  [1532] "Willoughby, an equally striking opposition of character was no"              
##  [1533] "hindrance to the regard of Colonel Brandon.  She saw it with concern;"       
##  [1534] "for what could a silent man of five and thirty hope, when opposed to a"      
##  [1535] "very lively one of five and twenty? and as she could not even wish him"      
##  [1536] "successful, she heartily wished him indifferent.  She liked him--in"         
##  [1537] "spite of his gravity and reserve, she beheld in him an object of"            
##  [1538] "interest.  His manners, though serious, were mild; and his reserve"          
##  [1539] "appeared rather the result of some oppression of spirits than of any"        
##  [1540] "natural gloominess of temper.  Sir John had dropped hints of past"           
##  [1541] "injuries and disappointments, which justified her belief of his being"       
##  [1542] "an unfortunate man, and she regarded him with respect and compassion."       
##  [1543] ""                                                                            
##  [1544] "Perhaps she pitied and esteemed him the more because he was slighted by"     
##  [1545] "Willoughby and Marianne, who, prejudiced against him for being neither"      
##  [1546] "lively nor young, seemed resolved to undervalue his merits."                 
##  [1547] ""                                                                            
##  [1548] "\"Brandon is just the kind of man,\" said Willoughby one day, when they"     
##  [1549] "were talking of him together, \"whom every body speaks well of, and"         
##  [1550] "nobody cares about; whom all are delighted to see, and nobody remembers"     
##  [1551] "to talk to.\""                                                               
##  [1552] ""                                                                            
##  [1553] "\"That is exactly what I think of him,\" cried Marianne."                    
##  [1554] ""                                                                            
##  [1555] "\"Do not boast of it, however,\" said Elinor, \"for it is injustice in"      
##  [1556] "both of you.  He is highly esteemed by all the family at the park, and"      
##  [1557] "I never see him myself without taking pains to converse with him.\""         
##  [1558] ""                                                                            
##  [1559] "\"That he is patronised by YOU,\" replied Willoughby, \"is certainly in"     
##  [1560] "his favour; but as for the esteem of the others, it is a reproach in"        
##  [1561] "itself.  Who would submit to the indignity of being approved by such a"      
##  [1562] "woman as Lady Middleton and Mrs. Jennings, that could command the"           
##  [1563] "indifference of any body else?\""                                            
##  [1564] ""                                                                            
##  [1565] "\"But perhaps the abuse of such people as yourself and Marianne will"        
##  [1566] "make amends for the regard of Lady Middleton and her mother.  If their"      
##  [1567] "praise is censure, your censure may be praise, for they are not more"        
##  [1568] "undiscerning, than you are prejudiced and unjust.\""                         
##  [1569] ""                                                                            
##  [1570] "\"In defence of your protege you can even be saucy.\""                       
##  [1571] ""                                                                            
##  [1572] "\"My protege, as you call him, is a sensible man; and sense will always"     
##  [1573] "have attractions for me.  Yes, Marianne, even in a man between thirty"       
##  [1574] "and forty.  He has seen a great deal of the world; has been abroad, has"     
##  [1575] "read, and has a thinking mind.  I have found him capable of giving me"       
##  [1576] "much information on various subjects; and he has always answered my"         
##  [1577] "inquiries with readiness of good-breeding and good nature.\""                
##  [1578] ""                                                                            
##  [1579] "\"That is to say,\" cried Marianne contemptuously, \"he has told you, that"  
##  [1580] "in the East Indies the climate is hot, and the mosquitoes are"               
##  [1581] "troublesome.\""                                                              
##  [1582] ""                                                                            
##  [1583] "\"He WOULD have told me so, I doubt not, had I made any such inquiries,"     
##  [1584] "but they happened to be points on which I had been previously informed.\""   
##  [1585] ""                                                                            
##  [1586] "\"Perhaps,\" said Willoughby, \"his observations may have extended to the"   
##  [1587] "existence of nabobs, gold mohrs, and palanquins.\""                          
##  [1588] ""                                                                            
##  [1589] "\"I may venture to say that HIS observations have stretched much further"    
##  [1590] "than your candour.  But why should you dislike him?\""                       
##  [1591] ""                                                                            
##  [1592] "\"I do not dislike him.  I consider him, on the contrary, as a very"         
##  [1593] "respectable man, who has every body's good word, and nobody's notice;"       
##  [1594] "who, has more money than he can spend, more time than he knows how to"       
##  [1595] "employ, and two new coats every year.\""                                     
##  [1596] ""                                                                            
##  [1597] "\"Add to which,\" cried Marianne, \"that he has neither genius, taste, nor"  
##  [1598] "spirit.  That his understanding has no brilliancy, his feelings no"          
##  [1599] "ardour, and his voice no expression.\""                                      
##  [1600] ""                                                                            
##  [1601] "\"You decide on his imperfections so much in the mass,\" replied Elinor,"    
##  [1602] "\"and so much on the strength of your own imagination, that the"             
##  [1603] "commendation I am able to give of him is comparatively cold and"             
##  [1604] "insipid.  I can only pronounce him to be a sensible man, well-bred,"         
##  [1605] "well-informed, of gentle address, and, I believe, possessing an amiable"     
##  [1606] "heart.\""                                                                    
##  [1607] ""                                                                            
##  [1608] "\"Miss Dashwood,\" cried Willoughby, \"you are now using me unkindly.  You"  
##  [1609] "are endeavouring to disarm me by reason, and to convince me against my"      
##  [1610] "will.  But it will not do.  You shall find me as stubborn as you can be"     
##  [1611] "artful.  I have three unanswerable reasons for disliking Colonel"            
##  [1612] "Brandon; he threatened me with rain when I wanted it to be fine; he has"     
##  [1613] "found fault with the hanging of my curricle, and I cannot persuade him"      
##  [1614] "to buy my brown mare.  If it will be any satisfaction to you, however,"      
##  [1615] "to be told, that I believe his character to be in other respects"            
##  [1616] "irreproachable, I am ready to confess it.  And in return for an"             
##  [1617] "acknowledgment, which must give me some pain, you cannot deny me the"        
##  [1618] "privilege of disliking him as much as ever.\""                               
##  [1619] ""                                                                            
##  [1620] ""                                                                            
##  [1621] ""                                                                            
##  [1622] "CHAPTER 11"                                                                  
##  [1623] ""                                                                            
##  [1624] ""                                                                            
##  [1625] "Little had Mrs. Dashwood or her daughters imagined when they first came"     
##  [1626] "into Devonshire, that so many engagements would arise to occupy their"       
##  [1627] "time as shortly presented themselves, or that they should have such"         
##  [1628] "frequent invitations and such constant visitors as to leave them little"     
##  [1629] "leisure for serious employment.  Yet such was the case.  When Marianne"      
##  [1630] "was recovered, the schemes of amusement at home and abroad, which Sir"       
##  [1631] "John had been previously forming, were put into execution.  The private"     
##  [1632] "balls at the park then began; and parties on the water were made and"        
##  [1633] "accomplished as often as a showery October would allow.  In every"           
##  [1634] "meeting of the kind Willoughby was included; and the ease and"               
##  [1635] "familiarity which naturally attended these parties were exactly"             
##  [1636] "calculated to give increasing intimacy to his acquaintance with the"         
##  [1637] "Dashwoods, to afford him opportunity of witnessing the excellencies of"      
##  [1638] "Marianne, of marking his animated admiration of her, and of receiving,"      
##  [1639] "in her behaviour to himself, the most pointed assurance of her"              
##  [1640] "affection."                                                                  
##  [1641] ""                                                                            
##  [1642] "Elinor could not be surprised at their attachment.  She only wished"         
##  [1643] "that it were less openly shewn; and once or twice did venture to"            
##  [1644] "suggest the propriety of some self-command to Marianne.  But Marianne"       
##  [1645] "abhorred all concealment where no real disgrace could attend unreserve;"     
##  [1646] "and to aim at the restraint of sentiments which were not in themselves"      
##  [1647] "illaudable, appeared to her not merely an unnecessary effort, but a"         
##  [1648] "disgraceful subjection of reason to common-place and mistaken notions."      
##  [1649] "Willoughby thought the same; and their behaviour at all times, was an"       
##  [1650] "illustration of their opinions."                                             
##  [1651] ""                                                                            
##  [1652] "When he was present she had no eyes for any one else.  Every thing he"       
##  [1653] "did, was right.  Every thing he said, was clever.  If their evenings at"     
##  [1654] "the park were concluded with cards, he cheated himself and all the rest"     
##  [1655] "of the party to get her a good hand.  If dancing formed the amusement"       
##  [1656] "of the night, they were partners for half the time; and when obliged to"     
##  [1657] "separate for a couple of dances, were careful to stand together and"         
##  [1658] "scarcely spoke a word to any body else.  Such conduct made them of"          
##  [1659] "course most exceedingly laughed at; but ridicule could not shame, and"       
##  [1660] "seemed hardly to provoke them."                                              
##  [1661] ""                                                                            
##  [1662] "Mrs. Dashwood entered into all their feelings with a warmth which left"      
##  [1663] "her no inclination for checking this excessive display of them.  To her"     
##  [1664] "it was but the natural consequence of a strong affection in a young and"     
##  [1665] "ardent mind."                                                                
##  [1666] ""                                                                            
##  [1667] "This was the season of happiness to Marianne.  Her heart was devoted to"     
##  [1668] "Willoughby, and the fond attachment to Norland, which she brought with"      
##  [1669] "her from Sussex, was more likely to be softened than she had thought it"     
##  [1670] "possible before, by the charms which his society bestowed on her"            
##  [1671] "present home."                                                               
##  [1672] ""                                                                            
##  [1673] "Elinor's happiness was not so great.  Her heart was not so much at"          
##  [1674] "ease, nor her satisfaction in their amusements so pure.  They afforded"      
##  [1675] "her no companion that could make amends for what she had left behind,"       
##  [1676] "nor that could teach her to think of Norland with less regret than"          
##  [1677] "ever.  Neither Lady Middleton nor Mrs. Jennings could supply to her the"     
##  [1678] "conversation she missed; although the latter was an everlasting talker,"     
##  [1679] "and from the first had regarded her with a kindness which ensured her a"     
##  [1680] "large share of her discourse.  She had already repeated her own history"     
##  [1681] "to Elinor three or four times; and had Elinor's memory been equal to"        
##  [1682] "her means of improvement, she might have known very early in their"          
##  [1683] "acquaintance all the particulars of Mr. Jennings's last illness, and"        
##  [1684] "what he said to his wife a few minutes before he died.  Lady Middleton"      
##  [1685] "was more agreeable than her mother only in being more silent.  Elinor"       
##  [1686] "needed little observation to perceive that her reserve was a mere"           
##  [1687] "calmness of manner with which sense had nothing to do.  Towards her"         
##  [1688] "husband and mother she was the same as to them; and intimacy was"            
##  [1689] "therefore neither to be looked for nor desired.  She had nothing to say"     
##  [1690] "one day that she had not said the day before.  Her insipidity was"           
##  [1691] "invariable, for even her spirits were always the same; and though she"       
##  [1692] "did not oppose the parties arranged by her husband, provided every"          
##  [1693] "thing were conducted in style and her two eldest children attended her,"     
##  [1694] "she never appeared to receive more enjoyment from them than she might"       
##  [1695] "have experienced in sitting at home;--and so little did her presence"        
##  [1696] "add to the pleasure of the others, by any share in their conversation,"      
##  [1697] "that they were sometimes only reminded of her being amongst them by her"     
##  [1698] "solicitude about her troublesome boys."                                      
##  [1699] ""                                                                            
##  [1700] "In Colonel Brandon alone, of all her new acquaintance, did Elinor find"      
##  [1701] "a person who could in any degree claim the respect of abilities, excite"     
##  [1702] "the interest of friendship, or give pleasure as a companion."                
##  [1703] "Willoughby was out of the question.  Her admiration and regard, even"        
##  [1704] "her sisterly regard, was all his own; but he was a lover; his"               
##  [1705] "attentions were wholly Marianne's, and a far less agreeable man might"       
##  [1706] "have been more generally pleasing.  Colonel Brandon, unfortunately for"      
##  [1707] "himself, had no such encouragement to think only of Marianne, and in"        
##  [1708] "conversing with Elinor he found the greatest consolation for the"            
##  [1709] "indifference of her sister."                                                 
##  [1710] ""                                                                            
##  [1711] "Elinor's compassion for him increased, as she had reason to suspect"         
##  [1712] "that the misery of disappointed love had already been known to him."         
##  [1713] "This suspicion was given by some words which accidentally dropped from"      
##  [1714] "him one evening at the park, when they were sitting down together by"        
##  [1715] "mutual consent, while the others were dancing.  His eyes were fixed on"      
##  [1716] "Marianne, and, after a silence of some minutes, he said, with a faint"       
##  [1717] "smile, \"Your sister, I understand, does not approve of second"              
##  [1718] "attachments.\""                                                              
##  [1719] ""                                                                            
##  [1720] "\"No,\" replied Elinor, \"her opinions are all romantic.\""                  
##  [1721] ""                                                                            
##  [1722] "\"Or rather, as I believe, she considers them impossible to exist.\""        
##  [1723] ""                                                                            
##  [1724] "\"I believe she does.  But how she contrives it without reflecting on"       
##  [1725] "the character of her own father, who had himself two wives, I know not."     
##  [1726] "A few years however will settle her opinions on the reasonable basis of"     
##  [1727] "common sense and observation; and then they may be more easy to define"      
##  [1728] "and to justify than they now are, by any body but herself.\""                
##  [1729] ""                                                                            
##  [1730] "\"This will probably be the case,\" he replied; \"and yet there is"          
##  [1731] "something so amiable in the prejudices of a young mind, that one is"         
##  [1732] "sorry to see them give way to the reception of more general opinions.\""     
##  [1733] ""                                                                            
##  [1734] "\"I cannot agree with you there,\" said Elinor.  \"There are"                
##  [1735] "inconveniences attending such feelings as Marianne's, which all the"         
##  [1736] "charms of enthusiasm and ignorance of the world cannot atone for.  Her"      
##  [1737] "systems have all the unfortunate tendency of setting propriety at"           
##  [1738] "nought; and a better acquaintance with the world is what I look forward"     
##  [1739] "to as her greatest possible advantage.\""                                    
##  [1740] ""                                                                            
##  [1741] "After a short pause he resumed the conversation by saying,--"                
##  [1742] ""                                                                            
##  [1743] "\"Does your sister make no distinction in her objections against a"          
##  [1744] "second attachment? or is it equally criminal in every body?  Are those"      
##  [1745] "who have been disappointed in their first choice, whether from the"          
##  [1746] "inconstancy of its object, or the perverseness of circumstances, to be"      
##  [1747] "equally indifferent during the rest of their lives?\""                       
##  [1748] ""                                                                            
##  [1749] "\"Upon my word, I am not acquainted with the minutiae of her principles."    
##  [1750] "I only know that I never yet heard her admit any instance of a second"       
##  [1751] "attachment's being pardonable.\""                                            
##  [1752] ""                                                                            
##  [1753] "\"This,\" said he, \"cannot hold; but a change, a total change of"           
##  [1754] "sentiments--No, no, do not desire it; for when the romantic refinements"     
##  [1755] "of a young mind are obliged to give way, how frequently are they"            
##  [1756] "succeeded by such opinions as are but too common, and too dangerous!  I"     
##  [1757] "speak from experience.  I once knew a lady who in temper and mind"           
##  [1758] "greatly resembled your sister, who thought and judged like her, but who"     
##  [1759] "from an inforced change--from a series of unfortunate circumstances\"--"     
##  [1760] "Here he stopt suddenly; appeared to think that he had said too much,"        
##  [1761] "and by his countenance gave rise to conjectures, which might not"            
##  [1762] "otherwise have entered Elinor's head.  The lady would probably have"         
##  [1763] "passed without suspicion, had he not convinced Miss Dashwood that what"      
##  [1764] "concerned her ought not to escape his lips.  As it was, it required but"     
##  [1765] "a slight effort of fancy to connect his emotion with the tender"             
##  [1766] "recollection of past regard.  Elinor attempted no more.  But Marianne,"      
##  [1767] "in her place, would not have done so little.  The whole story would"         
##  [1768] "have been speedily formed under her active imagination; and every thing"     
##  [1769] "established in the most melancholy order of disastrous love."                
##  [1770] ""                                                                            
##  [1771] ""                                                                            
##  [1772] ""                                                                            
##  [1773] "CHAPTER 12"                                                                  
##  [1774] ""                                                                            
##  [1775] ""                                                                            
##  [1776] "As Elinor and Marianne were walking together the next morning the"           
##  [1777] "latter communicated a piece of news to her sister, which in spite of"        
##  [1778] "all that she knew before of Marianne's imprudence and want of thought,"      
##  [1779] "surprised her by its extravagant testimony of both.  Marianne told her,"     
##  [1780] "with the greatest delight, that Willoughby had given her a horse, one"       
##  [1781] "that he had bred himself on his estate in Somersetshire, and which was"      
##  [1782] "exactly calculated to carry a woman.  Without considering that it was"       
##  [1783] "not in her mother's plan to keep any horse, that if she were to alter"       
##  [1784] "her resolution in favour of this gift, she must buy another for the"         
##  [1785] "servant, and keep a servant to ride it, and after all, build a stable"       
##  [1786] "to receive them, she had accepted the present without hesitation, and"       
##  [1787] "told her sister of it in raptures."                                          
##  [1788] ""                                                                            
##  [1789] "\"He intends to send his groom into Somersetshire immediately for it,\""     
##  [1790] "she added, \"and when it arrives we will ride every day.  You shall"         
##  [1791] "share its use with me.  Imagine to yourself, my dear Elinor, the"            
##  [1792] "delight of a gallop on some of these downs.\""                               
##  [1793] ""                                                                            
##  [1794] "Most unwilling was she to awaken from such a dream of felicity to"           
##  [1795] "comprehend all the unhappy truths which attended the affair; and for"        
##  [1796] "some time she refused to submit to them.  As to an additional servant,"      
##  [1797] "the expense would be a trifle; Mama she was sure would never object to"      
##  [1798] "it; and any horse would do for HIM; he might always get one at the"          
##  [1799] "park; as to a stable, the merest shed would be sufficient.  Elinor then"     
##  [1800] "ventured to doubt the propriety of her receiving such a present from a"      
##  [1801] "man so little, or at least so lately known to her.  This was too much."      
##  [1802] ""                                                                            
##  [1803] "\"You are mistaken, Elinor,\" said she warmly, \"in supposing I know very"   
##  [1804] "little of Willoughby.  I have not known him long indeed, but I am much"      
##  [1805] "better acquainted with him, than I am with any other creature in the"        
##  [1806] "world, except yourself and mama.  It is not time or opportunity that is"     
##  [1807] "to determine intimacy;--it is disposition alone.  Seven years would be"      
##  [1808] "insufficient to make some people acquainted with each other, and seven"      
##  [1809] "days are more than enough for others.  I should hold myself guilty of"       
##  [1810] "greater impropriety in accepting a horse from my brother, than from"         
##  [1811] "Willoughby.  Of John I know very little, though we have lived together"      
##  [1812] "for years; but of Willoughby my judgment has long been formed.\""            
##  [1813] ""                                                                            
##  [1814] "Elinor thought it wisest to touch that point no more.  She knew her"         
##  [1815] "sister's temper.  Opposition on so tender a subject would only attach"       
##  [1816] "her the more to her own opinion.  But by an appeal to her affection for"     
##  [1817] "her mother, by representing the inconveniences which that indulgent"         
##  [1818] "mother must draw on herself, if (as would probably be the case) she"         
##  [1819] "consented to this increase of establishment, Marianne was shortly"           
##  [1820] "subdued; and she promised not to tempt her mother to such imprudent"         
##  [1821] "kindness by mentioning the offer, and to tell Willoughby when she saw"       
##  [1822] "him next, that it must be declined."                                         
##  [1823] ""                                                                            
##  [1824] "She was faithful to her word; and when Willoughby called at the"             
##  [1825] "cottage, the same day, Elinor heard her express her disappointment to"       
##  [1826] "him in a low voice, on being obliged to forego the acceptance of his"        
##  [1827] "present.  The reasons for this alteration were at the same time"             
##  [1828] "related, and they were such as to make further entreaty on his side"         
##  [1829] "impossible.  His concern however was very apparent; and after"               
##  [1830] "expressing it with earnestness, he added, in the same low voice,--\"But,"    
##  [1831] "Marianne, the horse is still yours, though you cannot use it now.  I"        
##  [1832] "shall keep it only till you can claim it.  When you leave Barton to"         
##  [1833] "form your own establishment in a more lasting home, Queen Mab shall"         
##  [1834] "receive you.\""                                                              
##  [1835] ""                                                                            
##  [1836] "This was all overheard by Miss Dashwood; and in the whole of the"            
##  [1837] "sentence, in his manner of pronouncing it, and in his addressing her"        
##  [1838] "sister by her Christian name alone, she instantly saw an intimacy so"        
##  [1839] "decided, a meaning so direct, as marked a perfect agreement between"         
##  [1840] "them.  From that moment she doubted not of their being engaged to each"      
##  [1841] "other; and the belief of it created no other surprise than that she, or"     
##  [1842] "any of their friends, should be left by tempers so frank, to discover"       
##  [1843] "it by accident."                                                             
##  [1844] ""                                                                            
##  [1845] "Margaret related something to her the next day, which placed this"           
##  [1846] "matter in a still clearer light.  Willoughby had spent the preceding"        
##  [1847] "evening with them, and Margaret, by being left some time in the parlour"     
##  [1848] "with only him and Marianne, had had opportunity for observations,"           
##  [1849] "which, with a most important face, she communicated to her eldest"           
##  [1850] "sister, when they were next by themselves."                                  
##  [1851] ""                                                                            
##  [1852] "\"Oh, Elinor!\" she cried, \"I have such a secret to tell you about"         
##  [1853] "Marianne.  I am sure she will be married to Mr. Willoughby very soon.\""     
##  [1854] ""                                                                            
##  [1855] "\"You have said so,\" replied Elinor, \"almost every day since they first"   
##  [1856] "met on High-church Down; and they had not known each other a week, I"        
##  [1857] "believe, before you were certain that Marianne wore his picture round"       
##  [1858] "her neck; but it turned out to be only the miniature of our great"           
##  [1859] "uncle.\""                                                                    
##  [1860] ""                                                                            
##  [1861] "\"But indeed this is quite another thing.  I am sure they will be"           
##  [1862] "married very soon, for he has got a lock of her hair.\""                     
##  [1863] ""                                                                            
##  [1864] "\"Take care, Margaret.  It may be only the hair of some great uncle of"      
##  [1865] "HIS.\""                                                                      
##  [1866] ""                                                                            
##  [1867] "\"But, indeed, Elinor, it is Marianne's. I am almost sure it is, for I"      
##  [1868] "saw him cut it off.  Last night after tea, when you and mama went out"       
##  [1869] "of the room, they were whispering and talking together as fast as could"     
##  [1870] "be, and he seemed to be begging something of her, and presently he took"     
##  [1871] "up her scissors and cut off a long lock of her hair, for it was all"         
##  [1872] "tumbled down her back; and he kissed it, and folded it up in a piece of"     
##  [1873] "white paper; and put it into his pocket-book.\""                             
##  [1874] ""                                                                            
##  [1875] "For such particulars, stated on such authority, Elinor could not"            
##  [1876] "withhold her credit; nor was she disposed to it, for the circumstance"       
##  [1877] "was in perfect unison with what she had heard and seen herself."             
##  [1878] ""                                                                            
##  [1879] "Margaret's sagacity was not always displayed in a way so satisfactory"       
##  [1880] "to her sister.  When Mrs. Jennings attacked her one evening at the"          
##  [1881] "park, to give the name of the young man who was Elinor's particular"         
##  [1882] "favourite, which had been long a matter of great curiosity to her,"          
##  [1883] "Margaret answered by looking at her sister, and saying, \"I must not"        
##  [1884] "tell, may I, Elinor?\""                                                      
##  [1885] ""                                                                            
##  [1886] "This of course made every body laugh; and Elinor tried to laugh too."        
##  [1887] "But the effort was painful.  She was convinced that Margaret had fixed"      
##  [1888] "on a person whose name she could not bear with composure to become a"        
##  [1889] "standing joke with Mrs. Jennings."                                           
##  [1890] ""                                                                            
##  [1891] "Marianne felt for her most sincerely; but she did more harm than good"       
##  [1892] "to the cause, by turning very red and saying in an angry manner to"          
##  [1893] "Margaret,"                                                                   
##  [1894] ""                                                                            
##  [1895] "\"Remember that whatever your conjectures may be, you have no right to"      
##  [1896] "repeat them.\""                                                              
##  [1897] ""                                                                            
##  [1898] "\"I never had any conjectures about it,\" replied Margaret; \"it was you"    
##  [1899] "who told me of it yourself.\""                                               
##  [1900] ""                                                                            
##  [1901] "This increased the mirth of the company, and Margaret was eagerly"           
##  [1902] "pressed to say something more."                                              
##  [1903] ""                                                                            
##  [1904] "\"Oh! pray, Miss Margaret, let us know all about it,\" said Mrs."            
##  [1905] "Jennings.  \"What is the gentleman's name?\""                                
##  [1906] ""                                                                            
##  [1907] "\"I must not tell, ma'am. But I know very well what it is; and I know"       
##  [1908] "where he is too.\""                                                          
##  [1909] ""                                                                            
##  [1910] "\"Yes, yes, we can guess where he is; at his own house at Norland to be"     
##  [1911] "sure.  He is the curate of the parish I dare say.\""                         
##  [1912] ""                                                                            
##  [1913] "\"No, THAT he is not.  He is of no profession at all.\""                     
##  [1914] ""                                                                            
##  [1915] "\"Margaret,\" said Marianne with great warmth, \"you know that all this is"  
##  [1916] "an invention of your own, and that there is no such person in"               
##  [1917] "existence.\""                                                                
##  [1918] ""                                                                            
##  [1919] "\"Well, then, he is lately dead, Marianne, for I am sure there was such"     
##  [1920] "a man once, and his name begins with an F.\""                                
##  [1921] ""                                                                            
##  [1922] "Most grateful did Elinor feel to Lady Middleton for observing, at this"      
##  [1923] "moment, \"that it rained very hard,\" though she believed the"               
##  [1924] "interruption to proceed less from any attention to her, than from her"       
##  [1925] "ladyship's great dislike of all such inelegant subjects of raillery as"      
##  [1926] "delighted her husband and mother.  The idea however started by her, was"     
##  [1927] "immediately pursued by Colonel Brandon, who was on every occasion"           
##  [1928] "mindful of the feelings of others; and much was said on the subject of"      
##  [1929] "rain by both of them.  Willoughby opened the piano-forte, and asked"         
##  [1930] "Marianne to sit down to it; and thus amidst the various endeavours of"       
##  [1931] "different people to quit the topic, it fell to the ground.  But not so"      
##  [1932] "easily did Elinor recover from the alarm into which it had thrown her."      
##  [1933] ""                                                                            
##  [1934] "A party was formed this evening for going on the following day to see a"     
##  [1935] "very fine place about twelve miles from Barton, belonging to a"              
##  [1936] "brother-in-law of Colonel Brandon, without whose interest it could not"      
##  [1937] "be seen, as the proprietor, who was then abroad, had left strict orders"     
##  [1938] "on that head.  The grounds were declared to be highly beautiful, and"        
##  [1939] "Sir John, who was particularly warm in their praise, might be allowed"       
##  [1940] "to be a tolerable judge, for he had formed parties to visit them, at"        
##  [1941] "least, twice every summer for the last ten years.  They contained a"         
##  [1942] "noble piece of water; a sail on which was to a form a great part of the"     
##  [1943] "morning's amusement; cold provisions were to be taken, open carriages"       
##  [1944] "only to be employed, and every thing conducted in the usual style of a"      
##  [1945] "complete party of pleasure."                                                 
##  [1946] ""                                                                            
##  [1947] "To some few of the company it appeared rather a bold undertaking,"           
##  [1948] "considering the time of year, and that it had rained every day for the"      
##  [1949] "last fortnight;--and Mrs. Dashwood, who had already a cold, was"             
##  [1950] "persuaded by Elinor to stay at home."                                        
##  [1951] ""                                                                            
##  [1952] ""                                                                            
##  [1953] ""                                                                            
##  [1954] "CHAPTER 13"                                                                  
##  [1955] ""                                                                            
##  [1956] ""                                                                            
##  [1957] "Their intended excursion to Whitwell turned out very different from"         
##  [1958] "what Elinor had expected.  She was prepared to be wet through,"              
##  [1959] "fatigued, and frightened; but the event was still more unfortunate, for"     
##  [1960] "they did not go at all."                                                     
##  [1961] ""                                                                            
##  [1962] "By ten o'clock the whole party was assembled at the park, where they"        
##  [1963] "were to breakfast.  The morning was rather favourable, though it had"        
##  [1964] "rained all night, as the clouds were then dispersing across the sky,"        
##  [1965] "and the sun frequently appeared.  They were all in high spirits and"         
##  [1966] "good humour, eager to be happy, and determined to submit to the"             
##  [1967] "greatest inconveniences and hardships rather than be otherwise."             
##  [1968] ""                                                                            
##  [1969] "While they were at breakfast the letters were brought in.  Among the"        
##  [1970] "rest there was one for Colonel Brandon;--he took it, looked at the"          
##  [1971] "direction, changed colour, and immediately left the room."                   
##  [1972] ""                                                                            
##  [1973] "\"What is the matter with Brandon?\" said Sir John."                         
##  [1974] ""                                                                            
##  [1975] "Nobody could tell."                                                          
##  [1976] ""                                                                            
##  [1977] "\"I hope he has had no bad news,\" said Lady Middleton.  \"It must be"       
##  [1978] "something extraordinary that could make Colonel Brandon leave my"            
##  [1979] "breakfast table so suddenly.\""                                              
##  [1980] ""                                                                            
##  [1981] "In about five minutes he returned."                                          
##  [1982] ""                                                                            
##  [1983] "\"No bad news, Colonel, I hope;\" said Mrs. Jennings, as soon as he"         
##  [1984] "entered the room."                                                           
##  [1985] ""                                                                            
##  [1986] "\"None at all, ma'am, I thank you.\""                                        
##  [1987] ""                                                                            
##  [1988] "\"Was it from Avignon?  I hope it is not to say that your sister is"         
##  [1989] "worse.\""                                                                    
##  [1990] ""                                                                            
##  [1991] "\"No, ma'am. It came from town, and is merely a letter of business.\""       
##  [1992] ""                                                                            
##  [1993] "\"But how came the hand to discompose you so much, if it was only a"         
##  [1994] "letter of business?  Come, come, this won't do, Colonel; so let us hear"     
##  [1995] "the truth of it.\""                                                          
##  [1996] ""                                                                            
##  [1997] "\"My dear madam,\" said Lady Middleton, \"recollect what you are saying.\""  
##  [1998] ""                                                                            
##  [1999] "\"Perhaps it is to tell you that your cousin Fanny is married?\" said"       
##  [2000] "Mrs. Jennings, without attending to her daughter's reproof."                 
##  [2001] ""                                                                            
##  [2002] "\"No, indeed, it is not.\""                                                  
##  [2003] ""                                                                            
##  [2004] "\"Well, then, I know who it is from, Colonel.  And I hope she is well.\""    
##  [2005] ""                                                                            
##  [2006] "\"Whom do you mean, ma'am?\" said he, colouring a little."                   
##  [2007] ""                                                                            
##  [2008] "\"Oh! you know who I mean.\""                                                
##  [2009] ""                                                                            
##  [2010] "\"I am particularly sorry, ma'am,\" said he, addressing Lady Middleton,"     
##  [2011] "\"that I should receive this letter today, for it is on business which"      
##  [2012] "requires my immediate attendance in town.\""                                 
##  [2013] ""                                                                            
##  [2014] "\"In town!\" cried Mrs. Jennings.  \"What can you have to do in town at"     
##  [2015] "this time of year?\""                                                        
##  [2016] ""                                                                            
##  [2017] "\"My own loss is great,\" he continued, \"in being obliged to leave so"      
##  [2018] "agreeable a party; but I am the more concerned, as I fear my presence"       
##  [2019] "is necessary to gain your admittance at Whitwell.\""                         
##  [2020] ""                                                                            
##  [2021] "What a blow upon them all was this!"                                         
##  [2022] ""                                                                            
##  [2023] "\"But if you write a note to the housekeeper, Mr. Brandon,\" said"           
##  [2024] "Marianne, eagerly, \"will it not be sufficient?\""                           
##  [2025] ""                                                                            
##  [2026] "He shook his head."                                                          
##  [2027] ""                                                                            
##  [2028] "\"We must go,\" said Sir John.--\"It shall not be put off when we are so"    
##  [2029] "near it.  You cannot go to town till tomorrow, Brandon, that is all.\""      
##  [2030] ""                                                                            
##  [2031] "\"I wish it could be so easily settled.  But it is not in my power to"       
##  [2032] "delay my journey for one day!\""                                             
##  [2033] ""                                                                            
##  [2034] "\"If you would but let us know what your business is,\" said Mrs."           
##  [2035] "Jennings, \"we might see whether it could be put off or not.\""              
##  [2036] ""                                                                            
##  [2037] "\"You would not be six hours later,\" said Willoughby, \"if you were to"     
##  [2038] "defer your journey till our return.\""                                       
##  [2039] ""                                                                            
##  [2040] "\"I cannot afford to lose ONE hour.\"--"                                     
##  [2041] ""                                                                            
##  [2042] "Elinor then heard Willoughby say, in a low voice to Marianne, \"There"       
##  [2043] "are some people who cannot bear a party of pleasure.  Brandon is one of"     
##  [2044] "them.  He was afraid of catching cold I dare say, and invented this"         
##  [2045] "trick for getting out of it.  I would lay fifty guineas the letter was"      
##  [2046] "of his own writing.\""                                                       
##  [2047] ""                                                                            
##  [2048] "\"I have no doubt of it,\" replied Marianne."                                
##  [2049] ""                                                                            
##  [2050] "\"There is no persuading you to change your mind, Brandon, I know of"        
##  [2051] "old,\" said Sir John, \"when once you are determined on anything.  But,"     
##  [2052] "however, I hope you will think better of it.  Consider, here are the"        
##  [2053] "two Miss Careys come over from Newton, the three Miss Dashwoods walked"      
##  [2054] "up from the cottage, and Mr. Willoughby got up two hours before his"         
##  [2055] "usual time, on purpose to go to Whitwell.\""                                 
##  [2056] ""                                                                            
##  [2057] "Colonel Brandon again repeated his sorrow at being the cause of"             
##  [2058] "disappointing the party; but at the same time declared it to be"             
##  [2059] "unavoidable."                                                                
##  [2060] ""                                                                            
##  [2061] "\"Well, then, when will you come back again?\""                              
##  [2062] ""                                                                            
##  [2063] "\"I hope we shall see you at Barton,\" added her ladyship, \"as soon as"     
##  [2064] "you can conveniently leave town; and we must put off the party to"           
##  [2065] "Whitwell till you return.\""                                                 
##  [2066] ""                                                                            
##  [2067] "\"You are very obliging.  But it is so uncertain, when I may have it in"     
##  [2068] "my power to return, that I dare not engage for it at all.\""                 
##  [2069] ""                                                                            
##  [2070] "\"Oh! he must and shall come back,\" cried Sir John.  \"If he is not here"   
##  [2071] "by the end of the week, I shall go after him.\""                             
##  [2072] ""                                                                            
##  [2073] "\"Ay, so do, Sir John,\" cried Mrs. Jennings, \"and then perhaps you may"    
##  [2074] "find out what his business is.\""                                            
##  [2075] ""                                                                            
##  [2076] "\"I do not want to pry into other men's concerns.  I suppose it is"          
##  [2077] "something he is ashamed of.\""                                               
##  [2078] ""                                                                            
##  [2079] "Colonel Brandon's horses were announced."                                    
##  [2080] ""                                                                            
##  [2081] "\"You do not go to town on horseback, do you?\" added Sir John."             
##  [2082] ""                                                                            
##  [2083] "\"No. Only to Honiton.  I shall then go post.\""                             
##  [2084] ""                                                                            
##  [2085] "\"Well, as you are resolved to go, I wish you a good journey.  But you"      
##  [2086] "had better change your mind.\""                                              
##  [2087] ""                                                                            
##  [2088] "\"I assure you it is not in my power.\""                                     
##  [2089] ""                                                                            
##  [2090] "He then took leave of the whole party."                                      
##  [2091] ""                                                                            
##  [2092] "\"Is there no chance of my seeing you and your sisters in town this"         
##  [2093] "winter, Miss Dashwood?\""                                                    
##  [2094] ""                                                                            
##  [2095] "\"I am afraid, none at all.\""                                               
##  [2096] ""                                                                            
##  [2097] "\"Then I must bid you farewell for a longer time than I should wish to"      
##  [2098] "do.\""                                                                       
##  [2099] ""                                                                            
##  [2100] "To Marianne, he merely bowed and said nothing."                              
##  [2101] ""                                                                            
##  [2102] "\"Come Colonel,\" said Mrs. Jennings, \"before you go, do let us know what"  
##  [2103] "you are going about.\""                                                      
##  [2104] ""                                                                            
##  [2105] "He wished her a good morning, and, attended by Sir John, left the room."     
##  [2106] ""                                                                            
##  [2107] "The complaints and lamentations which politeness had hitherto"               
##  [2108] "restrained, now burst forth universally; and they all agreed again and"      
##  [2109] "again how provoking it was to be so disappointed."                           
##  [2110] ""                                                                            
##  [2111] "\"I can guess what his business is, however,\" said Mrs. Jennings"           
##  [2112] "exultingly."                                                                 
##  [2113] ""                                                                            
##  [2114] "\"Can you, ma'am?\" said almost every body."                                 
##  [2115] ""                                                                            
##  [2116] "\"Yes; it is about Miss Williams, I am sure.\""                              
##  [2117] ""                                                                            
##  [2118] "\"And who is Miss Williams?\" asked Marianne."                               
##  [2119] ""                                                                            
##  [2120] "\"What! do not you know who Miss Williams is? I am sure you must have"       
##  [2121] "heard of her before.  She is a relation of the Colonel's, my dear; a"        
##  [2122] "very near relation.  We will not say how near, for fear of shocking the"     
##  [2123] "young ladies.\" Then, lowering her voice a little, she said to Elinor,"      
##  [2124] "\"She is his natural daughter.\""                                            
##  [2125] ""                                                                            
##  [2126] "\"Indeed!\""                                                                 
##  [2127] ""                                                                            
##  [2128] "\"Oh, yes; and as like him as she can stare.  I dare say the Colonel"        
##  [2129] "will leave her all his fortune.\""                                           
##  [2130] ""                                                                            
##  [2131] "When Sir John returned, he joined most heartily in the general regret"       
##  [2132] "on so unfortunate an event; concluding however by observing, that as"        
##  [2133] "they were all got together, they must do something by way of being"          
##  [2134] "happy; and after some consultation it was agreed, that although"             
##  [2135] "happiness could only be enjoyed at Whitwell, they might procure a"           
##  [2136] "tolerable composure of mind by driving about the country.  The"              
##  [2137] "carriages were then ordered; Willoughby's was first, and Marianne never"     
##  [2138] "looked happier than when she got into it.  He drove through the park"        
##  [2139] "very fast, and they were soon out of sight; and nothing more of them"        
##  [2140] "was seen till their return, which did not happen till after the return"      
##  [2141] "of all the rest.  They both seemed delighted with their drive; but said"     
##  [2142] "only in general terms that they had kept in the lanes, while the others"     
##  [2143] "went on the downs."                                                          
##  [2144] ""                                                                            
##  [2145] "It was settled that there should be a dance in the evening, and that"        
##  [2146] "every body should be extremely merry all day long.  Some more of the"        
##  [2147] "Careys came to dinner, and they had the pleasure of sitting down nearly"     
##  [2148] "twenty to table, which Sir John observed with great contentment."            
##  [2149] "Willoughby took his usual place between the two elder Miss Dashwoods."       
##  [2150] "Mrs. Jennings sat on Elinor's right hand; and they had not been long"        
##  [2151] "seated, before she leant behind her and Willoughby, and said to"             
##  [2152] "Marianne, loud enough for them both to hear, \"I have found you out in"      
##  [2153] "spite of all your tricks.  I know where you spent the morning.\""            
##  [2154] ""                                                                            
##  [2155] "Marianne coloured, and replied very hastily, \"Where, pray?\"--"             
##  [2156] ""                                                                            
##  [2157] "\"Did not you know,\" said Willoughby, \"that we had been out in my"         
##  [2158] "curricle?\""                                                                 
##  [2159] ""                                                                            
##  [2160] "\"Yes, yes, Mr. Impudence, I know that very well, and I was determined"      
##  [2161] "to find out WHERE you had been to.-- I hope you like your house, Miss"       
##  [2162] "Marianne.  It is a very large one, I know; and when I come to see you,"      
##  [2163] "I hope you will have new-furnished it, for it wanted it very much when"      
##  [2164] "I was there six years ago.\""                                                
##  [2165] ""                                                                            
##  [2166] "Marianne turned away in great confusion.  Mrs. Jennings laughed"             
##  [2167] "heartily; and Elinor found that in her resolution to know where they"        
##  [2168] "had been, she had actually made her own woman enquire of Mr."                
##  [2169] "Willoughby's groom; and that she had by that method been informed that"      
##  [2170] "they had gone to Allenham, and spent a considerable time there in"           
##  [2171] "walking about the garden and going all over the house."                      
##  [2172] ""                                                                            
##  [2173] "Elinor could hardly believe this to be true, as it seemed very unlikely"     
##  [2174] "that Willoughby should propose, or Marianne consent, to enter the house"     
##  [2175] "while Mrs. Smith was in it, with whom Marianne had not the smallest"         
##  [2176] "acquaintance."                                                               
##  [2177] ""                                                                            
##  [2178] "As soon as they left the dining-room, Elinor enquired of her about it;"      
##  [2179] "and great was her surprise when she found that every circumstance"           
##  [2180] "related by Mrs. Jennings was perfectly true.  Marianne was quite angry"      
##  [2181] "with her for doubting it."                                                   
##  [2182] ""                                                                            
##  [2183] "\"Why should you imagine, Elinor, that we did not go there, or that we"      
##  [2184] "did not see the house?  Is not it what you have often wished to do"          
##  [2185] "yourself?\""                                                                 
##  [2186] ""                                                                            
##  [2187] "\"Yes, Marianne, but I would not go while Mrs. Smith was there, and with"    
##  [2188] "no other companion than Mr. Willoughby.\""                                   
##  [2189] ""                                                                            
##  [2190] "\"Mr. Willoughby however is the only person who can have a right to shew"    
##  [2191] "that house; and as he went in an open carriage, it was impossible to"        
##  [2192] "have any other companion.  I never spent a pleasanter morning in my"         
##  [2193] "life.\""                                                                     
##  [2194] ""                                                                            
##  [2195] "\"I am afraid,\" replied Elinor, \"that the pleasantness of an employment"   
##  [2196] "does not always evince its propriety.\""                                     
##  [2197] ""                                                                            
##  [2198] "\"On the contrary, nothing can be a stronger proof of it, Elinor; for if"    
##  [2199] "there had been any real impropriety in what I did, I should have been"       
##  [2200] "sensible of it at the time, for we always know when we are acting"           
##  [2201] "wrong, and with such a conviction I could have had no pleasure.\""           
##  [2202] ""                                                                            
##  [2203] "\"But, my dear Marianne, as it has already exposed you to some very"         
##  [2204] "impertinent remarks, do you not now begin to doubt the discretion of"        
##  [2205] "your own conduct?\""                                                         
##  [2206] ""                                                                            
##  [2207] "\"If the impertinent remarks of Mrs. Jennings are to be the proof of"        
##  [2208] "impropriety in conduct, we are all offending every moment of our lives."     
##  [2209] "I value not her censure any more than I should do her commendation.  I"      
##  [2210] "am not sensible of having done anything wrong in walking over Mrs."          
##  [2211] "Smith's grounds, or in seeing her house.  They will one day be Mr."          
##  [2212] "Willoughby's, and--\""                                                       
##  [2213] ""                                                                            
##  [2214] "\"If they were one day to be your own, Marianne, you would not be"           
##  [2215] "justified in what you have done.\""                                          
##  [2216] ""                                                                            
##  [2217] "She blushed at this hint; but it was even visibly gratifying to her;"        
##  [2218] "and after a ten minutes' interval of earnest thought, she came to her"       
##  [2219] "sister again, and said with great good humour, \"Perhaps, Elinor, it WAS"    
##  [2220] "rather ill-judged in me to go to Allenham; but Mr. Willoughby wanted"        
##  [2221] "particularly to shew me the place; and it is a charming house, I assure"     
##  [2222] "you.--There is one remarkably pretty sitting room up stairs; of a nice"      
##  [2223] "comfortable size for constant use, and with modern furniture it would"       
##  [2224] "be delightful.  It is a corner room, and has windows on two sides.  On"      
##  [2225] "one side you look across the bowling-green, behind the house, to a"          
##  [2226] "beautiful hanging wood, and on the other you have a view of the church"      
##  [2227] "and village, and, beyond them, of those fine bold hills that we have so"     
##  [2228] "often admired.  I did not see it to advantage, for nothing could be"         
##  [2229] "more forlorn than the furniture,--but if it were newly fitted up--a"         
##  [2230] "couple of hundred pounds, Willoughby says, would make it one of the"         
##  [2231] "pleasantest summer-rooms in England.\""                                      
##  [2232] ""                                                                            
##  [2233] "Could Elinor have listened to her without interruption from the others,"     
##  [2234] "she would have described every room in the house with equal delight."        
##  [2235] ""                                                                            
##  [2236] ""                                                                            
##  [2237] ""                                                                            
##  [2238] "CHAPTER 14"                                                                  
##  [2239] ""                                                                            
##  [2240] ""                                                                            
##  [2241] "The sudden termination of Colonel Brandon's visit at the park, with his"     
##  [2242] "steadiness in concealing its cause, filled the mind, and raised the"         
##  [2243] "wonder of Mrs. Jennings for two or three days; she was a great"              
##  [2244] "wonderer, as every one must be who takes a very lively interest in all"      
##  [2245] "the comings and goings of all their acquaintance.  She wondered, with"       
##  [2246] "little intermission what could be the reason of it; was sure there must"     
##  [2247] "be some bad news, and thought over every kind of distress that could"        
##  [2248] "have befallen him, with a fixed determination that he should not escape"     
##  [2249] "them all."                                                                   
##  [2250] ""                                                                            
##  [2251] "\"Something very melancholy must be the matter, I am sure,\" said she."      
##  [2252] "\"I could see it in his face.  Poor man!  I am afraid his circumstances"     
##  [2253] "may be bad.  The estate at Delaford was never reckoned more than two"        
##  [2254] "thousand a year, and his brother left everything sadly involved.  I do"      
##  [2255] "think he must have been sent for about money matters, for what else can"     
##  [2256] "it be?  I wonder whether it is so.  I would give anything to know the"       
##  [2257] "truth of it.  Perhaps it is about Miss Williams and, by the bye, I dare"     
##  [2258] "say it is, because he looked so conscious when I mentioned her.  May be"     
##  [2259] "she is ill in town; nothing in the world more likely, for I have a"          
##  [2260] "notion she is always rather sickly.  I would lay any wager it is about"      
##  [2261] "Miss Williams.  It is not so very likely he should be distressed in his"     
##  [2262] "circumstances NOW, for he is a very prudent man, and to be sure must"        
##  [2263] "have cleared the estate by this time.  I wonder what it can be!  May be"     
##  [2264] "his sister is worse at Avignon, and has sent for him over.  His setting"     
##  [2265] "off in such a hurry seems very like it.  Well, I wish him out of all"        
##  [2266] "his trouble with all my heart, and a good wife into the bargain.\""          
##  [2267] ""                                                                            
##  [2268] "So wondered, so talked Mrs. Jennings.  Her opinion varying with every"       
##  [2269] "fresh conjecture, and all seeming equally probable as they arose."           
##  [2270] "Elinor, though she felt really interested in the welfare of Colonel"         
##  [2271] "Brandon, could not bestow all the wonder on his going so suddenly away,"     
##  [2272] "which Mrs. Jennings was desirous of her feeling; for besides that the"       
##  [2273] "circumstance did not in her opinion justify such lasting amazement or"       
##  [2274] "variety of speculation, her wonder was otherwise disposed of.  It was"       
##  [2275] "engrossed by the extraordinary silence of her sister and Willoughby on"      
##  [2276] "the subject, which they must know to be peculiarly interesting to them"      
##  [2277] "all.  As this silence continued, every day made it appear more strange"      
##  [2278] "and more incompatible with the disposition of both.  Why they should"        
##  [2279] "not openly acknowledge to her mother and herself, what their constant"       
##  [2280] "behaviour to each other declared to have taken place, Elinor could not"      
##  [2281] "imagine."                                                                    
##  [2282] ""                                                                            
##  [2283] "She could easily conceive that marriage might not be immediately in"         
##  [2284] "their power; for though Willoughby was independent, there was no reason"     
##  [2285] "to believe him rich.  His estate had been rated by Sir John at about"        
##  [2286] "six or seven hundred a year; but he lived at an expense to which that"       
##  [2287] "income could hardly be equal, and he had himself often complained of"        
##  [2288] "his poverty.  But for this strange kind of secrecy maintained by them"       
##  [2289] "relative to their engagement, which in fact concealed nothing at all,"       
##  [2290] "she could not account; and it was so wholly contradictory to their"          
##  [2291] "general opinions and practice, that a doubt sometimes entered her mind"      
##  [2292] "of their being really engaged, and this doubt was enough to prevent her"     
##  [2293] "making any inquiry of Marianne."                                             
##  [2294] ""                                                                            
##  [2295] "Nothing could be more expressive of attachment to them all, than"            
##  [2296] "Willoughby's behaviour.  To Marianne it had all the distinguishing"          
##  [2297] "tenderness which a lover's heart could give, and to the rest of the"         
##  [2298] "family it was the affectionate attention of a son and a brother.  The"       
##  [2299] "cottage seemed to be considered and loved by him as his home; many more"     
##  [2300] "of his hours were spent there than at Allenham; and if no general"           
##  [2301] "engagement collected them at the park, the exercise which called him"        
##  [2302] "out in the morning was almost certain of ending there, where the rest"       
##  [2303] "of the day was spent by himself at the side of Marianne, and by his"         
##  [2304] "favourite pointer at her feet."                                              
##  [2305] ""                                                                            
##  [2306] "One evening in particular, about a week after Colonel Brandon left the"      
##  [2307] "country, his heart seemed more than usually open to every feeling of"        
##  [2308] "attachment to the objects around him; and on Mrs. Dashwood's happening"      
##  [2309] "to mention her design of improving the cottage in the spring, he warmly"     
##  [2310] "opposed every alteration of a place which affection had established as"      
##  [2311] "perfect with him."                                                           
##  [2312] ""                                                                            
##  [2313] "\"What!\" he exclaimed--\"Improve this dear cottage!  No. THAT I will"       
##  [2314] "never consent to.  Not a stone must be added to its walls, not an inch"      
##  [2315] "to its size, if my feelings are regarded.\""                                 
##  [2316] ""                                                                            
##  [2317] "\"Do not be alarmed,\" said Miss Dashwood, \"nothing of the kind will be"    
##  [2318] "done; for my mother will never have money enough to attempt it.\""           
##  [2319] ""                                                                            
##  [2320] "\"I am heartily glad of it,\" he cried.  \"May she always be poor, if she"   
##  [2321] "can employ her riches no better.\""                                          
##  [2322] ""                                                                            
##  [2323] "\"Thank you, Willoughby.  But you may be assured that I would not"           
##  [2324] "sacrifice one sentiment of local attachment of yours, or of any one"         
##  [2325] "whom I loved, for all the improvements in the world.  Depend upon it"        
##  [2326] "that whatever unemployed sum may remain, when I make up my accounts in"      
##  [2327] "the spring, I would even rather lay it uselessly by than dispose of it"      
##  [2328] "in a manner so painful to you.  But are you really so attached to this"      
##  [2329] "place as to see no defect in it?\""                                          
##  [2330] ""                                                                            
##  [2331] "\"I am,\" said he.  \"To me it is faultless.  Nay, more, I consider it as"   
##  [2332] "the only form of building in which happiness is attainable, and were I"      
##  [2333] "rich enough I would instantly pull Combe down, and build it up again in"     
##  [2334] "the exact plan of this cottage.\""                                           
##  [2335] ""                                                                            
##  [2336] "\"With dark narrow stairs and a kitchen that smokes, I suppose,\" said"      
##  [2337] "Elinor."                                                                     
##  [2338] ""                                                                            
##  [2339] "\"Yes,\" cried he in the same eager tone, \"with all and every thing"        
##  [2340] "belonging to it;--in no one convenience or INconvenience about it,"          
##  [2341] "should the least variation be perceptible.  Then, and then only, under"      
##  [2342] "such a roof, I might perhaps be as happy at Combe as I have been at"         
##  [2343] "Barton.\""                                                                   
##  [2344] ""                                                                            
##  [2345] "\"I flatter myself,\" replied Elinor, \"that even under the disadvantage"    
##  [2346] "of better rooms and a broader staircase, you will hereafter find your"       
##  [2347] "own house as faultless as you now do this.\""                                
##  [2348] ""                                                                            
##  [2349] "\"There certainly are circumstances,\" said Willoughby, \"which might"       
##  [2350] "greatly endear it to me; but this place will always have one claim of"       
##  [2351] "my affection, which no other can possibly share.\""                          
##  [2352] ""                                                                            
##  [2353] "Mrs. Dashwood looked with pleasure at Marianne, whose fine eyes were"        
##  [2354] "fixed so expressively on Willoughby, as plainly denoted how well she"        
##  [2355] "understood him."                                                             
##  [2356] ""                                                                            
##  [2357] "\"How often did I wish,\" added he, \"when I was at Allenham this time"      
##  [2358] "twelvemonth, that Barton cottage were inhabited!  I never passed within"     
##  [2359] "view of it without admiring its situation, and grieving that no one"         
##  [2360] "should live in it.  How little did I then think that the very first"         
##  [2361] "news I should hear from Mrs. Smith, when I next came into the country,"      
##  [2362] "would be that Barton cottage was taken: and I felt an immediate"
