##  [2363] "satisfaction and interest in the event, which nothing but a kind of"         
##  [2364] "prescience of what happiness I should experience from it, can account"       
##  [2365] "for.  Must it not have been so, Marianne?\" speaking to her in a lowered"    
##  [2366] "voice.  Then continuing his former tone, he said, \"And yet this house"      
##  [2367] "you would spoil, Mrs. Dashwood?  You would rob it of its simplicity by"      
##  [2368] "imaginary improvement! and this dear parlour in which our acquaintance"      
##  [2369] "first began, and in which so many happy hours have been since spent by"      
##  [2370] "us together, you would degrade to the condition of a common entrance,"       
##  [2371] "and every body would be eager to pass through the room which has"            
##  [2372] "hitherto contained within itself more real accommodation and comfort"        
##  [2373] "than any other apartment of the handsomest dimensions in the world"          
##  [2374] "could possibly afford.\""                                                    
##  [2375] ""                                                                            
##  [2376] "Mrs. Dashwood again assured him that no alteration of the kind should"       
##  [2377] "be attempted."                                                               
##  [2378] ""                                                                            
##  [2379] "\"You are a good woman,\" he warmly replied.  \"Your promise makes me"       
##  [2380] "easy.  Extend it a little farther, and it will make me happy.  Tell me"      
##  [2381] "that not only your house will remain the same, but that I shall ever"        
##  [2382] "find you and yours as unchanged as your dwelling; and that you will"         
##  [2383] "always consider me with the kindness which has made everything"              
##  [2384] "belonging to you so dear to me.\""                                           
##  [2385] ""                                                                            
##  [2386] "The promise was readily given, and Willoughby's behaviour during the"        
##  [2387] "whole of the evening declared at once his affection and happiness."          
##  [2388] ""                                                                            
##  [2389] "\"Shall we see you tomorrow to dinner?\" said Mrs. Dashwood, when he was"    
##  [2390] "leaving them.  \"I do not ask you to come in the morning, for we must"       
##  [2391] "walk to the park, to call on Lady Middleton.\""                              
##  [2392] ""                                                                            
##  [2393] "He engaged to be with them by four o'clock."                                 
##  [2394] ""                                                                            
##  [2395] ""                                                                            
##  [2396] ""                                                                            
##  [2397] "CHAPTER 15"                                                                  
##  [2398] ""                                                                            
##  [2399] ""                                                                            
##  [2400] "Mrs. Dashwood's visit to Lady Middleton took place the next day, and"        
##  [2401] "two of her daughters went with her; but Marianne excused herself from"       
##  [2402] "being of the party, under some trifling pretext of employment; and her"      
##  [2403] "mother, who concluded that a promise had been made by Willoughby the"        
##  [2404] "night before of calling on her while they were absent, was perfectly"        
##  [2405] "satisfied with her remaining at home."                                       
##  [2406] ""                                                                            
##  [2407] "On their return from the park they found Willoughby's curricle and"          
##  [2408] "servant in waiting at the cottage, and Mrs. Dashwood was convinced that"     
##  [2409] "her conjecture had been just.  So far it was all as she had foreseen;"       
##  [2410] "but on entering the house she beheld what no foresight had taught her"       
##  [2411] "to expect.  They were no sooner in the passage than Marianne came"           
##  [2412] "hastily out of the parlour apparently in violent affliction, with her"       
##  [2413] "handkerchief at her eyes; and without noticing them ran up stairs."          
##  [2414] "Surprised and alarmed they proceeded directly into the room she had"         
##  [2415] "just quitted, where they found only Willoughby, who was leaning against"     
##  [2416] "the mantel-piece with his back towards them.  He turned round on their"      
##  [2417] "coming in, and his countenance shewed that he strongly partook of the"       
##  [2418] "emotion which over-powered Marianne."                                        
##  [2419] ""                                                                            
##  [2420] "\"Is anything the matter with her?\" cried Mrs. Dashwood as she"             
##  [2421] "entered--\"is she ill?\""                                                    
##  [2422] ""                                                                            
##  [2423] "\"I hope not,\" he replied, trying to look cheerful; and with a forced"      
##  [2424] "smile presently added, \"It is I who may rather expect to be ill--for I"     
##  [2425] "am now suffering under a very heavy disappointment!\""                       
##  [2426] ""                                                                            
##  [2427] "\"Disappointment?\""                                                         
##  [2428] ""                                                                            
##  [2429] "\"Yes, for I am unable to keep my engagement with you.  Mrs. Smith has"      
##  [2430] "this morning exercised the privilege of riches upon a poor dependent"        
##  [2431] "cousin, by sending me on business to London.  I have just received my"       
##  [2432] "dispatches, and taken my farewell of Allenham; and by way of"                
##  [2433] "exhilaration I am now come to take my farewell of you.\""                    
##  [2434] ""                                                                            
##  [2435] "\"To London!--and are you going this morning?\""                             
##  [2436] ""                                                                            
##  [2437] "\"Almost this moment.\""                                                     
##  [2438] ""                                                                            
##  [2439] "\"This is very unfortunate.  But Mrs. Smith must be obliged;--and her"       
##  [2440] "business will not detain you from us long I hope.\""                         
##  [2441] ""                                                                            
##  [2442] "He coloured as he replied, \"You are very kind, but I have no idea of"       
##  [2443] "returning into Devonshire immediately.  My visits to Mrs. Smith are"         
##  [2444] "never repeated within the twelvemonth.\""                                    
##  [2445] ""                                                                            
##  [2446] "\"And is Mrs. Smith your only friend?  Is Allenham the only house in the"    
##  [2447] "neighbourhood to which you will be welcome?  For shame, Willoughby, can"     
##  [2448] "you wait for an invitation here?\""                                          
##  [2449] ""                                                                            
##  [2450] "His colour increased; and with his eyes fixed on the ground he only"         
##  [2451] "replied, \"You are too good.\""                                              
##  [2452] ""                                                                            
##  [2453] "Mrs. Dashwood looked at Elinor with surprise.  Elinor felt equal"            
##  [2454] "amazement.  For a few moments every one was silent.  Mrs. Dashwood"          
##  [2455] "first spoke."                                                                
##  [2456] ""                                                                            
##  [2457] "\"I have only to add, my dear Willoughby, that at Barton cottage you"        
##  [2458] "will always be welcome; for I will not press you to return here"             
##  [2459] "immediately, because you only can judge how far THAT might be pleasing"      
##  [2460] "to Mrs. Smith; and on this head I shall be no more disposed to question"     
##  [2461] "your judgment than to doubt your inclination.\""                             
##  [2462] ""                                                                            
##  [2463] "\"My engagements at present,\" replied Willoughby, confusedly, \"are of"     
##  [2464] "such a nature--that--I dare not flatter myself\"--"                          
##  [2465] ""                                                                            
##  [2466] "He stopt.  Mrs. Dashwood was too much astonished to speak, and another"      
##  [2467] "pause succeeded.  This was broken by Willoughby, who said with a faint"      
##  [2468] "smile, \"It is folly to linger in this manner.  I will not torment"          
##  [2469] "myself any longer by remaining among friends whose society it is"            
##  [2470] "impossible for me now to enjoy.\""                                           
##  [2471] ""                                                                            
##  [2472] "He then hastily took leave of them all and left the room.  They saw him"     
##  [2473] "step into his carriage, and in a minute it was out of sight."                
##  [2474] ""                                                                            
##  [2475] "Mrs. Dashwood felt too much for speech, and instantly quitted the"           
##  [2476] "parlour to give way in solitude to the concern and alarm which this"         
##  [2477] "sudden departure occasioned."                                                
##  [2478] ""                                                                            
##  [2479] "Elinor's uneasiness was at least equal to her mother's.  She thought of"     
##  [2480] "what had just passed with anxiety and distrust.  Willoughby's behaviour"     
##  [2481] "in taking leave of them, his embarrassment, and affectation of"              
##  [2482] "cheerfulness, and, above all, his unwillingness to accept her mother's"      
##  [2483] "invitation, a backwardness so unlike a lover, so unlike himself,"            
##  [2484] "greatly disturbed her.  One moment she feared that no serious design"        
##  [2485] "had ever been formed on his side; and the next that some unfortunate"        
##  [2486] "quarrel had taken place between him and her sister;--the distress in"        
##  [2487] "which Marianne had quitted the room was such as a serious quarrel could"     
##  [2488] "most reasonably account for, though when she considered what Marianne's"     
##  [2489] "love for him was, a quarrel seemed almost impossible."                       
##  [2490] ""                                                                            
##  [2491] "But whatever might be the particulars of their separation, her sister's"     
##  [2492] "affliction was indubitable; and she thought with the tenderest"              
##  [2493] "compassion of that violent sorrow which Marianne was in all probability"     
##  [2494] "not merely giving way to as a relief, but feeding and encouraging as a"      
##  [2495] "duty."                                                                       
##  [2496] ""                                                                            
##  [2497] "In about half an hour her mother returned, and though her eyes were"         
##  [2498] "red, her countenance was not uncheerful."                                    
##  [2499] ""                                                                            
##  [2500] "\"Our dear Willoughby is now some miles from Barton, Elinor,\" said she,"    
##  [2501] "as she sat down to work, \"and with how heavy a heart does he travel?\""     
##  [2502] ""                                                                            
##  [2503] "\"It is all very strange.  So suddenly to be gone! It seems but the work"    
##  [2504] "of a moment.  And last night he was with us so happy, so cheerful, so"       
##  [2505] "affectionate?  And now, after only ten minutes notice--Gone too without"     
##  [2506] "intending to return!--Something more than what he owned to us must have"     
##  [2507] "happened.  He did not speak, he did not behave like himself.  YOU must"      
##  [2508] "have seen the difference as well as I.  What can it be?  Can they have"      
##  [2509] "quarrelled?  Why else should he have shewn such unwillingness to accept"     
##  [2510] "your invitation here?\"--"                                                   
##  [2511] ""                                                                            
##  [2512] "\"It was not inclination that he wanted, Elinor; I could plainly see"        
##  [2513] "THAT.  He had not the power of accepting it.  I have thought it all"         
##  [2514] "over I assure you, and I can perfectly account for every thing that at"      
##  [2515] "first seemed strange to me as well as to you.\""                             
##  [2516] ""                                                                            
##  [2517] "\"Can you, indeed!\""                                                        
##  [2518] ""                                                                            
##  [2519] "\"Yes. I have explained it to myself in the most satisfactory way;--but"     
##  [2520] "you, Elinor, who love to doubt where you can--it will not satisfy YOU,"      
##  [2521] "I know; but you shall not talk ME out of my trust in it.  I am"              
##  [2522] "persuaded that Mrs. Smith suspects his regard for Marianne, disapproves"     
##  [2523] "of it, (perhaps because she has other views for him,) and on that"           
##  [2524] "account is eager to get him away;--and that the business which she"          
##  [2525] "sends him off to transact is invented as an excuse to dismiss him."          
##  [2526] "This is what I believe to have happened.  He is, moreover, aware that"       
##  [2527] "she DOES disapprove the connection, he dares not therefore at present"       
##  [2528] "confess to her his engagement with Marianne, and he feels himself"           
##  [2529] "obliged, from his dependent situation, to give into her schemes, and"        
##  [2530] "absent himself from Devonshire for a while.  You will tell me, I know,"      
##  [2531] "that this may or may NOT have happened; but I will listen to no cavil,"      
##  [2532] "unless you can point out any other method of understanding the affair"       
##  [2533] "as satisfactory at this.  And now, Elinor, what have you to say?\""          
##  [2534] ""                                                                            
##  [2535] "\"Nothing, for you have anticipated my answer.\""                            
##  [2536] ""                                                                            
##  [2537] "\"Then you would have told me, that it might or might not have happened."    
##  [2538] "Oh, Elinor, how incomprehensible are your feelings!  You had rather"         
##  [2539] "take evil upon credit than good.  You had rather look out for misery"        
##  [2540] "for Marianne, and guilt for poor Willoughby, than an apology for the"        
##  [2541] "latter.  You are resolved to think him blameable, because he took leave"     
##  [2542] "of us with less affection than his usual behaviour has shewn.  And is"       
##  [2543] "no allowance to be made for inadvertence, or for spirits depressed by"       
##  [2544] "recent disappointment?  Are no probabilities to be accepted, merely"         
##  [2545] "because they are not certainties?  Is nothing due to the man whom we"        
##  [2546] "have all such reason to love, and no reason in the world to think ill"       
##  [2547] "of?  To the possibility of motives unanswerable in themselves, though"       
##  [2548] "unavoidably secret for a while?  And, after all, what is it you suspect"     
##  [2549] "him of?\""                                                                   
##  [2550] ""                                                                            
##  [2551] "\"I can hardly tell myself.  But suspicion of something unpleasant is"       
##  [2552] "the inevitable consequence of such an alteration as we just witnessed"       
##  [2553] "in him.  There is great truth, however, in what you have now urged of"       
##  [2554] "the allowances which ought to be made for him, and it is my wish to be"      
##  [2555] "candid in my judgment of every body.  Willoughby may undoubtedly have"       
##  [2556] "very sufficient reasons for his conduct, and I will hope that he has."       
##  [2557] "But it would have been more like Willoughby to acknowledge them at"          
##  [2558] "once.  Secrecy may be advisable; but still I cannot help wondering at"       
##  [2559] "its being practiced by him.\""                                               
##  [2560] ""                                                                            
##  [2561] "\"Do not blame him, however, for departing from his character, where the"    
##  [2562] "deviation is necessary.  But you really do admit the justice of what I"      
##  [2563] "have said in his defence?--I am happy--and he is acquitted.\""               
##  [2564] ""                                                                            
##  [2565] "\"Not entirely.  It may be proper to conceal their engagement (if they"      
##  [2566] "ARE engaged) from Mrs. Smith--and if that is the case, it must be"           
##  [2567] "highly expedient for Willoughby to be but little in Devonshire at"           
##  [2568] "present.  But this is no excuse for their concealing it from us.\""          
##  [2569] ""                                                                            
##  [2570] "\"Concealing it from us! my dear child, do you accuse Willoughby and"        
##  [2571] "Marianne of concealment? This is strange indeed, when your eyes have"        
##  [2572] "been reproaching them every day for incautiousness.\""                       
##  [2573] ""                                                                            
##  [2574] "\"I want no proof of their affection,\" said Elinor; \"but of their"         
##  [2575] "engagement I do.\""                                                          
##  [2576] ""                                                                            
##  [2577] "\"I am perfectly satisfied of both.\""                                       
##  [2578] ""                                                                            
##  [2579] "\"Yet not a syllable has been said to you on the subject, by either of"      
##  [2580] "them.\""                                                                     
##  [2581] ""                                                                            
##  [2582] "\"I have not wanted syllables where actions have spoken so plainly.  Has"    
##  [2583] "not his behaviour to Marianne and to all of us, for at least the last"       
##  [2584] "fortnight, declared that he loved and considered her as his future"          
##  [2585] "wife, and that he felt for us the attachment of the nearest relation?"       
##  [2586] "Have we not perfectly understood each other?  Has not my consent been"       
##  [2587] "daily asked by his looks, his manner, his attentive and affectionate"        
##  [2588] "respect?  My Elinor, is it possible to doubt their engagement?  How"         
##  [2589] "could such a thought occur to you?  How is it to be supposed that"           
##  [2590] "Willoughby, persuaded as he must be of your sister's love, should leave"     
##  [2591] "her, and leave her perhaps for months, without telling her of his"           
##  [2592] "affection;--that they should part without a mutual exchange of"              
##  [2593] "confidence?\""                                                               
##  [2594] ""                                                                            
##  [2595] "\"I confess,\" replied Elinor, \"that every circumstance except ONE is in"   
##  [2596] "favour of their engagement; but that ONE is the total silence of both"       
##  [2597] "on the subject, and with me it almost outweighs every other.\""              
##  [2598] ""                                                                            
##  [2599] "\"How strange this is!  You must think wretchedly indeed of Willoughby,"     
##  [2600] "if, after all that has openly passed between them, you can doubt the"        
##  [2601] "nature of the terms on which they are together.  Has he been acting a"       
##  [2602] "part in his behaviour to your sister all this time?  Do you suppose him"     
##  [2603] "really indifferent to her?\""                                                
##  [2604] ""                                                                            
##  [2605] "\"No, I cannot think that.  He must and does love her I am sure.\""          
##  [2606] ""                                                                            
##  [2607] "\"But with a strange kind of tenderness, if he can leave her with such"      
##  [2608] "indifference, such carelessness of the future, as you attribute to him.\""   
##  [2609] ""                                                                            
##  [2610] "\"You must remember, my dear mother, that I have never considered this"      
##  [2611] "matter as certain.  I have had my doubts, I confess; but they are"           
##  [2612] "fainter than they were, and they may soon be entirely done away.  If we"     
##  [2613] "find they correspond, every fear of mine will be removed.\""                 
##  [2614] ""                                                                            
##  [2615] "\"A mighty concession indeed!  If you were to see them at the altar, you"    
##  [2616] "would suppose they were going to be married.  Ungracious girl!  But I"       
##  [2617] "require no such proof.  Nothing in my opinion has ever passed to"            
##  [2618] "justify doubt; no secrecy has been attempted; all has been uniformly"        
##  [2619] "open and unreserved.  You cannot doubt your sister's wishes.  It must"       
##  [2620] "be Willoughby therefore whom you suspect.  But why?  Is he not a man of"     
##  [2621] "honour and feeling? Has there been any inconsistency on his side to"         
##  [2622] "create alarm? can he be deceitful?\""                                        
##  [2623] ""                                                                            
##  [2624] "\"I hope not, I believe not,\" cried Elinor.  \"I love Willoughby,"          
##  [2625] "sincerely love him; and suspicion of his integrity cannot be more"           
##  [2626] "painful to yourself than to me.  It has been involuntary, and I will"        
##  [2627] "not encourage it.  I was startled, I confess, by the alteration in his"      
##  [2628] "manners this morning;--he did not speak like himself, and did not"           
##  [2629] "return your kindness with any cordiality.  But all this may be"              
##  [2630] "explained by such a situation of his affairs as you have supposed.  He"      
##  [2631] "had just parted from my sister, had seen her leave him in the greatest"      
##  [2632] "affliction; and if he felt obliged, from a fear of offending Mrs."           
##  [2633] "Smith, to resist the temptation of returning here soon, and yet aware"       
##  [2634] "that by declining your invitation, by saying that he was going away for"     
##  [2635] "some time, he should seem to act an ungenerous, a suspicious part by"        
##  [2636] "our family, he might well be embarrassed and disturbed.  In such a"          
##  [2637] "case, a plain and open avowal of his difficulties would have been more"      
##  [2638] "to his honour I think, as well as more consistent with his general"          
##  [2639] "character;--but I will not raise objections against any one's conduct"       
##  [2640] "on so illiberal a foundation, as a difference in judgment from myself,"      
##  [2641] "or a deviation from what I may think right and consistent.\""                
##  [2642] ""                                                                            
##  [2643] "\"You speak very properly.  Willoughby certainly does not deserve to be"     
##  [2644] "suspected.  Though WE have not known him long, he is no stranger in"         
##  [2645] "this part of the world; and who has ever spoken to his disadvantage?"        
##  [2646] "Had he been in a situation to act independently and marry immediately,"      
##  [2647] "it might have been odd that he should leave us without acknowledging"        
##  [2648] "everything to me at once: but this is not the case.  It is an"               
##  [2649] "engagement in some respects not prosperously begun, for their marriage"      
##  [2650] "must be at a very uncertain distance; and even secrecy, as far as it"        
##  [2651] "can be observed, may now be very advisable.\""                               
##  [2652] ""                                                                            
##  [2653] "They were interrupted by the entrance of Margaret; and Elinor was then"      
##  [2654] "at liberty to think over the representations of her mother, to"              
##  [2655] "acknowledge the probability of many, and hope for the justice of all."       
##  [2656] ""                                                                            
##  [2657] "They saw nothing of Marianne till dinner time, when she entered the"         
##  [2658] "room and took her place at the table without saying a word.  Her eyes"       
##  [2659] "were red and swollen; and it seemed as if her tears were even then"          
##  [2660] "restrained with difficulty.  She avoided the looks of them all, could"       
##  [2661] "neither eat nor speak, and after some time, on her mother's silently"        
##  [2662] "pressing her hand with tender compassion, her small degree of fortitude"     
##  [2663] "was quite overcome, she burst into tears and left the room."                 
##  [2664] ""                                                                            
##  [2665] "This violent oppression of spirits continued the whole evening.  She"        
##  [2666] "was without any power, because she was without any desire of command"        
##  [2667] "over herself.  The slightest mention of anything relative to Willoughby"     
##  [2668] "overpowered her in an instant; and though her family were most"              
##  [2669] "anxiously attentive to her comfort, it was impossible for them, if they"     
##  [2670] "spoke at all, to keep clear of every subject which her feelings"             
##  [2671] "connected with him."                                                         
##  [2672] ""                                                                            
##  [2673] ""                                                                            
##  [2674] ""                                                                            
##  [2675] "CHAPTER 16"                                                                  
##  [2676] ""                                                                            
##  [2677] ""                                                                            
##  [2678] "Marianne would have thought herself very inexcusable had she been able"      
##  [2679] "to sleep at all the first night after parting from Willoughby.  She"         
##  [2680] "would have been ashamed to look her family in the face the next"             
##  [2681] "morning, had she not risen from her bed in more need of repose than"         
##  [2682] "when she lay down in it.  But the feelings which made such composure a"      
##  [2683] "disgrace, left her in no danger of incurring it.  She was awake the"         
##  [2684] "whole night, and she wept the greatest part of it.  She got up with a"       
##  [2685] "headache, was unable to talk, and unwilling to take any nourishment;"        
##  [2686] "giving pain every moment to her mother and sisters, and forbidding all"      
##  [2687] "attempt at consolation from either.  Her sensibility was potent enough!"     
##  [2688] ""                                                                            
##  [2689] "When breakfast was over she walked out by herself, and wandered about"       
##  [2690] "the village of Allenham, indulging the recollection of past enjoyment"       
##  [2691] "and crying over the present reverse for the chief of the morning."           
##  [2692] ""                                                                            
##  [2693] "The evening passed off in the equal indulgence of feeling.  She played"      
##  [2694] "over every favourite song that she had been used to play to Willoughby,"     
##  [2695] "every air in which their voices had been oftenest joined, and sat at"        
##  [2696] "the instrument gazing on every line of music that he had written out"        
##  [2697] "for her, till her heart was so heavy that no farther sadness could be"       
##  [2698] "gained; and this nourishment of grief was every day applied.  She spent"     
##  [2699] "whole hours at the pianoforte alternately singing and crying; her voice"     
##  [2700] "often totally suspended by her tears.  In books too, as well as in"          
##  [2701] "music, she courted the misery which a contrast between the past and"         
##  [2702] "present was certain of giving.  She read nothing but what they had been"     
##  [2703] "used to read together."                                                      
##  [2704] ""                                                                            
##  [2705] "Such violence of affliction indeed could not be supported for ever; it"      
##  [2706] "sunk within a few days into a calmer melancholy; but these employments,"     
##  [2707] "to which she daily recurred, her solitary walks and silent meditations,"     
##  [2708] "still produced occasional effusions of sorrow as lively as ever."            
##  [2709] ""                                                                            
##  [2710] "No letter from Willoughby came; and none seemed expected by Marianne."       
##  [2711] "Her mother was surprised, and Elinor again became uneasy.  But Mrs."         
##  [2712] "Dashwood could find explanations whenever she wanted them, which at"         
##  [2713] "least satisfied herself."                                                    
##  [2714] ""                                                                            
##  [2715] "\"Remember, Elinor,\" said she, \"how very often Sir John fetches our"       
##  [2716] "letters himself from the post, and carries them to it.  We have already"     
##  [2717] "agreed that secrecy may be necessary, and we must acknowledge that it"       
##  [2718] "could not be maintained if their correspondence were to pass through"        
##  [2719] "Sir John's hands.\""                                                         
##  [2720] ""                                                                            
##  [2721] "Elinor could not deny the truth of this, and she tried to find in it a"      
##  [2722] "motive sufficient for their silence.  But there was one method so"           
##  [2723] "direct, so simple, and in her opinion so eligible of knowing the real"       
##  [2724] "state of the affair, and of instantly removing all mystery, that she"        
##  [2725] "could not help suggesting it to her mother."                                 
##  [2726] ""                                                                            
##  [2727] "\"Why do you not ask Marianne at once,\" said she, \"whether she is or she"  
##  [2728] "is not engaged to Willoughby?  From you, her mother, and so kind, so"        
##  [2729] "indulgent a mother, the question could not give offence.  It would be"       
##  [2730] "the natural result of your affection for her.  She used to be all"           
##  [2731] "unreserve, and to you more especially.\""                                    
##  [2732] ""                                                                            
##  [2733] "\"I would not ask such a question for the world.  Supposing it possible"     
##  [2734] "that they are not engaged, what distress would not such an enquiry"          
##  [2735] "inflict!  At any rate it would be most ungenerous.  I should never"          
##  [2736] "deserve her confidence again, after forcing from her a confession of"        
##  [2737] "what is meant at present to be unacknowledged to any one.  I know"           
##  [2738] "Marianne's heart: I know that she dearly loves me, and that I shall not"     
##  [2739] "be the last to whom the affair is made known, when circumstances make"       
##  [2740] "the revealment of it eligible.  I would not attempt to force the"            
##  [2741] "confidence of any one; of a child much less; because a sense of duty"        
##  [2742] "would prevent the denial which her wishes might direct.\""                   
##  [2743] ""                                                                            
##  [2744] "Elinor thought this generosity overstrained, considering her sister's"       
##  [2745] "youth, and urged the matter farther, but in vain; common sense, common"      
##  [2746] "care, common prudence, were all sunk in Mrs. Dashwood's romantic"            
##  [2747] "delicacy."                                                                   
##  [2748] ""                                                                            
##  [2749] "It was several days before Willoughby's name was mentioned before"           
##  [2750] "Marianne by any of her family; Sir John and Mrs. Jennings, indeed, were"     
##  [2751] "not so nice; their witticisms added pain to many a painful hour;--but"       
##  [2752] "one evening, Mrs. Dashwood, accidentally taking up a volume of"              
##  [2753] "Shakespeare, exclaimed,"                                                     
##  [2754] ""                                                                            
##  [2755] "\"We have never finished Hamlet, Marianne; our dear Willoughby went away"    
##  [2756] "before we could get through it.  We will put it by, that when he comes"      
##  [2757] "again...But it may be months, perhaps, before THAT happens.\""               
##  [2758] ""                                                                            
##  [2759] "\"Months!\" cried Marianne, with strong surprise.  \"No--nor many weeks.\""  
##  [2760] ""                                                                            
##  [2761] "Mrs. Dashwood was sorry for what she had said; but it gave Elinor"           
##  [2762] "pleasure, as it produced a reply from Marianne so expressive of"             
##  [2763] "confidence in Willoughby and knowledge of his intentions."                   
##  [2764] ""                                                                            
##  [2765] "One morning, about a week after his leaving the country, Marianne was"       
##  [2766] "prevailed on to join her sisters in their usual walk, instead of"            
##  [2767] "wandering away by herself.  Hitherto she had carefully avoided every"        
##  [2768] "companion in her rambles.  If her sisters intended to walk on the"           
##  [2769] "downs, she directly stole away towards the lanes; if they talked of the"     
##  [2770] "valley, she was as speedy in climbing the hills, and could never be"         
##  [2771] "found when the others set off.  But at length she was secured by the"        
##  [2772] "exertions of Elinor, who greatly disapproved such continual seclusion."      
##  [2773] "They walked along the road through the valley, and chiefly in silence,"      
##  [2774] "for Marianne's MIND could not be controlled, and Elinor, satisfied with"     
##  [2775] "gaining one point, would not then attempt more.  Beyond the entrance of"     
##  [2776] "the valley, where the country, though still rich, was less wild and"         
##  [2777] "more open, a long stretch of the road which they had travelled on first"     
##  [2778] "coming to Barton, lay before them; and on reaching that point, they"         
##  [2779] "stopped to look around them, and examine a prospect which formed the"        
##  [2780] "distance of their view from the cottage, from a spot which they had"         
##  [2781] "never happened to reach in any of their walks before."                       
##  [2782] ""                                                                            
##  [2783] "Amongst the objects in the scene, they soon discovered an animated one;"     
##  [2784] "it was a man on horseback riding towards them.  In a few minutes they"       
##  [2785] "could distinguish him to be a gentleman; and in a moment afterwards"         
##  [2786] "Marianne rapturously exclaimed,"                                             
##  [2787] ""                                                                            
##  [2788] "\"It is he; it is indeed;--I know it is!\"--and was hastening to meet"       
##  [2789] "him, when Elinor cried out,"                                                 
##  [2790] ""                                                                            
##  [2791] "\"Indeed, Marianne, I think you are mistaken.  It is not Willoughby."        
##  [2792] "The person is not tall enough for him, and has not his air.\""               
##  [2793] ""                                                                            
##  [2794] "\"He has, he has,\" cried Marianne, \"I am sure he has.  His air, his"       
##  [2795] "coat, his horse.  I knew how soon he would come.\""                          
##  [2796] ""                                                                            
##  [2797] "She walked eagerly on as she spoke; and Elinor, to screen Marianne from"     
##  [2798] "particularity, as she felt almost certain of its not being Willoughby,"      
##  [2799] "quickened her pace and kept up with her.  They were soon within thirty"      
##  [2800] "yards of the gentleman.  Marianne looked again; her heart sunk within"       
##  [2801] "her; and abruptly turning round, she was hurrying back, when the voices"     
##  [2802] "of both her sisters were raised to detain her; a third, almost as well"      
##  [2803] "known as Willoughby's, joined them in begging her to stop, and she"          
##  [2804] "turned round with surprise to see and welcome Edward Ferrars."               
##  [2805] ""                                                                            
##  [2806] "He was the only person in the world who could at that moment be"             
##  [2807] "forgiven for not being Willoughby; the only one who could have gained a"     
##  [2808] "smile from her; but she dispersed her tears to smile on HIM, and in her"     
##  [2809] "sister's happiness forgot for a time her own disappointment."                
##  [2810] ""                                                                            
##  [2811] "He dismounted, and giving his horse to his servant, walked back with"        
##  [2812] "them to Barton, whither he was purposely coming to visit them."              
##  [2813] ""                                                                            
##  [2814] "He was welcomed by them all with great cordiality, but especially by"        
##  [2815] "Marianne, who showed more warmth of regard in her reception of him than"     
##  [2816] "even Elinor herself.  To Marianne, indeed, the meeting between Edward"       
##  [2817] "and her sister was but a continuation of that unaccountable coldness"        
##  [2818] "which she had often observed at Norland in their mutual behaviour.  On"      
##  [2819] "Edward's side, more particularly, there was a deficiency of all that a"      
##  [2820] "lover ought to look and say on such an occasion.  He was confused,"          
##  [2821] "seemed scarcely sensible of pleasure in seeing them, looked neither"         
##  [2822] "rapturous nor gay, said little but what was forced from him by"              
##  [2823] "questions, and distinguished Elinor by no mark of affection.  Marianne"      
##  [2824] "saw and listened with increasing surprise.  She began almost to feel a"      
##  [2825] "dislike of Edward; and it ended, as every feeling must end with her, by"     
##  [2826] "carrying back her thoughts to Willoughby, whose manners formed a"            
##  [2827] "contrast sufficiently striking to those of his brother elect."               
##  [2828] ""                                                                            
##  [2829] "After a short silence which succeeded the first surprise and enquiries"      
##  [2830] "of meeting, Marianne asked Edward if he came directly from London.  No,"     
##  [2831] "he had been in Devonshire a fortnight."                                      
##  [2832] ""                                                                            
##  [2833] "\"A fortnight!\" she repeated, surprised at his being so long in the same"   
##  [2834] "county with Elinor without seeing her before."                               
##  [2835] ""                                                                            
##  [2836] "He looked rather distressed as he added, that he had been staying with"      
##  [2837] "some friends near Plymouth."                                                 
##  [2838] ""                                                                            
##  [2839] "\"Have you been lately in Sussex?\" said Elinor."                            
##  [2840] ""                                                                            
##  [2841] "\"I was at Norland about a month ago.\""                                     
##  [2842] ""                                                                            
##  [2843] "\"And how does dear, dear Norland look?\" cried Marianne."                   
##  [2844] ""                                                                            
##  [2845] "\"Dear, dear Norland,\" said Elinor, \"probably looks much as it always"     
##  [2846] "does at this time of the year.  The woods and walks thickly covered"         
##  [2847] "with dead leaves.\""                                                         
##  [2848] ""                                                                            
##  [2849] "\"Oh,\" cried Marianne, \"with what transporting sensation have I formerly"  
##  [2850] "seen them fall!  How have I delighted, as I walked, to see them driven"      
##  [2851] "in showers about me by the wind!  What feelings have they, the season,"      
##  [2852] "the air altogether inspired!  Now there is no one to regard them.  They"     
##  [2853] "are seen only as a nuisance, swept hastily off, and driven as much as"       
##  [2854] "possible from the sight.\""                                                  
##  [2855] ""                                                                            
##  [2856] "\"It is not every one,\" said Elinor, \"who has your passion for dead"       
##  [2857] "leaves.\""                                                                   
##  [2858] ""                                                                            
##  [2859] "\"No; my feelings are not often shared, not often understood.  But"          
##  [2860] "SOMETIMES they are.\"--As she said this, she sunk into a reverie for a"      
##  [2861] "few moments;--but rousing herself again, \"Now, Edward,\" said she,"         
##  [2862] "calling his attention to the prospect, \"here is Barton valley.  Look up"    
##  [2863] "to it, and be tranquil if you can.  Look at those hills!  Did you ever"      
##  [2864] "see their equals?  To the left is Barton park, amongst those woods and"      
##  [2865] "plantations.  You may see the end of the house.  And there, beneath"         
##  [2866] "that farthest hill, which rises with such grandeur, is our cottage.\""       
##  [2867] ""                                                                            
##  [2868] "\"It is a beautiful country,\" he replied; \"but these bottoms must be"      
##  [2869] "dirty in winter.\""                                                          
##  [2870] ""                                                                            
##  [2871] "\"How can you think of dirt, with such objects before you?\""                
##  [2872] ""                                                                            
##  [2873] "\"Because,\" replied he, smiling, \"among the rest of the objects before"    
##  [2874] "me, I see a very dirty lane.\""                                              
##  [2875] ""                                                                            
##  [2876] "\"How strange!\" said Marianne to herself as she walked on."                 
##  [2877] ""                                                                            
##  [2878] "\"Have you an agreeable neighbourhood here?  Are the Middletons pleasant"    
##  [2879] "people?\""                                                                   
##  [2880] ""                                                                            
##  [2881] "\"No, not all,\" answered Marianne; \"we could not be more unfortunately"    
##  [2882] "situated.\""                                                                 
##  [2883] ""                                                                            
##  [2884] "\"Marianne,\" cried her sister, \"how can you say so? How can you be so"     
##  [2885] "unjust?  They are a very respectable family, Mr. Ferrars; and towards"       
##  [2886] "us have behaved in the friendliest manner.  Have you forgot, Marianne,"      
##  [2887] "how many pleasant days we have owed to them?\""                              
##  [2888] ""                                                                            
##  [2889] "\"No,\" said Marianne, in a low voice, \"nor how many painful moments.\""    
##  [2890] ""                                                                            
##  [2891] "Elinor took no notice of this; and directing her attention to their"         
##  [2892] "visitor, endeavoured to support something like discourse with him, by"       
##  [2893] "talking of their present residence, its conveniences, &c. extorting"         
##  [2894] "from him occasional questions and remarks.  His coldness and reserve"        
##  [2895] "mortified her severely; she was vexed and half angry; but resolving to"      
##  [2896] "regulate her behaviour to him by the past rather than the present, she"      
##  [2897] "avoided every appearance of resentment or displeasure, and treated him"      
##  [2898] "as she thought he ought to be treated from the family connection."           
##  [2899] ""                                                                            
##  [2900] ""                                                                            
##  [2901] ""                                                                            
##  [2902] "CHAPTER 17"                                                                  
##  [2903] ""                                                                            
##  [2904] ""                                                                            
##  [2905] "Mrs. Dashwood was surprised only for a moment at seeing him; for his"        
##  [2906] "coming to Barton was, in her opinion, of all things the most natural."       
##  [2907] "Her joy and expression of regard long outlived her wonder.  He received"     
##  [2908] "the kindest welcome from her; and shyness, coldness, reserve could not"      
##  [2909] "stand against such a reception.  They had begun to fail him before he"       
##  [2910] "entered the house, and they were quite overcome by the captivating"          
##  [2911] "manners of Mrs. Dashwood.  Indeed a man could not very well be in love"      
##  [2912] "with either of her daughters, without extending the passion to her; and"     
##  [2913] "Elinor had the satisfaction of seeing him soon become more like"             
##  [2914] "himself.  His affections seemed to reanimate towards them all, and his"      
##  [2915] "interest in their welfare again became perceptible.  He was not in"          
##  [2916] "spirits, however; he praised their house, admired its prospect, was"         
##  [2917] "attentive, and kind; but still he was not in spirits.  The whole family"     
##  [2918] "perceived it, and Mrs. Dashwood, attributing it to some want of"             
##  [2919] "liberality in his mother, sat down to table indignant against all"           
##  [2920] "selfish parents."                                                            
##  [2921] ""                                                                            
##  [2922] "\"What are Mrs. Ferrars's views for you at present, Edward?\" said she,"     
##  [2923] "when dinner was over and they had drawn round the fire; \"are you still"     
##  [2924] "to be a great orator in spite of yourself?\""                                
##  [2925] ""                                                                            
##  [2926] "\"No. I hope my mother is now convinced that I have no more talents than"    
##  [2927] "inclination for a public life!\""                                            
##  [2928] ""                                                                            
##  [2929] "\"But how is your fame to be established? for famous you must be to"         
##  [2930] "satisfy all your family; and with no inclination for expense, no"            
##  [2931] "affection for strangers, no profession, and no assurance, you may find"      
##  [2932] "it a difficult matter.\""                                                    
##  [2933] ""                                                                            
##  [2934] "\"I shall not attempt it.  I have no wish to be distinguished; and have"     
##  [2935] "every reason to hope I never shall.  Thank Heaven! I cannot be forced"       
##  [2936] "into genius and eloquence.\""                                                
##  [2937] ""                                                                            
##  [2938] "\"You have no ambition, I well know.  Your wishes are all moderate.\""       
##  [2939] ""                                                                            
##  [2940] "\"As moderate as those of the rest of the world, I believe.  I wish as"      
##  [2941] "well as every body else to be perfectly happy; but, like every body"         
##  [2942] "else it must be in my own way.  Greatness will not make me so.\""            
##  [2943] ""                                                                            
##  [2944] "\"Strange that it would!\" cried Marianne.  \"What have wealth or grandeur"  
##  [2945] "to do with happiness?\""                                                     
##  [2946] ""                                                                            
##  [2947] "\"Grandeur has but little,\" said Elinor, \"but wealth has much to do with"  
##  [2948] "it.\""                                                                       
##  [2949] ""                                                                            
##  [2950] "\"Elinor, for shame!\" said Marianne, \"money can only give happiness"       
##  [2951] "where there is nothing else to give it.  Beyond a competence, it can"        
##  [2952] "afford no real satisfaction, as far as mere self is concerned.\""            
##  [2953] ""                                                                            
##  [2954] "\"Perhaps,\" said Elinor, smiling, \"we may come to the same point.  YOUR"   
##  [2955] "competence and MY wealth are very much alike, I dare say; and without"       
##  [2956] "them, as the world goes now, we shall both agree that every kind of"         
##  [2957] "external comfort must be wanting.  Your ideas are only more noble than"      
##  [2958] "mine.  Come, what is your competence?\""                                     
##  [2959] ""                                                                            
##  [2960] "\"About eighteen hundred or two thousand a year; not more than THAT.\""      
##  [2961] ""                                                                            
##  [2962] "Elinor laughed.  \"TWO thousand a year! ONE is my wealth! I guessed how"     
##  [2963] "it would end.\""                                                             
##  [2964] ""                                                                            
##  [2965] "\"And yet two thousand a-year is a very moderate income,\" said Marianne."   
##  [2966] "\"A family cannot well be maintained on a smaller.  I am sure I am not"      
##  [2967] "extravagant in my demands.  A proper establishment of servants, a"           
##  [2968] "carriage, perhaps two, and hunters, cannot be supported on less.\""          
##  [2969] ""                                                                            
##  [2970] "Elinor smiled again, to hear her sister describing so accurately their"      
##  [2971] "future expenses at Combe Magna."                                             
##  [2972] ""                                                                            
##  [2973] "\"Hunters!\" repeated Edward--\"but why must you have hunters?  Every body"  
##  [2974] "does not hunt.\""                                                            
##  [2975] ""                                                                            
##  [2976] "Marianne coloured as she replied, \"But most people do.\""                   
##  [2977] ""                                                                            
##  [2978] "\"I wish,\" said Margaret, striking out a novel thought, \"that somebody"    
##  [2979] "would give us all a large fortune apiece!\""                                 
##  [2980] ""                                                                            
##  [2981] "\"Oh that they would!\" cried Marianne, her eyes sparkling with"             
##  [2982] "animation, and her cheeks glowing with the delight of such imaginary"        
##  [2983] "happiness."                                                                  
##  [2984] ""                                                                            
##  [2985] "\"We are all unanimous in that wish, I suppose,\" said Elinor, \"in spite"   
##  [2986] "of the insufficiency of wealth.\""                                           
##  [2987] ""                                                                            
##  [2988] "\"Oh dear!\" cried Margaret, \"how happy I should be!  I wonder what I"      
##  [2989] "should do with it!\""                                                        
##  [2990] ""                                                                            
##  [2991] "Marianne looked as if she had no doubt on that point."                       
##  [2992] ""                                                                            
##  [2993] "\"I should be puzzled to spend so large a fortune myself,\" said Mrs."       
##  [2994] "Dashwood, \"if my children were all to be rich without my help.\""           
##  [2995] ""                                                                            
##  [2996] "\"You must begin your improvements on this house,\" observed Elinor, \"and"  
##  [2997] "your difficulties will soon vanish.\""                                       
##  [2998] ""                                                                            
##  [2999] "\"What magnificent orders would travel from this family to London,\" said"   
##  [3000] "Edward, \"in such an event!  What a happy day for booksellers,"              
##  [3001] "music-sellers, and print-shops!  You, Miss Dashwood, would give a"           
##  [3002] "general commission for every new print of merit to be sent you--and as"      
##  [3003] "for Marianne, I know her greatness of soul, there would not be music"        
##  [3004] "enough in London to content her.  And books!--Thomson, Cowper,"              
##  [3005] "Scott--she would buy them all over and over again: she would buy up"         
##  [3006] "every copy, I believe, to prevent their falling into unworthy hands;"        
##  [3007] "and she would have every book that tells her how to admire an old"           
##  [3008] "twisted tree.  Should not you, Marianne?  Forgive me, if I am very"          
##  [3009] "saucy.  But I was willing to shew you that I had not forgot our old"         
##  [3010] "disputes.\""                                                                 
##  [3011] ""                                                                            
##  [3012] "\"I love to be reminded of the past, Edward--whether it be melancholy or"    
##  [3013] "gay, I love to recall it--and you will never offend me by talking of"        
##  [3014] "former times.  You are very right in supposing how my money would be"        
##  [3015] "spent--some of it, at least--my loose cash would certainly be employed"      
##  [3016] "in improving my collection of music and books.\""                            
##  [3017] ""                                                                            
##  [3018] "\"And the bulk of your fortune would be laid out in annuities on the"        
##  [3019] "authors or their heirs.\""                                                   
##  [3020] ""                                                                            
##  [3021] "\"No, Edward, I should have something else to do with it.\""                 
##  [3022] ""                                                                            
##  [3023] "\"Perhaps, then, you would bestow it as a reward on that person who"         
##  [3024] "wrote the ablest defence of your favourite maxim, that no one can ever"      
##  [3025] "be in love more than once in their life--your opinion on that point is"      
##  [3026] "unchanged, I presume?\""                                                     
##  [3027] ""                                                                            
##  [3028] "\"Undoubtedly. At my time of life opinions are tolerably fixed.  It is"      
##  [3029] "not likely that I should now see or hear any thing to change them.\""        
##  [3030] ""                                                                            
##  [3031] "\"Marianne is as steadfast as ever, you see,\" said Elinor, \"she is not"    
##  [3032] "at all altered.\""                                                           
##  [3033] ""                                                                            
##  [3034] "\"She is only grown a little more grave than she was.\""                     
##  [3035] ""                                                                            
##  [3036] "\"Nay, Edward,\" said Marianne, \"you need not reproach me.  You are not"    
##  [3037] "very gay yourself.\""                                                        
##  [3038] ""                                                                            
##  [3039] "\"Why should you think so!\" replied he, with a sigh.  \"But gaiety never"   
##  [3040] "was a part of MY character.\""                                               
##  [3041] ""                                                                            
##  [3042] "\"Nor do I think it a part of Marianne's,\" said Elinor; \"I should hardly"  
##  [3043] "call her a lively girl--she is very earnest, very eager in all she"          
##  [3044] "does--sometimes talks a great deal and always with animation--but she"       
##  [3045] "is not often really merry.\""                                                
##  [3046] ""                                                                            
##  [3047] "\"I believe you are right,\" he replied, \"and yet I have always set her"    
##  [3048] "down as a lively girl.\""                                                    
##  [3049] ""                                                                            
##  [3050] "\"I have frequently detected myself in such kind of mistakes,\" said"        
##  [3051] "Elinor, \"in a total misapprehension of character in some point or"          
##  [3052] "other: fancying people so much more gay or grave, or ingenious or"           
##  [3053] "stupid than they really are, and I can hardly tell why or in what the"       
##  [3054] "deception originated.  Sometimes one is guided by what they say of"          
##  [3055] "themselves, and very frequently by what other people say of them,"           
##  [3056] "without giving oneself time to deliberate and judge.\""                      
##  [3057] ""                                                                            
##  [3058] "\"But I thought it was right, Elinor,\" said Marianne, \"to be guided"       
##  [3059] "wholly by the opinion of other people.  I thought our judgments were"        
##  [3060] "given us merely to be subservient to those of neighbours.  This has"         
##  [3061] "always been your doctrine, I am sure.\""                                     
##  [3062] ""                                                                            
##  [3063] "\"No, Marianne, never.  My doctrine has never aimed at the subjection of"    
##  [3064] "the understanding.  All I have ever attempted to influence has been the"     
##  [3065] "behaviour.  You must not confound my meaning.  I am guilty, I confess,"      
##  [3066] "of having often wished you to treat our acquaintance in general with"        
##  [3067] "greater attention; but when have I advised you to adopt their"               
##  [3068] "sentiments or to conform to their judgment in serious matters?\""            
##  [3069] ""                                                                            
##  [3070] "\"You have not been able to bring your sister over to your plan of"          
##  [3071] "general civility,\" said Edward to Elinor.  \"Do you gain no ground?\""      
##  [3072] ""                                                                            
##  [3073] "\"Quite the contrary,\" replied Elinor, looking expressively at Marianne."   
##  [3074] ""                                                                            
##  [3075] "\"My judgment,\" he returned, \"is all on your side of the question; but I"  
##  [3076] "am afraid my practice is much more on your sister's.  I never wish to"       
##  [3077] "offend, but I am so foolishly shy, that I often seem negligent, when I"      
##  [3078] "am only kept back by my natural awkwardness.  I have frequently thought"     
##  [3079] "that I must have been intended by nature to be fond of low company, I"       
##  [3080] "am so little at my ease among strangers of gentility!\""                     
##  [3081] ""                                                                            
##  [3082] "\"Marianne has not shyness to excuse any inattention of hers,\" said"        
##  [3083] "Elinor."                                                                     
##  [3084] ""                                                                            
##  [3085] "\"She knows her own worth too well for false shame,\" replied Edward."       
##  [3086] "\"Shyness is only the effect of a sense of inferiority in some way or"       
##  [3087] "other.  If I could persuade myself that my manners were perfectly easy"      
##  [3088] "and graceful, I should not be shy.\""                                        
##  [3089] ""                                                                            
##  [3090] "\"But you would still be reserved,\" said Marianne, \"and that is worse.\""  
##  [3091] ""                                                                            
##  [3092] "Edward started--\"Reserved! Am I reserved, Marianne?\""                      
##  [3093] ""                                                                            
##  [3094] "\"Yes, very.\""                                                              
##  [3095] ""                                                                            
##  [3096] "\"I do not understand you,\" replied he, colouring.  \"Reserved!--how, in"   
##  [3097] "what manner?  What am I to tell you?  What can you suppose?\""               
##  [3098] ""                                                                            
##  [3099] "Elinor looked surprised at his emotion; but trying to laugh off the"         
##  [3100] "subject, she said to him, \"Do not you know my sister well enough to"        
##  [3101] "understand what she means?  Do not you know she calls every one"             
##  [3102] "reserved who does not talk as fast, and admire what she admires as"          
##  [3103] "rapturously as herself?\""                                                   
##  [3104] ""                                                                            
##  [3105] "Edward made no answer.  His gravity and thoughtfulness returned on him"      
##  [3106] "in their fullest extent--and he sat for some time silent and dull."          
##  [3107] ""                                                                            
##  [3108] ""                                                                            
##  [3109] ""                                                                            
##  [3110] "CHAPTER 18"                                                                  
##  [3111] ""                                                                            
##  [3112] ""                                                                            
##  [3113] "Elinor saw, with great uneasiness the low spirits of her friend.  His"       
##  [3114] "visit afforded her but a very partial satisfaction, while his own"           
##  [3115] "enjoyment in it appeared so imperfect.  It was evident that he was"          
##  [3116] "unhappy; she wished it were equally evident that he still distinguished"     
##  [3117] "her by the same affection which once she had felt no doubt of"               
##  [3118] "inspiring; but hitherto the continuance of his preference seemed very"       
##  [3119] "uncertain; and the reservedness of his manner towards her contradicted"      
##  [3120] "one moment what a more animated look had intimated the preceding one."       
##  [3121] ""                                                                            
##  [3122] "He joined her and Marianne in the breakfast-room the next morning"           
##  [3123] "before the others were down; and Marianne, who was always eager to"          
##  [3124] "promote their happiness as far as she could, soon left them to"              
##  [3125] "themselves.  But before she was half way upstairs she heard the parlour"     
##  [3126] "door open, and, turning round, was astonished to see Edward himself"         
##  [3127] "come out."                                                                   
##  [3128] ""                                                                            
##  [3129] "\"I am going into the village to see my horses,\" said he, \"as you are"     
##  [3130] "not yet ready for breakfast; I shall be back again presently.\""             
##  [3131] ""                                                                            
##  [3132] "                    ***"                                                     
##  [3133] ""                                                                            
##  [3134] "Edward returned to them with fresh admiration of the surrounding"            
##  [3135] "country; in his walk to the village, he had seen many parts of the"          
##  [3136] "valley to advantage; and the village itself, in a much higher situation"     
##  [3137] "than the cottage, afforded a general view of the whole, which had"           
##  [3138] "exceedingly pleased him.  This was a subject which ensured Marianne's"       
##  [3139] "attention, and she was beginning to describe her own admiration of"          
##  [3140] "these scenes, and to question him more minutely on the objects that had"     
##  [3141] "particularly struck him, when Edward interrupted her by saying, \"You"       
##  [3142] "must not enquire too far, Marianne--remember I have no knowledge in the"     
##  [3143] "picturesque, and I shall offend you by my ignorance and want of taste"       
##  [3144] "if we come to particulars.  I shall call hills steep, which ought to be"     
##  [3145] "bold; surfaces strange and uncouth, which ought to be irregular and"         
##  [3146] "rugged; and distant objects out of sight, which ought only to be"            
##  [3147] "indistinct through the soft medium of a hazy atmosphere.  You must be"       
##  [3148] "satisfied with such admiration as I can honestly give.  I call it a"         
##  [3149] "very fine country--the hills are steep, the woods seem full of fine"         
##  [3150] "timber, and the valley looks comfortable and snug--with rich meadows"        
##  [3151] "and several neat farm houses scattered here and there.  It exactly"          
##  [3152] "answers my idea of a fine country, because it unites beauty with"            
##  [3153] "utility--and I dare say it is a picturesque one too, because you admire"     
##  [3154] "it; I can easily believe it to be full of rocks and promontories, grey"      
##  [3155] "moss and brush wood, but these are all lost on me.  I know nothing of"       
##  [3156] "the picturesque.\""                                                          
##  [3157] ""                                                                            
##  [3158] "\"I am afraid it is but too true,\" said Marianne; \"but why should you"     
##  [3159] "boast of it?\""                                                              
##  [3160] ""                                                                            
##  [3161] "\"I suspect,\" said Elinor, \"that to avoid one kind of affectation,"        
##  [3162] "Edward here falls into another.  Because he believes many people"            
##  [3163] "pretend to more admiration of the beauties of nature than they really"       
##  [3164] "feel, and is disgusted with such pretensions, he affects greater"            
##  [3165] "indifference and less discrimination in viewing them himself than he"        
##  [3166] "possesses.  He is fastidious and will have an affectation of his own.\""     
##  [3167] ""                                                                            
##  [3168] "\"It is very true,\" said Marianne, \"that admiration of landscape scenery"  
##  [3169] "is become a mere jargon.  Every body pretends to feel and tries to"          
##  [3170] "describe with the taste and elegance of him who first defined what"          
##  [3171] "picturesque beauty was.  I detest jargon of every kind, and sometimes I"     
##  [3172] "have kept my feelings to myself, because I could find no language to"        
##  [3173] "describe them in but what was worn and hackneyed out of all sense and"       
##  [3174] "meaning.\""                                                                  
##  [3175] ""                                                                            
##  [3176] "\"I am convinced,\" said Edward, \"that you really feel all the delight in"  
##  [3177] "a fine prospect which you profess to feel.  But, in return, your sister"     
##  [3178] "must allow me to feel no more than I profess.  I like a fine prospect,"      
##  [3179] "but not on picturesque principles.  I do not like crooked, twisted,"         
##  [3180] "blasted trees.  I admire them much more if they are tall, straight, and"     
##  [3181] "flourishing.  I do not like ruined, tattered cottages.  I am not fond"       
##  [3182] "of nettles or thistles, or heath blossoms.  I have more pleasure in a"       
##  [3183] "snug farm-house than a watch-tower--and a troop of tidy, happy villages"     
##  [3184] "please me better than the finest banditti in the world.\""                   
##  [3185] ""                                                                            
##  [3186] "Marianne looked with amazement at Edward, with compassion at her"            
##  [3187] "sister.  Elinor only laughed."                                               
##  [3188] ""                                                                            
##  [3189] "The subject was continued no farther; and Marianne remained"                 
##  [3190] "thoughtfully silent, till a new object suddenly engaged her attention."      
##  [3191] "She was sitting by Edward, and in taking his tea from Mrs. Dashwood,"        
##  [3192] "his hand passed so directly before her, as to make a ring, with a plait"     
##  [3193] "of hair in the centre, very conspicuous on one of his fingers."              
##  [3194] ""                                                                            
##  [3195] "\"I never saw you wear a ring before, Edward,\" she cried.  \"Is that"       
##  [3196] "Fanny's hair? I remember her promising to give you some.  But I should"      
##  [3197] "have thought her hair had been darker.\""                                    
##  [3198] ""                                                                            
##  [3199] "Marianne spoke inconsiderately what she really felt--but when she saw"       
##  [3200] "how much she had pained Edward, her own vexation at her want of thought"     
##  [3201] "could not be surpassed by his.  He coloured very deeply, and giving a"       
##  [3202] "momentary glance at Elinor, replied, \"Yes; it is my sister's hair.  The"    
##  [3203] "setting always casts a different shade on it, you know.\""                   
##  [3204] ""                                                                            
##  [3205] "Elinor had met his eye, and looked conscious likewise.  That the hair"       
##  [3206] "was her own, she instantaneously felt as well satisfied as Marianne;"        
##  [3207] "the only difference in their conclusions was, that what Marianne"            
##  [3208] "considered as a free gift from her sister, Elinor was conscious must"        
##  [3209] "have been procured by some theft or contrivance unknown to herself."         
##  [3210] "She was not in a humour, however, to regard it as an affront, and"           
##  [3211] "affecting to take no notice of what passed, by instantly talking of"         
##  [3212] "something else, she internally resolved henceforward to catch every"         
##  [3213] "opportunity of eyeing the hair and of satisfying herself, beyond all"        
##  [3214] "doubt, that it was exactly the shade of her own."                            
##  [3215] ""                                                                            
##  [3216] "Edward's embarrassment lasted some time, and it ended in an absence of"      
##  [3217] "mind still more settled.  He was particularly grave the whole morning."      
##  [3218] "Marianne severely censured herself for what she had said; but her own"       
##  [3219] "forgiveness might have been more speedy, had she known how little"           
##  [3220] "offence it had given her sister."                                            
##  [3221] ""                                                                            
##  [3222] "Before the middle of the day, they were visited by Sir John and Mrs."        
##  [3223] "Jennings, who, having heard of the arrival of a gentleman at the"            
##  [3224] "cottage, came to take a survey of the guest.  With the assistance of"        
##  [3225] "his mother-in-law, Sir John was not long in discovering that the name"       
##  [3226] "of Ferrars began with an F. and this prepared a future mine of raillery"     
##  [3227] "against the devoted Elinor, which nothing but the newness of their"          
##  [3228] "acquaintance with Edward could have prevented from being immediately"        
##  [3229] "sprung.  But, as it was, she only learned, from some very significant"       
##  [3230] "looks, how far their penetration, founded on Margaret's instructions,"       
##  [3231] "extended."                                                                   
##  [3232] ""                                                                            
##  [3233] "Sir John never came to the Dashwoods without either inviting them to"        
##  [3234] "dine at the park the next day, or to drink tea with them that evening."      
##  [3235] "On the present occasion, for the better entertainment of their visitor,"     
##  [3236] "towards whose amusement he felt himself bound to contribute, he wished"      
##  [3237] "to engage them for both."                                                    
##  [3238] ""                                                                            
##  [3239] "\"You MUST drink tea with us to night,\" said he, \"for we shall be quite"   
##  [3240] "alone--and tomorrow you must absolutely dine with us, for we shall be a"     
##  [3241] "large party.\""                                                              
##  [3242] ""                                                                            
##  [3243] "Mrs. Jennings enforced the necessity.  \"And who knows but you may raise"    
##  [3244] "a dance,\" said she.  \"And that will tempt YOU, Miss Marianne.\""           
##  [3245] ""                                                                            
##  [3246] "\"A dance!\" cried Marianne.  \"Impossible! Who is to dance?\""              
##  [3247] ""                                                                            
##  [3248] "\"Who! why yourselves, and the Careys, and Whitakers to be sure.--What!"     
##  [3249] "you thought nobody could dance because a certain person that shall be"       
##  [3250] "nameless is gone!\""
