##  [3251] ""                                                                            
##  [3252] "\"I wish with all my soul,\" cried Sir John, \"that Willoughby were among"   
##  [3253] "us again.\""                                                                 
##  [3254] ""                                                                            
##  [3255] "This, and Marianne's blushing, gave new suspicions to Edward.  \"And who"    
##  [3256] "is Willoughby?\" said he, in a low voice, to Miss Dashwood, by whom he"      
##  [3257] "was sitting."                                                                
##  [3258] ""                                                                            
##  [3259] "She gave him a brief reply.  Marianne's countenance was more"                
##  [3260] "communicative.  Edward saw enough to comprehend, not only the meaning"       
##  [3261] "of others, but such of Marianne's expressions as had puzzled him"            
##  [3262] "before; and when their visitors left them, he went immediately round"        
##  [3263] "her, and said, in a whisper, \"I have been guessing.  Shall I tell you"      
##  [3264] "my guess?\""                                                                 
##  [3265] ""                                                                            
##  [3266] "\"What do you mean?\""                                                       
##  [3267] ""                                                                            
##  [3268] "\"Shall I tell you.\""                                                       
##  [3269] ""                                                                            
##  [3270] "\"Certainly.\""                                                              
##  [3271] ""                                                                            
##  [3272] "\"Well then; I guess that Mr. Willoughby hunts.\""                           
##  [3273] ""                                                                            
##  [3274] "Marianne was surprised and confused, yet she could not help smiling at"      
##  [3275] "the quiet archness of his manner, and after a moment's silence, said,"       
##  [3276] ""                                                                            
##  [3277] "\"Oh, Edward! How can you?--But the time will come I hope...I am sure"       
##  [3278] "you will like him.\""                                                        
##  [3279] ""                                                                            
##  [3280] "\"I do not doubt it,\" replied he, rather astonished at her earnestness"     
##  [3281] "and warmth; for had he not imagined it to be a joke for the good of her"     
##  [3282] "acquaintance in general, founded only on a something or a nothing"           
##  [3283] "between Mr. Willoughby and herself, he would not have ventured to"           
##  [3284] "mention it."                                                                 
##  [3285] ""                                                                            
##  [3286] ""                                                                            
##  [3287] ""                                                                            
##  [3288] "CHAPTER 19"                                                                  
##  [3289] ""                                                                            
##  [3290] ""                                                                            
##  [3291] "Edward remained a week at the cottage; he was earnestly pressed by Mrs."     
##  [3292] "Dashwood to stay longer; but, as if he were bent only on"                    
##  [3293] "self-mortification, he seemed resolved to be gone when his enjoyment"        
##  [3294] "among his friends was at the height.  His spirits, during the last two"      
##  [3295] "or three days, though still very unequal, were greatly improved--he"         
##  [3296] "grew more and more partial to the house and environs--never spoke of"        
##  [3297] "going away without a sigh--declared his time to be wholly"                   
##  [3298] "disengaged--even doubted to what place he should go when he left"            
##  [3299] "them--but still, go he must.  Never had any week passed so quickly--he"      
##  [3300] "could hardly believe it to be gone.  He said so repeatedly; other"           
##  [3301] "things he said too, which marked the turn of his feelings and gave the"      
##  [3302] "lie to his actions.  He had no pleasure at Norland; he detested being"       
##  [3303] "in town; but either to Norland or London, he must go.  He valued their"      
##  [3304] "kindness beyond any thing, and his greatest happiness was in being with"     
##  [3305] "them.  Yet, he must leave them at the end of a week, in spite of their"      
##  [3306] "wishes and his own, and without any restraint on his time."                  
##  [3307] ""                                                                            
##  [3308] "Elinor placed all that was astonishing in this way of acting to his"         
##  [3309] "mother's account; and it was happy for her that he had a mother whose"       
##  [3310] "character was so imperfectly known to her, as to be the general excuse"      
##  [3311] "for every thing strange on the part of her son.  Disappointed, however,"     
##  [3312] "and vexed as she was, and sometimes displeased with his uncertain"           
##  [3313] "behaviour to herself, she was very well disposed on the whole to regard"     
##  [3314] "his actions with all the candid allowances and generous qualifications,"     
##  [3315] "which had been rather more painfully extorted from her, for"                 
##  [3316] "Willoughby's service, by her mother.  His want of spirits, of openness,"     
##  [3317] "and of consistency, were most usually attributed to his want of"             
##  [3318] "independence, and his better knowledge of Mrs. Ferrars's disposition"        
##  [3319] "and designs.  The shortness of his visit, the steadiness of his purpose"     
##  [3320] "in leaving them, originated in the same fettered inclination, the same"      
##  [3321] "inevitable necessity of temporizing with his mother.  The old"               
##  [3322] "well-established grievance of duty against will, parent against child,"      
##  [3323] "was the cause of all.  She would have been glad to know when these"          
##  [3324] "difficulties were to cease, this opposition was to yield,--when Mrs."        
##  [3325] "Ferrars would be reformed, and her son be at liberty to be happy.  But"      
##  [3326] "from such vain wishes she was forced to turn for comfort to the renewal"     
##  [3327] "of her confidence in Edward's affection, to the remembrance of every"        
##  [3328] "mark of regard in look or word which fell from him while at Barton, and"     
##  [3329] "above all to that flattering proof of it which he constantly wore round"     
##  [3330] "his finger."                                                                 
##  [3331] ""                                                                            
##  [3332] "\"I think, Edward,\" said Mrs. Dashwood, as they were at breakfast the"      
##  [3333] "last morning, \"you would be a happier man if you had any profession to"     
##  [3334] "engage your time and give an interest to your plans and actions.  Some"      
##  [3335] "inconvenience to your friends, indeed, might result from it--you would"      
##  [3336] "not be able to give them so much of your time.  But (with a smile) you"      
##  [3337] "would be materially benefited in one particular at least--you would"         
##  [3338] "know where to go when you left them.\""                                      
##  [3339] ""                                                                            
##  [3340] "\"I do assure you,\" he replied, \"that I have long thought on this point,"  
##  [3341] "as you think now.  It has been, and is, and probably will always be a"       
##  [3342] "heavy misfortune to me, that I have had no necessary business to engage"     
##  [3343] "me, no profession to give me employment, or afford me any thing like"        
##  [3344] "independence.  But unfortunately my own nicety, and the nicety of my"        
##  [3345] "friends, have made me what I am, an idle, helpless being.  We never"         
##  [3346] "could agree in our choice of a profession.  I always preferred the"          
##  [3347] "church, as I still do.  But that was not smart enough for my family."        
##  [3348] "They recommended the army.  That was a great deal too smart for me."         
##  [3349] "The law was allowed to be genteel enough; many young men, who had"           
##  [3350] "chambers in the Temple, made a very good appearance in the first"            
##  [3351] "circles, and drove about town in very knowing gigs.  But I had no"           
##  [3352] "inclination for the law, even in this less abstruse study of it, which"      
##  [3353] "my family approved.  As for the navy, it had fashion on its side, but I"     
##  [3354] "was too old when the subject was first started to enter it--and, at"         
##  [3355] "length, as there was no necessity for my having any profession at all,"      
##  [3356] "as I might be as dashing and expensive without a red coat on my back as"     
##  [3357] "with one, idleness was pronounced on the whole to be most advantageous"      
##  [3358] "and honourable, and a young man of eighteen is not in general so"            
##  [3359] "earnestly bent on being busy as to resist the solicitations of his"          
##  [3360] "friends to do nothing.  I was therefore entered at Oxford and have been"     
##  [3361] "properly idle ever since.\""                                                 
##  [3362] ""                                                                            
##  [3363] "\"The consequence of which, I suppose, will be,\" said Mrs. Dashwood,"       
##  [3364] "\"since leisure has not promoted your own happiness, that your sons will"    
##  [3365] "be brought up to as many pursuits, employments, professions, and trades"     
##  [3366] "as Columella's.\""                                                           
##  [3367] ""                                                                            
##  [3368] "\"They will be brought up,\" said he, in a serious accent, \"to be as"       
##  [3369] "unlike myself as is possible.  In feeling, in action, in condition, in"      
##  [3370] "every thing.\""                                                              
##  [3371] ""                                                                            
##  [3372] "\"Come, come; this is all an effusion of immediate want of spirits,"         
##  [3373] "Edward.  You are in a melancholy humour, and fancy that any one unlike"      
##  [3374] "yourself must be happy.  But remember that the pain of parting from"         
##  [3375] "friends will be felt by every body at times, whatever be their"              
##  [3376] "education or state.  Know your own happiness.  You want nothing but"         
##  [3377] "patience--or give it a more fascinating name, call it hope.  Your"           
##  [3378] "mother will secure to you, in time, that independence you are so"            
##  [3379] "anxious for; it is her duty, and it will, it must ere long become her"       
##  [3380] "happiness to prevent your whole youth from being wasted in discontent."      
##  [3381] "How much may not a few months do?\""                                         
##  [3382] ""                                                                            
##  [3383] "\"I think,\" replied Edward, \"that I may defy many months to produce any"   
##  [3384] "good to me.\""                                                               
##  [3385] ""                                                                            
##  [3386] "This desponding turn of mind, though it could not be communicated to"        
##  [3387] "Mrs. Dashwood, gave additional pain to them all in the parting, which"       
##  [3388] "shortly took place, and left an uncomfortable impression on Elinor's"        
##  [3389] "feelings especially, which required some trouble and time to subdue."        
##  [3390] "But as it was her determination to subdue it, and to prevent herself"        
##  [3391] "from appearing to suffer more than what all her family suffered on his"      
##  [3392] "going away, she did not adopt the method so judiciously employed by"         
##  [3393] "Marianne, on a similar occasion, to augment and fix her sorrow, by"          
##  [3394] "seeking silence, solitude and idleness.  Their means were as different"      
##  [3395] "as their objects, and equally suited to the advancement of each."            
##  [3396] ""                                                                            
##  [3397] "Elinor sat down to her drawing-table as soon as he was out of the"           
##  [3398] "house, busily employed herself the whole day, neither sought nor"            
##  [3399] "avoided the mention of his name, appeared to interest herself almost as"     
##  [3400] "much as ever in the general concerns of the family, and if, by this"         
##  [3401] "conduct, she did not lessen her own grief, it was at least prevented"        
##  [3402] "from unnecessary increase, and her mother and sisters were spared much"      
##  [3403] "solicitude on her account."                                                  
##  [3404] ""                                                                            
##  [3405] "Such behaviour as this, so exactly the reverse of her own, appeared no"      
##  [3406] "more meritorious to Marianne, than her own had seemed faulty to her."        
##  [3407] "The business of self-command she settled very easily;--with strong"          
##  [3408] "affections it was impossible, with calm ones it could have no merit."        
##  [3409] "That her sister's affections WERE calm, she dared not deny, though she"      
##  [3410] "blushed to acknowledge it; and of the strength of her own, she gave a"       
##  [3411] "very striking proof, by still loving and respecting that sister, in"         
##  [3412] "spite of this mortifying conviction."                                        
##  [3413] ""                                                                            
##  [3414] "Without shutting herself up from her family, or leaving the house in"        
##  [3415] "determined solitude to avoid them, or lying awake the whole night to"        
##  [3416] "indulge meditation, Elinor found every day afforded her leisure enough"      
##  [3417] "to think of Edward, and of Edward's behaviour, in every possible"            
##  [3418] "variety which the different state of her spirits at different times"         
##  [3419] "could produce,--with tenderness, pity, approbation, censure, and doubt."     
##  [3420] "There were moments in abundance, when, if not by the absence of her"         
##  [3421] "mother and sisters, at least by the nature of their employments,"            
##  [3422] "conversation was forbidden among them, and every effect of solitude was"     
##  [3423] "produced.  Her mind was inevitably at liberty; her thoughts could not"       
##  [3424] "be chained elsewhere; and the past and the future, on a subject so"          
##  [3425] "interesting, must be before her, must force her attention, and engross"      
##  [3426] "her memory, her reflection, and her fancy."                                  
##  [3427] ""                                                                            
##  [3428] "From a reverie of this kind, as she sat at her drawing-table, she was"       
##  [3429] "roused one morning, soon after Edward's leaving them, by the arrival of"     
##  [3430] "company.  She happened to be quite alone.  The closing of the little"        
##  [3431] "gate, at the entrance of the green court in front of the house, drew"        
##  [3432] "her eyes to the window, and she saw a large party walking up to the"         
##  [3433] "door.  Amongst them were Sir John and Lady Middleton and Mrs. Jennings,"     
##  [3434] "but there were two others, a gentleman and lady, who were quite unknown"     
##  [3435] "to her.  She was sitting near the window, and as soon as Sir John"           
##  [3436] "perceived her, he left the rest of the party to the ceremony of"             
##  [3437] "knocking at the door, and stepping across the turf, obliged her to open"     
##  [3438] "the casement to speak to him, though the space was so short between the"     
##  [3439] "door and the window, as to make it hardly possible to speak at one"          
##  [3440] "without being heard at the other."                                           
##  [3441] ""                                                                            
##  [3442] "\"Well,\" said he, \"we have brought you some strangers.  How do you like"   
##  [3443] "them?\""                                                                     
##  [3444] ""                                                                            
##  [3445] "\"Hush! they will hear you.\""                                               
##  [3446] ""                                                                            
##  [3447] "\"Never mind if they do.  It is only the Palmers.  Charlotte is very"        
##  [3448] "pretty, I can tell you.  You may see her if you look this way.\""            
##  [3449] ""                                                                            
##  [3450] "As Elinor was certain of seeing her in a couple of minutes, without"         
##  [3451] "taking that liberty, she begged to be excused."                              
##  [3452] ""                                                                            
##  [3453] "\"Where is Marianne? Has she run away because we are come? I see her"        
##  [3454] "instrument is open.\""                                                       
##  [3455] ""                                                                            
##  [3456] "\"She is walking, I believe.\""                                              
##  [3457] ""                                                                            
##  [3458] "They were now joined by Mrs. Jennings, who had not patience enough to"       
##  [3459] "wait till the door was opened before she told HER story.  She came"          
##  [3460] "hallooing to the window, \"How do you do, my dear?  How does Mrs."           
##  [3461] "Dashwood do?  And where are your sisters?  What! all alone! you will be"     
##  [3462] "glad of a little company to sit with you.  I have brought my other son"      
##  [3463] "and daughter to see you.  Only think of their coming so suddenly!  I"        
##  [3464] "thought I heard a carriage last night, while we were drinking our tea,"      
##  [3465] "but it never entered my head that it could be them.  I thought of"           
##  [3466] "nothing but whether it might not be Colonel Brandon come back again; so"     
##  [3467] "I said to Sir John, I do think I hear a carriage; perhaps it is Colonel"     
##  [3468] "Brandon come back again\"--"                                                 
##  [3469] ""                                                                            
##  [3470] "Elinor was obliged to turn from her, in the middle of her story, to"         
##  [3471] "receive the rest of the party; Lady Middleton introduced the two"            
##  [3472] "strangers; Mrs. Dashwood and Margaret came down stairs at the same"          
##  [3473] "time, and they all sat down to look at one another, while Mrs. Jennings"     
##  [3474] "continued her story as she walked through the passage into the parlour,"     
##  [3475] "attended by Sir John."                                                       
##  [3476] ""                                                                            
##  [3477] "Mrs. Palmer was several years younger than Lady Middleton, and totally"      
##  [3478] "unlike her in every respect.  She was short and plump, had a very"           
##  [3479] "pretty face, and the finest expression of good humour in it that could"      
##  [3480] "possibly be.  Her manners were by no means so elegant as her sister's,"      
##  [3481] "but they were much more prepossessing.  She came in with a smile,"           
##  [3482] "smiled all the time of her visit, except when she laughed, and smiled"       
##  [3483] "when she went away.  Her husband was a grave looking young man of five"      
##  [3484] "or six and twenty, with an air of more fashion and sense than his wife,"     
##  [3485] "but of less willingness to please or be pleased.  He entered the room"       
##  [3486] "with a look of self-consequence, slightly bowed to the ladies, without"      
##  [3487] "speaking a word, and, after briefly surveying them and their"                
##  [3488] "apartments, took up a newspaper from the table, and continued to read"       
##  [3489] "it as long as he staid."                                                     
##  [3490] ""                                                                            
##  [3491] "Mrs. Palmer, on the contrary, who was strongly endowed by nature with a"     
##  [3492] "turn for being uniformly civil and happy, was hardly seated before her"      
##  [3493] "admiration of the parlour and every thing in it burst forth."                
##  [3494] ""                                                                            
##  [3495] "\"Well! what a delightful room this is! I never saw anything so"             
##  [3496] "charming!  Only think, Mama, how it is improved since I was here last!"      
##  [3497] "I always thought it such a sweet place, ma'am! (turning to Mrs."             
##  [3498] "Dashwood) but you have made it so charming!  Only look, sister, how"         
##  [3499] "delightful every thing is! How I should like such a house for myself!"       
##  [3500] "Should not you, Mr. Palmer?\""                                               
##  [3501] ""                                                                            
##  [3502] "Mr. Palmer made her no answer, and did not even raise his eyes from the"     
##  [3503] "newspaper."                                                                  
##  [3504] ""                                                                            
##  [3505] "\"Mr. Palmer does not hear me,\" said she, laughing; \"he never does"        
##  [3506] "sometimes.  It is so ridiculous!\""                                          
##  [3507] ""                                                                            
##  [3508] "This was quite a new idea to Mrs. Dashwood; she had never been used to"      
##  [3509] "find wit in the inattention of any one, and could not help looking with"     
##  [3510] "surprise at them both."                                                      
##  [3511] ""                                                                            
##  [3512] "Mrs. Jennings, in the meantime, talked on as loud as she could, and"         
##  [3513] "continued her account of their surprise, the evening before, on seeing"      
##  [3514] "their friends, without ceasing till every thing was told.  Mrs. Palmer"      
##  [3515] "laughed heartily at the recollection of their astonishment, and every"       
##  [3516] "body agreed, two or three times over, that it had been quite an"             
##  [3517] "agreeable surprise."                                                         
##  [3518] ""                                                                            
##  [3519] "\"You may believe how glad we all were to see them,\" added Mrs."            
##  [3520] "Jennings, leaning forward towards Elinor, and speaking in a low voice"       
##  [3521] "as if she meant to be heard by no one else, though they were seated on"      
##  [3522] "different sides of the room; \"but, however, I can't help wishing they"      
##  [3523] "had not travelled quite so fast, nor made such a long journey of it,"        
##  [3524] "for they came all round by London upon account of some business, for"        
##  [3525] "you know (nodding significantly and pointing to her daughter) it was"        
##  [3526] "wrong in her situation.  I wanted her to stay at home and rest this"         
##  [3527] "morning, but she would come with us; she longed so much to see you all!\""   
##  [3528] ""                                                                            
##  [3529] "Mrs. Palmer laughed, and said it would not do her any harm."                 
##  [3530] ""                                                                            
##  [3531] "\"She expects to be confined in February,\" continued Mrs. Jennings."        
##  [3532] ""                                                                            
##  [3533] "Lady Middleton could no longer endure such a conversation, and"              
##  [3534] "therefore exerted herself to ask Mr. Palmer if there was any news in"        
##  [3535] "the paper."                                                                  
##  [3536] ""                                                                            
##  [3537] "\"No, none at all,\" he replied, and read on."                               
##  [3538] ""                                                                            
##  [3539] "\"Here comes Marianne,\" cried Sir John.  \"Now, Palmer, you shall see a"    
##  [3540] "monstrous pretty girl.\""                                                    
##  [3541] ""                                                                            
##  [3542] "He immediately went into the passage, opened the front door, and"            
##  [3543] "ushered her in himself.  Mrs. Jennings asked her, as soon as she"            
##  [3544] "appeared, if she had not been to Allenham; and Mrs. Palmer laughed so"       
##  [3545] "heartily at the question, as to show she understood it.  Mr. Palmer"         
##  [3546] "looked up on her entering the room, stared at her some minutes, and"         
##  [3547] "then returned to his newspaper.  Mrs. Palmer's eye was now caught by"        
##  [3548] "the drawings which hung round the room.  She got up to examine them."        
##  [3549] ""                                                                            
##  [3550] "\"Oh! dear, how beautiful these are!  Well! how delightful!  Do but"         
##  [3551] "look, mama, how sweet! I declare they are quite charming; I could look"      
##  [3552] "at them for ever.\" And then sitting down again, she very soon forgot"       
##  [3553] "that there were any such things in the room."                                
##  [3554] ""                                                                            
##  [3555] "When Lady Middleton rose to go away, Mr. Palmer rose also, laid down"        
##  [3556] "the newspaper, stretched himself and looked at them all around."             
##  [3557] ""                                                                            
##  [3558] "\"My love, have you been asleep?\" said his wife, laughing."                 
##  [3559] ""                                                                            
##  [3560] "He made her no answer; and only observed, after again examining the"         
##  [3561] "room, that it was very low pitched, and that the ceiling was crooked."       
##  [3562] "He then made his bow, and departed with the rest."                           
##  [3563] ""                                                                            
##  [3564] "Sir John had been very urgent with them all to spend the next day at"        
##  [3565] "the park.  Mrs. Dashwood, who did not chuse to dine with them oftener"       
##  [3566] "than they dined at the cottage, absolutely refused on her own account;"      
##  [3567] "her daughters might do as they pleased.  But they had no curiosity to"       
##  [3568] "see how Mr. and Mrs. Palmer ate their dinner, and no expectation of"         
##  [3569] "pleasure from them in any other way.  They attempted, therefore,"            
##  [3570] "likewise, to excuse themselves; the weather was uncertain, and not"          
##  [3571] "likely to be good.  But Sir John would not be satisfied--the carriage"       
##  [3572] "should be sent for them and they must come.  Lady Middleton too, though"     
##  [3573] "she did not press their mother, pressed them.  Mrs. Jennings and Mrs."       
##  [3574] "Palmer joined their entreaties, all seemed equally anxious to avoid a"       
##  [3575] "family party; and the young ladies were obliged to yield."                   
##  [3576] ""                                                                            
##  [3577] "\"Why should they ask us?\" said Marianne, as soon as they were gone."       
##  [3578] "\"The rent of this cottage is said to be low; but we have it on very"        
##  [3579] "hard terms, if we are to dine at the park whenever any one is staying"       
##  [3580] "either with them, or with us.\""                                             
##  [3581] ""                                                                            
##  [3582] "\"They mean no less to be civil and kind to us now,\" said Elinor, \"by"     
##  [3583] "these frequent invitations, than by those which we received from them a"     
##  [3584] "few weeks ago.  The alteration is not in them, if their parties are"         
##  [3585] "grown tedious and dull.  We must look for the change elsewhere.\""           
##  [3586] ""                                                                            
##  [3587] ""                                                                            
##  [3588] ""                                                                            
##  [3589] "CHAPTER 20"                                                                  
##  [3590] ""                                                                            
##  [3591] ""                                                                            
##  [3592] "As the Miss Dashwoods entered the drawing-room of the park the next"         
##  [3593] "day, at one door, Mrs. Palmer came running in at the other, looking as"      
##  [3594] "good humoured and merry as before.  She took them all most"                  
##  [3595] "affectionately by the hand, and expressed great delight in seeing them"      
##  [3596] "again."                                                                      
##  [3597] ""                                                                            
##  [3598] "\"I am so glad to see you!\" said she, seating herself between Elinor and"   
##  [3599] "Marianne, \"for it is so bad a day I was afraid you might not come,"         
##  [3600] "which would be a shocking thing, as we go away again tomorrow. We must"      
##  [3601] "go, for the Westons come to us next week you know.  It was quite a"          
##  [3602] "sudden thing our coming at all, and I knew nothing of it till the"           
##  [3603] "carriage was coming to the door, and then Mr. Palmer asked me if I"          
##  [3604] "would go with him to Barton.  He is so droll! He never tells me any"         
##  [3605] "thing! I am so sorry we cannot stay longer; however we shall meet again"     
##  [3606] "in town very soon, I hope.\""                                                
##  [3607] ""                                                                            
##  [3608] "They were obliged to put an end to such an expectation."                     
##  [3609] ""                                                                            
##  [3610] "\"Not go to town!\" cried Mrs. Palmer, with a laugh, \"I shall be quite"     
##  [3611] "disappointed if you do not.  I could get the nicest house in the world for"  
##  [3612] "you, next door to ours, in Hanover-square.  You must come, indeed.  I"       
##  [3613] "am sure I shall be very happy to chaperon you at any time till I am"         
##  [3614] "confined, if Mrs. Dashwood should not like to go into public.\""             
##  [3615] ""                                                                            
##  [3616] "They thanked her; but were obliged to resist all her entreaties."            
##  [3617] ""                                                                            
##  [3618] "\"Oh, my love,\" cried Mrs. Palmer to her husband, who just then entered"    
##  [3619] "the room--\"you must help me to persuade the Miss Dashwoods to go to"        
##  [3620] "town this winter.\""                                                         
##  [3621] ""                                                                            
##  [3622] "Her love made no answer; and after slightly bowing to the ladies, began"     
##  [3623] "complaining of the weather."                                                 
##  [3624] ""                                                                            
##  [3625] "\"How horrid all this is!\" said he.  \"Such weather makes every thing and"  
##  [3626] "every body disgusting.  Dullness is as much produced within doors as"        
##  [3627] "without, by rain.  It makes one detest all one's acquaintance.  What"        
##  [3628] "the devil does Sir John mean by not having a billiard room in his"           
##  [3629] "house?  How few people know what comfort is!  Sir John is as stupid as"      
##  [3630] "the weather.\""                                                              
##  [3631] ""                                                                            
##  [3632] "The rest of the company soon dropt in."                                      
##  [3633] ""                                                                            
##  [3634] "\"I am afraid, Miss Marianne,\" said Sir John, \"you have not been able to"  
##  [3635] "take your usual walk to Allenham today.\""                                   
##  [3636] ""                                                                            
##  [3637] "Marianne looked very grave and said nothing."                                
##  [3638] ""                                                                            
##  [3639] "\"Oh, don't be so sly before us,\" said Mrs. Palmer; \"for we know all"      
##  [3640] "about it, I assure you; and I admire your taste very much, for I think"      
##  [3641] "he is extremely handsome.  We do not live a great way from him in the"       
##  [3642] "country, you know.  Not above ten miles, I dare say.\""                      
##  [3643] ""                                                                            
##  [3644] "\"Much nearer thirty,\" said her husband."                                   
##  [3645] ""                                                                            
##  [3646] "\"Ah, well! there is not much difference.  I never was at his house; but"    
##  [3647] "they say it is a sweet pretty place.\""                                      
##  [3648] ""                                                                            
##  [3649] "\"As vile a spot as I ever saw in my life,\" said Mr. Palmer."               
##  [3650] ""                                                                            
##  [3651] "Marianne remained perfectly silent, though her countenance betrayed her"     
##  [3652] "interest in what was said."                                                  
##  [3653] ""                                                                            
##  [3654] "\"Is it very ugly?\" continued Mrs. Palmer--\"then it must be some other"    
##  [3655] "place that is so pretty I suppose.\""                                        
##  [3656] ""                                                                            
##  [3657] "When they were seated in the dining room, Sir John observed with regret"     
##  [3658] "that they were only eight all together."                                     
##  [3659] ""                                                                            
##  [3660] "\"My dear,\" said he to his lady, \"it is very provoking that we should be"  
##  [3661] "so few.  Why did not you ask the Gilberts to come to us today?\""            
##  [3662] ""                                                                            
##  [3663] "\"Did not I tell you, Sir John, when you spoke to me about it before,"       
##  [3664] "that it could not be done?  They dined with us last.\""                      
##  [3665] ""                                                                            
##  [3666] "\"You and I, Sir John,\" said Mrs. Jennings, \"should not stand upon such"   
##  [3667] "ceremony.\""                                                                 
##  [3668] ""                                                                            
##  [3669] "\"Then you would be very ill-bred,\" cried Mr. Palmer."                      
##  [3670] ""                                                                            
##  [3671] "\"My love you contradict every body,\" said his wife with her usual"         
##  [3672] "laugh.  \"Do you know that you are quite rude?\""                            
##  [3673] ""                                                                            
##  [3674] "\"I did not know I contradicted any body in calling your mother"             
##  [3675] "ill-bred.\""                                                                 
##  [3676] ""                                                                            
##  [3677] "\"Ay, you may abuse me as you please,\" said the good-natured old lady,"     
##  [3678] "\"you have taken Charlotte off my hands, and cannot give her back again."    
##  [3679] "So there I have the whip hand of you.\""                                     
##  [3680] ""                                                                            
##  [3681] "Charlotte laughed heartily to think that her husband could not get rid"      
##  [3682] "of her; and exultingly said, she did not care how cross he was to her,"      
##  [3683] "as they must live together.  It was impossible for any one to be more"       
##  [3684] "thoroughly good-natured, or more determined to be happy than Mrs."           
##  [3685] "Palmer.  The studied indifference, insolence, and discontent of her"         
##  [3686] "husband gave her no pain; and when he scolded or abused her, she was"        
##  [3687] "highly diverted."                                                            
##  [3688] ""                                                                            
##  [3689] "\"Mr. Palmer is so droll!\" said she, in a whisper, to Elinor.  \"He is"     
##  [3690] "always out of humour.\""                                                     
##  [3691] ""                                                                            
##  [3692] "Elinor was not inclined, after a little observation, to give him credit"     
##  [3693] "for being so genuinely and unaffectedly ill-natured or ill-bred as he"       
##  [3694] "wished to appear.  His temper might perhaps be a little soured by"           
##  [3695] "finding, like many others of his sex, that through some unaccountable"       
##  [3696] "bias in favour of beauty, he was the husband of a very silly"                
##  [3697] "woman,--but she knew that this kind of blunder was too common for any"       
##  [3698] "sensible man to be lastingly hurt by it.-- It was rather a wish of"          
##  [3699] "distinction, she believed, which produced his contemptuous treatment of"     
##  [3700] "every body, and his general abuse of every thing before him.  It was"        
##  [3701] "the desire of appearing superior to other people.  The motive was too"       
##  [3702] "common to be wondered at; but the means, however they might succeed by"      
##  [3703] "establishing his superiority in ill-breeding, were not likely to attach"     
##  [3704] "any one to him except his wife."                                             
##  [3705] ""                                                                            
##  [3706] "\"Oh, my dear Miss Dashwood,\" said Mrs. Palmer soon afterwards, \"I have"   
##  [3707] "got such a favour to ask of you and your sister.  Will you come and"         
##  [3708] "spend some time at Cleveland this Christmas?  Now, pray do,--and come"       
##  [3709] "while the Westons are with us.  You cannot think how happy I shall be!"      
##  [3710] "It will be quite delightful!--My love,\" applying to her husband, \"don't"   
##  [3711] "you long to have the Miss Dashwoods come to Cleveland?\""                    
##  [3712] ""                                                                            
##  [3713] "\"Certainly,\" he replied, with a sneer--\"I came into Devonshire with no"   
##  [3714] "other view.\""                                                               
##  [3715] ""                                                                            
##  [3716] "\"There now,\"--said his lady, \"you see Mr. Palmer expects you; so you"     
##  [3717] "cannot refuse to come.\""                                                    
##  [3718] ""                                                                            
##  [3719] "They both eagerly and resolutely declined her invitation."                   
##  [3720] ""                                                                            
##  [3721] "\"But indeed you must and shall come.  I am sure you will like it of all"    
##  [3722] "things.  The Westons will be with us, and it will be quite delightful."      
##  [3723] "You cannot think what a sweet place Cleveland is; and we are so gay"         
##  [3724] "now, for Mr. Palmer is always going about the country canvassing"            
##  [3725] "against the election; and so many people came to dine with us that I"        
##  [3726] "never saw before, it is quite charming!  But, poor fellow! it is very"       
##  [3727] "fatiguing to him! for he is forced to make every body like him.\""           
##  [3728] ""                                                                            
##  [3729] "Elinor could hardly keep her countenance as she assented to the"             
##  [3730] "hardship of such an obligation."                                             
##  [3731] ""                                                                            
##  [3732] "\"How charming it will be,\" said Charlotte, \"when he is in"                
##  [3733] "Parliament!--won't it? How I shall laugh!  It will be so ridiculous to"      
##  [3734] "see all his letters directed to him with an M.P.--But do you know, he"       
##  [3735] "says, he will never frank for me?  He declares he won't.  Don't you,"        
##  [3736] "Mr. Palmer?\""                                                               
##  [3737] ""                                                                            
##  [3738] "Mr. Palmer took no notice of her."                                           
##  [3739] ""                                                                            
##  [3740] "\"He cannot bear writing, you know,\" she continued--\"he says it is quite"  
##  [3741] "shocking.\""                                                                 
##  [3742] ""                                                                            
##  [3743] "\"No,\" said he, \"I never said any thing so irrational.  Don't palm all"    
##  [3744] "your abuses of languages upon me.\""                                         
##  [3745] ""                                                                            
##  [3746] "\"There now; you see how droll he is.  This is always the way with him!"     
##  [3747] "Sometimes he won't speak to me for half a day together, and then he"         
##  [3748] "comes out with something so droll--all about any thing in the world.\""      
##  [3749] ""                                                                            
##  [3750] "She surprised Elinor very much as they returned into the drawing-room,"      
##  [3751] "by asking her whether she did not like Mr. Palmer excessively."              
##  [3752] ""                                                                            
##  [3753] "\"Certainly,\" said Elinor; \"he seems very agreeable.\""                    
##  [3754] ""                                                                            
##  [3755] "\"Well--I am so glad you do.  I thought you would, he is so pleasant;"       
##  [3756] "and Mr. Palmer is excessively pleased with you and your sisters I can"       
##  [3757] "tell you, and you can't think how disappointed he will be if you don't"      
##  [3758] "come to Cleveland.--I can't imagine why you should object to it.\""          
##  [3759] ""                                                                            
##  [3760] "Elinor was again obliged to decline her invitation; and by changing the"     
##  [3761] "subject, put a stop to her entreaties.  She thought it probable that as"     
##  [3762] "they lived in the same county, Mrs. Palmer might be able to give some"       
##  [3763] "more particular account of Willoughby's general character, than could"       
##  [3764] "be gathered from the Middletons' partial acquaintance with him; and she"     
##  [3765] "was eager to gain from any one, such a confirmation of his merits as"        
##  [3766] "might remove the possibility of fear from Marianne.  She began by"           
##  [3767] "inquiring if they saw much of Mr. Willoughby at Cleveland, and whether"      
##  [3768] "they were intimately acquainted with him."                                   
##  [3769] ""                                                                            
##  [3770] "\"Oh dear, yes; I know him extremely well,\" replied Mrs. Palmer;--\"Not"    
##  [3771] "that I ever spoke to him, indeed; but I have seen him for ever in town."     
##  [3772] "Somehow or other I never happened to be staying at Barton while he was"      
##  [3773] "at Allenham.  Mama saw him here once before;--but I was with my uncle"       
##  [3774] "at Weymouth.  However, I dare say we should have seen a great deal of"       
##  [3775] "him in Somersetshire, if it had not happened very unluckily that we"         
##  [3776] "should never have been in the country together.  He is very little at"       
##  [3777] "Combe, I believe; but if he were ever so much there, I do not think Mr."     
##  [3778] "Palmer would visit him, for he is in the opposition, you know, and"          
##  [3779] "besides it is such a way off.  I know why you inquire about him, very"       
##  [3780] "well; your sister is to marry him.  I am monstrous glad of it, for then"     
##  [3781] "I shall have her for a neighbour you know.\""                                
##  [3782] ""                                                                            
##  [3783] "\"Upon my word,\" replied Elinor, \"you know much more of the matter than"   
##  [3784] "I do, if you have any reason to expect such a match.\""                      
##  [3785] ""                                                                            
##  [3786] "\"Don't pretend to deny it, because you know it is what every body talks"    
##  [3787] "of.  I assure you I heard of it in my way through town.\""                   
##  [3788] ""                                                                            
##  [3789] "\"My dear Mrs. Palmer!\""                                                    
##  [3790] ""                                                                            
##  [3791] "\"Upon my honour I did.--I met Colonel Brandon Monday morning in"            
##  [3792] "Bond-street, just before we left town, and he told me of it directly.\""     
##  [3793] ""                                                                            
##  [3794] "\"You surprise me very much.  Colonel Brandon tell you of it!  Surely"       
##  [3795] "you must be mistaken.  To give such intelligence to a person who could"      
##  [3796] "not be interested in it, even if it were true, is not what I should"         
##  [3797] "expect Colonel Brandon to do.\""                                             
##  [3798] ""                                                                            
##  [3799] "\"But I do assure you it was so, for all that, and I will tell you how"      
##  [3800] "it happened.  When we met him, he turned back and walked with us; and"       
##  [3801] "so we began talking of my brother and sister, and one thing and"             
##  [3802] "another, and I said to him, 'So, Colonel, there is a new family come to"     
##  [3803] "Barton cottage, I hear, and mama sends me word they are very pretty,"        
##  [3804] "and that one of them is going to be married to Mr. Willoughby of Combe"      
##  [3805] "Magna.  Is it true, pray? for of course you must know, as you have been"     
##  [3806] "in Devonshire so lately.'\""                                                 
##  [3807] ""                                                                            
##  [3808] "\"And what did the Colonel say?\""                                           
##  [3809] ""                                                                            
##  [3810] "\"Oh--he did not say much; but he looked as if he knew it to be true, so"    
##  [3811] "from that moment I set it down as certain.  It will be quite"                
##  [3812] "delightful, I declare!  When is it to take place?\""                         
##  [3813] ""                                                                            
##  [3814] "\"Mr. Brandon was very well I hope?\""                                       
##  [3815] ""                                                                            
##  [3816] "\"Oh! yes, quite well; and so full of your praises, he did nothing but"      
##  [3817] "say fine things of you.\""                                                   
##  [3818] ""                                                                            
##  [3819] "\"I am flattered by his commendation.  He seems an excellent man; and I"     
##  [3820] "think him uncommonly pleasing.\""                                            
##  [3821] ""                                                                            
##  [3822] "\"So do I.--He is such a charming man, that it is quite a pity he should"    
##  [3823] "be so grave and so dull.  Mama says HE was in love with your sister"         
##  [3824] "too.-- I assure you it was a great compliment if he was, for he hardly"      
##  [3825] "ever falls in love with any body.\""                                         
##  [3826] ""                                                                            
##  [3827] "\"Is Mr. Willoughby much known in your part of Somersetshire?\" said"        
##  [3828] "Elinor."                                                                     
##  [3829] ""                                                                            
##  [3830] "\"Oh! yes, extremely well; that is, I do not believe many people are"        
##  [3831] "acquainted with him, because Combe Magna is so far off; but they all"        
##  [3832] "think him extremely agreeable I assure you.  Nobody is more liked than"      
##  [3833] "Mr. Willoughby wherever he goes, and so you may tell your sister.  She"      
##  [3834] "is a monstrous lucky girl to get him, upon my honour; not but that he"       
##  [3835] "is much more lucky in getting her, because she is so very handsome and"      
##  [3836] "agreeable, that nothing can be good enough for her.  However, I don't"       
##  [3837] "think her hardly at all handsomer than you, I assure you; for I think"       
##  [3838] "you both excessively pretty, and so does Mr. Palmer too I am sure,"          
##  [3839] "though we could not get him to own it last night.\""                         
##  [3840] ""                                                                            
##  [3841] "Mrs. Palmer's information respecting Willoughby was not very material;"      
##  [3842] "but any testimony in his favour, however small, was pleasing to her."        
##  [3843] ""                                                                            
##  [3844] "\"I am so glad we are got acquainted at last,\" continued"                   
##  [3845] "Charlotte.--\"And now I hope we shall always be great friends.  You"         
##  [3846] "can't think how much I longed to see you!  It is so delightful that you"     
##  [3847] "should live at the cottage!  Nothing can be like it, to be sure!  And I"     
##  [3848] "am so glad your sister is going to be well married!  I hope you will be"     
##  [3849] "a great deal at Combe Magna.  It is a sweet place, by all accounts.\""       
##  [3850] ""                                                                            
##  [3851] "\"You have been long acquainted with Colonel Brandon, have not you?\""       
##  [3852] ""                                                                            
##  [3853] "\"Yes, a great while; ever since my sister married.-- He was a"              
##  [3854] "particular friend of Sir John's. I believe,\" she added in a low voice,"     
##  [3855] "\"he would have been very glad to have had me, if he could.  Sir John"       
##  [3856] "and Lady Middleton wished it very much.  But mama did not think the"         
##  [3857] "match good enough for me, otherwise Sir John would have mentioned it to"     
##  [3858] "the Colonel, and we should have been married immediately.\""                 
##  [3859] ""                                                                            
##  [3860] "\"Did not Colonel Brandon know of Sir John's proposal to your mother"        
##  [3861] "before it was made?  Had he never owned his affection to yourself?\""        
##  [3862] ""                                                                            
##  [3863] "\"Oh, no; but if mama had not objected to it, I dare say he would have"      
##  [3864] "liked it of all things.  He had not seen me then above twice, for it"        
##  [3865] "was before I left school.  However, I am much happier as I am.  Mr."         
##  [3866] "Palmer is the kind of man I like.\""                                         
##  [3867] ""                                                                            
##  [3868] ""                                                                            
##  [3869] ""                                                                            
##  [3870] "CHAPTER 21"                                                                  
##  [3871] ""                                                                            
##  [3872] ""                                                                            
##  [3873] "The Palmers returned to Cleveland the next day, and the two families at"     
##  [3874] "Barton were again left to entertain each other.  But this did not last"      
##  [3875] "long; Elinor had hardly got their last visitors out of her head, had"        
##  [3876] "hardly done wondering at Charlotte's being so happy without a cause, at"     
##  [3877] "Mr. Palmer's acting so simply, with good abilities, and at the strange"      
##  [3878] "unsuitableness which often existed between husband and wife, before Sir"     
##  [3879] "John's and Mrs. Jennings's active zeal in the cause of society,"             
##  [3880] "procured her some other new acquaintance to see and observe."                
##  [3881] ""                                                                            
##  [3882] "In a morning's excursion to Exeter, they had met with two young ladies,"     
##  [3883] "whom Mrs. Jennings had the satisfaction of discovering to be her"            
##  [3884] "relations, and this was enough for Sir John to invite them directly to"      
##  [3885] "the park, as soon as their present engagements at Exeter were over."         
##  [3886] "Their engagements at Exeter instantly gave way before such an"               
##  [3887] "invitation, and Lady Middleton was thrown into no little alarm on the"       
##  [3888] "return of Sir John, by hearing that she was very soon to receive a"          
##  [3889] "visit from two girls whom she had never seen in her life, and of whose"      
##  [3890] "elegance,--whose tolerable gentility even, she could have no proof; for"     
##  [3891] "the assurances of her husband and mother on that subject went for"           
##  [3892] "nothing at all.  Their being her relations too made it so much the"          
##  [3893] "worse; and Mrs. Jennings's attempts at consolation were therefore"           
##  [3894] "unfortunately founded, when she advised her daughter not to care about"      
##  [3895] "their being so fashionable; because they were all cousins and must put"      
##  [3896] "up with one another.  As it was impossible, however, now to prevent"         
##  [3897] "their coming, Lady Middleton resigned herself to the idea of it, with"       
##  [3898] "all the philosophy of a well-bred woman, contenting herself with merely"     
##  [3899] "giving her husband a gentle reprimand on the subject five or six times"      
##  [3900] "every day."                                                                  
##  [3901] ""                                                                            
##  [3902] "The young ladies arrived: their appearance was by no means ungenteel or"     
##  [3903] "unfashionable.  Their dress was very smart, their manners very civil,"       
##  [3904] "they were delighted with the house, and in raptures with the furniture,"     
##  [3905] "and they happened to be so doatingly fond of children that Lady"             
##  [3906] "Middleton's good opinion was engaged in their favour before they had"        
##  [3907] "been an hour at the Park.  She declared them to be very agreeable girls"     
##  [3908] "indeed, which for her ladyship was enthusiastic admiration.  Sir John's"     
##  [3909] "confidence in his own judgment rose with this animated praise, and he"       
##  [3910] "set off directly for the cottage to tell the Miss Dashwoods of the Miss"     
##  [3911] "Steeles' arrival, and to assure them of their being the sweetest girls"      
##  [3912] "in the world.  From such commendation as this, however, there was not"       
##  [3913] "much to be learned; Elinor well knew that the sweetest girls in the"         
##  [3914] "world were to be met with in every part of England, under every"             
##  [3915] "possible variation of form, face, temper and understanding.  Sir John"       
##  [3916] "wanted the whole family to walk to the Park directly and look at his"        
##  [3917] "guests.  Benevolent, philanthropic man!  It was painful to him even to"      
##  [3918] "keep a third cousin to himself."                                             
##  [3919] ""                                                                            
##  [3920] "\"Do come now,\" said he--\"pray come--you must come--I declare you shall"   
##  [3921] "come--You can't think how you will like them.  Lucy is monstrous"            
##  [3922] "pretty, and so good humoured and agreeable!  The children are all"           
##  [3923] "hanging about her already, as if she was an old acquaintance.  And they"     
##  [3924] "both long to see you of all things, for they have heard at Exeter that"      
##  [3925] "you are the most beautiful creatures in the world; and I have told them"     
##  [3926] "it is all very true, and a great deal more.  You will be delighted with"     
##  [3927] "them I am sure.  They have brought the whole coach full of playthings"       
##  [3928] "for the children.  How can you be so cross as not to come?  Why they"        
##  [3929] "are your cousins, you know, after a fashion.  YOU are my cousins, and"       
##  [3930] "they are my wife's, so you must be related.\""                               
##  [3931] ""                                                                            
##  [3932] "But Sir John could not prevail.  He could only obtain a promise of"          
##  [3933] "their calling at the Park within a day or two, and then left them in"        
##  [3934] "amazement at their indifference, to walk home and boast anew of their"       
##  [3935] "attractions to the Miss Steeles, as he had been already boasting of the"     
##  [3936] "Miss Steeles to them."                                                       
##  [3937] ""                                                                            
##  [3938] "When their promised visit to the Park and consequent introduction to"        
##  [3939] "these young ladies took place, they found in the appearance of the"          
##  [3940] "eldest, who was nearly thirty, with a very plain and not a sensible"         
##  [3941] "face, nothing to admire; but in the other, who was not more than two or"     
##  [3942] "three and twenty, they acknowledged considerable beauty; her features"       
##  [3943] "were pretty, and she had a sharp quick eye, and a smartness of air,"         
##  [3944] "which though it did not give actual elegance or grace, gave distinction"     
##  [3945] "to her person.-- Their manners were particularly civil, and Elinor soon"     
##  [3946] "allowed them credit for some kind of sense, when she saw with what"          
##  [3947] "constant and judicious attention they were making themselves agreeable"      
##  [3948] "to Lady Middleton.  With her children they were in continual raptures,"      
##  [3949] "extolling their beauty, courting their notice, and humouring their"          
##  [3950] "whims; and such of their time as could be spared from the importunate"       
##  [3951] "demands which this politeness made on it, was spent in admiration of"        
##  [3952] "whatever her ladyship was doing, if she happened to be doing any thing,"     
##  [3953] "or in taking patterns of some elegant new dress, in which her"               
##  [3954] "appearance the day before had thrown them into unceasing delight."           
##  [3955] "Fortunately for those who pay their court through such foibles, a fond"      
##  [3956] "mother, though, in pursuit of praise for her children, the most"             
##  [3957] "rapacious of human beings, is likewise the most credulous; her demands"      
##  [3958] "are exorbitant; but she will swallow any thing; and the excessive"           
##  [3959] "affection and endurance of the Miss Steeles towards her offspring were"      
##  [3960] "viewed therefore by Lady Middleton without the smallest surprise or"         
##  [3961] "distrust.  She saw with maternal complacency all the impertinent"            
##  [3962] "encroachments and mischievous tricks to which her cousins submitted."        
##  [3963] "She saw their sashes untied, their hair pulled about their ears, their"      
##  [3964] "work-bags searched, and their knives and scissors stolen away, and felt"     
##  [3965] "no doubt of its being a reciprocal enjoyment.  It suggested no other"        
##  [3966] "surprise than that Elinor and Marianne should sit so composedly by,"         
##  [3967] "without claiming a share in what was passing."                               
##  [3968] ""                                                                            
##  [3969] "\"John is in such spirits today!\" said she, on his taking Miss Steeles's"   
##  [3970] "pocket handkerchief, and throwing it out of window--\"He is full of"         
##  [3971] "monkey tricks.\""                                                            
##  [3972] ""                                                                            
##  [3973] "And soon afterwards, on the second boy's violently pinching one of the"      
##  [3974] "same lady's fingers, she fondly observed, \"How playful William is!\""       
##  [3975] ""                                                                            
##  [3976] "\"And here is my sweet little Annamaria,\" she added, tenderly caressing"    
##  [3977] "a little girl of three years old, who had not made a noise for the last"     
##  [3978] "two minutes; \"And she is always so gentle and quiet--Never was there"       
##  [3979] "such a quiet little thing!\""                                                
##  [3980] ""                                                                            
##  [3981] "But unfortunately in bestowing these embraces, a pin in her ladyship's"      
##  [3982] "head dress slightly scratching the child's neck, produced from this"         
##  [3983] "pattern of gentleness such violent screams, as could hardly be outdone"      
##  [3984] "by any creature professedly noisy.  The mother's consternation was"          
##  [3985] "excessive; but it could not surpass the alarm of the Miss Steeles, and"      
##  [3986] "every thing was done by all three, in so critical an emergency, which"       
##  [3987] "affection could suggest as likely to assuage the agonies of the little"      
##  [3988] "sufferer.  She was seated in her mother's lap, covered with kisses, her"     
##  [3989] "wound bathed with lavender-water, by one of the Miss Steeles, who was"       
##  [3990] "on her knees to attend her, and her mouth stuffed with sugar plums by"       
##  [3991] "the other.  With such a reward for her tears, the child was too wise to"     
##  [3992] "cease crying.  She still screamed and sobbed lustily, kicked her two"        
##  [3993] "brothers for offering to touch her, and all their united soothings were"     
##  [3994] "ineffectual till Lady Middleton luckily remembering that in a scene of"      
##  [3995] "similar distress last week, some apricot marmalade had been"                 
##  [3996] "successfully applied for a bruised temple, the same remedy was eagerly"      
##  [3997] "proposed for this unfortunate scratch, and a slight intermission of"         
##  [3998] "screams in the young lady on hearing it, gave them reason to hope that"      
##  [3999] "it would not be rejected.-- She was carried out of the room therefore"       
##  [4000] "in her mother's arms, in quest of this medicine, and as the two boys"        
##  [4001] "chose to follow, though earnestly entreated by their mother to stay"         
##  [4002] "behind, the four young ladies were left in a quietness which the room"       
##  [4003] "had not known for many hours."                                               
##  [4004] ""                                                                            
##  [4005] "\"Poor little creatures!\" said Miss Steele, as soon as they were gone."     
##  [4006] "\"It might have been a very sad accident.\""                                 
##  [4007] ""                                                                            
##  [4008] "\"Yet I hardly know how,\" cried Marianne, \"unless it had been under"       
##  [4009] "totally different circumstances.  But this is the usual way of"              
##  [4010] "heightening alarm, where there is nothing to be alarmed at in reality.\""    
##  [4011] ""                                                                            
##  [4012] "\"What a sweet woman Lady Middleton is!\" said Lucy Steele."                 
##  [4013] ""                                                                            
##  [4014] "Marianne was silent; it was impossible for her to say what she did not"      
##  [4015] "feel, however trivial the occasion; and upon Elinor therefore the whole"     
##  [4016] "task of telling lies when politeness required it, always fell.  She did"     
##  [4017] "her best when thus called on, by speaking of Lady Middleton with more"       
##  [4018] "warmth than she felt, though with far less than Miss Lucy."                  
##  [4019] ""                                                                            
##  [4020] "\"And Sir John too,\" cried the elder sister, \"what a charming man he is!\""
##  [4021] ""                                                                            
##  [4022] "Here too, Miss Dashwood's commendation, being only simple and just,"         
##  [4023] "came in without any eclat.  She merely observed that he was perfectly"       
##  [4024] "good humoured and friendly."                                                 
##  [4025] ""                                                                            
##  [4026] "\"And what a charming little family they have!  I never saw such fine"       
##  [4027] "children in my life.--I declare I quite doat upon them already, and"         
##  [4028] "indeed I am always distractedly fond of children.\""                         
##  [4029] ""                                                                            
##  [4030] "\"I should guess so,\" said Elinor, with a smile, \"from what I have"        
##  [4031] "witnessed this morning.\""                                                   
##  [4032] ""                                                                            
##  [4033] "\"I have a notion,\" said Lucy, \"you think the little Middletons rather"    
##  [4034] "too much indulged; perhaps they may be the outside of enough; but it is"     
##  [4035] "so natural in Lady Middleton; and for my part, I love to see children"       
##  [4036] "full of life and spirits; I cannot bear them if they are tame and"           
##  [4037] "quiet.\""                                                                    
##  [4038] ""                                                                            
##  [4039] "\"I confess,\" replied Elinor, \"that while I am at Barton Park, I never"    
##  [4040] "think of tame and quiet children with any abhorrence.\""                     
##  [4041] ""                                                                            
##  [4042] "A short pause succeeded this speech, which was first broken by Miss"         
##  [4043] "Steele, who seemed very much disposed for conversation, and who now"         
##  [4044] "said rather abruptly, \"And how do you like Devonshire, Miss Dashwood?"      
##  [4045] "I suppose you were very sorry to leave Sussex.\""                            
##  [4046] ""                                                                            
##  [4047] "In some surprise at the familiarity of this question, or at least of"        
##  [4048] "the manner in which it was spoken, Elinor replied that she was."             
##  [4049] ""                                                                            
##  [4050] "\"Norland is a prodigious beautiful place, is not it?\" added Miss Steele."  
##  [4051] ""                                                                            
##  [4052] "\"We have heard Sir John admire it excessively,\" said Lucy, who seemed"     
##  [4053] "to think some apology necessary for the freedom of her sister."              
##  [4054] ""                                                                            
##  [4055] "\"I think every one MUST admire it,\" replied Elinor, \"who ever saw the"    
##  [4056] "place; though it is not to be supposed that any one can estimate its"        
##  [4057] "beauties as we do.\""                                                        
##  [4058] ""                                                                            
##  [4059] "\"And had you a great many smart beaux there?  I suppose you have not so"    
##  [4060] "many in this part of the world; for my part, I think they are a vast"        
##  [4061] "addition always.\""                                                          
##  [4062] ""                                                                            
##  [4063] "\"But why should you think,\" said Lucy, looking ashamed of her sister,"     
##  [4064] "\"that there are not as many genteel young men in Devonshire as Sussex?\""   
##  [4065] ""                                                                            
##  [4066] "\"Nay, my dear, I'm sure I don't pretend to say that there an't.  I'm"       
##  [4067] "sure there's a vast many smart beaux in Exeter; but you know, how could"     
##  [4068] "I tell what smart beaux there might be about Norland; and I was only"        
##  [4069] "afraid the Miss Dashwoods might find it dull at Barton, if they had not"     
##  [4070] "so many as they used to have.  But perhaps you young ladies may not"         
##  [4071] "care about the beaux, and had as lief be without them as with them."         
##  [4072] "For my part, I think they are vastly agreeable, provided they dress"         
##  [4073] "smart and behave civil.  But I can't bear to see them dirty and nasty."      
##  [4074] "Now there's Mr. Rose at Exeter, a prodigious smart young man, quite a"       
##  [4075] "beau, clerk to Mr. Simpson, you know, and yet if you do but meet him of"     
##  [4076] "a morning, he is not fit to be seen.-- I suppose your brother was quite"     
##  [4077] "a beau, Miss Dashwood, before he married, as he was so rich?\""              
##  [4078] ""                                                                            
##  [4079] "\"Upon my word,\" replied Elinor, \"I cannot tell you, for I do not"         
##  [4080] "perfectly comprehend the meaning of the word.  But this I can say, that"     
##  [4081] "if he ever was a beau before he married, he is one still for there is"       
##  [4082] "not the smallest alteration in him.\""                                       
##  [4083] ""                                                                            
##  [4084] "\"Oh! dear! one never thinks of married men's being beaux--they have"        
##  [4085] "something else to do.\""                                                     
##  [4086] ""                                                                            
##  [4087] "\"Lord! Anne,\" cried her sister, \"you can talk of nothing but"             
##  [4088] "beaux;--you will make Miss Dashwood believe you think of nothing else.\""    
##  [4089] "And then to turn the discourse, she began admiring the house and the"        
##  [4090] "furniture."                                                                  
##  [4091] ""                                                                            
##  [4092] "This specimen of the Miss Steeles was enough.  The vulgar freedom and"       
##  [4093] "folly of the eldest left her no recommendation, and as Elinor was not"       
##  [4094] "blinded by the beauty, or the shrewd look of the youngest, to her want"      
##  [4095] "of real elegance and artlessness, she left the house without any wish"       
##  [4096] "of knowing them better."                                                     
##  [4097] ""                                                                            
##  [4098] "Not so the Miss Steeles.--They came from Exeter, well provided with"         
##  [4099] "admiration for the use of Sir John Middleton, his family, and all his"       
##  [4100] "relations, and no niggardly proportion was now dealt out to his fair"        
##  [4101] "cousins, whom they declared to be the most beautiful, elegant,"              
##  [4102] "accomplished, and agreeable girls they had ever beheld, and with whom"       
##  [4103] "they were particularly anxious to be better acquainted.-- And to be"         
##  [4104] "better acquainted therefore, Elinor soon found was their inevitable"         
##  [4105] "lot, for as Sir John was entirely on the side of the Miss Steeles,"          
##  [4106] "their party would be too strong for opposition, and that kind of"            
##  [4107] "intimacy must be submitted to, which consists of sitting an hour or two"     
##  [4108] "together in the same room almost every day.  Sir John could do no more;"     
##  [4109] "but he did not know that any more was required: to be together was, in"      
##  [4110] "his opinion, to be intimate, and while his continual schemes for their"      
##  [4111] "meeting were effectual, he had not a doubt of their being established"       
##  [4112] "friends."                                                                    
##  [4113] ""                                                                            
##  [4114] "To do him justice, he did every thing in his power to promote their"         
##  [4115] "unreserve, by making the Miss Steeles acquainted with whatever he knew"      
##  [4116] "or supposed of his cousins' situations in the most delicate"                 
##  [4117] "particulars,--and Elinor had not seen them more than twice, before the"      
##  [4118] "eldest of them wished her joy on her sister's having been so lucky as"       
##  [4119] "to make a conquest of a very smart beau since she came to Barton."           
##  [4120] ""                                                                            
##  [4121] "\"'Twill be a fine thing to have her married so young to be sure,\" said"    
##  [4122] "she, \"and I hear he is quite a beau, and prodigious handsome.  And I"       
##  [4123] "hope you may have as good luck yourself soon,--but perhaps you may have"     
##  [4124] "a friend in the corner already.\""                                           
##  [4125] ""                                                                            
##  [4126] "Elinor could not suppose that Sir John would be more nice in"                
##  [4127] "proclaiming his suspicions of her regard for Edward, than he had been"       
##  [4128] "with respect to Marianne; indeed it was rather his favourite joke of"        
##  [4129] "the two, as being somewhat newer and more conjectural; and since"            
##  [4130] "Edward's visit, they had never dined together without his drinking to"       
##  [4131] "her best affections with so much significancy and so many nods and"          
##  [4132] "winks, as to excite general attention.  The letter F--had been likewise"     
##  [4133] "invariably brought forward, and found productive of such countless"          
##  [4134] "jokes, that its character as the wittiest letter in the alphabet had"        
##  [4135] "been long established with Elinor."                                          
##  [4136] ""                                                                            
##  [4137] "The Miss Steeles, as she expected, had now all the benefit of these"         
##  [4138] "jokes, and in the eldest of them they raised a curiosity to know the"
