##  [4139] "name of the gentleman alluded to, which, though often impertinently"         
##  [4140] "expressed, was perfectly of a piece with her general inquisitiveness"        
##  [4141] "into the concerns of their family.  But Sir John did not sport long"         
##  [4142] "with the curiosity which he delighted to raise, for he had at least as"      
##  [4143] "much pleasure in telling the name, as Miss Steele had in hearing it."        
##  [4144] ""                                                                            
##  [4145] "\"His name is Ferrars,\" said he, in a very audible whisper; \"but pray do"  
##  [4146] "not tell it, for it's a great secret.\""                                     
##  [4147] ""                                                                            
##  [4148] "\"Ferrars!\" repeated Miss Steele; \"Mr. Ferrars is the happy man, is he?"   
##  [4149] "What! your sister-in-law's brother, Miss Dashwood? a very agreeable"         
##  [4150] "young man to be sure; I know him very well.\""                               
##  [4151] ""                                                                            
##  [4152] "\"How can you say so, Anne?\" cried Lucy, who generally made an amendment"   
##  [4153] "to all her sister's assertions.  \"Though we have seen him once or twice"    
##  [4154] "at my uncle's, it is rather too much to pretend to know him very well.\""    
##  [4155] ""                                                                            
##  [4156] "Elinor heard all this with attention and surprise.  \"And who was this"      
##  [4157] "uncle?  Where did he live?  How came they acquainted?\"  She wished very"    
##  [4158] "much to have the subject continued, though she did not chuse to join in"     
##  [4159] "it herself; but nothing more of it was said, and for the first time in"      
##  [4160] "her life, she thought Mrs. Jennings deficient either in curiosity after"     
##  [4161] "petty information, or in a disposition to communicate it.  The manner"       
##  [4162] "in which Miss Steele had spoken of Edward, increased her curiosity; for"     
##  [4163] "it struck her as being rather ill-natured, and suggested the suspicion"      
##  [4164] "of that lady's knowing, or fancying herself to know something to his"        
##  [4165] "disadvantage.--But her curiosity was unavailing, for no farther notice"      
##  [4166] "was taken of Mr. Ferrars's name by Miss Steele when alluded to, or even"     
##  [4167] "openly mentioned by Sir John."                                               
##  [4168] ""                                                                            
##  [4169] ""                                                                            
##  [4170] ""                                                                            
##  [4171] "CHAPTER 22"                                                                  
##  [4172] ""                                                                            
##  [4173] ""                                                                            
##  [4174] "Marianne, who had never much toleration for any thing like"                  
##  [4175] "impertinence, vulgarity, inferiority of parts, or even difference of"        
##  [4176] "taste from herself, was at this time particularly ill-disposed, from"        
##  [4177] "the state of her spirits, to be pleased with the Miss Steeles, or to"        
##  [4178] "encourage their advances; and to the invariable coldness of her"             
##  [4179] "behaviour towards them, which checked every endeavour at intimacy on"        
##  [4180] "their side, Elinor principally attributed that preference of herself"        
##  [4181] "which soon became evident in the manners of both, but especially of"         
##  [4182] "Lucy, who missed no opportunity of engaging her in conversation, or of"      
##  [4183] "striving to improve their acquaintance by an easy and frank"                 
##  [4184] "communication of her sentiments."                                            
##  [4185] ""                                                                            
##  [4186] "Lucy was naturally clever; her remarks were often just and amusing; and"     
##  [4187] "as a companion for half an hour Elinor frequently found her agreeable;"      
##  [4188] "but her powers had received no aid from education: she was ignorant and"     
##  [4189] "illiterate; and her deficiency of all mental improvement, her want of"       
##  [4190] "information in the most common particulars, could not be concealed from"     
##  [4191] "Miss Dashwood, in spite of her constant endeavour to appear to"              
##  [4192] "advantage.  Elinor saw, and pitied her for, the neglect of abilities"        
##  [4193] "which education might have rendered so respectable; but she saw, with"       
##  [4194] "less tenderness of feeling, the thorough want of delicacy, of"               
##  [4195] "rectitude, and integrity of mind, which her attentions, her"                 
##  [4196] "assiduities, her flatteries at the Park betrayed; and she could have no"     
##  [4197] "lasting satisfaction in the company of a person who joined insincerity"      
##  [4198] "with ignorance; whose want of instruction prevented their meeting in"        
##  [4199] "conversation on terms of equality, and whose conduct toward others made"     
##  [4200] "every shew of attention and deference towards herself perfectly"             
##  [4201] "valueless."                                                                  
##  [4202] ""                                                                            
##  [4203] "\"You will think my question an odd one, I dare say,\" said Lucy to her"     
##  [4204] "one day, as they were walking together from the park to the"                 
##  [4205] "cottage--\"but pray, are you personally acquainted with your"                
##  [4206] "sister-in-law's mother, Mrs. Ferrars?\""                                     
##  [4207] ""                                                                            
##  [4208] "Elinor DID think the question a very odd one, and her countenance"           
##  [4209] "expressed it, as she answered that she had never seen Mrs. Ferrars."         
##  [4210] ""                                                                            
##  [4211] "\"Indeed!\" replied Lucy; \"I wonder at that, for I thought you must have"   
##  [4212] "seen her at Norland sometimes.  Then, perhaps, you cannot tell me what"      
##  [4213] "sort of a woman she is?\""                                                   
##  [4214] ""                                                                            
##  [4215] "\"No,\" returned Elinor, cautious of giving her real opinion of Edward's"    
##  [4216] "mother, and not very desirous of satisfying what seemed impertinent"         
##  [4217] "curiosity-- \"I know nothing of her.\""                                      
##  [4218] ""                                                                            
##  [4219] "\"I am sure you think me very strange, for enquiring about her in such a"    
##  [4220] "way,\" said Lucy, eyeing Elinor attentively as she spoke; \"but perhaps"     
##  [4221] "there may be reasons--I wish I might venture; but however I hope you"        
##  [4222] "will do me the justice of believing that I do not mean to be"                
##  [4223] "impertinent.\""                                                              
##  [4224] ""                                                                            
##  [4225] "Elinor made her a civil reply, and they walked on for a few minutes in"      
##  [4226] "silence.  It was broken by Lucy, who renewed the subject again by"           
##  [4227] "saying, with some hesitation,"                                               
##  [4228] ""                                                                            
##  [4229] "\"I cannot bear to have you think me impertinently curious.  I am sure I"    
##  [4230] "would rather do any thing in the world than be thought so by a person"       
##  [4231] "whose good opinion is so well worth having as yours.  And I am sure I"       
##  [4232] "should not have the smallest fear of trusting YOU; indeed, I should be"      
##  [4233] "very glad of your advice how to manage in such an uncomfortable"             
##  [4234] "situation as I am; but, however, there is no occasion to trouble YOU."       
##  [4235] "I am sorry you do not happen to know Mrs. Ferrars.\""                        
##  [4236] ""                                                                            
##  [4237] "\"I am sorry I do NOT,\" said Elinor, in great astonishment, \"if it could"  
##  [4238] "be of any use to YOU to know my opinion of her.  But really I never"         
##  [4239] "understood that you were at all connected with that family, and"             
##  [4240] "therefore I am a little surprised, I confess, at so serious an inquiry"      
##  [4241] "into her character.\""                                                       
##  [4242] ""                                                                            
##  [4243] "\"I dare say you are, and I am sure I do not at all wonder at it.  But"      
##  [4244] "if I dared tell you all, you would not be so much surprised.  Mrs."          
##  [4245] "Ferrars is certainly nothing to me at present--but the time MAY"             
##  [4246] "come--how soon it will come must depend upon herself--when we may be"        
##  [4247] "very intimately connected.\""                                                
##  [4248] ""                                                                            
##  [4249] "She looked down as she said this, amiably bashful, with only one side"       
##  [4250] "glance at her companion to observe its effect on her."                       
##  [4251] ""                                                                            
##  [4252] "\"Good heavens!\" cried Elinor, \"what do you mean?  Are you acquainted"     
##  [4253] "with Mr. Robert Ferrars?  Can you be?\" And she did not feel much"           
##  [4254] "delighted with the idea of such a sister-in-law."                            
##  [4255] ""                                                                            
##  [4256] "\"No,\" replied Lucy, \"not to Mr. ROBERT Ferrars--I never saw him in my"    
##  [4257] "life; but,\" fixing her eyes upon Elinor, \"to his eldest brother.\""        
##  [4258] ""                                                                            
##  [4259] "What felt Elinor at that moment? Astonishment, that would have been as"      
##  [4260] "painful as it was strong, had not an immediate disbelief of the"             
##  [4261] "assertion attended it.  She turned towards Lucy in silent amazement,"        
##  [4262] "unable to divine the reason or object of such a declaration; and though"     
##  [4263] "her complexion varied, she stood firm in incredulity, and felt in no"        
##  [4264] "danger of an hysterical fit, or a swoon."                                    
##  [4265] ""                                                                            
##  [4266] "\"You may well be surprised,\" continued Lucy; \"for to be sure you could"   
##  [4267] "have had no idea of it before; for I dare say he never dropped the"          
##  [4268] "smallest hint of it to you or any of your family; because it was always"     
##  [4269] "meant to be a great secret, and I am sure has been faithfully kept so"       
##  [4270] "by me to this hour.  Not a soul of all my relations know of it but"          
##  [4271] "Anne, and I never should have mentioned it to you, if I had not felt"        
##  [4272] "the greatest dependence in the world upon your secrecy; and I really"        
##  [4273] "thought my behaviour in asking so many questions about Mrs. Ferrars"         
##  [4274] "must seem so odd, that it ought to be explained.  And I do not think"        
##  [4275] "Mr. Ferrars can be displeased, when he knows I have trusted you,"            
##  [4276] "because I know he has the highest opinion in the world of all your"          
##  [4277] "family, and looks upon yourself and the other Miss Dashwoods quite as"       
##  [4278] "his own sisters.\"--She paused."                                             
##  [4279] ""                                                                            
##  [4280] "Elinor for a few moments remained silent.  Her astonishment at what she"     
##  [4281] "heard was at first too great for words; but at length forcing herself"       
##  [4282] "to speak, and to speak cautiously, she said, with calmness of manner,"       
##  [4283] "which tolerably well concealed her surprise and solicitude-- \"May I ask"    
##  [4284] "if your engagement is of long standing?\""                                   
##  [4285] ""                                                                            
##  [4286] "\"We have been engaged these four years.\""                                  
##  [4287] ""                                                                            
##  [4288] "\"Four years!\""                                                             
##  [4289] ""                                                                            
##  [4290] "\"Yes.\""                                                                    
##  [4291] ""                                                                            
##  [4292] "Elinor, though greatly shocked, still felt unable to believe it."            
##  [4293] ""                                                                            
##  [4294] "\"I did not know,\" said she, \"that you were even acquainted till the"      
##  [4295] "other day.\""                                                                
##  [4296] ""                                                                            
##  [4297] "\"Our acquaintance, however, is of many years date.  He was under my"        
##  [4298] "uncle's care, you know, a considerable while.\""                             
##  [4299] ""                                                                            
##  [4300] "\"Your uncle!\""                                                             
##  [4301] ""                                                                            
##  [4302] "\"Yes; Mr. Pratt.  Did you never hear him talk of Mr. Pratt?\""              
##  [4303] ""                                                                            
##  [4304] "\"I think I have,\" replied Elinor, with an exertion of spirits, which"      
##  [4305] "increased with her increase of emotion."                                     
##  [4306] ""                                                                            
##  [4307] "\"He was four years with my uncle, who lives at Longstaple, near"            
##  [4308] "Plymouth.  It was there our acquaintance begun, for my sister and me"        
##  [4309] "was often staying with my uncle, and it was there our engagement was"        
##  [4310] "formed, though not till a year after he had quitted as a pupil; but he"      
##  [4311] "was almost always with us afterwards.  I was very unwilling to enter"        
##  [4312] "into it, as you may imagine, without the knowledge and approbation of"       
##  [4313] "his mother; but I was too young, and loved him too well, to be so"           
##  [4314] "prudent as I ought to have been.-- Though you do not know him so well"       
##  [4315] "as me, Miss Dashwood, you must have seen enough of him to be sensible"       
##  [4316] "he is very capable of making a woman sincerely attached to him.\""           
##  [4317] ""                                                                            
##  [4318] "\"Certainly,\" answered Elinor, without knowing what she said; but after"    
##  [4319] "a moment's reflection, she added, with revived security of Edward's"         
##  [4320] "honour and love, and her companion's falsehood--\"Engaged to Mr. Edward"     
##  [4321] "Ferrars!--I confess myself so totally surprised at what you tell me,"        
##  [4322] "that really--I beg your pardon; but surely there must be some mistake"       
##  [4323] "of person or name.  We cannot mean the same Mr. Ferrars.\""                  
##  [4324] ""                                                                            
##  [4325] "\"We can mean no other,\" cried Lucy, smiling.  \"Mr. Edward Ferrars, the"   
##  [4326] "eldest son of Mrs. Ferrars, of Park Street, and brother of your"             
##  [4327] "sister-in-law, Mrs. John Dashwood, is the person I mean; you must allow"     
##  [4328] "that I am not likely to be deceived as to the name of the man on who"        
##  [4329] "all my happiness depends.\""                                                 
##  [4330] ""                                                                            
##  [4331] "\"It is strange,\" replied Elinor, in a most painful perplexity, \"that I"   
##  [4332] "should never have heard him even mention your name.\""                       
##  [4333] ""                                                                            
##  [4334] "\"No; considering our situation, it was not strange.  Our first care has"    
##  [4335] "been to keep the matter secret.-- You knew nothing of me, or my family,"     
##  [4336] "and, therefore, there could be no OCCASION for ever mentioning my name"      
##  [4337] "to you; and, as he was always particularly afraid of his sister's"           
##  [4338] "suspecting any thing, THAT was reason enough for his not mentioning it.\""   
##  [4339] ""                                                                            
##  [4340] "She was silent.--Elinor's security sunk; but her self-command did not"       
##  [4341] "sink with it."                                                               
##  [4342] ""                                                                            
##  [4343] "\"Four years you have been engaged,\" said she with a firm voice."           
##  [4344] ""                                                                            
##  [4345] "\"Yes; and heaven knows how much longer we may have to wait.  Poor"          
##  [4346] "Edward!  It puts him quite out of heart.\" Then taking a small miniature"    
##  [4347] "from her pocket, she added, \"To prevent the possibility of mistake, be"     
##  [4348] "so good as to look at this face.  It does not do him justice, to be"         
##  [4349] "sure, but yet I think you cannot be deceived as to the person it was"        
##  [4350] "drew for.--I have had it above these three years.\""                         
##  [4351] ""                                                                            
##  [4352] "She put it into her hands as she spoke; and when Elinor saw the"             
##  [4353] "painting, whatever other doubts her fear of a too hasty decision, or"        
##  [4354] "her wish of detecting falsehood might suffer to linger in her mind, she"     
##  [4355] "could have none of its being Edward's face.  She returned it almost"         
##  [4356] "instantly, acknowledging the likeness."                                      
##  [4357] ""                                                                            
##  [4358] "\"I have never been able,\" continued Lucy, \"to give him my picture in"     
##  [4359] "return, which I am very much vexed at, for he has been always so"            
##  [4360] "anxious to get it!  But I am determined to set for it the very first"        
##  [4361] "opportunity.\""                                                              
##  [4362] ""                                                                            
##  [4363] "\"You are quite in the right,\" replied Elinor calmly.  They then"           
##  [4364] "proceeded a few paces in silence.  Lucy spoke first."                        
##  [4365] ""                                                                            
##  [4366] "\"I am sure,\" said she, \"I have no doubt in the world of your faithfully"  
##  [4367] "keeping this secret, because you must know of what importance it is to"      
##  [4368] "us, not to have it reach his mother; for she would never approve of it,"     
##  [4369] "I dare say.  I shall have no fortune, and I fancy she is an exceeding"       
##  [4370] "proud woman.\""                                                              
##  [4371] ""                                                                            
##  [4372] "\"I certainly did not seek your confidence,\" said Elinor; \"but you do me"  
##  [4373] "no more than justice in imagining that I may be depended on.  Your"          
##  [4374] "secret is safe with me; but pardon me if I express some surprise at so"      
##  [4375] "unnecessary a communication.  You must at least have felt that my being"     
##  [4376] "acquainted with it could not add to its safety.\""                           
##  [4377] ""                                                                            
##  [4378] "As she said this, she looked earnestly at Lucy, hoping to discover"          
##  [4379] "something in her countenance; perhaps the falsehood of the greatest"         
##  [4380] "part of what she had been saying; but Lucy's countenance suffered no"        
##  [4381] "change."                                                                     
##  [4382] ""                                                                            
##  [4383] "\"I was afraid you would think I was taking a great liberty with you,\""     
##  [4384] "said she, \"in telling you all this.  I have not known you long to be"       
##  [4385] "sure, personally at least, but I have known you and all your family by"      
##  [4386] "description a great while; and as soon as I saw you, I felt almost as"       
##  [4387] "if you was an old acquaintance.  Besides in the present case, I really"      
##  [4388] "thought some explanation was due to you after my making such particular"     
##  [4389] "inquiries about Edward's mother; and I am so unfortunate, that I have"       
##  [4390] "not a creature whose advice I can ask.  Anne is the only person that"        
##  [4391] "knows of it, and she has no judgment at all; indeed, she does me a"          
##  [4392] "great deal more harm than good, for I am in constant fear of her"            
##  [4393] "betraying me.  She does not know how to hold her tongue, as you must"        
##  [4394] "perceive, and I am sure I was in the greatest fright in the world"           
##  [4395] "t'other day, when Edward's name was mentioned by Sir John, lest she"         
##  [4396] "should out with it all.  You can't think how much I go through in my"        
##  [4397] "mind from it altogether.  I only wonder that I am alive after what I"        
##  [4398] "have suffered for Edward's sake these last four years.  Every thing in"      
##  [4399] "such suspense and uncertainty; and seeing him so seldom--we can hardly"      
##  [4400] "meet above twice a-year.  I am sure I wonder my heart is not quite"          
##  [4401] "broke.\""                                                                    
##  [4402] ""                                                                            
##  [4403] "Here she took out her handkerchief; but Elinor did not feel very"            
##  [4404] "compassionate."                                                              
##  [4405] ""                                                                            
##  [4406] "\"Sometimes.\" continued Lucy, after wiping her eyes, \"I think whether it"  
##  [4407] "would not be better for us both to break off the matter entirely.\"  As"     
##  [4408] "she said this, she looked directly at her companion.  \"But then at"         
##  [4409] "other times I have not resolution enough for it.-- I cannot bear the"        
##  [4410] "thoughts of making him so miserable, as I know the very mention of such"     
##  [4411] "a thing would do.  And on my own account too--so dear as he is to me--I"     
##  [4412] "don't think I could be equal to it.  What would you advise me to do in"      
##  [4413] "such a case, Miss Dashwood?  What would you do yourself?\""                  
##  [4414] ""                                                                            
##  [4415] "\"Pardon me,\" replied Elinor, startled by the question; \"but I can give"   
##  [4416] "you no advice under such circumstances.  Your own judgment must direct"      
##  [4417] "you.\""                                                                      
##  [4418] ""                                                                            
##  [4419] "\"To be sure,\" continued Lucy, after a few minutes silence on both"         
##  [4420] "sides, \"his mother must provide for him sometime or other; but poor"        
##  [4421] "Edward is so cast down by it!  Did you not think him dreadful"               
##  [4422] "low-spirited when he was at Barton?  He was so miserable when he left"       
##  [4423] "us at Longstaple, to go to you, that I was afraid you would think him"       
##  [4424] "quite ill.\""                                                                
##  [4425] ""                                                                            
##  [4426] "\"Did he come from your uncle's, then, when he visited us?\""                
##  [4427] ""                                                                            
##  [4428] "\"Oh, yes; he had been staying a fortnight with us.  Did you think he"       
##  [4429] "came directly from town?\""                                                  
##  [4430] ""                                                                            
##  [4431] "\"No,\" replied Elinor, most feelingly sensible of every fresh"              
##  [4432] "circumstance in favour of Lucy's veracity; \"I remember he told us, that"    
##  [4433] "he had been staying a fortnight with some friends near Plymouth.\" She"      
##  [4434] "remembered too, her own surprise at the time, at his mentioning nothing"     
##  [4435] "farther of those friends, at his total silence with respect even to"         
##  [4436] "their names."                                                                
##  [4437] ""                                                                            
##  [4438] "\"Did not you think him sadly out of spirits?\" repeated Lucy."              
##  [4439] ""                                                                            
##  [4440] "\"We did, indeed, particularly so when he first arrived.\""                  
##  [4441] ""                                                                            
##  [4442] "\"I begged him to exert himself for fear you should suspect what was the"    
##  [4443] "matter; but it made him so melancholy, not being able to stay more than"     
##  [4444] "a fortnight with us, and seeing me so much affected.-- Poor fellow!--I"      
##  [4445] "am afraid it is just the same with him now; for he writes in wretched"       
##  [4446] "spirits.  I heard from him just before I left Exeter;\" taking a letter"     
##  [4447] "from her pocket and carelessly showing the direction to Elinor.  \"You"      
##  [4448] "know his hand, I dare say, a charming one it is; but that is not"            
##  [4449] "written so well as usual.--He was tired, I dare say, for he had just"        
##  [4450] "filled the sheet to me as full as possible.\""                               
##  [4451] ""                                                                            
##  [4452] "Elinor saw that it WAS his hand, and she could doubt no longer.  This"       
##  [4453] "picture, she had allowed herself to believe, might have been"                
##  [4454] "accidentally obtained; it might not have been Edward's gift; but a"          
##  [4455] "correspondence between them by letter, could subsist only under a"           
##  [4456] "positive engagement, could be authorised by nothing else; for a few"         
##  [4457] "moments, she was almost overcome--her heart sunk within her, and she"        
##  [4458] "could hardly stand; but exertion was indispensably necessary; and she"       
##  [4459] "struggled so resolutely against the oppression of her feelings, that"        
##  [4460] "her success was speedy, and for the time complete."                          
##  [4461] ""                                                                            
##  [4462] "\"Writing to each other,\" said Lucy, returning the letter into her"         
##  [4463] "pocket, \"is the only comfort we have in such long separations.  Yes, I"     
##  [4464] "have one other comfort in his picture, but poor Edward has not even"         
##  [4465] "THAT.  If he had but my picture, he says he should be easy.  I gave him"     
##  [4466] "a lock of my hair set in a ring when he was at Longstaple last, and"         
##  [4467] "that was some comfort to him, he said, but not equal to a picture."          
##  [4468] "Perhaps you might notice the ring when you saw him?\""                       
##  [4469] ""                                                                            
##  [4470] "\"I did,\" said Elinor, with a composure of voice, under which was"          
##  [4471] "concealed an emotion and distress beyond any thing she had ever felt"        
##  [4472] "before.  She was mortified, shocked, confounded."                            
##  [4473] ""                                                                            
##  [4474] "Fortunately for her, they had now reached the cottage, and the"              
##  [4475] "conversation could be continued no farther.  After sitting with them a"      
##  [4476] "few minutes, the Miss Steeles returned to the Park, and Elinor was then"     
##  [4477] "at liberty to think and be wretched."                                        
##  [4478] ""                                                                            
##  [4479] ""                                                                            
##  [4480] ""                                                                            
##  [4481] ""                                                                            
##  [4482] ""                                                                            
##  [4483] "[At this point in the first and second editions, Volume 1 ends.]"            
##  [4484] ""                                                                            
##  [4485] ""                                                                            
##  [4486] ""                                                                            
##  [4487] ""                                                                            
##  [4488] ""                                                                            
##  [4489] "CHAPTER 23"                                                                  
##  [4490] ""                                                                            
##  [4491] ""                                                                            
##  [4492] "However small Elinor's general dependence on Lucy's veracity might be,"      
##  [4493] "it was impossible for her on serious reflection to suspect it in the"        
##  [4494] "present case, where no temptation could be answerable to the folly of"       
##  [4495] "inventing a falsehood of such a description.  What Lucy had asserted to"     
##  [4496] "be true, therefore, Elinor could not, dared not longer doubt; supported"     
##  [4497] "as it was too on every side by such probabilities and proofs, and"           
##  [4498] "contradicted by nothing but her own wishes.  Their opportunity of"           
##  [4499] "acquaintance in the house of Mr. Pratt was a foundation for the rest,"       
##  [4500] "at once indisputable and alarming; and Edward's visit near Plymouth,"        
##  [4501] "his melancholy state of mind, his dissatisfaction at his own prospects,"     
##  [4502] "his uncertain behaviour towards herself, the intimate knowledge of the"      
##  [4503] "Miss Steeles as to Norland and their family connections, which had"          
##  [4504] "often surprised her, the picture, the letter, the ring, formed"              
##  [4505] "altogether such a body of evidence, as overcame every fear of"               
##  [4506] "condemning him unfairly, and established as a fact, which no partiality"     
##  [4507] "could set aside, his ill-treatment of herself.--Her resentment of such"      
##  [4508] "behaviour, her indignation at having been its dupe, for a short time"        
##  [4509] "made her feel only for herself; but other ideas, other considerations,"      
##  [4510] "soon arose.  Had Edward been intentionally deceiving her?  Had he"           
##  [4511] "feigned a regard for her which he did not feel?  Was his engagement to"      
##  [4512] "Lucy an engagement of the heart?  No; whatever it might once have been,"     
##  [4513] "she could not believe it such at present.  His affection was all her"        
##  [4514] "own.  She could not be deceived in that.  Her mother, sisters, Fanny,"       
##  [4515] "all had been conscious of his regard for her at Norland; it was not an"      
##  [4516] "illusion of her own vanity.  He certainly loved her.  What a softener"       
##  [4517] "of the heart was this persuasion!  How much could it not tempt her to"       
##  [4518] "forgive!  He had been blamable, highly blamable, in remaining at"            
##  [4519] "Norland after he first felt her influence over him to be more than it"       
##  [4520] "ought to be.  In that, he could not be defended; but if he had injured"      
##  [4521] "her, how much more had he injured himself; if her case were pitiable,"       
##  [4522] "his was hopeless.  His imprudence had made her miserable for a while;"       
##  [4523] "but it seemed to have deprived himself of all chance of ever being"          
##  [4524] "otherwise.  She might in time regain tranquillity; but HE, what had he"      
##  [4525] "to look forward to?  Could he ever be tolerably happy with Lucy Steele;"     
##  [4526] "could he, were his affection for herself out of the question, with his"      
##  [4527] "integrity, his delicacy, and well-informed mind, be satisfied with a"        
##  [4528] "wife like her--illiterate, artful, and selfish?"                             
##  [4529] ""                                                                            
##  [4530] "The youthful infatuation of nineteen would naturally blind him to every"     
##  [4531] "thing but her beauty and good nature; but the four succeeding"               
##  [4532] "years--years, which if rationally spent, give such improvement to the"       
##  [4533] "understanding, must have opened his eyes to her defects of education,"       
##  [4534] "while the same period of time, spent on her side in inferior society"        
##  [4535] "and more frivolous pursuits, had perhaps robbed her of that simplicity"      
##  [4536] "which might once have given an interesting character to her beauty."         
##  [4537] ""                                                                            
##  [4538] "If in the supposition of his seeking to marry herself, his difficulties"     
##  [4539] "from his mother had seemed great, how much greater were they now likely"     
##  [4540] "to be, when the object of his engagement was undoubtedly inferior in"        
##  [4541] "connections, and probably inferior in fortune to herself.  These"            
##  [4542] "difficulties, indeed, with a heart so alienated from Lucy, might not"        
##  [4543] "press very hard upon his patience; but melancholy was the state of the"      
##  [4544] "person by whom the expectation of family opposition and unkindness,"         
##  [4545] "could be felt as a relief!"                                                  
##  [4546] ""                                                                            
##  [4547] "As these considerations occurred to her in painful succession, she wept"     
##  [4548] "for him, more than for herself.  Supported by the conviction of having"      
##  [4549] "done nothing to merit her present unhappiness, and consoled by the"          
##  [4550] "belief that Edward had done nothing to forfeit her esteem, she thought"      
##  [4551] "she could even now, under the first smart of the heavy blow, command"        
##  [4552] "herself enough to guard every suspicion of the truth from her mother"        
##  [4553] "and sisters.  And so well was she able to answer her own expectations,"      
##  [4554] "that when she joined them at dinner only two hours after she had first"      
##  [4555] "suffered the extinction of all her dearest hopes, no one would have"         
##  [4556] "supposed from the appearance of the sisters, that Elinor was mourning"       
##  [4557] "in secret over obstacles which must divide her for ever from the object"     
##  [4558] "of her love, and that Marianne was internally dwelling on the"               
##  [4559] "perfections of a man, of whose whole heart she felt thoroughly"              
##  [4560] "possessed, and whom she expected to see in every carriage which drove"       
##  [4561] "near their house."                                                           
##  [4562] ""                                                                            
##  [4563] "The necessity of concealing from her mother and Marianne, what had been"     
##  [4564] "entrusted in confidence to herself, though it obliged her to unceasing"      
##  [4565] "exertion, was no aggravation of Elinor's distress.  On the contrary it"      
##  [4566] "was a relief to her, to be spared the communication of what would give"      
##  [4567] "such affliction to them, and to be saved likewise from hearing that"         
##  [4568] "condemnation of Edward, which would probably flow from the excess of"        
##  [4569] "their partial affection for herself, and which was more than she felt"       
##  [4570] "equal to support."                                                           
##  [4571] ""                                                                            
##  [4572] "From their counsel, or their conversation, she knew she could receive"       
##  [4573] "no assistance, their tenderness and sorrow must add to her distress,"        
##  [4574] "while her self-command would neither receive encouragement from their"       
##  [4575] "example nor from their praise.  She was stronger alone, and her own"         
##  [4576] "good sense so well supported her, that her firmness was as unshaken,"        
##  [4577] "her appearance of cheerfulness as invariable, as with regrets so"            
##  [4578] "poignant and so fresh, it was possible for them to be."                      
##  [4579] ""                                                                            
##  [4580] "Much as she had suffered from her first conversation with Lucy on the"       
##  [4581] "subject, she soon felt an earnest wish of renewing it; and this for"         
##  [4582] "more reasons than one.  She wanted to hear many particulars of their"        
##  [4583] "engagement repeated again, she wanted more clearly to understand what"       
##  [4584] "Lucy really felt for Edward, whether there were any sincerity in her"        
##  [4585] "declaration of tender regard for him, and she particularly wanted to"        
##  [4586] "convince Lucy, by her readiness to enter on the matter again, and her"       
##  [4587] "calmness in conversing on it, that she was no otherwise interested in"       
##  [4588] "it than as a friend, which she very much feared her involuntary"             
##  [4589] "agitation, in their morning discourse, must have left at least"              
##  [4590] "doubtful.  That Lucy was disposed to be jealous of her appeared very"        
##  [4591] "probable: it was plain that Edward had always spoken highly in her"          
##  [4592] "praise, not merely from Lucy's assertion, but from her venturing to"         
##  [4593] "trust her on so short a personal acquaintance, with a secret so"             
##  [4594] "confessedly and evidently important.  And even Sir John's joking"            
##  [4595] "intelligence must have had some weight.  But indeed, while Elinor"           
##  [4596] "remained so well assured within herself of being really beloved by"          
##  [4597] "Edward, it required no other consideration of probabilities to make it"      
##  [4598] "natural that Lucy should be jealous; and that she was so, her very"          
##  [4599] "confidence was a proof.  What other reason for the disclosure of the"        
##  [4600] "affair could there be, but that Elinor might be informed by it of"           
##  [4601] "Lucy's superior claims on Edward, and be taught to avoid him in future?"     
##  [4602] "She had little difficulty in understanding thus much of her rival's"         
##  [4603] "intentions, and while she was firmly resolved to act by her as every"        
##  [4604] "principle of honour and honesty directed, to combat her own affection"       
##  [4605] "for Edward and to see him as little as possible; she could not deny"         
##  [4606] "herself the comfort of endeavouring to convince Lucy that her heart was"     
##  [4607] "unwounded.  And as she could now have nothing more painful to hear on"       
##  [4608] "the subject than had already been told, she did not mistrust her own"        
##  [4609] "ability of going through a repetition of particulars with composure."        
##  [4610] ""                                                                            
##  [4611] "But it was not immediately that an opportunity of doing so could be"         
##  [4612] "commanded, though Lucy was as well disposed as herself to take"              
##  [4613] "advantage of any that occurred; for the weather was not often fine"          
##  [4614] "enough to allow of their joining in a walk, where they might most"           
##  [4615] "easily separate themselves from the others; and though they met at"          
##  [4616] "least every other evening either at the park or cottage, and chiefly at"     
##  [4617] "the former, they could not be supposed to meet for the sake of"              
##  [4618] "conversation.  Such a thought would never enter either Sir John or Lady"     
##  [4619] "Middleton's head; and therefore very little leisure was ever given for"      
##  [4620] "a general chat, and none at all for particular discourse.  They met for"     
##  [4621] "the sake of eating, drinking, and laughing together, playing at cards,"      
##  [4622] "or consequences, or any other game that was sufficiently noisy."             
##  [4623] ""                                                                            
##  [4624] "One or two meetings of this kind had taken place, without affording"         
##  [4625] "Elinor any chance of engaging Lucy in private, when Sir John called at"      
##  [4626] "the cottage one morning, to beg, in the name of charity, that they"          
##  [4627] "would all dine with Lady Middleton that day, as he was obliged to"           
##  [4628] "attend the club at Exeter, and she would otherwise be quite alone,"          
##  [4629] "except her mother and the two Miss Steeles.  Elinor, who foresaw a"          
##  [4630] "fairer opening for the point she had in view, in such a party as this"       
##  [4631] "was likely to be, more at liberty among themselves under the tranquil"       
##  [4632] "and well-bred direction of Lady Middleton than when her husband united"      
##  [4633] "them together in one noisy purpose, immediately accepted the"                
##  [4634] "invitation; Margaret, with her mother's permission, was equally"             
##  [4635] "compliant, and Marianne, though always unwilling to join any of their"       
##  [4636] "parties, was persuaded by her mother, who could not bear to have her"        
##  [4637] "seclude herself from any chance of amusement, to go likewise."               
##  [4638] ""                                                                            
##  [4639] "The young ladies went, and Lady Middleton was happily preserved from"        
##  [4640] "the frightful solitude which had threatened her.  The insipidity of the"     
##  [4641] "meeting was exactly such as Elinor had expected; it produced not one"        
##  [4642] "novelty of thought or expression, and nothing could be less interesting"     
##  [4643] "than the whole of their discourse both in the dining parlour and"            
##  [4644] "drawing room: to the latter, the children accompanied them, and while"       
##  [4645] "they remained there, she was too well convinced of the impossibility of"     
##  [4646] "engaging Lucy's attention to attempt it.  They quitted it only with the"     
##  [4647] "removal of the tea-things.  The card-table was then placed, and Elinor"      
##  [4648] "began to wonder at herself for having ever entertained a hope of"            
##  [4649] "finding time for conversation at the park.  They all rose up in"             
##  [4650] "preparation for a round game."                                               
##  [4651] ""                                                                            
##  [4652] "\"I am glad,\" said Lady Middleton to Lucy, \"you are not going to finish"   
##  [4653] "poor little Annamaria's basket this evening; for I am sure it must hurt"     
##  [4654] "your eyes to work filigree by candlelight.  And we will make the dear"       
##  [4655] "little love some amends for her disappointment to-morrow, and then I"        
##  [4656] "hope she will not much mind it.\""                                           
##  [4657] ""                                                                            
##  [4658] "This hint was enough, Lucy recollected herself instantly and replied,"       
##  [4659] "\"Indeed you are very much mistaken, Lady Middleton; I am only waiting"      
##  [4660] "to know whether you can make your party without me, or I should have"        
##  [4661] "been at my filigree already.  I would not disappoint the little angel"       
##  [4662] "for all the world: and if you want me at the card-table now, I am"           
##  [4663] "resolved to finish the basket after supper.\""                               
##  [4664] ""                                                                            
##  [4665] "\"You are very good, I hope it won't hurt your eyes--will you ring the"      
##  [4666] "bell for some working candles?  My poor little girl would be sadly"          
##  [4667] "disappointed, I know, if the basket was not finished tomorrow, for"          
##  [4668] "though I told her it certainly would not, I am sure she depends upon"        
##  [4669] "having it done.\""                                                           
##  [4670] ""                                                                            
##  [4671] "Lucy directly drew her work table near her and reseated herself with an"     
##  [4672] "alacrity and cheerfulness which seemed to infer that she could taste no"     
##  [4673] "greater delight than in making a filigree basket for a spoilt child."        
##  [4674] ""                                                                            
##  [4675] "Lady Middleton proposed a rubber of Casino to the others.  No one made"      
##  [4676] "any objection but Marianne, who with her usual inattention to the forms"     
##  [4677] "of general civility, exclaimed, \"Your Ladyship will have the goodness"      
##  [4678] "to excuse ME--you know I detest cards.  I shall go to the piano-forte;"      
##  [4679] "I have not touched it since it was tuned.\"  And without farther"            
##  [4680] "ceremony, she turned away and walked to the instrument."                     
##  [4681] ""                                                                            
##  [4682] "Lady Middleton looked as if she thanked heaven that SHE had never made"      
##  [4683] "so rude a speech."                                                           
##  [4684] ""                                                                            
##  [4685] "\"Marianne can never keep long from that instrument you know, ma'am,\""      
##  [4686] "said Elinor, endeavouring to smooth away the offence; \"and I do not"        
##  [4687] "much wonder at it; for it is the very best toned piano-forte I ever"         
##  [4688] "heard.\""                                                                    
##  [4689] ""                                                                            
##  [4690] "The remaining five were now to draw their cards."                            
##  [4691] ""                                                                            
##  [4692] "\"Perhaps,\" continued Elinor, \"if I should happen to cut out, I may be"    
##  [4693] "of some use to Miss Lucy Steele, in rolling her papers for her; and"         
##  [4694] "there is so much still to be done to the basket, that it must be"            
##  [4695] "impossible I think for her labour singly, to finish it this evening.  I"     
##  [4696] "should like the work exceedingly, if she would allow me a share in it.\""    
##  [4697] ""                                                                            
##  [4698] "\"Indeed I shall be very much obliged to you for your help,\" cried Lucy,"   
##  [4699] "\"for I find there is more to be done to it than I thought there was;"       
##  [4700] "and it would be a shocking thing to disappoint dear Annamaria after"         
##  [4701] "all.\""                                                                      
##  [4702] ""                                                                            
##  [4703] "\"Oh! that would be terrible, indeed,\" said Miss Steele-- \"Dear little"    
##  [4704] "soul, how I do love her!\""                                                  
##  [4705] ""                                                                            
##  [4706] "\"You are very kind,\" said Lady Middleton to Elinor; \"and as you really"   
##  [4707] "like the work, perhaps you will be as well pleased not to cut in till"       
##  [4708] "another rubber, or will you take your chance now?\""                         
##  [4709] ""                                                                            
##  [4710] "Elinor joyfully profited by the first of these proposals, and thus by a"     
##  [4711] "little of that address which Marianne could never condescend to"             
##  [4712] "practise, gained her own end, and pleased Lady Middleton at the same"        
##  [4713] "time.  Lucy made room for her with ready attention, and the two fair"        
##  [4714] "rivals were thus seated side by side at the same table, and, with the"       
##  [4715] "utmost harmony, engaged in forwarding the same work.  The pianoforte at"     
##  [4716] "which Marianne, wrapped up in her own music and her own thoughts, had"       
##  [4717] "by this time forgotten that any body was in the room besides herself,"       
##  [4718] "was luckily so near them that Miss Dashwood now judged she might"            
##  [4719] "safely, under the shelter of its noise, introduce the interesting"           
##  [4720] "subject, without any risk of being heard at the card-table."                 
##  [4721] ""                                                                            
##  [4722] ""                                                                            
##  [4723] ""                                                                            
##  [4724] "CHAPTER 24"                                                                  
##  [4725] ""                                                                            
##  [4726] ""                                                                            
##  [4727] "In a firm, though cautious tone, Elinor thus began."                         
##  [4728] ""                                                                            
##  [4729] "\"I should be undeserving of the confidence you have honoured me with,"      
##  [4730] "if I felt no desire for its continuance, or no farther curiosity on its"     
##  [4731] "subject.  I will not apologize therefore for bringing it forward again.\""   
##  [4732] ""                                                                            
##  [4733] "\"Thank you,\" cried Lucy warmly, \"for breaking the ice; you have set my"   
##  [4734] "heart at ease by it; for I was somehow or other afraid I had offended"       
##  [4735] "you by what I told you that Monday.\""                                       
##  [4736] ""                                                                            
##  [4737] "\"Offended me! How could you suppose so? Believe me,\" and Elinor spoke"     
##  [4738] "it with the truest sincerity, \"nothing could be farther from my"            
##  [4739] "intention than to give you such an idea.  Could you have a motive for"       
##  [4740] "the trust, that was not honourable and flattering to me?\""                  
##  [4741] ""                                                                            
##  [4742] "\"And yet I do assure you,\" replied Lucy, her little sharp eyes full of"    
##  [4743] "meaning, \"there seemed to me to be a coldness and displeasure in your"      
##  [4744] "manner that made me quite uncomfortable.  I felt sure that you was"          
##  [4745] "angry with me; and have been quarrelling with myself ever since, for"        
##  [4746] "having took such a liberty as to trouble you with my affairs.  But I am"     
##  [4747] "very glad to find it was only my own fancy, and that you really do not"      
##  [4748] "blame me.  If you knew what a consolation it was to me to relieve my"        
##  [4749] "heart speaking to you of what I am always thinking of every moment of"       
##  [4750] "my life, your compassion would make you overlook every thing else I am"      
##  [4751] "sure.\""                                                                     
##  [4752] ""                                                                            
##  [4753] "\"Indeed, I can easily believe that it was a very great relief to you,"      
##  [4754] "to acknowledge your situation to me, and be assured that you shall"          
##  [4755] "never have reason to repent it.  Your case is a very unfortunate one;"       
##  [4756] "you seem to me to be surrounded with difficulties, and you will have"        
##  [4757] "need of all your mutual affection to support you under them.  Mr."           
##  [4758] "Ferrars, I believe, is entirely dependent on his mother.\""                  
##  [4759] ""                                                                            
##  [4760] "\"He has only two thousand pounds of his own; it would be madness to"        
##  [4761] "marry upon that, though for my own part, I could give up every prospect"     
##  [4762] "of more without a sigh.  I have been always used to a very small"            
##  [4763] "income, and could struggle with any poverty for him; but I love him too"     
##  [4764] "well to be the selfish means of robbing him, perhaps, of all that his"       
##  [4765] "mother might give him if he married to please her.  We must wait, it"        
##  [4766] "may be for many years.  With almost every other man in the world, it"        
##  [4767] "would be an alarming prospect; but Edward's affection and constancy"         
##  [4768] "nothing can deprive me of I know.\""                                         
##  [4769] ""                                                                            
##  [4770] "\"That conviction must be every thing to you; and he is undoubtedly"         
##  [4771] "supported by the same trust in your's.  If the strength of your"             
##  [4772] "reciprocal attachment had failed, as between many people, and under"         
##  [4773] "many circumstances it naturally would during a four years' engagement,"      
##  [4774] "your situation would have been pitiable, indeed.\""                          
##  [4775] ""                                                                            
##  [4776] "Lucy here looked up; but Elinor was careful in guarding her countenance"     
##  [4777] "from every expression that could give her words a suspicious tendency."      
##  [4778] ""                                                                            
##  [4779] "\"Edward's love for me,\" said Lucy, \"has been pretty well put to the"      
##  [4780] "test, by our long, very long absence since we were first engaged, and"       
##  [4781] "it has stood the trial so well, that I should be unpardonable to doubt"      
##  [4782] "it now.  I can safely say that he has never gave me one moment's alarm"      
##  [4783] "on that account from the first.\""                                           
##  [4784] ""                                                                            
##  [4785] "Elinor hardly knew whether to smile or sigh at this assertion."              
##  [4786] ""                                                                            
##  [4787] "Lucy went on.  \"I am rather of a jealous temper too by nature, and from"    
##  [4788] "our different situations in life, from his being so much more in the"        
##  [4789] "world than me, and our continual separation, I was enough inclined for"      
##  [4790] "suspicion, to have found out the truth in an instant, if there had been"     
##  [4791] "the slightest alteration in his behaviour to me when we met, or any"         
##  [4792] "lowness of spirits that I could not account for, or if he had talked"        
##  [4793] "more of one lady than another, or seemed in any respect less happy at"       
##  [4794] "Longstaple than he used to be.  I do not mean to say that I am"              
##  [4795] "particularly observant or quick-sighted in general, but in such a case"      
##  [4796] "I am sure I could not be deceived.\""                                        
##  [4797] ""                                                                            
##  [4798] "\"All this,\" thought Elinor, \"is very pretty; but it can impose upon"      
##  [4799] "neither of us.\""                                                            
##  [4800] ""                                                                            
##  [4801] "\"But what,\" said she after a short silence, \"are your views? or have"     
##  [4802] "you none but that of waiting for Mrs. Ferrars's death, which is a"           
##  [4803] "melancholy and shocking extremity?--Is her son determined to submit to"      
##  [4804] "this, and to all the tediousness of the many years of suspense in which"     
##  [4805] "it may involve you, rather than run the risk of her displeasure for a"       
##  [4806] "while by owning the truth?\""                                                
##  [4807] ""                                                                            
##  [4808] "\"If we could be certain that it would be only for a while!  But Mrs."       
##  [4809] "Ferrars is a very headstrong proud woman, and in her first fit of anger"     
##  [4810] "upon hearing it, would very likely secure every thing to Robert, and"        
##  [4811] "the idea of that, for Edward's sake, frightens away all my inclination"      
##  [4812] "for hasty measures.\""                                                       
##  [4813] ""                                                                            
##  [4814] "\"And for your own sake too, or you are carrying your disinterestedness"     
##  [4815] "beyond reason.\""                                                            
##  [4816] ""                                                                            
##  [4817] "Lucy looked at Elinor again, and was silent."                                
##  [4818] ""                                                                            
##  [4819] "\"Do you know Mr. Robert Ferrars?\" asked Elinor."                           
##  [4820] ""                                                                            
##  [4821] "\"Not at all--I never saw him; but I fancy he is very unlike his"            
##  [4822] "brother--silly and a great coxcomb.\""                                       
##  [4823] ""                                                                            
##  [4824] "\"A great coxcomb!\" repeated Miss Steele, whose ear had caught those"       
##  [4825] "words by a sudden pause in Marianne's music.-- \"Oh, they are talking of"    
##  [4826] "their favourite beaux, I dare say.\""                                        
##  [4827] ""                                                                            
##  [4828] "\"No sister,\" cried Lucy, \"you are mistaken there, our favourite beaux"    
##  [4829] "are NOT great coxcombs.\""                                                   
##  [4830] ""                                                                            
##  [4831] "\"I can answer for it that Miss Dashwood's is not,\" said Mrs. Jennings,"    
##  [4832] "laughing heartily; \"for he is one of the modestest, prettiest behaved"      
##  [4833] "young men I ever saw; but as for Lucy, she is such a sly little"             
##  [4834] "creature, there is no finding out who SHE likes.\""                          
##  [4835] ""                                                                            
##  [4836] "\"Oh,\" cried Miss Steele, looking significantly round at them, \"I dare"    
##  [4837] "say Lucy's beau is quite as modest and pretty behaved as Miss"               
##  [4838] "Dashwood's.\""                                                               
##  [4839] ""                                                                            
##  [4840] "Elinor blushed in spite of herself.  Lucy bit her lip, and looked"           
##  [4841] "angrily at her sister.  A mutual silence took place for some time."          
##  [4842] "Lucy first put an end to it by saying in a lower tone, though Marianne"      
##  [4843] "was then giving them the powerful protection of a very magnificent"          
##  [4844] "concerto--"                                                                  
##  [4845] ""                                                                            
##  [4846] "\"I will honestly tell you of one scheme which has lately come into my"      
##  [4847] "head, for bringing matters to bear; indeed I am bound to let you into"       
##  [4848] "the secret, for you are a party concerned.  I dare say you have seen"        
##  [4849] "enough of Edward to know that he would prefer the church to every other"     
##  [4850] "profession; now my plan is that he should take orders as soon as he"         
##  [4851] "can, and then through your interest, which I am sure you would be kind"      
##  [4852] "enough to use out of friendship for him, and I hope out of some regard"      
##  [4853] "to me, your brother might be persuaded to give him Norland living;"          
##  [4854] "which I understand is a very good one, and the present incumbent not"        
##  [4855] "likely to live a great while.  That would be enough for us to marry"         
##  [4856] "upon, and we might trust to time and chance for the rest.\""                 
##  [4857] ""                                                                            
##  [4858] "\"I should always be happy,\" replied Elinor, \"to show any mark of my"      
##  [4859] "esteem and friendship for Mr. Ferrars; but do you not perceive that my"      
##  [4860] "interest on such an occasion would be perfectly unnecessary?  He is"         
##  [4861] "brother to Mrs. John Dashwood--THAT must be recommendation enough to"        
##  [4862] "her husband.\""                                                              
##  [4863] ""                                                                            
##  [4864] "\"But Mrs. John Dashwood would not much approve of Edward's going into"      
##  [4865] "orders.\""                                                                   
##  [4866] ""                                                                            
##  [4867] "\"Then I rather suspect that my interest would do very little.\""            
##  [4868] ""                                                                            
##  [4869] "They were again silent for many minutes.  At length Lucy exclaimed with"     
##  [4870] "a deep sigh,"                                                                
##  [4871] ""                                                                            
##  [4872] "\"I believe it would be the wisest way to put an end to the business at"     
##  [4873] "once by dissolving the engagement.  We seem so beset with difficulties"      
##  [4874] "on every side, that though it would make us miserable for a time, we"        
##  [4875] "should be happier perhaps in the end.  But you will not give me your"        
##  [4876] "advice, Miss Dashwood?\""                                                    
##  [4877] ""                                                                            
##  [4878] "\"No,\" answered Elinor, with a smile, which concealed very agitated"        
##  [4879] "feelings, \"on such a subject I certainly will not.  You know very well"     
##  [4880] "that my opinion would have no weight with you, unless it were on the"        
##  [4881] "side of your wishes.\""                                                      
##  [4882] ""                                                                            
##  [4883] "\"Indeed you wrong me,\" replied Lucy, with great solemnity; \"I know"       
##  [4884] "nobody of whose judgment I think so highly as I do of yours; and I do"       
##  [4885] "really believe, that if you was to say to me, 'I advise you by all"          
##  [4886] "means to put an end to your engagement with Edward Ferrars, it will be"      
##  [4887] "more for the happiness of both of you,' I should resolve upon doing it"      
##  [4888] "immediately.\""                                                              
##  [4889] ""                                                                            
##  [4890] "Elinor blushed for the insincerity of Edward's future wife, and"             
##  [4891] "replied, \"This compliment would effectually frighten me from giving any"    
##  [4892] "opinion on the subject had I formed one.  It raises my influence much"       
##  [4893] "too high; the power of dividing two people so tenderly attached is too"      
##  [4894] "much for an indifferent person.\""                                           
##  [4895] ""                                                                            
##  [4896] "\"'Tis because you are an indifferent person,\" said Lucy, with some"        
##  [4897] "pique, and laying a particular stress on those words, \"that your"           
##  [4898] "judgment might justly have such weight with me.  If you could be"            
##  [4899] "supposed to be biased in any respect by your own feelings, your opinion"     
##  [4900] "would not be worth having.\""                                                
##  [4901] ""                                                                            
##  [4902] "Elinor thought it wisest to make no answer to this, lest they might"         
##  [4903] "provoke each other to an unsuitable increase of ease and unreserve; and"     
##  [4904] "was even partly determined never to mention the subject again.  Another"     
##  [4905] "pause therefore of many minutes' duration, succeeded this speech, and"       
##  [4906] "Lucy was still the first to end it."                                         
##  [4907] ""                                                                            
##  [4908] "\"Shall you be in town this winter, Miss Dashwood?\" said she with all"      
##  [4909] "her accustomary complacency."                                                
##  [4910] ""                                                                            
##  [4911] "\"Certainly not.\""                                                          
##  [4912] ""                                                                            
##  [4913] "\"I am sorry for that,\" returned the other, while her eyes brightened at"   
##  [4914] "the information, \"it would have gave me such pleasure to meet you"          
##  [4915] "there!  But I dare say you will go for all that.  To be sure, your"          
##  [4916] "brother and sister will ask you to come to them.\""                          
##  [4917] ""                                                                            
##  [4918] "\"It will not be in my power to accept their invitation if they do.\""       
##  [4919] ""                                                                            
##  [4920] "\"How unlucky that is! I had quite depended upon meeting you there."         
##  [4921] "Anne and me are to go the latter end of January to some relations who"       
##  [4922] "have been wanting us to visit them these several years!  But I only go"      
##  [4923] "for the sake of seeing Edward.  He will be there in February, otherwise"     
##  [4924] "London would have no charms for me; I have not spirits for it.\""            
##  [4925] ""                                                                            
##  [4926] "Elinor was soon called to the card-table by the conclusion of the first"     
##  [4927] "rubber, and the confidential discourse of the two ladies was therefore"      
##  [4928] "at an end, to which both of them submitted without any reluctance, for"      
##  [4929] "nothing had been said on either side to make them dislike each other"        
##  [4930] "less than they had done before; and Elinor sat down to the card table"       
##  [4931] "with the melancholy persuasion that Edward was not only without"             
##  [4932] "affection for the person who was to be his wife; but that he had not"        
##  [4933] "even the chance of being tolerably happy in marriage, which sincere"         
##  [4934] "affection on HER side would have given, for self-interest alone could"       
##  [4935] "induce a woman to keep a man to an engagement, of which she seemed so"       
##  [4936] "thoroughly aware that he was weary."                                         
##  [4937] ""                                                                            
##  [4938] "From this time the subject was never revived by Elinor, and when"            
##  [4939] "entered on by Lucy, who seldom missed an opportunity of introducing it,"     
##  [4940] "and was particularly careful to inform her confidante, of her happiness"     
##  [4941] "whenever she received a letter from Edward, it was treated by the"           
##  [4942] "former with calmness and caution, and dismissed as soon as civility"         
##  [4943] "would allow; for she felt such conversations to be an indulgence which"      
##  [4944] "Lucy did not deserve, and which were dangerous to herself."                  
##  [4945] ""                                                                            
##  [4946] "The visit of the Miss Steeles at Barton Park was lengthened far beyond"      
##  [4947] "what the first invitation implied.  Their favour increased; they could"      
##  [4948] "not be spared; Sir John would not hear of their going; and in spite of"      
##  [4949] "their numerous and long arranged engagements in Exeter, in spite of the"     
##  [4950] "absolute necessity of returning to fulfill them immediately, which was"      
##  [4951] "in full force at the end of every week, they were prevailed on to stay"      
##  [4952] "nearly two months at the park, and to assist in the due celebration of"      
##  [4953] "that festival which requires a more than ordinary share of private"          
##  [4954] "balls and large dinners to proclaim its importance."                         
##  [4955] ""                                                                            
##  [4956] ""                                                                            
##  [4957] ""                                                                            
##  [4958] "CHAPTER 25"                                                                  
##  [4959] ""                                                                            
##  [4960] ""                                                                            
##  [4961] "Though Mrs. Jennings was in the habit of spending a large portion of"        
##  [4962] "the year at the houses of her children and friends, she was not without"     
##  [4963] "a settled habitation of her own.  Since the death of her husband, who"       
##  [4964] "had traded with success in a less elegant part of the town, she had"         
##  [4965] "resided every winter in a house in one of the streets near Portman"          
##  [4966] "Square.  Towards this home, she began on the approach of January to"         
##  [4967] "turn her thoughts, and thither she one day abruptly, and very"               
##  [4968] "unexpectedly by them, asked the elder Misses Dashwood to accompany her."     
##  [4969] "Elinor, without observing the varying complexion of her sister, and the"     
##  [4970] "animated look which spoke no indifference to the plan, immediately gave"     
##  [4971] "a grateful but absolute denial for both, in which she believed herself"      
##  [4972] "to be speaking their united inclinations.  The reason alleged was their"     
##  [4973] "determined resolution of not leaving their mother at that time of the"       
##  [4974] "year.  Mrs. Jennings received the refusal with some surprise, and"           
##  [4975] "repeated her invitation immediately."                                        
##  [4976] ""                                                                            
##  [4977] "\"Oh, Lord! I am sure your mother can spare you very well, and I DO beg"     
##  [4978] "you will favour me with your company, for I've quite set my heart upon"      
##  [4979] "it.  Don't fancy that you will be any inconvenience to me, for I shan't"     
##  [4980] "put myself at all out of my way for you.  It will only be sending Betty"     
##  [4981] "by the coach, and I hope I can afford THAT.  We three shall be able to"      
##  [4982] "go very well in my chaise; and when we are in town, if you do not like"      
##  [4983] "to go wherever I do, well and good, you may always go with one of my"        
##  [4984] "daughters.  I am sure your mother will not object to it; for I have had"     
##  [4985] "such good luck in getting my own children off my hands that she will"        
##  [4986] "think me a very fit person to have the charge of you; and if I don't"        
##  [4987] "get one of you at least well married before I have done with you, it"        
##  [4988] "shall not be my fault.  I shall speak a good word for you to all the"        
##  [4989] "young men, you may depend upon it.\""                                        
##  [4990] ""                                                                            
##  [4991] "\"I have a notion,\" said Sir John, \"that Miss Marianne would not object"   
##  [4992] "to such a scheme, if her elder sister would come into it.  It is very"       
##  [4993] "hard indeed that she should not have a little pleasure, because Miss"        
##  [4994] "Dashwood does not wish it.  So I would advise you two, to set off for"       
##  [4995] "town, when you are tired of Barton, without saying a word to Miss"           
##  [4996] "Dashwood about it.\""                                                        
##  [4997] ""                                                                            
##  [4998] "\"Nay,\" cried Mrs. Jennings, \"I am sure I shall be monstrous glad of"      
##  [4999] "Miss Marianne's company, whether Miss Dashwood will go or not, only the"     
##  [5000] "more the merrier say I, and I thought it would be more comfortable for"      
##  [5001] "them to be together; because, if they got tired of me, they might talk"      
##  [5002] "to one another, and laugh at my old ways behind my back.  But one or"        
##  [5003] "the other, if not both of them, I must have.  Lord bless me! how do you"     
##  [5004] "think I can live poking by myself, I who have been always used till"         
##  [5005] "this winter to have Charlotte with me.  Come, Miss Marianne, let us"         
##  [5006] "strike hands upon the bargain, and if Miss Dashwood will change her"         
##  [5007] "mind by and bye, why so much the better.\""                                  
##  [5008] ""                                                                            
##  [5009] "\"I thank you, ma'am, sincerely thank you,\" said Marianne, with warmth:"    
##  [5010] "\"your invitation has insured my gratitude for ever, and it would give"      
##  [5011] "me such happiness, yes, almost the greatest happiness I am capable of,"      
##  [5012] "to be able to accept it.  But my mother, my dearest, kindest mother,--I"     
##  [5013] "feel the justice of what Elinor has urged, and if she were to be made"       
##  [5014] "less happy, less comfortable by our absence--Oh! no, nothing should"         
##  [5015] "tempt me to leave her.  It should not, must not be a struggle.\""            
##  [5016] ""                                                                            
##  [5017] "Mrs. Jennings repeated her assurance that Mrs. Dashwood could spare"         
##  [5018] "them perfectly well; and Elinor, who now understood her sister, and saw"     
##  [5019] "to what indifference to almost every thing else she was carried by her"      
##  [5020] "eagerness to be with Willoughby again, made no farther direct"               
##  [5021] "opposition to the plan, and merely referred it to her mother's"              
##  [5022] "decision, from whom however she scarcely expected to receive any"            
##  [5023] "support in her endeavour to prevent a visit, which she could not"            
##  [5024] "approve of for Marianne, and which on her own account she had"               
##  [5025] "particular reasons to avoid.  Whatever Marianne was desirous of, her"        
##  [5026] "mother would be eager to promote--she could not expect to influence the"
