##  [5027] "latter to cautiousness of conduct in an affair respecting which she had"     
##  [5028] "never been able to inspire her with distrust; and she dared not explain"     
##  [5029] "the motive of her own disinclination for going to London.  That"             
##  [5030] "Marianne, fastidious as she was, thoroughly acquainted with Mrs."            
##  [5031] "Jennings' manners, and invariably disgusted by them, should overlook"        
##  [5032] "every inconvenience of that kind, should disregard whatever must be"         
##  [5033] "most wounding to her irritable feelings, in her pursuit of one object,"      
##  [5034] "was such a proof, so strong, so full, of the importance of that object"      
##  [5035] "to her, as Elinor, in spite of all that had passed, was not prepared to"     
##  [5036] "witness."                                                                    
##  [5037] ""                                                                            
##  [5038] "On being informed of the invitation, Mrs. Dashwood, persuaded that such"     
##  [5039] "an excursion would be productive of much amusement to both her"              
##  [5040] "daughters, and perceiving through all her affectionate attention to"         
##  [5041] "herself, how much the heart of Marianne was in it, would not hear of"        
##  [5042] "their declining the offer upon HER account; insisted on their both"          
##  [5043] "accepting it directly; and then began to foresee, with her usual"            
##  [5044] "cheerfulness, a variety of advantages that would accrue to them all,"        
##  [5045] "from this separation."                                                       
##  [5046] ""                                                                            
##  [5047] "\"I am delighted with the plan,\" she cried, \"it is exactly what I could"   
##  [5048] "wish.  Margaret and I shall be as much benefited by it as yourselves."       
##  [5049] "When you and the Middletons are gone, we shall go on so quietly and"         
##  [5050] "happily together with our books and our music! You will find Margaret"       
##  [5051] "so improved when you come back again!  I have a little plan of"              
##  [5052] "alteration for your bedrooms too, which may now be performed without"        
##  [5053] "any inconvenience to any one.  It is very right that you SHOULD go to"       
##  [5054] "town; I would have every young woman of your condition in life"              
##  [5055] "acquainted with the manners and amusements of London.  You will be"          
##  [5056] "under the care of a motherly good sort of woman, of whose kindness to"       
##  [5057] "you I can have no doubt.  And in all probability you will see your"          
##  [5058] "brother, and whatever may be his faults, or the faults of his wife,"         
##  [5059] "when I consider whose son he is, I cannot bear to have you so wholly"        
##  [5060] "estranged from each other.\""                                                
##  [5061] ""                                                                            
##  [5062] "\"Though with your usual anxiety for our happiness,\" said Elinor, \"you"    
##  [5063] "have been obviating every impediment to the present scheme which"            
##  [5064] "occurred to you, there is still one objection which, in my opinion,"         
##  [5065] "cannot be so easily removed.\""                                              
##  [5066] ""                                                                            
##  [5067] "Marianne's countenance sunk."                                                
##  [5068] ""                                                                            
##  [5069] "\"And what,\" said Mrs. Dashwood, \"is my dear prudent Elinor going to"      
##  [5070] "suggest?  What formidable obstacle is she now to bring forward?  Do let"     
##  [5071] "me hear a word about the expense of it.\""                                   
##  [5072] ""                                                                            
##  [5073] "\"My objection is this; though I think very well of Mrs. Jennings's"         
##  [5074] "heart, she is not a woman whose society can afford us pleasure, or"          
##  [5075] "whose protection will give us consequence.\""                                
##  [5076] ""                                                                            
##  [5077] "\"That is very true,\" replied her mother, \"but of her society,"            
##  [5078] "separately from that of other people, you will scarcely have any thing"      
##  [5079] "at all, and you will almost always appear in public with Lady"               
##  [5080] "Middleton.\""                                                                
##  [5081] ""                                                                            
##  [5082] "\"If Elinor is frightened away by her dislike of Mrs. Jennings,\" said"      
##  [5083] "Marianne, \"at least it need not prevent MY accepting her invitation.  I"    
##  [5084] "have no such scruples, and I am sure I could put up with every"              
##  [5085] "unpleasantness of that kind with very little effort.\""                      
##  [5086] ""                                                                            
##  [5087] "Elinor could not help smiling at this display of indifference towards"       
##  [5088] "the manners of a person, to whom she had often had difficulty in"            
##  [5089] "persuading Marianne to behave with tolerable politeness; and resolved"       
##  [5090] "within herself, that if her sister persisted in going, she would go"         
##  [5091] "likewise, as she did not think it proper that Marianne should be left"       
##  [5092] "to the sole guidance of her own judgment, or that Mrs. Jennings should"      
##  [5093] "be abandoned to the mercy of Marianne for all the comfort of her"            
##  [5094] "domestic hours.  To this determination she was the more easily"              
##  [5095] "reconciled, by recollecting that Edward Ferrars, by Lucy's account, was"     
##  [5096] "not to be in town before February; and that their visit, without any"        
##  [5097] "unreasonable abridgement, might be previously finished."                     
##  [5098] ""                                                                            
##  [5099] "\"I will have you BOTH go,\" said Mrs. Dashwood; \"these objections are"     
##  [5100] "nonsensical.  You will have much pleasure in being in London, and"           
##  [5101] "especially in being together; and if Elinor would ever condescend to"        
##  [5102] "anticipate enjoyment, she would foresee it there from a variety of"          
##  [5103] "sources; she would, perhaps, expect some from improving her"                 
##  [5104] "acquaintance with her sister-in-law's family.\""                             
##  [5105] ""                                                                            
##  [5106] "Elinor had often wished for an opportunity of attempting to weaken her"      
##  [5107] "mother's dependence on the attachment of Edward and herself, that the"       
##  [5108] "shock might be less when the whole truth were revealed, and now on this"     
##  [5109] "attack, though almost hopeless of success, she forced herself to begin"      
##  [5110] "her design by saying, as calmly as she could, \"I like Edward Ferrars"       
##  [5111] "very much, and shall always be glad to see him; but as to the rest of"       
##  [5112] "the family, it is a matter of perfect indifference to me, whether I am"      
##  [5113] "ever known to them or not.\""                                                
##  [5114] ""                                                                            
##  [5115] "Mrs. Dashwood smiled, and said nothing.  Marianne lifted up her eyes in"     
##  [5116] "astonishment, and Elinor conjectured that she might as well have held"       
##  [5117] "her tongue."                                                                 
##  [5118] ""                                                                            
##  [5119] "After very little farther discourse, it was finally settled that the"        
##  [5120] "invitation should be fully accepted.  Mrs. Jennings received the"            
##  [5121] "information with a great deal of joy, and many assurances of kindness"       
##  [5122] "and care; nor was it a matter of pleasure merely to her.  Sir John was"      
##  [5123] "delighted; for to a man, whose prevailing anxiety was the dread of"          
##  [5124] "being alone, the acquisition of two, to the number of inhabitants in"        
##  [5125] "London, was something.  Even Lady Middleton took the trouble of being"       
##  [5126] "delighted, which was putting herself rather out of her way; and as for"      
##  [5127] "the Miss Steeles, especially Lucy, they had never been so happy in"          
##  [5128] "their lives as this intelligence made them."                                 
##  [5129] ""                                                                            
##  [5130] "Elinor submitted to the arrangement which counteracted her wishes with"      
##  [5131] "less reluctance than she had expected to feel.  With regard to herself,"     
##  [5132] "it was now a matter of unconcern whether she went to town or not, and"       
##  [5133] "when she saw her mother so thoroughly pleased with the plan, and her"        
##  [5134] "sister exhilarated by it in look, voice, and manner, restored to all"        
##  [5135] "her usual animation, and elevated to more than her usual gaiety, she"        
##  [5136] "could not be dissatisfied with the cause, and would hardly allow"            
##  [5137] "herself to distrust the consequence."                                        
##  [5138] ""                                                                            
##  [5139] "Marianne's joy was almost a degree beyond happiness, so great was the"       
##  [5140] "perturbation of her spirits and her impatience to be gone.  Her"             
##  [5141] "unwillingness to quit her mother was her only restorative to calmness;"      
##  [5142] "and at the moment of parting her grief on that score was excessive."         
##  [5143] "Her mother's affliction was hardly less, and Elinor was the only one of"     
##  [5144] "the three, who seemed to consider the separation as any thing short of"      
##  [5145] "eternal."                                                                    
##  [5146] ""                                                                            
##  [5147] "Their departure took place in the first week in January.  The"               
##  [5148] "Middletons were to follow in about a week.  The Miss Steeles kept their"     
##  [5149] "station at the park, and were to quit it only with the rest of the"          
##  [5150] "family."                                                                     
##  [5151] ""                                                                            
##  [5152] ""                                                                            
##  [5153] ""                                                                            
##  [5154] "CHAPTER 26"                                                                  
##  [5155] ""                                                                            
##  [5156] ""                                                                            
##  [5157] "Elinor could not find herself in the carriage with Mrs. Jennings, and"       
##  [5158] "beginning a journey to London under her protection, and as her guest,"       
##  [5159] "without wondering at her own situation, so short had their acquaintance"     
##  [5160] "with that lady been, so wholly unsuited were they in age and"                
##  [5161] "disposition, and so many had been her objections against such a measure"     
##  [5162] "only a few days before! But these objections had all, with that happy"       
##  [5163] "ardour of youth which Marianne and her mother equally shared, been"          
##  [5164] "overcome or overlooked; and Elinor, in spite of every occasional doubt"      
##  [5165] "of Willoughby's constancy, could not witness the rapture of delightful"      
##  [5166] "expectation which filled the whole soul and beamed in the eyes of"           
##  [5167] "Marianne, without feeling how blank was her own prospect, how cheerless"     
##  [5168] "her own state of mind in the comparison, and how gladly she would"           
##  [5169] "engage in the solicitude of Marianne's situation to have the same"           
##  [5170] "animating object in view, the same possibility of hope.  A short, a"         
##  [5171] "very short time however must now decide what Willoughby's intentions"        
##  [5172] "were; in all probability he was already in town.  Marianne's eagerness"      
##  [5173] "to be gone declared her dependence on finding him there; and Elinor was"     
##  [5174] "resolved not only upon gaining every new light as to his character"          
##  [5175] "which her own observation or the intelligence of others could give her,"     
##  [5176] "but likewise upon watching his behaviour to her sister with such"            
##  [5177] "zealous attention, as to ascertain what he was and what he meant,"           
##  [5178] "before many meetings had taken place.  Should the result of her"             
##  [5179] "observations be unfavourable, she was determined at all events to open"      
##  [5180] "the eyes of her sister; should it be otherwise, her exertions would be"      
##  [5181] "of a different nature--she must then learn to avoid every selfish"           
##  [5182] "comparison, and banish every regret which might lessen her satisfaction"     
##  [5183] "in the happiness of Marianne."                                               
##  [5184] ""                                                                            
##  [5185] "They were three days on their journey, and Marianne's behaviour as they"     
##  [5186] "travelled was a happy specimen of what future complaisance and"              
##  [5187] "companionableness to Mrs. Jennings might be expected to be.  She sat in"     
##  [5188] "silence almost all the way, wrapt in her own meditations, and scarcely"      
##  [5189] "ever voluntarily speaking, except when any object of picturesque beauty"     
##  [5190] "within their view drew from her an exclamation of delight exclusively"       
##  [5191] "addressed to her sister.  To atone for this conduct therefore, Elinor"       
##  [5192] "took immediate possession of the post of civility which she had"             
##  [5193] "assigned herself, behaved with the greatest attention to Mrs. Jennings,"     
##  [5194] "talked with her, laughed with her, and listened to her whenever she"         
##  [5195] "could; and Mrs. Jennings on her side treated them both with all"             
##  [5196] "possible kindness, was solicitous on every occasion for their ease and"      
##  [5197] "enjoyment, and only disturbed that she could not make them choose their"     
##  [5198] "own dinners at the inn, nor extort a confession of their preferring"         
##  [5199] "salmon to cod, or boiled fowls to veal cutlets.  They reached town by"       
##  [5200] "three o'clock the third day, glad to be released, after such a journey,"     
##  [5201] "from the confinement of a carriage, and ready to enjoy all the luxury"       
##  [5202] "of a good fire."                                                             
##  [5203] ""                                                                            
##  [5204] "The house was handsome, and handsomely fitted up, and the young ladies"      
##  [5205] "were immediately put in possession of a very comfortable apartment.  It"     
##  [5206] "had formerly been Charlotte's, and over the mantelpiece still hung a"        
##  [5207] "landscape in coloured silks of her performance, in proof of her having"      
##  [5208] "spent seven years at a great school in town to some effect."                 
##  [5209] ""                                                                            
##  [5210] "As dinner was not to be ready in less than two hours from their"             
##  [5211] "arrival, Elinor determined to employ the interval in writing to her"         
##  [5212] "mother, and sat down for that purpose.  In a few moments Marianne did"       
##  [5213] "the same.  \"I am writing home, Marianne,\" said Elinor; \"had not you"      
##  [5214] "better defer your letter for a day or two?\""                                
##  [5215] ""                                                                            
##  [5216] "\"I am NOT going to write to my mother,\" replied Marianne, hastily, and"    
##  [5217] "as if wishing to avoid any farther inquiry.  Elinor said no more; it"        
##  [5218] "immediately struck her that she must then be writing to Willoughby; and"     
##  [5219] "the conclusion which as instantly followed was, that, however"               
##  [5220] "mysteriously they might wish to conduct the affair, they must be"            
##  [5221] "engaged.  This conviction, though not entirely satisfactory, gave her"       
##  [5222] "pleasure, and she continued her letter with greater alacrity."               
##  [5223] "Marianne's was finished in a very few minutes; in length it could be no"     
##  [5224] "more than a note; it was then folded up, sealed, and directed with"          
##  [5225] "eager rapidity.  Elinor thought she could distinguish a large W in the"      
##  [5226] "direction; and no sooner was it complete than Marianne, ringing the"         
##  [5227] "bell, requested the footman who answered it to get that letter conveyed"     
##  [5228] "for her to the two-penny post.  This decided the matter at once."            
##  [5229] ""                                                                            
##  [5230] "Her spirits still continued very high; but there was a flutter in them"      
##  [5231] "which prevented their giving much pleasure to her sister, and this"          
##  [5232] "agitation increased as the evening drew on.  She could scarcely eat any"     
##  [5233] "dinner, and when they afterwards returned to the drawing room, seemed"       
##  [5234] "anxiously listening to the sound of every carriage."                         
##  [5235] ""                                                                            
##  [5236] "It was a great satisfaction to Elinor that Mrs. Jennings, by being much"     
##  [5237] "engaged in her own room, could see little of what was passing.  The tea"     
##  [5238] "things were brought in, and already had Marianne been disappointed more"     
##  [5239] "than once by a rap at a neighbouring door, when a loud one was suddenly"     
##  [5240] "heard which could not be mistaken for one at any other house, Elinor"        
##  [5241] "felt secure of its announcing Willoughby's approach, and Marianne,"          
##  [5242] "starting up, moved towards the door.  Every thing was silent; this"          
##  [5243] "could not be borne many seconds; she opened the door, advanced a few"        
##  [5244] "steps towards the stairs, and after listening half a minute, returned"       
##  [5245] "into the room in all the agitation which a conviction of having heard"       
##  [5246] "him would naturally produce; in the ecstasy of her feelings at that"         
##  [5247] "instant she could not help exclaiming, \"Oh, Elinor, it is Willoughby,"      
##  [5248] "indeed it is!\" and seemed almost ready to throw herself into his arms,"     
##  [5249] "when Colonel Brandon appeared."                                              
##  [5250] ""                                                                            
##  [5251] "It was too great a shock to be borne with calmness, and she immediately"     
##  [5252] "left the room.  Elinor was disappointed too; but at the same time her"       
##  [5253] "regard for Colonel Brandon ensured his welcome with her; and she felt"       
##  [5254] "particularly hurt that a man so partial to her sister should perceive"       
##  [5255] "that she experienced nothing but grief and disappointment in seeing"         
##  [5256] "him.  She instantly saw that it was not unnoticed by him, that he even"      
##  [5257] "observed Marianne as she quitted the room, with such astonishment and"       
##  [5258] "concern, as hardly left him the recollection of what civility demanded"      
##  [5259] "towards herself."                                                            
##  [5260] ""                                                                            
##  [5261] "\"Is your sister ill?\" said he."                                            
##  [5262] ""                                                                            
##  [5263] "Elinor answered in some distress that she was, and then talked of"           
##  [5264] "head-aches, low spirits, and over fatigues; and of every thing to which"     
##  [5265] "she could decently attribute her sister's behaviour."                        
##  [5266] ""                                                                            
##  [5267] "He heard her with the most earnest attention, but seeming to recollect"      
##  [5268] "himself, said no more on the subject, and began directly to speak of"        
##  [5269] "his pleasure at seeing them in London, making the usual inquiries about"     
##  [5270] "their journey, and the friends they had left behind."                        
##  [5271] ""                                                                            
##  [5272] "In this calm kind of way, with very little interest on either side,"         
##  [5273] "they continued to talk, both of them out of spirits, and the thoughts"       
##  [5274] "of both engaged elsewhere.  Elinor wished very much to ask whether"          
##  [5275] "Willoughby were then in town, but she was afraid of giving him pain by"      
##  [5276] "any enquiry after his rival; and at length, by way of saying something,"     
##  [5277] "she asked if he had been in London ever since she had seen him last."        
##  [5278] "\"Yes,\" he replied, with some embarrassment, \"almost ever since; I have"   
##  [5279] "been once or twice at Delaford for a few days, but it has never been in"     
##  [5280] "my power to return to Barton.\""                                             
##  [5281] ""                                                                            
##  [5282] "This, and the manner in which it was said, immediately brought back to"      
##  [5283] "her remembrance all the circumstances of his quitting that place, with"      
##  [5284] "the uneasiness and suspicions they had caused to Mrs. Jennings, and she"     
##  [5285] "was fearful that her question had implied much more curiosity on the"        
##  [5286] "subject than she had ever felt."                                             
##  [5287] ""                                                                            
##  [5288] "Mrs. Jennings soon came in.  \"Oh! Colonel,\" said she, with her usual"      
##  [5289] "noisy cheerfulness, \"I am monstrous glad to see you--sorry I could not"     
##  [5290] "come before--beg your pardon, but I have been forced to look about me a"     
##  [5291] "little, and settle my matters; for it is a long while since I have been"     
##  [5292] "at home, and you know one has always a world of little odd things to do"     
##  [5293] "after one has been away for any time; and then I have had Cartwright to"     
##  [5294] "settle with-- Lord, I have been as busy as a bee ever since dinner!"         
##  [5295] "But pray, Colonel, how came you to conjure out that I should be in town"     
##  [5296] "today?\""                                                                    
##  [5297] ""                                                                            
##  [5298] "\"I had the pleasure of hearing it at Mr. Palmer's, where I have been"       
##  [5299] "dining.\""                                                                   
##  [5300] ""                                                                            
##  [5301] "\"Oh, you did; well, and how do they all do at their house?  How does"       
##  [5302] "Charlotte do?  I warrant you she is a fine size by this time.\""             
##  [5303] ""                                                                            
##  [5304] "\"Mrs. Palmer appeared quite well, and I am commissioned to tell you,"       
##  [5305] "that you will certainly see her to-morrow.\""                                
##  [5306] ""                                                                            
##  [5307] "\"Ay, to be sure, I thought as much.  Well, Colonel, I have brought two"     
##  [5308] "young ladies with me, you see--that is, you see but one of them now,"        
##  [5309] "but there is another somewhere.  Your friend, Miss Marianne, too--which"     
##  [5310] "you will not be sorry to hear.  I do not know what you and Mr."              
##  [5311] "Willoughby will do between you about her.  Ay, it is a fine thing to be"     
##  [5312] "young and handsome.  Well! I was young once, but I never was very"           
##  [5313] "handsome--worse luck for me.  However, I got a very good husband, and I"     
##  [5314] "don't know what the greatest beauty can do more.  Ah! poor man! he has"      
##  [5315] "been dead these eight years and better.  But Colonel, where have you"        
##  [5316] "been to since we parted?  And how does your business go on?  Come,"          
##  [5317] "come, let's have no secrets among friends.\""                                
##  [5318] ""                                                                            
##  [5319] "He replied with his accustomary mildness to all her inquiries, but"          
##  [5320] "without satisfying her in any.  Elinor now began to make the tea, and"       
##  [5321] "Marianne was obliged to appear again."                                       
##  [5322] ""                                                                            
##  [5323] "After her entrance, Colonel Brandon became more thoughtful and silent"       
##  [5324] "than he had been before, and Mrs. Jennings could not prevail on him to"      
##  [5325] "stay long.  No other visitor appeared that evening, and the ladies were"     
##  [5326] "unanimous in agreeing to go early to bed."                                   
##  [5327] ""                                                                            
##  [5328] "Marianne rose the next morning with recovered spirits and happy looks."      
##  [5329] "The disappointment of the evening before seemed forgotten in the"            
##  [5330] "expectation of what was to happen that day.  They had not long finished"     
##  [5331] "their breakfast before Mrs. Palmer's barouche stopped at the door, and"      
##  [5332] "in a few minutes she came laughing into the room: so delighted to see"       
##  [5333] "them all, that it was hard to say whether she received most pleasure"        
##  [5334] "from meeting her mother or the Miss Dashwoods again.  So surprised at"       
##  [5335] "their coming to town, though it was what she had rather expected all"        
##  [5336] "along; so angry at their accepting her mother's invitation after having"     
##  [5337] "declined her own, though at the same time she would never have forgiven"     
##  [5338] "them if they had not come!"                                                  
##  [5339] ""                                                                            
##  [5340] "\"Mr. Palmer will be so happy to see you,\" said she; \"What do you think"   
##  [5341] "he said when he heard of your coming with Mama?  I forget what it was"       
##  [5342] "now, but it was something so droll!\""                                       
##  [5343] ""                                                                            
##  [5344] "After an hour or two spent in what her mother called comfortable chat,"      
##  [5345] "or in other words, in every variety of inquiry concerning all their"         
##  [5346] "acquaintance on Mrs. Jennings's side, and in laughter without cause on"      
##  [5347] "Mrs. Palmer's, it was proposed by the latter that they should all"           
##  [5348] "accompany her to some shops where she had business that morning, to"         
##  [5349] "which Mrs. Jennings and Elinor readily consented, as having likewise"        
##  [5350] "some purchases to make themselves; and Marianne, though declining it at"     
##  [5351] "first was induced to go likewise."                                           
##  [5352] ""                                                                            
##  [5353] "Wherever they went, she was evidently always on the watch.  In Bond"         
##  [5354] "Street especially, where much of their business lay, her eyes were in"       
##  [5355] "constant inquiry; and in whatever shop the party were engaged, her mind"     
##  [5356] "was equally abstracted from every thing actually before them, from all"      
##  [5357] "that interested and occupied the others.  Restless and dissatisfied"         
##  [5358] "every where, her sister could never obtain her opinion of any article"       
##  [5359] "of purchase, however it might equally concern them both: she received"       
##  [5360] "no pleasure from anything; was only impatient to be at home again, and"      
##  [5361] "could with difficulty govern her vexation at the tediousness of Mrs."        
##  [5362] "Palmer, whose eye was caught by every thing pretty, expensive, or new;"      
##  [5363] "who was wild to buy all, could determine on none, and dawdled away her"      
##  [5364] "time in rapture and indecision."                                             
##  [5365] ""                                                                            
##  [5366] "It was late in the morning before they returned home; and no sooner had"     
##  [5367] "they entered the house than Marianne flew eagerly up stairs, and when"       
##  [5368] "Elinor followed, she found her turning from the table with a sorrowful"      
##  [5369] "countenance, which declared that no Willoughby had been there."              
##  [5370] ""                                                                            
##  [5371] "\"Has no letter been left here for me since we went out?\" said she to"      
##  [5372] "the footman who then entered with the parcels.  She was answered in the"     
##  [5373] "negative.  \"Are you quite sure of it?\" she replied.  \"Are you certain"    
##  [5374] "that no servant, no porter has left any letter or note?\""                   
##  [5375] ""                                                                            
##  [5376] "The man replied that none had."                                              
##  [5377] ""                                                                            
##  [5378] "\"How very odd!\" said she, in a low and disappointed voice, as she"         
##  [5379] "turned away to the window."                                                  
##  [5380] ""                                                                            
##  [5381] "\"How odd, indeed!\" repeated Elinor within herself, regarding her sister"   
##  [5382] "with uneasiness.  \"If she had not known him to be in town she would not"    
##  [5383] "have written to him, as she did; she would have written to Combe Magna;"     
##  [5384] "and if he is in town, how odd that he should neither come nor write!"        
##  [5385] "Oh! my dear mother, you must be wrong in permitting an engagement"           
##  [5386] "between a daughter so young, a man so little known, to be carried on in"     
##  [5387] "so doubtful, so mysterious a manner!  I long to inquire; and how will"       
##  [5388] "MY interference be borne.\""                                                 
##  [5389] ""                                                                            
##  [5390] "She determined, after some consideration, that if appearances continued"     
##  [5391] "many days longer as unpleasant as they now were, she would represent in"     
##  [5392] "the strongest manner to her mother the necessity of some serious"            
##  [5393] "enquiry into the affair."                                                    
##  [5394] ""                                                                            
##  [5395] "Mrs. Palmer and two elderly ladies of Mrs. Jennings's intimate"              
##  [5396] "acquaintance, whom she had met and invited in the morning, dined with"       
##  [5397] "them.  The former left them soon after tea to fulfill her evening"           
##  [5398] "engagements; and Elinor was obliged to assist in making a whist table"       
##  [5399] "for the others.  Marianne was of no use on these occasions, as she"          
##  [5400] "would never learn the game; but though her time was therefore at her"        
##  [5401] "own disposal, the evening was by no means more productive of pleasure"       
##  [5402] "to her than to Elinor, for it was spent in all the anxiety of"               
##  [5403] "expectation and the pain of disappointment.  She sometimes endeavoured"      
##  [5404] "for a few minutes to read; but the book was soon thrown aside, and she"      
##  [5405] "returned to the more interesting employment of walking backwards and"        
##  [5406] "forwards across the room, pausing for a moment whenever she came to the"     
##  [5407] "window, in hopes of distinguishing the long-expected rap."                   
##  [5408] ""                                                                            
##  [5409] ""                                                                            
##  [5410] ""                                                                            
##  [5411] "CHAPTER 27"                                                                  
##  [5412] ""                                                                            
##  [5413] ""                                                                            
##  [5414] "\"If this open weather holds much longer,\" said Mrs. Jennings, when they"   
##  [5415] "met at breakfast the following morning, \"Sir John will not like leaving"    
##  [5416] "Barton next week; 'tis a sad thing for sportsmen to lose a day's"            
##  [5417] "pleasure.  Poor souls!  I always pity them when they do; they seem to"       
##  [5418] "take it so much to heart.\""                                                 
##  [5419] ""                                                                            
##  [5420] "\"That is true,\" cried Marianne, in a cheerful voice, and walking to the"   
##  [5421] "window as she spoke, to examine the day.  \"I had not thought of that."      
##  [5422] "This weather will keep many sportsmen in the country.\""                     
##  [5423] ""                                                                            
##  [5424] "It was a lucky recollection, all her good spirits were restored by it."      
##  [5425] "\"It is charming weather for THEM indeed,\" she continued, as she sat"       
##  [5426] "down to the breakfast table with a happy countenance.  \"How much they"      
##  [5427] "must enjoy it! But\" (with a little return of anxiety) \"it cannot be"       
##  [5428] "expected to last long.  At this time of the year, and after such a"          
##  [5429] "series of rain, we shall certainly have very little more of it.  Frosts"     
##  [5430] "will soon set in, and in all probability with severity.  In another day"     
##  [5431] "or two perhaps; this extreme mildness can hardly last longer--nay,"          
##  [5432] "perhaps it may freeze tonight!\""                                            
##  [5433] ""                                                                            
##  [5434] "\"At any rate,\" said Elinor, wishing to prevent Mrs. Jennings from"         
##  [5435] "seeing her sister's thoughts as clearly as she did, \"I dare say we"         
##  [5436] "shall have Sir John and Lady Middleton in town by the end of next week.\""   
##  [5437] ""                                                                            
##  [5438] "\"Ay, my dear, I'll warrant you we do.  Mary always has her own way.\""      
##  [5439] ""                                                                            
##  [5440] "\"And now,\" silently conjectured Elinor, \"she will write to Combe by"      
##  [5441] "this day's post.\""                                                          
##  [5442] ""                                                                            
##  [5443] "But if she DID, the letter was written and sent away with a privacy"         
##  [5444] "which eluded all her watchfulness to ascertain the fact.  Whatever the"      
##  [5445] "truth of it might be, and far as Elinor was from feeling thorough"           
##  [5446] "contentment about it, yet while she saw Marianne in spirits, she could"      
##  [5447] "not be very uncomfortable herself.  And Marianne was in spirits; happy"      
##  [5448] "in the mildness of the weather, and still happier in her expectation of"     
##  [5449] "a frost."                                                                    
##  [5450] ""                                                                            
##  [5451] "The morning was chiefly spent in leaving cards at the houses of Mrs."        
##  [5452] "Jennings's acquaintance to inform them of her being in town; and"            
##  [5453] "Marianne was all the time busy in observing the direction of the wind,"      
##  [5454] "watching the variations of the sky and imagining an alteration in the"       
##  [5455] "air."                                                                        
##  [5456] ""                                                                            
##  [5457] "\"Don't you find it colder than it was in the morning, Elinor? There"        
##  [5458] "seems to me a very decided difference.  I can hardly keep my hands warm"     
##  [5459] "even in my muff.  It was not so yesterday, I think.  The clouds seem"        
##  [5460] "parting too, the sun will be out in a moment, and we shall have a clear"     
##  [5461] "afternoon.\""                                                                
##  [5462] ""                                                                            
##  [5463] "Elinor was alternately diverted and pained; but Marianne persevered,"        
##  [5464] "and saw every night in the brightness of the fire, and every morning in"     
##  [5465] "the appearance of the atmosphere, the certain symptoms of approaching"       
##  [5466] "frost."                                                                      
##  [5467] ""                                                                            
##  [5468] "The Miss Dashwoods had no greater reason to be dissatisfied with Mrs."       
##  [5469] "Jennings's style of living, and set of acquaintance, than with her"          
##  [5470] "behaviour to themselves, which was invariably kind.  Every thing in her"     
##  [5471] "household arrangements was conducted on the most liberal plan, and"          
##  [5472] "excepting a few old city friends, whom, to Lady Middleton's regret, she"     
##  [5473] "had never dropped, she visited no one to whom an introduction could at"      
##  [5474] "all discompose the feelings of her young companions.  Pleased to find"       
##  [5475] "herself more comfortably situated in that particular than she had"           
##  [5476] "expected, Elinor was very willing to compound for the want of much real"     
##  [5477] "enjoyment from any of their evening parties, which, whether at home or"      
##  [5478] "abroad, formed only for cards, could have little to amuse her."              
##  [5479] ""                                                                            
##  [5480] "Colonel Brandon, who had a general invitation to the house, was with"        
##  [5481] "them almost every day; he came to look at Marianne and talk to Elinor,"      
##  [5482] "who often derived more satisfaction from conversing with him than from"      
##  [5483] "any other daily occurrence, but who saw at the same time with much"          
##  [5484] "concern his continued regard for her sister.  She feared it was a"           
##  [5485] "strengthening regard.  It grieved her to see the earnestness with which"     
##  [5486] "he often watched Marianne, and his spirits were certainly worse than"        
##  [5487] "when at Barton."                                                             
##  [5488] ""                                                                            
##  [5489] "About a week after their arrival, it became certain that Willoughby was"     
##  [5490] "also arrived.  His card was on the table when they came in from the"         
##  [5491] "morning's drive."                                                            
##  [5492] ""                                                                            
##  [5493] "\"Good God!\" cried Marianne, \"he has been here while we were out.\""       
##  [5494] "Elinor, rejoiced to be assured of his being in London, now ventured to"      
##  [5495] "say, \"Depend upon it, he will call again tomorrow.\"  But Marianne"         
##  [5496] "seemed hardly to hear her, and on Mrs. Jennings's entrance, escaped with"    
##  [5497] "the precious card."                                                          
##  [5498] ""                                                                            
##  [5499] "This event, while it raised the spirits of Elinor, restored to those of"     
##  [5500] "her sister all, and more than all, their former agitation.  From this"       
##  [5501] "moment her mind was never quiet; the expectation of seeing him every"        
##  [5502] "hour of the day, made her unfit for any thing.  She insisted on being"       
##  [5503] "left behind, the next morning, when the others went out."                    
##  [5504] ""                                                                            
##  [5505] "Elinor's thoughts were full of what might be passing in Berkeley Street"     
##  [5506] "during their absence; but a moment's glance at her sister when they"         
##  [5507] "returned was enough to inform her, that Willoughby had paid no second"       
##  [5508] "visit there.  A note was just then brought in, and laid on the table."       
##  [5509] ""                                                                            
##  [5510] "\"For me!\" cried Marianne, stepping hastily forward."                       
##  [5511] ""                                                                            
##  [5512] "\"No, ma'am, for my mistress.\""                                             
##  [5513] ""                                                                            
##  [5514] "But Marianne, not convinced, took it instantly up."                          
##  [5515] ""                                                                            
##  [5516] "\"It is indeed for Mrs. Jennings; how provoking!\""                          
##  [5517] ""                                                                            
##  [5518] "\"You are expecting a letter, then?\" said Elinor, unable to be longer"      
##  [5519] "silent."                                                                     
##  [5520] ""                                                                            
##  [5521] "\"Yes, a little--not much.\""                                                
##  [5522] ""                                                                            
##  [5523] "After a short pause.  \"You have no confidence in me, Marianne.\""           
##  [5524] ""                                                                            
##  [5525] "\"Nay, Elinor, this reproach from YOU--you who have confidence in no"        
##  [5526] "one!\""                                                                      
##  [5527] ""                                                                            
##  [5528] "\"Me!\" returned Elinor in some confusion; \"indeed, Marianne, I have"       
##  [5529] "nothing to tell.\""                                                          
##  [5530] ""                                                                            
##  [5531] "\"Nor I,\" answered Marianne with energy, \"our situations then are alike."  
##  [5532] "We have neither of us any thing to tell; you, because you do not"            
##  [5533] "communicate, and I, because I conceal nothing.\""                            
##  [5534] ""                                                                            
##  [5535] "Elinor, distressed by this charge of reserve in herself, which she was"      
##  [5536] "not at liberty to do away, knew not how, under such circumstances, to"       
##  [5537] "press for greater openness in Marianne."                                     
##  [5538] ""                                                                            
##  [5539] "Mrs. Jennings soon appeared, and the note being given her, she read it"      
##  [5540] "aloud.  It was from Lady Middleton, announcing their arrival in Conduit"     
##  [5541] "Street the night before, and requesting the company of her mother and"       
##  [5542] "cousins the following evening.  Business on Sir John's part, and a"          
##  [5543] "violent cold on her own, prevented their calling in Berkeley Street."        
##  [5544] "The invitation was accepted; but when the hour of appointment drew"          
##  [5545] "near, necessary as it was in common civility to Mrs. Jennings, that"         
##  [5546] "they should both attend her on such a visit, Elinor had some difficulty"     
##  [5547] "in persuading her sister to go, for still she had seen nothing of"           
##  [5548] "Willoughby; and therefore was not more indisposed for amusement abroad,"     
##  [5549] "than unwilling to run the risk of his calling again in her absence."         
##  [5550] ""                                                                            
##  [5551] "Elinor found, when the evening was over, that disposition is not"            
##  [5552] "materially altered by a change of abode, for although scarcely settled"      
##  [5553] "in town, Sir John had contrived to collect around him, nearly twenty"        
##  [5554] "young people, and to amuse them with a ball.  This was an affair,"           
##  [5555] "however, of which Lady Middleton did not approve.  In the country, an"       
##  [5556] "unpremeditated dance was very allowable; but in London, where the"           
##  [5557] "reputation of elegance was more important and less easily attained, it"      
##  [5558] "was risking too much for the gratification of a few girls, to have it"       
##  [5559] "known that Lady Middleton had given a small dance of eight or nine"          
##  [5560] "couple, with two violins, and a mere side-board collation."                  
##  [5561] ""                                                                            
##  [5562] "Mr. and Mrs. Palmer were of the party; from the former, whom they had"       
##  [5563] "not seen before since their arrival in town, as he was careful to avoid"     
##  [5564] "the appearance of any attention to his mother-in-law, and therefore"         
##  [5565] "never came near her, they received no mark of recognition on their"          
##  [5566] "entrance.  He looked at them slightly, without seeming to know who they"     
##  [5567] "were, and merely nodded to Mrs. Jennings from the other side of the"         
##  [5568] "room.  Marianne gave one glance round the apartment as she entered: it"      
##  [5569] "was enough--HE was not there--and she sat down, equally ill-disposed to"     
##  [5570] "receive or communicate pleasure.  After they had been assembled about"       
##  [5571] "an hour, Mr. Palmer sauntered towards the Miss Dashwoods to express his"     
##  [5572] "surprise on seeing them in town, though Colonel Brandon had been first"      
##  [5573] "informed of their arrival at his house, and he had himself said"             
##  [5574] "something very droll on hearing that they were to come."                     
##  [5575] ""                                                                            
##  [5576] "\"I thought you were both in Devonshire,\" said he."                         
##  [5577] ""                                                                            
##  [5578] "\"Did you?\" replied Elinor."                                                
##  [5579] ""                                                                            
##  [5580] "\"When do you go back again?\""                                              
##  [5581] ""                                                                            
##  [5582] "\"I do not know.\" And thus ended their discourse."                          
##  [5583] ""                                                                            
##  [5584] "Never had Marianne been so unwilling to dance in her life, as she was"       
##  [5585] "that evening, and never so much fatigued by the exercise.  She"              
##  [5586] "complained of it as they returned to Berkeley Street."                       
##  [5587] ""                                                                            
##  [5588] "\"Aye, aye,\" said Mrs. Jennings, \"we know the reason of all that very"     
##  [5589] "well; if a certain person who shall be nameless, had been there, you"        
##  [5590] "would not have been a bit tired: and to say the truth it was not very"       
##  [5591] "pretty of him not to give you the meeting when he was invited.\""            
##  [5592] ""                                                                            
##  [5593] "\"Invited!\" cried Marianne."                                                
##  [5594] ""                                                                            
##  [5595] "\"So my daughter Middleton told me, for it seems Sir John met him"           
##  [5596] "somewhere in the street this morning.\" Marianne said no more, but"          
##  [5597] "looked exceedingly hurt.  Impatient in this situation to be doing"           
##  [5598] "something that might lead to her sister's relief, Elinor resolved to"        
##  [5599] "write the next morning to her mother, and hoped by awakening her fears"      
##  [5600] "for the health of Marianne, to procure those inquiries which had been"       
##  [5601] "so long delayed; and she was still more eagerly bent on this measure by"     
##  [5602] "perceiving after breakfast on the morrow, that Marianne was again"           
##  [5603] "writing to Willoughby, for she could not suppose it to be to any other"      
##  [5604] "person."                                                                     
##  [5605] ""                                                                            
##  [5606] "About the middle of the day, Mrs. Jennings went out by herself on"           
##  [5607] "business, and Elinor began her letter directly, while Marianne, too"         
##  [5608] "restless for employment, too anxious for conversation, walked from one"      
##  [5609] "window to the other, or sat down by the fire in melancholy meditation."      
##  [5610] "Elinor was very earnest in her application to her mother, relating all"      
##  [5611] "that had passed, her suspicions of Willoughby's inconstancy, urging her"     
##  [5612] "by every plea of duty and affection to demand from Marianne an account"      
##  [5613] "of her real situation with respect to him."                                  
##  [5614] ""                                                                            
##  [5615] "Her letter was scarcely finished, when a rap foretold a visitor, and"        
##  [5616] "Colonel Brandon was announced.  Marianne, who had seen him from the"         
##  [5617] "window, and who hated company of any kind, left the room before he"          
##  [5618] "entered it.  He looked more than usually grave, and though expressing"       
##  [5619] "satisfaction at finding Miss Dashwood alone, as if he had somewhat in"       
##  [5620] "particular to tell her, sat for some time without saying a word."            
##  [5621] "Elinor, persuaded that he had some communication to make in which her"       
##  [5622] "sister was concerned, impatiently expected its opening.  It was not the"     
##  [5623] "first time of her feeling the same kind of conviction; for, more than"       
##  [5624] "once before, beginning with the observation of \"your sister looks"          
##  [5625] "unwell to-day,\" or \"your sister seems out of spirits,\" he had appeared"   
##  [5626] "on the point, either of disclosing, or of inquiring, something"              
##  [5627] "particular about her.  After a pause of several minutes, their silence"      
##  [5628] "was broken, by his asking her in a voice of some agitation, when he was"     
##  [5629] "to congratulate her on the acquisition of a brother?  Elinor was not"        
##  [5630] "prepared for such a question, and having no answer ready, was obliged"       
##  [5631] "to adopt the simple and common expedient, of asking what he meant?  He"      
##  [5632] "tried to smile as he replied, \"your sister's engagement to Mr."             
##  [5633] "Willoughby is very generally known.\""                                       
##  [5634] ""                                                                            
##  [5635] "\"It cannot be generally known,\" returned Elinor, \"for her own family do"  
##  [5636] "not know it.\""                                                              
##  [5637] ""                                                                            
##  [5638] "He looked surprised and said, \"I beg your pardon, I am afraid my"           
##  [5639] "inquiry has been impertinent; but I had not supposed any secrecy"            
##  [5640] "intended, as they openly correspond, and their marriage is universally"      
##  [5641] "talked of.\""                                                                
##  [5642] ""                                                                            
##  [5643] "\"How can that be? By whom can you have heard it mentioned?\""               
##  [5644] ""                                                                            
##  [5645] "\"By many--by some of whom you know nothing, by others with whom you are"    
##  [5646] "most intimate, Mrs. Jennings, Mrs. Palmer, and the Middletons.  But"         
##  [5647] "still I might not have believed it, for where the mind is perhaps"           
##  [5648] "rather unwilling to be convinced, it will always find something to"          
##  [5649] "support its doubts, if I had not, when the servant let me in today,"         
##  [5650] "accidentally seen a letter in his hand, directed to Mr. Willoughby in"       
##  [5651] "your sister's writing.  I came to inquire, but I was convinced before I"     
##  [5652] "could ask the question.  Is every thing finally settled?  Is it"             
##  [5653] "impossible to-?  But I have no right, and I could have no chance of"         
##  [5654] "succeeding.  Excuse me, Miss Dashwood.  I believe I have been wrong in"      
##  [5655] "saying so much, but I hardly know what to do, and on your prudence I"        
##  [5656] "have the strongest dependence.  Tell me that it is all absolutely"           
##  [5657] "resolved on, that any attempt, that in short concealment, if"                
##  [5658] "concealment be possible, is all that remains.\""                             
##  [5659] ""                                                                            
##  [5660] "These words, which conveyed to Elinor a direct avowal of his love for"       
##  [5661] "her sister, affected her very much.  She was not immediately able to"        
##  [5662] "say anything, and even when her spirits were recovered, she debated for"     
##  [5663] "a short time, on the answer it would be most proper to give.  The real"      
##  [5664] "state of things between Willoughby and her sister was so little known"       
##  [5665] "to herself, that in endeavouring to explain it, she might be as liable"      
##  [5666] "to say too much as too little.  Yet as she was convinced that"               
##  [5667] "Marianne's affection for Willoughby, could leave no hope of Colonel"         
##  [5668] "Brandon's success, whatever the event of that affection might be, and"       
##  [5669] "at the same time wished to shield her conduct from censure, she thought"     
##  [5670] "it most prudent and kind, after some consideration, to say more than"        
##  [5671] "she really knew or believed.  She acknowledged, therefore, that though"      
##  [5672] "she had never been informed by themselves of the terms on which they"        
##  [5673] "stood with each other, of their mutual affection she had no doubt, and"      
##  [5674] "of their correspondence she was not astonished to hear."                     
##  [5675] ""                                                                            
##  [5676] "He listened to her with silent attention, and on her ceasing to speak,"      
##  [5677] "rose directly from his seat, and after saying in a voice of emotion,"        
##  [5678] "\"to your sister I wish all imaginable happiness; to Willoughby that he"     
##  [5679] "may endeavour to deserve her,\"--took leave, and went away."                 
##  [5680] ""                                                                            
##  [5681] "Elinor derived no comfortable feelings from this conversation, to"           
##  [5682] "lessen the uneasiness of her mind on other points; she was left, on the"     
##  [5683] "contrary, with a melancholy impression of Colonel Brandon's"                 
##  [5684] "unhappiness, and was prevented even from wishing it removed, by her"         
##  [5685] "anxiety for the very event that must confirm it."                            
##  [5686] ""                                                                            
##  [5687] ""                                                                            
##  [5688] ""                                                                            
##  [5689] "CHAPTER 28"                                                                  
##  [5690] ""                                                                            
##  [5691] ""                                                                            
##  [5692] "Nothing occurred during the next three or four days, to make Elinor"         
##  [5693] "regret what she had done, in applying to her mother; for Willoughby"         
##  [5694] "neither came nor wrote.  They were engaged about the end of that time"       
##  [5695] "to attend Lady Middleton to a party, from which Mrs. Jennings was kept"      
##  [5696] "away by the indisposition of her youngest daughter; and for this party,"     
##  [5697] "Marianne, wholly dispirited, careless of her appearance, and seeming"        
##  [5698] "equally indifferent whether she went or staid, prepared, without one"        
##  [5699] "look of hope or one expression of pleasure.  She sat by the"                 
##  [5700] "drawing-room fire after tea, till the moment of Lady Middleton's"            
##  [5701] "arrival, without once stirring from her seat, or altering her attitude,"     
##  [5702] "lost in her own thoughts, and insensible of her sister's presence; and"      
##  [5703] "when at last they were told that Lady Middleton waited for them at the"      
##  [5704] "door, she started as if she had forgotten that any one was expected."        
##  [5705] ""                                                                            
##  [5706] "They arrived in due time at the place of destination, and as soon as"        
##  [5707] "the string of carriages before them would allow, alighted, ascended the"     
##  [5708] "stairs, heard their names announced from one landing-place to another"       
##  [5709] "in an audible voice, and entered a room splendidly lit up, quite full"       
##  [5710] "of company, and insufferably hot.  When they had paid their tribute of"      
##  [5711] "politeness by curtsying to the lady of the house, they were permitted"       
##  [5712] "to mingle in the crowd, and take their share of the heat and"                
##  [5713] "inconvenience, to which their arrival must necessarily add.  After some"     
##  [5714] "time spent in saying little or doing less, Lady Middleton sat down to"       
##  [5715] "Cassino, and as Marianne was not in spirits for moving about, she and"       
##  [5716] "Elinor luckily succeeding to chairs, placed themselves at no great"          
##  [5717] "distance from the table."                                                    
##  [5718] ""                                                                            
##  [5719] "They had not remained in this manner long, before Elinor perceived"          
##  [5720] "Willoughby, standing within a few yards of them, in earnest"                 
##  [5721] "conversation with a very fashionable looking young woman.  She soon"         
##  [5722] "caught his eye, and he immediately bowed, but without attempting to"         
##  [5723] "speak to her, or to approach Marianne, though he could not but see her;"     
##  [5724] "and then continued his discourse with the same lady.  Elinor turned"         
##  [5725] "involuntarily to Marianne, to see whether it could be unobserved by"         
##  [5726] "her.  At that moment she first perceived him, and her whole countenance"     
##  [5727] "glowing with sudden delight, she would have moved towards him"               
##  [5728] "instantly, had not her sister caught hold of her."                           
##  [5729] ""                                                                            
##  [5730] "\"Good heavens!\" she exclaimed, \"he is there--he is there--Oh! why does"   
##  [5731] "he not look at me? why cannot I speak to him?\""                             
##  [5732] ""                                                                            
##  [5733] "\"Pray, pray be composed,\" cried Elinor, \"and do not betray what you"      
##  [5734] "feel to every body present.  Perhaps he has not observed you yet.\""         
##  [5735] ""                                                                            
##  [5736] "This however was more than she could believe herself; and to be"             
##  [5737] "composed at such a moment was not only beyond the reach of Marianne, it"     
##  [5738] "was beyond her wish.  She sat in an agony of impatience which affected"      
##  [5739] "every feature."                                                              
##  [5740] ""                                                                            
##  [5741] "At last he turned round again, and regarded them both; she started up,"      
##  [5742] "and pronouncing his name in a tone of affection, held out her hand to"       
##  [5743] "him.  He approached, and addressing himself rather to Elinor than"           
##  [5744] "Marianne, as if wishing to avoid her eye, and determined not to observe"     
##  [5745] "her attitude, inquired in a hurried manner after Mrs. Dashwood, and"         
##  [5746] "asked how long they had been in town.  Elinor was robbed of all"             
##  [5747] "presence of mind by such an address, and was unable to say a word.  But"     
##  [5748] "the feelings of her sister were instantly expressed.  Her face was"          
##  [5749] "crimsoned over, and she exclaimed, in a voice of the greatest emotion,"      
##  [5750] "\"Good God! Willoughby, what is the meaning of this?  Have you not"          
##  [5751] "received my letters?  Will you not shake hands with me?\""                   
##  [5752] ""                                                                            
##  [5753] "He could not then avoid it, but her touch seemed painful to him, and he"     
##  [5754] "held her hand only for a moment.  During all this time he was evidently"     
##  [5755] "struggling for composure.  Elinor watched his countenance and saw its"       
##  [5756] "expression becoming more tranquil.  After a moment's pause, he spoke"        
##  [5757] "with calmness."                                                              
##  [5758] ""                                                                            
##  [5759] "\"I did myself the honour of calling in Berkeley Street last Tuesday,"       
##  [5760] "and very much regretted that I was not fortunate enough to find"             
##  [5761] "yourselves and Mrs. Jennings at home.  My card was not lost, I hope.\""      
##  [5762] ""                                                                            
##  [5763] "\"But have you not received my notes?\" cried Marianne in the wildest"       
##  [5764] "anxiety.  \"Here is some mistake I am sure--some dreadful mistake.  What"    
##  [5765] "can be the meaning of it?  Tell me, Willoughby; for heaven's sake tell"      
##  [5766] "me, what is the matter?\""                                                   
##  [5767] ""                                                                            
##  [5768] "He made no reply; his complexion changed and all his embarrassment"          
##  [5769] "returned; but as if, on catching the eye of the young lady with whom he"     
##  [5770] "had been previously talking, he felt the necessity of instant exertion,"     
##  [5771] "he recovered himself again, and after saying, \"Yes, I had the pleasure"     
##  [5772] "of receiving the information of your arrival in town, which you were so"     
##  [5773] "good as to send me,\" turned hastily away with a slight bow and joined"      
##  [5774] "his friend."                                                                 
##  [5775] ""                                                                            
##  [5776] "Marianne, now looking dreadfully white, and unable to stand, sunk into"      
##  [5777] "her chair, and Elinor, expecting every moment to see her faint, tried"       
##  [5778] "to screen her from the observation of others, while reviving her with"       
##  [5779] "lavender water."                                                             
##  [5780] ""                                                                            
##  [5781] "\"Go to him, Elinor,\" she cried, as soon as she could speak, \"and force"   
##  [5782] "him to come to me.  Tell him I must see him again--must speak to him"        
##  [5783] "instantly.-- I cannot rest--I shall not have a moment's peace till this"     
##  [5784] "is explained--some dreadful misapprehension or other.-- Oh go to him"        
##  [5785] "this moment.\""                                                              
##  [5786] ""                                                                            
##  [5787] "\"How can that be done? No, my dearest Marianne, you must wait.  This is"    
##  [5788] "not the place for explanations.  Wait only till tomorrow.\""                 
##  [5789] ""                                                                            
##  [5790] "With difficulty however could she prevent her from following him"            
##  [5791] "herself; and to persuade her to check her agitation, to wait, at least,"     
##  [5792] "with the appearance of composure, till she might speak to him with more"     
##  [5793] "privacy and more effect, was impossible; for Marianne continued"             
##  [5794] "incessantly to give way in a low voice to the misery of her feelings,"       
##  [5795] "by exclamations of wretchedness.  In a short time Elinor saw Willoughby"     
##  [5796] "quit the room by the door towards the staircase, and telling Marianne"       
##  [5797] "that he was gone, urged the impossibility of speaking to him again that"     
##  [5798] "evening, as a fresh argument for her to be calm.  She instantly begged"      
##  [5799] "her sister would entreat Lady Middleton to take them home, as she was"       
##  [5800] "too miserable to stay a minute longer."                                      
##  [5801] ""                                                                            
##  [5802] "Lady Middleton, though in the middle of a rubber, on being informed"         
##  [5803] "that Marianne was unwell, was too polite to object for a moment to her"      
##  [5804] "wish of going away, and making over her cards to a friend, they"             
##  [5805] "departed as soon the carriage could be found.  Scarcely a word was"          
##  [5806] "spoken during their return to Berkeley Street.  Marianne was in a"           
##  [5807] "silent agony, too much oppressed even for tears; but as Mrs. Jennings"       
##  [5808] "was luckily not come home, they could go directly to their own room,"        
##  [5809] "where hartshorn restored her a little to herself.  She was soon"             
##  [5810] "undressed and in bed, and as she seemed desirous of being alone, her"        
##  [5811] "sister then left her, and while she waited the return of Mrs. Jennings,"     
##  [5812] "had leisure enough for thinking over the past."                              
##  [5813] ""                                                                            
##  [5814] "That some kind of engagement had subsisted between Willoughby and"           
##  [5815] "Marianne she could not doubt, and that Willoughby was weary of it,"          
##  [5816] "seemed equally clear; for however Marianne might still feed her own"         
##  [5817] "wishes, SHE could not attribute such behaviour to mistake or"                
##  [5818] "misapprehension of any kind.  Nothing but a thorough change of"              
##  [5819] "sentiment could account for it.  Her indignation would have been still"      
##  [5820] "stronger than it was, had she not witnessed that embarrassment which"        
##  [5821] "seemed to speak a consciousness of his own misconduct, and prevented"        
##  [5822] "her from believing him so unprincipled as to have been sporting with"        
##  [5823] "the affections of her sister from the first, without any design that"        
##  [5824] "would bear investigation.  Absence might have weakened his regard, and"      
##  [5825] "convenience might have determined him to overcome it, but that such a"       
##  [5826] "regard had formerly existed she could not bring herself to doubt."           
##  [5827] ""                                                                            
##  [5828] "As for Marianne, on the pangs which so unhappy a meeting must already"       
##  [5829] "have given her, and on those still more severe which might await her in"     
##  [5830] "its probable consequence, she could not reflect without the deepest"         
##  [5831] "concern.  Her own situation gained in the comparison; for while she"         
##  [5832] "could ESTEEM Edward as much as ever, however they might be divided in"       
##  [5833] "future, her mind might be always supported.  But every circumstance"         
##  [5834] "that could embitter such an evil seemed uniting to heighten the misery"      
##  [5835] "of Marianne in a final separation from Willoughby--in an immediate and"      
##  [5836] "irreconcilable rupture with him."                                            
##  [5837] ""                                                                            
##  [5838] ""                                                                            
##  [5839] ""                                                                            
##  [5840] "CHAPTER 29"                                                                  
##  [5841] ""                                                                            
##  [5842] ""                                                                            
##  [5843] "Before the house-maid had lit their fire the next day, or the sun"           
##  [5844] "gained any power over a cold, gloomy morning in January, Marianne, only"     
##  [5845] "half dressed, was kneeling against one of the window-seats for the sake"     
##  [5846] "of all the little light she could command from it, and writing as fast"      
##  [5847] "as a continual flow of tears would permit her.  In this situation,"          
##  [5848] "Elinor, roused from sleep by her agitation and sobs, first perceived"        
##  [5849] "her; and after observing her for a few moments with silent anxiety,"         
##  [5850] "said, in a tone of the most considerate gentleness,"                         
##  [5851] ""                                                                            
##  [5852] "\"Marianne, may I ask-?\""                                                   
##  [5853] ""                                                                            
##  [5854] "\"No, Elinor,\" she replied, \"ask nothing; you will soon know all.\""       
##  [5855] ""                                                                            
##  [5856] "The sort of desperate calmness with which this was said, lasted no"          
##  [5857] "longer than while she spoke, and was immediately followed by a return"       
##  [5858] "of the same excessive affliction.  It was some minutes before she could"     
##  [5859] "go on with her letter, and the frequent bursts of grief which still"         
##  [5860] "obliged her, at intervals, to withhold her pen, were proofs enough of"       
##  [5861] "her feeling how more than probable it was that she was writing for the"      
##  [5862] "last time to Willoughby."                                                    
##  [5863] ""                                                                            
##  [5864] "Elinor paid her every quiet and unobtrusive attention in her power; and"     
##  [5865] "she would have tried to sooth and tranquilize her still more, had not"       
##  [5866] "Marianne entreated her, with all the eagerness of the most nervous"          
##  [5867] "irritability, not to speak to her for the world.  In such"                   
##  [5868] "circumstances, it was better for both that they should not be long"          
##  [5869] "together; and the restless state of Marianne's mind not only prevented"      
##  [5870] "her from remaining in the room a moment after she was dressed, but"          
##  [5871] "requiring at once solitude and continual change of place, made her"          
##  [5872] "wander about the house till breakfast time, avoiding the sight of every"     
##  [5873] "body."                                                                       
##  [5874] ""                                                                            
##  [5875] "At breakfast she neither ate, nor attempted to eat any thing; and"           
##  [5876] "Elinor's attention was then all employed, not in urging her, not in"         
##  [5877] "pitying her, nor in appearing to regard her, but in endeavouring to"         
##  [5878] "engage Mrs. Jennings's notice entirely to herself."                          
##  [5879] ""                                                                            
##  [5880] "As this was a favourite meal with Mrs. Jennings, it lasted a"                
##  [5881] "considerable time, and they were just setting themselves, after it,"         
##  [5882] "round the common working table, when a letter was delivered to"              
##  [5883] "Marianne, which she eagerly caught from the servant, and, turning of a"      
##  [5884] "death-like paleness, instantly ran out of the room.  Elinor, who saw as"     
##  [5885] "plainly by this, as if she had seen the direction, that it must come"        
##  [5886] "from Willoughby, felt immediately such a sickness at heart as made her"      
##  [5887] "hardly able to hold up her head, and sat in such a general tremour as"       
##  [5888] "made her fear it impossible to escape Mrs. Jennings's notice.  That good"    
##  [5889] "lady, however, saw only that Marianne had received a letter from"            
##  [5890] "Willoughby, which appeared to her a very good joke, and which she"           
##  [5891] "treated accordingly, by hoping, with a laugh, that she would find it to"     
##  [5892] "her liking.  Of Elinor's distress, she was too busily employed in"           
##  [5893] "measuring lengths of worsted for her rug, to see any thing at all; and"      
##  [5894] "calmly continuing her talk, as soon as Marianne disappeared, she said,"      
##  [5895] ""                                                                            
##  [5896] "\"Upon my word, I never saw a young woman so desperately in love in my"      
##  [5897] "life!  MY girls were nothing to her, and yet they used to be foolish"        
##  [5898] "enough; but as for Miss Marianne, she is quite an altered creature.  I"      
##  [5899] "hope, from the bottom of my heart, he won't keep her waiting much"           
##  [5900] "longer, for it is quite grievous to see her look so ill and forlorn."        
##  [5901] "Pray, when are they to be married?\""                                        
##  [5902] ""                                                                            
##  [5903] "Elinor, though never less disposed to speak than at that moment,"            
##  [5904] "obliged herself to answer such an attack as this, and, therefore,"           
##  [5905] "trying to smile, replied, \"And have you really, Ma'am, talked yourself"     
##  [5906] "into a persuasion of my sister's being engaged to Mr. Willoughby?  I"        
##  [5907] "thought it had been only a joke, but so serious a question seems to"         
##  [5908] "imply more; and I must beg, therefore, that you will not deceive"            
##  [5909] "yourself any longer.  I do assure you that nothing would surprise me"        
##  [5910] "more than to hear of their being going to be married.\""                     
##  [5911] ""                                                                            
##  [5912] "\"For shame, for shame, Miss Dashwood! how can you talk so?  Don't we"       
##  [5913] "all know that it must be a match, that they were over head and ears in"      
##  [5914] "love with each other from the first moment they met?  Did not I see"
