##  [5915] "them together in Devonshire every day, and all day long; and did not I"      
##  [5916] "know that your sister came to town with me on purpose to buy wedding"        
##  [5917] "clothes?  Come, come, this won't do.  Because you are so sly about it"       
##  [5918] "yourself, you think nobody else has any senses; but it is no such"           
##  [5919] "thing, I can tell you, for it has been known all over town this ever so"     
##  [5920] "long.  I tell every body of it and so does Charlotte.\""                     
##  [5921] ""                                                                            
##  [5922] "\"Indeed, Ma'am,\" said Elinor, very seriously, \"you are mistaken."         
##  [5923] "Indeed, you are doing a very unkind thing in spreading the report, and"      
##  [5924] "you will find that you have though you will not believe me now.\""           
##  [5925] ""                                                                            
##  [5926] "Mrs. Jennings laughed again, but Elinor had not spirits to say more,"        
##  [5927] "and eager at all events to know what Willoughby had written, hurried"        
##  [5928] "away to their room, where, on opening the door, she saw Marianne"            
##  [5929] "stretched on the bed, almost choked by grief, one letter in her hand,"       
##  [5930] "and two or three others laying by her.  Elinor drew near, but without"       
##  [5931] "saying a word; and seating herself on the bed, took her hand, kissed"        
##  [5932] "her affectionately several times, and then gave way to a burst of"           
##  [5933] "tears, which at first was scarcely less violent than Marianne's. The"        
##  [5934] "latter, though unable to speak, seemed to feel all the tenderness of"        
##  [5935] "this behaviour, and after some time thus spent in joint affliction, she"     
##  [5936] "put all the letters into Elinor's hands; and then covering her face"         
##  [5937] "with her handkerchief, almost screamed with agony.  Elinor, who knew"        
##  [5938] "that such grief, shocking as it was to witness it, must have its"            
##  [5939] "course, watched by her till this excess of suffering had somewhat spent"     
##  [5940] "itself, and then turning eagerly to Willoughby's letter, read as"            
##  [5941] "follows:"                                                                    
##  [5942] ""                                                                            
##  [5943] "                              \"Bond Street, January."                       
##  [5944] "     \"MY DEAR MADAM,"                                                       
##  [5945] ""                                                                            
##  [5946] "     \"I have just had the honour of receiving your"                         
##  [5947] "     letter, for which I beg to return my sincere"                           
##  [5948] "     acknowledgments.  I am much concerned to find there"                    
##  [5949] "     was anything in my behaviour last night that did"                       
##  [5950] "     not meet your approbation; and though I am quite at"                    
##  [5951] "     a loss to discover in what point I could be so"                         
##  [5952] "     unfortunate as to offend you, I entreat your"                           
##  [5953] "     forgiveness of what I can assure you to have been"                      
##  [5954] "     perfectly unintentional.  I shall never reflect on"                     
##  [5955] "     my former acquaintance with your family in Devonshire"                  
##  [5956] "     without the most grateful pleasure, and flatter"                        
##  [5957] "     myself it will not be broken by any mistake or"                         
##  [5958] "     misapprehension of my actions.  My esteem for your"                     
##  [5959] "     whole family is very sincere; but if I have been so"                    
##  [5960] "     unfortunate as to give rise to a belief of more than"                   
##  [5961] "     I felt, or meant to express, I shall reproach myself"                   
##  [5962] "     for not having been more guarded in my professions"                     
##  [5963] "     of that esteem.  That I should ever have meant more"                    
##  [5964] "     you will allow to be impossible, when you understand"                   
##  [5965] "     that my affections have been long engaged elsewhere,"                   
##  [5966] "     and it will not be many weeks, I believe, before"                       
##  [5967] "     this engagement is fulfilled.  It is with great"                        
##  [5968] "     regret that I obey your commands in returning the"                      
##  [5969] "     letters with which I have been honoured from you,"                      
##  [5970] "     and the lock of hair, which you so obligingly bestowed"                 
##  [5971] "     on me."                                                                 
##  [5972] ""                                                                            
##  [5973] "     \"I am, dear Madam,"                                                    
##  [5974] "               \"Your most obedient"                                         
##  [5975] "                    \"humble servant,"                                       
##  [5976] "                                        \"JOHN WILLOUGHBY.\""                
##  [5977] ""                                                                            
##  [5978] ""                                                                            
##  [5979] "With what indignation such a letter as this must be read by Miss"            
##  [5980] "Dashwood, may be imagined.  Though aware, before she began it, that it"      
##  [5981] "must bring a confession of his inconstancy, and confirm their"               
##  [5982] "separation for ever, she was not aware that such language could be"          
##  [5983] "suffered to announce it; nor could she have supposed Willoughby capable"     
##  [5984] "of departing so far from the appearance of every honourable and"             
##  [5985] "delicate feeling--so far from the common decorum of a gentleman, as to"      
##  [5986] "send a letter so impudently cruel: a letter which, instead of bringing"      
##  [5987] "with his desire of a release any professions of regret, acknowledged no"     
##  [5988] "breach of faith, denied all peculiar affection whatever--a letter of"        
##  [5989] "which every line was an insult, and which proclaimed its writer to be"       
##  [5990] "deep in hardened villainy."                                                  
##  [5991] ""                                                                            
##  [5992] "She paused over it for some time with indignant astonishment; then read"     
##  [5993] "it again and again; but every perusal only served to increase her"           
##  [5994] "abhorrence of the man, and so bitter were her feelings against him,"         
##  [5995] "that she dared not trust herself to speak, lest she might wound"             
##  [5996] "Marianne still deeper by treating their disengagement, not as a loss to"     
##  [5997] "her of any possible good but as an escape from the worst and most"           
##  [5998] "irremediable of all evils, a connection, for life, with an unprincipled"     
##  [5999] "man, as a deliverance the most real, a blessing the most important."         
##  [6000] ""                                                                            
##  [6001] "In her earnest meditations on the contents of the letter, on the"            
##  [6002] "depravity of that mind which could dictate it, and probably, on the"         
##  [6003] "very different mind of a very different person, who had no other"            
##  [6004] "connection whatever with the affair than what her heart gave him with"       
##  [6005] "every thing that passed, Elinor forgot the immediate distress of her"        
##  [6006] "sister, forgot that she had three letters on her lap yet unread, and so"     
##  [6007] "entirely forgot how long she had been in the room, that when on hearing"     
##  [6008] "a carriage drive up to the door, she went to the window to see who"          
##  [6009] "could be coming so unreasonably early, she was all astonishment to"          
##  [6010] "perceive Mrs. Jennings's chariot, which she knew had not been ordered"       
##  [6011] "till one.  Determined not to quit Marianne, though hopeless of"              
##  [6012] "contributing, at present, to her ease, she hurried away to excuse"           
##  [6013] "herself from attending Mrs. Jennings, on account of her sister being"        
##  [6014] "indisposed.  Mrs. Jennings, with a thoroughly good-humoured concern for"     
##  [6015] "its cause, admitted the excuse most readily, and Elinor, after seeing"       
##  [6016] "her safe off, returned to Marianne, whom she found attempting to rise"       
##  [6017] "from the bed, and whom she reached just in time to prevent her from"         
##  [6018] "falling on the floor, faint and giddy from a long want of proper rest"       
##  [6019] "and food; for it was many days since she had any appetite, and many"         
##  [6020] "nights since she had really slept; and now, when her mind was no longer"     
##  [6021] "supported by the fever of suspense, the consequence of all this was"         
##  [6022] "felt in an aching head, a weakened stomach, and a general nervous"           
##  [6023] "faintness.  A glass of wine, which Elinor procured for her directly,"        
##  [6024] "made her more comfortable, and she was at last able to express some"         
##  [6025] "sense of her kindness, by saying,"                                           
##  [6026] ""                                                                            
##  [6027] "\"Poor Elinor! how unhappy I make you!\""                                    
##  [6028] ""                                                                            
##  [6029] "\"I only wish,\" replied her sister, \"there were any thing I COULD do,"     
##  [6030] "which might be of comfort to you.\""                                         
##  [6031] ""                                                                            
##  [6032] "This, as every thing else would have been, was too much for Marianne,"       
##  [6033] "who could only exclaim, in the anguish of her heart, \"Oh! Elinor, I am"     
##  [6034] "miserable, indeed,\" before her voice was entirely lost in sobs."            
##  [6035] ""                                                                            
##  [6036] "Elinor could no longer witness this torrent of unresisted grief in"          
##  [6037] "silence."                                                                    
##  [6038] ""                                                                            
##  [6039] "\"Exert yourself, dear Marianne,\" she cried, \"if you would not kill"       
##  [6040] "yourself and all who love you.  Think of your mother; think of her"          
##  [6041] "misery while YOU suffer: for her sake you must exert yourself.\""            
##  [6042] ""                                                                            
##  [6043] "\"I cannot, I cannot,\" cried Marianne; \"leave me, leave me, if I"          
##  [6044] "distress you; leave me, hate me, forget me!  but do not torture me so."      
##  [6045] "Oh! how easy for those, who have no sorrow of their own to talk of"          
##  [6046] "exertion!  Happy, happy Elinor, YOU cannot have an idea of what I"           
##  [6047] "suffer.\""                                                                   
##  [6048] ""                                                                            
##  [6049] "\"Do you call ME happy, Marianne?  Ah! if you knew!--And can you believe"    
##  [6050] "me to be so, while I see you so wretched!\""                                 
##  [6051] ""                                                                            
##  [6052] "\"Forgive me, forgive me,\" throwing her arms round her sister's neck; \"I"  
##  [6053] "know you feel for me; I know what a heart you have; but yet you"             
##  [6054] "are--you must be happy; Edward loves you--what, oh what, can do away"        
##  [6055] "such happiness as that?\""                                                   
##  [6056] ""                                                                            
##  [6057] "\"Many, many circumstances,\" said Elinor, solemnly."                        
##  [6058] ""                                                                            
##  [6059] "\"No, no, no,\" cried Marianne wildly, \"he loves you, and only you.  You"   
##  [6060] "CAN have no grief.\""                                                        
##  [6061] ""                                                                            
##  [6062] "\"I can have no pleasure while I see you in this state.\""                   
##  [6063] ""                                                                            
##  [6064] "\"And you will never see me otherwise.  Mine is a misery which nothing"      
##  [6065] "can do away.\""                                                              
##  [6066] ""                                                                            
##  [6067] "\"You must not talk so, Marianne.  Have you no comforts? no friends?  Is"    
##  [6068] "your loss such as leaves no opening for consolation?  Much as you"           
##  [6069] "suffer now, think of what you would have suffered if the discovery of"       
##  [6070] "his character had been delayed to a later period--if your engagement"        
##  [6071] "had been carried on for months and months, as it might have been,"           
##  [6072] "before he chose to put an end to it.  Every additional day of unhappy"       
##  [6073] "confidence, on your side, would have made the blow more dreadful.\""         
##  [6074] ""                                                                            
##  [6075] "\"Engagement!\" cried Marianne, \"there has been no engagement.\""           
##  [6076] ""                                                                            
##  [6077] "\"No engagement!\""                                                          
##  [6078] ""                                                                            
##  [6079] "\"No, he is not so unworthy as you believe him.  He has broken no faith"     
##  [6080] "with me.\""                                                                  
##  [6081] ""                                                                            
##  [6082] "\"But he told you that he loved you.\""                                      
##  [6083] ""                                                                            
##  [6084] "\"Yes--no--never absolutely.  It was every day implied, but never"           
##  [6085] "professedly declared.  Sometimes I thought it had been--but it never"        
##  [6086] "was.\""                                                                      
##  [6087] ""                                                                            
##  [6088] "\"Yet you wrote to him?\"--"                                                 
##  [6089] ""                                                                            
##  [6090] "\"Yes--could that be wrong after all that had passed?-- But I cannot"        
##  [6091] "talk.\""                                                                     
##  [6092] ""                                                                            
##  [6093] "Elinor said no more, and turning again to the three letters which now"       
##  [6094] "raised a much stronger curiosity than before, directly ran over the"         
##  [6095] "contents of all.  The first, which was what her sister had sent him on"      
##  [6096] "their arrival in town, was to this effect."                                  
##  [6097] ""                                                                            
##  [6098] "                         Berkeley Street, January."                          
##  [6099] ""                                                                            
##  [6100] "     \"How surprised you will be, Willoughby, on"                            
##  [6101] "     receiving this; and I think you will feel something"                    
##  [6102] "     more than surprise, when you know that I am in town."                   
##  [6103] "     An opportunity of coming hither, though with Mrs."                      
##  [6104] "     Jennings, was a temptation we could not resist."                        
##  [6105] "     I wish you may receive this in time to come here"                       
##  [6106] "     to-night, but I will not depend on it.  At any rate"                    
##  [6107] "     I shall expect you to-morrow. For the present, adieu."                  
##  [6108] ""                                                                            
##  [6109] "                                             \"M.D.\""                       
##  [6110] ""                                                                            
##  [6111] "Her second note, which had been written on the morning after the dance"      
##  [6112] "at the Middletons', was in these words:--"                                   
##  [6113] ""                                                                            
##  [6114] "     \"I cannot express my disappointment in having"                         
##  [6115] "     missed you the day before yesterday, nor my astonishment"               
##  [6116] "     at not having received any answer to a note which"                      
##  [6117] "     I sent you above a week ago.  I have been expecting"                    
##  [6118] "     to hear from you, and still more to see you, every"                     
##  [6119] "     hour of the day.  Pray call again as soon as possible,"                 
##  [6120] "     and explain the reason of my having expected this"                      
##  [6121] "     in vain.  You had better come earlier another time,"                    
##  [6122] "     because we are generally out by one.  We were last"                     
##  [6123] "     night at Lady Middleton's, where there was a dance."                    
##  [6124] "     I have been told that you were asked to be of the"                      
##  [6125] "     party.  But could it be so?  You must be very much"                     
##  [6126] "     altered indeed since we parted, if that could be"                       
##  [6127] "     the case, and you not there.  But I will not suppose"                   
##  [6128] "     this possible, and I hope very soon to receive your"                    
##  [6129] "     personal assurance of its being otherwise."                             
##  [6130] ""                                                                            
##  [6131] "                                            \"M.D.\""                        
##  [6132] ""                                                                            
##  [6133] "The contents of her last note to him were these:--"                          
##  [6134] ""                                                                            
##  [6135] "     \"What am I to imagine, Willoughby, by your"                            
##  [6136] "     behaviour last night?  Again I demand an explanation"                   
##  [6137] "     of it.  I was prepared to meet you with the pleasure"                   
##  [6138] "     which our separation naturally produced, with the"                      
##  [6139] "     familiarity which our intimacy at Barton appeared"                      
##  [6140] "     to me to justify.  I was repulsed indeed! I have"                       
##  [6141] "     passed a wretched night in endeavouring to excuse"                      
##  [6142] "     a conduct which can scarcely be called less than"                       
##  [6143] "     insulting; but though I have not yet been able to"                      
##  [6144] "     form any reasonable apology for your behaviour,"                        
##  [6145] "     I am perfectly ready to hear your justification of"                     
##  [6146] "     it.  You have perhaps been misinformed, or purposely"                   
##  [6147] "     deceived, in something concerning me, which may have"                   
##  [6148] "     lowered me in your opinion.  Tell me what it is,"                       
##  [6149] "     explain the grounds on which you acted, and I shall"                    
##  [6150] "     be satisfied, in being able to satisfy you.  It"                        
##  [6151] "     would grieve me indeed to be obliged to think ill"                      
##  [6152] "     of you; but if I am to do it, if I am to learn that"                    
##  [6153] "     you are not what we have hitherto believed you, that"                   
##  [6154] "     your regard for us all was insincere, that your"                        
##  [6155] "     behaviour to me was intended only to deceive, let"                      
##  [6156] "     it be told as soon as possible.  My feelings are at"                    
##  [6157] "     present in a state of dreadful indecision; I wish"                      
##  [6158] "     to acquit you, but certainty on either side will be"                    
##  [6159] "     ease to what I now suffer.  If your sentiments are"                     
##  [6160] "     no longer what they were, you will return my notes,"                    
##  [6161] "     and the lock of my hair which is in your possession."                   
##  [6162] ""                                                                            
##  [6163] "                                             \"M.D.\""                       
##  [6164] ""                                                                            
##  [6165] "That such letters, so full of affection and confidence, could have been"     
##  [6166] "so answered, Elinor, for Willoughby's sake, would have been unwilling"       
##  [6167] "to believe.  But her condemnation of him did not blind her to the"           
##  [6168] "impropriety of their having been written at all; and she was silently"       
##  [6169] "grieving over the imprudence which had hazarded such unsolicited proofs"     
##  [6170] "of tenderness, not warranted by anything preceding, and most severely"       
##  [6171] "condemned by the event, when Marianne, perceiving that she had finished"     
##  [6172] "the letters, observed to her that they contained nothing but what any"       
##  [6173] "one would have written in the same situation."                               
##  [6174] ""                                                                            
##  [6175] "\"I felt myself,\" she added, \"to be as solemnly engaged to him, as if"     
##  [6176] "the strictest legal covenant had bound us to each other.\""                  
##  [6177] ""                                                                            
##  [6178] "\"I can believe it,\" said Elinor; \"but unfortunately he did not feel the"  
##  [6179] "same.\""                                                                     
##  [6180] ""                                                                            
##  [6181] "\"He DID feel the same, Elinor--for weeks and weeks he felt it.  I know"     
##  [6182] "he did.  Whatever may have changed him now, (and nothing but the"            
##  [6183] "blackest art employed against me can have done it), I was once as dear"      
##  [6184] "to him as my own soul could wish.  This lock of hair, which now he can"      
##  [6185] "so readily give up, was begged of me with the most earnest"                  
##  [6186] "supplication.  Had you seen his look, his manner, had you heard his"         
##  [6187] "voice at that moment!  Have you forgot the last evening of our being"        
##  [6188] "together at Barton?  The morning that we parted too!  When he told me"       
##  [6189] "that it might be many weeks before we met again--his distress--can I"        
##  [6190] "ever forget his distress?\""                                                 
##  [6191] ""                                                                            
##  [6192] "For a moment or two she could say no more; but when this emotion had"        
##  [6193] "passed away, she added, in a firmer tone,"                                   
##  [6194] ""                                                                            
##  [6195] "\"Elinor, I have been cruelly used; but not by Willoughby.\""                
##  [6196] ""                                                                            
##  [6197] "\"Dearest Marianne, who but himself?  By whom can he have been"              
##  [6198] "instigated?\""                                                               
##  [6199] ""                                                                            
##  [6200] "\"By all the world, rather than by his own heart.  I could rather"           
##  [6201] "believe every creature of my acquaintance leagued together to ruin me"       
##  [6202] "in his opinion, than believe his nature capable of such cruelty.  This"      
##  [6203] "woman of whom he writes--whoever she be--or any one, in short, but your"     
##  [6204] "own dear self, mama, and Edward, may have been so barbarous to bely me."     
##  [6205] "Beyond you three, is there a creature in the world whom I would not"         
##  [6206] "rather suspect of evil than Willoughby, whose heart I know so well?\""       
##  [6207] ""                                                                            
##  [6208] "Elinor would not contend, and only replied, \"Whoever may have been so"      
##  [6209] "detestably your enemy, let them be cheated of their malignant triumph,"      
##  [6210] "my dear sister, by seeing how nobly the consciousness of your own"           
##  [6211] "innocence and good intentions supports your spirits.  It is a"               
##  [6212] "reasonable and laudable pride which resists such malevolence.\""             
##  [6213] ""                                                                            
##  [6214] "\"No, no,\" cried Marianne, \"misery such as mine has no pride.  I care"     
##  [6215] "not who knows that I am wretched.  The triumph of seeing me so may be"       
##  [6216] "open to all the world.  Elinor, Elinor, they who suffer little may be"       
##  [6217] "proud and independent as they like--may resist insult, or return"            
##  [6218] "mortification--but I cannot.  I must feel--I must be wretched--and they"     
##  [6219] "are welcome to enjoy the consciousness of it that can.\""                    
##  [6220] ""                                                                            
##  [6221] "\"But for my mother's sake and mine--\""                                     
##  [6222] ""                                                                            
##  [6223] "\"I would do more than for my own.  But to appear happy when I am so"        
##  [6224] "miserable--Oh! who can require it?\""                                        
##  [6225] ""                                                                            
##  [6226] "Again they were both silent.  Elinor was employed in walking"                
##  [6227] "thoughtfully from the fire to the window, from the window to the fire,"      
##  [6228] "without knowing that she received warmth from one, or discerning"            
##  [6229] "objects through the other; and Marianne, seated at the foot of the bed,"     
##  [6230] "with her head leaning against one of its posts, again took up"               
##  [6231] "Willoughby's letter, and, after shuddering over every sentence,"             
##  [6232] "exclaimed--"                                                                 
##  [6233] ""                                                                            
##  [6234] "\"It is too much! Oh, Willoughby, Willoughby, could this be yours!"          
##  [6235] "Cruel, cruel--nothing can acquit you.  Elinor, nothing can.  Whatever"       
##  [6236] "he might have heard against me--ought he not to have suspended his"          
##  [6237] "belief? ought he not to have told me of it, to have given me the power"      
##  [6238] "of clearing myself? 'The lock of hair, (repeating it from the letter,)"      
##  [6239] "which you so obligingly bestowed on me'--That is unpardonable."              
##  [6240] "Willoughby, where was your heart when you wrote those words?  Oh,"           
##  [6241] "barbarously insolent!--Elinor, can he be justified?\""                       
##  [6242] ""                                                                            
##  [6243] "\"No, Marianne, in no possible way.\""                                       
##  [6244] ""                                                                            
##  [6245] "\"And yet this woman--who knows what her art may have been?--how long it"    
##  [6246] "may have been premeditated, and how deeply contrived by her!--Who is"        
##  [6247] "she?--Who can she be?--Whom did I ever hear him talk of as young and"        
##  [6248] "attractive among his female acquaintance?--Oh! no one, no one--he"           
##  [6249] "talked to me only of myself.\""                                              
##  [6250] ""                                                                            
##  [6251] "Another pause ensued; Marianne was greatly agitated, and it ended thus."     
##  [6252] ""                                                                            
##  [6253] "\"Elinor, I must go home.  I must go and comfort mama.  Can not we be"       
##  [6254] "gone to-morrow?\""                                                           
##  [6255] ""                                                                            
##  [6256] "\"To-morrow, Marianne!\""                                                    
##  [6257] ""                                                                            
##  [6258] "\"Yes, why should I stay here? I came only for Willoughby's sake--and"       
##  [6259] "now who cares for me? Who regards me?\""                                     
##  [6260] ""                                                                            
##  [6261] "\"It would be impossible to go to-morrow. We owe Mrs. Jennings much more"    
##  [6262] "than civility; and civility of the commonest kind must prevent such a"       
##  [6263] "hasty removal as that.\""                                                    
##  [6264] ""                                                                            
##  [6265] "\"Well then, another day or two, perhaps; but I cannot stay here long, I"    
##  [6266] "cannot stay to endure the questions and remarks of all these people."        
##  [6267] "The Middletons and Palmers--how am I to bear their pity?  The pity of"       
##  [6268] "such a woman as Lady Middleton!  Oh, what would HE say to that!\""           
##  [6269] ""                                                                            
##  [6270] "Elinor advised her to lie down again, and for a moment she did so; but"      
##  [6271] "no attitude could give her ease; and in restless pain of mind and body"      
##  [6272] "she moved from one posture to another, till growing more and more"           
##  [6273] "hysterical, her sister could with difficulty keep her on the bed at"         
##  [6274] "all, and for some time was fearful of being constrained to call for"         
##  [6275] "assistance.  Some lavender drops, however, which she was at length"          
##  [6276] "persuaded to take, were of use; and from that time till Mrs. Jennings"       
##  [6277] "returned, she continued on the bed quiet and motionless."                    
##  [6278] ""                                                                            
##  [6279] ""                                                                            
##  [6280] ""                                                                            
##  [6281] "CHAPTER 30"                                                                  
##  [6282] ""                                                                            
##  [6283] ""                                                                            
##  [6284] "Mrs. Jennings came immediately to their room on her return, and without"     
##  [6285] "waiting to have her request of admittance answered, opened the door and"     
##  [6286] "walked in with a look of real concern."                                      
##  [6287] ""                                                                            
##  [6288] "\"How do you do my dear?\"--said she in a voice of great compassion to"      
##  [6289] "Marianne, who turned away her face without attempting to answer."            
##  [6290] ""                                                                            
##  [6291] "\"How is she, Miss Dashwood?--Poor thing! she looks very bad.-- No"          
##  [6292] "wonder.  Ay, it is but too true.  He is to be married very soon--a"          
##  [6293] "good-for-nothing fellow!  I have no patience with him.  Mrs. Taylor"         
##  [6294] "told me of it half an hour ago, and she was told it by a particular"         
##  [6295] "friend of Miss Grey herself, else I am sure I should not have believed"      
##  [6296] "it; and I was almost ready to sink as it was.  Well, said I, all I can"      
##  [6297] "say is, that if this be true, he has used a young lady of my"                
##  [6298] "acquaintance abominably ill, and I wish with all my soul his wife may"       
##  [6299] "plague his heart out.  And so I shall always say, my dear, you may"          
##  [6300] "depend on it.  I have no notion of men's going on in this way; and if"       
##  [6301] "ever I meet him again, I will give him such a dressing as he has not"        
##  [6302] "had this many a day.  But there is one comfort, my dear Miss Marianne;"      
##  [6303] "he is not the only young man in the world worth having; and with your"       
##  [6304] "pretty face you will never want admirers.  Well, poor thing!  I won't"       
##  [6305] "disturb her any longer, for she had better have her cry out at once and"     
##  [6306] "have done with.  The Parrys and Sandersons luckily are coming tonight"       
##  [6307] "you know, and that will amuse her.\""                                        
##  [6308] ""                                                                            
##  [6309] "She then went away, walking on tiptoe out of the room, as if she"            
##  [6310] "supposed her young friend's affliction could be increased by noise."         
##  [6311] ""                                                                            
##  [6312] "Marianne, to the surprise of her sister, determined on dining with"          
##  [6313] "them.  Elinor even advised her against it.  But \"no, she would go down;"    
##  [6314] "she could bear it very well, and the bustle about her would be less.\""      
##  [6315] "Elinor, pleased to have her governed for a moment by such a motive,"         
##  [6316] "though believing it hardly possible that she could sit out the dinner,"      
##  [6317] "said no more; and adjusting her dress for her as well as she could,"         
##  [6318] "while Marianne still remained on the bed, was ready to assist her into"      
##  [6319] "the dining room as soon as they were summoned to it."                        
##  [6320] ""                                                                            
##  [6321] "When there, though looking most wretchedly, she ate more and was calmer"     
##  [6322] "than her sister had expected.  Had she tried to speak, or had she been"      
##  [6323] "conscious of half Mrs. Jennings's well-meant but ill-judged attentions"      
##  [6324] "to her, this calmness could not have been maintained; but not a"             
##  [6325] "syllable escaped her lips; and the abstraction of her thoughts"              
##  [6326] "preserved her in ignorance of every thing that was passing before her."      
##  [6327] ""                                                                            
##  [6328] "Elinor, who did justice to Mrs. Jennings's kindness, though its"             
##  [6329] "effusions were often distressing, and sometimes almost ridiculous, made"     
##  [6330] "her those acknowledgments, and returned her those civilities, which her"     
##  [6331] "sister could not make or return for herself.  Their good friend saw"         
##  [6332] "that Marianne was unhappy, and felt that every thing was due to her"         
##  [6333] "which might make her at all less so.  She treated her therefore, with"       
##  [6334] "all the indulgent fondness of a parent towards a favourite child on the"     
##  [6335] "last day of its holidays.  Marianne was to have the best place by the"       
##  [6336] "fire, was to be tempted to eat by every delicacy in the house, and to"       
##  [6337] "be amused by the relation of all the news of the day.  Had not Elinor,"      
##  [6338] "in the sad countenance of her sister, seen a check to all mirth, she"        
##  [6339] "could have been entertained by Mrs. Jennings's endeavours to cure a"         
##  [6340] "disappointment in love, by a variety of sweetmeats and olives, and a"        
##  [6341] "good fire.  As soon, however, as the consciousness of all this was"          
##  [6342] "forced by continual repetition on Marianne, she could stay no longer."       
##  [6343] "With a hasty exclamation of Misery, and a sign to her sister not to"         
##  [6344] "follow her, she directly got up and hurried out of the room."                
##  [6345] ""                                                                            
##  [6346] "\"Poor soul!\" cried Mrs. Jennings, as soon as she was gone, \"how it"       
##  [6347] "grieves me to see her!  And I declare if she is not gone away without"       
##  [6348] "finishing her wine!  And the dried cherries too!  Lord! nothing seems"       
##  [6349] "to do her any good.  I am sure if I knew of any thing she would like, I"     
##  [6350] "would send all over the town for it.  Well, it is the oddest thing to"       
##  [6351] "me, that a man should use such a pretty girl so ill!  But when there is"     
##  [6352] "plenty of money on one side, and next to none on the other, Lord bless"      
##  [6353] "you! they care no more about such things!--\""                               
##  [6354] ""                                                                            
##  [6355] "\"The lady then--Miss Grey I think you called her--is very rich?\""          
##  [6356] ""                                                                            
##  [6357] "\"Fifty thousand pounds, my dear.  Did you ever see her? a smart,"           
##  [6358] "stylish girl they say, but not handsome.  I remember her aunt very"          
##  [6359] "well, Biddy Henshawe; she married a very wealthy man.  But the family"       
##  [6360] "are all rich together.  Fifty thousand pounds! and by all accounts, it"      
##  [6361] "won't come before it's wanted; for they say he is all to pieces.  No"        
##  [6362] "wonder! dashing about with his curricle and hunters!  Well, it don't"        
##  [6363] "signify talking; but when a young man, be who he will, comes and makes"      
##  [6364] "love to a pretty girl, and promises marriage, he has no business to fly"     
##  [6365] "off from his word only because he grows poor, and a richer girl is"          
##  [6366] "ready to have him.  Why don't he, in such a case, sell his horses, let"      
##  [6367] "his house, turn off his servants, and make a thorough reform at once? I"     
##  [6368] "warrant you, Miss Marianne would have been ready to wait till matters"       
##  [6369] "came round.  But that won't do now-a-days; nothing in the way of"            
##  [6370] "pleasure can ever be given up by the young men of this age.\""               
##  [6371] ""                                                                            
##  [6372] "\"Do you know what kind of a girl Miss Grey is?  Is she said to be"          
##  [6373] "amiable?\""                                                                  
##  [6374] ""                                                                            
##  [6375] "\"I never heard any harm of her; indeed I hardly ever heard her"             
##  [6376] "mentioned; except that Mrs. Taylor did say this morning, that one day"       
##  [6377] "Miss Walker hinted to her, that she believed Mr. and Mrs. Ellison would"     
##  [6378] "not be sorry to have Miss Grey married, for she and Mrs. Ellison could"      
##  [6379] "never agree.\"--"                                                            
##  [6380] ""                                                                            
##  [6381] "\"And who are the Ellisons?\""                                               
##  [6382] ""                                                                            
##  [6383] "\"Her guardians, my dear.  But now she is of age and may choose for"         
##  [6384] "herself; and a pretty choice she has made!--What now,\" after pausing a"     
##  [6385] "moment--\"your poor sister is gone to her own room, I suppose, to moan"      
##  [6386] "by herself.  Is there nothing one can get to comfort her?  Poor dear,"       
##  [6387] "it seems quite cruel to let her be alone.  Well, by-and-by we shall"         
##  [6388] "have a few friends, and that will amuse her a little.  What shall we"        
##  [6389] "play at?  She hates whist I know; but is there no round game she cares"      
##  [6390] "for?\""                                                                      
##  [6391] ""                                                                            
##  [6392] "\"Dear ma'am, this kindness is quite unnecessary.  Marianne, I dare say,"    
##  [6393] "will not leave her room again this evening.  I shall persuade her if I"      
##  [6394] "can to go early to bed, for I am sure she wants rest.\""                     
##  [6395] ""                                                                            
##  [6396] "\"Aye, I believe that will be best for her.  Let her name her own"           
##  [6397] "supper, and go to bed.  Lord! no wonder she has been looking so bad and"     
##  [6398] "so cast down this last week or two, for this matter I suppose has been"      
##  [6399] "hanging over her head as long as that.  And so the letter that came"         
##  [6400] "today finished it!  Poor soul!  I am sure if I had had a notion of it,"      
##  [6401] "I would not have joked her about it for all my money.  But then you"         
##  [6402] "know, how should I guess such a thing?  I made sure of its being"            
##  [6403] "nothing but a common love letter, and you know young people like to be"      
##  [6404] "laughed at about them.  Lord!  how concerned Sir John and my daughters"      
##  [6405] "will be when they hear it!  If I had my senses about me I might have"        
##  [6406] "called in Conduit Street in my way home, and told them of it.  But I"        
##  [6407] "shall see them tomorrow.\""                                                  
##  [6408] ""                                                                            
##  [6409] "\"It would be unnecessary I am sure, for you to caution Mrs. Palmer and"     
##  [6410] "Sir John against ever naming Mr. Willoughby, or making the slightest"        
##  [6411] "allusion to what has passed, before my sister.  Their own good-nature"       
##  [6412] "must point out to them the real cruelty of appearing to know any thing"      
##  [6413] "about it when she is present; and the less that may ever be said to"         
##  [6414] "myself on the subject, the more my feelings will be spared, as you my"       
##  [6415] "dear madam will easily believe.\""                                           
##  [6416] ""                                                                            
##  [6417] "\"Oh! Lord! yes, that I do indeed.  It must be terrible for you to hear"     
##  [6418] "it talked of; and as for your sister, I am sure I would not mention a"       
##  [6419] "word about it to her for the world.  You saw I did not all dinner time."     
##  [6420] "No more would Sir John, nor my daughters, for they are all very"             
##  [6421] "thoughtful and considerate; especially if I give them a hint, as I"          
##  [6422] "certainly will.  For my part, I think the less that is said about such"      
##  [6423] "things, the better, the sooner 'tis blown over and forgot.  And what"        
##  [6424] "does talking ever do you know?\""                                            
##  [6425] ""                                                                            
##  [6426] "\"In this affair it can only do harm; more so perhaps than in many cases"    
##  [6427] "of a similar kind, for it has been attended by circumstances which, for"     
##  [6428] "the sake of every one concerned in it, make it unfit to become the"          
##  [6429] "public conversation.  I must do THIS justice to Mr. Willoughby--he has"      
##  [6430] "broken no positive engagement with my sister.\""                             
##  [6431] ""                                                                            
##  [6432] "\"Law, my dear!  Don't pretend to defend him.  No positive engagement"       
##  [6433] "indeed! after taking her all over Allenham House, and fixing on the"         
##  [6434] "very rooms they were to live in hereafter!\""                                
##  [6435] ""                                                                            
##  [6436] "Elinor, for her sister's sake, could not press the subject farther, and"     
##  [6437] "she hoped it was not required of her for Willoughby's; since, though"        
##  [6438] "Marianne might lose much, he could gain very little by the enforcement"      
##  [6439] "of the real truth.  After a short silence on both sides, Mrs. Jennings,"     
##  [6440] "with all her natural hilarity, burst forth again."                           
##  [6441] ""                                                                            
##  [6442] "\"Well, my dear, 'tis a true saying about an ill-wind, for it will be"       
##  [6443] "all the better for Colonel Brandon.  He will have her at last; aye,"         
##  [6444] "that he will.  Mind me, now, if they an't married by Mid-summer.  Lord!"     
##  [6445] "how he'll chuckle over this news!  I hope he will come tonight.  It"         
##  [6446] "will be all to one a better match for your sister.  Two thousand a year"     
##  [6447] "without debt or drawback--except the little love-child, indeed; aye, I"      
##  [6448] "had forgot her; but she may be 'prenticed out at a small cost, and then"     
##  [6449] "what does it signify?  Delaford is a nice place, I can tell you;"            
##  [6450] "exactly what I call a nice old fashioned place, full of comforts and"        
##  [6451] "conveniences; quite shut in with great garden walls that are covered"        
##  [6452] "with the best fruit-trees in the country; and such a mulberry tree in"       
##  [6453] "one corner!  Lord! how Charlotte and I did stuff the only time we were"      
##  [6454] "there!  Then, there is a dove-cote, some delightful stew-ponds, and a"       
##  [6455] "very pretty canal; and every thing, in short, that one could wish for;"      
##  [6456] "and, moreover, it is close to the church, and only a quarter of a mile"      
##  [6457] "from the turnpike-road, so 'tis never dull, for if you only go and sit"      
##  [6458] "up in an old yew arbour behind the house, you may see all the carriages"     
##  [6459] "that pass along.  Oh! 'tis a nice place!  A butcher hard by in the"          
##  [6460] "village, and the parsonage-house within a stone's throw.  To my fancy,"      
##  [6461] "a thousand times prettier than Barton Park, where they are forced to"        
##  [6462] "send three miles for their meat, and have not a neighbour nearer than"       
##  [6463] "your mother.  Well, I shall spirit up the Colonel as soon as I can."         
##  [6464] "One shoulder of mutton, you know, drives another down.  If we CAN but"       
##  [6465] "put Willoughby out of her head!\""                                           
##  [6466] ""                                                                            
##  [6467] "\"Ay, if we can do THAT, Ma'am,\" said Elinor, \"we shall do very well"      
##  [6468] "with or without Colonel Brandon.\" And then rising, she went away to"        
##  [6469] "join Marianne, whom she found, as she expected, in her own room,"            
##  [6470] "leaning, in silent misery, over the small remains of a fire, which,"         
##  [6471] "till Elinor's entrance, had been her only light."                            
##  [6472] ""                                                                            
##  [6473] "\"You had better leave me,\" was all the notice that her sister received"    
##  [6474] "from her."                                                                   
##  [6475] ""                                                                            
##  [6476] "\"I will leave you,\" said Elinor, \"if you will go to bed.\" But this,"     
##  [6477] "from the momentary perverseness of impatient suffering, she at first"        
##  [6478] "refused to do.  Her sister's earnest, though gentle persuasion,"             
##  [6479] "however, soon softened her to compliance, and Elinor saw her lay her"        
##  [6480] "aching head on the pillow, and as she hoped, in a way to get some quiet"     
##  [6481] "rest before she left her."                                                   
##  [6482] ""                                                                            
##  [6483] "In the drawing-room, whither she then repaired, she was soon joined by"      
##  [6484] "Mrs. Jennings, with a wine-glass, full of something, in her hand."           
##  [6485] ""                                                                            
##  [6486] "\"My dear,\" said she, entering, \"I have just recollected that I have"      
##  [6487] "some of the finest old Constantia wine in the house that ever was"           
##  [6488] "tasted, so I have brought a glass of it for your sister.  My poor"           
##  [6489] "husband! how fond he was of it!  Whenever he had a touch of his old"         
##  [6490] "colicky gout, he said it did him more good than any thing else in the"       
##  [6491] "world.  Do take it to your sister.\""                                        
##  [6492] ""                                                                            
##  [6493] "\"Dear Ma'am,\" replied Elinor, smiling at the difference of the"            
##  [6494] "complaints for which it was recommended, \"how good you are!  But I have"    
##  [6495] "just left Marianne in bed, and, I hope, almost asleep; and as I think"       
##  [6496] "nothing will be of so much service to her as rest, if you will give me"      
##  [6497] "leave, I will drink the wine myself.\""                                      
##  [6498] ""                                                                            
##  [6499] "Mrs. Jennings, though regretting that she had not been five minutes"         
##  [6500] "earlier, was satisfied with the compromise; and Elinor, as she"              
##  [6501] "swallowed the chief of it, reflected, that though its effects on a"          
##  [6502] "colicky gout were, at present, of little importance to her, its healing"     
##  [6503] "powers, on a disappointed heart might be as reasonably tried on herself"     
##  [6504] "as on her sister."                                                           
##  [6505] ""                                                                            
##  [6506] "Colonel Brandon came in while the party were at tea, and by his manner"      
##  [6507] "of looking round the room for Marianne, Elinor immediately fancied that"     
##  [6508] "he neither expected nor wished to see her there, and, in short, that he"     
##  [6509] "was already aware of what occasioned her absence.  Mrs. Jennings was"        
##  [6510] "not struck by the same thought; for soon after his entrance, she walked"     
##  [6511] "across the room to the tea-table where Elinor presided, and whispered--"     
##  [6512] "\"The Colonel looks as grave as ever you see.  He knows nothing of it;"      
##  [6513] "do tell him, my dear.\""                                                     
##  [6514] ""                                                                            
##  [6515] "He shortly afterwards drew a chair close to hers, and, with a look"          
##  [6516] "which perfectly assured her of his good information, inquired after her"     
##  [6517] "sister."                                                                     
##  [6518] ""                                                                            
##  [6519] "\"Marianne is not well,\" said she.  \"She has been indisposed all day,"     
##  [6520] "and we have persuaded her to go to bed.\""                                   
##  [6521] ""                                                                            
##  [6522] "\"Perhaps, then,\" he hesitatingly replied, \"what I heard this morning"     
##  [6523] "may be--there may be more truth in it than I could believe possible at"      
##  [6524] "first.\""                                                                    
##  [6525] ""                                                                            
##  [6526] "\"What did you hear?\""                                                      
##  [6527] ""                                                                            
##  [6528] "\"That a gentleman, whom I had reason to think--in short, that a man,"       
##  [6529] "whom I KNEW to be engaged--but how shall I tell you?  If you know it"        
##  [6530] "already, as surely you must, I may be spared.\""                             
##  [6531] ""                                                                            
##  [6532] "\"You mean,\" answered Elinor, with forced calmness, \"Mr. Willoughby's"     
##  [6533] "marriage with Miss Grey.  Yes, we DO know it all.  This seems to have"       
##  [6534] "been a day of general elucidation, for this very morning first unfolded"     
##  [6535] "it to us.  Mr. Willoughby is unfathomable!  Where did you hear it?\""        
##  [6536] ""                                                                            
##  [6537] "\"In a stationer's shop in Pall Mall, where I had business.  Two ladies"     
##  [6538] "were waiting for their carriage, and one of them was giving the other"       
##  [6539] "an account of the intended match, in a voice so little attempting"           
##  [6540] "concealment, that it was impossible for me not to hear all.  The name"       
##  [6541] "of Willoughby, John Willoughby, frequently repeated, first caught my"        
##  [6542] "attention; and what followed was a positive assertion that every thing"      
##  [6543] "was now finally settled respecting his marriage with Miss Grey--it was"      
##  [6544] "no longer to be a secret--it would take place even within a few weeks,"      
##  [6545] "with many particulars of preparations and other matters.  One thing,"        
##  [6546] "especially, I remember, because it served to identify the man still"         
##  [6547] "more:--as soon as the ceremony was over, they were to go to Combe"           
##  [6548] "Magna, his seat in Somersetshire.  My astonishment!--but it would be"        
##  [6549] "impossible to describe what I felt.  The communicative lady I learnt,"       
##  [6550] "on inquiry, for I stayed in the shop till they were gone, was a Mrs."        
##  [6551] "Ellison, and that, as I have been since informed, is the name of Miss"       
##  [6552] "Grey's guardian.\""                                                          
##  [6553] ""                                                                            
##  [6554] "\"It is.  But have you likewise heard that Miss Grey has fifty thousand"     
##  [6555] "pounds?  In that, if in any thing, we may find an explanation.\""            
##  [6556] ""                                                                            
##  [6557] "\"It may be so; but Willoughby is capable--at least I think\"--he stopped"   
##  [6558] "a moment; then added in a voice which seemed to distrust itself, \"And"      
##  [6559] "your sister--how did she--\""                                                
##  [6560] ""                                                                            
##  [6561] "\"Her sufferings have been very severe.  I have only to hope that they"      
##  [6562] "may be proportionately short.  It has been, it is a most cruel"              
##  [6563] "affliction.  Till yesterday, I believe, she never doubted his regard;"       
##  [6564] "and even now, perhaps--but I am almost convinced that he never was"          
##  [6565] "really attached to her.  He has been very deceitful! and, in some"           
##  [6566] "points, there seems a hardness of heart about him.\""                        
##  [6567] ""                                                                            
##  [6568] "\"Ah!\" said Colonel Brandon, \"there is, indeed!  But your sister does"     
##  [6569] "not--I think you said so--she does not consider quite as you do?\""          
##  [6570] ""                                                                            
##  [6571] "\"You know her disposition, and may believe how eagerly she would still"     
##  [6572] "justify him if she could.\""                                                 
##  [6573] ""                                                                            
##  [6574] "He made no answer; and soon afterwards, by the removal of the"               
##  [6575] "tea-things, and the arrangement of the card parties, the subject was"        
##  [6576] "necessarily dropped.  Mrs. Jennings, who had watched them with pleasure"     
##  [6577] "while they were talking, and who expected to see the effect of Miss"         
##  [6578] "Dashwood's communication, in such an instantaneous gaiety on Colonel"        
##  [6579] "Brandon's side, as might have become a man in the bloom of youth, of"        
##  [6580] "hope and happiness, saw him, with amazement, remain the whole evening"       
##  [6581] "more serious and thoughtful than usual."                                     
##  [6582] ""                                                                            
##  [6583] ""                                                                            
##  [6584] ""                                                                            
##  [6585] "CHAPTER 31"                                                                  
##  [6586] ""                                                                            
##  [6587] ""                                                                            
##  [6588] "From a night of more sleep than she had expected, Marianne awoke the"        
##  [6589] "next morning to the same consciousness of misery in which she had"           
##  [6590] "closed her eyes."                                                            
##  [6591] ""                                                                            
##  [6592] "Elinor encouraged her as much as possible to talk of what she felt; and"     
##  [6593] "before breakfast was ready, they had gone through the subject again and"     
##  [6594] "again; and with the same steady conviction and affectionate counsel on"      
##  [6595] "Elinor's side, the same impetuous feelings and varying opinions on"          
##  [6596] "Marianne's, as before.  Sometimes she could believe Willoughby to be as"     
##  [6597] "unfortunate and as innocent as herself, and at others, lost every"           
##  [6598] "consolation in the impossibility of acquitting him.  At one moment she"      
##  [6599] "was absolutely indifferent to the observation of all the world, at"          
##  [6600] "another she would seclude herself from it for ever, and at a third"          
##  [6601] "could resist it with energy.  In one thing, however, she was uniform,"       
##  [6602] "when it came to the point, in avoiding, where it was possible, the"          
##  [6603] "presence of Mrs. Jennings, and in a determined silence when obliged to"      
##  [6604] "endure it.  Her heart was hardened against the belief of Mrs."               
##  [6605] "Jennings's entering into her sorrows with any compassion."                   
##  [6606] ""                                                                            
##  [6607] "\"No, no, no, it cannot be,\" she cried; \"she cannot feel.  Her kindness"   
##  [6608] "is not sympathy; her good-nature is not tenderness.  All that she wants"     
##  [6609] "is gossip, and she only likes me now because I supply it.\""                 
##  [6610] ""                                                                            
##  [6611] "Elinor had not needed this to be assured of the injustice to which her"      
##  [6612] "sister was often led in her opinion of others, by the irritable"             
##  [6613] "refinement of her own mind, and the too great importance placed by her"      
##  [6614] "on the delicacies of a strong sensibility, and the graces of a polished"     
##  [6615] "manner.  Like half the rest of the world, if more than half there be"        
##  [6616] "that are clever and good, Marianne, with excellent abilities and an"         
##  [6617] "excellent disposition, was neither reasonable nor candid.  She expected"     
##  [6618] "from other people the same opinions and feelings as her own, and she"        
##  [6619] "judged of their motives by the immediate effect of their actions on"         
##  [6620] "herself.  Thus a circumstance occurred, while the sisters were together"     
##  [6621] "in their own room after breakfast, which sunk the heart of Mrs."             
##  [6622] "Jennings still lower in her estimation; because, through her own"            
##  [6623] "weakness, it chanced to prove a source of fresh pain to herself, though"     
##  [6624] "Mrs. Jennings was governed in it by an impulse of the utmost goodwill."      
##  [6625] ""                                                                            
##  [6626] "With a letter in her outstretched hand, and countenance gaily smiling,"      
##  [6627] "from the persuasion of bringing comfort, she entered their room, saying,"    
##  [6628] ""                                                                            
##  [6629] "\"Now, my dear, I bring you something that I am sure will do you good.\""    
##  [6630] ""                                                                            
##  [6631] "Marianne heard enough.  In one moment her imagination placed before her"     
##  [6632] "a letter from Willoughby, full of tenderness and contrition,"                
##  [6633] "explanatory of all that had passed, satisfactory, convincing; and"           
##  [6634] "instantly followed by Willoughby himself, rushing eagerly into the room"     
##  [6635] "to inforce, at her feet, by the eloquence of his eyes, the assurances"       
##  [6636] "of his letter.  The work of one moment was destroyed by the next.  The"      
##  [6637] "hand writing of her mother, never till then unwelcome, was before her;"      
##  [6638] "and, in the acuteness of the disappointment which followed such an"          
##  [6639] "ecstasy of more than hope, she felt as if, till that instant, she had"       
##  [6640] "never suffered."                                                             
##  [6641] ""                                                                            
##  [6642] "The cruelty of Mrs. Jennings no language, within her reach in her"           
##  [6643] "moments of happiest eloquence, could have expressed; and now she could"      
##  [6644] "reproach her only by the tears which streamed from her eyes with"            
##  [6645] "passionate violence--a reproach, however, so entirely lost on its"           
##  [6646] "object, that after many expressions of pity, she withdrew, still"            
##  [6647] "referring her to the letter of comfort.  But the letter, when she was"       
##  [6648] "calm enough to read it, brought little comfort.  Willoughby filled"          
##  [6649] "every page.  Her mother, still confident of their engagement, and"           
##  [6650] "relying as warmly as ever on his constancy, had only been roused by"         
##  [6651] "Elinor's application, to intreat from Marianne greater openness towards"     
##  [6652] "them both; and this, with such tenderness towards her, such affection"       
##  [6653] "for Willoughby, and such a conviction of their future happiness in each"     
##  [6654] "other, that she wept with agony through the whole of it."                    
##  [6655] ""                                                                            
##  [6656] "All her impatience to be at home again now returned; her mother was"         
##  [6657] "dearer to her than ever; dearer through the very excess of her mistaken"     
##  [6658] "confidence in Willoughby, and she was wildly urgent to be gone."             
##  [6659] "Elinor, unable herself to determine whether it were better for Marianne"     
##  [6660] "to be in London or at Barton, offered no counsel of her own except of"       
##  [6661] "patience till their mother's wishes could be known; and at length she"       
##  [6662] "obtained her sister's consent to wait for that knowledge."                   
##  [6663] ""                                                                            
##  [6664] "Mrs. Jennings left them earlier than usual; for she could not be easy"       
##  [6665] "till the Middletons and Palmers were able to grieve as much as herself;"     
##  [6666] "and positively refusing Elinor's offered attendance, went out alone for"     
##  [6667] "the rest of the morning.  Elinor, with a very heavy heart, aware of the"     
##  [6668] "pain she was going to communicate, and perceiving, by Marianne's"            
##  [6669] "letter, how ill she had succeeded in laying any foundation for it, then"     
##  [6670] "sat down to write her mother an account of what had passed, and entreat"     
##  [6671] "her directions for the future; while Marianne, who came into the"            
##  [6672] "drawing-room on Mrs. Jennings's going away, remained fixed at the table"     
##  [6673] "where Elinor wrote, watching the advancement of her pen, grieving over"      
##  [6674] "her for the hardship of such a task, and grieving still more fondly"         
##  [6675] "over its effect on her mother."                                              
##  [6676] ""                                                                            
##  [6677] "In this manner they had continued about a quarter of an hour, when"          
##  [6678] "Marianne, whose nerves could not then bear any sudden noise, was"            
##  [6679] "startled by a rap at the door."                                              
##  [6680] ""                                                                            
##  [6681] "\"Who can this be?\" cried Elinor.  \"So early too! I thought we HAD been"   
##  [6682] "safe.\""                                                                     
##  [6683] ""                                                                            
##  [6684] "Marianne moved to the window--"                                              
##  [6685] ""                                                                            
##  [6686] "\"It is Colonel Brandon!\" said she, with vexation.  \"We are never safe"    
##  [6687] "from HIM.\""                                                                 
##  [6688] ""                                                                            
##  [6689] "\"He will not come in, as Mrs. Jennings is from home.\""                     
##  [6690] ""                                                                            
##  [6691] "\"I will not trust to THAT,\" retreating to her own room.  \"A man who has"  
##  [6692] "nothing to do with his own time has no conscience in his intrusion on"       
##  [6693] "that of others.\""                                                           
##  [6694] ""                                                                            
##  [6695] "The event proved her conjecture right, though it was founded on"             
##  [6696] "injustice and error; for Colonel Brandon DID come in; and Elinor, who"       
##  [6697] "was convinced that solicitude for Marianne brought him thither, and who"     
##  [6698] "saw THAT solicitude in his disturbed and melancholy look, and in his"        
##  [6699] "anxious though brief inquiry after her, could not forgive her sister"        
##  [6700] "for esteeming him so lightly."                                               
##  [6701] ""                                                                            
##  [6702] "\"I met Mrs. Jennings in Bond Street,\" said he, after the first"            
##  [6703] "salutation, \"and she encouraged me to come on; and I was the more"          
##  [6704] "easily encouraged, because I thought it probable that I might find you"      
##  [6705] "alone, which I was very desirous of doing.  My object--my wish--my sole"     
##  [6706] "wish in desiring it--I hope, I believe it is--is to be a means of"           
##  [6707] "giving comfort;--no, I must not say comfort--not present comfort--but"       
##  [6708] "conviction, lasting conviction to your sister's mind.  My regard for"        
##  [6709] "her, for yourself, for your mother--will you allow me to prove it, by"       
##  [6710] "relating some circumstances which nothing but a VERY sincere"                
##  [6711] "regard--nothing but an earnest desire of being useful--I think I am"         
##  [6712] "justified--though where so many hours have been spent in convincing"         
##  [6713] "myself that I am right, is there not some reason to fear I may be"           
##  [6714] "wrong?\" He stopped."                                                        
##  [6715] ""                                                                            
##  [6716] "\"I understand you,\" said Elinor.  \"You have something to tell me of Mr."  
##  [6717] "Willoughby, that will open his character farther.  Your telling it will"     
##  [6718] "be the greatest act of friendship that can be shewn Marianne.  MY"           
##  [6719] "gratitude will be insured immediately by any information tending to"         
##  [6720] "that end, and HERS must be gained by it in time.  Pray, pray let me"         
##  [6721] "hear it.\""                                                                  
##  [6722] ""                                                                            
##  [6723] "\"You shall; and, to be brief, when I quitted Barton last October,--but"     
##  [6724] "this will give you no idea--I must go farther back.  You will find me a"     
##  [6725] "very awkward narrator, Miss Dashwood; I hardly know where to begin.  A"      
##  [6726] "short account of myself, I believe, will be necessary, and it SHALL be"      
##  [6727] "a short one.  On such a subject,\" sighing heavily, \"can I have little"     
##  [6728] "temptation to be diffuse.\""                                                 
##  [6729] ""                                                                            
##  [6730] "He stopt a moment for recollection, and then, with another sigh, went"       
##  [6731] "on."                                                                         
##  [6732] ""                                                                            
##  [6733] "\"You have probably entirely forgotten a conversation--(it is not to be"     
##  [6734] "supposed that it could make any impression on you)--a conversation"          
##  [6735] "between us one evening at Barton Park--it was the evening of a"              
##  [6736] "dance--in which I alluded to a lady I had once known, as resembling, in"     
##  [6737] "some measure, your sister Marianne.\""                                       
##  [6738] ""                                                                            
##  [6739] "\"Indeed,\" answered Elinor, \"I have NOT forgotten it.\" He looked pleased" 
##  [6740] "by this remembrance, and added,"                                             
##  [6741] ""                                                                            
##  [6742] "\"If I am not deceived by the uncertainty, the partiality of tender"         
##  [6743] "recollection, there is a very strong resemblance between them, as well"      
##  [6744] "in mind as person.  The same warmth of heart, the same eagerness of"         
##  [6745] "fancy and spirits.  This lady was one of my nearest relations, an"           
##  [6746] "orphan from her infancy, and under the guardianship of my father.  Our"      
##  [6747] "ages were nearly the same, and from our earliest years we were"              
##  [6748] "playfellows and friends.  I cannot remember the time when I did not"         
##  [6749] "love Eliza; and my affection for her, as we grew up, was such, as"           
##  [6750] "perhaps, judging from my present forlorn and cheerless gravity, you"         
##  [6751] "might think me incapable of having ever felt.  Hers, for me, was, I"         
##  [6752] "believe, fervent as the attachment of your sister to Mr. Willoughby and"     
##  [6753] "it was, though from a different cause, no less unfortunate.  At"             
##  [6754] "seventeen she was lost to me for ever.  She was married--married"            
##  [6755] "against her inclination to my brother.  Her fortune was large, and our"      
##  [6756] "family estate much encumbered.  And this, I fear, is all that can be"        
##  [6757] "said for the conduct of one, who was at once her uncle and guardian."        
##  [6758] "My brother did not deserve her; he did not even love her.  I had hoped"      
##  [6759] "that her regard for me would support her under any difficulty, and for"      
##  [6760] "some time it did; but at last the misery of her situation, for she"          
##  [6761] "experienced great unkindness, overcame all her resolution, and though"       
##  [6762] "she had promised me that nothing--but how blindly I relate!  I have"         
##  [6763] "never told you how this was brought on.  We were within a few hours of"      
##  [6764] "eloping together for Scotland.  The treachery, or the folly, of my"          
##  [6765] "cousin's maid betrayed us.  I was banished to the house of a relation"       
##  [6766] "far distant, and she was allowed no liberty, no society, no amusement,"      
##  [6767] "till my father's point was gained.  I had depended on her fortitude too"     
##  [6768] "far, and the blow was a severe one--but had her marriage been happy, so"     
##  [6769] "young as I then was, a few months must have reconciled me to it, or at"      
##  [6770] "least I should not have now to lament it.  This however was not the"         
##  [6771] "case.  My brother had no regard for her; his pleasures were not what"        
##  [6772] "they ought to have been, and from the first he treated her unkindly."        
##  [6773] "The consequence of this, upon a mind so young, so lively, so"                
##  [6774] "inexperienced as Mrs. Brandon's, was but too natural.  She resigned"         
##  [6775] "herself at first to all the misery of her situation; and happy had it"       
##  [6776] "been if she had not lived to overcome those regrets which the"               
##  [6777] "remembrance of me occasioned.  But can we wonder that, with such a"          
##  [6778] "husband to provoke inconstancy, and without a friend to advise or"           
##  [6779] "restrain her (for my father lived only a few months after their"             
##  [6780] "marriage, and I was with my regiment in the East Indies) she should"         
##  [6781] "fall?  Had I remained in England, perhaps--but I meant to promote the"       
##  [6782] "happiness of both by removing from her for years, and for that purpose"      
##  [6783] "had procured my exchange.  The shock which her marriage had given me,\""     
##  [6784] "he continued, in a voice of great agitation, \"was of trifling"              
##  [6785] "weight--was nothing to what I felt when I heard, about two years"            
##  [6786] "afterwards, of her divorce.  It was THAT which threw this gloom,--even"      
##  [6787] "now the recollection of what I suffered--\""                                 
##  [6788] ""                                                                            
##  [6789] "He could say no more, and rising hastily walked for a few minutes about"     
##  [6790] "the room.  Elinor, affected by his relation, and still more by his"          
##  [6791] "distress, could not speak.  He saw her concern, and coming to her, took"     
##  [6792] "her hand, pressed it, and kissed it with grateful respect.  A few"           
##  [6793] "minutes more of silent exertion enabled him to proceed with composure."      
##  [6794] ""                                                                            
##  [6795] "\"It was nearly three years after this unhappy period before I returned"     
##  [6796] "to England.  My first care, when I DID arrive, was of course to seek"        
##  [6797] "for her; but the search was as fruitless as it was melancholy.  I could"     
##  [6798] "not trace her beyond her first seducer, and there was every reason to"       
##  [6799] "fear that she had removed from him only to sink deeper in a life of"         
##  [6800] "sin.  Her legal allowance was not adequate to her fortune, nor"              
##  [6801] "sufficient for her comfortable maintenance, and I learnt from my"            
##  [6802] "brother that the power of receiving it had been made over some months"
