##  [6803] "before to another person.  He imagined, and calmly could he imagine it,"     
##  [6804] "that her extravagance, and consequent distress, had obliged her to"          
##  [6805] "dispose of it for some immediate relief.  At last, however, and after I"     
##  [6806] "had been six months in England, I DID find her.  Regard for a former"        
##  [6807] "servant of my own, who had since fallen into misfortune, carried me to"      
##  [6808] "visit him in a spunging-house, where he was confined for debt; and"          
##  [6809] "there, in the same house, under a similar confinement, was my unfortunate"   
##  [6810] "sister.  So altered--so faded--worn down by acute suffering of every"        
##  [6811] "kind! hardly could I believe the melancholy and sickly figure before"        
##  [6812] "me, to be the remains of the lovely, blooming, healthful girl, on whom"      
##  [6813] "I had once doted.  What I endured in so beholding her--but I have no"        
##  [6814] "right to wound your feelings by attempting to describe it--I have"           
##  [6815] "pained you too much already.  That she was, to all appearance, in the"       
##  [6816] "last stage of a consumption, was--yes, in such a situation it was my"        
##  [6817] "greatest comfort.  Life could do nothing for her, beyond giving time"        
##  [6818] "for a better preparation for death; and that was given.  I saw her"          
##  [6819] "placed in comfortable lodgings, and under proper attendants; I visited"      
##  [6820] "her every day during the rest of her short life: I was with her in her"      
##  [6821] "last moments.\""                                                             
##  [6822] ""                                                                            
##  [6823] "Again he stopped to recover himself; and Elinor spoke her feelings in"       
##  [6824] "an exclamation of tender concern, at the fate of his unfortunate friend."    
##  [6825] ""                                                                            
##  [6826] "\"Your sister, I hope, cannot be offended,\" said he, \"by the resemblance"  
##  [6827] "I have fancied between her and my poor disgraced relation.  Their"           
##  [6828] "fates, their fortunes, cannot be the same; and had the natural sweet"        
##  [6829] "disposition of the one been guarded by a firmer mind, or a happier"          
##  [6830] "marriage, she might have been all that you will live to see the other"       
##  [6831] "be.  But to what does all this lead?  I seem to have been distressing"       
##  [6832] "you for nothing.  Ah! Miss Dashwood--a subject such as this--untouched"      
##  [6833] "for fourteen years--it is dangerous to handle it at all!  I WILL be"         
##  [6834] "more collected--more concise.  She left to my care her only child, a"        
##  [6835] "little girl, the offspring of her first guilty connection, who was then"     
##  [6836] "about three years old.  She loved the child, and had always kept it"         
##  [6837] "with her.  It was a valued, a precious trust to me; and gladly would I"      
##  [6838] "have discharged it in the strictest sense, by watching over her"             
##  [6839] "education myself, had the nature of our situations allowed it; but I"        
##  [6840] "had no family, no home; and my little Eliza was therefore placed at"         
##  [6841] "school.  I saw her there whenever I could, and after the death of my"        
##  [6842] "brother, (which happened about five years ago, and which left to me the"     
##  [6843] "possession of the family property,) she visited me at Delaford.  I"          
##  [6844] "called her a distant relation; but I am well aware that I have in"           
##  [6845] "general been suspected of a much nearer connection with her.  It is now"     
##  [6846] "three years ago (she had just reached her fourteenth year,) that I"          
##  [6847] "removed her from school, to place her under the care of a very"              
##  [6848] "respectable woman, residing in Dorsetshire, who had the charge of four"      
##  [6849] "or five other girls of about the same time of life; and for two years I"     
##  [6850] "had every reason to be pleased with her situation.  But last February,"      
##  [6851] "almost a twelvemonth back, she suddenly disappeared.  I had allowed"         
##  [6852] "her, (imprudently, as it has since turned out,) at her earnest desire,"      
##  [6853] "to go to Bath with one of her young friends, who was attending her"          
##  [6854] "father there for his health.  I knew him to be a very good sort of man,"     
##  [6855] "and I thought well of his daughter--better than she deserved, for, with"     
##  [6856] "a most obstinate and ill-judged secrecy, she would tell nothing, would"      
##  [6857] "give no clue, though she certainly knew all.  He, her father, a"             
##  [6858] "well-meaning, but not a quick-sighted man, could really, I believe,"         
##  [6859] "give no information; for he had been generally confined to the house,"       
##  [6860] "while the girls were ranging over the town and making what acquaintance"     
##  [6861] "they chose; and he tried to convince me, as thoroughly as he was"            
##  [6862] "convinced himself, of his daughter's being entirely unconcerned in the"      
##  [6863] "business.  In short, I could learn nothing but that she was gone; all"       
##  [6864] "the rest, for eight long months, was left to conjecture.  What I"            
##  [6865] "thought, what I feared, may be imagined; and what I suffered too.\""         
##  [6866] ""                                                                            
##  [6867] "\"Good heavens!\" cried Elinor, \"could it be--could Willoughby!\"--"        
##  [6868] ""                                                                            
##  [6869] "\"The first news that reached me of her,\" he continued, \"came in a"        
##  [6870] "letter from herself, last October.  It was forwarded to me from"             
##  [6871] "Delaford, and I received it on the very morning of our intended party"       
##  [6872] "to Whitwell; and this was the reason of my leaving Barton so suddenly,"      
##  [6873] "which I am sure must at the time have appeared strange to every body,"       
##  [6874] "and which I believe gave offence to some.  Little did Mr. Willoughby"        
##  [6875] "imagine, I suppose, when his looks censured me for incivility in"            
##  [6876] "breaking up the party, that I was called away to the relief of one whom"     
##  [6877] "he had made poor and miserable; but HAD he known it, what would it have"     
##  [6878] "availed?  Would he have been less gay or less happy in the smiles of"        
##  [6879] "your sister?  No, he had already done that, which no man who CAN feel"       
##  [6880] "for another would do.  He had left the girl whose youth and innocence"       
##  [6881] "he had seduced, in a situation of the utmost distress, with no"              
##  [6882] "creditable home, no help, no friends, ignorant of his address!  He had"      
##  [6883] "left her, promising to return; he neither returned, nor wrote, nor"          
##  [6884] "relieved her.\""                                                             
##  [6885] ""                                                                            
##  [6886] "\"This is beyond every thing!\" exclaimed Elinor."                           
##  [6887] ""                                                                            
##  [6888] "\"His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than"    
##  [6889] "both.  Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what"      
##  [6890] "I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on"       
##  [6891] "being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt"        
##  [6892] "for all your sakes.  When I came to you last week and found you alone,"      
##  [6893] "I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when"      
##  [6894] "it WAS known.  My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but"       
##  [6895] "now you will comprehend it.  To suffer you all to be so deceived; to"        
##  [6896] "see your sister--but what could I do?  I had no hope of interfering"         
##  [6897] "with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet"     
##  [6898] "reclaim him.  But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what"     
##  [6899] "were his designs on her.  Whatever they may have been, however, she may"     
##  [6900] "now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own"       
##  [6901] "condition, when she compares it with that of my poor Eliza, when she"        
##  [6902] "considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and"        
##  [6903] "pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as"      
##  [6904] "strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self-reproach, which"        
##  [6905] "must attend her through life.  Surely this comparison must have its use"     
##  [6906] "with her.  She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing.  They"            
##  [6907] "proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace.  On the"              
##  [6908] "contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them."          
##  [6909] "Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it,"        
##  [6910] "must strengthen every attachment.  Use your own discretion, however, in"     
##  [6911] "communicating to her what I have told you.  You must know best what"         
##  [6912] "will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed"     
##  [6913] "it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have"          
##  [6914] "suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family"               
##  [6915] "afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to"         
##  [6916] "raise myself at the expense of others.\""                                    
##  [6917] ""                                                                            
##  [6918] "Elinor's thanks followed this speech with grateful earnestness;"             
##  [6919] "attended too with the assurance of her expecting material advantage to"      
##  [6920] "Marianne, from the communication of what had passed."                        
##  [6921] ""                                                                            
##  [6922] "\"I have been more pained,\" said she, \"by her endeavors to acquit him"     
##  [6923] "than by all the rest; for it irritates her mind more than the most"          
##  [6924] "perfect conviction of his unworthiness can do.  Now, though at first"        
##  [6925] "she will suffer much, I am sure she will soon become easier.  Have"          
##  [6926] "you,\" she continued, after a short silence, \"ever seen Mr. Willoughby"     
##  [6927] "since you left him at Barton?\""                                             
##  [6928] ""                                                                            
##  [6929] "\"Yes,\" he replied gravely, \"once I have.  One meeting was unavoidable.\"" 
##  [6930] ""                                                                            
##  [6931] "Elinor, startled by his manner, looked at him anxiously, saying,"            
##  [6932] ""                                                                            
##  [6933] "\"What? have you met him to--\""                                             
##  [6934] ""                                                                            
##  [6935] "\"I could meet him no other way.  Eliza had confessed to me, though most"    
##  [6936] "reluctantly, the name of her lover; and when he returned to town, which"     
##  [6937] "was within a fortnight after myself, we met by appointment, he to"           
##  [6938] "defend, I to punish his conduct.  We returned unwounded, and the"            
##  [6939] "meeting, therefore, never got abroad.\""                                     
##  [6940] ""                                                                            
##  [6941] "Elinor sighed over the fancied necessity of this; but to a man and a"        
##  [6942] "soldier she presumed not to censure it."                                     
##  [6943] ""                                                                            
##  [6944] "\"Such,\" said Colonel Brandon, after a pause, \"has been the unhappy"       
##  [6945] "resemblance between the fate of mother and daughter! and so imperfectly"     
##  [6946] "have I discharged my trust!\""                                               
##  [6947] ""                                                                            
##  [6948] "\"Is she still in town?\""                                                   
##  [6949] ""                                                                            
##  [6950] "\"No; as soon as she recovered from her lying-in, for I found her near"      
##  [6951] "her delivery, I removed her and her child into the country, and there"       
##  [6952] "she remains.\""                                                              
##  [6953] ""                                                                            
##  [6954] "Recollecting, soon afterwards, that he was probably dividing Elinor"         
##  [6955] "from her sister, he put an end to his visit, receiving from her again"       
##  [6956] "the same grateful acknowledgments, and leaving her full of compassion"       
##  [6957] "and esteem for him."                                                         
##  [6958] ""                                                                            
##  [6959] ""                                                                            
##  [6960] ""                                                                            
##  [6961] "CHAPTER 32"                                                                  
##  [6962] ""                                                                            
##  [6963] ""                                                                            
##  [6964] "When the particulars of this conversation were repeated by Miss"             
##  [6965] "Dashwood to her sister, as they very soon were, the effect on her was"       
##  [6966] "not entirely such as the former had hoped to see.  Not that Marianne"        
##  [6967] "appeared to distrust the truth of any part of it, for she listened to"       
##  [6968] "it all with the most steady and submissive attention, made neither"          
##  [6969] "objection nor remark, attempted no vindication of Willoughby, and"           
##  [6970] "seemed to shew by her tears that she felt it to be impossible.  But"         
##  [6971] "though this behaviour assured Elinor that the conviction of this guilt"      
##  [6972] "WAS carried home to her mind, though she saw with satisfaction the"          
##  [6973] "effect of it, in her no longer avoiding Colonel Brandon when he called,"     
##  [6974] "in her speaking to him, even voluntarily speaking, with a kind of"           
##  [6975] "compassionate respect, and though she saw her spirits less violently"        
##  [6976] "irritated than before, she did not see her less wretched.  Her mind did"     
##  [6977] "become settled, but it was settled in a gloomy dejection.  She felt the"     
##  [6978] "loss of Willoughby's character yet more heavily than she had felt the"       
##  [6979] "loss of his heart; his seduction and desertion of Miss Williams, the"        
##  [6980] "misery of that poor girl, and the doubt of what his designs might ONCE"      
##  [6981] "have been on herself, preyed altogether so much on her spirits, that"        
##  [6982] "she could not bring herself to speak of what she felt even to Elinor;"       
##  [6983] "and, brooding over her sorrows in silence, gave more pain to her sister"     
##  [6984] "than could have been communicated by the most open and most frequent"        
##  [6985] "confession of them."                                                         
##  [6986] ""                                                                            
##  [6987] "To give the feelings or the language of Mrs. Dashwood on receiving and"      
##  [6988] "answering Elinor's letter would be only to give a repetition of what"        
##  [6989] "her daughters had already felt and said; of a disappointment hardly"         
##  [6990] "less painful than Marianne's, and an indignation even greater than"          
##  [6991] "Elinor's.  Long letters from her, quickly succeeding each other,"            
##  [6992] "arrived to tell all that she suffered and thought; to express her"           
##  [6993] "anxious solicitude for Marianne, and entreat she would bear up with"         
##  [6994] "fortitude under this misfortune.  Bad indeed must the nature of"             
##  [6995] "Marianne's affliction be, when her mother could talk of fortitude!"          
##  [6996] "mortifying and humiliating must be the origin of those regrets, which"       
##  [6997] "SHE could wish her not to indulge!"                                          
##  [6998] ""                                                                            
##  [6999] "Against the interest of her own individual comfort, Mrs. Dashwood had"       
##  [7000] "determined that it would be better for Marianne to be any where, at"         
##  [7001] "that time, than at Barton, where every thing within her view would be"       
##  [7002] "bringing back the past in the strongest and most afflicting manner, by"      
##  [7003] "constantly placing Willoughby before her, such as she had always seen"       
##  [7004] "him there.  She recommended it to her daughters, therefore, by all"          
##  [7005] "means not to shorten their visit to Mrs. Jennings; the length of which,"     
##  [7006] "though never exactly fixed, had been expected by all to comprise at"         
##  [7007] "least five or six weeks.  A variety of occupations, of objects, and of"      
##  [7008] "company, which could not be procured at Barton, would be inevitable"         
##  [7009] "there, and might yet, she hoped, cheat Marianne, at times, into some"        
##  [7010] "interest beyond herself, and even into some amusement, much as the"          
##  [7011] "ideas of both might now be spurned by her."                                  
##  [7012] ""                                                                            
##  [7013] "From all danger of seeing Willoughby again, her mother considered her"       
##  [7014] "to be at least equally safe in town as in the country, since his"            
##  [7015] "acquaintance must now be dropped by all who called themselves her"           
##  [7016] "friends.  Design could never bring them in each other's way: negligence"     
##  [7017] "could never leave them exposed to a surprise; and chance had less in"        
##  [7018] "its favour in the crowd of London than even in the retirement of"            
##  [7019] "Barton, where it might force him before her while paying that visit at"      
##  [7020] "Allenham on his marriage, which Mrs. Dashwood, from foreseeing at first"     
##  [7021] "as a probable event, had brought herself to expect as a certain one."        
##  [7022] ""                                                                            
##  [7023] "She had yet another reason for wishing her children to remain where"         
##  [7024] "they were; a letter from her son-in-law had told her that he and his"        
##  [7025] "wife were to be in town before the middle of February, and she judged"       
##  [7026] "it right that they should sometimes see their brother."                      
##  [7027] ""                                                                            
##  [7028] "Marianne had promised to be guided by her mother's opinion, and she"         
##  [7029] "submitted to it therefore without opposition, though it proved"              
##  [7030] "perfectly different from what she wished and expected, though she felt"      
##  [7031] "it to be entirely wrong, formed on mistaken grounds, and that by"            
##  [7032] "requiring her longer continuance in London it deprived her of the only"      
##  [7033] "possible alleviation of her wretchedness, the personal sympathy of her"      
##  [7034] "mother, and doomed her to such society and such scenes as must prevent"      
##  [7035] "her ever knowing a moment's rest."                                           
##  [7036] ""                                                                            
##  [7037] "But it was a matter of great consolation to her, that what brought evil"     
##  [7038] "to herself would bring good to her sister; and Elinor, on the other"         
##  [7039] "hand, suspecting that it would not be in her power to avoid Edward"          
##  [7040] "entirely, comforted herself by thinking, that though their longer stay"      
##  [7041] "would therefore militate against her own happiness, it would be better"      
##  [7042] "for Marianne than an immediate return into Devonshire."                      
##  [7043] ""                                                                            
##  [7044] "Her carefulness in guarding her sister from ever hearing Willoughby's"       
##  [7045] "name mentioned, was not thrown away.  Marianne, though without knowing"      
##  [7046] "it herself, reaped all its advantage; for neither Mrs. Jennings, nor"        
##  [7047] "Sir John, nor even Mrs. Palmer herself, ever spoke of him before her."       
##  [7048] "Elinor wished that the same forbearance could have extended towards"         
##  [7049] "herself, but that was impossible, and she was obliged to listen day"         
##  [7050] "after day to the indignation of them all."                                   
##  [7051] ""                                                                            
##  [7052] "Sir John, could not have thought it possible.  \"A man of whom he had"       
##  [7053] "always had such reason to think well!  Such a good-natured fellow!  He"      
##  [7054] "did not believe there was a bolder rider in England!  It was an"             
##  [7055] "unaccountable business.  He wished him at the devil with all his heart."     
##  [7056] "He would not speak another word to him, meet him where he might, for"        
##  [7057] "all the world!  No, not if it were to be by the side of Barton covert,"      
##  [7058] "and they were kept watching for two hours together.  Such a scoundrel"       
##  [7059] "of a fellow! such a deceitful dog!  It was only the last time they met"      
##  [7060] "that he had offered him one of Folly's puppies! and this was the end of"     
##  [7061] "it!\""                                                                       
##  [7062] ""                                                                            
##  [7063] "Mrs. Palmer, in her way, was equally angry.  \"She was determined to"        
##  [7064] "drop his acquaintance immediately, and she was very thankful that she"       
##  [7065] "had never been acquainted with him at all.  She wished with all her"         
##  [7066] "heart Combe Magna was not so near Cleveland; but it did not signify,"        
##  [7067] "for it was a great deal too far off to visit; she hated him so much"         
##  [7068] "that she was resolved never to mention his name again, and she should"       
##  [7069] "tell everybody she saw, how good-for-nothing he was.\""                      
##  [7070] ""                                                                            
##  [7071] "The rest of Mrs. Palmer's sympathy was shewn in procuring all the"           
##  [7072] "particulars in her power of the approaching marriage, and communicating"     
##  [7073] "them to Elinor.  She could soon tell at what coachmaker's the new"           
##  [7074] "carriage was building, by what painter Mr. Willoughby's portrait was"        
##  [7075] "drawn, and at what warehouse Miss Grey's clothes might be seen."             
##  [7076] ""                                                                            
##  [7077] "The calm and polite unconcern of Lady Middleton on the occasion was a"       
##  [7078] "happy relief to Elinor's spirits, oppressed as they often were by the"       
##  [7079] "clamorous kindness of the others.  It was a great comfort to her to be"      
##  [7080] "sure of exciting no interest in ONE person at least among their circle"      
##  [7081] "of friends: a great comfort to know that there was ONE who would meet"       
##  [7082] "her without feeling any curiosity after particulars, or any anxiety for"     
##  [7083] "her sister's health."                                                        
##  [7084] ""                                                                            
##  [7085] "Every qualification is raised at times, by the circumstances of the"         
##  [7086] "moment, to more than its real value; and she was sometimes worried down"     
##  [7087] "by officious condolence to rate good-breeding as more indispensable to"      
##  [7088] "comfort than good-nature."                                                   
##  [7089] ""                                                                            
##  [7090] "Lady Middleton expressed her sense of the affair about once every day,"      
##  [7091] "or twice, if the subject occurred very often, by saying, \"It is very"       
##  [7092] "shocking, indeed!\" and by the means of this continual though gentle"        
##  [7093] "vent, was able not only to see the Miss Dashwoods from the first"            
##  [7094] "without the smallest emotion, but very soon to see them without"             
##  [7095] "recollecting a word of the matter; and having thus supported the"            
##  [7096] "dignity of her own sex, and spoken her decided censure of what was"          
##  [7097] "wrong in the other, she thought herself at liberty to attend to the"         
##  [7098] "interest of her own assemblies, and therefore determined (though rather"     
##  [7099] "against the opinion of Sir John) that as Mrs. Willoughby would at once"      
##  [7100] "be a woman of elegance and fortune, to leave her card with her as soon"      
##  [7101] "as she married."                                                             
##  [7102] ""                                                                            
##  [7103] "Colonel Brandon's delicate, unobtrusive enquiries were never unwelcome"      
##  [7104] "to Miss Dashwood.  He had abundantly earned the privilege of intimate"       
##  [7105] "discussion of her sister's disappointment, by the friendly zeal with"        
##  [7106] "which he had endeavoured to soften it, and they always conversed with"       
##  [7107] "confidence.  His chief reward for the painful exertion of disclosing"        
##  [7108] "past sorrows and present humiliations, was given in the pitying eye"         
##  [7109] "with which Marianne sometimes observed him, and the gentleness of her"       
##  [7110] "voice whenever (though it did not often happen) she was obliged, or"         
##  [7111] "could oblige herself to speak to him.  THESE assured him that his"           
##  [7112] "exertion had produced an increase of good-will towards himself, and"         
##  [7113] "THESE gave Elinor hopes of its being farther augmented hereafter; but"       
##  [7114] "Mrs. Jennings, who knew nothing of all this, who knew only that the"         
##  [7115] "Colonel continued as grave as ever, and that she could neither prevail"      
##  [7116] "on him to make the offer himself, nor commission her to make it for"         
##  [7117] "him, began, at the end of two days, to think that, instead of"               
##  [7118] "Midsummer, they would not be married till Michaelmas, and by the end of"     
##  [7119] "a week that it would not be a match at all.  The good understanding"         
##  [7120] "between the Colonel and Miss Dashwood seemed rather to declare that the"     
##  [7121] "honours of the mulberry-tree, the canal, and the yew arbour, would all"      
##  [7122] "be made over to HER; and Mrs. Jennings had, for some time ceased to"         
##  [7123] "think at all of Mrs. Ferrars."                                               
##  [7124] ""                                                                            
##  [7125] "Early in February, within a fortnight from the receipt of Willoughby's"      
##  [7126] "letter, Elinor had the painful office of informing her sister that he"       
##  [7127] "was married.  She had taken care to have the intelligence conveyed to"       
##  [7128] "herself, as soon as it was known that the ceremony was over, as she was"     
##  [7129] "desirous that Marianne should not receive the first notice of it from"       
##  [7130] "the public papers, which she saw her eagerly examining every morning."       
##  [7131] ""                                                                            
##  [7132] "She received the news with resolute composure; made no observation on"       
##  [7133] "it, and at first shed no tears; but after a short time they would burst"     
##  [7134] "out, and for the rest of the day, she was in a state hardly less"            
##  [7135] "pitiable than when she first learnt to expect the event."                    
##  [7136] ""                                                                            
##  [7137] "The Willoughbys left town as soon as they were married; and Elinor now"      
##  [7138] "hoped, as there could be no danger of her seeing either of them, to"         
##  [7139] "prevail on her sister, who had never yet left the house since the blow"      
##  [7140] "first fell, to go out again by degrees as she had done before."              
##  [7141] ""                                                                            
##  [7142] "About this time the two Miss Steeles, lately arrived at their cousin's"      
##  [7143] "house in Bartlett's Buildings, Holburn, presented themselves again"          
##  [7144] "before their more grand relations in Conduit and Berkeley Streets; and"      
##  [7145] "were welcomed by them all with great cordiality."                            
##  [7146] ""                                                                            
##  [7147] "Elinor only was sorry to see them.  Their presence always gave her"          
##  [7148] "pain, and she hardly knew how to make a very gracious return to the"         
##  [7149] "overpowering delight of Lucy in finding her STILL in town."                  
##  [7150] ""                                                                            
##  [7151] "\"I should have been quite disappointed if I had not found you here"         
##  [7152] "STILL,\" said she repeatedly, with a strong emphasis on the word.  \"But"    
##  [7153] "I always thought I SHOULD.  I was almost sure you would not leave"           
##  [7154] "London yet awhile; though you TOLD me, you know, at Barton, that you"        
##  [7155] "should not stay above a MONTH.  But I thought, at the time, that you"        
##  [7156] "would most likely change your mind when it came to the point.  It would"     
##  [7157] "have been such a great pity to have went away before your brother and"       
##  [7158] "sister came.  And now to be sure you will be in no hurry to be gone.  I"     
##  [7159] "am amazingly glad you did not keep to YOUR WORD.\""                          
##  [7160] ""                                                                            
##  [7161] "Elinor perfectly understood her, and was forced to use all her"              
##  [7162] "self-command to make it appear that she did NOT."                            
##  [7163] ""                                                                            
##  [7164] "\"Well, my dear,\" said Mrs. Jennings, \"and how did you travel?\""          
##  [7165] ""                                                                            
##  [7166] "\"Not in the stage, I assure you,\" replied Miss Steele, with quick"         
##  [7167] "exultation; \"we came post all the way, and had a very smart beau to"        
##  [7168] "attend us.  Dr. Davies was coming to town, and so we thought we'd join"      
##  [7169] "him in a post-chaise; and he behaved very genteelly, and paid ten or"        
##  [7170] "twelve shillings more than we did.\""                                        
##  [7171] ""                                                                            
##  [7172] "\"Oh, oh!\" cried Mrs. Jennings; \"very pretty, indeed! and the Doctor is"   
##  [7173] "a single man, I warrant you.\""                                              
##  [7174] ""                                                                            
##  [7175] "\"There now,\" said Miss Steele, affectedly simpering, \"everybody laughs"   
##  [7176] "at me so about the Doctor, and I cannot think why.  My cousins say they"     
##  [7177] "are sure I have made a conquest; but for my part I declare I never"          
##  [7178] "think about him from one hour's end to another.  'Lord! here comes your"     
##  [7179] "beau, Nancy,' my cousin said t'other day, when she saw him crossing the"     
##  [7180] "street to the house.  My beau, indeed! said I--I cannot think who you"       
##  [7181] "mean.  The Doctor is no beau of mine.\""                                     
##  [7182] ""                                                                            
##  [7183] "\"Aye, aye, that is very pretty talking--but it won't do--the Doctor is"     
##  [7184] "the man, I see.\""                                                           
##  [7185] ""                                                                            
##  [7186] "\"No, indeed!\" replied her cousin, with affected earnestness, \"and I beg"  
##  [7187] "you will contradict it, if you ever hear it talked of.\""                    
##  [7188] ""                                                                            
##  [7189] "Mrs. Jennings directly gave her the gratifying assurance that she"           
##  [7190] "certainly would NOT, and Miss Steele was made completely happy."             
##  [7191] ""                                                                            
##  [7192] "\"I suppose you will go and stay with your brother and sister, Miss"         
##  [7193] "Dashwood, when they come to town,\" said Lucy, returning, after a"           
##  [7194] "cessation of hostile hints, to the charge."                                  
##  [7195] ""                                                                            
##  [7196] "\"No, I do not think we shall.\""                                            
##  [7197] ""                                                                            
##  [7198] "\"Oh, yes, I dare say you will.\""                                           
##  [7199] ""                                                                            
##  [7200] "Elinor would not humour her by farther opposition."                          
##  [7201] ""                                                                            
##  [7202] "\"What a charming thing it is that Mrs. Dashwood can spare you both for"     
##  [7203] "so long a time together!\""                                                  
##  [7204] ""                                                                            
##  [7205] "\"Long a time, indeed!\" interposed Mrs. Jennings.  \"Why, their visit is"   
##  [7206] "but just begun!\""                                                           
##  [7207] ""                                                                            
##  [7208] "Lucy was silenced."                                                          
##  [7209] ""                                                                            
##  [7210] "\"I am sorry we cannot see your sister, Miss Dashwood,\" said Miss"          
##  [7211] "Steele.  \"I am sorry she is not well--\" for Marianne had left the room"    
##  [7212] "on their arrival."                                                           
##  [7213] ""                                                                            
##  [7214] "\"You are very good.  My sister will be equally sorry to miss the"           
##  [7215] "pleasure of seeing you; but she has been very much plagued lately with"      
##  [7216] "nervous head-aches, which make her unfit for company or conversation.\""     
##  [7217] ""                                                                            
##  [7218] "\"Oh, dear, that is a great pity! but such old friends as Lucy and"          
##  [7219] "me!--I think she might see US; and I am sure we would not speak a word.\""   
##  [7220] ""                                                                            
##  [7221] "Elinor, with great civility, declined the proposal.  Her sister was"         
##  [7222] "perhaps laid down upon the bed, or in her dressing gown, and therefore"      
##  [7223] "not able to come to them."                                                   
##  [7224] ""                                                                            
##  [7225] "\"Oh, if that's all,\" cried Miss Steele, \"we can just as well go and see"  
##  [7226] "HER.\""                                                                      
##  [7227] ""                                                                            
##  [7228] "Elinor began to find this impertinence too much for her temper; but she"     
##  [7229] "was saved the trouble of checking it, by Lucy's sharp reprimand, which"      
##  [7230] "now, as on many occasions, though it did not give much sweetness to the"     
##  [7231] "manners of one sister, was of advantage in governing those of the other."    
##  [7232] ""                                                                            
##  [7233] ""                                                                            
##  [7234] ""                                                                            
##  [7235] "CHAPTER 33"                                                                  
##  [7236] ""                                                                            
##  [7237] ""                                                                            
##  [7238] "After some opposition, Marianne yielded to her sister's entreaties, and"     
##  [7239] "consented to go out with her and Mrs. Jennings one morning for half an"      
##  [7240] "hour. She expressly conditioned, however, for paying no visits, and"         
##  [7241] "would do no more than accompany them to Gray's in Sackville Street,"         
##  [7242] "where Elinor was carrying on a negotiation for the exchange of a few"        
##  [7243] "old-fashioned jewels of her mother."                                         
##  [7244] ""                                                                            
##  [7245] "When they stopped at the door, Mrs. Jennings recollected that there was"     
##  [7246] "a lady at the other end of the street on whom she ought to call; and as"     
##  [7247] "she had no business at Gray's, it was resolved, that while her young"        
##  [7248] "friends transacted their's, she should pay her visit and return for"         
##  [7249] "them."                                                                       
##  [7250] ""                                                                            
##  [7251] "On ascending the stairs, the Miss Dashwoods found so many people before"     
##  [7252] "them in the room, that there was not a person at liberty to tend to"         
##  [7253] "their orders; and they were obliged to wait.  All that could be done"        
##  [7254] "was, to sit down at that end of the counter which seemed to promise the"     
##  [7255] "quickest succession; one gentleman only was standing there, and it is"       
##  [7256] "probable that Elinor was not without hope of exciting his politeness to"     
##  [7257] "a quicker despatch.  But the correctness of his eye, and the delicacy"       
##  [7258] "of his taste, proved to be beyond his politeness.  He was giving orders"     
##  [7259] "for a toothpick-case for himself, and till its size, shape, and"             
##  [7260] "ornaments were determined, all of which, after examining and debating"       
##  [7261] "for a quarter of an hour over every toothpick-case in the shop, were"        
##  [7262] "finally arranged by his own inventive fancy, he had no leisure to"           
##  [7263] "bestow any other attention on the two ladies, than what was comprised"       
##  [7264] "in three or four very broad stares; a kind of notice which served to"        
##  [7265] "imprint on Elinor the remembrance of a person and face, of strong,"          
##  [7266] "natural, sterling insignificance, though adorned in the first style of"      
##  [7267] "fashion."                                                                    
##  [7268] ""                                                                            
##  [7269] "Marianne was spared from the troublesome feelings of contempt and"           
##  [7270] "resentment, on this impertinent examination of their features, and on"       
##  [7271] "the puppyism of his manner in deciding on all the different horrors of"      
##  [7272] "the different toothpick-cases presented to his inspection, by remaining"     
##  [7273] "unconscious of it all; for she was as well able to collect her thoughts"     
##  [7274] "within herself, and be as ignorant of what was passing around her, in"       
##  [7275] "Mr. Gray's shop, as in her own bedroom."                                     
##  [7276] ""                                                                            
##  [7277] "At last the affair was decided.  The ivory, the gold, and the pearls,"       
##  [7278] "all received their appointment, and the gentleman having named the last"     
##  [7279] "day on which his existence could be continued without the possession of"     
##  [7280] "the toothpick-case, drew on his gloves with leisurely care, and"             
##  [7281] "bestowing another glance on the Miss Dashwoods, but such a one as"           
##  [7282] "seemed rather to demand than express admiration, walked off with a"          
##  [7283] "happy air of real conceit and affected indifference."                        
##  [7284] ""                                                                            
##  [7285] "Elinor lost no time in bringing her business forward, was on the point"      
##  [7286] "of concluding it, when another gentleman presented himself at her side."     
##  [7287] "She turned her eyes towards his face, and found him with some surprise"      
##  [7288] "to be her brother."                                                          
##  [7289] ""                                                                            
##  [7290] "Their affection and pleasure in meeting was just enough to make a very"      
##  [7291] "creditable appearance in Mr. Gray's shop.  John Dashwood was really far"     
##  [7292] "from being sorry to see his sisters again; it rather gave them"              
##  [7293] "satisfaction; and his inquiries after their mother were respectful and"      
##  [7294] "attentive."                                                                  
##  [7295] ""                                                                            
##  [7296] "Elinor found that he and Fanny had been in town two days."                   
##  [7297] ""                                                                            
##  [7298] "\"I wished very much to call upon you yesterday,\" said he, \"but it was"    
##  [7299] "impossible, for we were obliged to take Harry to see the wild beasts at"     
##  [7300] "Exeter Exchange; and we spent the rest of the day with Mrs. Ferrars."        
##  [7301] "Harry was vastly pleased.  THIS morning I had fully intended to call on"     
##  [7302] "you, if I could possibly find a spare half hour, but one has always so"      
##  [7303] "much to do on first coming to town.  I am come here to bespeak Fanny a"      
##  [7304] "seal.  But tomorrow I think I shall certainly be able to call in"            
##  [7305] "Berkeley Street, and be introduced to your friend Mrs. Jennings.  I"         
##  [7306] "understand she is a woman of very good fortune.  And the Middletons"         
##  [7307] "too, you must introduce me to THEM.  As my mother-in-law's relations, I"     
##  [7308] "shall be happy to show them every respect.  They are excellent"              
##  [7309] "neighbours to you in the country, I understand.\""                           
##  [7310] ""                                                                            
##  [7311] "\"Excellent indeed.  Their attention to our comfort, their friendliness"     
##  [7312] "in every particular, is more than I can express.\""                          
##  [7313] ""                                                                            
##  [7314] "\"I am extremely glad to hear it, upon my word; extremely glad indeed."      
##  [7315] "But so it ought to be; they are people of large fortune, they are"           
##  [7316] "related to you, and every civility and accommodation that can serve to"      
##  [7317] "make your situation pleasant might be reasonably expected.  And so you"      
##  [7318] "are most comfortably settled in your little cottage and want for"            
##  [7319] "nothing!  Edward brought us a most charming account of the place: the"       
##  [7320] "most complete thing of its kind, he said, that ever was, and you all"        
##  [7321] "seemed to enjoy it beyond any thing.  It was a great satisfaction to us"     
##  [7322] "to hear it, I assure you.\""                                                 
##  [7323] ""                                                                            
##  [7324] "Elinor did feel a little ashamed of her brother; and was not sorry to"       
##  [7325] "be spared the necessity of answering him, by the arrival of Mrs."            
##  [7326] "Jennings's servant, who came to tell her that his mistress waited for"       
##  [7327] "them at the door."                                                           
##  [7328] ""                                                                            
##  [7329] "Mr. Dashwood attended them down stairs, was introduced to Mrs. Jennings"     
##  [7330] "at the door of her carriage, and repeating his hope of being able to"        
##  [7331] "call on them the next day, took leave."                                      
##  [7332] ""                                                                            
##  [7333] "His visit was duly paid.  He came with a pretence at an apology from"        
##  [7334] "their sister-in-law, for not coming too; \"but she was so much engaged"      
##  [7335] "with her mother, that really she had no leisure for going any where.\""      
##  [7336] "Mrs. Jennings, however, assured him directly, that she should not stand"     
##  [7337] "upon ceremony, for they were all cousins, or something like it, and she"     
##  [7338] "should certainly wait on Mrs. John Dashwood very soon, and bring her"        
##  [7339] "sisters to see her.  His manners to THEM, though calm, were perfectly"       
##  [7340] "kind; to Mrs. Jennings, most attentively civil; and on Colonel"              
##  [7341] "Brandon's coming in soon after himself, he eyed him with a curiosity"        
##  [7342] "which seemed to say, that he only wanted to know him to be rich, to be"      
##  [7343] "equally civil to HIM."                                                       
##  [7344] ""                                                                            
##  [7345] "After staying with them half an hour, he asked Elinor to walk with him"      
##  [7346] "to Conduit Street, and introduce him to Sir John and Lady Middleton."        
##  [7347] "The weather was remarkably fine, and she readily consented.  As soon as"     
##  [7348] "they were out of the house, his enquiries began."                            
##  [7349] ""                                                                            
##  [7350] "\"Who is Colonel Brandon?  Is he a man of fortune?\""                        
##  [7351] ""                                                                            
##  [7352] "\"Yes; he has very good property in Dorsetshire.\""                          
##  [7353] ""                                                                            
##  [7354] "\"I am glad of it.  He seems a most gentlemanlike man; and I think,"         
##  [7355] "Elinor, I may congratulate you on the prospect of a very respectable"        
##  [7356] "establishment in life.\""                                                    
##  [7357] ""                                                                            
##  [7358] "\"Me, brother! what do you mean?\""                                          
##  [7359] ""                                                                            
##  [7360] "\"He likes you.  I observed him narrowly, and am convinced of it.  What"     
##  [7361] "is the amount of his fortune?\""                                             
##  [7362] ""                                                                            
##  [7363] "\"I believe about two thousand a year.\""                                    
##  [7364] ""                                                                            
##  [7365] "\"Two thousand a-year;\" and then working himself up to a pitch of"          
##  [7366] "enthusiastic generosity, he added, \"Elinor, I wish with all my heart it"    
##  [7367] "were TWICE as much, for your sake.\""                                        
##  [7368] ""                                                                            
##  [7369] "\"Indeed I believe you,\" replied Elinor; \"but I am very sure that"         
##  [7370] "Colonel Brandon has not the smallest wish of marrying ME.\""                 
##  [7371] ""                                                                            
##  [7372] "\"You are mistaken, Elinor; you are very much mistaken.  A very little"      
##  [7373] "trouble on your side secures him.  Perhaps just at present he may be"        
##  [7374] "undecided; the smallness of your fortune may make him hang back; his"        
##  [7375] "friends may all advise him against it.  But some of those little"            
##  [7376] "attentions and encouragements which ladies can so easily give will fix"      
##  [7377] "him, in spite of himself.  And there can be no reason why you should"        
##  [7378] "not try for him.  It is not to be supposed that any prior attachment on"     
##  [7379] "your side--in short, you know as to an attachment of that kind, it is"       
##  [7380] "quite out of the question, the objections are insurmountable--you have"      
##  [7381] "too much sense not to see all that.  Colonel Brandon must be the man;"       
##  [7382] "and no civility shall be wanting on my part to make him pleased with"        
##  [7383] "you and your family.  It is a match that must give universal"                
##  [7384] "satisfaction.  In short, it is a kind of thing that\"--lowering his"         
##  [7385] "voice to an important whisper--\"will be exceedingly welcome to ALL"         
##  [7386] "PARTIES.\" Recollecting himself, however, he added, \"That is, I mean to"    
##  [7387] "say--your friends are all truly anxious to see you well settled; Fanny"      
##  [7388] "particularly, for she has your interest very much at heart, I assure"        
##  [7389] "you.  And her mother too, Mrs. Ferrars, a very good-natured woman, I am"     
##  [7390] "sure it would give her great pleasure; she said as much the other day.\""    
##  [7391] ""                                                                            
##  [7392] "Elinor would not vouchsafe any answer."                                      
##  [7393] ""                                                                            
##  [7394] "\"It would be something remarkable, now,\" he continued, \"something"        
##  [7395] "droll, if Fanny should have a brother and I a sister settling at the"        
##  [7396] "same time.  And yet it is not very unlikely.\""                              
##  [7397] ""                                                                            
##  [7398] "\"Is Mr. Edward Ferrars,\" said Elinor, with resolution, \"going to be"      
##  [7399] "married?\""                                                                  
##  [7400] ""                                                                            
##  [7401] "\"It is not actually settled, but there is such a thing in agitation."       
##  [7402] "He has a most excellent mother.  Mrs. Ferrars, with the utmost"              
##  [7403] "liberality, will come forward, and settle on him a thousand a year, if"      
##  [7404] "the match takes place.  The lady is the Hon. Miss Morton, only daughter"     
##  [7405] "of the late Lord Morton, with thirty thousand pounds.  A very desirable"     
##  [7406] "connection on both sides, and I have not a doubt of its taking place in"     
##  [7407] "time.  A thousand a-year is a great deal for a mother to give away, to"      
##  [7408] "make over for ever; but Mrs. Ferrars has a noble spirit.  To give you"       
##  [7409] "another instance of her liberality:--The other day, as soon as we came"      
##  [7410] "to town, aware that money could not be very plenty with us just now,"        
##  [7411] "she put bank-notes into Fanny's hands to the amount of two hundred"          
##  [7412] "pounds.  And extremely acceptable it is, for we must live at a great"        
##  [7413] "expense while we are here.\""                                                
##  [7414] ""                                                                            
##  [7415] "He paused for her assent and compassion; and she forced herself to say,"     
##  [7416] ""                                                                            
##  [7417] "\"Your expenses both in town and country must certainly be considerable;"    
##  [7418] "but your income is a large one.\""                                           
##  [7419] ""                                                                            
##  [7420] "\"Not so large, I dare say, as many people suppose.  I do not mean to"       
##  [7421] "complain, however; it is undoubtedly a comfortable one, and I hope will"     
##  [7422] "in time be better.  The enclosure of Norland Common, now carrying on,"       
##  [7423] "is a most serious drain.  And then I have made a little purchase within"     
##  [7424] "this half year; East Kingham Farm, you must remember the place, where"       
##  [7425] "old Gibson used to live.  The land was so very desirable for me in"          
##  [7426] "every respect, so immediately adjoining my own property, that I felt it"     
##  [7427] "my duty to buy it.  I could not have answered it to my conscience to"        
##  [7428] "let it fall into any other hands.  A man must pay for his convenience;"      
##  [7429] "and it HAS cost me a vast deal of money.\""                                  
##  [7430] ""                                                                            
##  [7431] "\"More than you think it really and intrinsically worth.\""                  
##  [7432] ""                                                                            
##  [7433] "\"Why, I hope not that.  I might have sold it again, the next day, for"      
##  [7434] "more than I gave: but, with regard to the purchase-money, I might have"      
##  [7435] "been very unfortunate indeed; for the stocks were at that time so low,"      
##  [7436] "that if I had not happened to have the necessary sum in my banker's"         
##  [7437] "hands, I must have sold out to very great loss.\""                           
##  [7438] ""                                                                            
##  [7439] "Elinor could only smile."                                                    
##  [7440] ""                                                                            
##  [7441] "\"Other great and inevitable expenses too we have had on first coming to"    
##  [7442] "Norland.  Our respected father, as you well know, bequeathed all the"        
##  [7443] "Stanhill effects that remained at Norland (and very valuable they were)"     
##  [7444] "to your mother.  Far be it from me to repine at his doing so; he had an"     
##  [7445] "undoubted right to dispose of his own property as he chose, but, in"         
##  [7446] "consequence of it, we have been obliged to make large purchases of"          
##  [7447] "linen, china, &c. to supply the place of what was taken away.  You may"      
##  [7448] "guess, after all these expenses, how very far we must be from being"         
##  [7449] "rich, and how acceptable Mrs. Ferrars's kindness is.\""                      
##  [7450] ""                                                                            
##  [7451] "\"Certainly,\" said Elinor; \"and assisted by her liberality, I hope you"    
##  [7452] "may yet live to be in easy circumstances.\""                                 
##  [7453] ""                                                                            
##  [7454] "\"Another year or two may do much towards it,\" he gravely replied; \"but"   
##  [7455] "however there is still a great deal to be done.  There is not a stone"       
##  [7456] "laid of Fanny's green-house, and nothing but the plan of the"                
##  [7457] "flower-garden marked out.\""                                                 
##  [7458] ""                                                                            
##  [7459] "\"Where is the green-house to be?\""                                         
##  [7460] ""                                                                            
##  [7461] "\"Upon the knoll behind the house.  The old walnut trees are all come"       
##  [7462] "down to make room for it.  It will be a very fine object from many"          
##  [7463] "parts of the park, and the flower-garden will slope down just before"        
##  [7464] "it, and be exceedingly pretty.  We have cleared away all the old thorns"     
##  [7465] "that grew in patches over the brow.\""                                       
##  [7466] ""                                                                            
##  [7467] "Elinor kept her concern and her censure to herself; and was very"            
##  [7468] "thankful that Marianne was not present, to share the provocation."           
##  [7469] ""                                                                            
##  [7470] "Having now said enough to make his poverty clear, and to do away the"        
##  [7471] "necessity of buying a pair of ear-rings for each of his sisters, in his"     
##  [7472] "next visit at Gray's his thoughts took a cheerfuller turn, and he began"     
##  [7473] "to congratulate Elinor on having such a friend as Mrs. Jennings."            
##  [7474] ""                                                                            
##  [7475] "\"She seems a most valuable woman indeed--Her house, her style of"           
##  [7476] "living, all bespeak an exceeding good income; and it is an acquaintance"     
##  [7477] "that has not only been of great use to you hitherto, but in the end may"     
##  [7478] "prove materially advantageous.--Her inviting you to town is certainly a"     
##  [7479] "vast thing in your favour; and indeed, it speaks altogether so great a"      
##  [7480] "regard for you, that in all probability when she dies you will not be"       
##  [7481] "forgotten.-- She must have a great deal to leave.\""                         
##  [7482] ""                                                                            
##  [7483] "\"Nothing at all, I should rather suppose; for she has only her"             
##  [7484] "jointure, which will descend to her children.\""                             
##  [7485] ""                                                                            
##  [7486] "\"But it is not to be imagined that she lives up to her income.  Few"        
##  [7487] "people of common prudence will do THAT; and whatever she saves, she"         
##  [7488] "will be able to dispose of.\""                                               
##  [7489] ""                                                                            
##  [7490] "\"And do you not think it more likely that she should leave it to her"       
##  [7491] "daughters, than to us?\""                                                    
##  [7492] ""                                                                            
##  [7493] "\"Her daughters are both exceedingly well married, and therefore I"          
##  [7494] "cannot perceive the necessity of her remembering them farther."              
##  [7495] "Whereas, in my opinion, by her taking so much notice of you, and"            
##  [7496] "treating you in this kind of way, she has given you a sort of claim on"      
##  [7497] "her future consideration, which a conscientious woman would not"             
##  [7498] "disregard.  Nothing can be kinder than her behaviour; and she can"           
##  [7499] "hardly do all this, without being aware of the expectation it raises.\""     
##  [7500] ""                                                                            
##  [7501] "\"But she raises none in those most concerned.  Indeed, brother, your"       
##  [7502] "anxiety for our welfare and prosperity carries you too far.\""               
##  [7503] ""                                                                            
##  [7504] "\"Why, to be sure,\" said he, seeming to recollect himself, \"people have"   
##  [7505] "little, have very little in their power.  But, my dear Elinor, what is"      
##  [7506] "the matter with Marianne?-- she looks very unwell, has lost her colour,"     
##  [7507] "and is grown quite thin.  Is she ill?\""                                     
##  [7508] ""                                                                            
##  [7509] "\"She is not well, she has had a nervous complaint on her for several"       
##  [7510] "weeks.\""                                                                    
##  [7511] ""                                                                            
##  [7512] "\"I am sorry for that.  At her time of life, any thing of an illness"        
##  [7513] "destroys the bloom for ever!  Hers has been a very short one!  She was"      
##  [7514] "as handsome a girl last September, as I ever saw; and as likely to"          
##  [7515] "attract the man.  There was something in her style of beauty, to please"     
##  [7516] "them particularly.  I remember Fanny used to say that she would marry"       
##  [7517] "sooner and better than you did; not but what she is exceedingly fond of"     
##  [7518] "YOU, but so it happened to strike her.  She will be mistaken, however."      
##  [7519] "I question whether Marianne NOW, will marry a man worth more than five"      
##  [7520] "or six hundred a-year, at the utmost, and I am very much deceived if"        
##  [7521] "YOU do not do better.  Dorsetshire!  I know very little of Dorsetshire;"     
##  [7522] "but, my dear Elinor, I shall be exceedingly glad to know more of it;"        
##  [7523] "and I think I can answer for your having Fanny and myself among the"         
##  [7524] "earliest and best pleased of your visitors.\""                               
##  [7525] ""                                                                            
##  [7526] "Elinor tried very seriously to convince him that there was no"               
##  [7527] "likelihood of her marrying Colonel Brandon; but it was an expectation"       
##  [7528] "of too much pleasure to himself to be relinquished, and he was really"       
##  [7529] "resolved on seeking an intimacy with that gentleman, and promoting the"      
##  [7530] "marriage by every possible attention.  He had just compunction enough"       
##  [7531] "for having done nothing for his sisters himself, to be exceedingly"          
##  [7532] "anxious that everybody else should do a great deal; and an offer from"       
##  [7533] "Colonel Brandon, or a legacy from Mrs. Jennings, was the easiest means"      
##  [7534] "of atoning for his own neglect."                                             
##  [7535] ""                                                                            
##  [7536] "They were lucky enough to find Lady Middleton at home, and Sir John"         
##  [7537] "came in before their visit ended.  Abundance of civilities passed on"        
##  [7538] "all sides.  Sir John was ready to like anybody, and though Mr. Dashwood"     
##  [7539] "did not seem to know much about horses, he soon set him down as a very"      
##  [7540] "good-natured fellow: while Lady Middleton saw enough of fashion in his"      
##  [7541] "appearance to think his acquaintance worth having; and Mr. Dashwood"         
##  [7542] "went away delighted with both."                                              
##  [7543] ""                                                                            
##  [7544] "\"I shall have a charming account to carry to Fanny,\" said he, as he"       
##  [7545] "walked back with his sister.  \"Lady Middleton is really a most elegant"     
##  [7546] "woman!  Such a woman as I am sure Fanny will be glad to know.  And Mrs."     
##  [7547] "Jennings too, an exceedingly well-behaved woman, though not so elegant"      
##  [7548] "as her daughter.  Your sister need not have any scruple even of"             
##  [7549] "visiting HER, which, to say the truth, has been a little the case, and"      
##  [7550] "very naturally; for we only knew that Mrs. Jennings was the widow of a"      
##  [7551] "man who had got all his money in a low way; and Fanny and Mrs. Ferrars"      
##  [7552] "were both strongly prepossessed, that neither she nor her daughters"         
##  [7553] "were such kind of women as Fanny would like to associate with.  But now"     
##  [7554] "I can carry her a most satisfactory account of both.\""                      
##  [7555] ""                                                                            
##  [7556] ""                                                                            
##  [7557] ""                                                                            
##  [7558] "CHAPTER 34"                                                                  
##  [7559] ""                                                                            
##  [7560] ""                                                                            
##  [7561] "Mrs. John Dashwood had so much confidence in her husband's judgment,"        
##  [7562] "that she waited the very next day both on Mrs. Jennings and her"             
##  [7563] "daughter; and her confidence was rewarded by finding even the former,"       
##  [7564] "even the woman with whom her sisters were staying, by no means unworthy"     
##  [7565] "her notice; and as for Lady Middleton, she found her one of the most"        
##  [7566] "charming women in the world!"                                                
##  [7567] ""                                                                            
##  [7568] "Lady Middleton was equally pleased with Mrs. Dashwood.  There was a"         
##  [7569] "kind of cold hearted selfishness on both sides, which mutually"              
##  [7570] "attracted them; and they sympathised with each other in an insipid"          
##  [7571] "propriety of demeanor, and a general want of understanding."                 
##  [7572] ""                                                                            
##  [7573] "The same manners, however, which recommended Mrs. John Dashwood to the"      
##  [7574] "good opinion of Lady Middleton did not suit the fancy of Mrs. Jennings,"     
##  [7575] "and to HER she appeared nothing more than a little proud-looking woman"      
##  [7576] "of uncordial address, who met her husband's sisters without any"             
##  [7577] "affection, and almost without having anything to say to them; for of"        
##  [7578] "the quarter of an hour bestowed on Berkeley Street, she sat at least"        
##  [7579] "seven minutes and a half in silence."                                        
##  [7580] ""                                                                            
##  [7581] "Elinor wanted very much to know, though she did not chuse to ask,"           
##  [7582] "whether Edward was then in town; but nothing would have induced Fanny"       
##  [7583] "voluntarily to mention his name before her, till able to tell her that"      
##  [7584] "his marriage with Miss Morton was resolved on, or till her husband's"        
##  [7585] "expectations on Colonel Brandon were answered; because she believed"         
##  [7586] "them still so very much attached to each other, that they could not be"      
##  [7587] "too sedulously divided in word and deed on every occasion.  The"             
##  [7588] "intelligence however, which SHE would not give, soon flowed from"            
##  [7589] "another quarter.  Lucy came very shortly to claim Elinor's compassion"       
##  [7590] "on being unable to see Edward, though he had arrived in town with Mr."       
##  [7591] "and Mrs. Dashwood.  He dared not come to Bartlett's Buildings for fear"      
##  [7592] "of detection, and though their mutual impatience to meet, was not to be"     
##  [7593] "told, they could do nothing at present but write."                           
##  [7594] ""                                                                            
##  [7595] "Edward assured them himself of his being in town, within a very short"       
##  [7596] "time, by twice calling in Berkeley Street.  Twice was his card found on"     
##  [7597] "the table, when they returned from their morning's engagements.  Elinor"     
##  [7598] "was pleased that he had called; and still more pleased that she had"         
##  [7599] "missed him."                                                                 
##  [7600] ""                                                                            
##  [7601] "The Dashwoods were so prodigiously delighted with the Middletons, that,"     
##  [7602] "though not much in the habit of giving anything, they determined to"         
##  [7603] "give them--a dinner; and soon after their acquaintance began, invited"       
##  [7604] "them to dine in Harley Street, where they had taken a very good house"       
##  [7605] "for three months.  Their sisters and Mrs. Jennings were invited"             
##  [7606] "likewise, and John Dashwood was careful to secure Colonel Brandon, who,"     
##  [7607] "always glad to be where the Miss Dashwoods were, received his eager"         
##  [7608] "civilities with some surprise, but much more pleasure.  They were to"        
##  [7609] "meet Mrs. Ferrars; but Elinor could not learn whether her sons were to"      
##  [7610] "be of the party.  The expectation of seeing HER, however, was enough to"     
##  [7611] "make her interested in the engagement; for though she could now meet"        
##  [7612] "Edward's mother without that strong anxiety which had once promised to"      
##  [7613] "attend such an introduction, though she could now see her with perfect"      
##  [7614] "indifference as to her opinion of herself, her desire of being in"           
##  [7615] "company with Mrs. Ferrars, her curiosity to know what she was like, was"     
##  [7616] "as lively as ever."                                                          
##  [7617] ""                                                                            
##  [7618] "The interest with which she thus anticipated the party, was soon"            
##  [7619] "afterwards increased, more powerfully than pleasantly, by her hearing"       
##  [7620] "that the Miss Steeles were also to be at it."                                
##  [7621] ""                                                                            
##  [7622] "So well had they recommended themselves to Lady Middleton, so agreeable"     
##  [7623] "had their assiduities made them to her, that though Lucy was certainly"      
##  [7624] "not so elegant, and her sister not even genteel, she was as ready as"        
##  [7625] "Sir John to ask them to spend a week or two in Conduit Street; and it"       
##  [7626] "happened to be particularly convenient to the Miss Steeles, as soon as"      
##  [7627] "the Dashwoods' invitation was known, that their visit should begin a"        
##  [7628] "few days before the party took place."                                       
##  [7629] ""                                                                            
##  [7630] "Their claims to the notice of Mrs. John Dashwood, as the nieces of the"      
##  [7631] "gentleman who for many years had had the care of her brother, might not"     
##  [7632] "have done much, however, towards procuring them seats at her table; but"     
##  [7633] "as Lady Middleton's guests they must be welcome; and Lucy, who had long"     
##  [7634] "wanted to be personally known to the family, to have a nearer view of"       
##  [7635] "their characters and her own difficulties, and to have an opportunity"       
##  [7636] "of endeavouring to please them, had seldom been happier in her life,"        
##  [7637] "than she was on receiving Mrs. John Dashwood's card."                        
##  [7638] ""                                                                            
##  [7639] "On Elinor its effect was very different.  She began immediately to"          
##  [7640] "determine, that Edward who lived with his mother, must be asked as his"      
##  [7641] "mother was, to a party given by his sister; and to see him for the"          
##  [7642] "first time, after all that passed, in the company of Lucy!--she hardly"      
##  [7643] "knew how she could bear it!"                                                 
##  [7644] ""                                                                            
##  [7645] "These apprehensions, perhaps, were not founded entirely on reason, and"      
##  [7646] "certainly not at all on truth.  They were relieved however, not by her"      
##  [7647] "own recollection, but by the good will of Lucy, who believed herself to"     
##  [7648] "be inflicting a severe disappointment when she told her that Edward"         
##  [7649] "certainly would not be in Harley Street on Tuesday, and even hoped to"       
##  [7650] "be carrying the pain still farther by persuading her that he was kept"       
##  [7651] "away by the extreme affection for herself, which he could not conceal"       
##  [7652] "when they were together."                                                    
##  [7653] ""                                                                            
##  [7654] "The important Tuesday came that was to introduce the two young ladies"       
##  [7655] "to this formidable mother-in-law."                                           
##  [7656] ""                                                                            
##  [7657] "\"Pity me, dear Miss Dashwood!\" said Lucy, as they walked up the stairs"    
##  [7658] "together--for the Middletons arrived so directly after Mrs. Jennings,"       
##  [7659] "that they all followed the servant at the same time--\"There is nobody"      
##  [7660] "here but you, that can feel for me.--I declare I can hardly stand."          
##  [7661] "Good gracious!--In a moment I shall see the person that all my"              
##  [7662] "happiness depends on--that is to be my mother!\"--"                          
##  [7663] ""                                                                            
##  [7664] "Elinor could have given her immediate relief by suggesting the"              
##  [7665] "possibility of its being Miss Morton's mother, rather than her own,"         
##  [7666] "whom they were about to behold; but instead of doing that, she assured"      
##  [7667] "her, and with great sincerity, that she did pity her--to the utter"          
##  [7668] "amazement of Lucy, who, though really uncomfortable herself, hoped at"       
##  [7669] "least to be an object of irrepressible envy to Elinor."                      
##  [7670] ""                                                                            
##  [7671] "Mrs. Ferrars was a little, thin woman, upright, even to formality, in"       
##  [7672] "her figure, and serious, even to sourness, in her aspect.  Her"              
##  [7673] "complexion was sallow; and her features small, without beauty, and"          
##  [7674] "naturally without expression; but a lucky contraction of the brow had"       
##  [7675] "rescued her countenance from the disgrace of insipidity, by giving it"       
##  [7676] "the strong characters of pride and ill nature.  She was not a woman of"      
##  [7677] "many words; for, unlike people in general, she proportioned them to the"     
##  [7678] "number of her ideas; and of the few syllables that did escape her, not"      
##  [7679] "one fell to the share of Miss Dashwood, whom she eyed with the spirited"     
##  [7680] "determination of disliking her at all events."                               
##  [7681] ""                                                                            
##  [7682] "Elinor could not NOW be made unhappy by this behaviour.-- A few months"      
##  [7683] "ago it would have hurt her exceedingly; but it was not in Mrs. Ferrars'"     
##  [7684] "power to distress her by it now;--and the difference of her manners to"      
##  [7685] "the Miss Steeles, a difference which seemed purposely made to humble"        
##  [7686] "her more, only amused her.  She could not but smile to see the"              
##  [7687] "graciousness of both mother and daughter towards the very person-- for"      
##  [7688] "Lucy was particularly distinguished--whom of all others, had they known"     
##  [7689] "as much as she did, they would have been most anxious to mortify; while"     
##  [7690] "she herself, who had comparatively no power to wound them, sat"
