##  [7691] "pointedly slighted by both.  But while she smiled at a graciousness so"      
##  [7692] "misapplied, she could not reflect on the mean-spirited folly from which"     
##  [7693] "it sprung, nor observe the studied attentions with which the Miss"           
##  [7694] "Steeles courted its continuance, without thoroughly despising them all"      
##  [7695] "four."                                                                       
##  [7696] ""                                                                            
##  [7697] "Lucy was all exultation on being so honorably distinguished; and Miss"       
##  [7698] "Steele wanted only to be teazed about Dr. Davies to be perfectly happy."     
##  [7699] ""                                                                            
##  [7700] "The dinner was a grand one, the servants were numerous, and every thing"     
##  [7701] "bespoke the Mistress's inclination for show, and the Master's ability"       
##  [7702] "to support it.  In spite of the improvements and additions which were"       
##  [7703] "making to the Norland estate, and in spite of its owner having once"         
##  [7704] "been within some thousand pounds of being obliged to sell out at a"          
##  [7705] "loss, nothing gave any symptom of that indigence which he had tried to"      
##  [7706] "infer from it;--no poverty of any kind, except of conversation,"             
##  [7707] "appeared--but there, the deficiency was considerable.  John Dashwood"        
##  [7708] "had not much to say for himself that was worth hearing, and his wife"        
##  [7709] "had still less.  But there was no peculiar disgrace in this; for it was"     
##  [7710] "very much the case with the chief of their visitors, who almost all"         
##  [7711] "laboured under one or other of these disqualifications for being"            
##  [7712] "agreeable--Want of sense, either natural or improved--want of"               
##  [7713] "elegance--want of spirits--or want of temper."                               
##  [7714] ""                                                                            
##  [7715] "When the ladies withdrew to the drawing-room after dinner, this poverty"     
##  [7716] "was particularly evident, for the gentlemen HAD supplied the discourse"      
##  [7717] "with some variety--the variety of politics, inclosing land, and"             
##  [7718] "breaking horses--but then it was all over; and one subject only engaged"     
##  [7719] "the ladies till coffee came in, which was the comparative heights of"        
##  [7720] "Harry Dashwood, and Lady Middleton's second son William, who were"           
##  [7721] "nearly of the same age."                                                     
##  [7722] ""                                                                            
##  [7723] "Had both the children been there, the affair might have been determined"     
##  [7724] "too easily by measuring them at once; but as Harry only was present, it"     
##  [7725] "was all conjectural assertion on both sides; and every body had a right"     
##  [7726] "to be equally positive in their opinion, and to repeat it over and over"     
##  [7727] "again as often as they liked."                                               
##  [7728] ""                                                                            
##  [7729] "The parties stood thus:"                                                     
##  [7730] ""                                                                            
##  [7731] "The two mothers, though each really convinced that her own son was the"      
##  [7732] "tallest, politely decided in favour of the other."                           
##  [7733] ""                                                                            
##  [7734] "The two grandmothers, with not less partiality, but more sincerity,"         
##  [7735] "were equally earnest in support of their own descendant."                    
##  [7736] ""                                                                            
##  [7737] "Lucy, who was hardly less anxious to please one parent than the other,"      
##  [7738] "thought the boys were both remarkably tall for their age, and could not"     
##  [7739] "conceive that there could be the smallest difference in the world"           
##  [7740] "between them; and Miss Steele, with yet greater address gave it, as"         
##  [7741] "fast as she could, in favour of each."                                       
##  [7742] ""                                                                            
##  [7743] "Elinor, having once delivered her opinion on William's side, by which"       
##  [7744] "she offended Mrs. Ferrars and Fanny still more, did not see the"             
##  [7745] "necessity of enforcing it by any farther assertion; and Marianne, when"      
##  [7746] "called on for hers, offended them all, by declaring that she had no"         
##  [7747] "opinion to give, as she had never thought about it."                         
##  [7748] ""                                                                            
##  [7749] "Before her removing from Norland, Elinor had painted a very pretty pair"     
##  [7750] "of screens for her sister-in-law, which being now just mounted and"          
##  [7751] "brought home, ornamented her present drawing room; and these screens,"       
##  [7752] "catching the eye of John Dashwood on his following the other gentlemen"      
##  [7753] "into the room, were officiously handed by him to Colonel Brandon for"        
##  [7754] "his admiration."                                                             
##  [7755] ""                                                                            
##  [7756] "\"These are done by my eldest sister,\" said he; \"and you, as a man of"     
##  [7757] "taste, will, I dare say, be pleased with them.  I do not know whether"       
##  [7758] "you have ever happened to see any of her performances before, but she"       
##  [7759] "is in general reckoned to draw extremely well.\""                            
##  [7760] ""                                                                            
##  [7761] "The Colonel, though disclaiming all pretensions to connoisseurship,"         
##  [7762] "warmly admired the screens, as he would have done any thing painted by"      
##  [7763] "Miss Dashwood; and on the curiosity of the others being of course"           
##  [7764] "excited, they were handed round for general inspection.  Mrs. Ferrars,"      
##  [7765] "not aware of their being Elinor's work, particularly requested to look"      
##  [7766] "at them; and after they had received gratifying testimony of Lady"           
##  [7767] "Middletons's approbation, Fanny presented them to her mother,"               
##  [7768] "considerately informing her, at the same time, that they were done by"       
##  [7769] "Miss Dashwood."                                                              
##  [7770] ""                                                                            
##  [7771] "\"Hum\"--said Mrs. Ferrars--\"very pretty,\"--and without regarding them at" 
##  [7772] "all, returned them to her daughter."                                         
##  [7773] ""                                                                            
##  [7774] "Perhaps Fanny thought for a moment that her mother had been quite rude"      
##  [7775] "enough,--for, colouring a little, she immediately said,"                     
##  [7776] ""                                                                            
##  [7777] "\"They are very pretty, ma'am--an't they?\" But then again, the dread of"    
##  [7778] "having been too civil, too encouraging herself, probably came over her,"     
##  [7779] "for she presently added,"                                                    
##  [7780] ""                                                                            
##  [7781] "\"Do you not think they are something in Miss Morton's style of"             
##  [7782] "painting, Ma'am?--She DOES paint most delightfully!--How beautifully"        
##  [7783] "her last landscape is done!\""                                               
##  [7784] ""                                                                            
##  [7785] "\"Beautifully indeed!  But SHE does every thing well.\""                     
##  [7786] ""                                                                            
##  [7787] "Marianne could not bear this.--She was already greatly displeased with"      
##  [7788] "Mrs. Ferrars; and such ill-timed praise of another, at Elinor's"             
##  [7789] "expense, though she had not any notion of what was principally meant by"     
##  [7790] "it, provoked her immediately to say with warmth,"                            
##  [7791] ""                                                                            
##  [7792] "\"This is admiration of a very particular kind!--what is Miss Morton to"     
##  [7793] "us?--who knows, or who cares, for her?--it is Elinor of whom WE think"       
##  [7794] "and speak.\""                                                                
##  [7795] ""                                                                            
##  [7796] "And so saying, she took the screens out of her sister-in-law's hands,"       
##  [7797] "to admire them herself as they ought to be admired."                         
##  [7798] ""                                                                            
##  [7799] "Mrs. Ferrars looked exceedingly angry, and drawing herself up more"          
##  [7800] "stiffly than ever, pronounced in retort this bitter philippic, \"Miss"       
##  [7801] "Morton is Lord Morton's daughter.\""                                         
##  [7802] ""                                                                            
##  [7803] "Fanny looked very angry too, and her husband was all in a fright at his"     
##  [7804] "sister's audacity.  Elinor was much more hurt by Marianne's warmth than"     
##  [7805] "she had been by what produced it; but Colonel Brandon's eyes, as they"       
##  [7806] "were fixed on Marianne, declared that he noticed only what was amiable"      
##  [7807] "in it, the affectionate heart which could not bear to see a sister"          
##  [7808] "slighted in the smallest point."                                             
##  [7809] ""                                                                            
##  [7810] "Marianne's feelings did not stop here.  The cold insolence of Mrs."          
##  [7811] "Ferrars's general behaviour to her sister, seemed, to her, to foretell"      
##  [7812] "such difficulties and distresses to Elinor, as her own wounded heart"        
##  [7813] "taught her to think of with horror; and urged by a strong impulse of"        
##  [7814] "affectionate sensibility, she moved after a moment, to her sister's"         
##  [7815] "chair, and putting one arm round her neck, and one cheek close to hers,"     
##  [7816] "said in a low, but eager, voice,"                                            
##  [7817] ""                                                                            
##  [7818] "\"Dear, dear Elinor, don't mind them.  Don't let them make YOU unhappy.\""   
##  [7819] ""                                                                            
##  [7820] "She could say no more; her spirits were quite overcome, and hiding her"      
##  [7821] "face on Elinor's shoulder, she burst into tears.  Every body's"              
##  [7822] "attention was called, and almost every body was concerned.--Colonel"         
##  [7823] "Brandon rose up and went to them without knowing what he did.--Mrs."         
##  [7824] "Jennings, with a very intelligent \"Ah! poor dear,\" immediately gave her"   
##  [7825] "her salts; and Sir John felt so desperately enraged against the author"      
##  [7826] "of this nervous distress, that he instantly changed his seat to one"         
##  [7827] "close by Lucy Steele, and gave her, in a whisper, a brief account of"        
##  [7828] "the whole shocking affair."                                                  
##  [7829] ""                                                                            
##  [7830] "In a few minutes, however, Marianne was recovered enough to put an end"      
##  [7831] "to the bustle, and sit down among the rest; though her spirits retained"     
##  [7832] "the impression of what had passed, the whole evening."                       
##  [7833] ""                                                                            
##  [7834] "\"Poor Marianne!\" said her brother to Colonel Brandon, in a low voice,"     
##  [7835] "as soon as he could secure his attention,-- \"She has not such good"         
##  [7836] "health as her sister,--she is very nervous,--she has not Elinor's"           
##  [7837] "constitution;--and one must allow that there is something very trying"       
##  [7838] "to a young woman who HAS BEEN a beauty in the loss of her personal"          
##  [7839] "attractions.  You would not think it perhaps, but Marianne WAS"              
##  [7840] "remarkably handsome a few months ago; quite as handsome as Elinor.--"        
##  [7841] "Now you see it is all gone.\""                                               
##  [7842] ""                                                                            
##  [7843] ""                                                                            
##  [7844] ""                                                                            
##  [7845] "CHAPTER 35"                                                                  
##  [7846] ""                                                                            
##  [7847] ""                                                                            
##  [7848] "Elinor's curiosity to see Mrs. Ferrars was satisfied.-- She had found"       
##  [7849] "in her every thing that could tend to make a farther connection between"     
##  [7850] "the families undesirable.-- She had seen enough of her pride, her"           
##  [7851] "meanness, and her determined prejudice against herself, to comprehend"       
##  [7852] "all the difficulties that must have perplexed the engagement, and"           
##  [7853] "retarded the marriage, of Edward and herself, had he been otherwise"         
##  [7854] "free;--and she had seen almost enough to be thankful for her OWN sake,"      
##  [7855] "that one greater obstacle preserved her from suffering under any other"      
##  [7856] "of Mrs. Ferrars's creation, preserved her from all dependence upon her"      
##  [7857] "caprice, or any solicitude for her good opinion.  Or at least, if she"       
##  [7858] "did not bring herself quite to rejoice in Edward's being fettered to"        
##  [7859] "Lucy, she determined, that had Lucy been more amiable, she OUGHT to"         
##  [7860] "have rejoiced."                                                              
##  [7861] ""                                                                            
##  [7862] "She wondered that Lucy's spirits could be so very much elevated by the"      
##  [7863] "civility of Mrs. Ferrars;--that her interest and her vanity should so"       
##  [7864] "very much blind her as to make the attention which seemed only paid her"     
##  [7865] "because she was NOT ELINOR, appear a compliment to herself--or to allow"     
##  [7866] "her to derive encouragement from a preference only given her, because"       
##  [7867] "her real situation was unknown.  But that it was so, had not only been"      
##  [7868] "declared by Lucy's eyes at the time, but was declared over again the"        
##  [7869] "next morning more openly, for at her particular desire, Lady Middleton"      
##  [7870] "set her down in Berkeley Street on the chance of seeing Elinor alone,"       
##  [7871] "to tell her how happy she was."                                              
##  [7872] ""                                                                            
##  [7873] "The chance proved a lucky one, for a message from Mrs. Palmer soon"          
##  [7874] "after she arrived, carried Mrs. Jennings away."                              
##  [7875] ""                                                                            
##  [7876] "\"My dear friend,\" cried Lucy, as soon as they were by themselves, \"I"     
##  [7877] "come to talk to you of my happiness.  Could anything be so flattering"       
##  [7878] "as Mrs. Ferrars's way of treating me yesterday?  So exceeding affable"       
##  [7879] "as she was!--You know how I dreaded the thoughts of seeing her;--but"        
##  [7880] "the very moment I was introduced, there was such an affability in her"       
##  [7881] "behaviour as really should seem to say, she had quite took a fancy to"       
##  [7882] "me.  Now was not it so?-- You saw it all; and was not you quite struck"      
##  [7883] "with it?\""                                                                  
##  [7884] ""                                                                            
##  [7885] "\"She was certainly very civil to you.\""                                    
##  [7886] ""                                                                            
##  [7887] "\"Civil!--Did you see nothing but only civility?-- I saw a vast deal"        
##  [7888] "more.  Such kindness as fell to the share of nobody but me!--No pride,"      
##  [7889] "no hauteur, and your sister just the same--all sweetness and"                
##  [7890] "affability!\""                                                               
##  [7891] ""                                                                            
##  [7892] "Elinor wished to talk of something else, but Lucy still pressed her to"      
##  [7893] "own that she had reason for her happiness; and Elinor was obliged to go"     
##  [7894] "on.--"                                                                       
##  [7895] ""                                                                            
##  [7896] "\"Undoubtedly, if they had known your engagement,\" said she, \"nothing"     
##  [7897] "could be more flattering than their treatment of you;--but as that was"      
##  [7898] "not the case\"--"                                                            
##  [7899] ""                                                                            
##  [7900] "\"I guessed you would say so,\"--replied Lucy quickly--\"but there was no"   
##  [7901] "reason in the world why Mrs. Ferrars should seem to like me, if she did"     
##  [7902] "not, and her liking me is every thing.  You shan't talk me out of my"        
##  [7903] "satisfaction.  I am sure it will all end well, and there will be no"         
##  [7904] "difficulties at all, to what I used to think.  Mrs. Ferrars is a"            
##  [7905] "charming woman, and so is your sister.  They are both delightful women,"     
##  [7906] "indeed!--I wonder I should never hear you say how agreeable Mrs."            
##  [7907] "Dashwood was!\""                                                             
##  [7908] ""                                                                            
##  [7909] "To this Elinor had no answer to make, and did not attempt any."              
##  [7910] ""                                                                            
##  [7911] "\"Are you ill, Miss Dashwood?--you seem low--you don't speak;--sure you"     
##  [7912] "an't well.\""                                                                
##  [7913] ""                                                                            
##  [7914] "\"I never was in better health.\""                                           
##  [7915] ""                                                                            
##  [7916] "\"I am glad of it with all my heart; but really you did not look it.  I"     
##  [7917] "should be sorry to have YOU ill; you, that have been the greatest"           
##  [7918] "comfort to me in the world!--Heaven knows what I should have done"           
##  [7919] "without your friendship.\"--"                                                
##  [7920] ""                                                                            
##  [7921] "Elinor tried to make a civil answer, though doubting her own success."       
##  [7922] "But it seemed to satisfy Lucy, for she directly replied,"                    
##  [7923] ""                                                                            
##  [7924] "\"Indeed I am perfectly convinced of your regard for me, and next to"        
##  [7925] "Edward's love, it is the greatest comfort I have.--Poor Edward!--But"        
##  [7926] "now there is one good thing, we shall be able to meet, and meet pretty"      
##  [7927] "often, for Lady Middleton's delighted with Mrs. Dashwood, so we shall"       
##  [7928] "be a good deal in Harley Street, I dare say, and Edward spends half his"     
##  [7929] "time with his sister--besides, Lady Middleton and Mrs. Ferrars will"         
##  [7930] "visit now;--and Mrs. Ferrars and your sister were both so good to say"       
##  [7931] "more than once, they should always be glad to see me.-- They are such"       
##  [7932] "charming women!--I am sure if ever you tell your sister what I think of"     
##  [7933] "her, you cannot speak too high.\""                                           
##  [7934] ""                                                                            
##  [7935] "But Elinor would not give her any encouragement to hope that she SHOULD"     
##  [7936] "tell her sister.  Lucy continued."                                           
##  [7937] ""                                                                            
##  [7938] "\"I am sure I should have seen it in a moment, if Mrs. Ferrars had took"     
##  [7939] "a dislike to me.  If she had only made me a formal courtesy, for"            
##  [7940] "instance, without saying a word, and never after had took any notice of"     
##  [7941] "me, and never looked at me in a pleasant way--you know what I mean--if"      
##  [7942] "I had been treated in that forbidding sort of way, I should have gave"       
##  [7943] "it all up in despair.  I could not have stood it.  For where she DOES"       
##  [7944] "dislike, I know it is most violent.\""                                       
##  [7945] ""                                                                            
##  [7946] "Elinor was prevented from making any reply to this civil triumph, by"        
##  [7947] "the door's being thrown open, the servant's announcing Mr. Ferrars, and"     
##  [7948] "Edward's immediately walking in."                                            
##  [7949] ""                                                                            
##  [7950] "It was a very awkward moment; and the countenance of each shewed that"       
##  [7951] "it was so.  They all looked exceedingly foolish; and Edward seemed to"       
##  [7952] "have as great an inclination to walk out of the room again, as to"           
##  [7953] "advance farther into it.  The very circumstance, in its unpleasantest"       
##  [7954] "form, which they would each have been most anxious to avoid, had fallen"     
##  [7955] "on them.--They were not only all three together, but were together"          
##  [7956] "without the relief of any other person.  The ladies recovered"               
##  [7957] "themselves first.  It was not Lucy's business to put herself forward,"       
##  [7958] "and the appearance of secrecy must still be kept up.  She could"             
##  [7959] "therefore only LOOK her tenderness, and after slightly addressing him,"      
##  [7960] "said no more."                                                               
##  [7961] ""                                                                            
##  [7962] "But Elinor had more to do; and so anxious was she, for his sake and her"     
##  [7963] "own, to do it well, that she forced herself, after a moment's"               
##  [7964] "recollection, to welcome him, with a look and manner that were almost"       
##  [7965] "easy, and almost open; and another struggle, another effort still"           
##  [7966] "improved them.  She would not allow the presence of Lucy, nor the"           
##  [7967] "consciousness of some injustice towards herself, to deter her from"          
##  [7968] "saying that she was happy to see him, and that she had very much"            
##  [7969] "regretted being from home, when he called before in Berkeley Street."        
##  [7970] "She would not be frightened from paying him those attentions which, as"      
##  [7971] "a friend and almost a relation, were his due, by the observant eyes of"      
##  [7972] "Lucy, though she soon perceived them to be narrowly watching her."           
##  [7973] ""                                                                            
##  [7974] "Her manners gave some re-assurance to Edward, and he had courage enough"     
##  [7975] "to sit down; but his embarrassment still exceeded that of the ladies in"     
##  [7976] "a proportion, which the case rendered reasonable, though his sex might"      
##  [7977] "make it rare; for his heart had not the indifference of Lucy's, nor"         
##  [7978] "could his conscience have quite the ease of Elinor's."                       
##  [7979] ""                                                                            
##  [7980] "Lucy, with a demure and settled air, seemed determined to make no"           
##  [7981] "contribution to the comfort of the others, and would not say a word;"        
##  [7982] "and almost every thing that WAS said, proceeded from Elinor, who was"        
##  [7983] "obliged to volunteer all the information about her mother's health,"         
##  [7984] "their coming to town, &c. which Edward ought to have inquired about,"        
##  [7985] "but never did."                                                              
##  [7986] ""                                                                            
##  [7987] "Her exertions did not stop here; for she soon afterwards felt herself"       
##  [7988] "so heroically disposed as to determine, under pretence of fetching"          
##  [7989] "Marianne, to leave the others by themselves; and she really did it, and"     
##  [7990] "THAT in the handsomest manner, for she loitered away several minutes on"     
##  [7991] "the landing-place, with the most high-minded fortitude, before she went"     
##  [7992] "to her sister.  When that was once done, however, it was time for the"       
##  [7993] "raptures of Edward to cease; for Marianne's joy hurried her into the"        
##  [7994] "drawing-room immediately.  Her pleasure in seeing him was like every"        
##  [7995] "other of her feelings, strong in itself, and strongly spoken.  She met"      
##  [7996] "him with a hand that would be taken, and a voice that expressed the"         
##  [7997] "affection of a sister."                                                      
##  [7998] ""                                                                            
##  [7999] "\"Dear Edward!\" she cried, \"this is a moment of great happiness!--This"    
##  [8000] "would almost make amends for every thing!\""                                 
##  [8001] ""                                                                            
##  [8002] "Edward tried to return her kindness as it deserved, but before such"         
##  [8003] "witnesses he dared not say half what he really felt.  Again they all"        
##  [8004] "sat down, and for a moment or two all were silent; while Marianne was"       
##  [8005] "looking with the most speaking tenderness, sometimes at Edward and"          
##  [8006] "sometimes at Elinor, regretting only that their delight in each other"       
##  [8007] "should be checked by Lucy's unwelcome presence.  Edward was the first"       
##  [8008] "to speak, and it was to notice Marianne's altered looks, and express"        
##  [8009] "his fear of her not finding London agree with her."                          
##  [8010] ""                                                                            
##  [8011] "\"Oh, don't think of me!\" she replied with spirited earnestness, though"    
##  [8012] "her eyes were filled with tears as she spoke, \"don't think of MY"           
##  [8013] "health.  Elinor is well, you see.  That must be enough for us both.\""       
##  [8014] ""                                                                            
##  [8015] "This remark was not calculated to make Edward or Elinor more easy, nor"      
##  [8016] "to conciliate the good will of Lucy, who looked up at Marianne with no"      
##  [8017] "very benignant expression."                                                  
##  [8018] ""                                                                            
##  [8019] "\"Do you like London?\" said Edward, willing to say any thing that might"    
##  [8020] "introduce another subject."                                                  
##  [8021] ""                                                                            
##  [8022] "\"Not at all.  I expected much pleasure in it, but I have found none."       
##  [8023] "The sight of you, Edward, is the only comfort it has afforded; and"          
##  [8024] "thank Heaven! you are what you always were!\""                               
##  [8025] ""                                                                            
##  [8026] "She paused--no one spoke."                                                   
##  [8027] ""                                                                            
##  [8028] "\"I think, Elinor,\" she presently added, \"we must employ Edward to take"   
##  [8029] "care of us in our return to Barton.  In a week or two, I suppose, we"        
##  [8030] "shall be going; and, I trust, Edward will not be very unwilling to"          
##  [8031] "accept the charge.\""                                                        
##  [8032] ""                                                                            
##  [8033] "Poor Edward muttered something, but what it was, nobody knew, not even"      
##  [8034] "himself.  But Marianne, who saw his agitation, and could easily trace"       
##  [8035] "it to whatever cause best pleased herself, was perfectly satisfied, and"     
##  [8036] "soon talked of something else."                                              
##  [8037] ""                                                                            
##  [8038] "\"We spent such a day, Edward, in Harley Street yesterday!  So dull, so"     
##  [8039] "wretchedly dull!--But I have much to say to you on that head, which"         
##  [8040] "cannot be said now.\""                                                       
##  [8041] ""                                                                            
##  [8042] "And with this admirable discretion did she defer the assurance of her"       
##  [8043] "finding their mutual relatives more disagreeable than ever, and of her"      
##  [8044] "being particularly disgusted with his mother, till they were more in"        
##  [8045] "private."                                                                    
##  [8046] ""                                                                            
##  [8047] "\"But why were you not there, Edward?--Why did you not come?\""              
##  [8048] ""                                                                            
##  [8049] "\"I was engaged elsewhere.\""                                                
##  [8050] ""                                                                            
##  [8051] "\"Engaged!  But what was that, when such friends were to be met?\""          
##  [8052] ""                                                                            
##  [8053] "\"Perhaps, Miss Marianne,\" cried Lucy, eager to take some revenge on"       
##  [8054] "her, \"you think young men never stand upon engagements, if they have no"    
##  [8055] "mind to keep them, little as well as great.\""                               
##  [8056] ""                                                                            
##  [8057] "Elinor was very angry, but Marianne seemed entirely insensible of the"       
##  [8058] "sting; for she calmly replied,"                                              
##  [8059] ""                                                                            
##  [8060] "\"Not so, indeed; for, seriously speaking, I am very sure that"              
##  [8061] "conscience only kept Edward from Harley Street.  And I really believe"       
##  [8062] "he HAS the most delicate conscience in the world; the most scrupulous"       
##  [8063] "in performing every engagement, however minute, and however it may make"     
##  [8064] "against his interest or pleasure.  He is the most fearful of giving"         
##  [8065] "pain, of wounding expectation, and the most incapable of being selfish,"     
##  [8066] "of any body I ever saw.  Edward, it is so, and I will say it.  What!"        
##  [8067] "are you never to hear yourself praised!--Then you must be no friend of"      
##  [8068] "mine; for those who will accept of my love and esteem, must submit to"       
##  [8069] "my open commendation.\""                                                     
##  [8070] ""                                                                            
##  [8071] "The nature of her commendation, in the present case, however, happened"      
##  [8072] "to be particularly ill-suited to the feelings of two thirds of her"          
##  [8073] "auditors, and was so very unexhilarating to Edward, that he very soon"       
##  [8074] "got up to go away."                                                          
##  [8075] ""                                                                            
##  [8076] "\"Going so soon!\" said Marianne; \"my dear Edward, this must not be.\""     
##  [8077] ""                                                                            
##  [8078] "And drawing him a little aside, she whispered her persuasion that Lucy"      
##  [8079] "could not stay much longer.  But even this encouragement failed, for he"     
##  [8080] "would go; and Lucy, who would have outstaid him, had his visit lasted"       
##  [8081] "two hours, soon afterwards went away."                                       
##  [8082] ""                                                                            
##  [8083] "\"What can bring her here so often?\" said Marianne, on her leaving them."   
##  [8084] "\"Could not she see that we wanted her gone!--how teazing to Edward!\""      
##  [8085] ""                                                                            
##  [8086] "\"Why so?--we were all his friends, and Lucy has been the longest known"     
##  [8087] "to him of any.  It is but natural that he should like to see her as"         
##  [8088] "well as ourselves.\""                                                        
##  [8089] ""                                                                            
##  [8090] "Marianne looked at her steadily, and said, \"You know, Elinor, that this"    
##  [8091] "is a kind of talking which I cannot bear.  If you only hope to have"         
##  [8092] "your assertion contradicted, as I must suppose to be the case, you"          
##  [8093] "ought to recollect that I am the last person in the world to do it.  I"      
##  [8094] "cannot descend to be tricked out of assurances, that are not really"         
##  [8095] "wanted.\""                                                                   
##  [8096] ""                                                                            
##  [8097] "She then left the room; and Elinor dared not follow her to say more,"        
##  [8098] "for bound as she was by her promise of secrecy to Lucy, she could give"      
##  [8099] "no information that would convince Marianne; and painful as the"             
##  [8100] "consequences of her still continuing in an error might be, she was"          
##  [8101] "obliged to submit to it.  All that she could hope, was that Edward"          
##  [8102] "would not often expose her or himself to the distress of hearing"            
##  [8103] "Marianne's mistaken warmth, nor to the repetition of any other part of"      
##  [8104] "the pain that had attended their recent meeting--and this she had every"     
##  [8105] "reason to expect."                                                           
##  [8106] ""                                                                            
##  [8107] ""                                                                            
##  [8108] ""                                                                            
##  [8109] "CHAPTER 36"                                                                  
##  [8110] ""                                                                            
##  [8111] ""                                                                            
##  [8112] "Within a few days after this meeting, the newspapers announced to the"       
##  [8113] "world, that the lady of Thomas Palmer, Esq. was safely delivered of a"       
##  [8114] "son and heir; a very interesting and satisfactory paragraph, at least"       
##  [8115] "to all those intimate connections who knew it before."                       
##  [8116] ""                                                                            
##  [8117] "This event, highly important to Mrs. Jennings's happiness, produced a"       
##  [8118] "temporary alteration in the disposal of her time, and influenced, in a"      
##  [8119] "like degree, the engagements of her young friends; for as she wished to"     
##  [8120] "be as much as possible with Charlotte, she went thither every morning as"    
##  [8121] "soon as she was dressed, and did not return till late in the evening;"       
##  [8122] "and the Miss Dashwoods, at the particular request of the Middletons,"        
##  [8123] "spent the whole of every day in Conduit Street. For their own comfort"       
##  [8124] "they would much rather have remained, at least all the morning, in Mrs."     
##  [8125] "Jennings's house; but it was not a thing to be urged against the wishes"     
##  [8126] "of everybody. Their hours were therefore made over to Lady Middleton and"    
##  [8127] "the two Miss Steeles, by whom their company, in fact was as little"          
##  [8128] "valued, as it was professedly sought."                                       
##  [8129] ""                                                                            
##  [8130] "They had too much sense to be desirable companions to the former; and"       
##  [8131] "by the latter they were considered with a jealous eye, as intruding on"      
##  [8132] "THEIR ground, and sharing the kindness which they wanted to monopolize."     
##  [8133] "Though nothing could be more polite than Lady Middleton's behaviour to"      
##  [8134] "Elinor and Marianne, she did not really like them at all.  Because they"     
##  [8135] "neither flattered herself nor her children, she could not believe them"      
##  [8136] "good-natured; and because they were fond of reading, she fancied them"       
##  [8137] "satirical: perhaps without exactly knowing what it was to be satirical;"     
##  [8138] "but THAT did not signify.  It was censure in common use, and easily"         
##  [8139] "given."                                                                      
##  [8140] ""                                                                            
##  [8141] "Their presence was a restraint both on her and on Lucy.  It checked the"     
##  [8142] "idleness of one, and the business of the other.  Lady Middleton was"         
##  [8143] "ashamed of doing nothing before them, and the flattery which Lucy was"       
##  [8144] "proud to think of and administer at other times, she feared they would"      
##  [8145] "despise her for offering.  Miss Steele was the least discomposed of the"     
##  [8146] "three, by their presence; and it was in their power to reconcile her to"     
##  [8147] "it entirely.  Would either of them only have given her a full and"           
##  [8148] "minute account of the whole affair between Marianne and Mr. Willoughby,"     
##  [8149] "she would have thought herself amply rewarded for the sacrifice of the"      
##  [8150] "best place by the fire after dinner, which their arrival occasioned."        
##  [8151] "But this conciliation was not granted; for though she often threw out"       
##  [8152] "expressions of pity for her sister to Elinor, and more than once dropt"      
##  [8153] "a reflection on the inconstancy of beaux before Marianne, no effect was"     
##  [8154] "produced, but a look of indifference from the former, or of disgust in"      
##  [8155] "the latter.  An effort even yet lighter might have made her their"           
##  [8156] "friend.  Would they only have laughed at her about the Doctor!  But so"      
##  [8157] "little were they, anymore than the others, inclined to oblige her, that"     
##  [8158] "if Sir John dined from home, she might spend a whole day without"            
##  [8159] "hearing any other raillery on the subject, than what she was kind"           
##  [8160] "enough to bestow on herself."                                                
##  [8161] ""                                                                            
##  [8162] "All these jealousies and discontents, however, were so totally"              
##  [8163] "unsuspected by Mrs. Jennings, that she thought it a delightful thing"        
##  [8164] "for the girls to be together; and generally congratulated her young"         
##  [8165] "friends every night, on having escaped the company of a stupid old"          
##  [8166] "woman so long.  She joined them sometimes at Sir John's, sometimes at"       
##  [8167] "her own house; but wherever it was, she always came in excellent"            
##  [8168] "spirits, full of delight and importance, attributing Charlotte's well"       
##  [8169] "doing to her own care, and ready to give so exact, so minute a detail"       
##  [8170] "of her situation, as only Miss Steele had curiosity enough to desire."       
##  [8171] "One thing DID disturb her; and of that she made her daily complaint."        
##  [8172] "Mr. Palmer maintained the common, but unfatherly opinion among his sex,"     
##  [8173] "of all infants being alike; and though she could plainly perceive, at"       
##  [8174] "different times, the most striking resemblance between this baby and"        
##  [8175] "every one of his relations on both sides, there was no convincing his"       
##  [8176] "father of it; no persuading him to believe that it was not exactly like"     
##  [8177] "every other baby of the same age; nor could he even be brought to"           
##  [8178] "acknowledge the simple proposition of its being the finest child in the"     
##  [8179] "world."                                                                      
##  [8180] ""                                                                            
##  [8181] "I come now to the relation of a misfortune, which about this time"           
##  [8182] "befell Mrs. John Dashwood.  It so happened that while her two sisters"       
##  [8183] "with Mrs. Jennings were first calling on her in Harley Street, another"      
##  [8184] "of her acquaintance had dropt in--a circumstance in itself not"              
##  [8185] "apparently likely to produce evil to her.  But while the imaginations"       
##  [8186] "of other people will carry them away to form wrong judgments of our"         
##  [8187] "conduct, and to decide on it by slight appearances, one's happiness"         
##  [8188] "must in some measure be always at the mercy of chance.  In the present"      
##  [8189] "instance, this last-arrived lady allowed her fancy to so far outrun"         
##  [8190] "truth and probability, that on merely hearing the name of the Miss"          
##  [8191] "Dashwoods, and understanding them to be Mr. Dashwood's sisters, she"         
##  [8192] "immediately concluded them to be staying in Harley Street; and this"         
##  [8193] "misconstruction produced within a day or two afterwards, cards of"           
##  [8194] "invitation for them as well as for their brother and sister, to a small"     
##  [8195] "musical party at her house.  The consequence of which was, that Mrs."        
##  [8196] "John Dashwood was obliged to submit not only to the exceedingly great"       
##  [8197] "inconvenience of sending her carriage for the Miss Dashwoods, but, what"     
##  [8198] "was still worse, must be subject to all the unpleasantness of appearing"     
##  [8199] "to treat them with attention: and who could tell that they might not"        
##  [8200] "expect to go out with her a second time?  The power of disappointing"        
##  [8201] "them, it was true, must always be hers.  But that was not enough; for"       
##  [8202] "when people are determined on a mode of conduct which they know to be"       
##  [8203] "wrong, they feel injured by the expectation of any thing better from"        
##  [8204] "them."                                                                       
##  [8205] ""                                                                            
##  [8206] "Marianne had now been brought by degrees, so much into the habit of"         
##  [8207] "going out every day, that it was become a matter of indifference to"         
##  [8208] "her, whether she went or not: and she prepared quietly and mechanically"     
##  [8209] "for every evening's engagement, though without expecting the smallest"       
##  [8210] "amusement from any, and very often without knowing, till the last"           
##  [8211] "moment, where it was to take her."                                           
##  [8212] ""                                                                            
##  [8213] "To her dress and appearance she was grown so perfectly indifferent, as"      
##  [8214] "not to bestow half the consideration on it, during the whole of her"         
##  [8215] "toilet, which it received from Miss Steele in the first five minutes of"     
##  [8216] "their being together, when it was finished.  Nothing escaped HER minute"     
##  [8217] "observation and general curiosity; she saw every thing, and asked every"     
##  [8218] "thing; was never easy till she knew the price of every part of"              
##  [8219] "Marianne's dress; could have guessed the number of her gowns altogether"     
##  [8220] "with better judgment than Marianne herself, and was not without hopes"       
##  [8221] "of finding out before they parted, how much her washing cost per week,"      
##  [8222] "and how much she had every year to spend upon herself.  The"                 
##  [8223] "impertinence of these kind of scrutinies, moreover, was generally"           
##  [8224] "concluded with a compliment, which though meant as its douceur, was"         
##  [8225] "considered by Marianne as the greatest impertinence of all; for after"       
##  [8226] "undergoing an examination into the value and make of her gown, the"          
##  [8227] "colour of her shoes, and the arrangement of her hair, she was almost"        
##  [8228] "sure of being told that upon \"her word she looked vastly smart, and she"    
##  [8229] "dared to say she would make a great many conquests.\""                       
##  [8230] ""                                                                            
##  [8231] "With such encouragement as this, was she dismissed on the present"           
##  [8232] "occasion, to her brother's carriage; which they were ready to enter"         
##  [8233] "five minutes after it stopped at the door, a punctuality not very"           
##  [8234] "agreeable to their sister-in-law, who had preceded them to the house of"     
##  [8235] "her acquaintance, and was there hoping for some delay on their part"         
##  [8236] "that might inconvenience either herself or her coachman."                    
##  [8237] ""                                                                            
##  [8238] "The events of this evening were not very remarkable.  The party, like"       
##  [8239] "other musical parties, comprehended a great many people who had real"        
##  [8240] "taste for the performance, and a great many more who had none at all;"       
##  [8241] "and the performers themselves were, as usual, in their own estimation,"      
##  [8242] "and that of their immediate friends, the first private performers in"        
##  [8243] "England."                                                                    
##  [8244] ""                                                                            
##  [8245] "As Elinor was neither musical, nor affecting to be so, she made no"          
##  [8246] "scruple of turning her eyes from the grand pianoforte, whenever it"          
##  [8247] "suited her, and unrestrained even by the presence of a harp, and"            
##  [8248] "violoncello, would fix them at pleasure on any other object in the"          
##  [8249] "room.  In one of these excursive glances she perceived among a group of"     
##  [8250] "young men, the very he, who had given them a lecture on toothpick-cases"     
##  [8251] "at Gray's.  She perceived him soon afterwards looking at herself, and"       
##  [8252] "speaking familiarly to her brother; and had just determined to find out"     
##  [8253] "his name from the latter, when they both came towards her, and Mr."          
##  [8254] "Dashwood introduced him to her as Mr. Robert Ferrars."                       
##  [8255] ""                                                                            
##  [8256] "He addressed her with easy civility, and twisted his head into a bow"        
##  [8257] "which assured her as plainly as words could have done, that he was"          
##  [8258] "exactly the coxcomb she had heard him described to be by Lucy.  Happy"       
##  [8259] "had it been for her, if her regard for Edward had depended less on his"      
##  [8260] "own merit, than on the merit of his nearest relations!  For then his"        
##  [8261] "brother's bow must have given the finishing stroke to what the"              
##  [8262] "ill-humour of his mother and sister would have begun.  But while she"        
##  [8263] "wondered at the difference of the two young men, she did not find that"      
##  [8264] "the emptiness of conceit of the one, put her out of all charity with"        
##  [8265] "the modesty and worth of the other.  Why they WERE different, Robert"        
##  [8266] "exclaimed to her himself in the course of a quarter of an hour's"            
##  [8267] "conversation; for, talking of his brother, and lamenting the extreme"        
##  [8268] "GAUCHERIE which he really believed kept him from mixing in proper"           
##  [8269] "society, he candidly and generously attributed it much less to any"          
##  [8270] "natural deficiency, than to the misfortune of a private education;"          
##  [8271] "while he himself, though probably without any particular, any material"      
##  [8272] "superiority by nature, merely from the advantage of a public school,"        
##  [8273] "was as well fitted to mix in the world as any other man."                    
##  [8274] ""                                                                            
##  [8275] "\"Upon my soul,\" he added, \"I believe it is nothing more; and so I often"  
##  [8276] "tell my mother, when she is grieving about it.  'My dear Madam,' I"          
##  [8277] "always say to her, 'you must make yourself easy.  The evil is now"           
##  [8278] "irremediable, and it has been entirely your own doing.  Why would you"       
##  [8279] "be persuaded by my uncle, Sir Robert, against your own judgment, to"         
##  [8280] "place Edward under private tuition, at the most critical time of his"        
##  [8281] "life?  If you had only sent him to Westminster as well as myself,"           
##  [8282] "instead of sending him to Mr. Pratt's, all this would have been"             
##  [8283] "prevented.' This is the way in which I always consider the matter, and"      
##  [8284] "my mother is perfectly convinced of her error.\""                            
##  [8285] ""                                                                            
##  [8286] "Elinor would not oppose his opinion, because, whatever might be her"         
##  [8287] "general estimation of the advantage of a public school, she could not"       
##  [8288] "think of Edward's abode in Mr. Pratt's family, with any satisfaction."       
##  [8289] ""                                                                            
##  [8290] "\"You reside in Devonshire, I think,\"--was his next observation, \"in a"    
##  [8291] "cottage near Dawlish.\""                                                     
##  [8292] ""                                                                            
##  [8293] "Elinor set him right as to its situation; and it seemed rather"              
##  [8294] "surprising to him that anybody could live in Devonshire, without living"     
##  [8295] "near Dawlish.  He bestowed his hearty approbation however on their"          
##  [8296] "species of house."                                                           
##  [8297] ""                                                                            
##  [8298] "\"For my own part,\" said he, \"I am excessively fond of a cottage; there"   
##  [8299] "is always so much comfort, so much elegance about them.  And I protest,"     
##  [8300] "if I had any money to spare, I should buy a little land and build one"       
##  [8301] "myself, within a short distance of London, where I might drive myself"       
##  [8302] "down at any time, and collect a few friends about me, and be happy.  I"      
##  [8303] "advise every body who is going to build, to build a cottage.  My friend"     
##  [8304] "Lord Courtland came to me the other day on purpose to ask my advice,"        
##  [8305] "and laid before me three different plans of Bonomi's.  I was to decide"      
##  [8306] "on the best of them.  'My dear Courtland,' said I, immediately throwing"     
##  [8307] "them all into the fire, 'do not adopt either of them, but by all means"      
##  [8308] "build a cottage.' And that I fancy, will be the end of it."                  
##  [8309] ""                                                                            
##  [8310] "\"Some people imagine that there can be no accommodations, no space in a"    
##  [8311] "cottage; but this is all a mistake.  I was last month at my friend"          
##  [8312] "Elliott's, near Dartford.  Lady Elliott wished to give a dance.  'But"       
##  [8313] "how can it be done?' said she; 'my dear Ferrars, do tell me how it is"       
##  [8314] "to be managed.  There is not a room in this cottage that will hold ten"      
##  [8315] "couple, and where can the supper be?' I immediately saw that there"          
##  [8316] "could be no difficulty in it, so I said, 'My dear Lady Elliott, do not"      
##  [8317] "be uneasy.  The dining parlour will admit eighteen couple with ease;"        
##  [8318] "card-tables may be placed in the drawing-room; the library may be open"      
##  [8319] "for tea and other refreshments; and let the supper be set out in the"        
##  [8320] "saloon.'  Lady Elliott was delighted with the thought.  We measured the"     
##  [8321] "dining-room, and found it would hold exactly eighteen couple, and the"       
##  [8322] "affair was arranged precisely after my plan.  So that, in fact, you"         
##  [8323] "see, if people do but know how to set about it, every comfort may be as"     
##  [8324] "well enjoyed in a cottage as in the most spacious dwelling.\""               
##  [8325] ""                                                                            
##  [8326] "Elinor agreed to it all, for she did not think he deserved the"              
##  [8327] "compliment of rational opposition."                                          
##  [8328] ""                                                                            
##  [8329] "As John Dashwood had no more pleasure in music than his eldest sister,"      
##  [8330] "his mind was equally at liberty to fix on any thing else; and a thought"     
##  [8331] "struck him during the evening, which he communicated to his wife, for"       
##  [8332] "her approbation, when they got home.  The consideration of Mrs."             
##  [8333] "Dennison's mistake, in supposing his sisters their guests, had"              
##  [8334] "suggested the propriety of their being really invited to become such,"       
##  [8335] "while Mrs. Jennings's engagements kept her from home.  The expense would"    
##  [8336] "be nothing, the inconvenience not more; and it was altogether an"            
##  [8337] "attention which the delicacy of his conscience pointed out to be"            
##  [8338] "requisite to its complete enfranchisement from his promise to his"           
##  [8339] "father.  Fanny was startled at the proposal."                                
##  [8340] ""                                                                            
##  [8341] "\"I do not see how it can be done,\" said she, \"without affronting Lady"    
##  [8342] "Middleton, for they spend every day with her; otherwise I should be"         
##  [8343] "exceedingly glad to do it.  You know I am always ready to pay them any"      
##  [8344] "attention in my power, as my taking them out this evening shews.  But"       
##  [8345] "they are Lady Middleton's visitors.  How can I ask them away from her?\""    
##  [8346] ""                                                                            
##  [8347] "Her husband, but with great humility, did not see the force of her"          
##  [8348] "objection.  \"They had already spent a week in this manner in Conduit"       
##  [8349] "Street, and Lady Middleton could not be displeased at their giving the"      
##  [8350] "same number of days to such near relations.\""                               
##  [8351] ""                                                                            
##  [8352] "Fanny paused a moment, and then, with fresh vigor, said,"                    
##  [8353] ""                                                                            
##  [8354] "\"My love I would ask them with all my heart, if it was in my power."        
##  [8355] "But I had just settled within myself to ask the Miss Steeles to spend a"     
##  [8356] "few days with us.  They are very well behaved, good kind of girls; and"      
##  [8357] "I think the attention is due to them, as their uncle did so very well"       
##  [8358] "by Edward.  We can ask your sisters some other year, you know; but the"      
##  [8359] "Miss Steeles may not be in town any more.  I am sure you will like"          
##  [8360] "them; indeed, you DO like them, you know, very much already, and so"         
##  [8361] "does my mother; and they are such favourites with Harry!\""                  
##  [8362] ""                                                                            
##  [8363] "Mr. Dashwood was convinced.  He saw the necessity of inviting the Miss"      
##  [8364] "Steeles immediately, and his conscience was pacified by the resolution"      
##  [8365] "of inviting his sisters another year; at the same time, however, slyly"      
##  [8366] "suspecting that another year would make the invitation needless, by"         
##  [8367] "bringing Elinor to town as Colonel Brandon's wife, and Marianne as"          
##  [8368] "THEIR visitor."                                                              
##  [8369] ""                                                                            
##  [8370] "Fanny, rejoicing in her escape, and proud of the ready wit that had"         
##  [8371] "procured it, wrote the next morning to Lucy, to request her company and"     
##  [8372] "her sister's, for some days, in Harley Street, as soon as Lady"              
##  [8373] "Middleton could spare them.  This was enough to make Lucy really and"        
##  [8374] "reasonably happy.  Mrs. Dashwood seemed actually working for her,"           
##  [8375] "herself; cherishing all her hopes, and promoting all her views!  Such"       
##  [8376] "an opportunity of being with Edward and his family was, above all"           
##  [8377] "things, the most material to her interest, and such an invitation the"       
##  [8378] "most gratifying to her feelings!  It was an advantage that could not be"     
##  [8379] "too gratefully acknowledged, nor too speedily made use of; and the"          
##  [8380] "visit to Lady Middleton, which had not before had any precise limits,"       
##  [8381] "was instantly discovered to have been always meant to end in two days'"      
##  [8382] "time."                                                                       
##  [8383] ""                                                                            
##  [8384] "When the note was shown to Elinor, as it was within ten minutes after"       
##  [8385] "its arrival, it gave her, for the first time, some share in the"             
##  [8386] "expectations of Lucy; for such a mark of uncommon kindness, vouchsafed"      
##  [8387] "on so short an acquaintance, seemed to declare that the good-will"           
##  [8388] "towards her arose from something more than merely malice against"            
##  [8389] "herself; and might be brought, by time and address, to do every thing"       
##  [8390] "that Lucy wished.  Her flattery had already subdued the pride of Lady"       
##  [8391] "Middleton, and made an entry into the close heart of Mrs. John"              
##  [8392] "Dashwood; and these were effects that laid open the probability of"          
##  [8393] "greater."                                                                    
##  [8394] ""                                                                            
##  [8395] "The Miss Steeles removed to Harley Street, and all that reached Elinor"      
##  [8396] "of their influence there, strengthened her expectation of the event."        
##  [8397] "Sir John, who called on them more than once, brought home such accounts"     
##  [8398] "of the favour they were in, as must be universally striking.  Mrs."          
##  [8399] "Dashwood had never been so much pleased with any young women in her"         
##  [8400] "life, as she was with them; had given each of them a needle book made"       
##  [8401] "by some emigrant; called Lucy by her Christian name; and did not know"       
##  [8402] "whether she should ever be able to part with them."                          
##  [8403] ""                                                                            
##  [8404] ""                                                                            
##  [8405] ""                                                                            
##  [8406] ""                                                                            
##  [8407] ""                                                                            
##  [8408] "[At this point in the first and second editions, Volume II ended.]"          
##  [8409] ""                                                                            
##  [8410] ""                                                                            
##  [8411] ""                                                                            
##  [8412] ""                                                                            
##  [8413] "CHAPTER 37"                                                                  
##  [8414] ""                                                                            
##  [8415] ""                                                                            
##  [8416] "Mrs. Palmer was so well at the end of a fortnight, that her mother felt"     
##  [8417] "it no longer necessary to give up the whole of her time to her; and,"        
##  [8418] "contenting herself with visiting her once or twice a day, returned from"     
##  [8419] "that period to her own home, and her own habits, in which she found the"     
##  [8420] "Miss Dashwoods very ready to resume their former share."                     
##  [8421] ""                                                                            
##  [8422] "About the third or fourth morning after their being thus resettled in"       
##  [8423] "Berkeley Street, Mrs. Jennings, on returning from her ordinary visit to"     
##  [8424] "Mrs. Palmer, entered the drawing-room, where Elinor was sitting by"          
##  [8425] "herself, with an air of such hurrying importance as prepared her to"         
##  [8426] "hear something wonderful; and giving her time only to form that idea,"       
##  [8427] "began directly to justify it, by saying,"                                    
##  [8428] ""                                                                            
##  [8429] "\"Lord! my dear Miss Dashwood! have you heard the news?\""                   
##  [8430] ""                                                                            
##  [8431] "\"No, ma'am.  What is it?\""                                                 
##  [8432] ""                                                                            
##  [8433] "\"Something so strange!  But you shall hear it all.-- When I got to Mr."     
##  [8434] "Palmer's, I found Charlotte quite in a fuss about the child.  She was"       
##  [8435] "sure it was very ill--it cried, and fretted, and was all over pimples."      
##  [8436] "So I looked at it directly, and, 'Lord! my dear,' says I, 'it is"            
##  [8437] "nothing in the world, but the red gum--' and nurse said just the same."      
##  [8438] "But Charlotte, she would not be satisfied, so Mr. Donavan was sent for;"     
##  [8439] "and luckily he happened to just come in from Harley Street, so he"           
##  [8440] "stepped over directly, and as soon as ever Mama, he said"                    
##  [8441] "just as we did, that it was nothing in the world but the red gum, and"       
##  [8442] "then Charlotte was easy.  And so, just as he was going away again, it"       
##  [8443] "came into my head, I am sure I do not know how I happened to think of"       
##  [8444] "it, but it came into my head to ask him if there was any news.  So upon"     
##  [8445] "that, he smirked, and simpered, and looked grave, and seemed to know"        
##  [8446] "something or other, and at last he said in a whisper, 'For fear any"         
##  [8447] "unpleasant report should reach the young ladies under your care as to"       
##  [8448] "their sister's indisposition, I think it advisable to say, that I"           
##  [8449] "believe there is no great reason for alarm; I hope Mrs. Dashwood will"       
##  [8450] "do very well.'\""                                                            
##  [8451] ""                                                                            
##  [8452] "\"What! is Fanny ill?\""                                                     
##  [8453] ""                                                                            
##  [8454] "\"That is exactly what I said, my dear.  'Lord!' says I, 'is Mrs."           
##  [8455] "Dashwood ill?' So then it all came out; and the long and the short of"       
##  [8456] "the matter, by all I can learn, seems to be this.  Mr. Edward Ferrars,"      
##  [8457] "the very young man I used to joke with you about (but however, as it"        
##  [8458] "turns out, I am monstrous glad there was never any thing in it), Mr."        
##  [8459] "Edward Ferrars, it seems, has been engaged above this twelvemonth to my"     
##  [8460] "cousin Lucy!--There's for you, my dear!--And not a creature knowing a"       
##  [8461] "syllable of the matter, except Nancy!--Could you have believed such a"       
##  [8462] "thing possible?-- There is no great wonder in their liking one another;"     
##  [8463] "but that matters should be brought so forward between them, and nobody"      
##  [8464] "suspect it!--THAT is strange!--I never happened to see them together,"       
##  [8465] "or I am sure I should have found it out directly.  Well, and so this"        
##  [8466] "was kept a great secret, for fear of Mrs. Ferrars, and neither she nor"      
##  [8467] "your brother or sister suspected a word of the matter;--till this very"      
##  [8468] "morning, poor Nancy, who, you know, is a well-meaning creature, but no"      
##  [8469] "conjurer, popt it all out.  'Lord!' thinks she to herself, 'they are"        
##  [8470] "all so fond of Lucy, to be sure they will make no difficulty about it;'"     
##  [8471] "and so, away she went to your sister, who was sitting all alone at her"      
##  [8472] "carpet-work, little suspecting what was to come--for she had just been"      
##  [8473] "saying to your brother, only five minutes before, that she thought to"       
##  [8474] "make a match between Edward and some Lord's daughter or other, I forget"     
##  [8475] "who.  So you may think what a blow it was to all her vanity and pride."      
##  [8476] "She fell into violent hysterics immediately, with such screams as"           
##  [8477] "reached your brother's ears, as he was sitting in his own dressing-room"     
##  [8478] "down stairs, thinking about writing a letter to his steward in the"          
##  [8479] "country.  So up he flew directly, and a terrible scene took place, for"      
##  [8480] "Lucy was come to them by that time, little dreaming what was going on."      
##  [8481] "Poor soul!  I pity HER.  And I must say, I think she was used very"          
##  [8482] "hardly; for your sister scolded like any fury, and soon drove her into"      
##  [8483] "a fainting fit.  Nancy, she fell upon her knees, and cried bitterly;"        
##  [8484] "and your brother, he walked about the room, and said he did not know"        
##  [8485] "what to do.  Mrs. Dashwood declared they should not stay a minute"           
##  [8486] "longer in the house, and your brother was forced to go down upon HIS"        
##  [8487] "knees too, to persuade her to let them stay till they had packed up"         
##  [8488] "their clothes.  THEN she fell into hysterics again, and he was so"           
##  [8489] "frightened that he would send for Mr. Donavan, and Mr. Donavan found"        
##  [8490] "the house in all this uproar.  The carriage was at the door ready to"        
##  [8491] "take my poor cousins away, and they were just stepping in as he came"        
##  [8492] "off; poor Lucy in such a condition, he says, she could hardly walk; and"     
##  [8493] "Nancy, she was almost as bad.  I declare, I have no patience with your"      
##  [8494] "sister; and I hope, with all my heart, it will be a match in spite of"       
##  [8495] "her.  Lord! what a taking poor Mr. Edward will be in when he hears of"       
##  [8496] "it!  To have his love used so scornfully! for they say he is monstrous"      
##  [8497] "fond of her, as well he may.  I should not wonder, if he was to be in"       
##  [8498] "the greatest passion!--and Mr. Donavan thinks just the same.  He and I"      
##  [8499] "had a great deal of talk about it; and the best of all is, that he is"       
##  [8500] "gone back again to Harley Street, that he may be within call when Mrs."      
##  [8501] "Ferrars is told of it, for she was sent for as soon as ever my cousins"      
##  [8502] "left the house, for your sister was sure SHE would be in hysterics too;"     
##  [8503] "and so she may, for what I care.  I have no pity for either of them.  I"     
##  [8504] "have no notion of people's making such a to-do about money and"              
##  [8505] "greatness.  There is no reason on earth why Mr. Edward and Lucy should"      
##  [8506] "not marry; for I am sure Mrs. Ferrars may afford to do very well by her"     
##  [8507] "son, and though Lucy has next to nothing herself, she knows better than"     
##  [8508] "any body how to make the most of every thing; I dare say, if Mrs."           
##  [8509] "Ferrars would only allow him five hundred a-year, she would make as"         
##  [8510] "good an appearance with it as any body else would with eight.  Lord!"        
##  [8511] "how snug they might live in such another cottage as yours--or a little"      
##  [8512] "bigger--with two maids, and two men; and I believe I could help them to"     
##  [8513] "a housemaid, for my Betty has a sister out of place, that would fit"         
##  [8514] "them exactly.\""                                                             
##  [8515] ""                                                                            
##  [8516] "Here Mrs. Jennings ceased, and as Elinor had had time enough to collect"     
##  [8517] "her thoughts, she was able to give such an answer, and make such"            
##  [8518] "observations, as the subject might naturally be supposed to produce."        
##  [8519] "Happy to find that she was not suspected of any extraordinary interest"      
##  [8520] "in it; that Mrs. Jennings (as she had of late often hoped might be the"      
##  [8521] "case) had ceased to imagine her at all attached to Edward; and happy"        
##  [8522] "above all the rest, in the absence of Marianne, she felt very well able"     
##  [8523] "to speak of the affair without embarrassment, and to give her judgment,"     
##  [8524] "as she believed, with impartiality on the conduct of every one"              
##  [8525] "concerned in it."                                                            
##  [8526] ""                                                                            
##  [8527] "She could hardly determine what her own expectation of its event really"     
##  [8528] "was; though she earnestly tried to drive away the notion of its being"       
##  [8529] "possible to end otherwise at last, than in the marriage of Edward and"       
##  [8530] "Lucy.  What Mrs. Ferrars would say and do, though there could not be a"      
##  [8531] "doubt of its nature, she was anxious to hear; and still more anxious to"     
##  [8532] "know how Edward would conduct himself.  For HIM she felt much"               
##  [8533] "compassion;--for Lucy very little--and it cost her some pains to"            
##  [8534] "procure that little;--for the rest of the party none at all."                
##  [8535] ""                                                                            
##  [8536] "As Mrs. Jennings could talk on no other subject, Elinor soon saw the"        
##  [8537] "necessity of preparing Marianne for its discussion.  No time was to be"      
##  [8538] "lost in undeceiving her, in making her acquainted with the real truth,"      
##  [8539] "and in endeavouring to bring her to hear it talked of by others,"            
##  [8540] "without betraying that she felt any uneasiness for her sister, or any"       
##  [8541] "resentment against Edward."                                                  
##  [8542] ""                                                                            
##  [8543] "Elinor's office was a painful one.--She was going to remove what she"        
##  [8544] "really believed to be her sister's chief consolation,--to give such"         
##  [8545] "particulars of Edward as she feared would ruin him for ever in her good"     
##  [8546] "opinion,-and to make Marianne, by a resemblance in their situations,"        
##  [8547] "which to HER fancy would seem strong, feel all her own disappointment"       
##  [8548] "over again.  But unwelcome as such a task must be, it was necessary to"      
##  [8549] "be done, and Elinor therefore hastened to perform it."                       
##  [8550] ""                                                                            
##  [8551] "She was very far from wishing to dwell on her own feelings, or to"           
##  [8552] "represent herself as suffering much, any otherwise than as the"              
##  [8553] "self-command she had practised since her first knowledge of Edward's"        
##  [8554] "engagement, might suggest a hint of what was practicable to Marianne."       
##  [8555] "Her narration was clear and simple; and though it could not be given"        
##  [8556] "without emotion, it was not accompanied by violent agitation, nor"           
##  [8557] "impetuous grief.--THAT belonged rather to the hearer, for Marianne"          
##  [8558] "listened with horror, and cried excessively.  Elinor was to be the"          
##  [8559] "comforter of others in her own distresses, no less than in theirs; and"      
##  [8560] "all the comfort that could be given by assurances of her own composure"      
##  [8561] "of mind, and a very earnest vindication of Edward from every charge but"     
##  [8562] "of imprudence, was readily offered."                                         
##  [8563] ""                                                                            
##  [8564] "But Marianne for some time would give credit to neither.  Edward seemed"     
##  [8565] "a second Willoughby; and acknowledging as Elinor did, that she HAD"          
##  [8566] "loved him most sincerely, could she feel less than herself!  As for"         
##  [8567] "Lucy Steele, she considered her so totally unamiable, so absolutely"         
##  [8568] "incapable of attaching a sensible man, that she could not be persuaded"      
##  [8569] "at first to believe, and afterwards to pardon, any former affection of"      
##  [8570] "Edward for her.  She would not even admit it to have been natural; and"      
##  [8571] "Elinor left her to be convinced that it was so, by that which only"          
##  [8572] "could convince her, a better knowledge of mankind."                          
##  [8573] ""                                                                            
##  [8574] "Her first communication had reached no farther than to state the fact"       
##  [8575] "of the engagement, and the length of time it had existed.--Marianne's"       
##  [8576] "feelings had then broken in, and put an end to all regularity of"            
##  [8577] "detail; and for some time all that could be done was to soothe her"          
##  [8578] "distress, lessen her alarms, and combat her resentment.  The first"
