##  [8579] "question on her side, which led to farther particulars, was,--"              
##  [8580] ""                                                                            
##  [8581] "\"How long has this been known to you, Elinor? has he written to you?\""     
##  [8582] ""                                                                            
##  [8583] "\"I have known it these four months.  When Lucy first came to Barton"        
##  [8584] "Park last November, she told me in confidence of her engagement.\""          
##  [8585] ""                                                                            
##  [8586] "At these words, Marianne's eyes expressed the astonishment which her"        
##  [8587] "lips could not utter.  After a pause of wonder, she exclaimed--"             
##  [8588] ""                                                                            
##  [8589] "\"Four months!--Have you known of this four months?\""                       
##  [8590] ""                                                                            
##  [8591] "Elinor confirmed it."                                                        
##  [8592] ""                                                                            
##  [8593] "\"What!--while attending me in all my misery, has this been on your"         
##  [8594] "heart?--And I have reproached you for being happy!\"--"                      
##  [8595] ""                                                                            
##  [8596] "\"It was not fit that you should then know how much I was the reverse!\""    
##  [8597] ""                                                                            
##  [8598] "\"Four months!\"--cried Marianne again.--\"So calm!--so cheerful!--how"      
##  [8599] "have you been supported?\"--"                                                
##  [8600] ""                                                                            
##  [8601] "\"By feeling that I was doing my duty.--My promise to Lucy, obliged me"      
##  [8602] "to be secret.  I owed it to her, therefore, to avoid giving any hint of"     
##  [8603] "the truth; and I owed it to my family and friends, not to create in"         
##  [8604] "them a solicitude about me, which it could not be in my power to"            
##  [8605] "satisfy.\""                                                                  
##  [8606] ""                                                                            
##  [8607] "Marianne seemed much struck."                                                
##  [8608] ""                                                                            
##  [8609] "\"I have very often wished to undeceive yourself and my mother,\" added"     
##  [8610] "Elinor; \"and once or twice I have attempted it;--but without betraying"     
##  [8611] "my trust, I never could have convinced you.\""                               
##  [8612] ""                                                                            
##  [8613] "\"Four months!--and yet you loved him!\"--"                                  
##  [8614] ""                                                                            
##  [8615] "\"Yes. But I did not love only him;--and while the comfort of others was"    
##  [8616] "dear to me, I was glad to spare them from knowing how much I felt."          
##  [8617] "Now, I can think and speak of it with little emotion.  I would not have"     
##  [8618] "you suffer on my account; for I assure you I no longer suffer"               
##  [8619] "materially myself.  I have many things to support me.  I am not"             
##  [8620] "conscious of having provoked the disappointment by any imprudence of my"     
##  [8621] "own, I have borne it as much as possible without spreading it farther."      
##  [8622] "I acquit Edward of essential misconduct.  I wish him very happy; and I"      
##  [8623] "am so sure of his always doing his duty, that though now he may harbour"     
##  [8624] "some regret, in the end he must become so.  Lucy does not want sense,"       
##  [8625] "and that is the foundation on which every thing good may be built.--And"     
##  [8626] "after all, Marianne, after all that is bewitching in the idea of a"          
##  [8627] "single and constant attachment, and all that can be said of one's"           
##  [8628] "happiness depending entirely on any particular person, it is not"            
##  [8629] "meant--it is not fit--it is not possible that it should be so.-- Edward"     
##  [8630] "will marry Lucy; he will marry a woman superior in person and"               
##  [8631] "understanding to half her sex; and time and habit will teach him to"         
##  [8632] "forget that he ever thought another superior to HER.\"--"                    
##  [8633] ""                                                                            
##  [8634] "\"If such is your way of thinking,\" said Marianne, \"if the loss of what"   
##  [8635] "is most valued is so easily to be made up by something else, your"           
##  [8636] "resolution, your self-command, are, perhaps, a little less to be"            
##  [8637] "wondered at.--They are brought more within my comprehension.\""              
##  [8638] ""                                                                            
##  [8639] "\"I understand you.--You do not suppose that I have ever felt much.--For"    
##  [8640] "four months, Marianne, I have had all this hanging on my mind, without"      
##  [8641] "being at liberty to speak of it to a single creature; knowing that it"       
##  [8642] "would make you and my mother most unhappy whenever it were explained to"     
##  [8643] "you, yet unable to prepare you for it in the least.-- It was told"           
##  [8644] "me,--it was in a manner forced on me by the very person herself, whose"      
##  [8645] "prior engagement ruined all my prospects; and told me, as I thought,"        
##  [8646] "with triumph.-- This person's suspicions, therefore, I have had to"          
##  [8647] "oppose, by endeavouring to appear indifferent where I have been most"        
##  [8648] "deeply interested;--and it has not been only once;--I have had her"          
##  [8649] "hopes and exultation to listen to again and again.-- I have known"           
##  [8650] "myself to be divided from Edward for ever, without hearing one"              
##  [8651] "circumstance that could make me less desire the connection.--Nothing"        
##  [8652] "has proved him unworthy; nor has anything declared him indifferent to"       
##  [8653] "me.-- I have had to contend against the unkindness of his sister, and"       
##  [8654] "the insolence of his mother; and have suffered the punishment of an"         
##  [8655] "attachment, without enjoying its advantages.-- And all this has been"        
##  [8656] "going on at a time, when, as you know too well, it has not been my only"     
##  [8657] "unhappiness.-- If you can think me capable of ever feeling--surely you"      
##  [8658] "may suppose that I have suffered NOW.  The composure of mind with which"     
##  [8659] "I have brought myself at present to consider the matter, the"                
##  [8660] "consolation that I have been willing to admit, have been the effect of"      
##  [8661] "constant and painful exertion;--they did not spring up of"                   
##  [8662] "themselves;--they did not occur to relieve my spirits at first.-- No,"       
##  [8663] "Marianne.--THEN, if I had not been bound to silence, perhaps nothing"        
##  [8664] "could have kept me entirely--not even what I owed to my dearest"             
##  [8665] "friends--from openly shewing that I was VERY unhappy.\"--"                   
##  [8666] ""                                                                            
##  [8667] "Marianne was quite subdued.--"                                               
##  [8668] ""                                                                            
##  [8669] "\"Oh! Elinor,\" she cried, \"you have made me hate myself for ever.--How"    
##  [8670] "barbarous have I been to you!--you, who have been my only comfort, who"      
##  [8671] "have borne with me in all my misery, who have seemed to be only"             
##  [8672] "suffering for me!--Is this my gratitude?--Is this the only return I can"     
##  [8673] "make you?--Because your merit cries out upon myself, I have been trying"     
##  [8674] "to do it away.\""                                                            
##  [8675] ""                                                                            
##  [8676] "The tenderest caresses followed this confession.  In such a frame of"        
##  [8677] "mind as she was now in, Elinor had no difficulty in obtaining from her"      
##  [8678] "whatever promise she required; and at her request, Marianne engaged"         
##  [8679] "never to speak of the affair to any one with the least appearance of"        
##  [8680] "bitterness;--to meet Lucy without betraying the smallest increase of"        
##  [8681] "dislike to her;--and even to see Edward himself, if chance should bring"     
##  [8682] "them together, without any diminution of her usual cordiality.-- These"      
##  [8683] "were great concessions;--but where Marianne felt that she had injured,"      
##  [8684] "no reparation could be too much for her to make."                            
##  [8685] ""                                                                            
##  [8686] "She performed her promise of being discreet, to admiration.--She"            
##  [8687] "attended to all that Mrs. Jennings had to say upon the subject, with an"     
##  [8688] "unchanging complexion, dissented from her in nothing, and was heard"         
##  [8689] "three times to say, \"Yes, ma'am.\"--She listened to her praise of Lucy"     
##  [8690] "with only moving from one chair to another, and when Mrs. Jennings"          
##  [8691] "talked of Edward's affection, it cost her only a spasm in her"               
##  [8692] "throat.--Such advances towards heroism in her sister, made Elinor feel"      
##  [8693] "equal to any thing herself."                                                 
##  [8694] ""                                                                            
##  [8695] "The next morning brought a farther trial of it, in a visit from their"       
##  [8696] "brother, who came with a most serious aspect to talk over the dreadful"      
##  [8697] "affair, and bring them news of his wife."                                    
##  [8698] ""                                                                            
##  [8699] "\"You have heard, I suppose,\" said he with great solemnity, as soon as"     
##  [8700] "he was seated, \"of the very shocking discovery that took place under"       
##  [8701] "our roof yesterday.\""                                                       
##  [8702] ""                                                                            
##  [8703] "They all looked their assent; it seemed too awful a moment for speech."      
##  [8704] ""                                                                            
##  [8705] "\"Your sister,\" he continued, \"has suffered dreadfully.  Mrs. Ferrars"     
##  [8706] "too--in short it has been a scene of such complicated distress--but I"       
##  [8707] "will hope that the storm may be weathered without our being any of us"       
##  [8708] "quite overcome.  Poor Fanny! she was in hysterics all yesterday.  But I"     
##  [8709] "would not alarm you too much.  Donavan says there is nothing materially"     
##  [8710] "to be apprehended; her constitution is a good one, and her resolution"       
##  [8711] "equal to any thing.  She has borne it all, with the fortitude of an"         
##  [8712] "angel!  She says she never shall think well of anybody again; and one"       
##  [8713] "cannot wonder at it, after being so deceived!--meeting with such"            
##  [8714] "ingratitude, where so much kindness had been shewn, so much confidence"      
##  [8715] "had been placed!  It was quite out of the benevolence of her heart,"         
##  [8716] "that she had asked these young women to her house; merely because she"       
##  [8717] "thought they deserved some attention, were harmless, well-behaved"           
##  [8718] "girls, and would be pleasant companions; for otherwise we both wished"       
##  [8719] "very much to have invited you and Marianne to be with us, while your"        
##  [8720] "kind friend there, was attending her daughter.  And now to be so"            
##  [8721] "rewarded!  'I wish, with all my heart,' says poor Fanny in her"              
##  [8722] "affectionate way, 'that we had asked your sisters instead of them.'\""       
##  [8723] ""                                                                            
##  [8724] "Here he stopped to be thanked; which being done, he went on."                
##  [8725] ""                                                                            
##  [8726] "\"What poor Mrs. Ferrars suffered, when first Fanny broke it to her, is"     
##  [8727] "not to be described.  While she with the truest affection had been"          
##  [8728] "planning a most eligible connection for him, was it to be supposed that"     
##  [8729] "he could be all the time secretly engaged to another person!--such a"        
##  [8730] "suspicion could never have entered her head!  If she suspected ANY"          
##  [8731] "prepossession elsewhere, it could not be in THAT quarter.  'THERE, to"       
##  [8732] "be sure,' said she, 'I might have thought myself safe.' She was quite"       
##  [8733] "in an agony.  We consulted together, however, as to what should be"          
##  [8734] "done, and at last she determined to send for Edward.  He came.  But I"       
##  [8735] "am sorry to relate what ensued.  All that Mrs. Ferrars could say to"         
##  [8736] "make him put an end to the engagement, assisted too as you may well"         
##  [8737] "suppose by my arguments, and Fanny's entreaties, was of no avail."           
##  [8738] "Duty, affection, every thing was disregarded.  I never thought Edward"       
##  [8739] "so stubborn, so unfeeling before.  His mother explained to him her"          
##  [8740] "liberal designs, in case of his marrying Miss Morton; told him she"          
##  [8741] "would settle on him the Norfolk estate, which, clear of land-tax,"           
##  [8742] "brings in a good thousand a-year; offered even, when matters grew"           
##  [8743] "desperate, to make it twelve hundred; and in opposition to this, if he"      
##  [8744] "still persisted in this low connection, represented to him the certain"      
##  [8745] "penury that must attend the match.  His own two thousand pounds she"         
##  [8746] "protested should be his all; she would never see him again; and so far"      
##  [8747] "would she be from affording him the smallest assistance, that if he"         
##  [8748] "were to enter into any profession with a view of better support, she"        
##  [8749] "would do all in her power to prevent him advancing in it.\""                 
##  [8750] ""                                                                            
##  [8751] "Here Marianne, in an ecstasy of indignation, clapped her hands"              
##  [8752] "together, and cried, \"Gracious God!  can this be possible!\""               
##  [8753] ""                                                                            
##  [8754] "\"Well may you wonder, Marianne,\" replied her brother, \"at the obstinacy"  
##  [8755] "which could resist such arguments as these.  Your exclamation is very"       
##  [8756] "natural.\""                                                                  
##  [8757] ""                                                                            
##  [8758] "Marianne was going to retort, but she remembered her promises, and"          
##  [8759] "forbore."                                                                    
##  [8760] ""                                                                            
##  [8761] "\"All this, however,\" he continued, \"was urged in vain.  Edward said"      
##  [8762] "very little; but what he did say, was in the most determined manner."        
##  [8763] "Nothing should prevail on him to give up his engagement.  He would"          
##  [8764] "stand to it, cost him what it might.\""                                      
##  [8765] ""                                                                            
##  [8766] "\"Then,\" cried Mrs. Jennings with blunt sincerity, no longer able to be"    
##  [8767] "silent, \"he has acted like an honest man! I beg your pardon, Mr."           
##  [8768] "Dashwood, but if he had done otherwise, I should have thought him a"         
##  [8769] "rascal.  I have some little concern in the business, as well as"             
##  [8770] "yourself, for Lucy Steele is my cousin, and I believe there is not a"        
##  [8771] "better kind of girl in the world, nor one who more deserves a good"          
##  [8772] "husband.\""                                                                  
##  [8773] ""                                                                            
##  [8774] "John Dashwood was greatly astonished; but his nature was calm, not open"     
##  [8775] "to provocation, and he never wished to offend anybody, especially"           
##  [8776] "anybody of good fortune.  He therefore replied, without any resentment,"     
##  [8777] ""                                                                            
##  [8778] "\"I would by no means speak disrespectfully of any relation of yours,"       
##  [8779] "madam.  Miss Lucy Steele is, I dare say, a very deserving young woman,"      
##  [8780] "but in the present case you know, the connection must be impossible."        
##  [8781] "And to have entered into a secret engagement with a young man under her"     
##  [8782] "uncle's care, the son of a woman especially of such very large fortune"      
##  [8783] "as Mrs. Ferrars, is perhaps, altogether a little extraordinary. In"          
##  [8784] "short, I do not mean to reflect upon the behaviour of any person whom"       
##  [8785] "you have a regard for, Mrs. Jennings.  We all wish her extremely happy;"     
##  [8786] "and Mrs. Ferrars's conduct throughout the whole, has been such as every"     
##  [8787] "conscientious, good mother, in like circumstances, would adopt.  It has"     
##  [8788] "been dignified and liberal.  Edward has drawn his own lot, and I fear"       
##  [8789] "it will be a bad one.\""                                                     
##  [8790] ""                                                                            
##  [8791] "Marianne sighed out her similar apprehension; and Elinor's heart wrung"      
##  [8792] "for the feelings of Edward, while braving his mother's threats, for a"       
##  [8793] "woman who could not reward him."                                             
##  [8794] ""                                                                            
##  [8795] "\"Well, sir,\" said Mrs. Jennings, \"and how did it end?\""                  
##  [8796] ""                                                                            
##  [8797] "\"I am sorry to say, ma'am, in a most unhappy rupture:-- Edward is"          
##  [8798] "dismissed for ever from his mother's notice.  He left her house"             
##  [8799] "yesterday, but where he is gone, or whether he is still in town, I do"       
##  [8800] "not know; for WE of course can make no inquiry.\""                           
##  [8801] ""                                                                            
##  [8802] "\"Poor young man!--and what is to become of him?\""                          
##  [8803] ""                                                                            
##  [8804] "\"What, indeed, ma'am!  It is a melancholy consideration.  Born to the"      
##  [8805] "prospect of such affluence!  I cannot conceive a situation more"             
##  [8806] "deplorable.  The interest of two thousand pounds--how can a man live on"     
##  [8807] "it?--and when to that is added the recollection, that he might, but for"     
##  [8808] "his own folly, within three months have been in the receipt of two"          
##  [8809] "thousand, five hundred a-year (for Miss Morton has thirty thousand"          
##  [8810] "pounds,) I cannot picture to myself a more wretched condition.  We must"     
##  [8811] "all feel for him; and the more so, because it is totally out of our"         
##  [8812] "power to assist him.\""                                                      
##  [8813] ""                                                                            
##  [8814] "\"Poor young man!\" cried Mrs. Jennings, \"I am sure he should be very"      
##  [8815] "welcome to bed and board at my house; and so I would tell him if I"          
##  [8816] "could see him.  It is not fit that he should be living about at his own"     
##  [8817] "charge now, at lodgings and taverns.\""                                      
##  [8818] ""                                                                            
##  [8819] "Elinor's heart thanked her for such kindness towards Edward, though she"     
##  [8820] "could not forbear smiling at the form of it."                                
##  [8821] ""                                                                            
##  [8822] "\"If he would only have done as well by himself,\" said John Dashwood,"      
##  [8823] "\"as all his friends were disposed to do by him, he might now have been"     
##  [8824] "in his proper situation, and would have wanted for nothing.  But as it"      
##  [8825] "is, it must be out of anybody's power to assist him.  And there is one"      
##  [8826] "thing more preparing against him, which must be worse than all--his"         
##  [8827] "mother has determined, with a very natural kind of spirit, to settle"        
##  [8828] "THAT estate upon Robert immediately, which might have been Edward's, on"     
##  [8829] "proper conditions.  I left her this morning with her lawyer, talking"        
##  [8830] "over the business.\""                                                        
##  [8831] ""                                                                            
##  [8832] "\"Well!\" said Mrs. Jennings, \"that is HER revenge.  Everybody has a way"   
##  [8833] "of their own.  But I don't think mine would be, to make one son"             
##  [8834] "independent, because another had plagued me.\""                              
##  [8835] ""                                                                            
##  [8836] "Marianne got up and walked about the room."                                  
##  [8837] ""                                                                            
##  [8838] "\"Can anything be more galling to the spirit of a man,\" continued John,"    
##  [8839] "\"than to see his younger brother in possession of an estate which might"    
##  [8840] "have been his own?  Poor Edward!  I feel for him sincerely.\""               
##  [8841] ""                                                                            
##  [8842] "A few minutes more spent in the same kind of effusion, concluded his"        
##  [8843] "visit; and with repeated assurances to his sisters that he really"           
##  [8844] "believed there was no material danger in Fanny's indisposition, and"         
##  [8845] "that they need not therefore be very uneasy about it, he went away;"         
##  [8846] "leaving the three ladies unanimous in their sentiments on the present"       
##  [8847] "occasion, as far at least as it regarded Mrs. Ferrars's conduct, the"        
##  [8848] "Dashwoods', and Edward's."                                                   
##  [8849] ""                                                                            
##  [8850] "Marianne's indignation burst forth as soon as he quitted the room; and"      
##  [8851] "as her vehemence made reserve impossible in Elinor, and unnecessary in"      
##  [8852] "Mrs. Jennings, they all joined in a very spirited critique upon the"         
##  [8853] "party."                                                                      
##  [8854] ""                                                                            
##  [8855] ""                                                                            
##  [8856] ""                                                                            
##  [8857] "CHAPTER 38"                                                                  
##  [8858] ""                                                                            
##  [8859] ""                                                                            
##  [8860] "Mrs. Jennings was very warm in her praise of Edward's conduct, but only"     
##  [8861] "Elinor and Marianne understood its true merit.  THEY only knew how"          
##  [8862] "little he had had to tempt him to be disobedient, and how small was the"     
##  [8863] "consolation, beyond the consciousness of doing right, that could remain"     
##  [8864] "to him in the loss of friends and fortune.  Elinor gloried in his"           
##  [8865] "integrity; and Marianne forgave all his offences in compassion for his"      
##  [8866] "punishment.  But though confidence between them was, by this public"         
##  [8867] "discovery, restored to its proper state, it was not a subject on which"      
##  [8868] "either of them were fond of dwelling when alone.  Elinor avoided it"         
##  [8869] "upon principle, as tending to fix still more upon her thoughts, by the"      
##  [8870] "too warm, too positive assurances of Marianne, that belief of Edward's"      
##  [8871] "continued affection for herself which she rather wished to do away; and"     
##  [8872] "Marianne's courage soon failed her, in trying to converse upon a topic"      
##  [8873] "which always left her more dissatisfied with herself than ever, by the"      
##  [8874] "comparison it necessarily produced between Elinor's conduct and her own."    
##  [8875] ""                                                                            
##  [8876] "She felt all the force of that comparison; but not as her sister had"        
##  [8877] "hoped, to urge her to exertion now; she felt it with all the pain of"        
##  [8878] "continual self-reproach, regretted most bitterly that she had never"         
##  [8879] "exerted herself before; but it brought only the torture of penitence,"       
##  [8880] "without the hope of amendment.  Her mind was so much weakened that she"      
##  [8881] "still fancied present exertion impossible, and therefore it only"            
##  [8882] "dispirited her more."                                                        
##  [8883] ""                                                                            
##  [8884] "Nothing new was heard by them, for a day or two afterwards, of affairs"      
##  [8885] "in Harley Street, or Bartlett's Buildings.  But though so much of the"       
##  [8886] "matter was known to them already, that Mrs. Jennings might have had"         
##  [8887] "enough to do in spreading that knowledge farther, without seeking after"     
##  [8888] "more, she had resolved from the first to pay a visit of comfort and"         
##  [8889] "inquiry to her cousins as soon as she could; and nothing but the"            
##  [8890] "hindrance of more visitors than usual, had prevented her going to them"      
##  [8891] "within that time."                                                           
##  [8892] ""                                                                            
##  [8893] "The third day succeeding their knowledge of the particulars, was so"         
##  [8894] "fine, so beautiful a Sunday as to draw many to Kensington Gardens,"          
##  [8895] "though it was only the second week in March.  Mrs. Jennings and Elinor"      
##  [8896] "were of the number; but Marianne, who knew that the Willoughbys were"        
##  [8897] "again in town, and had a constant dread of meeting them, chose rather"       
##  [8898] "to stay at home, than venture into so public a place."                       
##  [8899] ""                                                                            
##  [8900] "An intimate acquaintance of Mrs. Jennings joined them soon after they"       
##  [8901] "entered the Gardens, and Elinor was not sorry that by her continuing"        
##  [8902] "with them, and engaging all Mrs. Jennings's conversation, she was"           
##  [8903] "herself left to quiet reflection.  She saw nothing of the Willoughbys,"      
##  [8904] "nothing of Edward, and for some time nothing of anybody who could by"        
##  [8905] "any chance whether grave or gay, be interesting to her.  But at last"        
##  [8906] "she found herself with some surprise, accosted by Miss Steele, who,"         
##  [8907] "though looking rather shy, expressed great satisfaction in meeting"          
##  [8908] "them, and on receiving encouragement from the particular kindness of"        
##  [8909] "Mrs. Jennings, left her own party for a short time, to join their's."        
##  [8910] "Mrs. Jennings immediately whispered to Elinor,"                              
##  [8911] ""                                                                            
##  [8912] "\"Get it all out of her, my dear.  She will tell you any thing if you"       
##  [8913] "ask.  You see I cannot leave Mrs. Clarke.\""                                 
##  [8914] ""                                                                            
##  [8915] "It was lucky, however, for Mrs. Jennings's curiosity and Elinor's too,"      
##  [8916] "that she would tell any thing WITHOUT being asked; for nothing would"        
##  [8917] "otherwise have been learnt."                                                 
##  [8918] ""                                                                            
##  [8919] "\"I am so glad to meet you;\" said Miss Steele, taking her familiarly by"    
##  [8920] "the arm--\"for I wanted to see you of all things in the world.\"  And"       
##  [8921] "then lowering her voice, \"I suppose Mrs. Jennings has heard all about"      
##  [8922] "it.  Is she angry?\""                                                        
##  [8923] ""                                                                            
##  [8924] "\"Not at all, I believe, with you.\""                                        
##  [8925] ""                                                                            
##  [8926] "\"That is a good thing.  And Lady Middleton, is SHE angry?\""                
##  [8927] ""                                                                            
##  [8928] "\"I cannot suppose it possible that she should be.\""                        
##  [8929] ""                                                                            
##  [8930] "\"I am monstrous glad of it.  Good gracious!  I have had such a time of"     
##  [8931] "it!  I never saw Lucy in such a rage in my life.  She vowed at first"        
##  [8932] "she would never trim me up a new bonnet, nor do any thing else for me"       
##  [8933] "again, so long as she lived; but now she is quite come to, and we are"       
##  [8934] "as good friends as ever.  Look, she made me this bow to my hat, and put"     
##  [8935] "in the feather last night.  There now, YOU are going to laugh at me"         
##  [8936] "too.  But why should not I wear pink ribbons?  I do not care if it IS"       
##  [8937] "the Doctor's favourite colour.  I am sure, for my part, I should never"      
##  [8938] "have known he DID like it better than any other colour, if he had not"       
##  [8939] "happened to say so.  My cousins have been so plaguing me!  I declare"        
##  [8940] "sometimes I do not know which way to look before them.\""                    
##  [8941] ""                                                                            
##  [8942] "She had wandered away to a subject on which Elinor had nothing to say,"      
##  [8943] "and therefore soon judged it expedient to find her way back again to"        
##  [8944] "the first."                                                                  
##  [8945] ""                                                                            
##  [8946] "\"Well, but Miss Dashwood,\" speaking triumphantly, \"people may say what"   
##  [8947] "they chuse about Mr. Ferrars's declaring he would not have Lucy, for it"     
##  [8948] "is no such thing I can tell you; and it is quite a shame for such"           
##  [8949] "ill-natured reports to be spread abroad.  Whatever Lucy might think"         
##  [8950] "about it herself, you know, it was no business of other people to set"       
##  [8951] "it down for certain.\""                                                      
##  [8952] ""                                                                            
##  [8953] "\"I never heard any thing of the kind hinted at before, I assure you,\""     
##  [8954] "said Elinor."                                                                
##  [8955] ""                                                                            
##  [8956] "\"Oh, did not you?  But it WAS said, I know, very well, and by more than"    
##  [8957] "one; for Miss Godby told Miss Sparks, that nobody in their senses could"     
##  [8958] "expect Mr. Ferrars to give up a woman like Miss Morton, with thirty"         
##  [8959] "thousand pounds to her fortune, for Lucy Steele that had nothing at"         
##  [8960] "all; and I had it from Miss Sparks myself.  And besides that, my cousin"     
##  [8961] "Richard said himself, that when it came to the point he was afraid Mr."      
##  [8962] "Ferrars would be off; and when Edward did not come near us for three"        
##  [8963] "days, I could not tell what to think myself; and I believe in my heart"      
##  [8964] "Lucy gave it up all for lost; for we came away from your brother's"          
##  [8965] "Wednesday, and we saw nothing of him not all Thursday, Friday, and"          
##  [8966] "Saturday, and did not know what was become of him.  Once Lucy thought"       
##  [8967] "to write to him, but then her spirits rose against that.  However this"      
##  [8968] "morning he came just as we came home from church; and then it all came"      
##  [8969] "out, how he had been sent for Wednesday to Harley Street, and been"          
##  [8970] "talked to by his mother and all of them, and how he had declared before"     
##  [8971] "them all that he loved nobody but Lucy, and nobody but Lucy would he"        
##  [8972] "have.  And how he had been so worried by what passed, that as soon as"       
##  [8973] "he had went away from his mother's house, he had got upon his horse,"        
##  [8974] "and rid into the country, some where or other; and how he had stayed"        
##  [8975] "about at an inn all Thursday and Friday, on purpose to get the better"       
##  [8976] "of it.  And after thinking it all over and over again, he said, it"          
##  [8977] "seemed to him as if, now he had no fortune, and no nothing at all, it"       
##  [8978] "would be quite unkind to keep her on to the engagement, because it must"     
##  [8979] "be for her loss, for he had nothing but two thousand pounds, and no"         
##  [8980] "hope of any thing else; and if he was to go into orders, as he had some"     
##  [8981] "thoughts, he could get nothing but a curacy, and how was they to live"       
##  [8982] "upon that?--He could not bear to think of her doing no better, and so"       
##  [8983] "he begged, if she had the least mind for it, to put an end to the"           
##  [8984] "matter directly, and leave him shift for himself.  I heard him say all"      
##  [8985] "this as plain as could possibly be.  And it was entirely for HER sake,"      
##  [8986] "and upon HER account, that he said a word about being off, and not upon"     
##  [8987] "his own.  I will take my oath he never dropt a syllable of being tired"      
##  [8988] "of her, or of wishing to marry Miss Morton, or any thing like it.  But,"     
##  [8989] "to be sure, Lucy would not give ear to such kind of talking; so she"         
##  [8990] "told him directly (with a great deal about sweet and love, you know,"        
##  [8991] "and all that--Oh, la! one can't repeat such kind of things you"              
##  [8992] "know)--she told him directly, she had not the least mind in the world"       
##  [8993] "to be off, for she could live with him upon a trifle, and how little so"     
##  [8994] "ever he might have, she should be very glad to have it all, you know,"       
##  [8995] "or something of the kind.  So then he was monstrous happy, and talked"       
##  [8996] "on some time about what they should do, and they agreed he should take"      
##  [8997] "orders directly, and they must wait to be married till he got a living."     
##  [8998] "And just then I could not hear any more, for my cousin called from"          
##  [8999] "below to tell me Mrs. Richardson was come in her coach, and would take"      
##  [9000] "one of us to Kensington Gardens; so I was forced to go into the room"        
##  [9001] "and interrupt them, to ask Lucy if she would like to go, but she did"        
##  [9002] "not care to leave Edward; so I just run up stairs and put on a pair of"      
##  [9003] "silk stockings and came off with the Richardsons.\""                         
##  [9004] ""                                                                            
##  [9005] "\"I do not understand what you mean by interrupting them,\" said Elinor;"    
##  [9006] "\"you were all in the same room together, were not you?\""                   
##  [9007] ""                                                                            
##  [9008] "\"No, indeed, not us.  La! Miss Dashwood, do you think people make love"     
##  [9009] "when any body else is by?  Oh, for shame!--To be sure you must know"         
##  [9010] "better than that.  (Laughing affectedly.)--No, no; they were shut up in"     
##  [9011] "the drawing-room together, and all I heard was only by listening at the"     
##  [9012] "door.\""                                                                     
##  [9013] ""                                                                            
##  [9014] "\"How!\" cried Elinor; \"have you been repeating to me what you only"        
##  [9015] "learnt yourself by listening at the door?  I am sorry I did not know it"     
##  [9016] "before; for I certainly would not have suffered you to give me"              
##  [9017] "particulars of a conversation which you ought not to have known"             
##  [9018] "yourself.  How could you behave so unfairly by your sister?\""               
##  [9019] ""                                                                            
##  [9020] "\"Oh, la! there is nothing in THAT.  I only stood at the door, and heard"    
##  [9021] "what I could.  And I am sure Lucy would have done just the same by me;"      
##  [9022] "for a year or two back, when Martha Sharpe and I had so many secrets"        
##  [9023] "together, she never made any bones of hiding in a closet, or behind a"       
##  [9024] "chimney-board, on purpose to hear what we said.\""                           
##  [9025] ""                                                                            
##  [9026] "Elinor tried to talk of something else; but Miss Steele could not be"        
##  [9027] "kept beyond a couple of minutes, from what was uppermost in her mind."       
##  [9028] ""                                                                            
##  [9029] "\"Edward talks of going to Oxford soon,\" said she; \"but now he is"         
##  [9030] "lodging at No. --, Pall Mall.  What an ill-natured woman his mother is,"     
##  [9031] "an't she? And your brother and sister were not very kind! However, I"        
##  [9032] "shan't say anything against them to YOU; and to be sure they did send"       
##  [9033] "us home in their own chariot, which was more than I looked for.  And"        
##  [9034] "for my part, I was all in a fright for fear your sister should ask us"       
##  [9035] "for the huswifes she had gave us a day or two before; but, however,"         
##  [9036] "nothing was said about them, and I took care to keep mine out of sight."     
##  [9037] "Edward have got some business at Oxford, he says; so he must go there"       
##  [9038] "for a time; and after THAT, as soon as he can light upon a Bishop, he"       
##  [9039] "will be ordained.  I wonder what curacy he will get!--Good gracious!"        
##  [9040] "(giggling as she spoke) I'd lay my life I know what my cousins will"         
##  [9041] "say, when they hear of it.  They will tell me I should write to the"         
##  [9042] "Doctor, to get Edward the curacy of his new living.  I know they will;"      
##  [9043] "but I am sure I would not do such a thing for all the world.-- 'La!' I"      
##  [9044] "shall say directly, 'I wonder how you could think of such a thing?  I"       
##  [9045] "write to the Doctor, indeed!'\""                                             
##  [9046] ""                                                                            
##  [9047] "\"Well,\" said Elinor, \"it is a comfort to be prepared against the worst."  
##  [9048] "You have got your answer ready.\""                                           
##  [9049] ""                                                                            
##  [9050] "Miss Steele was going to reply on the same subject, but the approach of"     
##  [9051] "her own party made another more necessary."                                  
##  [9052] ""                                                                            
##  [9053] "\"Oh, la! here come the Richardsons.  I had a vast deal more to say to"      
##  [9054] "you, but I must not stay away from them not any longer.  I assure you"       
##  [9055] "they are very genteel people.  He makes a monstrous deal of money, and"      
##  [9056] "they keep their own coach.  I have not time to speak to Mrs. Jennings"       
##  [9057] "about it myself, but pray tell her I am quite happy to hear she is not"      
##  [9058] "in anger against us, and Lady Middleton the same; and if anything"           
##  [9059] "should happen to take you and your sister away, and Mrs. Jennings"           
##  [9060] "should want company, I am sure we should be very glad to come and stay"      
##  [9061] "with her for as long a time as she likes.  I suppose Lady Middleton"         
##  [9062] "won't ask us any more this bout.  Good-by; I am sorry Miss Marianne was"     
##  [9063] "not here.  Remember me kindly to her.  La! if you have not got your"         
##  [9064] "spotted muslin on!--I wonder you was not afraid of its being torn.\""        
##  [9065] ""                                                                            
##  [9066] "Such was her parting concern; for after this, she had time only to pay"      
##  [9067] "her farewell compliments to Mrs. Jennings, before her company was"           
##  [9068] "claimed by Mrs. Richardson; and Elinor was left in possession of"            
##  [9069] "knowledge which might feed her powers of reflection some time, though"       
##  [9070] "she had learnt very little more than what had been already foreseen and"     
##  [9071] "foreplanned in her own mind.  Edward's marriage with Lucy was as firmly"     
##  [9072] "determined on, and the time of its taking place remained as absolutely"      
##  [9073] "uncertain, as she had concluded it would be;--every thing depended,"         
##  [9074] "exactly after her expectation, on his getting that preferment, of"           
##  [9075] "which, at present, there seemed not the smallest chance."                    
##  [9076] ""                                                                            
##  [9077] "As soon as they returned to the carriage, Mrs. Jennings was eager for"       
##  [9078] "information; but as Elinor wished to spread as little as possible"           
##  [9079] "intelligence that had in the first place been so unfairly obtained, she"     
##  [9080] "confined herself to the brief repetition of such simple particulars, as"     
##  [9081] "she felt assured that Lucy, for the sake of her own consequence, would"      
##  [9082] "choose to have known.  The continuance of their engagement, and the"         
##  [9083] "means that were able to be taken for promoting its end, was all her"         
##  [9084] "communication; and this produced from Mrs. Jennings the following"           
##  [9085] "natural remark."                                                             
##  [9086] ""                                                                            
##  [9087] "\"Wait for his having a living!--ay, we all know how THAT will"              
##  [9088] "end:--they will wait a twelvemonth, and finding no good comes of it,"        
##  [9089] "will set down upon a curacy of fifty pounds a-year, with the interest"       
##  [9090] "of his two thousand pounds, and what little matter Mr. Steele and Mr."       
##  [9091] "Pratt can give her.--Then they will have a child every year! and Lord"       
##  [9092] "help 'em! how poor they will be!--I must see what I can give them"           
##  [9093] "towards furnishing their house.  Two maids and two men, indeed!--as I"       
##  [9094] "talked of t'other day.--No, no, they must get a stout girl of all"           
##  [9095] "works.-- Betty's sister would never do for them NOW.\""                      
##  [9096] ""                                                                            
##  [9097] "The next morning brought Elinor a letter by the two-penny post from"         
##  [9098] "Lucy herself.  It was as follows:"                                           
##  [9099] ""                                                                            
##  [9100] "                    \"Bartlett's Building, March."                           
##  [9101] ""                                                                            
##  [9102] "     \"I hope my dear Miss Dashwood will excuse the"                         
##  [9103] "     liberty I take of writing to her; but I know your"                      
##  [9104] "     friendship for me will make you pleased to hear such"                   
##  [9105] "     a good account of myself and my dear Edward, after"                     
##  [9106] "     all the troubles we have went through lately,"                          
##  [9107] "     therefore will make no more apologies, but proceed"                     
##  [9108] "     to say that, thank God! though we have suffered"                        
##  [9109] "     dreadfully, we are both quite well now, and as happy"                   
##  [9110] "     as we must always be in one another's love.  We have"                   
##  [9111] "     had great trials, and great persecutions, but"                          
##  [9112] "     however, at the same time, gratefully acknowledge"                      
##  [9113] "     many friends, yourself not the least among them,"                       
##  [9114] "     whose great kindness I shall always thankfully"                         
##  [9115] "     remember, as will Edward too, who I have told of"                       
##  [9116] "     it.  I am sure you will be glad to hear, as likewise"                   
##  [9117] "     dear Mrs. Jennings, I spent two happy hours with"                       
##  [9118] "     him yesterday afternoon, he would not hear of our"                      
##  [9119] "     parting, though earnestly did I, as I thought my"                       
##  [9120] "     duty required, urge him to it for prudence sake,"                       
##  [9121] "     and would have parted for ever on the spot, would"                      
##  [9122] "     he consent to it; but he said it should never be,"                      
##  [9123] "     he did not regard his mother's anger, while he could"                   
##  [9124] "     have my affections; our prospects are not very"                         
##  [9125] "     bright, to be sure, but we must wait, and hope for"                     
##  [9126] "     the best; he will be ordained shortly; and should"                      
##  [9127] "     it ever be in your power to recommend him to any"                       
##  [9128] "     body that has a living to bestow, am very sure you"                     
##  [9129] "     will not forget us, and dear Mrs. Jennings too,"                        
##  [9130] "     trust she will speak a good word for us to Sir John,"                   
##  [9131] "     or Mr. Palmer, or any friend that may be able to"                       
##  [9132] "     assist us.--Poor Anne was much to blame for what"                       
##  [9133] "     she did, but she did it for the best, so I say"                         
##  [9134] "     nothing; hope Mrs. Jennings won't think it too much"                    
##  [9135] "     trouble to give us a call, should she come this way"                    
##  [9136] "     any morning, 'twould be a great kindness, and my"                       
##  [9137] "     cousins would be proud to know her.--My paper reminds"                  
##  [9138] "     me to conclude; and begging to be most gratefully"                      
##  [9139] "     and respectfully remembered to her, and to Sir John,"                   
##  [9140] "     and Lady Middleton, and the dear children, when you"                    
##  [9141] "     chance to see them, and love to Miss Marianne,"                         
##  [9142] ""                                                                            
##  [9143] "                                      \"I am, &c.\""                         
##  [9144] ""                                                                            
##  [9145] "As soon as Elinor had finished it, she performed what she concluded to"      
##  [9146] "be its writer's real design, by placing it in the hands of Mrs."             
##  [9147] "Jennings, who read it aloud with many comments of satisfaction and"          
##  [9148] "praise."                                                                     
##  [9149] ""                                                                            
##  [9150] "\"Very well indeed!--how prettily she writes!--aye, that was quite"          
##  [9151] "proper to let him be off if he would.  That was just like Lucy.--Poor"       
##  [9152] "soul! I wish I COULD get him a living, with all my heart.--She calls me"     
##  [9153] "dear Mrs. Jennings, you see.  She is a good-hearted girl as ever"            
##  [9154] "lived.--Very well upon my word.  That sentence is very prettily turned."     
##  [9155] "Yes, yes, I will go and see her, sure enough.  How attentive she is, to"     
##  [9156] "think of every body!--Thank you, my dear, for shewing it me.  It is as"      
##  [9157] "pretty a letter as ever I saw, and does Lucy's head and heart great"         
##  [9158] "credit.\""                                                                   
##  [9159] ""                                                                            
##  [9160] ""                                                                            
##  [9161] ""                                                                            
##  [9162] "CHAPTER 39"                                                                  
##  [9163] ""                                                                            
##  [9164] ""                                                                            
##  [9165] "The Miss Dashwoods had now been rather more than two months in town,"        
##  [9166] "and Marianne's impatience to be gone increased every day.  She sighed"       
##  [9167] "for the air, the liberty, the quiet of the country; and fancied that if"     
##  [9168] "any place could give her ease, Barton must do it.  Elinor was hardly"        
##  [9169] "less anxious than herself for their removal, and only so much less bent"     
##  [9170] "on its being effected immediately, as that she was conscious of the"         
##  [9171] "difficulties of so long a journey, which Marianne could not be brought"      
##  [9172] "to acknowledge.  She began, however, seriously to turn her thoughts"         
##  [9173] "towards its accomplishment, and had already mentioned their wishes to"       
##  [9174] "their kind hostess, who resisted them with all the eloquence of her"         
##  [9175] "good-will, when a plan was suggested, which, though detaining them from"     
##  [9176] "home yet a few weeks longer, appeared to Elinor altogether much more"        
##  [9177] "eligible than any other. The Palmers were to remove to Cleveland about"      
##  [9178] "the end of March, for the Easter holidays; and Mrs. Jennings, with both"     
##  [9179] "her friends, received a very warm invitation from Charlotte to go with"      
##  [9180] "them.  This would not, in itself, have been sufficient for the delicacy"     
##  [9181] "of Miss Dashwood;--but it was inforced with so much real politeness by"      
##  [9182] "Mr. Palmer himself, as, joined to the very great amendment of his"           
##  [9183] "manners towards them since her sister had been known to be unhappy,"         
##  [9184] "induced her to accept it with pleasure."                                     
##  [9185] ""                                                                            
##  [9186] "When she told Marianne what she had done, however, her first reply was"      
##  [9187] "not very auspicious."                                                        
##  [9188] ""                                                                            
##  [9189] "\"Cleveland!\"--she cried, with great agitation.  \"No, I cannot go to"      
##  [9190] "Cleveland.\"--"                                                              
##  [9191] ""                                                                            
##  [9192] "\"You forget,\" said Elinor gently, \"that its situation is not...that it"   
##  [9193] "is not in the neighbourhood of...\""                                         
##  [9194] ""                                                                            
##  [9195] "\"But it is in Somersetshire.--I cannot go into Somersetshire.--There,"      
##  [9196] "where I looked forward to going...No, Elinor, you cannot expect me to"       
##  [9197] "go there.\""                                                                 
##  [9198] ""                                                                            
##  [9199] "Elinor would not argue upon the propriety of overcoming such"                
##  [9200] "feelings;--she only endeavoured to counteract them by working on"            
##  [9201] "others;--represented it, therefore, as a measure which would fix the"        
##  [9202] "time of her returning to that dear mother, whom she so much wished to"       
##  [9203] "see, in a more eligible, more comfortable manner, than any other plan"       
##  [9204] "could do, and perhaps without any greater delay.  From Cleveland, which"     
##  [9205] "was within a few miles of Bristol, the distance to Barton was not"           
##  [9206] "beyond one day, though a long day's journey; and their mother's servant"     
##  [9207] "might easily come there to attend them down; and as there could be no"       
##  [9208] "occasion of their staying above a week at Cleveland, they might now be"      
##  [9209] "at home in little more than three weeks' time.  As Marianne's affection"     
##  [9210] "for her mother was sincere, it must triumph with little difficulty,"         
##  [9211] "over the imaginary evils she had started."                                   
##  [9212] ""                                                                            
##  [9213] "Mrs. Jennings was so far from being weary of her guests, that she"           
##  [9214] "pressed them very earnestly to return with her again from Cleveland."        
##  [9215] "Elinor was grateful for the attention, but it could not alter her"           
##  [9216] "design; and their mother's concurrence being readily gained, every"          
##  [9217] "thing relative to their return was arranged as far as it could be;--and"     
##  [9218] "Marianne found some relief in drawing up a statement of the hours that"      
##  [9219] "were yet to divide her from Barton."                                         
##  [9220] ""                                                                            
##  [9221] "\"Ah! Colonel, I do not know what you and I shall do without the Miss"       
##  [9222] "Dashwoods;\"--was Mrs. Jennings's address to him when he first called on"    
##  [9223] "her, after their leaving her was settled--\"for they are quite resolved"     
##  [9224] "upon going home from the Palmers;--and how forlorn we shall be, when I"      
##  [9225] "come back!--Lord! we shall sit and gape at one another as dull as two"       
##  [9226] "cats.\""                                                                     
##  [9227] ""                                                                            
##  [9228] "Perhaps Mrs. Jennings was in hopes, by this vigorous sketch of their"        
##  [9229] "future ennui, to provoke him to make that offer, which might give"           
##  [9230] "himself an escape from it;--and if so, she had soon afterwards good"         
##  [9231] "reason to think her object gained; for, on Elinor's moving to the"           
##  [9232] "window to take more expeditiously the dimensions of a print, which she"      
##  [9233] "was going to copy for her friend, he followed her to it with a look of"      
##  [9234] "particular meaning, and conversed with her there for several minutes."       
##  [9235] "The effect of his discourse on the lady too, could not escape her"           
##  [9236] "observation, for though she was too honorable to listen, and had even"       
##  [9237] "changed her seat, on purpose that she might NOT hear, to one close by"       
##  [9238] "the piano forte on which Marianne was playing, she could not keep"           
##  [9239] "herself from seeing that Elinor changed colour, attended with"               
##  [9240] "agitation, and was too intent on what he said to pursue her"                 
##  [9241] "employment.-- Still farther in confirmation of her hopes, in the"            
##  [9242] "interval of Marianne's turning from one lesson to another, some words"       
##  [9243] "of the Colonel's inevitably reached her ear, in which he seemed to be"       
##  [9244] "apologising for the badness of his house.  This set the matter beyond a"     
##  [9245] "doubt.  She wondered, indeed, at his thinking it necessary to do so;"        
##  [9246] "but supposed it to be the proper etiquette.  What Elinor said in reply"      
##  [9247] "she could not distinguish, but judged from the motion of her lips, that"     
##  [9248] "she did not think THAT any material objection;--and Mrs. Jennings"           
##  [9249] "commended her in her heart for being so honest.  They then talked on"        
##  [9250] "for a few minutes longer without her catching a syllable, when another"      
##  [9251] "lucky stop in Marianne's performance brought her these words in the"         
##  [9252] "Colonel's calm voice,--"                                                     
##  [9253] ""                                                                            
##  [9254] "\"I am afraid it cannot take place very soon.\""                             
##  [9255] ""                                                                            
##  [9256] "Astonished and shocked at so unlover-like a speech, she was almost"          
##  [9257] "ready to cry out, \"Lord! what should hinder it?\"--but checking her"        
##  [9258] "desire, confined herself to this silent ejaculation."                        
##  [9259] ""                                                                            
##  [9260] "\"This is very strange!--sure he need not wait to be older.\""               
##  [9261] ""                                                                            
##  [9262] "This delay on the Colonel's side, however, did not seem to offend or"        
##  [9263] "mortify his fair companion in the least, for on their breaking up the"       
##  [9264] "conference soon afterwards, and moving different ways, Mrs. Jennings"        
##  [9265] "very plainly heard Elinor say, and with a voice which shewed her to"         
##  [9266] "feel what she said,"                                                         
##  [9267] ""                                                                            
##  [9268] "\"I shall always think myself very much obliged to you.\""                   
##  [9269] ""                                                                            
##  [9270] "Mrs. Jennings was delighted with her gratitude, and only wondered that"      
##  [9271] "after hearing such a sentence, the Colonel should be able to take leave"     
##  [9272] "of them, as he immediately did, with the utmost sang-froid, and go away"     
##  [9273] "without making her any reply!--She had not thought her old friend could"     
##  [9274] "have made so indifferent a suitor."                                          
##  [9275] ""                                                                            
##  [9276] "What had really passed between them was to this effect."                     
##  [9277] ""                                                                            
##  [9278] "\"I have heard,\" said he, with great compassion, \"of the injustice your"   
##  [9279] "friend Mr. Ferrars has suffered from his family; for if I understand"        
##  [9280] "the matter right, he has been entirely cast off by them for persevering"     
##  [9281] "in his engagement with a very deserving young woman.-- Have I been"          
##  [9282] "rightly informed?--Is it so?--\""                                            
##  [9283] ""                                                                            
##  [9284] "Elinor told him that it was."                                                
##  [9285] ""                                                                            
##  [9286] "\"The cruelty, the impolitic cruelty,\"--he replied, with great"             
##  [9287] "feeling,--\"of dividing, or attempting to divide, two young people long"     
##  [9288] "attached to each other, is terrible.-- Mrs. Ferrars does not know what"      
##  [9289] "she may be doing--what she may drive her son to.  I have seen Mr."           
##  [9290] "Ferrars two or three times in Harley Street, and am much pleased with"       
##  [9291] "him.  He is not a young man with whom one can be intimately acquainted"      
##  [9292] "in a short time, but I have seen enough of him to wish him well for his"     
##  [9293] "own sake, and as a friend of yours, I wish it still more.  I understand"     
##  [9294] "that he intends to take orders.  Will you be so good as to tell him"         
##  [9295] "that the living of Delaford, now just vacant, as I am informed by this"      
##  [9296] "day's post, is his, if he think it worth his acceptance--but THAT,"          
##  [9297] "perhaps, so unfortunately circumstanced as he is now, it may be"             
##  [9298] "nonsense to appear to doubt; I only wish it were more  valuable.-- It"       
##  [9299] "is a rectory, but a small one; the late incumbent, I believe, did not"       
##  [9300] "make more than 200 L per annum, and though it is certainly capable of"       
##  [9301] "improvement, I fear, not to such an amount as to afford him a very"          
##  [9302] "comfortable income.  Such as it is, however, my pleasure in presenting"      
##  [9303] "it to him, will be very great.  Pray assure him of it.\""                    
##  [9304] ""                                                                            
##  [9305] "Elinor's astonishment at this commission could hardly have been"             
##  [9306] "greater, had the Colonel been really making her an offer of his hand."       
##  [9307] "The preferment, which only two days before she had considered as"            
##  [9308] "hopeless for Edward, was already provided to enable him to marry;--and"      
##  [9309] "SHE, of all people in the world, was fixed on to bestow it!--Her"            
##  [9310] "emotion was such as Mrs. Jennings had attributed to a very different"        
##  [9311] "cause;--but whatever minor feelings less pure, less pleasing, might"         
##  [9312] "have a share in that emotion, her esteem for the general benevolence,"       
##  [9313] "and her gratitude for the particular friendship, which together"             
##  [9314] "prompted Colonel Brandon to this act, were strongly felt, and warmly"        
##  [9315] "expressed.  She thanked him for it with all her heart, spoke of"             
##  [9316] "Edward's principles and disposition with that praise which she knew"         
##  [9317] "them to deserve; and promised to undertake the commission with"              
##  [9318] "pleasure, if it were really his wish to put off so agreeable an office"      
##  [9319] "to another.  But at the same time, she could not help thinking that no"      
##  [9320] "one could so well perform it as himself.  It was an office in short,"        
##  [9321] "from which, unwilling to give Edward the pain of receiving an"               
##  [9322] "obligation from HER, she would have been very glad to be spared"             
##  [9323] "herself;-- but Colonel Brandon, on motives of equal delicacy, declining"     
##  [9324] "it likewise, still seemed so desirous of its being given through her"        
##  [9325] "means, that she would not on any account make farther opposition."           
##  [9326] "Edward, she believed, was still in town, and fortunately she had heard"      
##  [9327] "his address from Miss Steele.  She could undertake therefore to inform"      
##  [9328] "him of it, in the course of the day.  After this had been settled,"          
##  [9329] "Colonel Brandon began to talk of his own advantage in securing so"           
##  [9330] "respectable and agreeable a neighbour, and THEN it was that he"              
##  [9331] "mentioned with regret, that the house was small and indifferent;--an"        
##  [9332] "evil which Elinor, as Mrs. Jennings had supposed her to do, made very"       
##  [9333] "light of, at least as far as regarded its size."                             
##  [9334] ""                                                                            
##  [9335] "\"The smallness of the house,\" said she, \"I cannot imagine any"            
##  [9336] "inconvenience to them, for it will be in proportion to their family and"     
##  [9337] "income.\""                                                                   
##  [9338] ""                                                                            
##  [9339] "By which the Colonel was surprised to find that SHE was considering Mr."     
##  [9340] "Ferrars's marriage as the certain consequence of the presentation; for"      
##  [9341] "he did not suppose it possible that Delaford living could supply such"       
##  [9342] "an income, as anybody in his style of life would venture to settle"          
##  [9343] "on--and he said so."                                                         
##  [9344] ""                                                                            
##  [9345] "\"This little rectory CAN do no more than make Mr. Ferrars comfortable"      
##  [9346] "as a bachelor; it cannot enable him to marry.  I am sorry to say that"       
##  [9347] "my patronage ends with this; and my interest is hardly more extensive."      
##  [9348] "If, however, by an unforeseen chance it should be in my power to serve"      
##  [9349] "him farther, I must think very differently of him from what I now do,"       
##  [9350] "if I am not as ready to be useful to him then as I sincerely wish I"         
##  [9351] "could be at present.  What I am now doing indeed, seems nothing at all,"     
##  [9352] "since it can advance him so little towards what must be his principal,"      
##  [9353] "his only object of happiness.  His marriage must still be a distant"         
##  [9354] "good;--at least, I am afraid it cannot take place very soon.--\""            
##  [9355] ""                                                                            
##  [9356] "Such was the sentence which, when misunderstood, so justly offended the"     
##  [9357] "delicate feelings of Mrs. Jennings; but after this narration of what"        
##  [9358] "really passed between Colonel Brandon and Elinor, while they stood at"       
##  [9359] "the window, the gratitude expressed by the latter on their parting, may"     
##  [9360] "perhaps appear in general, not less reasonably excited, nor less"            
##  [9361] "properly worded than if it had arisen from an offer of marriage."            
##  [9362] ""                                                                            
##  [9363] ""                                                                            
##  [9364] ""                                                                            
##  [9365] "CHAPTER 40"                                                                  
##  [9366] ""                                                                            
##  [9367] ""                                                                            
##  [9368] "\"Well, Miss Dashwood,\" said Mrs. Jennings, sagaciously smiling, as soon"   
##  [9369] "as the gentleman had withdrawn, \"I do not ask you what the Colonel has"     
##  [9370] "been saying to you; for though, upon my honour, I TRIED to keep out of"      
##  [9371] "hearing, I could not help catching enough to understand his business."       
##  [9372] "And I assure you I never was better pleased in my life, and I wish you"      
##  [9373] "joy of it with all my heart.\""                                              
##  [9374] ""                                                                            
##  [9375] "\"Thank you, ma'am,\" said Elinor.  \"It is a matter of great joy to me;"    
##  [9376] "and I feel the goodness of Colonel Brandon most sensibly.  There are"        
##  [9377] "not many men who would act as he has done.  Few people who have so"          
##  [9378] "compassionate a heart!  I never was more astonished in my life.\""           
##  [9379] ""                                                                            
##  [9380] "\"Lord! my dear, you are very modest.  I an't the least astonished at it"    
##  [9381] "in the world, for I have often thought of late, there was nothing more"      
##  [9382] "likely to happen.\""                                                         
##  [9383] ""                                                                            
##  [9384] "\"You judged from your knowledge of the Colonel's general benevolence;"      
##  [9385] "but at least you could not foresee that the opportunity would so very"       
##  [9386] "soon occur.\""                                                               
##  [9387] ""                                                                            
##  [9388] "\"Opportunity!\" repeated Mrs. Jennings--\"Oh! as to that, when a man has"   
##  [9389] "once made up his mind to such a thing, somehow or other he will soon"        
##  [9390] "find an opportunity.  Well, my dear, I wish you joy of it again and"         
##  [9391] "again; and if ever there was a happy couple in the world, I think I"         
##  [9392] "shall soon know where to look for them.\""                                   
##  [9393] ""                                                                            
##  [9394] "\"You mean to go to Delaford after them I suppose,\" said Elinor, with a"    
##  [9395] "faint smile."                                                                
##  [9396] ""                                                                            
##  [9397] "\"Aye, my dear, that I do, indeed.  And as to the house being a bad one,"    
##  [9398] "I do not know what the Colonel would be at, for it is as good a one as"      
##  [9399] "ever I saw.\""                                                               
##  [9400] ""                                                                            
##  [9401] "\"He spoke of its being out of repair.\""                                    
##  [9402] ""                                                                            
##  [9403] "\"Well, and whose fault is that? why don't he repair it?--who should do"     
##  [9404] "it but himself?\""                                                           
##  [9405] ""                                                                            
##  [9406] "They were interrupted by the servant's coming in to announce the"            
##  [9407] "carriage being at the door; and Mrs. Jennings immediately preparing to"      
##  [9408] "go, said,--"                                                                 
##  [9409] ""                                                                            
##  [9410] "\"Well, my dear, I must be gone before I have had half my talk out."         
##  [9411] "But, however, we may have it all over in the evening; for we shall be"       
##  [9412] "quite alone.  I do not ask you to go with me, for I dare say your mind"      
##  [9413] "is too full of the matter to care for company; and besides, you must"        
##  [9414] "long to tell your sister all about it.\""                                    
##  [9415] ""                                                                            
##  [9416] "Marianne had left the room before the conversation began."                   
##  [9417] ""                                                                            
##  [9418] "\"Certainly, ma'am, I shall tell Marianne of it; but I shall not mention"    
##  [9419] "it at present to any body else.\""                                           
##  [9420] ""                                                                            
##  [9421] "\"Oh! very well,\" said Mrs. Jennings rather disappointed.  \"Then you"      
##  [9422] "would not have me tell it to Lucy, for I think of going as far as"           
##  [9423] "Holborn to-day.\""                                                           
##  [9424] ""                                                                            
##  [9425] "\"No, ma'am, not even Lucy if you please.  One day's delay will not be"      
##  [9426] "very material; and till I have written to Mr. Ferrars, I think it ought"     
##  [9427] "not to be mentioned to any body else.  I shall do THAT directly.  It is"     
##  [9428] "of importance that no time should be lost with him, for he will of"          
##  [9429] "course have much to do relative to his ordination.\""                        
##  [9430] ""                                                                            
##  [9431] "This speech at first puzzled Mrs. Jennings exceedingly.  Why Mr."            
##  [9432] "Ferrars was to have been written to about it in such a hurry, she could"     
##  [9433] "not immediately comprehend.  A few moments' reflection, however,"            
##  [9434] "produced a very happy idea, and she exclaimed;--"                            
##  [9435] ""                                                                            
##  [9436] "\"Oh, ho!--I understand you.  Mr. Ferrars is to be the man.  Well, so"       
##  [9437] "much the better for him.  Ay, to be sure, he must be ordained in"            
##  [9438] "readiness; and I am very glad to find things are so forward between"         
##  [9439] "you.  But, my dear, is not this rather out of character?  Should not"        
##  [9440] "the Colonel write himself?--sure, he is the proper person.\""                
##  [9441] ""                                                                            
##  [9442] "Elinor did not quite understand the beginning of Mrs. Jennings's"            
##  [9443] "speech, neither did she think it worth inquiring into; and therefore"        
##  [9444] "only replied to its conclusion."                                             
##  [9445] ""                                                                            
##  [9446] "\"Colonel Brandon is so delicate a man, that he rather wished any one to"    
##  [9447] "announce his intentions to Mr. Ferrars than himself.\""                      
##  [9448] ""                                                                            
##  [9449] "\"And so YOU are forced to do it.  Well THAT is an odd kind of delicacy!"    
##  [9450] "However, I will not disturb you (seeing her preparing to write.)  You"       
##  [9451] "know your own concerns best.  So goodby, my dear.  I have not heard of"      
##  [9452] "any thing to please me so well since Charlotte was brought to bed.\""        
##  [9453] ""                                                                            
##  [9454] "And away she went; but returning again in a moment,"                         
##  [9455] ""                                                                            
##  [9456] "\"I have just been thinking of Betty's sister, my dear.  I should be"        
##  [9457] "very glad to get her so good a mistress.  But whether she would do for"      
##  [9458] "a lady's maid, I am sure I can't tell.  She is an excellent housemaid,"      
##  [9459] "and works very well at her needle.  However, you will think of all that"     
##  [9460] "at your leisure.\""                                                          
##  [9461] ""                                                                            
##  [9462] "\"Certainly, ma'am,\" replied Elinor, not hearing much of what she said,"    
##  [9463] "and more anxious to be alone, than to be mistress of the subject."           
##  [9464] ""                                                                            
##  [9465] "How she should begin--how she should express herself in her note to"         
##  [9466] "Edward, was now all her concern.  The particular circumstances between"
