##  [9467] "them made a difficulty of that which to any other person would have"         
##  [9468] "been the easiest thing in the world; but she equally feared to say too"      
##  [9469] "much or too little, and sat deliberating over her paper, with the pen"       
##  [9470] "in her hand, till broken in on by the entrance of Edward himself."           
##  [9471] ""                                                                            
##  [9472] "He had met Mrs. Jennings at the door in her way to the carriage, as he"      
##  [9473] "came to leave his farewell card; and she, after apologising for not"         
##  [9474] "returning herself, had obliged him to enter, by saying that Miss"            
##  [9475] "Dashwood was above, and wanted to speak with him on very particular"         
##  [9476] "business."                                                                   
##  [9477] ""                                                                            
##  [9478] "Elinor had just been congratulating herself, in the midst of her"            
##  [9479] "perplexity, that however difficult it might be to express herself"           
##  [9480] "properly by letter, it was at least preferable to giving the"                
##  [9481] "information by word of mouth, when her visitor entered, to force her"        
##  [9482] "upon this greatest exertion of all.  Her astonishment and confusion"         
##  [9483] "were very great on his so sudden appearance.  She had not seen him"          
##  [9484] "before since his engagement became public, and therefore not since his"      
##  [9485] "knowing her to be acquainted with it; which, with the consciousness of"      
##  [9486] "what she had been thinking of, and what she had to tell him, made her"       
##  [9487] "feel particularly uncomfortable for some minutes.  He too was much"          
##  [9488] "distressed; and they sat down together in a most promising state of"         
##  [9489] "embarrassment.--Whether he had asked her pardon for his intrusion on"        
##  [9490] "first coming into the room, he could not recollect; but determining to"      
##  [9491] "be on the safe side, he made his apology in form as soon as he could"        
##  [9492] "say any thing, after taking a chair."                                        
##  [9493] ""                                                                            
##  [9494] "\"Mrs. Jennings told me,\" said he, \"that you wished to speak with me, at"  
##  [9495] "least I understood her so--or I certainly should not have intruded on"       
##  [9496] "you in such a manner; though at the same time, I should have been"           
##  [9497] "extremely sorry to leave London without seeing you and your sister;"         
##  [9498] "especially as it will most likely be some time--it is not probable that"     
##  [9499] "I should soon have the pleasure of meeting you again.  I go to Oxford"       
##  [9500] "tomorrow.\""                                                                 
##  [9501] ""                                                                            
##  [9502] "\"You would not have gone, however,\" said Elinor, recovering herself,"      
##  [9503] "and determined to get over what she so much dreaded as soon as"              
##  [9504] "possible, \"without receiving our good wishes, even if we had not been"      
##  [9505] "able to give them in person.  Mrs. Jennings was quite right in what she"     
##  [9506] "said.  I have something of consequence to inform you of, which I was on"     
##  [9507] "the point of communicating by paper.  I am charged with a most"              
##  [9508] "agreeable office (breathing rather faster than usual as she spoke.)"         
##  [9509] "Colonel Brandon, who was here only ten minutes ago, has desired me to"       
##  [9510] "say, that understanding you mean to take orders, he has great pleasure"      
##  [9511] "in offering you the living of Delaford now just vacant, and only wishes"     
##  [9512] "it were more valuable.  Allow me to congratulate you on having so"           
##  [9513] "respectable and well-judging a friend, and to join in his wish that the"     
##  [9514] "living--it is about two hundred a-year--were much more considerable,"        
##  [9515] "and such as might better enable you to--as might be more than a"             
##  [9516] "temporary accommodation to yourself--such, in short, as might establish"     
##  [9517] "all your views of happiness.\""                                              
##  [9518] ""                                                                            
##  [9519] "What Edward felt, as he could not say it himself, it cannot be expected"     
##  [9520] "that any one else should say for him.  He LOOKED all the astonishment"       
##  [9521] "which such unexpected, such unthought-of information could not fail of"      
##  [9522] "exciting; but he said only these two words,"                                 
##  [9523] ""                                                                            
##  [9524] "\"Colonel Brandon!\""                                                        
##  [9525] ""                                                                            
##  [9526] "\"Yes,\" continued Elinor, gathering more resolution, as some of the"        
##  [9527] "worst was over, \"Colonel Brandon means it as a testimony of his concern"    
##  [9528] "for what has lately passed--for the cruel situation in which the"            
##  [9529] "unjustifiable conduct of your family has placed you--a concern which I"      
##  [9530] "am sure Marianne, myself, and all your friends, must share; and"             
##  [9531] "likewise as a proof of his high esteem for your general character, and"      
##  [9532] "his particular approbation of your behaviour on the present occasion.\""     
##  [9533] ""                                                                            
##  [9534] "\"Colonel Brandon give ME a living!--Can it be possible?\""                  
##  [9535] ""                                                                            
##  [9536] "\"The unkindness of your own relations has made you astonished to find"      
##  [9537] "friendship any where.\""                                                     
##  [9538] ""                                                                            
##  [9539] "\"No,\" replied he, with sudden consciousness, \"not to find it in YOU;"     
##  [9540] "for I cannot be ignorant that to you, to your goodness, I owe it"            
##  [9541] "all.--I feel it--I would express it if I could--but, as you well know,"      
##  [9542] "I am no orator.\""                                                           
##  [9543] ""                                                                            
##  [9544] "\"You are very much mistaken.  I do assure you that you owe it entirely,"    
##  [9545] "at least almost entirely, to your own merit, and Colonel Brandon's"          
##  [9546] "discernment of it.  I have had no hand in it.  I did not even know,"         
##  [9547] "till I understood his design, that the living was vacant; nor had it"        
##  [9548] "ever occurred to me that he might have had such a living in his gift."       
##  [9549] "As a friend of mine, of my family, he may, perhaps--indeed I know he"        
##  [9550] "HAS, still greater pleasure in bestowing it; but, upon my word, you owe"     
##  [9551] "nothing to my solicitation.\""                                               
##  [9552] ""                                                                            
##  [9553] "Truth obliged her to acknowledge some small share in the action, but"        
##  [9554] "she was at the same time so unwilling to appear as the benefactress of"      
##  [9555] "Edward, that she acknowledged it with hesitation; which probably"            
##  [9556] "contributed to fix that suspicion in his mind which had recently"            
##  [9557] "entered it.  For a short time he sat deep in thought, after Elinor had"      
##  [9558] "ceased to speak;--at last, and as if it were rather an effort, he said,"     
##  [9559] ""                                                                            
##  [9560] "\"Colonel Brandon seems a man of great worth and respectability.  I have"    
##  [9561] "always heard him spoken of as such, and your brother I know esteems him"     
##  [9562] "highly.  He is undoubtedly a sensible man, and in his manners perfectly"     
##  [9563] "the gentleman.\""                                                            
##  [9564] ""                                                                            
##  [9565] "\"Indeed,\" replied Elinor, \"I believe that you will find him, on farther"  
##  [9566] "acquaintance, all that you have heard him to be, and as you will be"         
##  [9567] "such very near neighbours (for I understand the parsonage is almost"         
##  [9568] "close to the mansion-house,) it is particularly important that he"           
##  [9569] "SHOULD be all this.\""                                                       
##  [9570] ""                                                                            
##  [9571] "Edward made no answer; but when she had turned away her head, gave her"      
##  [9572] "a look so serious, so earnest, so uncheerful, as seemed to say, that he"     
##  [9573] "might hereafter wish the distance between the parsonage and the"             
##  [9574] "mansion-house much greater."                                                 
##  [9575] ""                                                                            
##  [9576] "\"Colonel Brandon, I think, lodges in St. James Street,\" said he, soon"     
##  [9577] "afterwards, rising from his chair."                                          
##  [9578] ""                                                                            
##  [9579] "Elinor told him the number of the house."                                    
##  [9580] ""                                                                            
##  [9581] "\"I must hurry away then, to give him those thanks which you will not"       
##  [9582] "allow me to give YOU; to assure him that he has made me a very--an"          
##  [9583] "exceedingly happy man.\""                                                    
##  [9584] ""                                                                            
##  [9585] "Elinor did not offer to detain him; and they parted, with a very"            
##  [9586] "earnest assurance on HER side of her unceasing good wishes for his"          
##  [9587] "happiness in every change of situation that might befall him; on HIS,"       
##  [9588] "with rather an attempt to return the same good will, than the power of"      
##  [9589] "expressing it."                                                              
##  [9590] ""                                                                            
##  [9591] "\"When I see him again,\" said Elinor to herself, as the door shut him"      
##  [9592] "out, \"I shall see him the husband of Lucy.\""                               
##  [9593] ""                                                                            
##  [9594] "And with this pleasing anticipation, she sat down to reconsider the"         
##  [9595] "past, recall the words and endeavour to comprehend all the feelings of"      
##  [9596] "Edward; and, of course, to reflect on her own with discontent."              
##  [9597] ""                                                                            
##  [9598] "When Mrs. Jennings came home, though she returned from seeing people"        
##  [9599] "whom she had never seen before, and of whom therefore she must have a"       
##  [9600] "great deal to say, her mind was so much more occupied by the important"      
##  [9601] "secret in her possession, than by anything else, that she reverted to"       
##  [9602] "it again as soon as Elinor appeared."                                        
##  [9603] ""                                                                            
##  [9604] "\"Well, my dear,\" she cried, \"I sent you up the young man.  Did not I"     
##  [9605] "do right?--And I suppose you had no great difficulty--You did not find"      
##  [9606] "him very unwilling to accept your proposal?\""                               
##  [9607] ""                                                                            
##  [9608] "\"No, ma'am; THAT was not very likely.\""                                    
##  [9609] ""                                                                            
##  [9610] "\"Well, and how soon will he be ready?--For it seems all to depend upon"     
##  [9611] "that.\""                                                                     
##  [9612] ""                                                                            
##  [9613] "\"Really,\" said Elinor, \"I know so little of these kind of forms, that I"  
##  [9614] "can hardly even conjecture as to the time, or the preparation"               
##  [9615] "necessary; but I suppose two or three months will complete his"              
##  [9616] "ordination.\""                                                               
##  [9617] ""                                                                            
##  [9618] "\"Two or three months!\" cried Mrs. Jennings; \"Lord! my dear, how calmly"   
##  [9619] "you talk of it; and can the Colonel wait two or three months! Lord"          
##  [9620] "bless me!--I am sure it would put ME quite out of patience!--And though"     
##  [9621] "one would be very glad to do a kindness by poor Mr. Ferrars, I do think"     
##  [9622] "it is not worth while to wait two or three months for him.  Sure"            
##  [9623] "somebody else might be found that would do as well; somebody that is in"     
##  [9624] "orders already.\""                                                           
##  [9625] ""                                                                            
##  [9626] "\"My dear ma'am,\" said Elinor, \"what can you be thinking of?-- Why,"       
##  [9627] "Colonel Brandon's only object is to be of use to Mr. Ferrars.\""             
##  [9628] ""                                                                            
##  [9629] "\"Lord bless you, my dear!--Sure you do not mean to persuade me that the"    
##  [9630] "Colonel only marries you for the sake of giving ten guineas to Mr."          
##  [9631] "Ferrars!\""                                                                  
##  [9632] ""                                                                            
##  [9633] "The deception could not continue after this; and an explanation"             
##  [9634] "immediately took place, by which both gained considerable amusement for"     
##  [9635] "the moment, without any material loss of happiness to either, for Mrs."      
##  [9636] "Jennings only exchanged one form of delight for another, and still"          
##  [9637] "without forfeiting her expectation of the first."                            
##  [9638] ""                                                                            
##  [9639] "\"Aye, aye, the parsonage is but a small one,\" said she, after the first"   
##  [9640] "ebullition of surprise and satisfaction was over, \"and very likely MAY"     
##  [9641] "be out of repair; but to hear a man apologising, as I thought, for a"        
##  [9642] "house that to my knowledge has five sitting rooms on the ground-floor,"      
##  [9643] "and I think the housekeeper told me could make up fifteen beds!--and to"     
##  [9644] "you too, that had been used to live in Barton cottage!-- It seems quite"     
##  [9645] "ridiculous.  But, my dear, we must touch up the Colonel to do some"          
##  [9646] "thing to the parsonage, and make it comfortable for them, before Lucy"       
##  [9647] "goes to it.\""                                                               
##  [9648] ""                                                                            
##  [9649] "\"But Colonel Brandon does not seem to have any idea of the living's"        
##  [9650] "being enough to allow them to marry.\""                                      
##  [9651] ""                                                                            
##  [9652] "\"The Colonel is a ninny, my dear; because he has two thousand a-year"       
##  [9653] "himself, he thinks that nobody else can marry on less.  Take my word"        
##  [9654] "for it, that, if I am alive, I shall be paying a visit at Delaford"          
##  [9655] "Parsonage before Michaelmas; and I am sure I shan't go if Lucy an't"         
##  [9656] "there.\""                                                                    
##  [9657] ""                                                                            
##  [9658] "Elinor was quite of her opinion, as to the probability of their not"         
##  [9659] "waiting for any thing more."                                                 
##  [9660] ""                                                                            
##  [9661] ""                                                                            
##  [9662] ""                                                                            
##  [9663] "CHAPTER 41"                                                                  
##  [9664] ""                                                                            
##  [9665] ""                                                                            
##  [9666] "Edward, having carried his thanks to Colonel Brandon, proceeded with"        
##  [9667] "his happiness to Lucy; and such was the excess of it by the time he"         
##  [9668] "reached Bartlett's Buildings, that she was able to assure Mrs."              
##  [9669] "Jennings, who called on her again the next day with her"                     
##  [9670] "congratulations, that she had never seen him in such spirits before in"      
##  [9671] "her life."                                                                   
##  [9672] ""                                                                            
##  [9673] "Her own happiness, and her own spirits, were at least very certain; and"     
##  [9674] "she joined Mrs. Jennings most heartily in her expectation of their"          
##  [9675] "being all comfortably together in Delaford Parsonage before Michaelmas."     
##  [9676] "So far was she, at the same time, from any backwardness to give Elinor"      
##  [9677] "that credit which Edward WOULD give her, that she spoke of her"              
##  [9678] "friendship for them both with the most grateful warmth, was ready to"        
##  [9679] "own all their obligation to her, and openly declared that no exertion"       
##  [9680] "for their good on Miss Dashwood's part, either present or future, would"     
##  [9681] "ever surprise her, for she believed her capable of doing any thing in"       
##  [9682] "the world for those she really valued.  As for Colonel Brandon, she was"     
##  [9683] "not only ready to worship him as a saint, but was moreover truly"            
##  [9684] "anxious that he should be treated as one in all worldly concerns;"           
##  [9685] "anxious that his tithes should be raised to the utmost; and scarcely"        
##  [9686] "resolved to avail herself, at Delaford, as far as she possibly could,"       
##  [9687] "of his servants, his carriage, his cows, and his poultry."                   
##  [9688] ""                                                                            
##  [9689] "It was now above a week since John Dashwood had called in Berkeley"          
##  [9690] "Street, and as since that time no notice had been taken by them of his"      
##  [9691] "wife's indisposition, beyond one verbal enquiry, Elinor began to feel"       
##  [9692] "it necessary to pay her a visit.--This was an obligation, however,"          
##  [9693] "which not only opposed her own inclination, but which had not the"           
##  [9694] "assistance of any encouragement from her companions.  Marianne, not"         
##  [9695] "contented with absolutely refusing to go herself, was very urgent to"        
##  [9696] "prevent her sister's going at all; and Mrs. Jennings, though her"            
##  [9697] "carriage was always at Elinor's service, so very much disliked Mrs."         
##  [9698] "John Dashwood, that not even her curiosity to see how she looked after"      
##  [9699] "the late discovery, nor her strong desire to affront her by taking"          
##  [9700] "Edward's part, could overcome her unwillingness to be in her company"        
##  [9701] "again.  The consequence was, that Elinor set out by herself to pay a"        
##  [9702] "visit, for which no one could really have less inclination, and to run"      
##  [9703] "the risk of a tete-a-tete with a woman, whom neither of the others had"      
##  [9704] "so much reason to dislike."                                                  
##  [9705] ""                                                                            
##  [9706] "Mrs. Dashwood was denied; but before the carriage could turn from the"       
##  [9707] "house, her husband accidentally came out.  He expressed great pleasure"      
##  [9708] "in meeting Elinor, told her that he had been just going to call in"          
##  [9709] "Berkeley Street, and, assuring her that Fanny would be very glad to see"     
##  [9710] "her, invited her to come in."                                                
##  [9711] ""                                                                            
##  [9712] "They walked up stairs in to the drawing-room.--Nobody was there."            
##  [9713] ""                                                                            
##  [9714] "\"Fanny is in her own room, I suppose,\" said he:--\"I will go to her"       
##  [9715] "presently, for I am sure she will not have the least objection in the"       
##  [9716] "world to seeing YOU.-- Very far from it, indeed.  NOW especially there"      
##  [9717] "cannot be--but however, you and Marianne were always great"                  
##  [9718] "favourites.--Why would not Marianne come?\"--"                               
##  [9719] ""                                                                            
##  [9720] "Elinor made what excuse she could for her."                                  
##  [9721] ""                                                                            
##  [9722] "\"I am not sorry to see you alone,\" he replied, \"for I have a good deal"   
##  [9723] "to say to you.  This living of Colonel Brandon's--can it be true?--has"      
##  [9724] "he really given it to Edward?--I heard it yesterday by chance, and was"      
##  [9725] "coming to you on purpose to enquire farther about it.\""                     
##  [9726] ""                                                                            
##  [9727] "\"It is perfectly true.--Colonel Brandon has given the living of"            
##  [9728] "Delaford to Edward.\""                                                       
##  [9729] ""                                                                            
##  [9730] "\"Really!--Well, this is very astonishing!--no relationship!--no"            
##  [9731] "connection between them!--and now that livings fetch such a"                 
##  [9732] "price!--what was the value of this?\""                                       
##  [9733] ""                                                                            
##  [9734] "\"About two hundred a year.\""                                               
##  [9735] ""                                                                            
##  [9736] "\"Very well--and for the next presentation to a living of that"              
##  [9737] "value--supposing the late incumbent to have been old and sickly, and"        
##  [9738] "likely to vacate it soon--he might have got I dare say--fourteen"            
##  [9739] "hundred pounds.  And how came he not to have settled that matter before"     
##  [9740] "this person's death?--NOW indeed it would be too late to sell it, but a"     
##  [9741] "man of Colonel Brandon's sense!--I wonder he should be so improvident"       
##  [9742] "in a point of such common, such natural, concern!--Well, I am convinced"     
##  [9743] "that there is a vast deal of inconsistency in almost every human"            
##  [9744] "character.  I suppose, however--on recollection--that the case may"          
##  [9745] "probably be THIS.  Edward is only to hold the living till the person to"     
##  [9746] "whom the Colonel has really sold the presentation, is old enough to"         
##  [9747] "take it.--Aye, aye, that is the fact, depend upon it.\""                     
##  [9748] ""                                                                            
##  [9749] "Elinor contradicted it, however, very positively; and by relating that"      
##  [9750] "she had herself been employed in conveying the offer from Colonel"           
##  [9751] "Brandon to Edward, and, therefore, must understand the terms on which"       
##  [9752] "it was given, obliged him to submit to her authority."                       
##  [9753] ""                                                                            
##  [9754] "\"It is truly astonishing!\"--he cried, after hearing what she"              
##  [9755] "said--\"what could be the Colonel's motive?\""                               
##  [9756] ""                                                                            
##  [9757] "\"A very simple one--to be of use to Mr. Ferrars.\""                         
##  [9758] ""                                                                            
##  [9759] "\"Well, well; whatever Colonel Brandon may be, Edward is a very lucky"       
##  [9760] "man.--You will not mention the matter to Fanny, however, for though I"       
##  [9761] "have broke it to her, and she bears it vastly well,--she will not like"      
##  [9762] "to hear it much talked of.\""                                                
##  [9763] ""                                                                            
##  [9764] "Elinor had some difficulty here to refrain from observing, that she"         
##  [9765] "thought Fanny might have borne with composure, an acquisition of wealth"     
##  [9766] "to her brother, by which neither she nor her child could be possibly"        
##  [9767] "impoverished."                                                               
##  [9768] ""                                                                            
##  [9769] "\"Mrs. Ferrars,\" added he, lowering his voice to the tone becoming so"      
##  [9770] "important a subject, \"knows nothing about it at present, and I believe"     
##  [9771] "it will be best to keep it entirely concealed from her as long as may"       
##  [9772] "be.-- When the marriage takes place, I fear she must hear of it all.\""      
##  [9773] ""                                                                            
##  [9774] "\"But why should such precaution be used?--Though it is not to be"           
##  [9775] "supposed that Mrs. Ferrars can have the smallest satisfaction in"            
##  [9776] "knowing that her son has money enough to live upon,--for THAT must be"       
##  [9777] "quite out of the question; yet why, upon her late behaviour, is she"         
##  [9778] "supposed to feel at all?--She has done with her son, she cast him off"       
##  [9779] "for ever, and has made all those over whom she had any influence, cast"      
##  [9780] "him off likewise.  Surely, after doing so, she cannot be imagined"           
##  [9781] "liable to any impression of sorrow or of joy on his account--she cannot"     
##  [9782] "be interested in any thing that befalls him.-- She would not be so weak"     
##  [9783] "as to throw away the comfort of a child, and yet retain the anxiety of"      
##  [9784] "a parent!\""                                                                 
##  [9785] ""                                                                            
##  [9786] "\"Ah! Elinor,\" said John, \"your reasoning is very good, but it is"         
##  [9787] "founded on ignorance of human nature.  When Edward's unhappy match"          
##  [9788] "takes place, depend upon it his mother will feel as much as if she had"      
##  [9789] "never discarded him; and, therefore every circumstance that may"             
##  [9790] "accelerate that dreadful event, must be concealed from her as much as"       
##  [9791] "possible.  Mrs. Ferrars can never forget that Edward is her son.\""          
##  [9792] ""                                                                            
##  [9793] "\"You surprise me; I should think it must nearly have escaped her memory"    
##  [9794] "by THIS time.\""                                                             
##  [9795] ""                                                                            
##  [9796] "\"You wrong her exceedingly.  Mrs. Ferrars is one of the most"               
##  [9797] "affectionate mothers in the world.\""                                        
##  [9798] ""                                                                            
##  [9799] "Elinor was silent."                                                          
##  [9800] ""                                                                            
##  [9801] "\"We think NOW,\"--said Mr. Dashwood, after a short pause, \"of ROBERT'S"    
##  [9802] "marrying Miss Morton.\""                                                     
##  [9803] ""                                                                            
##  [9804] "Elinor, smiling at the grave and decisive importance of her brother's"       
##  [9805] "tone, calmly replied,"                                                       
##  [9806] ""                                                                            
##  [9807] "\"The lady, I suppose, has no choice in the affair.\""                       
##  [9808] ""                                                                            
##  [9809] "\"Choice!--how do you mean?\""                                               
##  [9810] ""                                                                            
##  [9811] "\"I only mean that I suppose, from your manner of speaking, it must be"      
##  [9812] "the same to Miss Morton whether she marry Edward or Robert.\""               
##  [9813] ""                                                                            
##  [9814] "\"Certainly, there can be no difference; for Robert will now to all"         
##  [9815] "intents and purposes be considered as the eldest son;--and as to any"        
##  [9816] "thing else, they are both very agreeable young men: I do not know that"      
##  [9817] "one is superior to the other.\""                                             
##  [9818] ""                                                                            
##  [9819] "Elinor said no more, and John was also for a short time silent.--His"        
##  [9820] "reflections ended thus."                                                     
##  [9821] ""                                                                            
##  [9822] "\"Of ONE thing, my dear sister,\" kindly taking her hand, and speaking in"   
##  [9823] "an awful whisper,--\"I may assure you;--and I WILL do it, because I know"    
##  [9824] "it must gratify you.  I have good reason to think--indeed I have it"         
##  [9825] "from the best authority, or I should not repeat it, for otherwise it"        
##  [9826] "would be very wrong to say any thing about it--but I have it from the"       
##  [9827] "very best authority--not that I ever precisely heard Mrs. Ferrars say"       
##  [9828] "it herself--but her daughter DID, and I have it from her--That in"           
##  [9829] "short, whatever objections there might be against a certain--a certain"      
##  [9830] "connection--you understand me--it would have been far preferable to"         
##  [9831] "her, it would not have given her half the vexation that THIS does.  I"       
##  [9832] "was exceedingly pleased to hear that Mrs. Ferrars considered it in that"     
##  [9833] "light--a very gratifying circumstance you know to us all.  'It would"        
##  [9834] "have been beyond comparison,' she said, 'the least evil of the two, and"     
##  [9835] "she would be glad to compound NOW for nothing worse.' But however, all"      
##  [9836] "that is quite out of the question--not to be thought of or"                  
##  [9837] "mentioned--as to any attachment you know--it never could be--all that"       
##  [9838] "is gone by.  But I thought I would just tell you of this, because I"         
##  [9839] "knew how much it must please you.  Not that you have any reason to"          
##  [9840] "regret, my dear Elinor.  There is no doubt of your doing exceedingly"        
##  [9841] "well--quite as well, or better, perhaps, all things considered.  Has"        
##  [9842] "Colonel Brandon been with you lately?\""                                     
##  [9843] ""                                                                            
##  [9844] "Elinor had heard enough, if not to gratify her vanity, and raise her"        
##  [9845] "self-importance, to agitate her nerves and fill her mind;--and she was"      
##  [9846] "therefore glad to be spared from the necessity of saying much in reply"      
##  [9847] "herself, and from the danger of hearing any thing more from her"             
##  [9848] "brother, by the entrance of Mr. Robert Ferrars.  After a few moments'"       
##  [9849] "chat, John Dashwood, recollecting that Fanny was yet uninformed of her"      
##  [9850] "sister's being there, quitted the room in quest of her; and Elinor was"      
##  [9851] "left to improve her acquaintance with Robert, who, by the gay"               
##  [9852] "unconcern, the happy self-complacency of his manner while enjoying so"       
##  [9853] "unfair a division of his mother's love and liberality, to the prejudice"     
##  [9854] "of his banished brother, earned only by his own dissipated course of"        
##  [9855] "life, and that brother's integrity, was confirming her most"                 
##  [9856] "unfavourable opinion of his head and heart."                                 
##  [9857] ""                                                                            
##  [9858] "They had scarcely been two minutes by themselves, before he began to"        
##  [9859] "speak of Edward; for he, too, had heard of the living, and was very"         
##  [9860] "inquisitive on the subject.  Elinor repeated the particulars of it, as"      
##  [9861] "she had given them to John; and their effect on Robert, though very"         
##  [9862] "different, was not less striking than it had been on HIM.  He laughed"       
##  [9863] "most immoderately.  The idea of Edward's being a clergyman, and living"      
##  [9864] "in a small parsonage-house, diverted him beyond measure;--and when to"       
##  [9865] "that was added the fanciful imagery of Edward reading prayers in a"          
##  [9866] "white surplice, and publishing the banns of marriage between John Smith"     
##  [9867] "and Mary Brown, he could conceive nothing more ridiculous."                  
##  [9868] ""                                                                            
##  [9869] "Elinor, while she waited in silence and immovable gravity, the"              
##  [9870] "conclusion of such folly, could not restrain her eyes from being fixed"      
##  [9871] "on him with a look that spoke all the contempt it excited.  It was a"        
##  [9872] "look, however, very well bestowed, for it relieved her own feelings,"        
##  [9873] "and gave no intelligence to him.  He was recalled from wit to wisdom,"       
##  [9874] "not by any reproof of hers, but by his own sensibility."                     
##  [9875] ""                                                                            
##  [9876] "\"We may treat it as a joke,\" said he, at last, recovering from the"        
##  [9877] "affected laugh which had considerably lengthened out the genuine gaiety"     
##  [9878] "of the moment--\"but, upon my soul, it is a most serious business.  Poor"    
##  [9879] "Edward!  he is ruined for ever.  I am extremely sorry for it--for I"         
##  [9880] "know him to be a very good-hearted creature; as well-meaning a fellow"       
##  [9881] "perhaps, as any in the world.  You must not judge of him, Miss"              
##  [9882] "Dashwood, from YOUR slight acquaintance.--Poor Edward!--His manners are"     
##  [9883] "certainly not the happiest in nature.--But we are not all born, you"         
##  [9884] "know, with the same powers,--the same address.-- Poor fellow!--to see"       
##  [9885] "him in a circle of strangers!--to be sure it was pitiable enough!--but"      
##  [9886] "upon my soul, I believe he has as good a heart as any in the kingdom;"       
##  [9887] "and I declare and protest to you I never was so shocked in my life, as"      
##  [9888] "when it all burst forth.  I could not believe it.-- My mother was the"       
##  [9889] "first person who told me of it; and I, feeling myself called on to act"      
##  [9890] "with resolution, immediately said to her, 'My dear madam, I do not know"     
##  [9891] "what you may intend to do on the occasion, but as for myself, I must"        
##  [9892] "say, that if Edward does marry this young woman, I never will see him"       
##  [9893] "again.' That was what I said immediately.-- I was most uncommonly"           
##  [9894] "shocked, indeed!--Poor Edward!--he has done for himself"                     
##  [9895] "completely--shut himself out for ever from all decent society!--but, as"     
##  [9896] "I directly said to my mother, I am not in the least surprised at it;"        
##  [9897] "from his style of education, it was always to be expected.  My poor"         
##  [9898] "mother was half frantic.\""                                                  
##  [9899] ""                                                                            
##  [9900] "\"Have you ever seen the lady?\""                                            
##  [9901] ""                                                                            
##  [9902] "\"Yes; once, while she was staying in this house, I happened to drop in"     
##  [9903] "for ten minutes; and I saw quite enough of her.  The merest awkward"         
##  [9904] "country girl, without style, or elegance, and almost without beauty.--"      
##  [9905] "I remember her perfectly.  Just the kind of girl I should suppose"           
##  [9906] "likely to captivate poor Edward.  I offered immediately, as soon as my"      
##  [9907] "mother related the affair to me, to talk to him myself, and dissuade"        
##  [9908] "him from the match; but it was too late THEN, I found, to do any thing,"     
##  [9909] "for unluckily, I was not in the way at first, and knew nothing of it"        
##  [9910] "till after the breach had taken place, when it was not for me, you"          
##  [9911] "know, to interfere.  But had I been informed of it a few hours"              
##  [9912] "earlier--I think it is most probable--that something might have been"        
##  [9913] "hit on.  I certainly should have represented it to Edward in a very"         
##  [9914] "strong light.  'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you"     
##  [9915] "are doing.  You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a"        
##  [9916] "one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.' I cannot help"            
##  [9917] "thinking, in short, that means might have been found.  But now it is"        
##  [9918] "all too late.  He must be starved, you know;--that is certain;"              
##  [9919] "absolutely starved.\""                                                       
##  [9920] ""                                                                            
##  [9921] "He had just settled this point with great composure, when the entrance"      
##  [9922] "of Mrs. John Dashwood put an end to the subject.  But though SHE never"      
##  [9923] "spoke of it out of her own family, Elinor could see its influence on"        
##  [9924] "her mind, in the something like confusion of countenance with which she"     
##  [9925] "entered, and an attempt at cordiality in her behaviour to herself.  She"     
##  [9926] "even proceeded so far as to be concerned to find that Elinor and her"        
##  [9927] "sister were so soon to leave town, as she had hoped to see more of"          
##  [9928] "them;--an exertion in which her husband, who attended her into the"          
##  [9929] "room, and hung enamoured over her accents, seemed to distinguish every"      
##  [9930] "thing that was most affectionate and graceful."                              
##  [9931] ""                                                                            
##  [9932] ""                                                                            
##  [9933] ""                                                                            
##  [9934] "CHAPTER 42"                                                                  
##  [9935] ""                                                                            
##  [9936] ""                                                                            
##  [9937] "One other short call in Harley Street, in which Elinor received her"         
##  [9938] "brother's congratulations on their travelling so far towards Barton"         
##  [9939] "without any expense, and on Colonel Brandon's being to follow them to"       
##  [9940] "Cleveland in a day or two, completed the intercourse of the brother and"     
##  [9941] "sisters in town;--and a faint invitation from Fanny, to come to Norland"     
##  [9942] "whenever it should happen to be in their way, which of all things was"       
##  [9943] "the most unlikely to occur, with a more warm, though less public,"           
##  [9944] "assurance, from John to Elinor, of the promptitude with which he should"     
##  [9945] "come to see her at Delaford, was all that foretold any meeting in the"       
##  [9946] "country."                                                                    
##  [9947] ""                                                                            
##  [9948] "It amused her to observe that all her friends seemed determined to send"     
##  [9949] "her to Delaford;--a place, in which, of all others, she would now least"     
##  [9950] "chuse to visit, or wish to reside; for not only was it considered as"        
##  [9951] "her future home by her brother and Mrs. Jennings, but even Lucy, when"       
##  [9952] "they parted, gave her a pressing invitation to visit her there."             
##  [9953] ""                                                                            
##  [9954] "Very early in April, and tolerably early in the day, the two parties"        
##  [9955] "from Hanover Square and Berkeley Street set out from their respective"       
##  [9956] "homes, to meet, by appointment, on the road.  For the convenience of"        
##  [9957] "Charlotte and her child, they were to be more than two days on their"        
##  [9958] "journey, and Mr. Palmer, travelling more expeditiously with Colonel"         
##  [9959] "Brandon, was to join them at Cleveland soon after their arrival."            
##  [9960] ""                                                                            
##  [9961] "Marianne, few as had been her hours of comfort in London, and eager as"      
##  [9962] "she had long been to quit it, could not, when it came to the point, bid"     
##  [9963] "adieu to the house in which she had for the last time enjoyed those"         
##  [9964] "hopes, and that confidence, in Willoughby, which were now extinguished"      
##  [9965] "for ever, without great pain.  Nor could she leave the place in which"       
##  [9966] "Willoughby remained, busy in new engagements, and new schemes, in which"     
##  [9967] "SHE could have no share, without shedding many tears."                       
##  [9968] ""                                                                            
##  [9969] "Elinor's satisfaction, at the moment of removal, was more positive."         
##  [9970] "She had no such object for her lingering thoughts to fix on, she left"       
##  [9971] "no creature behind, from whom it would give her a moment's regret to be"     
##  [9972] "divided for ever, she was pleased to be free herself from the"               
##  [9973] "persecution of Lucy's friendship, she was grateful for bringing her"         
##  [9974] "sister away unseen by Willoughby since his marriage, and she looked"         
##  [9975] "forward with hope to what a few months of tranquility at Barton might"       
##  [9976] "do towards restoring Marianne's peace of mind, and confirming her own."      
##  [9977] ""                                                                            
##  [9978] "Their journey was safely performed.  The second day brought them into"       
##  [9979] "the cherished, or the prohibited, county of Somerset, for as such was"       
##  [9980] "it dwelt on by turns in Marianne's imagination; and in the forenoon of"      
##  [9981] "the third they drove up to Cleveland."                                       
##  [9982] ""                                                                            
##  [9983] "Cleveland was a spacious, modern-built house, situated on a sloping"         
##  [9984] "lawn.  It had no park, but the pleasure-grounds were tolerably"              
##  [9985] "extensive; and like every other place of the same degree of importance,"     
##  [9986] "it had its open shrubbery, and closer wood walk, a road of smooth"           
##  [9987] "gravel winding round a plantation, led to the front, the lawn was"           
##  [9988] "dotted over with timber, the house itself was under the guardianship of"     
##  [9989] "the fir, the mountain-ash, and the acacia, and a thick screen of them"       
##  [9990] "altogether, interspersed with tall Lombardy poplars, shut out the"           
##  [9991] "offices."                                                                    
##  [9992] ""                                                                            
##  [9993] "Marianne entered the house with a heart swelling with emotion from the"      
##  [9994] "consciousness of being only eighty miles from Barton, and not thirty"        
##  [9995] "from Combe Magna; and before she had been five minutes within its"           
##  [9996] "walls, while the others were busily helping Charlotte to show her child"     
##  [9997] "to the housekeeper, she quitted it again, stealing away through the"         
##  [9998] "winding shrubberies, now just beginning to be in beauty, to gain a"          
##  [9999] "distant eminence; where, from its Grecian temple, her eye, wandering"        
## [10000] "over a wide tract of country to the south-east, could fondly rest on"        
## [10001] "the farthest ridge of hills in the horizon, and fancy that from their"       
## [10002] "summits Combe Magna might be seen."                                          
## [10003] ""                                                                            
## [10004] "In such moments of precious, invaluable misery, she rejoiced in tears"       
## [10005] "of agony to be at Cleveland; and as she returned by a different circuit"     
## [10006] "to the house, feeling all the happy privilege of country liberty, of"        
## [10007] "wandering from place to place in free and luxurious solitude, she"           
## [10008] "resolved to spend almost every hour of every day while she remained"         
## [10009] "with the Palmers, in the indulgence of such solitary rambles."               
## [10010] ""                                                                            
## [10011] "She returned just in time to join the others as they quitted the house,"     
## [10012] "on an excursion through its more immediate premises; and the rest of"        
## [10013] "the morning was easily whiled away, in lounging round the kitchen"           
## [10014] "garden, examining the bloom upon its walls, and listening to the"            
## [10015] "gardener's lamentations upon blights, in dawdling through the"               
## [10016] "green-house, where the loss of her favourite plants, unwarily exposed,"      
## [10017] "and nipped by the lingering frost, raised the laughter of"                   
## [10018] "Charlotte,--and in visiting her poultry-yard, where, in the"                 
## [10019] "disappointed hopes of her dairy-maid, by hens forsaking their nests, or"     
## [10020] "being stolen by a fox, or in the rapid decrease of a promising young"        
## [10021] "brood, she found fresh sources of merriment."                                
## [10022] ""                                                                            
## [10023] "The morning was fine and dry, and Marianne, in her plan of employment"       
## [10024] "abroad, had not calculated for any change of weather during their stay"      
## [10025] "at Cleveland.  With great surprise therefore, did she find herself"          
## [10026] "prevented by a settled rain from going out again after dinner.  She had"     
## [10027] "depended on a twilight walk to the Grecian temple, and perhaps all over"     
## [10028] "the grounds, and an evening merely cold or damp would not have deterred"     
## [10029] "her from it; but a heavy and settled rain even SHE could not fancy dry"      
## [10030] "or pleasant weather for walking."                                            
## [10031] ""                                                                            
## [10032] "Their party was small, and the hours passed quietly away.  Mrs. Palmer"      
## [10033] "had her child, and Mrs. Jennings her carpet-work; they talked of the"        
## [10034] "friends they had left behind, arranged Lady Middleton's engagements,"        
## [10035] "and wondered whether Mr. Palmer and Colonel Brandon would get farther"       
## [10036] "than Reading that night.  Elinor, however little concerned in it,"           
## [10037] "joined in their discourse; and Marianne, who had the knack of finding"       
## [10038] "her way in every house to the library, however it might be avoided by"       
## [10039] "the family in general, soon procured herself a book."                        
## [10040] ""                                                                            
## [10041] "Nothing was wanting on Mrs. Palmer's side that constant and friendly"        
## [10042] "good humour could do, to make them feel themselves welcome.  The"            
## [10043] "openness and heartiness of her manner more than atoned for that want of"     
## [10044] "recollection and elegance which made her often deficient in the forms"       
## [10045] "of politeness; her kindness, recommended by so pretty a face, was"           
## [10046] "engaging; her folly, though evident was not disgusting, because it was"      
## [10047] "not conceited; and Elinor could have forgiven every thing but her laugh."    
## [10048] ""                                                                            
## [10049] "The two gentlemen arrived the next day to a very late dinner, affording"     
## [10050] "a pleasant enlargement of the party, and a very welcome variety to"          
## [10051] "their conversation, which a long morning of the same continued rain had"     
## [10052] "reduced very low."                                                           
## [10053] ""                                                                            
## [10054] "Elinor had seen so little of Mr. Palmer, and in that little had seen so"     
## [10055] "much variety in his address to her sister and herself, that she knew"        
## [10056] "not what to expect to find him in his own family.  She found him,"           
## [10057] "however, perfectly the gentleman in his behaviour to all his visitors,"      
## [10058] "and only occasionally rude to his wife and her mother; she found him"        
## [10059] "very capable of being a pleasant companion, and only prevented from"         
## [10060] "being so always, by too great an aptitude to fancy himself as much"          
## [10061] "superior to people in general, as he must feel himself to be to Mrs."        
## [10062] "Jennings and Charlotte.  For the rest of his character and habits, they"     
## [10063] "were marked, as far as Elinor could perceive, with no traits at all"         
## [10064] "unusual in his sex and time of life.  He was nice in his eating,"            
## [10065] "uncertain in his hours; fond of his child, though affecting to slight"       
## [10066] "it; and idled away the mornings at billiards, which ought to have been"      
## [10067] "devoted to business.  She liked him, however, upon the whole, much"          
## [10068] "better than she had expected, and in her heart was not sorry that she"       
## [10069] "could like him no more;--not sorry to be driven by the observation of"       
## [10070] "his Epicurism, his selfishness, and his conceit, to rest with"               
## [10071] "complacency on the remembrance of Edward's generous temper, simple"          
## [10072] "taste, and diffident feelings."                                              
## [10073] ""                                                                            
## [10074] "Of Edward, or at least of some of his concerns, she now received"            
## [10075] "intelligence from Colonel Brandon, who had been into Dorsetshire"            
## [10076] "lately; and who, treating her at once as the disinterested friend of"        
## [10077] "Mr. Ferrars, and the kind confidante of himself, talked to her a"            
## [10078] "great deal of the parsonage at Delaford, described its deficiencies,"        
## [10079] "and told her what he meant to do himself towards removing them.--His"        
## [10080] "behaviour to her in this, as well as in every other particular, his"         
## [10081] "open pleasure in meeting her after an absence of only ten days, his"         
## [10082] "readiness to converse with her, and his deference for her opinion,"          
## [10083] "might very well justify Mrs. Jennings's persuasion of his attachment,"       
## [10084] "and would have been enough, perhaps, had not Elinor still, as from the"      
## [10085] "first, believed Marianne his real favourite, to make her suspect it"         
## [10086] "herself.  But as it was, such a notion had scarcely ever entered her"        
## [10087] "head, except by Mrs. Jennings's suggestion; and she could not help"          
## [10088] "believing herself the nicest observer of the two;--she watched his"          
## [10089] "eyes, while Mrs. Jennings thought only of his behaviour;--and while his"     
## [10090] "looks of anxious solicitude on Marianne's feeling, in her head and"          
## [10091] "throat, the beginning of a heavy cold, because unexpressed by words,"        
## [10092] "entirely escaped the latter lady's observation;--SHE could discover in"      
## [10093] "them the quick feelings, and needless alarm of a lover."                     
## [10094] ""                                                                            
## [10095] "Two delightful twilight walks on the third and fourth evenings of her"       
## [10096] "being there, not merely on the dry gravel of the shrubbery, but all"         
## [10097] "over the grounds, and especially in the most distant parts of them,"         
## [10098] "where there was something more of wildness than in the rest, where the"      
## [10099] "trees were the oldest, and the grass was the longest and wettest,"           
## [10100] "had--assisted by the still greater imprudence of sitting in her wet"         
## [10101] "shoes and stockings--given Marianne a cold so violent as, though for a"      
## [10102] "day or two trifled with or denied, would force itself by increasing"         
## [10103] "ailments on the concern of every body, and the notice of herself."           
## [10104] "Prescriptions poured in from all quarters, and as usual, were all"           
## [10105] "declined.  Though heavy and feverish, with a pain in her limbs, and a"       
## [10106] "cough, and a sore throat, a good night's rest was to cure her entirely;"     
## [10107] "and it was with difficulty that Elinor prevailed on her, when she went"      
## [10108] "to bed, to try one or two of the simplest of the remedies."                  
## [10109] ""                                                                            
## [10110] ""                                                                            
## [10111] ""                                                                            
## [10112] "CHAPTER 43"                                                                  
## [10113] ""                                                                            
## [10114] ""                                                                            
## [10115] "Marianne got up the next morning at her usual time; to every inquiry"        
## [10116] "replied that she was better, and tried to prove herself so, by engaging"     
## [10117] "in her accustomary employments.  But a day spent in sitting shivering"       
## [10118] "over the fire with a book in her hand, which she was unable to read, or"     
## [10119] "in lying, weary and languid, on a sofa, did not speak much in favour of"     
## [10120] "her amendment; and when, at last, she went early to bed, more and more"      
## [10121] "indisposed, Colonel Brandon was only astonished at her sister's"             
## [10122] "composure, who, though attending and nursing her the whole day, against"     
## [10123] "Marianne's inclination, and forcing proper medicines on her at night,"       
## [10124] "trusted, like Marianne, to the certainty and efficacy of sleep, and"         
## [10125] "felt no real alarm."                                                         
## [10126] ""                                                                            
## [10127] "A very restless and feverish night, however, disappointed the"               
## [10128] "expectation of both; and when Marianne, after persisting in rising,"         
## [10129] "confessed herself unable to sit up, and returned voluntarily to her"         
## [10130] "bed, Elinor was very ready to adopt Mrs. Jennings's advice, of sending"      
## [10131] "for the Palmers' apothecary."                                                
## [10132] ""                                                                            
## [10133] "He came, examined his patient, and though encouraging Miss Dashwood to"      
## [10134] "expect that a very few days would restore her sister to health, yet, by"     
## [10135] "pronouncing her disorder to have a putrid tendency, and allowing the"        
## [10136] "word \"infection\" to pass his lips, gave instant alarm to Mrs. Palmer,"     
## [10137] "on her baby's account.  Mrs. Jennings, who had been inclined from the"       
## [10138] "first to think Marianne's complaint more serious than Elinor, now"           
## [10139] "looked very grave on Mr. Harris's report, and confirming Charlotte's"        
## [10140] "fears and caution, urged the necessity of her immediate removal with"        
## [10141] "her infant; and Mr. Palmer, though treating their apprehensions as"          
## [10142] "idle, found the anxiety and importunity of his wife too great to be"         
## [10143] "withstood.  Her departure, therefore, was fixed on; and within an hour"      
## [10144] "after Mr. Harris's arrival, she set off, with her little boy and his"        
## [10145] "nurse, for the house of a near relation of Mr. Palmer's, who lived a"        
## [10146] "few miles on the other side of Bath; whither her husband promised, at"       
## [10147] "her earnest entreaty, to join her in a day or two; and whither she was"      
## [10148] "almost equally urgent with her mother to accompany her.  Mrs. Jennings,"     
## [10149] "however, with a kindness of heart which made Elinor really love her,"        
## [10150] "declared her resolution of not stirring from Cleveland as long as"           
## [10151] "Marianne remained ill, and of endeavouring, by her own attentive care,"      
## [10152] "to supply to her the place of the mother she had taken her from; and"        
## [10153] "Elinor found her on every occasion a most willing and active helpmate,"      
## [10154] "desirous to share in all her fatigues, and often by her better"              
## [10155] "experience in nursing, of material use."                                     
## [10156] ""                                                                            
## [10157] "Poor Marianne, languid and low from the nature of her malady, and"           
## [10158] "feeling herself universally ill, could no longer hope that tomorrow"         
## [10159] "would find her recovered; and the idea of what tomorrow would have"          
## [10160] "produced, but for this unlucky illness, made every ailment severe; for"      
## [10161] "on that day they were to have begun their journey home; and, attended"       
## [10162] "the whole way by a servant of Mrs. Jennings, were to have taken their"       
## [10163] "mother by surprise on the following forenoon.  The little she said was"      
## [10164] "all in lamentation of this inevitable delay; though Elinor tried to"         
## [10165] "raise her spirits, and make her believe, as she THEN really believed"        
## [10166] "herself, that it would be a very short one."                                 
## [10167] ""                                                                            
## [10168] "The next day produced little or no alteration in the state of the"           
## [10169] "patient; she certainly was not better, and, except that there was no"        
## [10170] "amendment, did not appear worse.  Their party was now farther reduced;"      
## [10171] "for Mr. Palmer, though very unwilling to go as well from real humanity"      
## [10172] "and good-nature, as from a dislike of appearing to be frightened away"       
## [10173] "by his wife, was persuaded at last by Colonel Brandon to perform his"        
## [10174] "promise of following her; and while he was preparing to go, Colonel"         
## [10175] "Brandon himself, with a much greater exertion, began to talk of going"       
## [10176] "likewise.--Here, however, the kindness of Mrs. Jennings interposed most"     
## [10177] "acceptably; for to send the Colonel away while his love was in so much"      
## [10178] "uneasiness on her sister's account, would be to deprive them both, she"      
## [10179] "thought, of every comfort; and therefore telling him at once that his"       
## [10180] "stay at Cleveland was necessary to herself, that she should want him to"     
## [10181] "play at piquet of an evening, while Miss Dashwood was above with her"        
## [10182] "sister, &c. she urged him so strongly to remain, that he, who was"           
## [10183] "gratifying the first wish of his own heart by a compliance, could not"       
## [10184] "long even affect to demur; especially as Mrs. Jennings's entreaty was"       
## [10185] "warmly seconded by Mr. Palmer, who seemed to feel a relief to himself,"      
## [10186] "in leaving behind him a person so well able to assist or advise Miss"        
## [10187] "Dashwood in any emergence."                                                  
## [10188] ""                                                                            
## [10189] "Marianne was, of course, kept in ignorance of all these arrangements."       
## [10190] "She knew not that she had been the means of sending the owners of"           
## [10191] "Cleveland away, in about seven days from the time of their arrival.  It"     
## [10192] "gave her no surprise that she saw nothing of Mrs. Palmer; and as it"         
## [10193] "gave her likewise no concern, she never mentioned her name."                 
## [10194] ""                                                                            
## [10195] "Two days passed away from the time of Mr. Palmer's departure, and her"       
## [10196] "situation continued, with little variation, the same.  Mr. Harris, who"      
## [10197] "attended her every day, still talked boldly of a speedy recovery, and"       
## [10198] "Miss Dashwood was equally sanguine; but the expectation of the others"       
## [10199] "was by no means so cheerful.  Mrs. Jennings had determined very early"       
## [10200] "in the seizure that Marianne would never get over it, and Colonel"           
## [10201] "Brandon, who was chiefly of use in listening to Mrs. Jennings's"             
## [10202] "forebodings, was not in a state of mind to resist their influence.  He"      
## [10203] "tried to reason himself out of fears, which the different judgment of"       
## [10204] "the apothecary seemed to render absurd; but the many hours of each day"      
## [10205] "in which he was left entirely alone, were but too favourable for the"        
## [10206] "admission of every melancholy idea, and he could not expel from his"         
## [10207] "mind the persuasion that he should see Marianne no more."                    
## [10208] ""                                                                            
## [10209] "On the morning of the third day however, the gloomy anticipations of"        
## [10210] "both were almost done away; for when Mr. Harris arrived, he declared"        
## [10211] "his patient materially better.  Her pulse was much stronger, and every"      
## [10212] "symptom more favourable than on the preceding visit.  Elinor, confirmed"     
## [10213] "in every pleasant hope, was all cheerfulness; rejoicing that in her"         
## [10214] "letters to her mother, she had pursued her own judgment rather than her"     
## [10215] "friend's, in making very light of the indisposition which delayed them"      
## [10216] "at Cleveland; and almost fixing on the time when Marianne would be able"     
## [10217] "to travel."                                                                  
## [10218] ""                                                                            
## [10219] "But the day did not close so auspiciously as it began.-- Towards the"        
## [10220] "evening Marianne became ill again, growing more heavy, restless, and"        
## [10221] "uncomfortable than before.  Her sister, however, still sanguine, was"        
## [10222] "willing to attribute the change to nothing more than the fatigue of"         
## [10223] "having sat up to have her bed made; and carefully administering the"         
## [10224] "cordials prescribed, saw her, with satisfaction, sink at last into a"        
## [10225] "slumber, from which she expected the most beneficial effects.  Her"          
## [10226] "sleep, though not so quiet as Elinor wished to see it, lasted a"             
## [10227] "considerable time; and anxious to observe the result of it herself, she"     
## [10228] "resolved to sit with her during the whole of it.  Mrs. Jennings,"            
## [10229] "knowing nothing of any change in the patient, went unusually early to"       
## [10230] "bed; her maid, who was one of the principal nurses, was recreating"          
## [10231] "herself in the housekeeper's room, and Elinor remained alone with"           
## [10232] "Marianne."                                                                   
## [10233] ""                                                                            
## [10234] "The repose of the latter became more and more disturbed; and her"            
## [10235] "sister, who watched, with unremitting attention her continual change of"     
## [10236] "posture, and heard the frequent but inarticulate sounds of complaint"        
## [10237] "which passed her lips, was almost wishing to rouse her from so painful"      
## [10238] "a slumber, when Marianne, suddenly awakened by some accidental noise in"     
## [10239] "the house, started hastily up, and, with feverish wildness, cried out,--"    
## [10240] ""                                                                            
## [10241] "\"Is mama coming?--\""                                                       
## [10242] ""                                                                            
## [10243] "\"Not yet,\" cried the other, concealing her terror, and assisting"          
## [10244] "Marianne to lie down again, \"but she will be here, I hope, before it is"    
## [10245] "long.  It is a great way, you know, from hence to Barton.\""                 
## [10246] ""                                                                            
## [10247] "\"But she must not go round by London,\" cried Marianne, in the same"        
## [10248] "hurried manner.  \"I shall never see her, if she goes by London.\""          
## [10249] ""                                                                            
## [10250] "Elinor perceived with alarm that she was not quite herself, and, while"      
## [10251] "attempting to soothe her, eagerly felt her pulse.  It was lower and"         
## [10252] "quicker than ever!  and Marianne, still talking wildly of mama, her"         
## [10253] "alarm increased so rapidly, as to determine her on sending instantly"        
## [10254] "for Mr. Harris, and despatching a messenger to Barton for her mother."       
## [10255] "To consult with Colonel Brandon on the best means of effecting the"          
## [10256] "latter, was a thought which immediately followed the resolution of its"      
## [10257] "performance; and as soon she had rung up the maid to take her place by"      
## [10258] "her sister, she hastened down to the drawing-room, where she knew he"        
## [10259] "was generally to be found at a much later hour than the present."            
## [10260] ""                                                                            
## [10261] "It was no time for hesitation.  Her fears and her difficulties were"         
## [10262] "immediately before him.  Her fears, he had no courage, no confidence to"     
## [10263] "attempt the removal of:--he listened to them in silent despondence;--but"    
## [10264] "her difficulties were instantly obviated, for with a readiness that"         
## [10265] "seemed to speak the occasion, and the service pre-arranged in his mind,"     
## [10266] "he offered himself as the messenger who should fetch Mrs. Dashwood."         
## [10267] "Elinor made no resistance that was not easily overcome. She thanked him"     
## [10268] "with brief, though fervent gratitude, and while he went to hurry off his"    
## [10269] "servant with a message to Mr. Harris, and an order for post-horses"          
## [10270] "directly, she wrote a few lines to her mother."                              
## [10271] ""                                                                            
## [10272] "The comfort of such a friend at that moment as Colonel Brandon--or such"     
## [10273] "a companion for her mother,--how gratefully was it felt!--a companion"       
## [10274] "whose judgment would guide, whose attendance must relieve, and whose"        
## [10275] "friendship might soothe her!--as far as the shock of such a summons"         
## [10276] "COULD be lessened to her, his presence, his manners, his assistance,"        
## [10277] "would lessen it."                                                            
## [10278] ""                                                                            
## [10279] "HE, meanwhile, whatever he might feel, acted with all the firmness of a"     
## [10280] "collected mind, made every necessary arrangement with the utmost"            
## [10281] "despatch, and calculated with exactness the time in which she might"         
## [10282] "look for his return.  Not a moment was lost in delay of any kind.  The"      
## [10283] "horses arrived, even before they were expected, and Colonel Brandon"         
## [10284] "only pressing her hand with a look of solemnity, and a few words spoken"     
## [10285] "too low to reach her ear, hurried into the carriage.  It was then about"     
## [10286] "twelve o'clock, and she returned to her sister's apartment to wait for"      
## [10287] "the arrival of the apothecary, and to watch by her the rest of the"          
## [10288] "night.  It was a night of almost equal suffering to both.  Hour after"       
## [10289] "hour passed away in sleepless pain and delirium on Marianne's side, and"     
## [10290] "in the most cruel anxiety on Elinor's, before Mr. Harris appeared.  Her"     
## [10291] "apprehensions once raised, paid by their excess for all her former"          
## [10292] "security; and the servant who sat up with her, for she would not allow"      
## [10293] "Mrs. Jennings to be called, only tortured her more, by hints of what"        
## [10294] "her mistress had always thought."                                            
## [10295] ""                                                                            
## [10296] "Marianne's ideas were still, at intervals, fixed incoherently on her"        
## [10297] "mother, and whenever she mentioned her name, it gave a pang to the"          
## [10298] "heart of poor Elinor, who, reproaching herself for having trifled with"      
## [10299] "so many days of illness, and wretched for some immediate relief,"            
## [10300] "fancied that all relief might soon be in vain, that every thing had"         
## [10301] "been delayed too long, and pictured to herself her suffering mother"         
## [10302] "arriving too late to see this darling child, or to see her rational."        
## [10303] ""                                                                            
## [10304] "She was on the point of sending again for Mr. Harris, or if HE could"        
## [10305] "not come, for some other advice, when the former--but not till after"        
## [10306] "five o'clock--arrived.  His opinion, however, made some little amends"       
## [10307] "for his delay, for though acknowledging a very unexpected and"               
## [10308] "unpleasant alteration in his patient, he would not allow the danger to"      
## [10309] "be material, and talked of the relief which a fresh mode of treatment"       
## [10310] "must procure, with a confidence which, in a lesser degree, was"              
## [10311] "communicated to Elinor.  He promised to call again in the course of"         
## [10312] "three or four hours, and left both the patient and her anxious"              
## [10313] "attendant more composed than he had found them."                             
## [10314] ""                                                                            
## [10315] "With strong concern, and with many reproaches for not being called to"       
## [10316] "their aid, did Mrs. Jennings hear in the morning of what had passed."        
## [10317] "Her former apprehensions, now with greater reason restored, left her no"     
## [10318] "doubt of the event; and though trying to speak comfort to Elinor, her"       
## [10319] "conviction of her sister's danger would not allow her to offer the"          
## [10320] "comfort of hope.  Her heart was really grieved.  The rapid decay, the"       
## [10321] "early death of a girl so young, so lovely as Marianne, must have struck"     
## [10322] "a less interested person with concern.  On Mrs. Jennings's compassion"       
## [10323] "she had other claims.  She had been for three months her companion, was"     
## [10324] "still under her care, and she was known to have been greatly injured,"       
## [10325] "and long unhappy.  The distress of her sister too, particularly a"           
## [10326] "favourite, was before her;--and as for their mother, when Mrs. Jennings"     
## [10327] "considered that Marianne might probably be to HER what Charlotte was to"     
## [10328] "herself, her sympathy in HER sufferings was very sincere."                   
## [10329] ""                                                                            
## [10330] "Mr. Harris was punctual in his second visit;--but he came to be"             
## [10331] "disappointed in his hopes of what the last would produce.  His"              
## [10332] "medicines had failed;--the fever was unabated; and Marianne only more"       
## [10333] "quiet--not more herself--remained in a heavy stupor.  Elinor, catching"      
## [10334] "all, and more than all, his fears in a moment, proposed to call in"          
## [10335] "further advice.  But he judged it unnecessary: he had still something"       
## [10336] "more to try, some more fresh application, of whose success he was as"        
## [10337] "confident as the last, and his visit concluded with encouraging"             
## [10338] "assurances which reached the ear, but could not enter the heart of Miss"     
## [10339] "Dashwood.  She was calm, except when she thought of her mother; but she"     
## [10340] "was almost hopeless; and in this state she continued till noon,"             
## [10341] "scarcely stirring from her sister's bed, her thoughts wandering from"        
## [10342] "one image of grief, one suffering friend to another, and her spirits"        
## [10343] "oppressed to the utmost by the conversation of Mrs. Jennings, who"           
## [10344] "scrupled not to attribute the severity and danger of this attack to the"     
## [10345] "many weeks of previous indisposition which Marianne's disappointment"        
## [10346] "had brought on.  Elinor felt all the reasonableness of the idea, and it"     
## [10347] "gave fresh misery to her reflections."                                       
## [10348] ""                                                                            
## [10349] "About noon, however, she began--but with a caution--a dread of"              
## [10350] "disappointment which for some time kept her silent, even to her"             
## [10351] "friend--to fancy, to hope she could perceive a slight amendment in her"      
## [10352] "sister's pulse;--she waited, watched, and examined it again and"             
## [10353] "again;--and at last, with an agitation more difficult to bury under"         
## [10354] "exterior calmness, than all her foregoing distress, ventured to"
