## [10355] "communicate her hopes.  Mrs. Jennings, though forced, on examination,"       
## [10356] "to acknowledge a temporary revival, tried to keep her young friend from"     
## [10357] "indulging a thought of its continuance;--and Elinor, conning over every"     
## [10358] "injunction of distrust, told herself likewise not to hope.  But it was"      
## [10359] "too late.  Hope had already entered; and feeling all its anxious"            
## [10360] "flutter, she bent over her sister to watch--she hardly knew for what."       
## [10361] "Half an hour passed away, and the favourable symptom yet blessed her."       
## [10362] "Others even arose to confirm it.  Her breath, her skin, her lips, all"       
## [10363] "flattered Elinor with signs of amendment; and Marianne fixed her eyes"       
## [10364] "on her with a rational, though languid, gaze.  Anxiety and hope now"         
## [10365] "oppressed her in equal degrees, and left her no moment of tranquillity"      
## [10366] "till the arrival of Mr. Harris at four o'clock;--when his assurances,"       
## [10367] "his felicitations on a recovery in her sister even surpassing his"           
## [10368] "expectation, gave her confidence, comfort, and tears of joy."                
## [10369] ""                                                                            
## [10370] "Marianne was in every respect materially better, and he declared her"        
## [10371] "entirely out of danger.  Mrs. Jennings, perhaps satisfied with the"          
## [10372] "partial justification of her forebodings which had been found in their"      
## [10373] "late alarm, allowed herself to trust in his judgment, and admitted,"         
## [10374] "with unfeigned joy, and soon with unequivocal cheerfulness, the"             
## [10375] "probability of an entire recovery."                                          
## [10376] ""                                                                            
## [10377] "Elinor could not be cheerful.  Her joy was of a different kind, and led"     
## [10378] "to any thing rather than to gaiety.  Marianne restored to life, health,"     
## [10379] "friends, and to her doting mother, was an idea to fill her heart with"       
## [10380] "sensations of exquisite comfort, and expand it in fervent"                   
## [10381] "gratitude;--but it led to no outward demonstrations of joy, no words,"       
## [10382] "no smiles.  All within Elinor's breast was satisfaction, silent and"         
## [10383] "strong."                                                                     
## [10384] ""                                                                            
## [10385] "She continued by the side of her sister, with little intermission the"       
## [10386] "whole afternoon, calming every fear, satisfying every inquiry of her"        
## [10387] "enfeebled spirits, supplying every succour, and watching almost every"       
## [10388] "look and every breath.  The possibility of a relapse would of course,"       
## [10389] "in some moments, occur to remind her of what anxiety was--but when she"      
## [10390] "saw, on her frequent and minute examination, that every symptom of"          
## [10391] "recovery continued, and saw Marianne at six o'clock sink into a quiet,"      
## [10392] "steady, and to all appearance comfortable, sleep, she silenced every"        
## [10393] "doubt."                                                                      
## [10394] ""                                                                            
## [10395] "The time was now drawing on, when Colonel Brandon might be expected"         
## [10396] "back.  At ten o'clock, she trusted, or at least not much later her"          
## [10397] "mother would be relieved from the dreadful suspense in which she must"       
## [10398] "now be travelling towards them.  The Colonel, too!--perhaps scarcely"        
## [10399] "less an object of pity!--Oh!--how slow was the progress of time which"       
## [10400] "yet kept them in ignorance!"                                                 
## [10401] ""                                                                            
## [10402] "At seven o'clock, leaving Marianne still sweetly asleep, she joined"         
## [10403] "Mrs. Jennings in the drawing-room to tea.  Of breakfast she had been"        
## [10404] "kept by her fears, and of dinner by their sudden reverse, from eating"       
## [10405] "much;--and the present refreshment, therefore, with such feelings of"        
## [10406] "content as she brought to it, was particularly welcome.  Mrs. Jennings"      
## [10407] "would have persuaded her, at its conclusion, to take some rest before"       
## [10408] "her mother's arrival, and allow HER to take her place by Marianne; but"      
## [10409] "Elinor had no sense of fatigue, no capability of sleep at that moment"       
## [10410] "about her, and she was not to be kept away from her sister an"               
## [10411] "unnecessary instant.  Mrs. Jennings therefore attending her up stairs"       
## [10412] "into the sick chamber, to satisfy herself that all continued right,"         
## [10413] "left her there again to her charge and her thoughts, and retired to her"     
## [10414] "own room to write letters and sleep."                                        
## [10415] ""                                                                            
## [10416] "The night was cold and stormy.  The wind roared round the house, and"        
## [10417] "the rain beat against the windows; but Elinor, all happiness within,"        
## [10418] "regarded it not.  Marianne slept through every blast; and the"               
## [10419] "travellers--they had a rich reward in store, for every present"              
## [10420] "inconvenience."                                                              
## [10421] ""                                                                            
## [10422] "The clock struck eight.  Had it been ten, Elinor would have been"            
## [10423] "convinced that at that moment she heard a carriage driving up to the"        
## [10424] "house; and so strong was the persuasion that she DID, in spite of the"       
## [10425] "ALMOST impossibility of their being already come, that she moved into"       
## [10426] "the adjoining dressing-closet and opened a window shutter, to be"            
## [10427] "satisfied of the truth.  She instantly saw that her ears had not"            
## [10428] "deceived her.  The flaring lamps of a carriage were immediately in"          
## [10429] "view.  By their uncertain light she thought she could discern it to be"      
## [10430] "drawn by four horses; and this, while it told the excess of her poor"        
## [10431] "mother's alarm, gave some explanation to such unexpected rapidity."          
## [10432] ""                                                                            
## [10433] "Never in her life had Elinor found it so difficult to be calm, as at"        
## [10434] "that moment.  The knowledge of what her mother must be feeling as the"       
## [10435] "carriage stopt at the door--of her doubt--her dread--perhaps her"            
## [10436] "despair!--and of what SHE had to tell!--with such knowledge it was"          
## [10437] "impossible to be calm.  All that remained to be done was to be speedy;"      
## [10438] "and, therefore staying only till she could leave Mrs. Jennings's maid"       
## [10439] "with her sister, she hurried down stairs."                                   
## [10440] ""                                                                            
## [10441] "The bustle in the vestibule, as she passed along an inner lobby,"            
## [10442] "assured her that they were already in the house.  She rushed to the"         
## [10443] "drawing-room,--she entered it,--and saw only Willoughby."                    
## [10444] ""                                                                            
## [10445] ""                                                                            
## [10446] ""                                                                            
## [10447] "CHAPTER 44"                                                                  
## [10448] ""                                                                            
## [10449] ""                                                                            
## [10450] "Elinor, starting back with a look of horror at the sight of him, obeyed"     
## [10451] "the first impulse of her heart in turning instantly to quit the room,"       
## [10452] "and her hand was already on the lock, when its action was suspended by"      
## [10453] "his hastily advancing, and saying, in a voice rather of command than"        
## [10454] "supplication,"                                                               
## [10455] ""                                                                            
## [10456] "\"Miss Dashwood, for half an hour--for ten minutes--I entreat you to"        
## [10457] "stay.\""                                                                     
## [10458] ""                                                                            
## [10459] "\"No, sir,\" she replied with firmness, \"I shall NOT stay.  Your business"  
## [10460] "cannot be with ME.  The servants, I suppose, forgot to tell you that"        
## [10461] "Mr. Palmer was not in the house.\""                                          
## [10462] ""                                                                            
## [10463] "\"Had they told me,\" he cried with vehemence, \"that Mr. Palmer and all"    
## [10464] "his relations were at the devil, it would not have turned me from the"       
## [10465] "door.  My business is with you, and only you.\""                             
## [10466] ""                                                                            
## [10467] "\"With me!\"--in the utmost amazement--\"well, sir,--be quick--and if you"   
## [10468] "can--less violent.\""                                                        
## [10469] ""                                                                            
## [10470] "\"Sit down, and I will be both.\""                                           
## [10471] ""                                                                            
## [10472] "She hesitated; she knew not what to do.  The possibility of Colonel"         
## [10473] "Brandon's arriving and finding her there, came across her.  But she had"     
## [10474] "promised to hear him, and her curiosity no less than her honor was"          
## [10475] "engaged.  After a moment's recollection, therefore, concluding that"         
## [10476] "prudence required dispatch, and that her acquiescence would best"            
## [10477] "promote it, she walked silently towards the table, and sat down.  He"        
## [10478] "took the opposite chair, and for half a minute not a word was said by"       
## [10479] "either."                                                                     
## [10480] ""                                                                            
## [10481] "\"Pray be quick, sir,\"--said Elinor, impatiently;--\"I have no time to"     
## [10482] "spare.\""                                                                    
## [10483] ""                                                                            
## [10484] "He was sitting in an attitude of deep meditation, and seemed not to"         
## [10485] "hear her."                                                                   
## [10486] ""                                                                            
## [10487] "\"Your sister,\" said he, with abruptness, a moment afterwards--\"is out"    
## [10488] "of danger.  I heard it from the servant.  God be praised!--But is it"        
## [10489] "true? is it really true?\""                                                  
## [10490] ""                                                                            
## [10491] "Elinor would not speak.  He repeated the inquiry with yet greater"           
## [10492] "eagerness."                                                                  
## [10493] ""                                                                            
## [10494] "\"For God's sake tell me, is she out of danger, or is she not?\""            
## [10495] ""                                                                            
## [10496] "\"We hope she is.\""                                                         
## [10497] ""                                                                            
## [10498] "He rose up, and walked across the room."                                     
## [10499] ""                                                                            
## [10500] "\"Had I known as much half an hour ago--But since I AM here,\"--speaking"    
## [10501] "with a forced vivacity as he returned to his seat--\"what does it"           
## [10502] "signify?--For once, Miss Dashwood--it will be the last time,"                
## [10503] "perhaps--let us be cheerful together.--I am in a fine mood for"              
## [10504] "gaiety.-- Tell me honestly\"--a deeper glow overspreading his"               
## [10505] "cheeks--\"do you think me most a knave or a fool?\""                         
## [10506] ""                                                                            
## [10507] "Elinor looked at him with greater astonishment than ever.  She began to"     
## [10508] "think that he must be in liquor;--the strangeness of such a visit, and"      
## [10509] "of such manners, seemed no otherwise intelligible; and with this"            
## [10510] "impression she immediately rose, saying,"                                    
## [10511] ""                                                                            
## [10512] "\"Mr. Willoughby, I advise you at present to return to Combe--I am not"      
## [10513] "at leisure to remain with you longer.-- Whatever your business may be"       
## [10514] "with me, it will be better recollected and explained to-morrow.\""           
## [10515] ""                                                                            
## [10516] "\"I understand you,\" he replied, with an expressive smile, and a voice"     
## [10517] "perfectly calm; \"yes, I am very drunk.-- A pint of porter with my cold"     
## [10518] "beef at Marlborough was enough to over-set me.\""                            
## [10519] ""                                                                            
## [10520] "\"At Marlborough!\"--cried Elinor, more and more at a loss to understand"    
## [10521] "what he would be at."                                                        
## [10522] ""                                                                            
## [10523] "\"Yes,--I left London this morning at eight o'clock, and the only ten"       
## [10524] "minutes I have spent out of my chaise since that time procured me a"         
## [10525] "nuncheon at Marlborough.\""                                                  
## [10526] ""                                                                            
## [10527] "The steadiness of his manner, and the intelligence of his eye as he"         
## [10528] "spoke, convincing Elinor, that whatever other unpardonable folly might"      
## [10529] "bring him to Cleveland, he was not brought there by intoxication, she"       
## [10530] "said, after a moment's recollection,"                                        
## [10531] ""                                                                            
## [10532] "\"Mr. Willoughby, you OUGHT to feel, and I certainly DO--that after what"    
## [10533] "has passed--your coming here in this manner, and forcing yourself upon"      
## [10534] "my notice, requires a very particular excuse.--What is it, that you"         
## [10535] "mean by it?\"--"                                                             
## [10536] ""                                                                            
## [10537] "\"I mean,\"--said he, with serious energy--\"if I can, to make you hate me"  
## [10538] "one degree less than you do NOW.  I mean to offer some kind of"              
## [10539] "explanation, some kind of apology, for the past; to open my whole heart"     
## [10540] "to you, and by convincing you, that though I have been always a"             
## [10541] "blockhead, I have not been always a rascal, to obtain something like"        
## [10542] "forgiveness from Ma--from your sister.\""                                    
## [10543] ""                                                                            
## [10544] "\"Is this the real reason of your coming?\""                                 
## [10545] ""                                                                            
## [10546] "\"Upon my soul it is,\"--was his answer, with a warmth which brought all"    
## [10547] "the former Willoughby to her remembrance, and in spite of herself made"      
## [10548] "her think him sincere."                                                      
## [10549] ""                                                                            
## [10550] "\"If that is all, you may be satisfied already,--for Marianne DOES--she"     
## [10551] "has LONG forgiven you.\""                                                    
## [10552] ""                                                                            
## [10553] "\"Has she?\"--he cried, in the same eager tone.-- \"Then she has forgiven"   
## [10554] "me before she ought to have done it.  But she shall forgive me again,"       
## [10555] "and on more reasonable grounds.--NOW will you listen to me?\""               
## [10556] ""                                                                            
## [10557] "Elinor bowed her assent."                                                    
## [10558] ""                                                                            
## [10559] "\"I do not know,\" said he, after a pause of expectation on her side, and"   
## [10560] "thoughtfulness on his own,--\"how YOU may have accounted for my"             
## [10561] "behaviour to your sister, or what diabolical motive you may have"            
## [10562] "imputed to me.-- Perhaps you will hardly think the better of me,--it is"     
## [10563] "worth the trial however, and you shall hear every thing.  When I first"      
## [10564] "became intimate in your family, I had no other intention, no other view"     
## [10565] "in the acquaintance than to pass my time pleasantly while I was obliged"     
## [10566] "to remain in Devonshire, more pleasantly than I had ever done before."       
## [10567] "Your sister's lovely person and interesting manners could not but"           
## [10568] "please me; and her behaviour to me almost from the first, was of a"          
## [10569] "kind--It is astonishing, when I reflect on what it was, and what SHE"        
## [10570] "was, that my heart should have been so insensible!  But at first I must"     
## [10571] "confess, my vanity only was elevated by it.  Careless of her happiness,"     
## [10572] "thinking only of my own amusement, giving way to feelings which I had"       
## [10573] "always been too much in the habit of indulging, I endeavoured, by every"     
## [10574] "means in my power, to make myself pleasing to her, without any design"       
## [10575] "of returning her affection.\""                                               
## [10576] ""                                                                            
## [10577] "Miss Dashwood, at this point, turning her eyes on him with the most"         
## [10578] "angry contempt, stopped him, by saying,"                                     
## [10579] ""                                                                            
## [10580] "\"It is hardly worth while, Mr. Willoughby, for you to relate, or for me"    
## [10581] "to listen any longer.  Such a beginning as this cannot be followed by"       
## [10582] "any thing.-- Do not let me be pained by hearing any thing more on the"       
## [10583] "subject.\""                                                                  
## [10584] ""                                                                            
## [10585] "\"I insist on you hearing the whole of it,\" he replied, \"My fortune was"   
## [10586] "never large, and I had always been expensive, always in the habit of"        
## [10587] "associating with people of better income than myself.  Every year since"     
## [10588] "my coming of age, or even before, I believe, had added to my debts; and"     
## [10589] "though the death of my old cousin, Mrs. Smith, was to set me free; yet"      
## [10590] "that event being uncertain, and possibly far distant, it had been for"       
## [10591] "some time my intention to re-establish my circumstances by marrying a"       
## [10592] "woman of fortune.  To attach myself to your sister, therefore, was not"      
## [10593] "a thing to be thought of;--and with a meanness, selfishness,"                
## [10594] "cruelty--which no indignant, no contemptuous look, even of yours, Miss"      
## [10595] "Dashwood, can ever reprobate too much--I was acting in this manner,"         
## [10596] "trying to engage her regard, without a thought of returning it.--But"        
## [10597] "one thing may be said for me: even in that horrid state of selfish"          
## [10598] "vanity, I did not know the extent of the injury I meditated, because I"      
## [10599] "did not THEN know what it was to love.  But have I ever known it?--Well"     
## [10600] "may it be doubted; for, had I really loved, could I have sacrificed my"      
## [10601] "feelings to vanity, to avarice?--or, what is more, could I have"             
## [10602] "sacrificed hers?-- But I have done it.  To avoid a comparative poverty,"     
## [10603] "which her affection and her society would have deprived of all its"          
## [10604] "horrors, I have, by raising myself to affluence, lost every thing that"      
## [10605] "could make it a blessing.\""                                                 
## [10606] ""                                                                            
## [10607] "\"You did then,\" said Elinor, a little softened, \"believe yourself at"     
## [10608] "one time attached to her?\""                                                 
## [10609] ""                                                                            
## [10610] "\"To have resisted such attractions, to have withstood such"                 
## [10611] "tenderness!--Is there a man on earth who could have done it?--Yes, I"        
## [10612] "found myself, by insensible degrees, sincerely fond of her; and the"         
## [10613] "happiest hours of my life were what I spent with her when I felt my"         
## [10614] "intentions were strictly honourable, and my feelings blameless.  Even"       
## [10615] "THEN, however, when fully determined on paying my addresses to her, I"       
## [10616] "allowed myself most improperly to put off, from day to day, the moment"      
## [10617] "of doing it, from an unwillingness to enter into an engagement while my"     
## [10618] "circumstances were so greatly embarrassed.  I will not reason here--nor"     
## [10619] "will I stop for YOU to expatiate on the absurdity, and the worse than"       
## [10620] "absurdity, of scrupling to engage my faith where my honour was already"      
## [10621] "bound.  The event has proved, that I was a cunning fool, providing with"     
## [10622] "great circumspection for a possible opportunity of making myself"            
## [10623] "contemptible and wretched for ever.  At last, however, my resolution"        
## [10624] "was taken, and I had determined, as soon as I could engage her alone,"       
## [10625] "to justify the attentions I had so invariably paid her, and openly"          
## [10626] "assure her of an affection which I had already taken such pains to"          
## [10627] "display.  But in the interim--in the interim of the very few hours that"     
## [10628] "were to pass, before I could have an opportunity of speaking with her"       
## [10629] "in private--a circumstance occurred--an unlucky circumstance, to ruin"       
## [10630] "all my resolution, and with it all my comfort.  A discovery took"            
## [10631] "place,\"--here he hesitated and looked down.--\"Mrs. Smith had somehow or"   
## [10632] "other been informed, I imagine by some distant relation, whose interest"     
## [10633] "it was to deprive me of her favour, of an affair, a connection--but I"       
## [10634] "need not explain myself farther,\" he added, looking at her with an"         
## [10635] "heightened colour and an enquiring eye--\"your particular intimacy--you"     
## [10636] "have probably heard the whole story long ago.\""                             
## [10637] ""                                                                            
## [10638] "\"I have,\" returned Elinor, colouring likewise, and hardening her heart"    
## [10639] "anew against any compassion for him, \"I have heard it all.  And how you"    
## [10640] "will explain away any part of your guilt in that dreadful business, I"       
## [10641] "confess is beyond my comprehension.\""                                       
## [10642] ""                                                                            
## [10643] "\"Remember,\" cried Willoughby, \"from whom you received the account."       
## [10644] "Could it be an impartial one?  I acknowledge that her situation and her"     
## [10645] "character ought to have been respected by me.  I do not mean to justify"     
## [10646] "myself, but at the same time cannot leave you to suppose that I have"        
## [10647] "nothing to urge--that because she was injured she was irreproachable,"       
## [10648] "and because I was a libertine, SHE must be a saint.  If the violence of"     
## [10649] "her passions, the weakness of her understanding--I do not mean,"             
## [10650] "however, to defend myself.  Her affection for me deserved better"            
## [10651] "treatment, and I often, with great self-reproach, recall the tenderness"     
## [10652] "which, for a very short time, had the power of creating any return.  I"      
## [10653] "wish--I heartily wish it had never been.  But I have injured more than"      
## [10654] "herself; and I have injured one, whose affection for me--(may I say"         
## [10655] "it?) was scarcely less warm than hers; and whose mind--Oh! how"              
## [10656] "infinitely superior!\"--"                                                    
## [10657] ""                                                                            
## [10658] "\"Your indifference, however, towards that unfortunate girl--I must say"     
## [10659] "it, unpleasant to me as the discussion of such a subject may well"           
## [10660] "be--your indifference is no apology for your cruel neglect of her.  Do"      
## [10661] "not think yourself excused by any weakness, any natural defect of"           
## [10662] "understanding on her side, in the wanton cruelty so evident on yours."       
## [10663] "You must have known, that while you were enjoying yourself in"               
## [10664] "Devonshire pursuing fresh schemes, always gay, always happy, she was"        
## [10665] "reduced to the extremest indigence.\""                                       
## [10666] ""                                                                            
## [10667] "\"But, upon my soul, I did NOT know it,\" he warmly replied; \"I did not"    
## [10668] "recollect that I had omitted to give her my direction; and common sense"     
## [10669] "might have told her how to find it out.\""                                   
## [10670] ""                                                                            
## [10671] "\"Well, sir, and what said Mrs. Smith?\""                                    
## [10672] ""                                                                            
## [10673] "\"She taxed me with the offence at once, and my confusion may be"            
## [10674] "guessed.  The purity of her life, the formality of her notions, her"         
## [10675] "ignorance of the world--every thing was against me.  The matter itself"      
## [10676] "I could not deny, and vain was every endeavour to soften it.  She was"       
## [10677] "previously disposed, I believe, to doubt the morality of my conduct in"      
## [10678] "general, and was moreover discontented with the very little attention,"      
## [10679] "the very little portion of my time that I had bestowed on her, in my"        
## [10680] "present visit.  In short, it ended in a total breach.  By one measure I"     
## [10681] "might have saved myself.  In the height of her morality, good woman!"        
## [10682] "she offered to forgive the past, if I would marry Eliza.  That could"        
## [10683] "not be--and I was formally dismissed from her favour and her house."         
## [10684] "The night following this affair--I was to go the next morning--was"          
## [10685] "spent by me in deliberating on what my future conduct should be.  The"       
## [10686] "struggle was great--but it ended too soon.  My affection for Marianne,"      
## [10687] "my thorough conviction of her attachment to me--it was all insufficient"     
## [10688] "to outweigh that dread of poverty, or get the better of those false"         
## [10689] "ideas of the necessity of riches, which I was naturally inclined to"         
## [10690] "feel, and expensive society had increased.  I had reason to believe"         
## [10691] "myself secure of my present wife, if I chose to address her, and I"          
## [10692] "persuaded myself to think that nothing else in common prudence remained"     
## [10693] "for me to do.  A heavy scene however awaited me, before I could leave"       
## [10694] "Devonshire;--I was engaged to dine with you on that very day; some"          
## [10695] "apology was therefore necessary for my breaking this engagement.  But"       
## [10696] "whether I should write this apology, or deliver it in person, was a"         
## [10697] "point of long debate.  To see Marianne, I felt, would be dreadful, and"      
## [10698] "I even doubted whether I could see her again, and keep to my"                
## [10699] "resolution.  In that point, however, I undervalued my own magnanimity,"      
## [10700] "as the event declared; for I went, I saw her, and saw her miserable,"        
## [10701] "and left her miserable--and left her hoping never to see her again.\""       
## [10702] ""                                                                            
## [10703] "\"Why did you call, Mr. Willoughby?\" said Elinor, reproachfully; \"a note"  
## [10704] "would have answered every purpose.-- Why was it necessary to call?\""        
## [10705] ""                                                                            
## [10706] "\"It was necessary to my own pride.  I could not bear to leave the"          
## [10707] "country in a manner that might lead you, or the rest of the"                 
## [10708] "neighbourhood, to suspect any part of what had really passed between"        
## [10709] "Mrs. Smith and myself--and I resolved therefore on calling at the"           
## [10710] "cottage, in my way to Honiton.  The sight of your dear sister, however,"     
## [10711] "was really dreadful; and, to heighten the matter, I found her alone."        
## [10712] "You were all gone I do not know where.  I had left her only the evening"     
## [10713] "before, so fully, so firmly resolved within my self on doing right!  A"      
## [10714] "few hours were to have engaged her to me for ever; and I remember how"       
## [10715] "happy, how gay were my spirits, as I walked from the cottage to"             
## [10716] "Allenham, satisfied with myself, delighted with every body!  But in"         
## [10717] "this, our last interview of friendship, I approached her with a sense"       
## [10718] "of guilt that almost took from me the power of dissembling.  Her"            
## [10719] "sorrow, her disappointment, her deep regret, when I told her that I was"     
## [10720] "obliged to leave Devonshire so immediately--I never shall forget"            
## [10721] "it--united too with such reliance, such confidence in me!--Oh,"              
## [10722] "God!--what a hard-hearted rascal I was!\""                                   
## [10723] ""                                                                            
## [10724] "They were both silent for a few moments.  Elinor first spoke."               
## [10725] ""                                                                            
## [10726] "\"Did you tell her that you should soon return?\""                           
## [10727] ""                                                                            
## [10728] "\"I do not know what I told her,\" he replied, impatiently; \"less than"     
## [10729] "was due to the past, beyond a doubt, and in all likelihood much more"        
## [10730] "than was justified by the future.  I cannot think of it.--It won't"          
## [10731] "do.--Then came your dear mother to torture me farther, with all her"         
## [10732] "kindness and confidence.  Thank Heaven! it DID torture me.  I was"           
## [10733] "miserable.  Miss Dashwood, you cannot have an idea of the comfort it"        
## [10734] "gives me to look back on my own misery.  I owe such a grudge to myself"      
## [10735] "for the stupid, rascally folly of my own heart, that all my past"            
## [10736] "sufferings under it are only triumph and exultation to me now.  Well, I"     
## [10737] "went, left all that I loved, and went to those to whom, at best, I was"      
## [10738] "only indifferent.  My journey to town--travelling with my own horses,"       
## [10739] "and therefore so tediously--no creature to speak to--my own reflections"     
## [10740] "so cheerful--when I looked forward every thing so inviting!--when I"         
## [10741] "looked back at Barton, the picture so soothing!--oh, it was a blessed"       
## [10742] "journey!\""                                                                  
## [10743] ""                                                                            
## [10744] "He stopped."                                                                 
## [10745] ""                                                                            
## [10746] "\"Well, sir,\" said Elinor, who, though pitying him, grew impatient for"     
## [10747] "his departure, \"and this is all?\""                                         
## [10748] ""                                                                            
## [10749] "\"Ah!--no,--have you forgot what passed in town?-- That infamous"            
## [10750] "letter--Did she shew it you?\""                                              
## [10751] ""                                                                            
## [10752] "\"Yes, I saw every note that passed.\""                                      
## [10753] ""                                                                            
## [10754] "\"When the first of hers reached me (as it immediately did, for I was in"    
## [10755] "town the whole time,) what I felt is--in the common phrase, not to be"       
## [10756] "expressed; in a more simple one--perhaps too simple to raise any"            
## [10757] "emotion--my feelings were very, very painful.--Every line, every word"       
## [10758] "was--in the hackneyed metaphor which their dear writer, were she here,"      
## [10759] "would forbid--a dagger to my heart.  To know that Marianne was in town"      
## [10760] "was--in the same language--a thunderbolt.--Thunderbolts and"                 
## [10761] "daggers!--what a reproof would she have given me!--her taste, her"           
## [10762] "opinions--I believe they are better known to me than my own,--and I am"      
## [10763] "sure they are dearer.\""                                                     
## [10764] ""                                                                            
## [10765] "Elinor's heart, which had undergone many changes in the course of this"      
## [10766] "extraordinary conversation, was now softened again;--yet she felt it"        
## [10767] "her duty to check such ideas in her companion as the last."                  
## [10768] ""                                                                            
## [10769] "\"This is not right, Mr. Willoughby.--Remember that you are married."        
## [10770] "Relate only what in your conscience you think necessary for me to hear.\""   
## [10771] ""                                                                            
## [10772] "\"Marianne's note, by assuring me that I was still as dear to her as in"     
## [10773] "former days, that in spite of the many, many weeks we had been"              
## [10774] "separated, she was as constant in her own feelings, and as full of"          
## [10775] "faith in the constancy of mine as ever, awakened all my remorse.  I say"     
## [10776] "awakened, because time and London, business and dissipation, had in"         
## [10777] "some measure quieted it, and I had been growing a fine hardened"             
## [10778] "villain, fancying myself indifferent to her, and chusing to fancy that"      
## [10779] "she too must have become indifferent to me; talking to myself of our"        
## [10780] "past attachment as a mere idle, trifling business, shrugging up my"          
## [10781] "shoulders in proof of its being so, and silencing every reproach,"           
## [10782] "overcoming every scruple, by secretly saying now and then, 'I shall be"      
## [10783] "heartily glad to hear she is well married.'-- But this note made me"         
## [10784] "know myself better.  I felt that she was infinitely dearer to me than"       
## [10785] "any other woman in the world, and that I was using her infamously.  But"     
## [10786] "every thing was then just settled between Miss Grey and me.  To retreat"     
## [10787] "was impossible.  All that I had to do, was to avoid you both.  I sent"       
## [10788] "no answer to Marianne, intending by that to preserve myself from her"        
## [10789] "farther notice; and for some time I was even determined not to call in"      
## [10790] "Berkeley Street;--but at last, judging it wiser to affect the air of a"      
## [10791] "cool, common acquaintance than anything else, I watched you all safely"      
## [10792] "out of the house one morning, and left my name.\""                           
## [10793] ""                                                                            
## [10794] "\"Watched us out of the house!\""                                            
## [10795] ""                                                                            
## [10796] "\"Even so.  You would be surprised to hear how often I watched you, how"     
## [10797] "often I was on the point of falling in with you.  I have entered many a"     
## [10798] "shop to avoid your sight, as the carriage drove by.  Lodging as I did"       
## [10799] "in Bond Street, there was hardly a day in which I did not catch a"           
## [10800] "glimpse of one or other of you; and nothing but the most constant"           
## [10801] "watchfulness on my side, a most invariably prevailing desire to keep"        
## [10802] "out of your sight, could have separated us so long.  I avoided the"          
## [10803] "Middletons as much as possible, as well as everybody else who was"           
## [10804] "likely to prove an acquaintance in common.  Not aware of their being in"     
## [10805] "town, however, I blundered on Sir John, I believe, the first day of his"     
## [10806] "coming, and the day after I had called at Mrs. Jennings's.  He asked me"     
## [10807] "to a party, a dance at his house in the evening.--Had he NOT told me as"     
## [10808] "an inducement that you and your sister were to be there, I should have"      
## [10809] "felt it too certain a thing, to trust myself near him.  The next"            
## [10810] "morning brought another short note from Marianne--still affectionate,"       
## [10811] "open, artless, confiding--everything that could make MY conduct most"        
## [10812] "hateful.  I could not answer it.  I tried--but could not frame a"            
## [10813] "sentence.  But I thought of her, I believe, every moment of the day."        
## [10814] "If you CAN pity me, Miss Dashwood, pity my situation as it was THEN."        
## [10815] "With my head and heart full of your sister, I was forced to play the"        
## [10816] "happy lover to another woman!--Those three or four weeks were worse"         
## [10817] "than all.  Well, at last, as I need not tell you, you were forced on"        
## [10818] "me; and what a sweet figure I cut!--what an evening of agony it was!--"      
## [10819] "Marianne, beautiful as an angel on one side, calling me Willoughby in"       
## [10820] "such a tone!--Oh, God!--holding out her hand to me, asking me for an"        
## [10821] "explanation, with those bewitching eyes fixed in such speaking"              
## [10822] "solicitude on my face!--and Sophia, jealous as the devil on the other"       
## [10823] "hand, looking all that was--Well, it does not signify; it is over"           
## [10824] "now.-- Such an evening!--I ran away from you all as soon as I could;"        
## [10825] "but not before I had seen Marianne's sweet face as white as"                 
## [10826] "death.--THAT was the last, last look I ever had of her;--the last"           
## [10827] "manner in which she appeared to me.  It was a horrid sight!--yet when I"     
## [10828] "thought of her to-day as really dying, it was a kind of comfort to me"       
## [10829] "to imagine that I knew exactly how she would appear to those, who saw"       
## [10830] "her last in this world.  She was before me, constantly before me, as I"      
## [10831] "travelled, in the same look and hue.\""                                      
## [10832] ""                                                                            
## [10833] "A short pause of mutual thoughtfulness succeeded.  Willoughby first"         
## [10834] "rousing himself, broke it thus:"                                             
## [10835] ""                                                                            
## [10836] "\"Well, let me make haste and be gone.  Your sister is certainly better,"    
## [10837] "certainly out of danger?\""                                                  
## [10838] ""                                                                            
## [10839] "\"We are assured of it.\""                                                   
## [10840] ""                                                                            
## [10841] "\"Your poor mother, too!--doting on Marianne.\""                             
## [10842] ""                                                                            
## [10843] "\"But the letter, Mr. Willoughby, your own letter; have you any thing to"    
## [10844] "say about that?\""                                                           
## [10845] ""                                                                            
## [10846] "\"Yes, yes, THAT in particular.  Your sister wrote to me again, you"         
## [10847] "know, the very next morning.  You saw what she said.  I was"                 
## [10848] "breakfasting at the Ellisons,--and her letter, with some others, was"        
## [10849] "brought to me there from my lodgings.  It happened to catch Sophia's"        
## [10850] "eye before it caught mine--and its size, the elegance of the paper, the"     
## [10851] "hand-writing altogether, immediately gave her a suspicion.  Some vague"      
## [10852] "report had reached her before of my attachment to some young lady in"        
## [10853] "Devonshire, and what had passed within her observation the preceding"        
## [10854] "evening had marked who the young lady was, and made her more jealous"        
## [10855] "than ever.  Affecting that air of playfulness, therefore, which is"          
## [10856] "delightful in a woman one loves, she opened the letter directly,"            
## [10857] "and read its contents.  She was well paid for her impudence."                
## [10858] "She read what made her wretched.  Her wretchedness I could have"             
## [10859] "borne, but her passion--her malice--At all events it must be appeased."      
## [10860] "And, in short--what do you think of my wife's style of"                      
## [10861] "letter-writing?--delicate--tender--truly feminine--was it not?\""            
## [10862] ""                                                                            
## [10863] "\"Your wife!--The letter was in your own hand-writing.\""                    
## [10864] ""                                                                            
## [10865] "\"Yes, but I had only the credit of servilely copying such sentences as"     
## [10866] "I was ashamed to put my name to.  The original was all her own--her own"     
## [10867] "happy thoughts and gentle diction.  But what could I do!--we were"           
## [10868] "engaged, every thing in preparation, the day almost fixed--But I am"         
## [10869] "talking like a fool.  Preparation!--day!--In honest words, her money"        
## [10870] "was necessary to me, and in a situation like mine, any thing was to be"      
## [10871] "done to prevent a rupture.  And after all, what did it signify to my"        
## [10872] "character in the opinion of Marianne and her friends, in what language"      
## [10873] "my answer was couched?--It must have been only to one end.  My business"     
## [10874] "was to declare myself a scoundrel, and whether I did it with a bow or a"     
## [10875] "bluster was of little importance.-- 'I am ruined for ever in their"          
## [10876] "opinion--' said I to myself--'I am shut out for ever from their"             
## [10877] "society, they already think me an unprincipled fellow, this letter will"     
## [10878] "only make them think me a blackguard one.' Such were my reasonings, as,"     
## [10879] "in a sort of desperate carelessness, I copied my wife's words, and"          
## [10880] "parted with the last relics of Marianne.  Her three notes--unluckily"        
## [10881] "they were all in my pocketbook, or I should have denied their"               
## [10882] "existence, and hoarded them for ever--I was forced to put them up, and"      
## [10883] "could not even kiss them.  And the lock of hair--that too I had always"      
## [10884] "carried about me in the same pocket-book, which was now searched by"         
## [10885] "Madam with the most ingratiating virulence,--the dear lock--all, every"      
## [10886] "memento was torn from me.\""                                                 
## [10887] ""                                                                            
## [10888] "\"You are very wrong, Mr. Willoughby, very blamable,\" said Elinor, while"   
## [10889] "her voice, in spite of herself, betrayed her compassionate emotion;"         
## [10890] "\"you ought not to speak in this way, either of Mrs. Willoughby or my"       
## [10891] "sister.  You had made your own choice.  It was not forced on you.  Your"     
## [10892] "wife has a claim to your politeness, to your respect, at least.  She"        
## [10893] "must be attached to you, or she would not have married you.  To treat"       
## [10894] "her with unkindness, to speak of her slightingly is no atonement to"         
## [10895] "Marianne--nor can I suppose it a relief to your own conscience.\""           
## [10896] ""                                                                            
## [10897] "\"Do not talk to me of my wife,\" said he with a heavy sigh.-- \"She does"   
## [10898] "not deserve your compassion.--She knew I had no regard for her when we"      
## [10899] "married.--Well, married we were, and came down to Combe Magna to be"         
## [10900] "happy, and afterwards returned to town to be gay.--And now do you pity"      
## [10901] "me, Miss Dashwood?--or have I said all this to no purpose?-- Am I--be"       
## [10902] "it only one degree--am I less guilty in your opinion than I was"             
## [10903] "before?--My intentions were not always wrong.  Have I explained away"        
## [10904] "any part of my guilt?\""                                                     
## [10905] ""                                                                            
## [10906] "\"Yes, you have certainly removed something--a little.-- You have proved"    
## [10907] "yourself, on the whole, less faulty than I had believed you.  You have"      
## [10908] "proved your heart less wicked, much less wicked.  But I hardly"              
## [10909] "know--the misery that you have inflicted--I hardly know what could have"     
## [10910] "made it worse.\""                                                            
## [10911] ""                                                                            
## [10912] "\"Will you repeat to your sister when she is recovered, what I have been"    
## [10913] "telling you?--Let me be a little lightened too in her opinion as well"       
## [10914] "as in yours.  You tell me that she has forgiven me already.  Let me be"      
## [10915] "able to fancy that a better knowledge of my heart, and of my present"        
## [10916] "feelings, will draw from her a more spontaneous, more natural, more"         
## [10917] "gentle, less dignified, forgiveness.  Tell her of my misery and my"          
## [10918] "penitence--tell her that my heart was never inconstant to her, and if"       
## [10919] "you will, that at this moment she is dearer to me than ever.\""              
## [10920] ""                                                                            
## [10921] "\"I will tell her all that is necessary to what may comparatively be"        
## [10922] "called, your justification.  But you have not explained to me the"           
## [10923] "particular reason of your coming now, nor how you heard of her illness.\""   
## [10924] ""                                                                            
## [10925] "\"Last night, in Drury Lane lobby, I ran against Sir John Middleton, and"    
## [10926] "when he saw who I was--for the first time these two months--he spoke to"     
## [10927] "me.--That he had cut me ever since my marriage, I had seen without"          
## [10928] "surprise or resentment.  Now, however, his good-natured, honest, stupid"     
## [10929] "soul, full of indignation against me, and concern for your sister,"          
## [10930] "could not resist the temptation of telling me what he knew ought"            
## [10931] "to--though probably he did not think it WOULD--vex me horridly.  As"         
## [10932] "bluntly as he could speak it, therefore, he told me that Marianne"           
## [10933] "Dashwood was dying of a putrid fever at Cleveland--a letter that"            
## [10934] "morning received from Mrs. Jennings declared her danger most"                
## [10935] "imminent--the Palmers are all gone off in a fright, &c.--I was too much"     
## [10936] "shocked to be able to pass myself off as insensible even to the"             
## [10937] "undiscerning Sir John.  His heart was softened in seeing mine suffer;"       
## [10938] "and so much of his ill-will was done away, that when we parted, he"          
## [10939] "almost shook me by the hand while he reminded me of an old promise"          
## [10940] "about a pointer puppy.  What I felt on hearing that your sister was"         
## [10941] "dying--and dying too, believing me the greatest villain upon earth,"         
## [10942] "scorning, hating me in her latest moments--for how could I tell what"        
## [10943] "horrid projects might not have been imputed?  ONE person I was sure"         
## [10944] "would represent me as capable of any thing-- What I felt was"                
## [10945] "dreadful!--My resolution was soon made, and at eight o'clock this"           
## [10946] "morning I was in my carriage.  Now you know all.\""                          
## [10947] ""                                                                            
## [10948] "Elinor made no answer.  Her thoughts were silently fixed on the"             
## [10949] "irreparable injury which too early an independence and its consequent"       
## [10950] "habits of idleness, dissipation, and luxury, had made in the mind, the"      
## [10951] "character, the happiness, of a man who, to every advantage of person"        
## [10952] "and talents, united a disposition naturally open and honest, and a"          
## [10953] "feeling, affectionate temper.  The world had made him extravagant and"       
## [10954] "vain--Extravagance and vanity had made him cold-hearted and selfish."        
## [10955] "Vanity, while seeking its own guilty triumph at the expense of another,"     
## [10956] "had involved him in a real attachment, which extravagance, or at least"      
## [10957] "its offspring, necessity, had required to be sacrificed.  Each faulty"       
## [10958] "propensity in leading him to evil, had led him likewise to punishment."      
## [10959] "The attachment, from which against honour, against feeling, against"         
## [10960] "every better interest he had outwardly torn himself, now, when no"           
## [10961] "longer allowable, governed every thought; and the connection, for the"       
## [10962] "sake of which he had, with little scruple, left her sister to misery,"       
## [10963] "was likely to prove a source of unhappiness to himself of a far more"        
## [10964] "incurable nature.  From a reverie of this kind she was recalled at the"      
## [10965] "end of some minutes by Willoughby, who, rousing himself from a reverie"      
## [10966] "at least equally painful, started up in preparation for going, and"          
## [10967] "said--"                                                                      
## [10968] ""                                                                            
## [10969] "\"There is no use in staying here; I must be off.\""                         
## [10970] ""                                                                            
## [10971] "\"Are you going back to town?\""                                             
## [10972] ""                                                                            
## [10973] "\"No--to Combe Magna.  I have business there; from thence to town in a"      
## [10974] "day or two.  Good bye.\""                                                    
## [10975] ""                                                                            
## [10976] "He held out his hand.  She could not refuse to give him hers;--he"           
## [10977] "pressed it with affection."                                                  
## [10978] ""                                                                            
## [10979] "\"And you DO think something better of me than you did?\"--said he,"         
## [10980] "letting it fall, and leaning against the mantel-piece as if forgetting"      
## [10981] "he was to go."                                                               
## [10982] ""                                                                            
## [10983] "Elinor assured him that she did;--that she forgave, pitied, wished him"      
## [10984] "well--was even interested in his happiness--and added some gentle"           
## [10985] "counsel as to the behaviour most likely to promote it.  His answer was"      
## [10986] "not very encouraging."                                                       
## [10987] ""                                                                            
## [10988] "\"As to that,\" said he, \"I must rub through the world as well as I can."   
## [10989] "Domestic happiness is out of the question.  If, however, I am allowed"       
## [10990] "to think that you and yours feel an interest in my fate and actions, it"     
## [10991] "may be the means--it may put me on my guard--at least, it may be"            
## [10992] "something to live for.  Marianne to be sure is lost to me for ever."         
## [10993] "Were I even by any blessed chance at liberty again--\""                      
## [10994] ""                                                                            
## [10995] "Elinor stopped him with a reproof."                                          
## [10996] ""                                                                            
## [10997] "\"Well,\"--he replied--\"once more good bye. I shall now go away and live"   
## [10998] "in dread of one event.\""                                                    
## [10999] ""                                                                            
## [11000] "\"What do you mean?\""                                                       
## [11001] ""                                                                            
## [11002] "\"Your sister's marriage.\""                                                 
## [11003] ""                                                                            
## [11004] "\"You are very wrong.  She can never be more lost to you than she is"        
## [11005] "now.\""                                                                      
## [11006] ""                                                                            
## [11007] "\"But she will be gained by some one else.  And if that some one should"     
## [11008] "be the very he whom, of all others, I could least bear--but I will not"      
## [11009] "stay to rob myself of all your compassionate goodwill, by shewing that"      
## [11010] "where I have most injured I can least forgive.  Good bye,--God bless"        
## [11011] "you!\""                                                                      
## [11012] ""                                                                            
## [11013] "And with these words, he almost ran out of the room."                        
## [11014] ""                                                                            
## [11015] ""                                                                            
## [11016] ""                                                                            
## [11017] "CHAPTER 45"                                                                  
## [11018] ""                                                                            
## [11019] ""                                                                            
## [11020] "Elinor, for some time after he left her, for some time even after the"       
## [11021] "sound of his carriage had died away, remained too much oppressed by a"       
## [11022] "crowd of ideas, widely differing in themselves, but of which sadness"        
## [11023] "was the general result, to think even of her sister."                        
## [11024] ""                                                                            
## [11025] "Willoughby, he, whom only half an hour ago she had abhorred as the most"     
## [11026] "worthless of men, Willoughby, in spite of all his faults, excited a"         
## [11027] "degree of commiseration for the sufferings produced by them, which made"     
## [11028] "her think of him as now separated for ever from her family, with a"          
## [11029] "tenderness, a regret, rather in proportion, as she soon acknowledged"        
## [11030] "within herself--to his wishes than to his merits.  She felt that his"        
## [11031] "influence over her mind was heightened by circumstances which ought not"     
## [11032] "in reason to have weight; by that person of uncommon attraction, that"       
## [11033] "open, affectionate, and lively manner which it was no merit to possess;"     
## [11034] "and by that still ardent love for Marianne, which it was not even"           
## [11035] "innocent to indulge.  But she felt that it was so, long, long before"        
## [11036] "she could feel his influence less."                                          
## [11037] ""                                                                            
## [11038] "When at last she returned to the unconscious Marianne, she found her"        
## [11039] "just awaking, refreshed by so long and sweet a sleep to the extent of"       
## [11040] "her hopes.  Elinor's heart was full.  The past, the present, the"            
## [11041] "future, Willoughby's visit, Marianne's safety, and her mother's"             
## [11042] "expected arrival, threw her altogether into an agitation of spirits"         
## [11043] "which kept off every indication of fatigue, and made her only fearful"       
## [11044] "of betraying herself to her sister.  Short was the time, however, in"        
## [11045] "which that fear could affect her, for within half an hour after"             
## [11046] "Willoughby's leaving the house, she was again called down stairs by the"     
## [11047] "sound of another carriage.--Eager to save her mother from every"             
## [11048] "unnecessary moment's horrible suspense, she ran immediately into the"        
## [11049] "hall, and reached the outward door just in time to receive and support"      
## [11050] "her as she entered it."                                                      
## [11051] ""                                                                            
## [11052] "Mrs. Dashwood, whose terror as they drew near the house had produced"        
## [11053] "almost the conviction of Marianne's being no more, had no voice to"          
## [11054] "inquire after her, no voice even for Elinor; but SHE, waiting neither"       
## [11055] "for salutation nor inquiry, instantly gave the joyful relief;--and her"      
## [11056] "mother, catching it with all her usual warmth, was in a moment as much"      
## [11057] "overcome by her happiness, as she had been before by her fears.  She"        
## [11058] "was supported into the drawing-room between her daughter and her"            
## [11059] "friend;--and there, shedding tears of joy, though still unable to"           
## [11060] "speak, embraced Elinor again and again, turning from her at intervals"       
## [11061] "to press Colonel Brandon's hand, with a look which spoke at once her"        
## [11062] "gratitude, and her conviction of his sharing with herself in the bliss"      
## [11063] "of the moment.  He shared it, however, in a silence even greater than"       
## [11064] "her own."                                                                    
## [11065] ""                                                                            
## [11066] "As soon as Mrs. Dashwood had recovered herself, to see Marianne was her"     
## [11067] "first desire; and in two minutes she was with her beloved child,"            
## [11068] "rendered dearer to her than ever by absence, unhappiness, and danger."       
## [11069] "Elinor's delight, as she saw what each felt in the meeting, was only"        
## [11070] "checked by an apprehension of its robbing Marianne of farther"               
## [11071] "sleep;--but Mrs. Dashwood could be calm, could be even prudent, when"        
## [11072] "the life of a child was at stake, and Marianne, satisfied in knowing"        
## [11073] "her mother was near her, and conscious of being too weak for"                
## [11074] "conversation, submitted readily to the silence and quiet prescribed by"      
## [11075] "every nurse around her.  Mrs. Dashwood WOULD sit up with her all night;"     
## [11076] "and Elinor, in compliance with her mother's entreaty, went to bed.  But"     
## [11077] "the rest, which one night entirely sleepless, and many hours of the"         
## [11078] "most wearing anxiety seemed to make requisite, was kept off by"              
## [11079] "irritation of spirits.  Willoughby, \"poor Willoughby,\" as she now"         
## [11080] "allowed herself to call him, was constantly in her thoughts; she would"      
## [11081] "not but have heard his vindication for the world, and now blamed, now"       
## [11082] "acquitted herself for having judged him so harshly before.  But her"         
## [11083] "promise of relating it to her sister was invariably painful.  She"           
## [11084] "dreaded the performance of it, dreaded what its effect on Marianne"          
## [11085] "might be; doubted whether after such an explanation she could ever be"       
## [11086] "happy with another; and for a moment wished Willoughby a widower."           
## [11087] "Then, remembering Colonel Brandon, reproved herself, felt that to HIS"       
## [11088] "sufferings and his constancy far more than to his rival's, the reward"       
## [11089] "of her sister was due, and wished any thing rather than Mrs."                
## [11090] "Willoughby's death."                                                         
## [11091] ""                                                                            
## [11092] "The shock of Colonel Brandon's errand at Barton had been much softened"      
## [11093] "to Mrs. Dashwood by her own previous alarm; for so great was her"            
## [11094] "uneasiness about Marianne, that she had already determined to set out"       
## [11095] "for Cleveland on that very day, without waiting for any further"             
## [11096] "intelligence, and had so far settled her journey before his arrival,"        
## [11097] "that the Careys were then expected every moment to fetch Margaret away,"     
## [11098] "as her mother was unwilling to take her where there might be infection."     
## [11099] ""                                                                            
## [11100] "Marianne continued to mend every day, and the brilliant cheerfulness of"     
## [11101] "Mrs. Dashwood's looks and spirits proved her to be, as she repeatedly"       
## [11102] "declared herself, one of the happiest women in the world.  Elinor could"     
## [11103] "not hear the declaration, nor witness its proofs without sometimes"          
## [11104] "wondering whether her mother ever recollected Edward.  But Mrs."             
## [11105] "Dashwood, trusting to the temperate account of her own disappointment"       
## [11106] "which Elinor had sent her, was led away by the exuberance of her joy to"     
## [11107] "think only of what would increase it.  Marianne was restored to her"         
## [11108] "from a danger in which, as she now began to feel, her own mistaken"          
## [11109] "judgment in encouraging the unfortunate attachment to Willoughby, had"       
## [11110] "contributed to place her;--and in her recovery she had yet another"          
## [11111] "source of joy unthought of by Elinor.  It was thus imparted to her, as"      
## [11112] "soon as any opportunity of private conference between them occurred."        
## [11113] ""                                                                            
## [11114] "\"At last we are alone.  My Elinor, you do not yet know all my"              
## [11115] "happiness.  Colonel Brandon loves Marianne.  He has told me so himself.\""   
## [11116] ""                                                                            
## [11117] "Her daughter, feeling by turns both pleased and pained, surprised and"       
## [11118] "not surprised, was all silent attention."                                    
## [11119] ""                                                                            
## [11120] "\"You are never like me, dear Elinor, or I should wonder at your"            
## [11121] "composure now.  Had I sat down to wish for any possible good to my"          
## [11122] "family, I should have fixed on Colonel Brandon's marrying one of you as"     
## [11123] "the object most desirable.  And I believe Marianne will be the most"         
## [11124] "happy with him of the two.\""                                                
## [11125] ""                                                                            
## [11126] "Elinor was half inclined to ask her reason for thinking so, because"         
## [11127] "satisfied that none founded on an impartial consideration of their age,"     
## [11128] "characters, or feelings, could be given;--but her mother must always be"     
## [11129] "carried away by her imagination on any interesting subject, and"             
## [11130] "therefore instead of an inquiry, she passed it off with a smile."            
## [11131] ""                                                                            
## [11132] "\"He opened his whole heart to me yesterday as we travelled.  It came"       
## [11133] "out quite unawares, quite undesignedly.  I, you may well believe, could"     
## [11134] "talk of nothing but my child;--he could not conceal his distress; I saw"     
## [11135] "that it equalled my own, and he perhaps, thinking that mere friendship,"     
## [11136] "as the world now goes, would not justify so warm a sympathy--or rather,"     
## [11137] "not thinking at all, I suppose--giving way to irresistible feelings,"        
## [11138] "made me acquainted with his earnest, tender, constant, affection for"        
## [11139] "Marianne.  He has loved her, my Elinor, ever since the first moment of"      
## [11140] "seeing her.\""                                                               
## [11141] ""                                                                            
## [11142] "Here, however, Elinor perceived,--not the language, not the professions"     
## [11143] "of Colonel Brandon, but the natural embellishments of her mother's"          
## [11144] "active fancy, which fashioned every thing delightful to her as it chose."    
## [11145] ""                                                                            
## [11146] "\"His regard for her, infinitely surpassing anything that Willoughby"        
## [11147] "ever felt or feigned, as much more warm, as more sincere or"                 
## [11148] "constant--which ever we are to call it--has subsisted through all the"       
## [11149] "knowledge of dear Marianne's unhappy prepossession for that worthless"       
## [11150] "young man!--and without selfishness--without encouraging a hope!--could"     
## [11151] "he have seen her happy with another--Such a noble mind!--such openness,"     
## [11152] "such sincerity!--no one can be deceived in HIM.\""                           
## [11153] ""                                                                            
## [11154] "\"Colonel Brandon's character,\" said Elinor, \"as an excellent man, is"     
## [11155] "well established.\""                                                         
## [11156] ""                                                                            
## [11157] "\"I know it is,\"--replied her mother seriously, \"or after such a warning," 
## [11158] "I should be the last to encourage such affection, or even to be pleased"     
## [11159] "by it.  But his coming for me as he did, with such active, such ready"       
## [11160] "friendship, is enough to prove him one of the worthiest of men.\""           
## [11161] ""                                                                            
## [11162] "\"His character, however,\" answered Elinor, \"does not rest on ONE act of"  
## [11163] "kindness, to which his affection for Marianne, were humanity out of the"     
## [11164] "case, would have prompted him.  To Mrs. Jennings, to the Middletons, he"     
## [11165] "has been long and intimately known; they equally love and respect him;"      
## [11166] "and even my own knowledge of him, though lately acquired, is very"           
## [11167] "considerable; and so highly do I value and esteem him, that if Marianne"     
## [11168] "can be happy with him, I shall be as ready as yourself to think our"         
## [11169] "connection the greatest blessing to us in the world.  What answer did"       
## [11170] "you give him?--Did you allow him to hope?\""                                 
## [11171] ""                                                                            
## [11172] "\"Oh! my love, I could not then talk of hope to him or to myself."           
## [11173] "Marianne might at that moment be dying.  But he did not ask for hope or"     
## [11174] "encouragement.  His was an involuntary confidence, an irrepressible"         
## [11175] "effusion to a soothing friend--not an application to a parent.  Yet"         
## [11176] "after a time I DID say, for at first I was quite overcome--that if she"      
## [11177] "lived, as I trusted she might, my greatest happiness would lie in"           
## [11178] "promoting their marriage; and since our arrival, since our delightful"       
## [11179] "security, I have repeated it to him more fully, have given him every"        
## [11180] "encouragement in my power.  Time, a very little time, I tell him, will"      
## [11181] "do everything;--Marianne's heart is not to be wasted for ever on such a"     
## [11182] "man as Willoughby.-- His own merits must soon secure it.\""                  
## [11183] ""                                                                            
## [11184] "\"To judge from the Colonel's spirits, however, you have not yet made"       
## [11185] "him equally sanguine.\""                                                     
## [11186] ""                                                                            
## [11187] "\"No.--He thinks Marianne's affection too deeply rooted for any change"      
## [11188] "in it under a great length of time, and even supposing her heart again"      
## [11189] "free, is too diffident of himself to believe, that with such a"              
## [11190] "difference of age and disposition he could ever attach her.  There,"         
## [11191] "however, he is quite mistaken.  His age is only so much beyond hers as"      
## [11192] "to be an advantage, as to make his character and principles fixed;--and"     
## [11193] "his disposition, I am well convinced, is exactly the very one to make"       
## [11194] "your sister happy.  And his person, his manners too, are all in his"         
## [11195] "favour.  My partiality does not blind me; he certainly is not so"            
## [11196] "handsome as Willoughby--but at the same time, there is something much"       
## [11197] "more pleasing in his countenance.-- There was always a something,--if"       
## [11198] "you remember,--in Willoughby's eyes at times, which I did not like.\""       
## [11199] ""                                                                            
## [11200] "Elinor could NOT remember it;--but her mother, without waiting for her"      
## [11201] "assent, continued,"                                                          
## [11202] ""                                                                            
## [11203] "\"And his manners, the Colonel's manners are not only more pleasing to"      
## [11204] "me than Willoughby's ever were, but they are of a kind I well know to"       
## [11205] "be more solidly attaching to Marianne.  Their gentleness, their genuine"     
## [11206] "attention to other people, and their manly unstudied simplicity is much"     
## [11207] "more accordant with her real disposition, than the liveliness--often"        
## [11208] "artificial, and often ill-timed of the other.  I am very sure myself,"       
## [11209] "that had Willoughby turned out as really amiable, as he has proved"          
## [11210] "himself the contrary, Marianne would yet never have been so happy with"      
## [11211] "HIM, as she will be with Colonel Brandon.\""                                 
## [11212] ""                                                                            
## [11213] "She paused.--Her daughter could not quite agree with her, but her"           
## [11214] "dissent was not heard, and therefore gave no offence."                       
## [11215] ""                                                                            
## [11216] "\"At Delaford, she will be within an easy distance of me,\" added Mrs."      
## [11217] "Dashwood, \"even if I remain at Barton; and in all probability,--for I"      
## [11218] "hear it is a large village,--indeed there certainly MUST be some small"      
## [11219] "house or cottage close by, that would suit us quite as well as our"          
## [11220] "present situation.\""                                                        
## [11221] ""                                                                            
## [11222] "Poor Elinor!--here was a new scheme for getting her to Delaford!--but"       
## [11223] "her spirit was stubborn."                                                    
## [11224] ""                                                                            
## [11225] "\"His fortune too!--for at my time of life you know, everybody cares"        
## [11226] "about THAT;--and though I neither know nor desire to know, what it"          
## [11227] "really is, I am sure it must be a good one.\""                               
## [11228] ""                                                                            
## [11229] "Here they were interrupted by the entrance of a third person, and"           
## [11230] "Elinor withdrew to think it all over in private, to wish success to her"     
## [11231] "friend, and yet in wishing it, to feel a pang for Willoughby."               
## [11232] ""                                                                            
## [11233] ""                                                                            
## [11234] ""                                                                            
## [11235] "CHAPTER 46"                                                                  
## [11236] ""                                                                            
## [11237] ""                                                                            
## [11238] "Marianne's illness, though weakening in its kind, had not been long"         
## [11239] "enough to make her recovery slow; and with youth, natural strength, and"     
## [11240] "her mother's presence in aid, it proceeded so smoothly as to enable her"     
## [11241] "to remove, within four days after the arrival of the latter, into Mrs."      
## [11242] "Palmer's dressing-room.  When there, at her own particular request, for"
