## [11243] "she was impatient to pour forth her thanks to him for fetching her"          
## [11244] "mother, Colonel Brandon was invited to visit her."                           
## [11245] ""                                                                            
## [11246] "His emotion on entering the room, in seeing her altered looks, and in"       
## [11247] "receiving the pale hand which she immediately held out to him, was"          
## [11248] "such, as, in Elinor's conjecture, must arise from something more than"       
## [11249] "his affection for Marianne, or the consciousness of its being known to"      
## [11250] "others; and she soon discovered in his melancholy eye and varying"           
## [11251] "complexion as he looked at her sister, the probable recurrence of many"      
## [11252] "past scenes of misery to his mind, brought back by that resemblance"         
## [11253] "between Marianne and Eliza already acknowledged, and now strengthened"       
## [11254] "by the hollow eye, the sickly skin, the posture of reclining weakness,"      
## [11255] "and the warm acknowledgment of peculiar obligation."                         
## [11256] ""                                                                            
## [11257] "Mrs. Dashwood, not less watchful of what passed than her daughter, but"      
## [11258] "with a mind very differently influenced, and therefore watching to very"     
## [11259] "different effect, saw nothing in the Colonel's behaviour but what arose"     
## [11260] "from the most simple and self-evident sensations, while in the actions"      
## [11261] "and words of Marianne she persuaded herself to think that something"         
## [11262] "more than gratitude already dawned."                                         
## [11263] ""                                                                            
## [11264] "At the end of another day or two, Marianne growing visibly stronger"         
## [11265] "every twelve hours, Mrs. Dashwood, urged equally by her own and her"         
## [11266] "daughter's wishes, began to talk of removing to Barton.  On HER"             
## [11267] "measures depended those of her two friends; Mrs. Jennings could not"         
## [11268] "quit Cleveland during the Dashwoods' stay; and Colonel Brandon was soon"     
## [11269] "brought, by their united request, to consider his own abode there as"        
## [11270] "equally determinate, if not equally indispensable.  At his and Mrs."         
## [11271] "Jennings's united request in return, Mrs. Dashwood was prevailed on to"      
## [11272] "accept the use of his carriage on her journey back, for the better"          
## [11273] "accommodation of her sick child; and the Colonel, at the joint"              
## [11274] "invitation of Mrs. Dashwood and Mrs. Jennings, whose active good-nature"     
## [11275] "made her friendly and hospitable for other people as well as herself,"       
## [11276] "engaged with pleasure to redeem it by a visit at the cottage, in the"        
## [11277] "course of a few weeks."                                                      
## [11278] ""                                                                            
## [11279] "The day of separation and departure arrived; and Marianne, after taking"     
## [11280] "so particular and lengthened a leave of Mrs. Jennings, one so earnestly"     
## [11281] "grateful, so full of respect and kind wishes as seemed due to her own"       
## [11282] "heart from a secret acknowledgment of past inattention, and bidding"         
## [11283] "Colonel Brandon farewell with a cordiality of a friend, was carefully"       
## [11284] "assisted by him into the carriage, of which he seemed anxious that she"      
## [11285] "should engross at least half.  Mrs. Dashwood and Elinor then followed,"      
## [11286] "and the others were left by themselves, to talk of the travellers, and"      
## [11287] "feel their own dullness, till Mrs. Jennings was summoned to her chaise"      
## [11288] "to take comfort in the gossip of her maid for the loss of her two young"     
## [11289] "companions; and Colonel Brandon immediately afterwards took his"             
## [11290] "solitary way to Delaford."                                                   
## [11291] ""                                                                            
## [11292] "The Dashwoods were two days on the road, and Marianne bore her journey"      
## [11293] "on both, without essential fatigue.  Every thing that the most zealous"      
## [11294] "affection, the most solicitous care could do to render her comfortable,"     
## [11295] "was the office of each watchful companion, and each found their reward"      
## [11296] "in her bodily ease, and her calmness of spirits.  To Elinor, the"            
## [11297] "observation of the latter was particularly grateful.  She, who had seen"     
## [11298] "her week after week so constantly suffering, oppressed by anguish of"        
## [11299] "heart which she had neither courage to speak of, nor fortitude to"           
## [11300] "conceal, now saw with a joy, which no other could equally share, an"         
## [11301] "apparent composure of mind, which, in being the result as she trusted"       
## [11302] "of serious reflection, must eventually lead her to contentment and"          
## [11303] "cheerfulness."                                                               
## [11304] ""                                                                            
## [11305] "As they approached Barton, indeed, and entered on scenes of which every"     
## [11306] "field and every tree brought some peculiar, some painful recollection,"      
## [11307] "she grew silent and thoughtful, and turning away her face from their"        
## [11308] "notice, sat earnestly gazing through the window.  But here, Elinor"          
## [11309] "could neither wonder nor blame; and when she saw, as she assisted"           
## [11310] "Marianne from the carriage, that she had been crying, she saw only an"       
## [11311] "emotion too natural in itself to raise any thing less tender than pity,"     
## [11312] "and in its unobtrusiveness entitled to praise.  In the whole of her"         
## [11313] "subsequent manner, she traced the direction of a mind awakened to"           
## [11314] "reasonable exertion; for no sooner had they entered their common"            
## [11315] "sitting-room, than Marianne turned her eyes around it with a look of"        
## [11316] "resolute firmness, as if determined at once to accustom herself to the"      
## [11317] "sight of every object with which the remembrance of Willoughby could be"     
## [11318] "connected.--She said little, but every sentence aimed at cheerfulness,"      
## [11319] "and though a sigh sometimes escaped her, it never passed away without"       
## [11320] "the atonement of a smile.  After dinner she would try her piano-forte."      
## [11321] "She went to it; but the music on which her eye first rested was an"          
## [11322] "opera, procured for her by Willoughby, containing some of their"             
## [11323] "favourite duets, and bearing on its outward leaf her own name in his"        
## [11324] "hand-writing.--That would not do.--She shook her head, put the music"        
## [11325] "aside, and after running over the keys for a minute, complained of"          
## [11326] "feebleness in her fingers, and closed the instrument again; declaring"       
## [11327] "however with firmness as she did so, that she should in future practice"     
## [11328] "much."                                                                       
## [11329] ""                                                                            
## [11330] "The next morning produced no abatement in these happy symptoms.  On the"     
## [11331] "contrary, with a mind and body alike strengthened by rest, she looked"       
## [11332] "and spoke with more genuine spirit, anticipating the pleasure of"            
## [11333] "Margaret's return, and talking of the dear family party which would"         
## [11334] "then be restored, of their mutual pursuits and cheerful society, as the"     
## [11335] "only happiness worth a wish."                                                
## [11336] ""                                                                            
## [11337] "\"When the weather is settled, and I have recovered my strength,\" said"     
## [11338] "she, \"we will take long walks together every day.  We will walk to the"     
## [11339] "farm at the edge of the down, and see how the children go on; we will"       
## [11340] "walk to Sir John's new plantations at Barton Cross, and the Abbeyland;"      
## [11341] "and we will often go to the old ruins of the Priory, and try to trace its"   
## [11342] "foundations as far as we are told they once reached.  I know we shall"       
## [11343] "be happy.  I know the summer will pass happily away.  I mean never to"       
## [11344] "be later in rising than six, and from that time till dinner I shall"         
## [11345] "divide every moment between music and reading.  I have formed my plan,"      
## [11346] "and am determined to enter on a course of serious study.  Our own"           
## [11347] "library is too well known to me, to be resorted to for any thing beyond"     
## [11348] "mere amusement.  But there are many works well worth reading at the"         
## [11349] "Park; and there are others of more modern production which I know I can"     
## [11350] "borrow of Colonel Brandon.  By reading only six hours a-day, I shall"        
## [11351] "gain in the course of a twelve-month a great deal of instruction which"      
## [11352] "I now feel myself to want.\""                                                
## [11353] ""                                                                            
## [11354] "Elinor honoured her for a plan which originated so nobly as this;"           
## [11355] "though smiling to see the same eager fancy which had been leading her"       
## [11356] "to the extreme of languid indolence and selfish repining, now at work"       
## [11357] "in introducing excess into a scheme of such rational employment and"         
## [11358] "virtuous self-control. Her smile however changed to a sigh when she"         
## [11359] "remembered that promise to Willoughby was yet unfulfilled, and feared"       
## [11360] "she had that to communicate which might again unsettle the mind of"          
## [11361] "Marianne, and ruin at least for a time this fair prospect of busy"           
## [11362] "tranquillity.  Willing therefore to delay the evil hour, she resolved"       
## [11363] "to wait till her sister's health were more secure, before she appointed"     
## [11364] "it.  But the resolution was made only to be broken."                         
## [11365] ""                                                                            
## [11366] "Marianne had been two or three days at home, before the weather was"         
## [11367] "fine enough for an invalid like herself to venture out.  But at last a"      
## [11368] "soft, genial morning appeared; such as might tempt the daughter's"           
## [11369] "wishes and the mother's confidence; and Marianne, leaning on Elinor's"       
## [11370] "arm, was authorised to walk as long as she could without fatigue, in"        
## [11371] "the lane before the house."                                                  
## [11372] ""                                                                            
## [11373] "The sisters set out at a pace, slow as the feebleness of Marianne in an"     
## [11374] "exercise hitherto untried since her illness required;--and they had"         
## [11375] "advanced only so far beyond the house as to admit a full view of the"        
## [11376] "hill, the important hill behind, when pausing with her eyes turned"          
## [11377] "towards it, Marianne calmly said,"                                           
## [11378] ""                                                                            
## [11379] "\"There, exactly there,\"--pointing with one hand, \"on that projecting"     
## [11380] "mound,--there I fell; and there I first saw Willoughby.\""                   
## [11381] ""                                                                            
## [11382] "Her voice sunk with the word, but presently reviving she added,"             
## [11383] ""                                                                            
## [11384] "\"I am thankful to find that I can look with so little pain on the"          
## [11385] "spot!--shall we ever talk on that subject, Elinor?\"--hesitatingly it"       
## [11386] "was said.--\"Or will it be wrong?--I can talk of it now, I hope, as I"       
## [11387] "ought to do.\"--"                                                            
## [11388] ""                                                                            
## [11389] "Elinor tenderly invited her to be open."                                     
## [11390] ""                                                                            
## [11391] "\"As for regret,\" said Marianne, \"I have done with that, as far as HE is"  
## [11392] "concerned.  I do not mean to talk to you of what my feelings have been"      
## [11393] "for him, but what they are NOW.--At present, if I could be satisfied on"     
## [11394] "one point, if I could be allowed to think that he was not ALWAYS acting"     
## [11395] "a part, not ALWAYS deceiving me;--but above all, if I could be assured"      
## [11396] "that he never was so VERY wicked as my fears have sometimes fancied"         
## [11397] "him, since the story of that unfortunate girl\"--"                           
## [11398] ""                                                                            
## [11399] "She stopt.  Elinor joyfully treasured her words as she answered,"            
## [11400] ""                                                                            
## [11401] "\"If you could be assured of that, you think you should be easy.\""          
## [11402] ""                                                                            
## [11403] "\"Yes. My peace of mind is doubly involved in it;--for not only is it"       
## [11404] "horrible to suspect a person, who has been what HE has been to ME, of"       
## [11405] "such designs,--but what must it make me appear to myself?--What in a"        
## [11406] "situation like mine, but a most shamefully unguarded affection could"        
## [11407] "expose me to\"--"                                                            
## [11408] ""                                                                            
## [11409] "\"How then,\" asked her sister, \"would you account for his behaviour?\""    
## [11410] ""                                                                            
## [11411] "\"I would suppose him,--Oh, how gladly would I suppose him, only fickle,"    
## [11412] "very, very fickle.\""                                                        
## [11413] ""                                                                            
## [11414] "Elinor said no more.  She was debating within herself on the"                
## [11415] "eligibility of beginning her story directly, or postponing it till"          
## [11416] "Marianne were in stronger health;--and they crept on for a few minutes"      
## [11417] "in silence."                                                                 
## [11418] ""                                                                            
## [11419] "\"I am not wishing him too much good,\" said Marianne at last with a"        
## [11420] "sigh, \"when I wish his secret reflections may be no more unpleasant"        
## [11421] "than my own.  He will suffer enough in them.\""                              
## [11422] ""                                                                            
## [11423] "\"Do you compare your conduct with his?\""                                   
## [11424] ""                                                                            
## [11425] "\"No. I compare it with what it ought to have been; I compare it with"       
## [11426] "yours.\""                                                                    
## [11427] ""                                                                            
## [11428] "\"Our situations have borne little resemblance.\""                           
## [11429] ""                                                                            
## [11430] "\"They have borne more than our conduct.--Do not, my dearest Elinor, let"    
## [11431] "your kindness defend what I know your judgment must censure.  My"            
## [11432] "illness has made me think-- It has given me leisure and calmness for"        
## [11433] "serious recollection.  Long before I was enough recovered to talk, I"        
## [11434] "was perfectly able to reflect.  I considered the past: I saw in my own"      
## [11435] "behaviour, since the beginning of our acquaintance with him last"            
## [11436] "autumn, nothing but a series of imprudence towards myself, and want of"      
## [11437] "kindness to others.  I saw that my own feelings had prepared my"             
## [11438] "sufferings, and that my want of fortitude under them had almost led me"      
## [11439] "to the grave.  My illness, I well knew, had been entirely brought on by"     
## [11440] "myself by such negligence of my own health, as I had felt even at the"       
## [11441] "time to be wrong.  Had I died,--it would have been self-destruction. I"      
## [11442] "did not know my danger till the danger was removed; but with such"           
## [11443] "feelings as these reflections gave me, I wonder at my recovery,--wonder"     
## [11444] "that the very eagerness of my desire to live, to have time for"              
## [11445] "atonement to my God, and to you all, did not kill me at once.  Had I"        
## [11446] "died,--in what peculiar misery should I have left you, my nurse, my"         
## [11447] "friend, my sister!--You, who had seen all the fretful selfishness of my"     
## [11448] "latter days; who had known all the murmurings of my heart!--How should"      
## [11449] "I have lived in YOUR remembrance!--My mother too! How could you have"        
## [11450] "consoled her!--I cannot express my own abhorrence of myself.  Whenever"      
## [11451] "I looked towards the past, I saw some duty neglected, or some failing"       
## [11452] "indulged.  Every body seemed injured by me.  The kindness, the"              
## [11453] "unceasing kindness of Mrs. Jennings, I had repaid with ungrateful"           
## [11454] "contempt.  To the Middletons, to the Palmers, the Steeles, to every"         
## [11455] "common acquaintance even, I had been insolent and unjust; with a heart"      
## [11456] "hardened against their merits, and a temper irritated by their very"         
## [11457] "attention.--To John, to Fanny,--yes, even to them, little as they"           
## [11458] "deserve, I had given less than their due.  But you,--you above all,"         
## [11459] "above my mother, had been wronged by me.  I, and only I, knew your"          
## [11460] "heart and its sorrows; yet to what did it influence me?--not to any"         
## [11461] "compassion that could benefit you or myself.--Your example was before"       
## [11462] "me; but to what avail?--Was I more considerate of you and your comfort?"     
## [11463] "Did I imitate your forbearance, or lessen your restraints, by taking"        
## [11464] "any part in those offices of general complaisance or particular"             
## [11465] "gratitude which you had hitherto been left to discharge"                     
## [11466] "alone?--No;--not less when I knew you to be unhappy, than when I had"        
## [11467] "believed you at ease, did I turn away from every exertion of duty or"        
## [11468] "friendship; scarcely allowing sorrow to exist but with me, regretting"       
## [11469] "only THAT heart which had deserted and wronged me, and leaving you, for"     
## [11470] "whom I professed an unbounded affection, to be miserable for my sake.\""     
## [11471] ""                                                                            
## [11472] "Here ceased the rapid flow of her self-reproving spirit; and Elinor,"        
## [11473] "impatient to soothe, though too honest to flatter, gave her instantly"       
## [11474] "that praise and support which her frankness and her contrition so well"      
## [11475] "deserved.  Marianne pressed her hand and replied,"                           
## [11476] ""                                                                            
## [11477] "\"You are very good.--The future must be my proof.  I have laid down my"     
## [11478] "plan, and if I am capable of adhering to it--my feelings shall be"           
## [11479] "governed and my temper improved.  They shall no longer worry others,"        
## [11480] "nor torture myself.  I shall now live solely for my family.  You, my"        
## [11481] "mother, and Margaret, must henceforth be all the world to me; you will"      
## [11482] "share my affections entirely between you.  From you, from my home, I"        
## [11483] "shall never again have the smallest incitement to move; and if I do mix"     
## [11484] "in other society, it will be only to shew that my spirit is humbled, my"     
## [11485] "heart amended, and that I can practise the civilities, the lesser"           
## [11486] "duties of life, with gentleness and forbearance.  As for Willoughby--to"     
## [11487] "say that I shall soon or that I shall ever forget him, would be idle."       
## [11488] "His remembrance can be overcome by no change of circumstances or"            
## [11489] "opinions.  But it shall be regulated, it shall be checked by religion,"      
## [11490] "by reason, by constant employment.\""                                        
## [11491] ""                                                                            
## [11492] "She paused--and added in a low voice, \"If I could but know HIS heart,"      
## [11493] "everything would become easy.\""                                             
## [11494] ""                                                                            
## [11495] "Elinor, who had now been for some time reflecting on the propriety or"       
## [11496] "impropriety of speedily hazarding her narration, without feeling at all"     
## [11497] "nearer decision than at first, heard this; and perceiving that as"           
## [11498] "reflection did nothing, resolution must do all, soon found herself"          
## [11499] "leading to the fact."                                                        
## [11500] ""                                                                            
## [11501] "She managed the recital, as she hoped, with address; prepared her"           
## [11502] "anxious listener with caution; related simply and honestly the chief"        
## [11503] "points on which Willoughby grounded his apology; did justice to his"         
## [11504] "repentance, and softened only his protestations of present regard."          
## [11505] "Marianne said not a word.--She trembled, her eyes were fixed on the"         
## [11506] "ground, and her lips became whiter than even sickness had left them.  A"     
## [11507] "thousand inquiries sprung up from her heart, but she dared not urge"         
## [11508] "one.  She caught every syllable with panting eagerness; her hand,"           
## [11509] "unknowingly to herself, closely pressed her sister's, and tears covered"     
## [11510] "her cheeks."                                                                 
## [11511] ""                                                                            
## [11512] "Elinor, dreading her being tired, led her towards home; and till they"       
## [11513] "reached the door of the cottage, easily conjecturing what her curiosity"     
## [11514] "must be though no question was suffered to speak it, talked of nothing"      
## [11515] "but Willoughby, and their conversation together; and was carefully"          
## [11516] "minute in every particular of speech and look, where minuteness could"       
## [11517] "be safely indulged.  As soon as they entered the house, Marianne with a"     
## [11518] "kiss of gratitude and these two words just articulate through her"           
## [11519] "tears, \"Tell mama,\" withdrew from her sister and walked slowly up"         
## [11520] "stairs.  Elinor would not attempt to disturb a solitude so reasonable"       
## [11521] "as what she now sought; and with a mind anxiously pre-arranging its"         
## [11522] "result, and a resolution of reviving the subject again, should Marianne"     
## [11523] "fail to do it, she turned into the parlour to fulfill her parting"           
## [11524] "injunction."                                                                 
## [11525] ""                                                                            
## [11526] ""                                                                            
## [11527] ""                                                                            
## [11528] "CHAPTER 47"                                                                  
## [11529] ""                                                                            
## [11530] ""                                                                            
## [11531] "Mrs. Dashwood did not hear unmoved the vindication of her former"            
## [11532] "favourite.  She rejoiced in his being cleared from some part of his"         
## [11533] "imputed guilt;--she was sorry for him;--she wished him happy.  But the"      
## [11534] "feelings of the past could not be recalled.--Nothing could restore him"      
## [11535] "with a faith unbroken--a character unblemished, to Marianne.  Nothing"       
## [11536] "could do away the knowledge of what the latter had suffered through his"     
## [11537] "means, nor remove the guilt of his conduct towards Eliza.  Nothing"          
## [11538] "could replace him, therefore, in her former esteem, nor injure the"          
## [11539] "interests of Colonel Brandon."                                               
## [11540] ""                                                                            
## [11541] "Had Mrs. Dashwood, like her daughter, heard Willoughby's story from"         
## [11542] "himself--had she witnessed his distress, and been under the influence"       
## [11543] "of his countenance and his manner, it is probable that her compassion"       
## [11544] "would have been greater.  But it was neither in Elinor's power, nor in"      
## [11545] "her wish, to rouse such feelings in another, by her retailed"                
## [11546] "explanation, as had at first been called forth in herself.  Reflection"      
## [11547] "had given calmness to her judgment, and sobered her own opinion of"          
## [11548] "Willoughby's deserts;--she wished, therefore, to declare only the"           
## [11549] "simple truth, and lay open such facts as were really due to his"             
## [11550] "character, without any embellishment of tenderness to lead the fancy"        
## [11551] "astray."                                                                     
## [11552] ""                                                                            
## [11553] "In the evening, when they were all three together, Marianne began"           
## [11554] "voluntarily to speak of him again;--but that it was not without an"          
## [11555] "effort, the restless, unquiet thoughtfulness in which she had been for"      
## [11556] "some time previously sitting--her rising colour, as she spoke,--and her"     
## [11557] "unsteady voice, plainly shewed."                                             
## [11558] ""                                                                            
## [11559] "\"I wish to assure you both,\" said she, \"that I see every thing--as you"   
## [11560] "can desire me to do.\""                                                      
## [11561] ""                                                                            
## [11562] "Mrs. Dashwood would have interrupted her instantly with soothing"            
## [11563] "tenderness, had not Elinor, who really wished to hear her sister's"          
## [11564] "unbiased opinion, by an eager sign, engaged her silence.  Marianne"          
## [11565] "slowly continued--"                                                          
## [11566] ""                                                                            
## [11567] "\"It is a great relief to me--what Elinor told me this morning--I have"      
## [11568] "now heard exactly what I wished to hear.\"--For some moments her voice"      
## [11569] "was lost; but recovering herself, she added, and with greater calmness"      
## [11570] "than before--\"I am now perfectly satisfied, I wish for no change.  I"       
## [11571] "never could have been happy with him, after knowing, as sooner or later"     
## [11572] "I must have known, all this.--I should have had no confidence, no"           
## [11573] "esteem.  Nothing could have done it away to my feelings.\""                  
## [11574] ""                                                                            
## [11575] "\"I know it--I know it,\" cried her mother.  \"Happy with a man of"          
## [11576] "libertine practices!--With one who so injured the peace of the dearest"      
## [11577] "of our friends, and the best of men!--No--my Marianne has not a heart"       
## [11578] "to be made happy with such a man!--Her conscience, her sensitive"            
## [11579] "conscience, would have felt all that the conscience of her husband"          
## [11580] "ought to have felt.\""                                                       
## [11581] ""                                                                            
## [11582] "Marianne sighed, and repeated, \"I wish for no change.\""                    
## [11583] ""                                                                            
## [11584] "\"You consider the matter,\" said Elinor, \"exactly as a good mind and a"    
## [11585] "sound understanding must consider it; and I dare say you perceive, as"       
## [11586] "well as myself, not only in this, but in many other circumstances,"          
## [11587] "reason enough to be convinced that your marriage must have involved you"     
## [11588] "in many certain troubles and disappointments, in which you would have"       
## [11589] "been poorly supported by an affection, on his side, much less certain."      
## [11590] "Had you married, you must have been always poor.  His expensiveness is"      
## [11591] "acknowledged even by himself, and his whole conduct declares that"           
## [11592] "self-denial is a word hardly understood by him.  His demands and your"       
## [11593] "inexperience together, on a small, very small income, must have brought"     
## [11594] "on distresses which would not be the LESS grievous to you, from having"      
## [11595] "been entirely unknown and unthought of before.  YOUR sense of honour"        
## [11596] "and honesty would have led you, I know, when aware of your situation,"       
## [11597] "to attempt all the economy that would appear to you possible: and,"          
## [11598] "perhaps, as long as your frugality retrenched only on your own comfort,"     
## [11599] "you might have been suffered to practice it, but beyond that--and how"       
## [11600] "little could the utmost of your single management do to stop the ruin"       
## [11601] "which had begun before your marriage?-- Beyond THAT, had you"                
## [11602] "endeavoured, however reasonably, to abridge HIS enjoyments, is it not"       
## [11603] "to be feared, that instead of prevailing on feelings so selfish to"          
## [11604] "consent to it, you would have lessened your own influence on his heart,"     
## [11605] "and made him regret the connection which had involved him in such"           
## [11606] "difficulties?\""                                                             
## [11607] ""                                                                            
## [11608] "Marianne's lips quivered, and she repeated the word \"Selfish?\" in a"       
## [11609] "tone that implied--\"do you really think him selfish?\""                     
## [11610] ""                                                                            
## [11611] "\"The whole of his behaviour,\" replied Elinor, \"from the beginning to"     
## [11612] "the end of the affair, has been grounded on selfishness.  It was"            
## [11613] "selfishness which first made him sport with your affections; which"          
## [11614] "afterwards, when his own were engaged, made him delay the confession of"     
## [11615] "it, and which finally carried him from Barton.  His own enjoyment, or"       
## [11616] "his own ease, was, in every particular, his ruling principle.\""             
## [11617] ""                                                                            
## [11618] "\"It is very true.  MY happiness never was his object.\""                    
## [11619] ""                                                                            
## [11620] "\"At present,\" continued Elinor, \"he regrets what he has done.  And why"   
## [11621] "does he regret it?--Because he finds it has not answered towards"            
## [11622] "himself.  It has not made him happy.  His circumstances are now"             
## [11623] "unembarrassed--he suffers from no evil of that kind; and he thinks only"     
## [11624] "that he has married a woman of a less amiable temper than yourself."         
## [11625] "But does it follow that had he married you, he would have been"              
## [11626] "happy?--The inconveniences would have been different.  He would then"        
## [11627] "have suffered under the pecuniary distresses which, because they are"        
## [11628] "removed, he now reckons as nothing.  He would have had a wife of whose"      
## [11629] "temper he could make no complaint, but he would have been always"            
## [11630] "necessitous--always poor; and probably would soon have learned to rank"      
## [11631] "the innumerable comforts of a clear estate and good income as of far"        
## [11632] "more importance, even to domestic happiness, than the mere temper of a"      
## [11633] "wife.\""                                                                     
## [11634] ""                                                                            
## [11635] "\"I have not a doubt of it,\" said Marianne; \"and I have nothing to"        
## [11636] "regret--nothing but my own folly.\""                                         
## [11637] ""                                                                            
## [11638] "\"Rather say your mother's imprudence, my child,\" said Mrs. Dashwood;"      
## [11639] "\"SHE must be answerable.\""                                                 
## [11640] ""                                                                            
## [11641] "Marianne would not let her proceed;--and Elinor, satisfied that each"        
## [11642] "felt their own error, wished to avoid any survey of the past that might"     
## [11643] "weaken her sister's spirits; she, therefore, pursuing the first"             
## [11644] "subject, immediately continued,"                                             
## [11645] ""                                                                            
## [11646] "\"One observation may, I think, be fairly drawn from the whole of the"       
## [11647] "story--that all Willoughby's difficulties have arisen from the first"        
## [11648] "offence against virtue, in his behaviour to Eliza Williams.  That crime"     
## [11649] "has been the origin of every lesser one, and of all his present"             
## [11650] "discontents.\""                                                              
## [11651] ""                                                                            
## [11652] "Marianne assented most feelingly to the remark; and her mother was led"      
## [11653] "by it to an enumeration of Colonel Brandon's injuries and merits, warm"      
## [11654] "as friendship and design could unitedly dictate.  Her daughter did not"      
## [11655] "look, however, as if much of it were heard by her."                          
## [11656] ""                                                                            
## [11657] "Elinor, according to her expectation, saw on the two or three following"     
## [11658] "days, that Marianne did not continue to gain strength as she had done;"      
## [11659] "but while her resolution was unsubdued, and she still tried to appear"       
## [11660] "cheerful and easy, her sister could safely trust to the effect of time"      
## [11661] "upon her health."                                                            
## [11662] ""                                                                            
## [11663] "Margaret returned, and the family were again all restored to each"           
## [11664] "other, again quietly settled at the cottage; and if not pursuing their"      
## [11665] "usual studies with quite so much vigour as when they first came to"          
## [11666] "Barton, at least planning a vigorous prosecution of them in future."         
## [11667] ""                                                                            
## [11668] "Elinor grew impatient for some tidings of Edward.  She had heard"            
## [11669] "nothing of him since her leaving London, nothing new of his plans,"          
## [11670] "nothing certain even of his present abode.  Some letters had passed"         
## [11671] "between her and her brother, in consequence of Marianne's illness; and"      
## [11672] "in the first of John's, there had been this sentence:-- \"We know"           
## [11673] "nothing of our unfortunate Edward, and can make no enquiries on so"          
## [11674] "prohibited a subject, but conclude him to be still at Oxford;\" which"       
## [11675] "was all the intelligence of Edward afforded her by the correspondence,"      
## [11676] "for his name was not even mentioned in any of the succeeding letters."       
## [11677] "She was not doomed, however, to be long in ignorance of his measures."       
## [11678] ""                                                                            
## [11679] "Their man-servant had been sent one morning to Exeter on business; and"      
## [11680] "when, as he waited at table, he had satisfied the inquiries of his"          
## [11681] "mistress as to the event of his errand, this was his voluntary"              
## [11682] "communication--"                                                             
## [11683] ""                                                                            
## [11684] "\"I suppose you know, ma'am, that Mr. Ferrars is married.\""                 
## [11685] ""                                                                            
## [11686] "Marianne gave a violent start, fixed her eyes upon Elinor, saw her"          
## [11687] "turning pale, and fell back in her chair in hysterics.  Mrs. Dashwood,"      
## [11688] "whose eyes, as she answered the servant's inquiry, had intuitively"          
## [11689] "taken the same direction, was shocked to perceive by Elinor's"               
## [11690] "countenance how much she really suffered, and a moment afterwards,"          
## [11691] "alike distressed by Marianne's situation, knew not on which child to"        
## [11692] "bestow her principal attention."                                             
## [11693] ""                                                                            
## [11694] "The servant, who saw only that Miss Marianne was taken ill, had sense"       
## [11695] "enough to call one of the maids, who, with Mrs. Dashwood's assistance,"      
## [11696] "supported her into the other room.  By that time, Marianne was rather"       
## [11697] "better, and her mother leaving her to the care of Margaret and the"          
## [11698] "maid, returned to Elinor, who, though still much disordered, had so far"     
## [11699] "recovered the use of her reason and voice as to be just beginning an"        
## [11700] "inquiry of Thomas, as to the source of his intelligence.  Mrs. Dashwood"     
## [11701] "immediately took all that trouble on herself; and Elinor had the"            
## [11702] "benefit of the information without the exertion of seeking it."              
## [11703] ""                                                                            
## [11704] "\"Who told you that Mr. Ferrars was married, Thomas?\""                      
## [11705] ""                                                                            
## [11706] "\"I see Mr. Ferrars myself, ma'am, this morning in Exeter, and his lady"     
## [11707] "too, Miss Steele as was.  They was stopping in a chaise at the door of"      
## [11708] "the New London Inn, as I went there with a message from Sally at the"        
## [11709] "Park to her brother, who is one of the post-boys. I happened to look up"     
## [11710] "as I went by the chaise, and so I see directly it was the youngest Miss"     
## [11711] "Steele; so I took off my hat, and she knew me and called to me, and"         
## [11712] "inquired after you, ma'am, and the young ladies, especially Miss"            
## [11713] "Marianne, and bid me I should give her compliments and Mr. Ferrars's,"       
## [11714] "their best compliments and service, and how sorry they was they had not"     
## [11715] "time to come on and see you, but they was in a great hurry to go"            
## [11716] "forwards, for they was going further down for a little while, but"           
## [11717] "howsever, when they come back, they'd make sure to come and see you.\""      
## [11718] ""                                                                            
## [11719] "\"But did she tell you she was married, Thomas?\""                           
## [11720] ""                                                                            
## [11721] "\"Yes, ma'am. She smiled, and said how she had changed her name since"       
## [11722] "she was in these parts.  She was always a very affable and free-spoken"      
## [11723] "young lady, and very civil behaved.  So, I made free to wish her joy.\""     
## [11724] ""                                                                            
## [11725] "\"Was Mr. Ferrars in the carriage with her?\""                               
## [11726] ""                                                                            
## [11727] "\"Yes, ma'am, I just see him leaning back in it, but he did not look"        
## [11728] "up;--he never was a gentleman much for talking.\""                           
## [11729] ""                                                                            
## [11730] "Elinor's heart could easily account for his not putting himself"             
## [11731] "forward; and Mrs. Dashwood probably found the same explanation."             
## [11732] ""                                                                            
## [11733] "\"Was there no one else in the carriage?\""                                  
## [11734] ""                                                                            
## [11735] "\"No, ma'am, only they two.\""                                               
## [11736] ""                                                                            
## [11737] "\"Do you know where they came from?\""                                       
## [11738] ""                                                                            
## [11739] "\"They come straight from town, as Miss Lucy--Mrs. Ferrars told me.\""       
## [11740] ""                                                                            
## [11741] "\"And are they going farther westward?\""                                    
## [11742] ""                                                                            
## [11743] "\"Yes, ma'am--but not to bide long.  They will soon be back again, and"      
## [11744] "then they'd be sure and call here.\""                                        
## [11745] ""                                                                            
## [11746] "Mrs. Dashwood now looked at her daughter; but Elinor knew better than"       
## [11747] "to expect them.  She recognised the whole of Lucy in the message, and"       
## [11748] "was very confident that Edward would never come near them.  She"             
## [11749] "observed in a low voice, to her mother, that they were probably going"       
## [11750] "down to Mr. Pratt's, near Plymouth."                                         
## [11751] ""                                                                            
## [11752] "Thomas's intelligence seemed over.  Elinor looked as if she wished to"       
## [11753] "hear more."                                                                  
## [11754] ""                                                                            
## [11755] "\"Did you see them off, before you came away?\""                             
## [11756] ""                                                                            
## [11757] "\"No, ma'am--the horses were just coming out, but I could not bide any"      
## [11758] "longer; I was afraid of being late.\""                                       
## [11759] ""                                                                            
## [11760] "\"Did Mrs. Ferrars look well?\""                                             
## [11761] ""                                                                            
## [11762] "\"Yes, ma'am, she said how she was very well; and to my mind she was"        
## [11763] "always a very handsome young lady--and she seemed vastly contented.\""       
## [11764] ""                                                                            
## [11765] "Mrs. Dashwood could think of no other question, and Thomas and the"          
## [11766] "tablecloth, now alike needless, were soon afterwards dismissed."             
## [11767] "Marianne had already sent to say, that she should eat nothing more."         
## [11768] "Mrs. Dashwood's and Elinor's appetites were equally lost, and Margaret"      
## [11769] "might think herself very well off, that with so much uneasiness as both"     
## [11770] "her sisters had lately experienced, so much reason as they had often"        
## [11771] "had to be careless of their meals, she had never been obliged to go"         
## [11772] "without her dinner before."                                                  
## [11773] ""                                                                            
## [11774] "When the dessert and the wine were arranged, and Mrs. Dashwood and"          
## [11775] "Elinor were left by themselves, they remained long together in a"            
## [11776] "similarity of thoughtfulness and silence.  Mrs. Dashwood feared to"          
## [11777] "hazard any remark, and ventured not to offer consolation.  She now"          
## [11778] "found that she had erred in relying on Elinor's representation of"           
## [11779] "herself; and justly concluded that every thing had been expressly"           
## [11780] "softened at the time, to spare her from an increase of unhappiness,"         
## [11781] "suffering as she then had suffered for Marianne.  She found that she"        
## [11782] "had been misled by the careful, the considerate attention of her"            
## [11783] "daughter, to think the attachment, which once she had so well"               
## [11784] "understood, much slighter in reality, than she had been wont to"             
## [11785] "believe, or than it was now proved to be.  She feared that under this"       
## [11786] "persuasion she had been unjust, inattentive, nay, almost unkind, to her"     
## [11787] "Elinor;--that Marianne's affliction, because more acknowledged, more"        
## [11788] "immediately before her, had too much engrossed her tenderness, and led"      
## [11789] "her away to forget that in Elinor she might have a daughter suffering"       
## [11790] "almost as much, certainly with less self-provocation, and greater"           
## [11791] "fortitude."                                                                  
## [11792] ""                                                                            
## [11793] ""                                                                            
## [11794] ""                                                                            
## [11795] "CHAPTER 48"                                                                  
## [11796] ""                                                                            
## [11797] ""                                                                            
## [11798] "Elinor now found the difference between the expectation of an"               
## [11799] "unpleasant event, however certain the mind may be told to consider it,"      
## [11800] "and certainty itself.  She now found, that in spite of herself, she had"     
## [11801] "always admitted a hope, while Edward remained single, that something"        
## [11802] "would occur to prevent his marrying Lucy; that some resolution of his"       
## [11803] "own, some mediation of friends, or some more eligible opportunity of"        
## [11804] "establishment for the lady, would arise to assist the happiness of all."     
## [11805] "But he was now married; and she condemned her heart for the lurking"         
## [11806] "flattery, which so much heightened the pain of the intelligence."            
## [11807] ""                                                                            
## [11808] "That he should be married soon, before (as she imagined) he could be in"     
## [11809] "orders, and consequently before he could be in possession of the"            
## [11810] "living, surprised her a little at first.  But she soon saw how likely"       
## [11811] "it was that Lucy, in her self-provident care, in her haste to secure"        
## [11812] "him, should overlook every thing but the risk of delay.  They were"          
## [11813] "married, married in town, and now hastening down to her uncle's.  What"      
## [11814] "had Edward felt on being within four miles from Barton, on seeing her"       
## [11815] "mother's servant, on hearing Lucy's message!"                                
## [11816] ""                                                                            
## [11817] "They would soon, she supposed, be settled at Delaford.--Delaford,--that"     
## [11818] "place in which so much conspired to give her an interest; which she"         
## [11819] "wished to be acquainted with, and yet desired to avoid.  She saw them"       
## [11820] "in an instant in their parsonage-house; saw in Lucy, the active,"            
## [11821] "contriving manager, uniting at once a desire of smart appearance with"       
## [11822] "the utmost frugality, and ashamed to be suspected of half her"               
## [11823] "economical practices;--pursuing her own interest in every thought,"          
## [11824] "courting the favour of Colonel Brandon, of Mrs. Jennings, and of every"      
## [11825] "wealthy friend.  In Edward--she knew not what she saw, nor what she"         
## [11826] "wished to see;--happy or unhappy,--nothing pleased her; she turned away"     
## [11827] "her head from every sketch of him."                                          
## [11828] ""                                                                            
## [11829] "Elinor flattered herself that some one of their connections in London"       
## [11830] "would write to them to announce the event, and give farther"                 
## [11831] "particulars,--but day after day passed off, and brought no letter, no"       
## [11832] "tidings.  Though uncertain that any one were to blame, she found fault"      
## [11833] "with every absent friend.  They were all thoughtless or indolent."           
## [11834] ""                                                                            
## [11835] "\"When do you write to Colonel Brandon, ma'am?\" was an inquiry which"       
## [11836] "sprung from the impatience of her mind to have something going on."          
## [11837] ""                                                                            
## [11838] "\"I wrote to him, my love, last week, and rather expect to see, than to"     
## [11839] "hear from him again.  I earnestly pressed his coming to us, and should"      
## [11840] "not be surprised to see him walk in today or tomorrow, or any day.\""        
## [11841] ""                                                                            
## [11842] "This was gaining something, something to look forward to.  Colonel"          
## [11843] "Brandon must have some information to give."                                 
## [11844] ""                                                                            
## [11845] "Scarcely had she so determined it, when the figure of a man on"              
## [11846] "horseback drew her eyes to the window.  He stopt at their gate.  It was"     
## [11847] "a gentleman, it was Colonel Brandon himself.  Now she could hear more;"      
## [11848] "and she trembled in expectation of it.  But--it was NOT Colonel"             
## [11849] "Brandon--neither his air--nor his height.  Were it possible, she must"       
## [11850] "say it must be Edward.  She looked again.  He had just dismounted;--she"     
## [11851] "could not be mistaken,--it WAS Edward.  She moved away and sat down."        
## [11852] "\"He comes from Mr. Pratt's purposely to see us.  I WILL be calm; I WILL"    
## [11853] "be mistress of myself.\""                                                    
## [11854] ""                                                                            
## [11855] "In a moment she perceived that the others were likewise aware of the"        
## [11856] "mistake.  She saw her mother and Marianne change colour; saw them look"      
## [11857] "at herself, and whisper a few sentences to each other.  She would have"      
## [11858] "given the world to be able to speak--and to make them understand that"       
## [11859] "she hoped no coolness, no slight, would appear in their behaviour to"        
## [11860] "him;--but she had no utterance, and was obliged to leave all to their"       
## [11861] "own discretion."                                                             
## [11862] ""                                                                            
## [11863] "Not a syllable passed aloud.  They all waited in silence for the"            
## [11864] "appearance of their visitor.  His footsteps were heard along the gravel"     
## [11865] "path; in a moment he was in the passage, and in another he was before"       
## [11866] "them."                                                                       
## [11867] ""                                                                            
## [11868] "His countenance, as he entered the room, was not too happy, even for"        
## [11869] "Elinor.  His complexion was white with agitation, and he looked as if"       
## [11870] "fearful of his reception, and conscious that he merited no kind one."        
## [11871] "Mrs. Dashwood, however, conforming, as she trusted, to the wishes of"        
## [11872] "that daughter, by whom she then meant in the warmth of her heart to be"      
## [11873] "guided in every thing, met with a look of forced complacency, gave him"      
## [11874] "her hand, and wished him joy."                                               
## [11875] ""                                                                            
## [11876] "He coloured, and stammered out an unintelligible reply.  Elinor's lips"      
## [11877] "had moved with her mother's, and, when the moment of action was over,"       
## [11878] "she wished that she had shaken hands with him too.  But it was then too"     
## [11879] "late, and with a countenance meaning to be open, she sat down again and"     
## [11880] "talked of the weather."                                                      
## [11881] ""                                                                            
## [11882] "Marianne had retreated as much as possible out of sight, to conceal her"     
## [11883] "distress; and Margaret, understanding some part, but not the whole of"       
## [11884] "the case, thought it incumbent on her to be dignified, and therefore"        
## [11885] "took a seat as far from him as she could, and maintained a strict"           
## [11886] "silence."                                                                    
## [11887] ""                                                                            
## [11888] "When Elinor had ceased to rejoice in the dryness of the season, a very"      
## [11889] "awful pause took place.  It was put an end to by Mrs. Dashwood, who"         
## [11890] "felt obliged to hope that he had left Mrs. Ferrars very well.  In a"         
## [11891] "hurried manner, he replied in the affirmative."                              
## [11892] ""                                                                            
## [11893] "Another pause."                                                              
## [11894] ""                                                                            
## [11895] "Elinor resolving to exert herself, though fearing the sound of her own"      
## [11896] "voice, now said,"                                                            
## [11897] ""                                                                            
## [11898] "\"Is Mrs. Ferrars at Longstaple?\""                                          
## [11899] ""                                                                            
## [11900] "\"At Longstaple!\" he replied, with an air of surprise.-- \"No, my mother"   
## [11901] "is in town.\""                                                               
## [11902] ""                                                                            
## [11903] "\"I meant,\" said Elinor, taking up some work from the table, \"to inquire"  
## [11904] "for Mrs. EDWARD Ferrars.\""                                                  
## [11905] ""                                                                            
## [11906] "She dared not look up;--but her mother and Marianne both turned their"       
## [11907] "eyes on him.  He coloured, seemed perplexed, looked doubtingly, and,"        
## [11908] "after some hesitation, said,--"                                              
## [11909] ""                                                                            
## [11910] "\"Perhaps you mean--my brother--you mean Mrs.--Mrs. ROBERT Ferrars.\""       
## [11911] ""                                                                            
## [11912] "\"Mrs. Robert Ferrars!\"--was repeated by Marianne and her mother in an"     
## [11913] "accent of the utmost amazement;--and though Elinor could not speak,"         
## [11914] "even HER eyes were fixed on him with the same impatient wonder.  He"         
## [11915] "rose from his seat, and walked to the window, apparently from not"           
## [11916] "knowing what to do; took up a pair of scissors that lay there, and"          
## [11917] "while spoiling both them and their sheath by cutting the latter to"          
## [11918] "pieces as he spoke, said, in a hurried voice,"                               
## [11919] ""                                                                            
## [11920] "\"Perhaps you do not know--you may not have heard that my brother is"        
## [11921] "lately married to--to the youngest--to Miss Lucy Steele.\""                  
## [11922] ""                                                                            
## [11923] "His words were echoed with unspeakable astonishment by all but Elinor,"      
## [11924] "who sat with her head leaning over her work, in a state of such"             
## [11925] "agitation as made her hardly know where she was."                            
## [11926] ""                                                                            
## [11927] "\"Yes,\" said he, \"they were married last week, and are now at Dawlish.\""  
## [11928] ""                                                                            
## [11929] "Elinor could sit it no longer.  She almost ran out of the room, and as"      
## [11930] "soon as the door was closed, burst into tears of joy, which at first"        
## [11931] "she thought would never cease.  Edward, who had till then looked any"        
## [11932] "where, rather than at her, saw her hurry away, and perhaps saw--or even"     
## [11933] "heard, her emotion; for immediately afterwards he fell into a reverie,"      
## [11934] "which no remarks, no inquiries, no affectionate address of Mrs."             
## [11935] "Dashwood could penetrate, and at last, without saying a word, quitted"       
## [11936] "the room, and walked out towards the village--leaving the others in the"     
## [11937] "greatest astonishment and perplexity on a change in his situation, so"       
## [11938] "wonderful and so sudden;--a perplexity which they had no means of"           
## [11939] "lessening but by their own conjectures."                                     
## [11940] ""                                                                            
## [11941] ""                                                                            
## [11942] ""                                                                            
## [11943] "CHAPTER 49"                                                                  
## [11944] ""                                                                            
## [11945] ""                                                                            
## [11946] "Unaccountable, however, as the circumstances of his release might"           
## [11947] "appear to the whole family, it was certain that Edward was free; and to"     
## [11948] "what purpose that freedom would be employed was easily pre-determined"       
## [11949] "by all;--for after experiencing the blessings of ONE imprudent"              
## [11950] "engagement, contracted without his mother's consent, as he had already"      
## [11951] "done for more than four years, nothing less could be expected of him in"     
## [11952] "the failure of THAT, than the immediate contraction of another."             
## [11953] ""                                                                            
## [11954] "His errand at Barton, in fact, was a simple one.  It was only to ask"        
## [11955] "Elinor to marry him;--and considering that he was not altogether"            
## [11956] "inexperienced in such a question, it might be strange that he should"        
## [11957] "feel so uncomfortable in the present case as he really did, so much in"      
## [11958] "need of encouragement and fresh air."                                        
## [11959] ""                                                                            
## [11960] "How soon he had walked himself into the proper resolution, however, how"     
## [11961] "soon an opportunity of exercising it occurred, in what manner he"            
## [11962] "expressed himself, and how he was received, need not be particularly"        
## [11963] "told.  This only need be said;--that when they all sat down to table at"     
## [11964] "four o'clock, about three hours after his arrival, he had secured his"       
## [11965] "lady, engaged her mother's consent, and was not only in the rapturous"       
## [11966] "profession of the lover, but, in the reality of reason and truth, one"       
## [11967] "of the happiest of men.  His situation indeed was more than commonly"        
## [11968] "joyful.  He had more than the ordinary triumph of accepted love to"          
## [11969] "swell his heart, and raise his spirits.  He was released without any"        
## [11970] "reproach to himself, from an entanglement which had long formed his"         
## [11971] "misery, from a woman whom he had long ceased to love;--and elevated at"      
## [11972] "once to that security with another, which he must have thought of"           
## [11973] "almost with despair, as soon as he had learnt to consider it with"           
## [11974] "desire.  He was brought, not from doubt or suspense, but from misery to"     
## [11975] "happiness;--and the change was openly spoken in such a genuine,"             
## [11976] "flowing, grateful cheerfulness, as his friends had never witnessed in"       
## [11977] "him before."                                                                 
## [11978] ""                                                                            
## [11979] "His heart was now open to Elinor, all its weaknesses, all its errors"        
## [11980] "confessed, and his first boyish attachment to Lucy treated with all the"     
## [11981] "philosophic dignity of twenty-four."                                         
## [11982] ""                                                                            
## [11983] "\"It was a foolish, idle inclination on my side,\" said he, \"the"           
## [11984] "consequence of ignorance of the world--and want of employment.  Had my"      
## [11985] "mother given me some active profession when I was removed at eighteen"       
## [11986] "from the care of Mr. Pratt, I think--nay, I am sure, it would never"         
## [11987] "have happened; for though I left Longstaple with what I thought, at the"     
## [11988] "time, a most unconquerable preference for his niece, yet had I then had"     
## [11989] "any pursuit, any object to engage my time and keep me at a distance"         
## [11990] "from her for a few months, I should very soon have outgrown the fancied"     
## [11991] "attachment, especially by mixing more with the world, as in such case I"     
## [11992] "must have done.  But instead of having any thing to do, instead of"          
## [11993] "having any profession chosen for me, or being allowed to chuse any"          
## [11994] "myself, I returned home to be completely idle; and for the first"            
## [11995] "twelvemonth afterwards I had not even the nominal employment, which"         
## [11996] "belonging to the university would have given me; for I was not entered"      
## [11997] "at Oxford till I was nineteen.  I had therefore nothing in the world to"     
## [11998] "do, but to fancy myself in love; and as my mother did not make my home"      
## [11999] "in every respect comfortable, as I had no friend, no companion in my"        
## [12000] "brother, and disliked new acquaintance, it was not unnatural for me to"      
## [12001] "be very often at Longstaple, where I always felt myself at home, and"        
## [12002] "was always sure of a welcome; and accordingly I spent the greatest part"     
## [12003] "of my time there from eighteen to nineteen: Lucy appeared everything"        
## [12004] "that was amiable and obliging.  She was pretty too--at least I thought"      
## [12005] "so THEN; and I had seen so little of other women, that I could make no"      
## [12006] "comparisons, and see no defects.  Considering everything, therefore, I"      
## [12007] "hope, foolish as our engagement was, foolish as it has since in every"       
## [12008] "way been proved, it was not at the time an unnatural or an inexcusable"      
## [12009] "piece of folly.\""                                                           
## [12010] ""                                                                            
## [12011] "The change which a few hours had wrought in the minds and the happiness"     
## [12012] "of the Dashwoods, was such--so great--as promised them all, the"             
## [12013] "satisfaction of a sleepless night.  Mrs. Dashwood, too happy to be"          
## [12014] "comfortable, knew not how to love Edward, nor praise Elinor enough, how"     
## [12015] "to be enough thankful for his release without wounding his delicacy,"        
## [12016] "nor how at once to give them leisure for unrestrained conversation"          
## [12017] "together, and yet enjoy, as she wished, the sight and society of both."      
## [12018] ""                                                                            
## [12019] "Marianne could speak HER happiness only by tears.  Comparisons would"        
## [12020] "occur--regrets would arise;--and her joy, though sincere as her love"        
## [12021] "for her sister, was of a kind to give her neither spirits nor language."     
## [12022] ""                                                                            
## [12023] "But Elinor--how are HER feelings to be described?--From the moment of"       
## [12024] "learning that Lucy was married to another, that Edward was free, to the"     
## [12025] "moment of his justifying the hopes which had so instantly followed, she"     
## [12026] "was every thing by turns but tranquil.  But when the second moment had"      
## [12027] "passed, when she found every doubt, every solicitude removed, compared"      
## [12028] "her situation with what so lately it had been,--saw him honourably"          
## [12029] "released from his former engagement, saw him instantly profiting by the"     
## [12030] "release, to address herself and declare an affection as tender, as"          
## [12031] "constant as she had ever supposed it to be,--she was oppressed, she was"     
## [12032] "overcome by her own felicity;--and happily disposed as is the human"         
## [12033] "mind to be easily familiarized with any change for the better, it"           
## [12034] "required several hours to give sedateness to her spirits, or any degree"     
## [12035] "of tranquillity to her heart."                                               
## [12036] ""                                                                            
## [12037] "Edward was now fixed at the cottage at least for a week;--for whatever"      
## [12038] "other claims might be made on him, it was impossible that less than a"       
## [12039] "week should be given up to the enjoyment of Elinor's company, or"            
## [12040] "suffice to say half that was to be said of the past, the present, and"       
## [12041] "the future;--for though a very few hours spent in the hard labor of"         
## [12042] "incessant talking will despatch more subjects than can really be in"         
## [12043] "common between any two rational creatures, yet with lovers it is"            
## [12044] "different.  Between THEM no subject is finished, no communication is"        
## [12045] "even made, till it has been made at least twenty times over."                
## [12046] ""                                                                            
## [12047] "Lucy's marriage, the unceasing and reasonable wonder among them all,"        
## [12048] "formed of course one of the earliest discussions of the lovers;--and"        
## [12049] "Elinor's particular knowledge of each party made it appear to her in"        
## [12050] "every view, as one of the most extraordinary and unaccountable"              
## [12051] "circumstances she had ever heard.  How they could be thrown together,"       
## [12052] "and by what attraction Robert could be drawn on to marry a girl, of"         
## [12053] "whose beauty she had herself heard him speak without any admiration,--a"     
## [12054] "girl too already engaged to his brother, and on whose account that"          
## [12055] "brother had been thrown off by his family--it was beyond her"                
## [12056] "comprehension to make out.  To her own heart it was a delightful"            
## [12057] "affair, to her imagination it was even a ridiculous one, but to her"         
## [12058] "reason, her judgment, it was completely a puzzle."                           
## [12059] ""                                                                            
## [12060] "Edward could only attempt an explanation by supposing, that, perhaps,"       
## [12061] "at first accidentally meeting, the vanity of the one had been so worked"     
## [12062] "on by the flattery of the other, as to lead by degrees to all the rest."     
## [12063] "Elinor remembered what Robert had told her in Harley Street, of his"         
## [12064] "opinion of what his own mediation in his brother's affairs might have"       
## [12065] "done, if applied to in time.  She repeated it to Edward."                    
## [12066] ""                                                                            
## [12067] "\"THAT was exactly like Robert,\"--was his immediate observation.--\"And"    
## [12068] "THAT,\" he presently added, \"might perhaps be in HIS head when the"         
## [12069] "acquaintance between them first began.  And Lucy perhaps at first might"     
## [12070] "think only of procuring his good offices in my favour.  Other designs"       
## [12071] "might afterward arise.\""                                                    
## [12072] ""                                                                            
## [12073] "How long it had been carrying on between them, however, he was equally"      
## [12074] "at a loss with herself to make out; for at Oxford, where he had"             
## [12075] "remained for choice ever since his quitting London, he had had no means"     
## [12076] "of hearing of her but from herself, and her letters to the very last"        
## [12077] "were neither less frequent, nor less affectionate than usual.  Not the"      
## [12078] "smallest suspicion, therefore, had ever occurred to prepare him for"         
## [12079] "what followed;--and when at last it burst on him in a letter from Lucy"      
## [12080] "herself, he had been for some time, he believed, half stupified between"     
## [12081] "the wonder, the horror, and the joy of such a deliverance.  He put the"      
## [12082] "letter into Elinor's hands."                                                 
## [12083] ""                                                                            
## [12084] "     \"DEAR SIR,"                                                            
## [12085] ""                                                                            
## [12086] "     \"Being very sure I have long lost your affections,"                    
## [12087] "     I have thought myself at liberty to bestow my own"                      
## [12088] "     on another, and have no doubt of being as happy with"                   
## [12089] "     him as I once used to think I might be with you;"                       
## [12090] "     but I scorn to accept a hand while the heart was"                       
## [12091] "     another's.  Sincerely wish you happy in your choice,"                   
## [12092] "     and it shall not be my fault if we are not always"                      
## [12093] "     good friends, as our near relationship now makes"                       
## [12094] "     proper.  I can safely say I owe you no ill-will,"                       
## [12095] "     and am sure you will be too generous to do us any"                      
## [12096] "     ill offices.  Your brother has gained my affections"                    
## [12097] "     entirely, and as we could not live without one"                         
## [12098] "     another, we are just returned from the altar, and"                      
## [12099] "     are now on our way to Dawlish for a few weeks, which"                   
## [12100] "     place your dear brother has great curiosity to see,"                    
## [12101] "     but thought I would first trouble you with these"                       
## [12102] "     few lines, and shall always remain,"                                    
## [12103] ""                                                                            
## [12104] "     \"Your sincere well-wisher, friend, and sister,"                        
## [12105] "                                        \"LUCY FERRARS."                     
## [12106] ""                                                                            
## [12107] "     \"I have burnt all your letters, and will return"                       
## [12108] "     your picture the first opportunity.  Please to destroy"                 
## [12109] "     my scrawls--but the ring with my hair you are very"                     
## [12110] "     welcome to keep.\""                                                     
## [12111] ""                                                                            
## [12112] "Elinor read and returned it without any comment."                            
## [12113] ""                                                                            
## [12114] "\"I will not ask your opinion of it as a composition,\" said"                
## [12115] "Edward.--\"For worlds would not I have had a letter of hers seen by YOU"     
## [12116] "in former days.--In a sister it is bad enough, but in a wife!--how I"        
## [12117] "have blushed over the pages of her writing!--and I believe I may say"        
## [12118] "that since the first half year of our foolish--business--this is the"        
## [12119] "only letter I ever received from her, of which the substance made me"        
## [12120] "any amends for the defect of the style.\""                                   
## [12121] ""                                                                            
## [12122] "\"However it may have come about,\" said Elinor, after a pause,--\"they"     
## [12123] "are certainly married.  And your mother has brought on herself a most"       
## [12124] "appropriate punishment.  The independence she settled on Robert,"            
## [12125] "through resentment against you, has put it in his power to make his own"     
## [12126] "choice; and she has actually been bribing one son with a thousand"           
## [12127] "a-year, to do the very deed which she disinherited the other for"            
## [12128] "intending to do.  She will hardly be less hurt, I suppose, by Robert's"      
## [12129] "marrying Lucy, than she would have been by your marrying her.\""             
## [12130] ""
